title: Sanidad financia Bimzelx de UCB en nuevas indicaciones para la artritis psoriásica y la espondiloartritis axial
summary: The Spanish Ministry of Health has approved funding for two new uses of Bimzelx (bimekizumab), created by the global biopharmaceutical company UCB, for treating psoriatic arthritis and the full range of active axial spondyloarthritis, including non-radiographic and radiographic forms, also known as ankylosing spondylitis. Bimzelx, a dual and selective blocker of interleukin 17A and interleukin 17F, is the first and only treatment to selectively inhibit both cytokines, crucial in the inflammation involved in both diseases. Its effectiveness has been proven in phase III clinical trials for each use, showing improvement in joint and skin symptoms in psoriatic arthritis patients and a consistent decrease in inflammation in axial spondyloarthritis patients. This funding decision supports a more personalized medicine approach, aiming to enhance the life quality of patients with these diseases.

title: Un máster en salud de la adolescencia 'pionero'
hco: SOC ESPAÑOLA DE MEDICINA DEL ADOLES
summary: Spain introduces a pioneering Master's program in comprehensive adolescent health, led by Dr. Félix Notario Herrero and Professor Nuria Garrido. This unique educational offering, supported by the University of Castilla-La Mancha (UCLM) and the Spanish Society of Adolescent Medicine (SEMA), aims to address the growing need for specialized professionals in adolescent health. Starting October 2, the program will cover both medical and social aspects of adolescent health, including legal and ethical considerations in the digital age. Designed for a wide range of professionals, from doctors to educators, the master's program offers 60 ECTS credits and encompasses 1,500 hours of training, delivered online to accommodate working professionals. This initiative seeks to improve early detection, treatment, and prevention of adolescent health issues while ensuring professional and patient safety through legal knowledge.

title: Impartirán en octubre un máster en salud del adolescente
hco: SOC ESPAÑOLA DE MEDICINA DEL ADOLES
summary: In October, the first edition of the Master's in Comprehensive Adolescent Health will be launched at the Albacete campus, under the direction of pediatric specialist Dr. Félix Notario and Dr. Nuria Garrido, a legal expert from UCLM. This pioneering national program, endorsed by UCLM and the Spanish Society of Adolescent Medicine (SEMA), aims to address the growing need for specialists trained in the comprehensive health needs of adolescents. The program is divided into two modules, which can be taken independently: an expert title in Adolescent Medicine from October to February, and an expert title in social health, ethics, and law of adolescents in the digital era from February to June. The master's program is designed for a wide range of professionals including doctors, nurses, public health professionals, social workers, educators, legal professionals, psychologists, and social care staff, offering them online training to understand relevant legislation to ensure the safety of both professionals and patients.

title: SEIMC y Gilead lanzan la primera edición de sus becas en enfermedades infecciosas | @diariofarma
summary: SEIMC and Gilead Sciences have launched the first edition of their research scholarships in infectious diseases, allowing ten Spanish researchers to undertake one to three-month training stays at leading European centers specializing in HIV, viral hepatitis, COVID-19, and invasive fungal infections. This initiative aims to support the continuity or initiation of research projects and foster the development of clinical practice skills and tools. It underscores SEIMC and Gilead's commitment to enhancing healthcare quality and promoting research in infectious diseases amid numerous challenges in the field. The scholarships are intended for SEIMC members, with applications to be sent to a specified email. Federico García and Marisa Álvarez, representing SEIMC and Gilead respectively, emphasized the importance of this initiative for professional development and research advancement in infectious diseases.

title: El Hospital Vithas Sevilla crea la Red de Unidades de Ensayos Clínicos para fomentar la investigación
summary: Vithas Sevilla Hospital has launched the Network of Clinical Trial Units to boost research and development of new pharmacological treatments. This network aims to be more effective and efficient in managing clinical trials, promoting collaboration among teams. The first unit, specialized in neuroscience and endocrinology, is located at Vithas Sevilla Hospital. The goal is to offer patients access to innovative medicines before they are marketed. So far, 55 clinical trials and 23 observational studies have been supported. There are plans to expand the network to other Vithas hospitals in Spain, covering areas such as oncology, cardiology, and pulmonology, in addition to the ones already mentioned. The Sevilla Clinical Trials Unit manages 25 studies, including early-phase trials for treatments against obesity and cardiovascular risk.

title: El doctor Pedro Serrano dirigirá los proyectos de investigación de la unidad de esclerosis múltiple del Hospital Vithas Sevilla
summary: Dr. Pedro Serrano has joined the Vithas Sevilla Hospital to lead the multiple sclerosis unit, being the only one of its kind within the private sector in Andalusia. Under his direction, there are plans to expand research in the field of neurological pathologies, including epilepsy and neurodegenerative diseases, in addition to strengthening clinical assistance. Serrano, with more than 25 years of experience and author of numerous scientific publications, also leads the Neuroimmunology and Neuroinflammation group at the Biomedical Research Institute of Malaga. The unit has worked on clinical trials and studies on multiple sclerosis, significantly contributing to the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of the disease. The Vithas Foundation, part of the Vithas group, supports research and training in the medical field, promoting projects that improve access to innovative treatments for patients.

title: Vithas abre sus hospitales de Alicante a pacientes británicos en lista de espera
summary: Vithas, a Spanish hospital group, has entered into an international collaboration agreement with Operations Abroad, a company with a network of eighty hospitals across forty countries worldwide. This partnership aims to cater to British patients on waiting lists, particularly for medical check-ups and surgical specialties, in Vithas hospitals located in Alicante. The agreement was signed by Victoria Verdú, Vithas' regional director in the Valencian Community, and Ekaterina Breslavtseva, responsible for the international department of Vithas hospitals in Alicante, alongside Ruth Taylor, CEO of Operations Abroad. Vithas' initiative is part of its strategy to focus on international patients, providing them with personalized health advisors and facilitating administrative procedures with national health systems and insurance companies. Operations Abroad specializes in managing UK patients seeking medical treatment abroad. Vithas, which reported revenues of 625 million euros in 2021, comprises 19 hospitals and 31 medical centers across thirteen provinces in Spain, showing a significant growth and expansion strategy in the national healthcare sector.

title: Salvan la vida a un adolescente senegalés que tenía un tumor facial de 20 centímetros
summary: A 15-year-old Senegalese teenager's life was saved by a joint effort from the Vithas Foundation, Hospital 9 de Octubre, the medical team led by Ignacio Solís, and the GUP Association, by removing a 20-centimeter facial tumor. The teenager had a large ameloblastoma affecting two-thirds of his jaw and reaching the base of his skull, which made it difficult for him to eat and drink. The surgery involved removing the tumor entirely and reconstructing the jaw with a fibula free flap. The patient, who had the tumor for about four years, was severely malnourished when he arrived in Spain. After a successful surgery and recovery, where his nutritional status greatly improved, allowing him to eat normally and gain weight, the teenager was able to go back to Senegal and lead a normal life again.

title: Los hospitales Vithas Xanit, Vithas Madrid y Vithas Valencia 9 de Octubre, entre los 20 mejores de España según Top Doctors
summary: The Vithas Xanit Internacional, Vithas Madrid Arturo Soria, and Vithas Valencia 9 de Octubre hospitals have been included among the top 20 hospitals in Spain by the Top Doctors platform, marking the first time this selection has been made. This recognition is based on the quality and experience of the medical staff, nominations from doctors and healthcare personnel, and verified patient reviews. The three centers stand out for their high quality standards, reflecting the Vithas group's commitment to patient care and processes to ensure it. The Vithas Xanit Internacional Hospital is notable for having obtained the Joint Commission International (JCI) accreditation three times, while the Vithas Madrid Arturo Soria University Hospital and the Vithas Valencia 9 de Octubre Hospital are also recognized for their excellence and commitment to continuous improvement and innovation.

title: El Instituto Oncológico Vithas incorpora a Javier Garde Noguera desde el centro de Castellón
summary: The Vithas Oncology Institute (IOV) has incorporated Javier Garde Noguera, coming from the Castellón center, as part of its expansion strategy and improvement in cancer care. The IOV, which is part of the 20 hospitals of the Vithas group, stands out for bringing together leaders of the specialties that treat cancer in Spain, all with extensive experience and an innovative approach to healthcare. These professionals, along with the latest technology in radiotherapy, diagnosis, and oncological surgery, position the IOV as a national reference in oncology. In addition, it offers complementary services such as genetic counseling, molecular diagnosis, cardio-oncology, support in nutrition, psycho-oncology, and exercise, ensuring comprehensive patient care. Collaboration with the Vithas Foundation promotes growth in oncological clinical trials, providing new opportunities for access to innovative treatments and drugs. This model of Vithas institutes, which began in 2022, is characterized by comprehensive medical care, the promotion of translational research, and teaching.

title: Vithas y la Fernando III acuerdan que la Facultad de Ciencias de la Salud esté en el hospital de Castilleja (Sevilla)
summary: Vithas and the future CEU Fernando III University have signed an agreement for the Vithas hospital in Castilleja de la Cuesta, Seville, to be the headquarters of the new Faculty of Health and Life Sciences. This commitment will allow degrees in Medicine, Nursing, Psychology, and Physiotherapy to be taught at the hospital, enabling students to receive both theoretical and practical classes at the center. This agreement is part of Vithas' vocation to promote university teaching among its professionals and contribute to the training of future healthcare professionals. The alliance with CEU seeks to improve the quality of hospital services and reaffirm the commitment to society. This project is part of a broader effort by Vithas, which already has three university hospitals in Madrid and seeks to expand this category to other centers in the group.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Canary Islands Health Research Institute Foundation (FIISC), under the Health Department of the Canary Islands Government, received a grant of 397,307 euros from the State Public Employment Service (SEPE) for hiring young researchers. This funding is part of the Investigo program, within the Next Generation EU recovery plan, aimed at enhancing biomedical research in the Canary Islands. It will allow for the hiring of twelve individuals under 30 years of age, for a twelve-month period to work on projects that improve scientific knowledge generation, healthcare quality, public health, and employability in the healthcare sector. Candidates must be unemployed and registered as job seekers with the Canary Islands Employment Service (SCE), which will preselect applicants. These researchers will work in the four university hospitals on the capital islands, contributing to research and innovation in various medical fields.

title: Servicio Canario de la Salud (SCS) destina 300 mil euros al desarrollo la investigación clínica
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Canary Health Service (SCS), via the Canarian Foundation for Health Research Institute of the Canary Islands (FIISC), has unveiled a 300,000 euros funding scheme for clinical research development. The aim is to back the recruitment of health professionals at public health centers for clinical-assistential tasks, freeing up others for research. This is in line with the Health Strategic Action of the Carlos III Health Institute. Grants vary from 30,000 euros for faculty to 20,000 euros for nurses and physiotherapists, targeting those in health research, clinical research, international projects, or leading Horizon Europe-funded projects. The goal is to boost talent incorporation and retention in the SCS, enhance the number of professionals blending research with clinical work, and improve knowledge transfer to patient care.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: Canarias has launched the first phase of the national epidemiological research project Cohorte IMPaCT, focusing on Precision Medicine. This project will involve 200,000 participants across Spain, monitored over 20 years, with Canarias selecting 12,000 individuals aged 16 to 79 from La Laguna, Telde, and La Palma. The initiative aims to explore the psychological, social, environmental, and biological determinants of health conditions and diseases in Spain. It is led by the Precision Medicine Infrastructure linked to Science and Technology (IMPaCT) created by the Carlos III Health Institute and coordinated by the Biomedical Research Networking Center (CIBER). The research involves all autonomous communities, the National Institute of Statistics (INE), 59 research groups, and 24 associated entities. Participants will undergo physical exams, health questionnaires, and biological sample collections at the beginning and every five years, with more frequent follow-ups via phone or apps. The study seeks to understand the causes of diseases, monitor health status with a focus on health inequalities, predict disease risk, and identify biomarkers for clinical precision medicine.

title: Canarias inicia la primera fase de una investigación epidemiológica nacional
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Canary Islands have started the first phase of a significant national epidemiological research project, called the IMPaCT Cohort, with the goal of studying the psychological, social, environmental, and biological determinants of the main health conditions and diseases in Spain. This study, driven by the Precision Medicine Infrastructure associated with Science and Technology (IMPaCT) and coordinated by the Biomedical Research Networking Center (CIBER), will involve 200,000 people aged between 16 and 79 from all over Spain, who will be followed for twenty years. In the Canary Islands, 12,000 people will participate. The project has the collaboration of all the autonomous communities, the National Statistics Institute (INE), 59 research groups, and 24 associated entities. The IMPaCT Cohort is expected to offer valuable insights into the causes of priority diseases in public health, monitor the health status of residents in Spain, predict disease risks, and identify useful biomarkers in clinical practice.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Insular-Materno Infantil University Hospital Complex, affiliated with the Health Department of the Canary Islands Government, has launched a training initiative called CHUIMI-Managing in Health. This program includes monthly lectures on clinical management to improve the skills of healthcare professionals, aiming for excellence in patient care. Supported by AMGEN and the Canarian Foundation for Health Research Institute (FIISC), it started with a lecture on the challenges and opportunities for female executives in change management. Future sessions will address topics such as team management, talent management, corporate identity, organization of healthcare institutions, artificial intelligence in healthcare, and innovation in health.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Canary Islands' Health Department received an award for a caregiver support project at the VII International and XIII National Congress of the Community Nursing Association (AEC). Named "Health Outcomes of Caregivers Following a Continued Group Educational Intervention Strategy," the project studied the impact of group workshops on caregivers' burden, mental health, life quality, and health literacy. Supported by the 'Salvador Tranche' grant from the Canary Islands Health Research Institute Foundation (FIISC) 2022 and the +AP Canarias Strategy, its goal was to evaluate the effects of educational group interventions on caregivers of chronically ill patients. The research included a non-random control group and an intervention group that attended fifteen workshops, both face-to-face and online, to assess the workshops' before-and-after effects and their acceptability. Early results show health literacy and life quality improvements in the intervention group, with a link between anxiety-depression presence and lower life quality and burden scores among caregivers.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Government of the Canary Islands, via the Canarian Health Service (SCS) and the Canarian Institute for Health Research Foundation (FIISC), has announced three funding calls for health research projects in 2023. These projects aim to address the health needs of the Canary Islands' population and improve the SCS's sustainability and solvency. With a total budget of 650,000 euros, a 40.6% increase from last year, the grants focus on three areas: Primary Care, Nursing and Health Care, and Hospital Care and Public Health. This initiative is part of the SCS's strategy to prioritize health research and innovation to enhance public health outcomes, ensure health services' effectiveness and cost-efficiency, and promote socio-economic development in the region, in line with the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda and the European Commission's Responsible Research and Innovation (RRI) philosophy.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Canary Islands Health Research Institute Foundation (FCIISC), under the Ministry of Health of the Government of the Canary Islands, will host the "Health Law and Research Conference" on February 24 and 25 at the Hotel Santa Catalina. This event in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria aims to discuss the legal regulations governing the research process and the main technical and scientific aspects that health researchers in the archipelago must follow. It will bring together health professionals from the research and legal fields, both nationally and regionally, to debate topics including legislation and bioethics in nursing research, data protection in the health sector, research objectives in health, and the penal treatment of clinical history confidentiality among other subjects of interest. The conference will feature lectures and debate tables with contributions from various professionals in the field.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The "Jornadas de Derecho e Investigación" conference, focusing on legal and research aspects within the health sector, took place in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, featuring discussions led by twenty-five experts in law and health research. Key participants included Ángel Víctor Torres, President of the Canary Islands, Blas Trujillo, Health Minister of the Canary Islands, Juan Luis Lorenzo, President of the Superior Court of Justice of the Canary Islands, and Esther Concepción Morales, substitute magistrate of the Social Chamber of the Superior Court of Justice of Madrid. The event, organized by the Health Research Institute Foundation of the Canary Islands and attached to the Canary Islands Health Ministry, highlighted the significance of Health Law, especially in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing the need for continuous knowledge updating for professionals to adapt to legal changes affecting health research. Topics discussed included legislation, bioethics in nursing research, data protection in healthcare, and the penal treatment of clinical record confidentiality.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN CANARIA INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA DECANARIAS
summary: The Government of the Canary Islands, under the direction of Migdalia Machín, announced the allocation of nearly 8.5 million euros for the predoctoral hiring of research personnel. This funding, an increase of over 2.5 million euros from the 2022 call, will benefit 85 researchers through 2024-2027, supported by the European Social Fund Plus. The initiative aims to enhance the Canary Islands' research environment and the consolidation of R&D+i groups. Beneficiaries include the University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, the University of La Laguna, the Canarian Foundation for Health Research, and the Spanish National Research Council, with 56% of the contracts awarded to women. This move underscores the government's commitment to promoting talent and investing in research as a fundamental pillar for the region's development.

title: Así será el futuro centro de investigación biomédica de Alicante
summary: The Alicante Health Department has tendered the works for the construction of the new biomedical research center, the Institute of Health and Biomedical Research of Alicante (Isabial), with an investment of 14.3 million euros and a completion period of 24 months. The building, which will be located at the General University Hospital Doctor Balmis, will have an area of 6,194 square meters and will be distributed over three floors. This project will allow the 44 research groups of Isabial, which currently total more than 600 researchers, to be brought together in a modern space equipped with the latest technology. The new infrastructure is expected to enhance excellence in research in Alicante, improving the working conditions of researchers and consolidating the Doctor Balmis Hospital and Isabial as benchmarks in biomedical science.

title: Así será el nuevo edificio de investigación biomédica del Hospital General de Alicante
summary: The Hospital General Universitario Doctor Balmis de Alicante is moving forward with the construction of a new biomedical research building, which will become the home for the Alicante Health and Biomedical Research Institute (Isabial). This initiative, starting with a budget of 14.3 million euros and expected to be completed within 24 months starting from the last quarter of 2024, is designed to improve the area's biomedical research capabilities. The facility will bring together over 600 researchers from 44 groups working in five existing research areas, who were previously dispersed in different parts of the hospital, into one single location. Covering 6,194 square meters on the grounds of the hospital's old garden, the building will have a contemporary three-story layout that includes administrative areas, a data processing center, educational spaces, and a laboratory section equipped with the latest technology. It will also include a Clinical Trials Unit and a Research Support Laboratory, with the goal of enhancing the province's biomedical research quality.

title: El Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria de Balears consigue la renovación de la acreditación como centro de excelencia investigadora
summary: The Health Research Institute of the Balearic Islands (IdISBa) has successfully renewed its accreditation as a health research institute by the Carlos III Health Institute (ISCIII), thus establishing itself as a center of research excellence in the National Health System. This recognition, previously obtained in January 2019, is extended for another five years, allowing IdISBa to continue its access to research programs, funding, and project development. The renewal underscores the progressive improvement and solid scientific performance of IdISBa, which has more than 800 researchers. The accreditation highlights the institute's ability to attract and retain research talent, as well as its contribution to primary care and the quality of its scientific production. IdISBa is the only institute of its kind accredited in the Balearic Islands, being part of a national network of 35 centers dedicated to health research.

title: A handful of walnuts everyday may boost attention among adolescents | Lifestyle Health | English Manorama
summary: A study by Spanish researchers published in eClinicalMedicine journal found that teenagers who eat walnuts daily or at least three times a week can significantly improve their cognitive abilities, including attention. This research involved 700 secondary school students aged 11 to 16 from Barcelona, emphasizing the importance of walnuts, which are rich in alpha-linolenic fatty acid (ALA), a type of omega-3 crucial for brain development, especially during adolescence. Adolescence is a period of significant biological changes, including hormonal transformations that stimulate synaptic growth in the frontal lobe, essential for neuropsychological maturation. The study showed that adolescents who consumed walnuts for at least 100 days had increased attention functions, and those with ADHD symptoms showed significant behavioral improvements. The findings highlight the importance of maintaining healthy dietary habits for proper cognitive and psychological development during adolescence.

title: Eating walnuts daily may enhance attention span & memory: Study
summary: A study published in eClinicalMedicine journal discovered that daily walnut consumption can positively affect adolescents' cognitive and psychological growth. Walnuts, high in alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), a vital omega-3 fatty acid, are essential for brain development. The study included 700 high school students aged 11 to 16, split into a control and an experimental group, with the latter eating 30 grams of walnuts daily for 6 months. Results indicated improvements in attention functions and behavior in those showing symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Also, there was a rise in fluid intelligence, which is more biologically inherent and less affected by learning. The study emphasizes the importance of a balanced diet with nutrient-rich foods like walnuts for the health and cognitive development of adolescents.

title: El consumo de alimentos ultraprocesados se asocia a una peor calidad del esperma
summary: A study led by the Universitat Rovira i Virgili (URV) and involving the Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria Pere Virgili (IISPV) and CIBEROBN has discovered a potential link between the consumption of ultra-processed foods and decreased sperm quality in healthy males aged 18 to 40. The research, part of the Led-fertyl study, evaluated 200 men in Catalonia through questionnaires, interviews, and analysis of blood, urine, and semen samples. It found that men whose diets consisted of about 30% ultra-processed foods were more likely to have altered sperm quality parameters as defined by the World Health Organization, including total sperm count, motility, and concentration. The study also indicated that replacing ultra-processed foods with minimally processed or unprocessed foods could improve sperm quality. These findings could lead to the creation of preventive or intervention programs aimed at addressing fertility issues related to poor sperm quality, highlighting the importance of further research in different populations to confirm these results.

title: Vivir condiciones adversas durante la infancia puede alterar los genes
summary: A study by the Instituto de Investigación Sanitaria Pere Virgili (IISPV) has found that adverse childhood experiences such as physical abuse, emotional maltreatment, or neglect can lead to a chemical change in the DNA, particularly in the DDR1 gene. This change, known as epigenetic modification, occurs more often under stressful conditions and is associated with the development of mental disorders like bipolar disorder. The study, part of the Bipogent project, involved 128 adults with bipolar disorder and 141 without any mental illness, and included clinical evaluations, psychological assessments, and blood samples. The DDR1 gene is important in brain cells known as oligodendrocytes, which insulate neurons with a myelin sheath, enabling quicker and more efficient information transfer. This discovery could pave the way for better, more tailored treatments for bipolar disorder in the future, using blood tests to assess the extent of the genetic change. The findings were published in the prestigious journal Molecular Psychiatry.

title: Identifican variantes genéticas que ayudarían a disminuir la disfunción psicosocial de pacientes con trastorno bipolar
summary: A study led by the Institut d'Investigació Sanitària Pere Virgili (IISPV), Hospital Universitari Institut Pere Mata, and the Centro de Investigación Biomédica en Red de Salud Mental (CIBERSAM), involving Pilar Alejandra Sáiz from the University of Oviedo, identified genetic variants in the DDR1 gene that are linked to cognitive abilities and psychosocial functioning in bipolar disorder patients. These cognitive abilities include memory, concentration, and information processing, which, when impaired, affect the patient's psychosocial function - their ability to perform routine tasks and interact socially. The findings could lead to early detection of patients at higher risk of cognitive and psychosocial deterioration, allowing for more personalized and effective treatment to improve their quality of life. However, further research involving more patients with varied profiles is needed before these tests can be implemented clinically. The study analyzed 3,035 samples provided by CIBERSAM and aims to use the identified DDR1 gene variants, along with those from other studies, as a tool for early detection in health systems. This research was recently published in the journal "Molecular Psychiatry" and involved collaboration from nine CIBERSAM research groups.

title: El catedrático de la URV Jordi Salas-Salvadó recibe el XIX Premio Internacional Hipócrates de investigación médica ...
summary: Jordi Salas-Salvadó, a professor at the Universitat Rovira i Virgili (URV), received the 19th International Hippocrates Award for Medical Research on Human Nutrition, granted by the Royal Academy of Medicine and Surgery of the Principality of Asturias, in recognition of his outstanding scientific and research career in nutrition. Salas-Salvadó, a leading figure in the study of the Mediterranean diet's health effects, delivered a lecture titled "Nutrients, Foods, or Dietary Patterns?" during the award ceremony. He directs the URV's Human Nutrition Unit, is a researcher at the Pere Virgili Health Research Institute, and the main researcher at the CIBER of Physiopathology of Obesity and Nutrition of the Carlos III Institute. His research focuses on clinical trials assessing the impact of diets and dietary compounds on obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. Salas-Salvadó has been pivotal in the PREDIMED study since 2005 and currently leads the ongoing PREDIMED-PLUS trial. He has published over 750 articles and has been cited in more than 76,000 scientific papers.

title: Los carbohidratos de mejor calidad contribuyen a una flora bacteriana intestinal más saludable
summary: A study conducted by the Human Nutrition research group of the University Rovira i Virgili and the Pere Virgili Health Research Institute, and published in 'Gut Microbes', has demonstrated that high-quality carbohydrates are good for the gut microbiota and metabolic health in people at high risk of cardiovascular disease. The study included 617 elderly individuals with a high cardiometabolic risk from across Spain, evaluating their Carbohydrate Quality Index (CQI) using validated food consumption questionnaires. This index takes into account aspects such as fiber content, whole grains, sugary drinks, and the glycemic index. Fecal samples were analyzed to assess the gut microbiota. The results showed that a diet rich in quality carbohydrates (high CQI) leads to a more diverse and abundant gut microbiota, which is linked to better cardiometabolic health and an increase in beneficial cardiovascular bacteria. Moreover, enhancing carbohydrate quality with a Mediterranean diet for a year resulted in a significant rise in healthy gut bacteria. This indicates that improving the quality of dietary carbohydrates can improve metabolism and cardiovascular health by influencing the gut microbiota, providing insights into creating specific diets for the betterment of metabolic health and for the prevention or reduction of disease.

title: Las personas con déficit de atención e hiperactividad viven menos, según un estudio
summary: A genetic study has found a link between Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and a lower life expectancy, with mortality rates up to five times higher than those without the disorder. Researchers identified 19 genetic regions associated with ADHD and reduced longevity, marking the first time such a connection has been established. The study, involving data from 19,099 ADHD patients and 34,194 healthy individuals, highlighted the TNKS gene among others, which plays a crucial role in chromosome regions related to longevity and is also linked to psychiatric traits and metabolic disorders common in ADHD patients. Additionally, early diagnosis of ADHD was emphasized as crucial, noting that those diagnosed in adulthood face a higher mortality risk compared to those diagnosed in childhood or adolescence. The study underscores the importance of early detection and support for ADHD patients to potentially reduce negative outcomes and mortality risk.

title: El Colegio de Farmacéuticos de Madrid renueva su sello de calidad 'Madrid Excelente' | @diariofarma
summary: The Official College of Pharmacists of Madrid (COFM) has renewed its 'Madrid Excelente' quality seal, awarded by the Community of Madrid, which recognizes organizations committed to continuous improvement, innovation, environmental and social respect, and user satisfaction. This seal, which the COFM obtained for the first time in 2002, endorses its commitment to excellence and leadership in the pharmaceutical field, as well as its focus on results and the user. The renewal of the seal involves an evaluation of COFM's management practices in areas such as purpose, planet, people, and progress. Manuel Martínez del Peral, president of the COFM, highlighted that this certification reflects the college's effort to grow in excellence and translate it into concrete results. Elena Mantilla, director of the Madrid Foundation for Competitiveness, expressed the pride of the Community of Madrid for the renewal of this distinction to the COFM.

title: Pediatras y psicólogos aragoneses detectan retrasos en el lenguaje por el abuso de las pantallas
hco: ASOCIACION DE PEDIATRIA DEATENCION PRIMARIA DE ARAGON
summary: Pediatricians and psychologists in Aragon have noticed language delays in children under 3 years old due to too much screen time. They point out that the early years are vital for physical and mental growth, and too much use of devices like tablets or smartphones can block natural brain development, causing speech problems at a young age. This inactive screen time also leads to delays in motor skills and sleep issues because the blue light affects melatonin production. Dr. María Pilar Mallada states that screens are not bad by themselves but must be used correctly. A campaign called 'Talk to him, look at him, sing to him, play. Stimulate his brain. Don't let a screen replace you' has started to inform parents about the dangers of wrong screen use during childhood, spreading educational brochures in healthcare centers to make people aware of the problem and promote healthier practices.

title: El Colegio de Enfermería de Santa Cruz de Tenerife renueva su Junta con Natalia Rodríguez al frente
hco: COLEGIO OFICIAL DE ENFERMERIADE SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE
summary: The Nursing College of Santa Cruz de Tenerife has renewed its Board of Directors, with Natalia Rodríguez as the new president. Under her leadership, the college seeks to continue the work of the last 30 years, focusing on professional development to ensure quality care and clinical safety for citizens. Rodríguez highlights the need to address historical claims such as increasing the number of nurses to improve nurse/patient ratios, consolidating job positions to prevent the flight of professionals, labor recognition, the development of specialties, the full implementation of nurse prescribing, and access to management positions. She also emphasizes the importance of responding to the care needs of an aging society with chronic health problems, which requires expanding the number of university places and staff in health systems. The new board includes Óscar Rey as vice president, Ana María González as secretary, Carlota Martín as treasurer, and several members.

title: Santander acoge las XXVII Jornadas de la Sociedad Cántabra de Medicina Familiar y Comunitaria | Portal ...
summary: Santander is hosting the 27th edition of the Cantabrian Society of Family and Community Medicine Conference on April 9 and 10, 2024. Over 100 professionals are expected to attend this event at the Palacio de la Magdalena, announced by the Health Councilor Zulema Gancedo, alongside the society's president Gema Suárez and board member Natalia Sebastiá. The conference aims to provide an innovative and enriching program covering topics such as chronic kidney disease from a primary care perspective, the evolution of family and community medicine over the last 40 years, initial patient care for multiple trauma, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) through workshops. It will also include the presentation of scientific communications, a member assembly, and awards for the best works presented. This year marks the society's 40th anniversary in Cantabria, celebrated by moving the event to a new location and emphasizing the importance of family medicine in prevention and health promotion, with a commitment from the University of Cantabria to include family medicine in its curriculum starting next year.

title: La Fundación de Investigación HM Hospitales vuelve a registrar cifras récord en 2023
summary: The HM Hospitals Research Foundation (FiHM) has reached record figures in 2023, conducting more than 300 clinical trials that benefited nearly a thousand patients, with a significant focus on oncology, representing 70% of the trials. The Phase I Clinical Trials Unit START - HM CIOCC, led by Dr. Emiliano Calvo, has been crucial in this achievement. Additionally, the foundation has produced 223 scientific publications, achieving the highest impact indices in its history. Advances in vaccine research and in the digital transformation of health data science are highlighted, collaborating with Savana to integrate artificial intelligence into research. The third edition of the 'Abarca Prize' was awarded to Douglas A. Melton for his research on type 1 diabetes. The FiHM also maintains intense charitable activity through the HM Nens Social Work Foundation and collaborations to improve diagnostic and social coverage.

title: Fundación de Investigación HM Hospitales y GSK se unen en busca de un mayor conocimiento de la COVID-19 grave
summary: HM Hospitals Research Foundation and GSK have formed an alliance to advance the knowledge of severe COVID-19, announced on April 24, 2023. This agreement focuses on the creation of the 'COVID-19 Observatory', a collaborative project aimed at optimizing the detection, care, and early treatment of patients at high risk of developing severe forms of the disease. The initiative also includes the publication and dissemination of patient registry results in scientific publications, with the goal of sharing the acquired knowledge. Additionally, training programs in severe eosinophilic asthma will be implemented to improve the diagnosis and treatment of this specific condition, thus improving care for patients affected by this and other COVID-19 related pathologies. The collaboration between both entities aims to deepen the understanding of the disease and improve the care and treatments available for patients.

title: Alberto Muñoz, nuevo presidente de la Fundación de Investigación HM Hospitales
summary: Alberto Muñoz has been appointed as the new president of the HM Hospitales Research Foundation. He is a research professor at the Higher Council for Scientific Research (CSIC) in the Biomedical Research Institute of Madrid (IIBM). This announcement was made through Diario Médico, a platform that requires professional health-related users to log in for accessing detailed medical information and services. The platform emphasizes its commitment to providing quality health information to professionals in the field.

title: Covid-19: el tratamiento anticoagulante a dosis altas puede reducir la tasa de muerte en un 30%
summary: High-dose anticoagulant treatment can reduce the death rate by 30% and the need for intubation by 25% in hospitalized non-critical COVID-19 patients, compared to standard low-dose anticoagulation treatment. This is based on the international study 'Freedom COVID', led by cardiologist Valentín Fuster and coordinated in Spain by the HM Hospitals Research Foundation. Conducted across 76 hospitals in ten countries, including Spain, the study involved 3,398 hospitalized adult COVID-19 patients not in ICU. It demonstrated that high-dose anticoagulation could improve survival, especially in patients with lung involvement but not requiring ICU admission. The findings, presented at the American College of Cardiology Congress in New Orleans and published by The Journal of American College of Cardiology (JACC), mark a potential change in the management of non-critical COVID-19 patients.

title: "El alcohol, cuanto menos mejor"
summary: The Spanish Society of Internal Medicine (SEMI) stresses the importance of reducing alcohol consumption due to its link with over 200 diseases, especially liver conditions like fatty liver disease caused by too much alcohol, obesity, or diabetes. Even minimal alcohol use can cause liver damage, underscoring the need to cut down on alcohol. In Spain, a large part of the population drinks alcohol, with varying consumption levels across different age groups. SEMI seeks to inform about the dangers of drinking alcohol, likening the need to change how alcohol is viewed to the shift in how cigarettes are seen. There is a reevaluation of the once recommended alcohol consumption limits, suggesting a move towards stricter guidelines. This effort is part of a larger campaign to tackle alcohol-related health problems, with alcohol being a key discussion point at the national internists meeting in Valencia.

title: El urólogo Leandro Reina (hospital Rafael Méndez), nuevo presidente de la Asociación Murciana de Urología
summary: Dr. Leandro Reina, a urologist at Rafael Méndez Hospital in Lorca, has been appointed president of the Murcian Urology Association. This appointment coincides with the introduction of the first Holep laser urological surgery (Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate) in the health area III of Lorca. The Holep technique is an innovation that allows the treatment of prostate adenomas causing urinary obstruction through a minimally invasive procedure, resulting in less pain and side effects for the patient. This advance positions Rafael Méndez Hospital at the forefront of urological treatments in the region, highlighting its commitment to medical excellence and improving the quality of life of patients.

title: El Ayuntamiento impulsa un proyecto para que mejore el conocimiento del cuidado de la piel y la prevención de ...
summary: The Madrid City Council has launched the 'Madrid Dermosaludable' project in collaboration with the Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (AEDV), with the goal of improving knowledge about skin care and the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) among citizens. The initiative will include awareness campaigns, informative sessions, and the creation of dermo-health classrooms in municipal health centers. Deputy Mayor Inma Sanz highlighted the importance of prevention and awareness about STDs, especially given the increase in these infections. Additionally, it was announced that Madrid Salud, which has worked for over 25 years in the prevention and care of STDs, will receive a budget increase in 2024 to continue developing public health services. The collaboration has also resulted in Madrid being awarded the 'Dermosaludable City' seal by the AEDV.

title: Un dermatólogo del Hospital Ramón y Cajal, nuevo coordinador electo del Grupo de Tricología de la Academia ...
summary: Dr. David Saceda Corralo, a dermatologist at the Ramón y Cajal University Hospital in the Community of Madrid, has been appointed the elected coordinator of the Trichology Group of the Spanish Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (AEDV) for a period of four years. His work will focus on promoting training and research in alopecia and hair follicle disorders. With a degree in Medicine from the University of Alcalá and specialized in Dermatology at the same hospital, Dr. Saceda has defended a doctoral thesis in trichology and is an Associate Professor at the University of Alcalá. He coordinates the hospital's Trichology Unit, recognized nationally and internationally, and is an active member of the #TricoHRC research group, with more than 120 scientific publications. In addition, he is the Scientific Coordinator of the International Master in Trichology and Hair Transplantation at the University of Alcalá and part of the panel of experts of the International Frontal Fibrosing Alopecia Cooperative Group.

title: INCIBE y Fundación IDIS firman un convenio para impulsar la ciberseguridad en el sector sanitario
hco: FUND INSTITUTO DESARROLLOY LA INTEGRACION DE LA SANIDAD
summary: The National Cybersecurity Institute of Spain (INCIBE) and the Institute for the Development and Integration of Health (IDIS Foundation) have signed a collaboration agreement for the next 4 years with the aim of reinforcing cybersecurity and cyber resilience in the private healthcare sector. This agreement seeks to promote awareness of cybersecurity, encourage training and qualification in this area, diagnose the level of cyber maturity of healthcare entities, and facilitate communication between INCIBE and the member entities of the IDIS Foundation. Félix Barrio, director general of INCIBE, emphasized the importance of understanding that cybersecurity is crucial for the security and privacy of the patient, highlighting that the NIS2 directive establishes measures to ensure cybersecurity in critical infrastructures and essential services in the European Union, including the healthcare sector.

title: Formalizado el contrato para realizar los servicios de secuenciación de ARN dentro del proyecto de investigación de ...
hco: FUNDACION INSTITUTO ESTUDIOSCIENCIAS SALUD CASTILLA Y LEON
summary: The contract has been formalized between the Health Sciences Studies Foundation of Castilla y León and Navarra de Servicios y Tecnología, S.A. for RNA sequencing services of 201 samples within a research project on precision personalized medicine focusing on Metabolic-Associated Fatty Liver Disease (MAFLD). This project, funded by the Spanish Ministry of Science, Innovation, and Universities with a €1.6 million grant, is part of the Recovery, Transformation, and Resilience Plan, specifically within the Carlos III Health Institute's precision medicine research projects. It aims to identify therapeutic targets and biomarkers for precision medicine in MAFLD. The project, with a duration of four years, involves around ten basic and clinical groups, including the Zamora Hospital Complex, and is coordinated by the National Center for Cardiovascular Research (CNIC). It falls under the Next Generation EU funds, aiming to advance personalized precision health projects to improve public health through scientific knowledge and innovation.

title: El Instituto de la Salud de Castilla y León celebra su 25 aniversario con homenajes y mesas redondas
hco: FUNDACION INSTITUTO ESTUDIOSCIENCIAS SALUD CASTILLA Y LEON
summary: The Castilla y León Health Institute (ICSCYL) celebrates its 25th anniversary with a program of activities that includes tributes and roundtables, starting on September 14. Founded in 1998, the ICSCYL has been a key center for health training and research in the region, having welcomed about 10,000 students annually and having a teaching staff of 4,000 professors. The foundation, a non-profit organization chaired by the Health Councilor, is dedicated to promoting training, research, and dissemination in various areas of public and health care. The anniversary activities include lectures and roundtables on relevant health topics, reflecting the institute's commitment to research and training in the field of health. The closing of the anniversary will feature the presence of the President of the Regional Government, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, and will mark the announcement of the creation of new associated centers.

title: El IECSCyL cumple 25 años con la investigación como buque insignia
hco: FUNDACION INSTITUTO ESTUDIOSCIENCIAS SALUD CASTILLA Y LEON
summary: The Castilla y León Health Sciences Studies Institute (IECSCyL), based in Soria, celebrates its 25th anniversary focusing on research as its main activity. During a commemorative event, the importance of the institute in managing research and training professionals in the health sector was highlighted. Since its creation in 1998, the IECSCyL has evolved to meet the training and research needs of health personnel in Castilla y León, adapting its statutes in 2022 to comply with current regulations. The non-profit foundation that manages it promotes training, research, and dissemination in public health, healthcare, and other related fields. To celebrate its anniversary, round tables and conferences on various health topics have been organized, with the participation of experts in the field.

title: El equipo de Enfermería de Urología gana el primer premio de Retos en Salud
hco: FUNDACION INSTITUTO ESTUDIOSCIENCIAS SALUD CASTILLA Y LEON
summary: The Urology Nursing team from Soria won the first prize at the Health Innovation Challenges contest for their project on alert bells indicating the end of irrigation serum. This initiative aims to improve patient safety by involving a device that notifies when the serum bag needs replacement, thus ensuring continuous post-surgical washing without constant manual checks. This project, started by nurse Roberto Álvarez Alonso, enhances nursing care efficiency and effectiveness, reduces complications, and improves patient rest, ultimately adding value to patient care. Additionally, the project received recognition for good practice in patient safety at a conference held at the General Hospital of Segovia on November 24, 2023. This innovation reflects the commitment of healthcare professionals to patient safety and quality of care, promoting the transfer and application of research and innovation results to develop health products, processes, and services.

title: El Colegio de Médicos de Las Palmas entrega sus becas para investigación y estancia en formación
hco: COLEGIO OFICIAL DE MEDICOS DE LAS P
summary: The Las Palmas Medical Association Foundation has awarded scholarships for research and training stays to a total of 21 projects, divided into eight for medical scientific research and 13 for training stays at prominent national and international centers. Since 1995, the institution has promoted these scholarships to encourage research and medical knowledge, marking an important recognition in the medical community of the province. The awarded research projects cover various areas such as healthy aging, leukemia, infection prevention, congenital heart disease, among others. The Special Research Scholarship doctor González Jaraba was awarded to three projects, with prizes ranging from 4,500 to 5,500 euros. Furthermore, the importance of these scholarships in retaining talent and motivating researchers in their scientific and professional work was highlighted. The Training Stay Scholarships offer financial aid of 4,000 euros each for training in various medical specialties at reference centers.

title: En Canarias más de 150 médicos fueron agredidos por sus propios pacientes en 2023
hco: COLEGIO OFICIAL DE MEDICOS DE LAS P
summary: In 2023, over 150 doctors in the Canary Islands were assaulted by their own patients, with 57% of the victims being female and 43% male. The majority of these incidents, almost 80%, involved threats and coercion, while 20% resulted in physical aggression or injury. More than 70% of these assaults occurred after disagreements with medical care. The College of Physicians of Las Palmas expressed concern over the rising number of attacks on healthcare professionals, noting that while 152 cases were reported, the actual number is likely higher. They emphasized the importance of reporting these incidents to both the police and the College, which acts on every reported case. The College has also recommended integrating assault data from both public and private sectors to better understand and address the issue.

title: Los nuevos MIR reciben su carné de colegiados
hco: COLEGIO OFICIAL DE MEDICOS DE LAS P
summary: The Official College of Physicians of Alicante welcomed 215 new resident doctors (MIR) who are starting their specialization in health centers of the province. The young doctor commission, along with the president of the college, encouraged the residents to take advantage of the facilities and services offered, and resolved doubts about the start of their residency. The importance of continuous training was highlighted, and services for member support, support initiatives, professional responsibilities, aids, scholarships, cultural and leisure activities were presented. During the event, awards from the I MIR Clinical Cases Contest were given out.

title: El Colegio de Médicos de Las Palmas inaugura nueva sede en Lanzarote
hco: COLEGIO OFICIAL DE MEDICOS DE LAS P
summary: The College of Physicians of Las Palmas inaugurated a new headquarters in Lanzarote, offering a larger and more comfortable space of 620 m2 spread over two floors, quintupling its previous area. Located on the road to San Bartolomé, this new headquarters improves accessibility, connection, and parking, being also close to the main hospital centers of Arrecife. The opening was attended by college members and health authorities. Pedro Cabrera, president of the College, highlighted the importance of doctors and the institution to society. Carlos García Zerpa and Vicente Román Peris, members of the College, highlighted the growth of medical college membership and the symbolism of the new building for the profession on the island. Aniuska Sutil, a college member, emphasized the need for expansion to meet current and future demands.

title: Las enfermeras piden al nuevo Gobierno Vasco "una escucha más activa y mayor estabilidad laboral"
summary: Nurses in Gipuzkoa, represented by Pilar Lekuona, president of the College of Nursing of Gipuzkoa, have expressed their dissatisfaction with their current working conditions, including job instability and a high number of temporary contracts. A survey conducted among 5,600 nurses revealed that 80% demand more nursing staff, 70% seek recognition of their specialties, better access to management positions, and greater acknowledgment from the government. The survey also showed that 64.6% of nurses rate the management of the health department poorly. Nurses are calling for more active listening from the administration and an opportunity to participate in discussions. These demands have been compiled into a report sent to political parties, hoping to influence the upcoming Basque Government's agenda.

title: Enfermería de Gipuzkoa alerta de posibles brotes de enfermedades que se previenen con vacunas
summary: The Official College of Nursing of Gipuzkoa (COEGI) has issued a warning about potential outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases such as measles, whooping cough, and pneumococcal disease. This alert comes during the World Immunization Week, celebrated from April 24 to 30, with the theme "Vaccination Saves Lives." COEGI emphasizes the importance of vaccination as the only effective way to prevent these airborne diseases. It also highlights the dangers of misinformation about vaccines spreading through various media and social networks, which can lead to public distrust and vaccine refusal. COEGI is organizing the IX Vaccination Update Day on May 6 to educate nurses about the latest in vaccination, including the prevention of Respiratory Syncytial Virus.

title: «Vemos brotes de tosferina o sarampión evitables con las vacunas»
summary: Rosa Sancho, the head of the vaccination committee at COEGI, highlighted the occurrence of preventable whooping cough and measles outbreaks due to vaccine avoidance. Despite expectations that the pandemic would raise awareness about the importance of vaccinations, the public quickly reverted to neglecting them. The World Health Organization estimates that vaccines can prevent over 20 deadly diseases and up to 5 million deaths annually with proper immunization. This statement was made in the context of the World Immunization Week, emphasizing the critical role of vaccines in public health.

title: La ‘Ruta Enfermera’ llega a Gipuzkoa
summary: The 'Nursing Route', a project promoted by the CGE and the Official College of Nursing of Gipuzkoa (COEGI), has arrived in San Sebastián, Gipuzkoa, from July 4 to 7. This traveling health trailer aims to promote healthy habits and raise awareness about the vital work of nurses at all stages of life. The initiative was inaugurated with the presence of local authorities and health professionals. The trailer offers informational spaces on health, pathologies, and the role of nurses, as well as private consultations for disease detection tests and a space for stroke detection. Talks and workshops on health are also organized. The campaign seeks to reinforce the visibility and recognition of nursing, emphasizing the importance of policies that support their work to improve healthcare.

title: 7 de cada 10 enfermeras que trabajan en Gipuzkoa creen que su situación profesional no ha mejorado en el último año
summary: A survey by the Official College of Nursing of Gipuzkoa (COEGI) shows that 70% of nurses in Gipuzkoa feel their work situation hasn't improved over the last year. Conducted for International Nurses Day on May 12th, it calls for more staff, better job stability, and improved treatment in organizations. Despite challenges, 88% of Gipuzkoa's nurses updated their skills through training last year. The survey found 49% have fixed schedules, while 51% work rotating shifts. Nearly 83% are proficient in Basque. Gipuzkoa has 5,475 active nurses, 92% women, with a diverse age range and a net increase in numbers. Last year, COEGI held 128 training events, both in-person and online. On International Nurses Day, COEGI's president stressed the need for recognition and support, noting nurses' crucial healthcare role. Events in Gipuzkoa included a lecture on healers' history and nurse recognition for service and loyalty.

title: «Las enfermeras en Gipuzkoa están muy cansadas y se sienten poco reconocidas»
summary: Pilar Lekuona, president of the Nursing College of Gipuzkoa, highlighted the exhaustion and lack of recognition felt by nurses in Gipuzkoa. She emphasized the critical need for social and health policymakers to provide the necessary tools and appreciation for nurses, especially on International Nurses Day. The statement reflects the sentiments of a significant majority of nurses in the region, who are dissatisfied with their working conditions and the manner in which their roles are being managed and acknowledged.

title: El presidente de la AECC, sobre la investigación contra el cáncer: "Estamos llenando el hueco que nos sep
summary: The president of the Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC), Ramón Reyes, highlighted on Onda Cero's "La Brújula" the importance of cancer research in Spain, noting an effort to close the gap with other countries in terms of investment and opportunities for Spanish researchers. It was mentioned that Spain invests 333 euros per inhabitant in cancer research, a figure lower than countries like Italy, France, or the Netherlands. World Cancer Research Day, celebrated under the motto 'Integrating diversity. Advancing research. Achieving equity', aims to boost oncological research globally and achieve a 70% survival rate by 2030. Reyes emphasized the need for greater diversity in oncological research to improve outcomes for patients worldwide and acknowledged the progress made in the last two years in Spain to improve investment in R&D in the fight against cancer.

title: La AECC entrega 60 ayudas para investigación contra el cáncer en Madrid por 5,17 millones de euros
summary: The Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC) has awarded 60 grants for cancer research in Madrid, with an investment of 5.17 million euros, as part of a larger effort that includes 233 grants and 29.4 million euros nationwide. These grants, announced on International Childhood Cancer Day, aim to increase cancer survival to 70% by 2030, improving treatment and diagnosis, especially in childhood cancers and those with a low survival rate. The event highlighted the importance of research, public-private collaboration, and commitment to science and society. Specific projects were mentioned, such as the FOSTER-CabOS clinical trial for osteosarcoma and the Interfant-21 protocol to improve the prognosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia in children under one year old. The AECC also emphasized European collaboration to promote collaborative clinical research in childhood cancer.

title: AECC, la familia que más fondos dedica a la investigación contra el cáncer
summary: AECC, the Spanish Association Against Cancer, is recognized as the leading private entity dedicating the most funds to cancer research. Celebrating its 70th anniversary, AECC operates with a budget of 130 million euros, employing 1,200 workers, and supported by 640,000 members and 30,000 volunteers. The association provides comprehensive services to cancer patients and their families, including free accommodation in Madrid for those undergoing treatment not available in their home regions. It also offers psychological, social, and medical support through its 52 national centers. Last year, AECC allocated 68 million euros to patient support, over 25 million to awareness, and 24.5 million to research, with a committed budget of around 104 million euros for 565 ongoing projects involving 1,500 researchers. AECC's funding primarily comes from private sources, emphasizing the importance of societal organization in addressing cancer. The association also acts as a lobby for equitable cancer care and research across Spain.

title: Inequidad en vacunas: la AEV advierte del riesgo de contar en España con 19 calendarios | @diariofarma
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) has highlighted the importance of vaccines in reducing health inequalities caused by factors such as misinformation and socioeconomic status. In Spain, the existence of 19 different vaccination schedules, due to powers transferred to the autonomous communities, has generated inequities in vaccine access. The AEV proposed that the Ministry of Health supply vaccines to the autonomous communities to ensure equitable access. Additionally, they emphasize the need for adequate vaccine coverage at a global level, as vaccine-preventable diseases can easily spread between countries. They face challenges such as misinformation and vaccine hesitancy, highlighting the importance of overcoming these barriers to prevent avoidable diseases and deaths. The evaluation of vaccination programs should include social indicators to avoid perpetuating health inequalities.

title: La Asociación Española de Vacunología anima a vacunarse contra el Covid-19, la gripe y el neumococo
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) has launched a campaign called 'The best plan this winter', aimed at promoting vaccination against influenza, Covid-19, and pneumococcal pneumonia in people over 60 and vulnerable populations. This campaign also includes parents of children between 6 months and 4 years, encouraging them to vaccinate the little ones against the flu, a new recommendation for this age group. The AEV highlighted the importance of vaccination as a preventive tool, remembering that respiratory diseases were the third leading cause of death in Spain in 2022. In addition, it pointed out the high mortality and hospitalizations caused by the flu each year and the significant vaccination coverage in children, but not so much in older adults for the pneumococcal vaccine. The campaign emphasizes that getting vaccinated is a healthy habit that can prevent serious diseases.

title: Arranca la campaña '#ClaroQueMeVacuno' para desterrar la idea de que las vacunas son cosa de niños
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) launched the '#OfCourseIGetVaccinated' campaign to change the perception that vaccines are only for children and to emphasize their importance throughout life. Launched during World Immunization Week, the campaign aims to raise awareness about the vital role of vaccines in disease prevention and their historical contribution to saving millions of lives. This initiative has been chosen to be spread on social media, where there is a notable mistrust about the safety and efficacy of vaccines. The campaign also features the participation of influencer Kalon Bay, who highlights the importance of keeping the vaccination schedule up to date through 'body painting'. Furthermore, it is reminded that vaccines are essential not only in childhood but also for workers in certain sectors, people with risk conditions, and travelers to countries with transmissible diseases. The AEV highlights achievements such as the eradication of smallpox and the prevention of millions of deaths from measles and COVID-19, although it points out that there is still work to be done, as evidenced by the low coverage of the flu vaccine in children.

title: Que los virus y bacterias no arruinen tu tiempo con los tuyos es el propósito de la Asociación Española de Vacunología para este invierno
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) has launched a campaign titled "The best plan for this winter" to encourage flu, COVID-19, and pneumococcal vaccinations among the elderly and vulnerable populations, and for the first time, recommends flu vaccinations for children up to four years old. Highlighting the significant impact of respiratory infections, which lead to numerous hospitalizations and deaths annually, the campaign aims to prevent these illnesses through vaccination. The AEV emphasizes the importance of vaccination as a means of protecting not only individuals but also the health system by reducing the burden of epidemic diseases. The campaign targets those over 60, vulnerable groups, and parents of young children, offering guidance on when, where, and how to get vaccinated, including the possibility of co-administering flu and COVID-19 vaccines.

title: Las vacunas salvarán 100 millones de vidas para 2030
summary: Vaccines are projected to save 100 million lives by 2030, doubling the 50 million saved between 2000 and 2019. This increase is partly attributed to the global response to COVID-19, which has accelerated the development and acceptance of vaccines, highlighting their importance in public health. A consensus document prepared by specialists and endorsed by the Spanish Association of Vaccinology emphasizes the paradigm shift that COVID-19 has represented for vaccination, with safe and effective vaccines developed in record time. This advancement has improved public perception of vaccines, reducing fear of side effects and expanding the possibilities for using technologies like mRNA for other diseases. Moreover, the potential of vaccines to prevent diseases such as cancer and reduce the burden on health services is highlighted, marking a promising future in the field of disease prevention and treatment.

title: 'El mejor plan para este invierno'; el nuevo mensaje de AEV para aumentar la vacunación | @diariofarma
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) has launched a campaign titled "The best plan for this winter" to encourage vaccination against flu, COVID-19, and pneumonia, especially targeting individuals aged 60 and over, vulnerable populations, and parents of children aged 6 to 59 months. This initiative aims to improve vaccination coverage, highlighting vaccines as crucial for maintaining immune system health and combating these significant health threats. The campaign, supported by various pharmaceutical companies and health organizations, follows an observed decline in vaccination interest after initial positive responses. It seeks to address this by increasing awareness and vaccination rates among the targeted groups to prevent hospitalizations and deaths associated with these diseases.

title: Adiós a las vacunas de Astrazéneca para el covid
summary: AstraZeneca has stopped selling its COVID-19 vaccine in Europe due to low demand and high stock, as well as recognizing serious side effects like blood clots. The vaccine was suspended in some areas, including Aragón, after being associated with blood clot incidents. It was later approved for use in people over 60. The European Commission consented to AstraZeneca's request to end the vaccine's marketing authorization, which was initially given on January 29, 2021, with sales ending on May 7. This follows a review and adjustment period in vaccine usage, especially in higher-risk groups, showing the company's reaction to the risks and changing public health situation.

title: La Asociación Española de Vacunología propone dedicar un espacio público a la vacunación de la Covid
summary: The Spanish Association of Vaccinology (AEV) has proposed to the city councils of the provincial capitals and autonomous cities of Spain to dedicate a street, square, or public space to Covid-19 vaccination, as recognition of this health achievement. The initiative seeks to pay tribute to everyone involved in the vaccination process, from its development to its administration to citizens, including healthcare personnel, administrative staff, and the pharmaceutical industry, among others. The proposal emphasizes the collective effort to overcome the pandemic, recalling its impact in Spain, with more than 120,000 deaths and thousands of hospital admissions until June 2023. The AEV highlights the start of vaccination at the end of 2020 as a moment of hope and a step towards the recovery of normality after the crisis generated by the virus.

title: La vacunología española: entre el éxito del calendario vacunas y el reto de inmunizar el futuro | @diariofarma
summary: Vaccinology in Spain faces the challenge of moving forward into the future after a successful 2023, marked by significant additions to the vaccination schedule and notable social support. The Virtual Vaccine Congress, organized by MSD, brings together experts to discuss the future role of vaccines, highlighting the pioneering introduction of vaccines against the respiratory syncytial virus and the rotavirus vaccine for children. The importance of vaccines beyond the established schedule is emphasized, pointing out their role in healthcare savings and health equity. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is recognized as a key tool in vaccine development and education. Furthermore, the need to extend vaccination programs beyond childhood is underlined, and the goal of eradicating the human papillomavirus (HPV) within a decade is mentioned, based on vaccination, screening, treatment, and awareness.

title: España, segundo país de la UE en la aplicación del calendario de vacunación infantil | @diariofarma
summary: Spain ranks as the second country within the European Union for the best implementation of its childhood vaccination schedule, according to a study published in the Expert Review of Vaccines. This evaluation was carried out by a group of European vaccinologists, including a member from the Spanish Association of Vaccinology. The study assessed all vaccines included in childhood schedules, whether recommended or funded, and assigned scores based on 'basic', 'extended', and 'increased' categories. Despite Spain's high ranking, the study was conducted before the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine in the country and did not consider the inclusion of monoclonal antibodies against the respiratory syncytial virus. The research aimed to examine the variation in the breadth of protection offered by National Immunization Programs (NIP) across Europe and proposed a framework for evaluating the comprehensiveness of pediatric NIPs in Europe. France, Italy, Latvia, and Spain were identified as countries with the most comprehensive NIPs. The study also aimed to initiate a discussion on the differences in NIP scores across countries and to promote the adoption of practices that could improve public health outcomes.

title: Almería estrena un programa para jóvenes con problemas de salud mental
summary: Almería has launched a pioneering program in Andalusia to support young people with mental health issues, facilitated by the Public Foundation for the Social Integration of People with Mental Illness (FAISEM) and the University of Almería (UAL). This initiative offers a space for active listening and support without an appointment from 5 to 10 PM at the Blas Infante social center. It aims to address the social support needs of these individuals, featuring collaboration from those with personal mental health experience, students, FAISEM professionals, and researchers. The program, highlighted for its innovative and inclusive approach, seeks to prevent crises, relapses, and hospitalizations by providing an open and accessible space for young people facing mental health challenges. It is part of an international network and employs the Open Dialogue approach, with training provided by experts in the field. The project will also be subject to a research study led by the University of Almería.

title: Más de 80.200 euros para el servicio de orientación al empleo de Faisem en Jaén para personas con discapacidad ...
summary: The Employment, Business, and Self-Employment Department has allocated over 80,200 euros to the Andalucía Orienta unit of the Andalusian Public Foundation for the Social Integration of People with Mental Illness (Faisem) in Jaén. This funding is aimed at providing personalized guidance and intensive support to individuals with intellectual or psychological disabilities in their job search. The initiative highlights the foundation's commitment to fostering an equal and inclusive society where no one is left behind. Faisem's work is crucial in improving employability for people with severe mental illnesses, offering them essential tools to achieve employment goals. The program, part of the broader Andalucía Orienta network managed by the Andalusian Employment Service, focuses on personalized employment insertion pathways, emphasizing individualized attention and continuous follow-up. This effort is part of a call that started in June 2023 and involves specialized attention for various groups facing insertion challenges, including those with physical, sensory, and intellectual disabilities, as well as individuals at risk of exclusion.

title: El Ayuntamiento de Lepe y Faisem estudian líneas de colaboración para reforzar el apoyo social
summary: The City Council of Lepe and the Andalusian Public Foundation for the Social Integration of People with Mental Illness (Faisem) are exploring collaboration avenues to strengthen social support, especially for people with severe mental disorders. In a recent meeting, they discussed the possibility of developing joint projects that improve social support programs in the coastal region. This collaboration is part of the City Council's commitment to mental health, reflected in the approval of an institutional motion to urgently address mental health issues. Faisem, dependent on the Andalusian Regional Government and founded in 1993, works on the development of social inclusion and recovery programs for people with mental disorders, serving around 9,000 people in Andalusia, including 632 in Huelva.

title: III Jornada Mujeres, Igualdad y Salud Mental de la fundación FAISEM
summary: The III Conference on Women, Equality and Mental Health, organized by the Andalusian Public Foundation for the Social Integration of People with Mental Illness (FAISEM), is scheduled for Thursday, December 14th at 10:00 AM at the Aula Magna of the Higher Technical School of Architecture of the University of Granada. The event will be chaired by Mar Venegas Medina, the Vice-Rector for Equality, Inclusion, and Social Commitment; Indalecio Sánchez-Montesinos García, head of the Territorial Delegation of Health and Consumption in Granada; Silvia Maraver Ayala, manager of FAISEM; and Trinidad Rus Molina, Director General of Socio-Health Care, Mental Health, and Addictions at the Ministry of Health and Consumption.

title: El TSJA condena a Faisem, fundación pública dependiente de la Consejería de Salud, por fraude en los procesos ...
summary: The High Court of Justice of Andalusia (TSJA) has condemned Faisem, a public foundation under the Andalusian Health Council, for fraud in its personnel selection processes. The court's decision supports the claim of the Andalusian Federation of Health and Sociosanitary Sectors of CCOO that the selection processes did not adhere to principles of equality, merit, and capacity.
