The congress will bring together more than 70 speakers and hundreds of professionals to discuss multidisciplinary topics related to aging, including frailty, nutrition, cardiogeriatrics, oncogeriatrics, dementia, diabetes, vaccines for the elderly, long-term care, unwanted loneliness, person-centered care, new technologies for aging, and psychological aspects of the elderly. The motto of the congress is "Designing a new future, Building networks, Working together," emphasizing the importance of collaboration in the field of geriatrics and gerontology.

title: CONVOCADOS LOS PREMIOS Y BECAS DE LA SEGG 2024
summary: The Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology (SEGG) has announced the call for Awards and Scholarships for the 2024 edition. Categories include the Beltrán Báguena Award, the Pañella Casas Award, the Salgado Alba Award, the New Image of Aging Award, Best Geriatrics Resident 2023-2024, Best Geriatric Nursing Resident 2023-2024, among others, aimed at recognizing professionals in the field of elderly care. The awards will be presented during the closing of the 2024 Congress on June 28 in Malaga. In addition, scholarships are offered for training and congress attendance, with application deadlines in April 2024 and award dates in April and June 2024. SEGG seeks to encourage participation and recognize work in the field of geriatrics and gerontology with these initiatives.

title: EL 75 ANIVERSARIO DE LA SEGG, EN EL CUPÓN DE LA ONCE
summary: The 75th anniversary of the Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology (SEGG) is celebrated with a special ONCE lottery coupon on Sunday, October 1st, 2023. This event aims to spread awareness of the organization, with 5.5 million coupons featuring an illustration of two elderly individuals and the slogan "Getting older is not a problem but an opportunity." The coupon was presented by Ángel Ávila, ONCE's subdelegate in Catalonia, and José Augusto García, president of SEGG, alongside Gloria González, an ONCE seller in Catalonia. ONCE coupons are sold by over 19,000 sellers and can also be purchased online or at authorized establishments. The Weekend Paycheck from ONCE offers various prizes, including a main prize of 300,000 euros plus 5,000 euros a month for 20 years to a single coupon holder, and additional prizes to other winners.

title: “LA GERIATRÍA SIEMPRE HA SIDO MULTIDISCPLINAR PORQUE LOS PACIENTES SON COMPLEJOS”
summary: Geriatrics has always been multidisciplinary due to the complexity of its patients. José Manuel Ribera Casado, author of "75 years of the Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology" (SEGG), emphasizes the importance of understanding the evolution of geriatrics and gerontology and their roles in addressing issues related to aging. Gerontology covers the biological, clinical (geriatrics), and social aspects of aging, requiring a wide range of professions to meet the diverse needs of the elderly. The SEGG, established in 1948, embodies these aspects, showcasing the multidisciplinary nature of geriatrics. Notable figures in its history include Manuel Beltrán Báguena, Gregorio Marañón, among others. The future challenges of the discipline include ensuring the integration of the elderly in society and fighting against ageism. Ribera Casado underscores the significance of multidisciplinarity in geriatrics, as elderly patients often have complex health problems that go beyond traditional medical limits, requiring a unified effort from different professionals.

title: Ni "poco" ni de "forma controlada": los geriatras piden cero sujeciones a los mayores en residencias u hospitales
summary: The Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology (SEGG) has presented the 'Care without Restraints 2023' document, requesting a legislative change to eliminate mechanical and pharmacological restraints in residences and hospitals, considering them a form of abuse. They argue that there are more respectful alternatives for the care of the elderly, emphasizing the need to respect their dignity and rights. The document proposes a restraint-free care model, requiring a national plan for its implementation, with the goal of completely abolishing restraints by 2025. This change also implies a transformation in the residential care model, promoting home care and the end of large-scale nursing homes. The SEGG highlights the importance of training for caregivers in this new care approach.

title: IÑAKI GABILONDO: “NO ACEPTES NUNCA QUE LA SOCIEDAD TE DESCARTE”
summary: Iñaki Gabilondo, a renowned figure with extensive media experience, spoke at the 63rd SEGG congress, emphasizing the importance of not allowing society to view older individuals as redundant. He reflected on his retirement and the future, discussing the extended lifespan without corresponding quality of life. Gabilondo highlighted the COVID-19 pandemic as a reminder of his age and society's gerontophobia. He criticized the societal tendency to sideline the elderly, comparing it to a virus that targets the aged. Gabilondo argued that while some initiatives have been taken to address the issue, the societal mindset that views the elderly as a burden persists. He stressed the need for a societal shift to value and integrate the elderly, ensuring they live meaningful lives. The conversation also touched on the diversity within the aging population and the importance of preparing for old age by embracing it as a part of life. Gabilondo advocated for active engagement in life regardless of age and criticized ageism, urging society to value the contributions and dignity of older individuals.

title: 63 CONGRESO: MÁS DE CIEN PONENTES PARA ABORDAR EL ENVEJECIMIENTO SALUDABLE
summary: The 63rd congress of the SEGG, to be held in Pamplona from June 7 to 9, focuses on healthy aging under the motto "Healthy aging: a shared challenge". This event will bring together more than a hundred speakers, specialists in geriatrics and social and biological gerontology, both national and international, to discuss how to improve aging and collaboration to achieve it. The congress will address the latest advances in physical exercise, nutrition, and social activity, emphasizing personalized prescription and addressing frailty and complexity in the elderly. Sessions on advances in the biology of aging, treatment of aging-associated diseases, and the importance of social integration of the elderly will be included. The event seeks to enhance the capabilities of the elderly, including strengthening the immune system and social participation.

title: LSTM-led project awarded over £1m to develop translational research and commercialisation framework | LSTM
summary: A project led by the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, called FLIGHT, focused on creating a framework for translational health research and commercial development, has received over £1m from the UK government. This grant is from the Research England’s Connecting Capability Fund / Research England Development Fund awards, aimed at encouraging partnerships between universities and the private sector to boost research commercialization and support economic growth. FLIGHT involves the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, and Brighton and Sussex Medical School, along with various business and global health partners. It intends to establish an Innovation and Enterprise Framework to commercialize translational research into public health systems products and treatments, tackling challenges in product development, regulatory navigation, and market access. The project also seeks to create best practice models for engaging with NHS and global health system providers, leveraging the success of LSTM-led iiCON in promoting collaboration between academic institutions and business partners.

title: Hasta el 40% de la población convive con alergia ocular
hco: SOCIEDAD ESPAÑOLA DE SUPERFICIEOCULAR Y CORNEA
summary: Up to 40% of the population lives with ocular allergy, as highlighted at the 20th Annual Meeting of the Spanish Society of Ocular Surface and Cornea (SESOC) held in Madrid. This event, sponsored by Faes Farma, focused on the latest updates in allergic conjunctivitis, a disease with increasing prevalence affecting both children and adults, significantly impairing their quality of life and sometimes causing irreversible visual damage. Experts discussed the clinical management of allergic rhinoconjunctivitis, treatment guidelines, and the relationship between ocular allergy and dry eye syndrome. The symposium emphasized the need for a multidisciplinary approach to ocular allergy, considering the perspectives of both ophthalmologists and allergists. New treatment strategies aim to preserve the tear film and reduce dehydration of the eye, with a trend towards preservative-free formulations in eye drops to minimize side effects and improve compatibility with contact lenses.

title: Alerta por el aumento de las alergias oculares en España: esta es la causa
hco: SOCIEDAD ESPAÑOLA DE SUPERFICIEOCULAR Y CORNEA
summary: More than 30% of the Spanish population suffers from eye allergies, a significant increase mainly attributed to climate change and environmental pollution. This condition, which can manifest in various ways such as allergic conjunctivitis, negatively affects both health and the economy due to its impact on productivity and increased pharmaceutical spending. Experts emphasize the importance of seeking medical attention for symptoms for proper diagnosis and treatment, and warn against self-medication. They also highlight the need to allocate more resources for the detection and control of these allergies, which would result in health benefits and savings for the health system. Eye allergies are more common in urban environments and mainly affect adults of working age, though they also impact children.

title: An investigation has been opened into the death of a scientist who was studying a transmissible and deadly disease in Spain
summary: An investigation has been launched into the death of a Spanish researcher who was investigating Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, a contagious and deadly neurodegenerative condition. The University of Barcelona, the researcher's employer, found thousands of unauthorized and potentially infectious samples in his lab freezer. This led to an internal probe by the university, the Bellvitge Biomedical Research Institute (IDIBELL), and the CIBER public consortium to determine the samples' origins and the risk of exposure to colleagues. The researcher, a 45-year-old biochemist, had exhibited symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease before dying in 2022 and had sought privacy about his illness. This incident has sparked concerns over safety measures and the management of dangerous substances in research environments, prompting a wider review of lab practices.

title: La bronquiolitis es la enfermedad respiratoria que "más complica al sistema sanitario"
hco: SOCIEDAD CANARIA DE PEDIATRIADE SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE
summary: Bronchiolitis is recognized as the respiratory illness that significantly burdens the healthcare system, especially impacting the Canary Islands and Spanish populations this winter, including influenza and bronchiolitis among children. Luis Ortigosa, president of the Canary Society of Pediatrics, points out that 90% of these diseases are caused by viruses, with antipyretics often being the treatment of choice. Although SARS-CoV-2 continues to circulate, the widespread vaccination has effectively managed COVID-19, though children have a lower rate of vaccination. Respiratory illnesses, particularly those due to the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), are common in the colder seasons, with infants under six months facing a greater risk of severe bronchiolitis complications. The healthcare system is strained with an increase in primary care visits and hospital admissions. Moreover, streptococcus infections, usually mild and antibiotic-treatable, can exacerbate viral infections. Ortigosa discourages the unnecessary use of antibiotics and suggests seeking specialist advice if respiratory symptoms deteriorate.

title: “Los profesionales de Atención Primaria estamos trabajando muchas horas y la población siente que no se le está atendiendo bien”
hco: SOCIEDAD NAVARRA DE MEDICINADE FAMILIA Y ATENCION PRIMARIA
summary: Primary Care professionals are working many hours, leading to a perception among the population that they are not being adequately served. Pepa Redín, president of the Navarre Society of Family and Primary Care Medicine (namFYC), emphasizes the need for a change in the healthcare model to address the disconnect between increased workload and patient satisfaction. The demand for healthcare has significantly risen, prompting a reevaluation of how to manage less severe health issues differently. Redín advocates for providing accessible, official information to help people manage minor illnesses independently, allowing professionals to focus on more serious conditions and patients with multiple ailments. This approach requires a collaborative effort among politicians, managers, workers, associations, and citizens for successful implementation.

title: Arranca la campaña de vacunación de la gripe en la Comunitat Valenciana
hco: SOCIEDAD VALENCIANA DEMEDICINA PREVENTIVA Y SALUD PUBLICA
summary: The Valencian Community has started its flu vaccination campaign, planning to administer two million doses at 2683 vaccination points, including 417 nursing homes. The goal is to immunize more than 1,350,000 people in a joint campaign that will also offer COVID-19 vaccines to those who qualify. The campaign seeks to protect the most vulnerable populations, with specific vaccination coverage goals for people over 65, healthcare and social health workers, pregnant women, and people with risk conditions. Additionally, a weakened intranasal vaccine will be introduced for children between 2 and 4 years old, and eligibility for the flu vaccine will be expanded to people over 60 and healthy children under five. The recommended COVID-19 vaccine is an mRNA vaccine based on the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain, following the recommendations of the WHO and the European Medicines Agency.

title: "Uno de cada cuatro sanitarios que se vacuna contra la gripe no lo hace contra la Covid"
hco: SOCIEDAD VALENCIANA DEMEDICINA PREVENTIVA Y SALUD PUBLICA
summary: The Valencian Society of Preventive Medicine and Public Health has expressed its concern about the low vaccination rate against influenza and COVID-19 among healthcare professionals. According to data presented, only 30% of the workers at the General Hospital of Elche have been vaccinated against the flu, and an even smaller percentage has been vaccinated against COVID-19. In the Vinalopó area, the figure slightly increases but does not exceed 40%. Dr. Juan Francisco Navarro, president of the Society, highlighted that one in four healthcare workers vaccinated against the flu does not vaccinate against the coronavirus, showing significant resistance to COVID-19 vaccination among this group.

title: ¿Quitar ya la mascarilla del transporte público o esperar un poco?
hco: SOCIEDAD VALENCIANA DEMEDICINA PREVENTIVA Y SALUD PUBLICA
summary: The Valencian Society of Preventive Medicine and Public Health and immunology experts consider it premature to remove masks in public transport due to the high circulation of respiratory viruses and suggest waiting until spring. The Minister of Health, Carolina Darias, indicates that the decision will be based on the opinion of experts and the epidemiological situation, maintaining the mandatory use of masks in certain spaces. There is debate about protecting vulnerable people in transport and the importance of ventilation. Some experts suggest waiting until March for a possible removal of masks, coinciding with better weather and ventilation. The final decision will depend on the epidemiological evolution and the recommendations of international experts.

title: Tres nuevas organizaciones se suman a Ceoma para seguir luchando por los derechos de los mayores
summary: Three new organizations have joined the Spanish Confederation of Older Adults (Ceoma) to continue advocating for the rights of the elderly. These new members are the Cultural and Social Association of Police (Acuspol), the Spanish Confederation of Senior Citizens' Classrooms (Ceate), and the Civil Society for Health (Socisalud). Ceoma, now comprising 26 confederated organizations, aims to make older adults protagonists in society. Socisalud focuses on reflecting on the health situation in the Community of Madrid, Ceate promotes cultural and ongoing education for active aging, and Acuspol, founded 25 years ago, includes retired police officers and seniors interested in their cause. These additions strengthen Ceoma's mission to represent seniors' general interests, defend their rights, and encourage their social and political participation.

title: Ceoma convoca el XII Congreso Nacional de Organizaciones de Mayores en Vigo para abril de 2025
summary: Ceoma, the Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations, has scheduled the XII National Congress of Senior Organizations for April 24 and 25, 2025, in Vigo. This event will bring together entities and professionals dedicated to the needs and demands of older people, highlighting the importance of senior talent in society. The president of Ceoma, Sabina Camacho, emphasized the relevance of addressing senior talent, especially in the context of the organization's 25th anniversary. The congress will address topics such as active and healthy aging, good treatment of older people, promoting work beyond 50 years, digital humanism, and the challenges of climate change. Additionally, the 'Seniors in Action 2025' Award will be presented to individuals who continue to contribute to society beyond 65 years. With nearly 10 million people over 65 in Spain, representing 20% of the population, this congress seeks to highlight the significant role of this group in society.

title: 'XII Congreso de Organizaciones de Mayores' de CEOMA
summary: The Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (CEOMA) will host the 'XII National Congress of Senior Organizations' on April 24 and 25, 2025, in Vigo. The congress aims to focus on senior talent, highlighting its importance in both public and private sectors. CEOMA, established in 2000, is using its 25th anniversary as an opportunity to address this topic. The event will invite professionals and entities from the sector, as well as seniors in general, to discuss the needs and demands of the elderly population. It seeks to promote active and healthy aging, demand respectful treatment of the elderly, support employment beyond 50, encourage digital humanism, and address climate change challenges. CEOMA also plans to award the 'Seniors in Action 2025' prize to recognize individuals over 65 who continue to contribute to various sectors. Currently, Spain has nearly 10 million people over 65, accounting for 20% of its population, with this demographic expected to grow, emphasizing the significance of active aging.

title: Antonio Burgueño: España terminará siendo un país libre de sujeciones para las personas mayores
summary: Antonio Burgueño, technical director of the Desatar program, and the president of CEOMA, Sabina Camacho, highlighted the importance of the 20th anniversary of the 'Desatar al anciano y al enfermo de Alzheimer' program, which seeks to free elderly and Alzheimer's patients from physical and chemical restraints. Burgueño stated that Spain will become a country free of restraints for the elderly, highlighting the progress and adoption of the model by more than 200 residences. The program, which has faced initial opposition, has proven to be successful and sustainable, improving the quality of life and dignity of the elderly. CEOMA celebrates the achievements of the program, which has been recognized internationally, and commits to continue working to eliminate unnecessary restraints in the care of the elderly and those with dementia.

title: CEOMA y CONJUPE confían que el IMSERSO convoque cuanto antes las subvenciones del área de personas mayores
summary: CEOMA (Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations) and CONJUPE (National Confederation of Retirees and Pensioners of Spain) trust that the new general director of IMSERSO (Institute for Seniors and Social Services), Mayte Sancho, will call as soon as possible for the subsidies for the senior citizen area for the years 2023 and 2024. In 2023, IMSERSO did not announce the expected subsidy, putting 32 entities dedicated to the defense and interests of the elderly in a critical situation. These organizations, vital for the senior community in Spain, depend on these aids for their survival and the development of activities. The lack of funding threatens the closure of these organizations, directly affecting about nine million elderly people in the country.

title: Entidades de mayores piden al IMSERSO que convoque "cuanto antes" las subvenciones de 2023 y 2024
summary: Senior entities, specifically the Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (CEOMA) and the National Confederation of Retirees and Pensioners of Spain (CONJUPES), have requested the Institute for Seniors and Social Services (IMSERSO) to announce the subsidies for the years 2023 and 2024 "as soon as possible". This request is due to the critical situation of 32 entities working in defense of the interests of older people, because the subsidy planned for 2023 has not been announced. These non-profit organizations, which are essential for the well-being of older people in Spain, depend on these aids to continue their work. The lack of funding has put them in a vulnerable situation, risking having to cease their activities, which would directly affect about nine million older people.

title: CEOMA: Las personas mayores son protagonistas de la sociedad
summary: The Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (CEOMA) highlights the importance of older people in society, especially in the context of the 'International Day of Older Persons'. With around 901 million people over 60 years old in the world, CEOMA advocates for active policies to promote healthy and active aging, eliminating ageism. It proposes the implementation of alert protocols for climate emergencies and improvements in the quality of life of older people, including humanized care and dignified treatment. The need to advance policies that favor older women and combat discrimination is emphasized. Moreover, the importance of economic tranquility, digital literacy, housing, and friendly environments, and good treatment to prevent unwanted loneliness is underlined. CEOMA claims an active and committed role for older people in society.

title: El programa 'Desatar' logra que 210 residencias en España eliminen las sujeciones a pacientes con demencia
summary: The 'Desatar' program, initiated by the Spanish Confederation of Organizations for the Elderly (CEOMA), celebrates its 20th anniversary, marking a significant achievement in the care of dementia patients in Spain. This pioneering initiative has successfully led to the elimination of physical and pharmacological restraints in 210 nursing homes across the country. The program focuses on training staff, preventing behavioral problems, and transforming care facilities both spatially and organizationally to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. Despite the progress, the director of the program, Antonio Burgueño, acknowledges the need for further efforts to eradicate restraints completely, given the more than 4,500 residences in Spain. The program aims for a deeper understanding and transformation of care practices, emphasizing the importance of transparency and the publication of restraint data by nursing homes, similar to practices in the United States.

title: Esperanza Guisado, nueva presidenta de la Comisión de Comunicación e Imagen de Ceoma
summary: Esperanza Guisado has been appointed as the new president of the Communication and Social Image Commission of the Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (Ceoma). With over 30 years of experience in Public Affairs, Regulatory Communication Strategies, and knowledge of markets in LATAM, the EU, and APAC, Guisado brings a wealth of experience to the role. She has held vice presidencies at Pfizer and Grifols and was the founder and director of the Pfizer Foundation in Spain. Guisado is also involved in volunteer work for non-profit companies in Madrid and collaborates with various NGOs, adding value to the commission's project and initiative. The commission also includes journalist José Julián Barriga Bravo, Arturo San Román Ferreiro, and Ceoma members Eduardo Rodríguez Rovira and Celia Moreno Garrido.

title: XI Congreso Nacional de Organizaciones de Mayores de CEOMA
summary: The XI National Congress of Senior Organizations organized by the Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (CEOMA), in collaboration with the Barcelona City Council and the Institute for Seniors and Social Services (IMSERSO), is set to occur on April 20th and 21st, 2023. A preliminary informative meeting will be held on March 30th, which can be followed via streaming. This congress aims to highlight the concerns and priorities of the elderly, fostering a space for dialogue to continue shaping the future of this demographic, which represents almost 10 million people, over 20% of Spain's population. This figure is expected to rise with the aging of the Baby Boomers. The event will take place in two iconic venues in Barcelona and is open for registration until March 31st, 2023. CEOMA encourages participation from friends and professionals associated with the senior community.

title: Entidades de mayores piden a Imserso convocar subvenciones
summary: Senior citizen associations have urged the Imserso (Institute for the Elderly and Social Services) to promptly announce the subsidies for 2023 and 2024. The Spanish Confederation of Senior Organizations (CEOMA) and the National Confederation of Retirees and Pensioners of Spain (CONJUPES) have expressed their trust in the newly appointed General Director of Imserso, Mayte Sancho, to address the issue. In 2023, Imserso failed to announce the expected subsidies, putting 32 entities working for the interests of the elderly in a critical situation. The organizations, crucial for the senior citizens in Spain, depend on these funds to continue their activities. Both CEOMA and CONJUPES have highlighted the importance of these organizations in representing and advocating for the elderly, emphasizing the urgent need for a solution to ensure their survival and continued support for approximately nine million older adults.

title: 'A la vejez, vitales', el movimiento que nace para defender la salud de las personas mayores
summary: 'A la vejez, vitales' is a movement initiated by various senior citizen associations, scientific societies, media outlets, business organizations in care services, and professional colleges with the goal of collaborating with public institutions to design policies for active and healthy aging focused on preventive health measures. This initiative aims to represent over six million older adults in Spain, promoting policies for disease prevention, healthy diets, and vaccination against diseases prevalent in later life stages. The movement seeks to work with national and regional administrations to foster an active and healthy aging process and support public awareness campaigns. It is part of the Decade of Healthy Ageing 2021-2030, established by the United Nations, aiming to improve the lives of older adults, their families, and communities. The movement also focuses on combating ageism, advocating for specialized geriatric care in primary and hospital care, and establishing a unified vaccination schedule for older adults to eliminate access inequities.

title: Innovación e impacto social en el primer Research Fest de UIC Barcelona
summary: The first Research Fest at UIC Barcelona, organized by the Vice-Rectorate for Research, Innovation, and Knowledge Transfer, successfully gathered over 300 participants including researchers, doctoral students, and business sector representatives. The event highlighted the importance of research and innovation in creating societal impact. Keynote speaker Francesc Subirada emphasized the necessity of aligning innovation with research to achieve real societal benefits. The fest featured roundtable discussions on strategic research areas like health, comprehensive care, social innovation, and the socioeconomic impact of research, particularly in health and public-private collaborations. A "Present your thesis in 4 minutes" contest showcased doctoral research, with Mireia Bayna winning for her work on advanced care planning. The day also included scientific poster exhibitions, a science communication workshop, awards for the year's best research articles, and the ThankUDay event, acknowledging the support from various organizations. UIC Barcelona, known for its close ties to the business world and international focus, continues to contribute significantly to research and society.

title: UIC Barcelona, primera universidad española en obtener la acreditación internacional de la ADA
summary: UIC Barcelona has become the first Spanish university to receive accreditation from the ADA's Continuing Education Recognition Program (ADA CERP) for its dental continuing education programs. This accreditation recognizes institutions that offer high-quality continuing education to dental professionals, enabling them to renew their dental licenses in the United States and other countries that require it. The ADA CERP evaluates and accredits institutions based on strict criteria such as quality, transparency, scientific content, duration, and program practices. The American Dental Association, established in 1859, is the world's largest and oldest national dental association, with over 161,000 members. This accreditation underscores UIC Barcelona's dedication to high-quality education and its commitment to the dental profession both nationally and internationally. Additionally, the Faculty of Dentistry at UIC Barcelona has been acknowledged in global rankings for its excellence in teaching and research, including the ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2023 in Dentistry & Oral Sciences. Four faculty members have also been ranked among the top 2% of the world's most-cited researchers by Stanford University.

title: UIC Barcelona, primera universidad española en obtener la acreditación de la American Dental Association
summary: UIC Barcelona has become the first Spanish university to receive accreditation from the American Dental Association (ADA). This accreditation, from the ADA's Continuing Education Recognition Program (ADA CERP), recognizes UIC Barcelona's commitment to high-quality continuous dental education. This achievement enables professionals completing continuing education courses at UIC Barcelona's Faculty of Dentistry to renew their dental licenses and practice in the United States and other countries recognizing this accreditation. The ADA, a leading US professional dental association with over 161,000 members, promotes oral health and represents dental professionals worldwide. ADA CERP evaluates educational providers on quality, transparency, scientific content, duration, and strategic planning. UIC Barcelona's Faculty of Dentistry is noted for its teaching and research excellence, high national and international rankings, and faculty members among the world's top 2% most cited researchers. The university also focuses on internationalization through collaborations and dual degree programs with prestigious institutions.

title: La nueva cátedra de UIC busca soluciones para pacientes con gran pérdida de dientes y tejidos duros
summary: The UIC Barcelona Medicalfit Chair, created by the Faculty of Dentistry of UIC Barcelona and the company Medicalfit, seeks to innovate in solutions for the rehabilitation of patients with significant loss of teeth and hard tissues. Focusing on research in implantology and restorative digital workflows, as well as on the continuous training of professionals in oral and maxillofacial surgery, this initiative responds to a basic social need and a professional challenge. Under the direction of Dr. Miguel Roig, the chair integrates teams from Restorative Dentistry, Oral Surgery, and Bioengineering, with the goal of advancing in subperiosteal implants, guided tissue grafts, and precision in prosthodontic techniques. This interdisciplinary project aims to constantly improve clinical options for patients, highlighting the importance of innovating in technology and equipment without forgetting the classical foundations of dentistry.

title: Un año más, UIC Barcelona se sitúa en el top 10 de las universidades con más aprobados en el MIR
summary: UIC Barcelona has maintained its position among the top 10 Spanish universities with the highest rates of students passing the MIR exam. In the 2024 call, 100% of UIC Barcelona's medical graduates passed the MIR exam, with 12% ranking among the top 1,000 of the 11,755 medical professionals competing for 8,772 MIR positions. This achievement highlights the university's consistent high performance in this indicator, boasting an average success rate of 98.6% over the last ten years, the highest in Spain. The Dean of the Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Dr. Esther Calbo, attributes this success to the effort of students and the high demands of the teaching staff. UIC Barcelona's educational methodology focuses on comprehensive training and the development of transversal competencies, recognized internationally by the WFME accreditation. UIC Barcelona, founded in 1997, offers a variety of undergraduate and postgraduate programs and is committed to research and societal service, with three university clinics in its Sant Cugat Campus.

title: La Rioja trabaja de forma conjunta por la salud mental: estos son los últimos avances
summary: La Rioja is making progress in the field of mental health through a joint effort among various entities such as the Rioja Health Foundation, Primary Care, the Mental Health Association of La Rioja, the Hope Phone, and the University of La Rioja. These organizations are collaborating on the Mental Health Plan, coordinated by Carlos Piserra. Significant advances have been made, such as the reactivation of the ADHD protocol and the expansion of the resource map for the prevention and promotion of mental health. In addition, projects focused on child and youth mental health, geriatric mental health, and severe mental disorders have been initiated. The opening of the Hygea Mental Health Home in Logroño has been highlighted, allowing users to lead a normal life. Fighting stigma and preventing suicide are also focus areas, with the University of La Rioja working on programs for young people.

title: Juan Carlos Oliva, nuevo gerente de la Fundación Rioja Salud
summary: Juan Carlos Oliva has been appointed as the new manager of the Fundación Rioja Salud, replacing Sergio Martínez, the current socialist mayor of Torrecilla en Cameros. Oliva has previously served as the director of the Digital Agency in the Government of La Rioja and has strong ties to research and innovation. Additionally, Luis Pérez Echeguren has been named to lead the Economic Development Agency of La Rioja (ADER), taking over from Luis Alonso, who was elected as a councilor for the PSOE in the Logroño City Council. Pérez has over two decades of experience within ADER, contributing to the establishment and internationalization of many companies. The government aims to revitalize ADER, planning to refound and modify it to better serve the economic and business fabric of La Rioja and achieve its foundational objectives.

title: El robot Adamo de Fundación Rioja Salud recibe el reconocimiento a la originalidad tecnológica en Premios 'SaluDigital'
summary: The Adamo robot, developed by the Rioja Health Foundation, has been awarded for its technological originality at the SaluDigital Awards. This device is the world's first collaborative robot for physiotherapy, capable of treating musculoskeletal pathologies through the application of thermoregulable compressed air. Adamo's technology allows directing compressed air to specific treatment points, previously defined by health professionals, without direct contact with the patient's skin, thus reducing the risk of cross-contamination. A clinical trial conducted in 2021 by the Biomedical Research Center of La Rioja (CIBIR) and the Rehabilitation Service of the Public Health System of La Rioja proved Adamo's effectiveness in reducing nonspecific low back pain, showing that it is as effective as conventional treatments and especially beneficial in overweight patients.

title: La Rioja mejorará la calidad asistencial con cinco proyectos sobre IA y big data
summary: La Rioja will implement five projects focused on artificial intelligence (AI) and big data in its Public Health System, with a budget of over 750,000 euros and a 24-month execution period. These initiatives aim to improve care and assistance quality through technological revolution. The projects include the analysis of the interrelation between individuals, animals, and ecosystems (ONE HEALTH), the supervision and suggestion of preventive actions in multiple organizational areas (SMART HOSPITAL), the use of AI to classify retina images and detect pathologies (OPHTHALMOLOGICAL SCREENING), the development of personalized medicine through the analysis of genomic data (PERSONALIZED MEDICINE), and the creation of AI-based tools to identify patients with rare diseases (RARE DISEASES). These projects are part of an effort to integrate La Rioja's health data at both national and European levels, optimizing diagnoses and treatments.

title: Cinco soluciones de inteligencia artificial para la atención sanitaria
summary: RiojaSalud, the public health system of La Rioja, will implement five new artificial intelligence (AI) solutions to improve patient care, funded by European funds. These solutions include the development of a Health Big Data and the application of advanced analytics and AI to promote predictive medicine and improve efficiency in health management. The initiatives will allow the integration of health data from La Rioja into the National and European Health Data Space, improving diagnoses and treatments through technological innovation. These solutions are expected to positively impact the quality of care, contributing to personalized medicine and boosting research and health management. The project has a budget of over 750,000 euros and a timeline of 24 months.

title: Hallan en La Rioja un nuevo biomarcador para diagnosticar y predecir la supervivencia de pacientes de cáncer colorrectal
summary: A new biomarker for diagnosing and predicting the survival of colorectal cancer patients has been identified in La Rioja by a joint research team from the Biomedical Research Center of La Rioja (CIBIR), the San Pedro University Hospital, and the University of La Rioja. The discovery revolves around a molecule named MDL1AS, which is pivotal in diagnosing the disease and whose modulated expression could be key in developing innovative therapies against cancer. This finding, presented on March 26 in conjunction with World Colon Cancer Day, marks a significant advancement in personalized oncology medicine, offering the potential for more effective treatments with fewer side effects. Additionally, the molecule MDL1AS, part of the long non-coding RNAs group, has been found to differentiate between tumor and healthy cells in colorectal cancer and shows promise for diagnosing other cancers such as breast and laryngeal cancer. High levels of this molecule at diagnosis were associated with improved five-year survival rates in advanced rectal cancer patients, highlighting its prognostic potential. The research has been published in the Cancers journal, contributing to the fight against one of the most common tumors in La Rioja, where early detection significantly enhances treatment and recovery chances.

title: El CIBIR inicia el desarrollo de cuatro tratamientos contra el párkinson
summary: The Biomedical Research Center of La Rioja (CIBIR) is developing four research projects focused on finding new treatments for Parkinson's disease. These projects are led by Dr. Lydia Álvarez-Erviti and her team, who have obtained funding close to one million euros from various sources, including the Ministry of Science and Innovation, the Carlos III Health Institute, and the Michael J. Fox Foundation. One of the projects, funded by the Michael J. Fox Foundation, aims to confirm a new therapeutic target to stop the death of dopaminergic neurons, which could benefit patients in the early stages of the disease and in the long term. Additionally, CIBIR is working on developing a treatment to stop the neurodegenerative process, understand the role of neuroinflammation in the disease, identify new biomarkers and therapeutic targets, and develop a potential vaccine and gene therapy treatment.

title: El Hospital San Pedro da un salto de calidad con el centro de simulación clínica avanzada
summary: The San Pedro Hospital in Logroño has significantly improved its educational offerings with the opening of a new advanced clinical simulation center. This center, located in the Cibir building, is equipped with the latest technology to train resident doctors and students in various medical specialties such as pediatrics, ophthalmology, and gastroenterology. The total investment has exceeded 750,000 euros, funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), and includes both the adaptation of the facilities and the acquisition of advanced medical equipment and mannequins. This center will allow healthcare professionals to develop practical skills in a controlled and realistic environment, thus improving the quality of training. Additionally, this project will be complemented by the School of Nursing and the future Medicine studies, in collaboration with the University of La Rioja, thereby strengthening the educational and health ecosystem in the region.

title: La transformación asistencial en Farmacia Hospitalaria de La Paz mejora la comunicación y la farmacoterapia en ...
summary: The University Hospital La Paz in Madrid has been awarded the Quality Seal for Pharmacy Service in Multidisciplinary Information Management to the Oncology-Hematology Patient by the Medicine and Health Products Sciences Foundation (Fundamed), with the support of BeiGene and the endorsement of the Spanish Society of Hospital Pharmacy (SEFH). This recognition highlights excellence in the information provided to oncology-hematology patients, ensuring they receive correct, precise, and complete data during their treatment. The Hospital Pharmacy of La Paz has innovated its care model by integrating Oncology specialists and facilitating access to pharmacotherapy through a complete process of traceability of oncological medicines. This approach improves communication and treatment of patients, placing them at the center of the care process and promoting shared decision-making.

title: La ULE y Primaria ponen coto a la ‘epidemia’, que matará a más personas que el cáncer
summary: A pioneering investigation in Spain, involving the University of León (ULE), all primary care managements in Spain, and the Spanish Society of Primary Care Physicians (Semergen), aims to find alternatives to antibiotics to prevent bacteria from becoming resistant. The research focuses on reducing the overprescription of antibiotics, especially for respiratory infections, by determining the effectiveness of rapid bivalent antigen tests (for COVID-19 and flu) in primary care patients with signs or symptoms of respiratory infection. This national multicenter clinical trial involves a controlled group of 350 patients and a randomized group of the same size, selecting 20 health centers across Spain. The study addresses the public health issue of antibiotic resistance and aims to minimize inappropriate prescriptions. The broader goal is to enhance the efficiency of primary care services, thereby improving prevention, early diagnosis, and disease control, which is crucial for tackling the challenge of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

title: Semergen hace entrega de los “Premios 50 Años Contigo”
summary: Semergen, the Spanish Society of Primary Care Physicians, celebrated its 50th anniversary by awarding the "Semergen 50 Years With You" prizes in a ceremony attended by about 500 representatives from the health sector, pharmaceutical industry, politics, and culture. Since its inception in 1973, Semergen has been a benchmark in training and research in Primary Care, committed to enhancing the professional skills of family doctors in clinical, teaching, and research areas to maintain patient care quality. The awards were presented in four categories: Public Offices, Media, Pharmaceutical Industry, and Performing Arts, recognizing individuals and institutions that have supported family doctors and contributed to improving society's health and well-being. Recipients included Ana Pastor, former Minister of Health, and Rafael Bengoa, considered the father of the Basque Health Service, among others from the pharmaceutical sector and the arts. The event also highlighted ongoing challenges in primary care and honored family doctors for their dedication to patient health.

title: Semergen: 50 años de pasión por la Atención Primaria
summary: The Spanish Society of Primary Care Physicians (SEMERGEN) celebrated its 50th anniversary at the National Prado Museum in Madrid, bringing together about 500 representatives from the healthcare, pharmaceutical, political, and cultural sectors. Since its foundation in 1973, SEMERGEN has positioned itself as a benchmark in training and research in Primary Care, committing to the improvement of the professional skills of family doctors. At the event, the "SEMERGEN 50 Years With You Awards" were presented in different categories, recognizing individuals and institutions that have supported family medicine and contributed to social well-being. Among the awardees were Ana Pastor, Second Vice President of Congress and former Minister of Health, and Rafael Bengoa, Minister of Health and Consumer Affairs of the Basque Government. Additionally, the work of media outlets, the pharmaceutical industry, and figures from the performing arts for their support to Primary Care was recognized.

title: La Clínica Universidad de Navarra busca pacientes con Parkinson para ayudar en una investigación
summary: The University Clinic of Navarra is recruiting Parkinson's patients to participate in a research study that will evaluate the benefits of physical exercise in improving motor and cognitive symptoms. The research, which will last 16 weeks, is a collaborative project with the Public University of Navarra (UPNA)-Navarrabiomed and is funded by the Carlos III Health Institute. Participants will follow a training program designed by the UPNA-Navarrabiomed's E-FIT group, which will include two weekly sessions of physical exercise adapted to their individual needs. Dr. María Cruz Rodríguez Oroz, head of the Clinic's Neurology Department, leads the study, emphasizing the importance of investigating the effect of exercise on the motor and cognitive function of Parkinson's patients. Those interested can contact the organizers by email or phone.

title: La Clínica Universidad de Navarra celebra el Día del Niño Hospitalizado junto con la Fundación Real Madrid
summary: The University Clinic of Navarra and the Real Madrid Foundation celebrated Hospitalized Children's Day at the Madrid headquarters, offering a day of sports and joy to the children of Pediatric Oncology. Representatives of the Foundation played basketball with the patients, in line with their mission to use sport to educate in values and contribute to social development. This activity is part of the collaboration between the Foundation and the Children Against Cancer program, seeking to provide distraction to the children and their families during treatment. Pilar Lorenzo and Dr. Elena Panizo highlighted the importance of these initiatives to improve the mood and health of the children. The Real Madrid Foundation has been implementing basketball programs in hospitals for more than a decade, and the Clinic is the first private hospital to join this collaboration.

title: Valorcito visita a los niños ingresados en la Clínica Universidad de Navarra
summary: Valorcito, the basketball mascot of the Real Madrid Foundation, visited the University Clinic of Navarra on May 13, International Day of Hospitalized Children, to interact with children undergoing oncological treatment. This event marks the inclusion of the clinic in the hospital children's basketball program that the Foundation has been implementing for almost two decades in major hospitals in the Community of Madrid and other centers. The program, aimed at hospitalized minors for long stays due to oncological treatments or mental health issues, among others, seeks to alleviate their time in the hospital through sport and teaching values such as motivation and teamwork. Almost two thousand minors benefit annually from this program, which has been praised by health professionals for its positive impact on the recovery and well-being of the children. The University Clinic of Navarra, specialized in proton therapy for childhood cancer, hopes to benefit close to a hundred patients with this program.

title: La Clínica Universidad de Navarra reorganiza su departamento de Comunicación
summary: The University Clinic of Navarra has completed the reorganization of its Department of Communication and Reputation, now under the unified direction of Álvaro Sánchez León. This restructuring returns the department to the configuration it had until November 2022, with a single director of communication for both Clinic locations in Madrid and Pamplona. Álvaro Sánchez León, a journalist specialized in health, has been internally promoted to this position after having worked in various media and being the author of four books. The department is divided into four areas: Content, Internal Communication, Media, and Reputation and Institutional Relations, led respectively by Sánchez León, Enrique Cabrera, Miguel García San Emeterio, and María González Zabal, the latter recently joined from the University of Navarra. The mission of the department is to support the work of the hospital, focused on care, research, and teaching, sharing its advances with society.

title: La Clínica de Navarra crecerá un 9% por la mayor demanda
summary: The University of Navarra Clinic anticipates a 9% growth in its revenue, reaching 356 million euros in the fiscal year 2023-2024, ending in August, due to an increase in healthcare demand. This growth follows a 7% increase in its revenue in 2023, reaching 326 million euros. Additionally, the clinic's EBITDA is expected to increase by 4%, reaching 32 million euros.

title: La Clínica Universidad de Navarra presenta en Uruguay terapias de vanguardia
summary: The University of Navarra Clinic has presented in Uruguay advanced therapies to fight cancer during the event "Curing cancer forever" in Montevideo. This center, one of the top 80 hospitals in the world, serves an average of 440,000 patients annually, including 3,000 cancer patients, thanks to its Cancer Center, which is based on more than 40 years of experience in personalized medicine. During the presentation, they highlighted the importance of early detection and continuous monitoring of the disease. Doctor Jesús San Miguel, with an extensive career and more than 950 scientific publications, emphasized in his speech the centrality of the patient in cancer treatment, relying on science to transform society. In addition, the preparation of Uruguayan medical professionals and collaboration with public and private organizations in Uruguay were praised.

title: La CUN y el CIMA estudian el uso de probióticos para mejorar el metabolismo de los pacientes con porfiria
summary: The Clínica Universidad de Navarra and the CIMA Universidad de Navarra are conducting a pioneering study (PROPAI) on the use of oral probiotics and postbiotics in patients with acute intermittent porphyria, a rare disease. The goal is to improve imbalances in glucose metabolism that these patients suffer from, which can lead to insulin resistance, prediabetes, and diabetes. After observing positive effects in preclinical models with mice, researchers aim to translate these findings to humans. This study represents an advancement in the development of innovative precision therapies to treat hereditary diseases such as porphyria, affecting 320 people in Spain. Moreover, the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to the treatment of porphyria was highlighted, as well as initiatives to emotionally and socially support patients and their families, such as the first Workshop on emotion and art organized by the Clínica Universidad de Navarra, the CIMA, and the Spanish Association of Porphyria.

title: El gran avance de la Clínica Universidad de Navarra para tratar un cáncer muy agresivo
summary: The Clínica Universidad de Navarra has made significant progress in treating a highly aggressive form of cancer, primarily advanced or recurrent pelvic tumors, often originating from colorectal cancer. These tumors were previously deemed inoperable, leading to low survival rates and poor quality of life due to the lack of surgical options. Dr. Jorge Baixauli, a specialist in General Surgery at the Cancer Center Clínica Universidad de Navarra, underwent training at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney, Australia, to learn techniques for removing these tumors, including those affecting bone, nerve, or vascular structures. This advancement allows for the surgical treatment of cases previously considered inoperable, combining efforts with a multidisciplinary team to reduce the high complication rates associated with these aggressive surgeries. This approach has shown promising results, offering over half of the patients a five-year survival rate while maintaining a good quality of life.

title: Pacientes oncopediátricos de la CUN comparten una tarde en el Museo Universidad de Navarra gracias a CaixaBank
summary: Pediatric oncology patients from the Clínica Universidad de Navarra enjoyed an afternoon at the Museo Universidad de Navarra, thanks to the collaboration of CaixaBank. They participated in an art workshop and visited the exhibition "A Promised Land," where they explored the origin and development of photography and searched for 12 art pieces in a collection of 900 items. Inspired by the collection on Egypt, they drew pyramids that later became part of a mural in the Museum's workshops. This activity was positively valued for its impact on the children's well-being and treatment progress, as well as in supporting their families.

title: Estos son los puestos de trabajo que oferta Fundesalud en Extremadura
summary: Fundesalud, a foundation for the training and research of health professionals in Extremadura, Spain, is offering four job positions for project technicians at its Mérida and Cáceres locations. The available positions include one R&D&I project technician for Clinical Trial Pharmacists, two R&D&I project technicians for Research Nurses (one in Cáceres and one in Mérida), and one R&D&I project technician for a Communication Specialist in Mérida. The contract types and salaries vary, with the Research Nurse in Mérida receiving a permanent contract and a salary of €22,997 for the Patient Safety Unit, while the Clinical Trial Pharmacist position offers a permanent contract with a salary of €25,312 annually. The Communication Specialist position also offers a permanent contract with a salary ranging between €22,997.37 and €25,312.58, depending on qualifications. The job announcement was published on May 6, 2024, in the Official Gazette of Extremadura, and applications are accepted through the Fundesalud website.

title: FundeSalud convoca una oferta de trabajo de técnico/a de proyectos de I+D+i para el Hospital Universitario de Badajoz
summary: FundeSalud has announced a job opening for a Research and Development (R&D) projects technician at the Pharmacogenetics Unit of the Hospital Universitario de Badajoz. The position requires applicants to have a Nursing degree plus an official Master's in Clinical Trials or Bioethics, at least 6 months of experience in Clinical Services, and a B2 level in English. Interested candidates must submit their applications through FundeSalud's website by March 21, 2024.

title: Fundesalud contará con 56.000 euros para el desarrollo del proyecto de I+D Care4diabetes
summary: Fundesalud, based in Extremadura, Spain, has been granted €56,190 for the development of the Care4Diabetes project, aimed at combating type 2 diabetes through lifestyle improvement programs. This initiative falls under the EU4HEALTH Program, reflecting the EU's commitment to enhancing public health and reducing disease risk factors. Extremadura, where 84,000 individuals suffer from diabetes (90% being type 2), will benefit from this project. The region also faces a high risk of increased diabetes cases due to unhealthy lifestyles. The project's goal is to promote healthy living habits to prevent or manage type 2 diabetes effectively. The importance of this initiative is underscored by the annual World Diabetes Day on November 14, which raises awareness about diabetes prevention and management.

title: Reunión de trabajo entre la alcaldesa de Villanueva y el director gerenete de Fundesalud
summary: On April 19, 2024, Ana Belén Fernández González, the mayor of Villanueva, met with José Luis González Sánchez, the managing director of FundeSalud. This meeting was part of the institutional relationships, specifically between the City Council and FundeSalud, a foundation linked to the SES that focuses on the training and research of health professionals in Extremadura. They discussed various health-related issues, notably the research unit in Villanueva by the Multidisciplinary Research Group of Extremadura (Grimex) supported by FundeSalud since 2007. Grimex, also part of INUBE, collaborates with researchers from the University of Extremadura and SES. Over the years, it has analyzed the medical conditions of over 12,000 cardiac patients and more than 3,000 healthy individuals through the Hermex project, worked internationally, hosted Erasmus students, and directed over 15 doctoral theses.

title: El SES organiza un homenaje a sus profesionales jubilados y fallecidos durante 2023
summary: The Ministry of Health and Social Services of the Junta de Extremadura, along with the Extremaduran Health Service (SES) and FUNDESALUD, will organize a tribute on April 30 to honor the SES professionals who retired or passed away in 2023. This event will include all professionals, from healthcare staff to services and administration, recognizing their dedication and commitment to the health and well-being of the Extremaduran community. The act will serve as a space to reflect on their legacy and for attendees to share memories and express their gratitude. The Ministry encourages participation in this act of recognition.

title: “El relevo generacional es delicado. Se jubilan más investigadores que nuevos comienzan”
summary: María Isabel Cotilla, head of department at FundeSalud, highlights the delicate situation of generational turnover in research, with more researchers retiring than new ones starting. Since joining in 2013, she has led the drive for clinical studies in Extremadura, noting an increase in female participation in clinical research, though she emphasizes the need for more support. FundeSalud, where she works, promotes research and innovation in health, offering resources for biomedical and health research. In the last 10 years, she has seen growth in the number of clinical studies, especially in oncology, cardiology, and other areas, highlighting the EMBER and CAMBRIA breast cancer trials, which seek to reduce the likelihood of relapse in high-risk patients.

title: Extremadura se suma al proyecto europeo EU-JAMRAI-2 que aborda la respuesta unificada de Europa a la resistencia ...
summary: Extremadura has joined the EU-JAMRAI-2 project, a European initiative addressing the unified response to antimicrobial resistance. The project, coordinated by France's National Institute of Health and Medical Research (INSERM) with the French Ministry of Health's support, involves 128 entities from 31 countries and has a budget of 62.5 million euros. The Extremaduran Health Service (SES) and FundeSalud, along with 18 other Spanish entities, are participating under the leadership of the Spanish Agency for Medicines and Health Products (AEMPS). The project's goal is to effectively share resistance to antimicrobials to continue protecting against pathogenic microorganism infections. Antimicrobial resistance poses a significant public health threat, causing 1.3 million deaths worldwide. Extremadura's role focuses on controlling and monitoring antimicrobial use in humans, animals, and the environment. The project aims to foster international cooperation, experience exchange, and establish antimicrobial surveillance strategies. Following the success of the original EU-JAMRAI project (2017-2021), EU-JAMRAI-2 promotes a comprehensive "One Health" work program involving EU member states, Iceland, Norway, Ukraine, and several European and global organizations to ensure project coherence with existing initiatives.

title: Quince mujeres mejoran sus secuelas del cáncer de mama iniciándose en el tiro con arco en Huelva
hco: FUNDACION ANDALUZA BETURIA PARA LAINVESTIGACION EN SALUD
summary: Fifteen women in Huelva have begun improving the aftereffects of breast cancer through archery, thanks to a project funded by the Fundación Atlantic Copper in collaboration with the Club Asirio de Tiro con Arco de Huelva and the Fundación Andaluza Beturia para la Investigación en Salud (FABIS). This initiative, which also involves the Unidad de Oncología Hospital Universitario Juan Ramón Jiménez and the Asociación Onubense de Cáncer de Mama ‘Santa Águeda’, aims to enhance the quality of life of oncological patients by offering an 11-month beginners' course in archery under supervision. The program reflects a commitment to aiding cancer recovery through engaging sports and is open to new participants, with the potential benefits including the prevention or reduction of lymphedema following mastectomy. Plans are also underway to form a competitive archery team for women who have undergone breast cancer surgery to participate in the Spanish Archery Championship.

title: La Asociación contra el Cáncer de Higuera de la Sierra dona 3.000 euros para la investigación de la enfermedad
hco: FUNDACION ANDALUZA BETURIA PARA LAINVESTIGACION EN SALUD
summary: The Virgen del Prado Cancer Association of Higuera de la Sierra has donated 3,000 euros to the Andalusian Foundation Beturia for Health Research (Fabis) to support biomedical research in cancer and improve the quality of life of oncological patients at the Riotinto Hospital. The donation was raised through charitable activities organized by the association, which is dedicated to fighting cancer and supporting those affected. Fabis, created by the Junta de Andalucía in 2005, promotes research in Health Sciences in the province of Huelva. The Riotinto Hospital offers comprehensive oncological care to its area of influence, thanks to the collaboration with the Juan Ramón Jiménez University Hospital.

title: La Sociedad Valenciana de Reumatología beca tres proyectos sobre espondilitis anquilosante, artritis reumatoide y ...
summary: The Valencian Society of Rheumatology, through its Foundation, has awarded scholarships to three research projects focused on ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis in psoriatic arthritis. One of the studies investigates the alterations in the sexual sphere of patients with ankylosing spondylitis, another focuses on osteoporosis in patients with psoriatic arthritis, evaluating risk factors and their association with disease activity, and the third examines how the practice of yoga can improve functionality and pain in patients with rheumatoid arthritis in remission. In addition, the Society has provided support for three rheumatologists to perform external rotations in medical centers in Spain and Germany, strengthening their training and preparation in the treatment and diagnosis of rheumatic diseases.

title: Nicole Hass: "Las mujeres a menudo son voces activas en la defensa de los derechos de los pacientes"
summary: Women are increasingly active in defending patient rights, especially within patient associations, where they not only participate as members but also, in some cases, hold leadership positions. This involvement is crucial for highlighting diseases that predominantly affect women, such as breast cancer and COPD, the latter seeing a rise in female patients due to factors like smoking habits and genetic predispositions. Nicole Hass, a spokesperson for the COPD Patient Association, emphasizes the importance of raising awareness about COPD's prevalence in women to avoid diagnostic delays, noting that symptoms in women may differ or be milder than in men. Despite their active roles, women still face challenges in achieving leadership positions within these associations, highlighting the need for greater recognition of their contributions to patient advocacy and health rights.

title: Cataluña, única región que limita un tratamiento para la EPOC con sanciones a sus médicos
summary: Catalonia is the only region in Spain that limits the prescription of triple therapy treatment for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), imposing economic sanctions on doctors who exceed a 20% cap of new prescriptions for this treatment. This measure, criticized by the COPD Patients Association (Apepoc), is attributed to economic reasons. Doctors and hospitals that exceed the established limit face financial penalties, which has generated concern among professionals and patients. Catalonia also stands out for having a high prevalence and underdiagnosis of COPD compared to the national average. The autonomous community is also notable for requiring Catalan as a requirement to practice medicine.

title: El diagnóstico temprano y acceso al tratamiento, reivindicaciones clave del Día Europeo del Alfa-1, el 25 de a
summary: April 25 is celebrated as European Alpha-1 Awareness Day, focused on claims such as early diagnosis and access to treatment for those affected by Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD), a genetic condition that causes serious respiratory and liver diseases. The Alpha-1 Association Spain, with the support of Grifols and CSL Behring, organizes informational tables in hospitals throughout Spain to promote awareness of this rare disease, emphasizing the importance of plasma donation, essential for the existing treatment. It is estimated that in Spain, of the 14,500 affected by the severe form of Alpha-1, the majority are not diagnosed. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin protein augmentation therapy, obtained from plasma, is the only treatment for the related lung disease, and 900 donations are needed to maintain a patient for a year. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic highlighted Spain's dependence on foreign plasma, mainly from the United States, and the need to improve plasma collection and increase awareness of donations.

title: Nos acercamos a más de 20 entidades de nuestro movimiento asociativo | FEDER
summary: Throughout 2023, FEDER has been engaging with its associative movement, aiming to foster closeness and communication with the 418 member associations through face-to-face meetings at their locations. This initiative, part of the "acercándonos" project, seeks to increase FEDER's proximity to its associative movement, acknowledge its mission, and understand the movement's priorities. The goal is to share experiences and challenges across Spain, particularly those faced by individuals with rare diseases, to enhance collaboration and cohesion within the movement at both regional and national levels. FEDER has met with over 20 entities, including Fundación Querer, Asociación Alfa 1 de España, and many others, focusing on various diseases and conditions, to better understand and address the needs and opportunities of the rare disease community.

title: Zamora acoge el Encuentro Nacional de Pacientes con Déficit de Alfa-1: una celebración de 25 años de lucha y esperanza
summary: Zamora hosts the National Meeting of Patients with Alpha-1 Deficiency, marking 25 years of efforts and hope in the fight against this rare genetic disease. From April 19 to 21, the city will gather patients, family members, and healthcare professionals from all over Spain to exchange experiences and knowledge. The event will include lectures by experts, mindfulness and nutrition sessions, and healthy walks. This meeting, organized by the Alfa-1 Spain Association, coincides with European Alpha-1 Awareness Day, focusing on awareness of the disease, the importance of early diagnosis, and equitable access to treatment. It is estimated that in Spain, 14,500 people could have the severe variant of Alpha-1, but only a fraction are diagnosed. The association, which represents more than 600 affected individuals and collaborators, appreciates the support of companies like Grifols, CSL Behring, and Vitalaire, essential for improving the quality of life of patients.

title: El congreso acoge la exposición fotográfica 'El lupus se revela'
summary: AstraZeneca and the Spanish Federation of Lupus (FELUPUS) launched the "Lupus Reveals Itself. Rebel against lupus, take control of the disease" campaign at the Congress of Deputies on May 14th, coinciding with World Lupus Day. Declared of social interest by the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER), the campaign aims to improve awareness about lupus, its impact on patients' lives, and the importance of proactive disease management. The initiative features a photographic project by Ana Nance, showcasing the daily challenges faced by lupus patients. The Congress hosted an exhibition from May 14th to 17th, highlighting the realities of living with this chronic autoimmune disease, which affects over 82,000 people in Spain. The event also included an institutional act addressing the unmet needs of lupus patients, emphasizing the need for innovation, research, better therapies, and a comprehensive health system approach to improve patients' quality of life.

title: Felupus lanza la campaña 'El Lupus se Revela' para mostrar el impacto de la enfermedad a través de la fotografía
summary: Felupus, part of COCEMFE, in collaboration with AstraZeneca and for World Lupus Day, has launched the campaign 'Lupus Reveals Itself, Rebel Against Lupus, Take Control of the Disease'. This photographic project, recognized as socially significant by the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER), aims to depict the daily life challenges and limitations faced by individuals with lupus through the lens of photographer Ana Nance. It emphasizes the importance of active participation by those with lupus in managing their condition to prevent flare-ups. Silvia Pérez Ortega, president of FELUPUS, highlights the campaign's role in raising societal awareness about lupus, a frequently occurring autoimmune disease that remains largely unknown to the public. She stresses the variability of symptoms and the difficulties in daily activities experienced by those with lupus. An exhibition at the Congress of Deputies from May 14 to 18 and an Instagram filter aim to further increase awareness. The campaign is part of the 'Don't Let Lupus Win' initiative, using art to bring attention to the condition and the needs of those affected.

title: La Asamblea de Extremadura, en apoyo de necesidades no cubiertas en lupus | @diariofarma
summary: The Assembly of Extremadura has unanimously ratified a declaration in support of the unmet needs of people with lupus, coinciding with the formation of the Lupus Association of Extremadura (Adelex), which joins the Spanish Federation of Lupus. This action is part of the initiative 'Do not let lupus win: It's time to act!', co-organized with AstraZeneca, which seeks to address the main medical and socioeconomic needs of those affected by this chronic autoimmune disease. The declaration promotes early diagnosis, a multidisciplinary therapeutic approach, and better access to therapies. It also highlights the importance of research, training in primary care, and socioeconomic measures such as the review of disability assessment and funding for sunscreen. Lupus affects more than 82,000 people in Spain, mostly young women, and its diagnosis can be delayed for up to six years.

title: Astrazeneca y Felupus se unen para mejorar el abordaje del lupus
summary: AstraZeneca and Felupus have launched a campaign titled "Do not let lupus win. Release hope" to improve the approach to lupus, declared of social interest by the Spanish Society of Rheumatology. The campaign aims to raise awareness about lupus, an autoimmune disease affecting over 82,000 people in Spain and 5 million worldwide, with 90% being women aged 15 to 44. Despite being one of the most common autoimmune diseases, 60% of Spaniards are unaware of lupus and its high mortality rate. The initiative highlights the need for early diagnosis, coordinated and multidisciplinary care, and access to new therapies for all patients. It emphasizes the importance of joint efforts among patients, industry, and administration to improve diagnosis and treatment, addressing the disease's varied manifestations and symptoms that often delay diagnosis. The campaign symbolically uses the burning of a wolf sculpture to represent the body attacking itself in lupus patients, with the emergence of a sculpture of a girl symbolizing hope for a better future.

title: AstraZeneca y FELUPUS buscan visibilizar el lupus "liberando la esperanza"
summary: AstraZeneca and FELUPUS have launched the campaign "Don't Let Lupus Win. Unleash Hope" to raise awareness about lupus, coinciding with World Lupus Day on May 10. The campaign aims to increase visibility for lupus, a systemic autoimmune disease affecting about 90,000 patients in Spain, yet only known by 40% of the population. Lupus predominantly affects women, often diagnosed during their reproductive years, impacting their reproductive situation and quality of life, including physical appearance due to swelling or skin lesions. The disease's varied symptoms can delay diagnosis, significantly affecting patients' lives. The campaign, presented in Madrid's Plaza de las Cortes, uses art to symbolize the struggle against lupus, featuring the burning of a wolf sculpture, representing the disease, and revealing a sculpture of a girl symbolizing hope. The event highlighted the need for advancements in early diagnosis, research, and the development of new therapies, addressed through a multidisciplinary approach. Rosa Romero, president of the Health Commission in Congress, emphasized the importance of national disease registration, early diagnosis, primary care reinforcement, and investment in research to make therapies accessible to all patients, highlighting the need for lupus to be included in political agendas.

title: Tres campañas por el Día Mundial del Lupus, tres pasos más hacia su concienciación
summary: On the occasion of World Lupus Day, the Spanish Lupus Federation (FELUPUS), in collaboration with AstraZeneca, has launched a campaign titled "Lupus Reveals Itself", along with two other awareness initiatives in partnership with the Spanish Society of Rheumatology, GSK, and the pharmaceutical company Otsuka. These campaigns seek to increase the visibility of this chronic autoimmune disease, which mainly affects women between 15 and 44 years old, and is characterized by an excess of antibodies that cause inflammation and damage in organs and tissues. The "Lupus Reveals Itself" campaign uses art to show the emotional impact of the disease, while Otsuka's initiative focuses on lupus nephritis, promoting medical training and multidisciplinary coordination among professionals. Additionally, the importance of photoprotection is highlighted due to the harmful effects of the sun on lupus patients.

title: Albacete acoge el XXI Congreso Nacional de Lupus
summary: Albacete hosts the 21st National Lupus Congress at the University Auditorium this weekend, focusing on lupus, an autoimmune disease where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues. This event aims to be a meeting point for health professionals, patients, associations, relatives, and caregivers to share advancements in treatments and chronic management strategies. Lupus requires a multidisciplinary approach, involving specialties like Internal Medicine, Rheumatology, Hematology, Neurology, Dermatology, Cardiology, and Nephrology. The congress features nurses and specialist doctors from various fields and regions. It is organized by the Lupus and Autoimmune Association of Castilla la Mancha (ALMAN) and the Spanish Federation of Lupus (FELUPUS). Key lupus facts include its prevalence among women, the severity of nephritis as a complication, the importance of early diagnosis and treatment, the association with other autoimmune diseases, and the existence of four clinical forms of lupus. The text also highlights the importance of clinical evaluation, the rarity of complete remission, and the fundamental role of hydroxychloroquine in treatment.

title: Lupus: los pacientes reivindican detección precoz y el abordaje multidisciplinar | @diariofarma
summary: Lupus patients advocate for early detection and a multidisciplinary approach in the campaign "Don't Let Lupus Win. Release Hope," launched by AstraZeneca and Felupus for World Lupus Day. Declared of social interest by the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER), the campaign aims to raise awareness of lupus, fight misunderstanding, and highlight the needs and hopes of those affected. A manifesto presented in Madrid calls for early diagnosis, better primary care training, coordinated multidisciplinary care, and access to new therapies. Lupus, affecting over 82,000 in Spain and 5 million worldwide, predominantly impacts women aged 15-44. Diagnosis often takes up to six years due to the disease's varied symptoms. The campaign emphasizes the importance of visibility and improved patient care through art, symbolized by the burning of a wolf sculpture, representing the disease's self-attack mechanism, and the unveiling of a hopeful girl sculpture.

title: Reumatólogos, pacientes y GSK presentan el cortometraje “Hay un lobo entre nosotros” para contar la realidad del lupus
summary: Rheumatologists, patients, and GSK have presented the short film "There's a Wolf Among Us" to illustrate the reality of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a chronic autoimmune disease that affects approximately 96,000 people in Spain and for which there is no cure. This short film aims to make the disease visible, raise awareness about the importance of early approach, and offer support to patients. The initiative has the support of the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER) and the Spanish Federation of Lupus Patients (FELUPUS).
