It is highlighted that early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term organic damage, such as lupus nephritis, one of the most serious complications. Furthermore, it is mentioned that the COVID-19 pandemic has prevented some patients from receiving optimal care, increasing the risk of organic damage. The campaign also includes a website with information and testimonials about lupus, and awareness-raising activities will be carried out in Seville during the SER National Congress.

title: No dejes que el lupus gane y libera la esperanza
summary: The text discusses the importance of World Lupus Day, celebrated on May 10th, under the theme "Don't let lupus win and release hope." This day, organized by patient associations worldwide, aims to raise awareness and educate both the public and healthcare professionals about lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease that affects over five million people globally, 90% of whom are women. Despite its high prevalence, about 60% of Spaniards are unaware of what lupus is or only know its name, making it an "invisible" disease. In Spain, approximately 40,000 people live with lupus, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more common and severe among women aged 15 to 44. The disease can significantly impact various organs and systems, with skin, bones, kidneys, digestive system, eyes, and the central nervous system being the most affected. Currently, there is no cure or effective treatment to prevent long-term organ damage caused by lupus, which can lead to increased disability and potentially be life-threatening. The World Lupus Federation emphasizes the importance of early detection, coordinated care, more research, access to new therapies, and addressing non-medical and socioeconomic needs of patients. The campaign encourages sharing experiences to combat the misunderstanding and loneliness often associated with lupus.

title: Cuáles son los síntomas del linfoma: cada año aparecen en España 10.000 nuevos casos
summary: In Spain, more than 10,000 cases of lymphoma are registered annually, a type of cancer that affects the cells of the lymphatic system responsible for fighting infections. The Spanish Association of People Affected by Lymphoma, Myeloma, and Leukemia (AEAL) has launched the 'It Could Be Lymphoma' campaign to promote early detection of this disease. There are two main types of lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma, less common, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the most frequent. In 2023, 1,539 cases of Hodgkin's lymphoma and 9,943 cases of non-Hodgkin's lymphomas are estimated in Spain. Symptoms can vary, but the most common is the presence of a painless lump in the neck, armpit, or groin. Other symptoms include night sweats, fever, itching, swelling of lymph nodes, involuntary weight loss, cough, difficulty breathing, abdominal swelling, fatigue, and anemia. The campaign seeks to increase awareness about lymphomas, their symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment options.

title: La atención integral, clave en el abordaje del cáncer de ovario
hco: ASOCIACION DE AFECTADOS DECANCER DE OVARIO – ASACO
summary: The MSD-AstraZeneca Alliance and Asaco highlight the importance of comprehensive care for ovarian cancer patients, emphasizing awareness of the patients' priority needs. It is estimated that in 2023 there will be 3,600 new diagnoses of ovarian cancer in Spain, with a prevalence of 27,585 cases and 2,036 deaths. The disease, which is often detected in late stages, requires a multidisciplinary approach and comprehensive support throughout the treatment. The need to improve the visibility of this pathology, promote dialogue between healthcare professionals and patients, and provide emotional support, including the figure of the psycho-oncologist from the diagnosis, is underlined. Advances in the knowledge of the molecular biology of ovarian cancer allow for precision medicine, although the diagnosis remains complex due to the nonspecificity and delay of symptoms.

title: Salida de la andaina de la Asociación Española contra el Cáncer en el Obelisco
summary: The Spanish Association Against Cancer organized the 11th edition of the charity walk "A Coruña on the move against cancer," starting at the Obelisk in A Coruña.

title: El Ayuntamiento de Quintanar de la Orden firma un Convenio junto a la Asociación Española contra el Cáncer en ...
summary: The Quintanar de la Orden City Council has signed an agreement with the Spanish Association Against Cancer in Toledo to create "Smoke-free zones" in the town, with the goal of reducing tobacco consumption in public spaces and promoting public health. During the meeting prior to the signing, the experiences of the local association were discussed, and the growing incidence of cancer in Spain was highlighted. The agreement includes the implementation of smoke-free spaces in areas such as parks, sports facilities, and bus stations. In addition, the improvements that the agreement will bring in terms of psychological, physiotherapeutic, economic, and social support for those affected by cancer were addressed. Mayor Pablo Nieto Toldos reaffirmed the city council's commitment to the fight against cancer and thanked the association for its collaboration.

title: El teléfono de la Asociación Española contra el Cáncer, el único de Europa que atiende llamadas 24 horas durante todo el año
summary: The Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC) has launched a campaign for its continuous telephone support service, 900 100 036, which is unique in Europe for being available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, and is free of charge. This service is notable for being the second in the world with this availability for people with cancer and their families, offering a gateway to professional care throughout Spain. The campaign seeks to raise awareness of this phone number and has been developed with real experiences from patients and technicians. The service addresses a variety of concerns, from how to communicate the disease to children to questions about treatment and support. The AECC also offers psychological support, medical advice, employment guidance, and free accompaniment. In addition, legal-labor questions for working-age patients, who represent 38% of those diagnosed in Spain in 2023, are addressed. This service is part of the AECC's strategies to achieve a 70% cancer survival rate by 2023, aiming to support those affected and their families in all the needs that arise during the illness.

title: El evento benéfico contra el cáncer de Benicàssim, en fotos
summary: The charity event against cancer in Benicàssim was a success, filling Plaza Constitución with a spirit of solidarity on Sunday afternoon. Organized by local resident Sara Fortea, the makeup event aimed to raise funds for the Spanish Association Against Cancer.

title: El Real Madrid se suma a la cuestación de la Asociación Española Contra el Cáncer
summary: Real Madrid joins the annual fundraising campaign of the Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC) held on May 9, 2024, to support research and the fight against this disease. Donations can be made through a digital piggy bank or bank transfer to Banco Santander, specifying "MESA REAL MADRID C. F." in the concept. The funds raised will be allocated to finance the programs developed by the AECC.

title: Un teléfono para responder al cáncer
summary: The Spanish Association Against Cancer has launched a campaign to raise awareness of their 24/7 support hotline (900 100 036) for cancer patients and their families, providing answers to various concerns related to the disease. This unique service in Europe, second only to the American Cancer Society's hotline, offers personalized support, including psychological, medical, and legal advice. The campaign highlights real-life inquiries from callers, emphasizing the importance of human connection over artificial intelligence in providing comfort and assistance. With an average of 550 daily calls, the service aims to address the emotional, social, and practical challenges faced by those affected by cancer. Additionally, the hotline also addresses employment-related questions, reflecting the significant impact of cancer on the working-age population in Spain.

title: La Asociación contra el Cáncer celebra dos charlas de prevención
summary: The Spanish Association Against Cancer, in collaboration with the Department of Social Welfare of the Municipality of Bueu, organizes two talks on cancer prevention. The first talk will focus on healthy lifestyle habits and will take place next Tuesday, the 21st, at 5 p.m. The second talk, scheduled for Tuesday, June 11, will address the issue of smoking. Both will be held in the multipurpose classroom of the Social Center of the Sea and will be given by Lola Andújar, a prevention technician of the Association. Admission to the talks will be free.

title: Este jueves 9 de mayo se celebra la cuestación de la Asociación Española contra el Cáncer (AECC)
summary: On May 9, the Spanish Association against Cancer (AECC) of Ciudad Real organizes its traditional Fundraising Day, an annual fundraising event under the motto 'All against cancer'. During this day, patients, volunteers, members, and the general public come together to ask for collaboration with the aim of continuing to offer free services, support cancer research, and achieve a survival goal of 70% by the year 2030.

title: Bressanello (AECC): "El cáncer es la enfermedad más temida"
summary: Patrizia Bressanello, from the Spanish Association Against Cancer (AECC), discussed the organization's 24-hour national telephone support service on RTVE's "Las mañanas de RNE" program. This year, Spain will see 286,000 new cancer cases, with an increasing number of young people being diagnosed. The AECC's campaign aims to offer continuous support, including psychological support, medical advice, social care, and volunteer companionship, to anyone in need. Bressanello emphasized the profound social fear of cancer and the challenging emotional process for both patients and their families. The service, staffed by 31 specially trained individuals, seeks to provide genuine well-being for callers. The contact number is 900 100 036.

title: La III Carrera de la Asociación Española contra el Cáncer se celebrará en Algeciras el 2 de junio
summary: The III Race of the Spanish Association against Cancer will be held in Algeciras on June 2. This charitable and non-competitive event, mainly sponsored by the Cepsa Foundation, will start at 10:00 in the parking lot of the Alcultura Association. The route includes several streets of the city, with both the start and finish at the same point. Bibs can be purchased at El Corte Inglés in Bahía de Algeciras or at the headquarters of the Association, with a cost of 10€ for adults and 5€ for children under 12 years old. The first 500 registered will receive a commemorative T-shirt. The funds raised will be entirely allocated to the programs and activities of the association in Algeciras, including psychosocial support to cancer patients and their families, prevention, and research. The Spanish Association Against Cancer, with 70 years of history, is the leading entity in Spain in the fight against cancer, dedicating efforts to prevention, support, and funding of oncological research projects.

title: Varios sanitarios europeos visitaron la Asociación contra el Cáncer de Segovia
summary: European healthcare professionals, participants of the HOPE exchange program, visited the Spanish Association Against Cancer in Segovia. The group included Bruno de Sousa Martins from Portugal, Milena Ziviv from Serbia, Alberto Fodale from Italy, and Julio César Santos Pastor from Segovia. They were introduced to the association's philosophy, strategic objectives, and services provided to cancer patients and their families. The association aims for a 70% survival rate by 2030 and to extend its services to more individuals. In 2023, the association served 968 people in 5,383 sessions across Segovia. There were 669 new cancer diagnoses per 100,000 inhabitants in the province, with prostate and breast cancer being the most common. The visitors expressed interest in the association's initiatives and the free services offered, highlighting the collaboration with the General Hospital of Segovia and expressing a desire to implement similar collaborations in their respective hospitals.

title: Avanzando hacia un modelo óptimo de cuidados a personas con el VIH - gTt
hco: GRUPO DE TRABAJO SOBRE TTO DEL VIH
summary: In Spain, a new model of comprehensive HIV care focused on the individual is being promoted in response to the challenges posed by the chronic nature of the infection. This model aims to overcome the current fragmentation of the care system, which limits equitable access to health services and varies depending on the patient's residence. Advances in HIV treatment have increased the life expectancy of patients, but have also led to an increase in age-related health conditions, affecting their well-being and quality of life. The model, supported by GeSIDA, SEISIDA, and ViiV Healthcare, proposes personalized care based on seven patient profiles, focusing on their specific needs and promoting better coordination among health professionals. This multidisciplinary and patient-centered approach seeks to improve the efficiency and sustainability of the health system, recognizing the importance of listening to and engaging patients in managing their health.

title: Una técnica de edición genética para eliminar el VIH se muestra exitosa en ratones - gTt
hco: GRUPO DE TRABAJO SOBRE TTO DEL VIH
summary: A team of U.S. researchers has successfully shown that a CRISPR-Cas 9 gene editing method combined with antiretroviral therapy can eliminate HIV infection in "humanized" mice, which have a human immune system. The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found that up to 58% of the mice treated this way were cured of HIV. The technique targets the CCR5 co-receptor that HIV uses to enter cells and the virus's genetic material in the host cells' DNA, cutting and removing it. This is a major step forward in HIV treatment research, indicating the possibility of a cure through gene editing and antiretroviral therapy. Future research will focus on primates and, if successful, will proceed to human clinical trials. This study builds on earlier research and aims for a functional cure for HIV.

title: La Fundación para el Desarrollo de la Enfermería (Fuden) sufre un ciberataque que expone datos personales
hco: FUNDACION PARA EL DESARROLLODE LA ENFERMERIA
summary: The Nursing Development Foundation (Fuden) has been the victim of a cyberattack that has exposed personal data of users registered in training activities. The attack, carried out using malware at the end of January, allowed cybercriminals unauthorized access to Fuden's systems. A cybercriminal from the United States managed to access academic records of 50,000 users in Spain, compromising data such as names, birth dates, telephone numbers, email addresses, and copies of ID cards. Fuden has notified the affected users, informed the Spanish Data Protection Agency, filed a complaint with the authorities, and recommended precautionary measures to users, such as changing passwords and two-factor authentication.

title: Carolina Chaves es la nueva secretaria de Formación de Satse
hco: FUNDACION PARA EL DESARROLLODE LA ENFERMERIA
summary: Carolina Chaves has been appointed as the new Training Secretary of Satse Ceuta and will also serve as the head of the Nursing Development Foundation (Fuden) in the autonomous city. This announcement was made by the Nursing and Physiotherapy Union, highlighting Chaves' recognition as a physiotherapist at the Otero Health Center and her selection for a key role in promoting training and professional development in nursing and physiotherapy in Ceuta. Satse expressed confidence in Chaves' ability to lead the Training Secretary and manage Fuden responsibilities, emphasizing her professional trajectory and commitment to advancing nursing and physiotherapy in the city. Chaves, grateful for the appointment, pledged to tirelessly work to enhance continuous training and professional development in Ceuta. Fuden plays a significant role in promoting training and research in the health sector, aiming to further its positive impact in Ceuta with Chaves' appointment.

title: La falta de médicos lastra la atención en las cárceles: "La situación es mala y el futuro puede ser aún peor"
summary: The lack of doctors in prisons significantly impacts healthcare services, with the situation described as bad and potentially worsening. At Zuera prison, with 1,310 inmates, there should be eight doctors, but currently, there is only one interim doctor and another contracted for 25 hours a week until June 2024. The Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health highlights a nearly 70% shortfall in medical professionals needed for adequate care. Since the 2003 Law of Cohesion and Quality of the National Health System, healthcare in prisons was to be transferred to each region, but only Catalonia, the Basque Country, and Navarre have done so, leaving others, like Aragon, under the Ministry of the Interior. The doctor deficit has shifted focus from scheduled to urgent care, with telemedicine services partially filling the gap. This shortage hinders diagnosing and treating inmates, many with mental health issues and addictions, and a significant portion never accessed healthcare before incarceration. The situation raises concerns about healthcare quality and the risk of professional intrusion, with calls for more psychiatric hospitals and better health rights access for inmates.

title: La preocupante situación sanitaria de las cárceles españolas: 1 médico por cada 200 presos
summary: The healthcare situation in Spanish prisons is alarming, with one doctor available for every 200 inmates. This shortage of medical staff is due to 65% of positions being unfilled, a situation that unions have been warning about for 20 years without any action taken to address it. Young healthcare professionals are not applying for positions in prisons, contributing to potential outbreaks of tuberculosis and other diseases. Over 70% of prisoners have had issues with drug addiction, requiring healthcare measures not commonly taken in public health settings. Additionally, the prison of Brieva has seen four staff members assaulted this year, highlighting the dangerous conditions and lack of personnel. José Joaquín Antón, the president of the Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health, emphasizes the long-standing warnings about these issues that have been ignored, leading to the current crisis.

title: El 70% de los presos con enfermedad mental grave no han tenido tratamiento antes de entrar en prisión
summary: 70% of prisoners with severe mental illness in Spain have not received treatment before entering prison, according to the 'White Book on healthcare for people with severe mental disorders in Spanish prisons' by the Spanish Society of Legal Psychiatry (SEPL) and the Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health (SESP). They state that 50% of inmates seen in psychiatric consultations are diagnosed with a severe mental disorder and urge the inclusion of mental health in prisons in the electoral programs for the 23-J elections. The lack of professionals and the double stigma faced by inmates with mental health issues are highlighted. Of the 55,180 inmates, 1,785 have high mental health needs, often young people with psychotic disorders and addictions. The suicide rate in prisons is eight to nine times higher than in the general population. There is a significant shortage of psychiatric care staff in prisons, with Spain's ratio of penitentiary doctors being much lower than the European average estimated by the World Health Organization. The situation is somewhat better in regions like Catalonia, the Basque Country, and Navarra, where healthcare competencies have been transferred to the regional level, unlike the rest of Spain.

title: La salud mental en las cárceles: «Es el problema más importante y el que peor se afronta»
summary: In Spain, there is a significant lack of mental health care in prisons, with only 0.2 psychiatrists for every 1,000 prisoners, as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO). The Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health estimates that 2,000 to 3,000 inmates have severe mental disorders. A third of prisoners in European jails have mental health issues, with suicide being the most common cause of death among them, indicating a higher rate than in the general population. The primary health care system in prisons has almost vanished, making it difficult to detect and treat mental health issues. Despite the urgent need, Spanish prisons do not have psychiatrists on staff and rely on externally hired psychiatrists for limited hours, which does not meet the needs of the prison population. This situation is in stark contrast to the high prevalence of mental health issues among prisoners, significantly higher than in the general population, affecting up to 90% of inmates.

title: José Francisco Díaz, nuevo gerente de la fundación Marqués de Valdecilla
summary: José Francisco Díaz has been appointed as the new manager of the Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation. He has a notable career in the health sector, having been the coordinator of the Breast Cancer Prevention Program of the Cantabria Health Council from September 1996 to December 2003, and the General Director of Public Health of the same council from July 2011 to July 2015. Díaz has also been instrumental in creating and developing the Registry of Advance Directives and has served as the president of the Deontology Commission of the Cantabria Medical Association, where he is currently a board member. With a background in Medicine and Surgery from the University of Cantabria, he specializes in Family and Community Medicine and Occupational Medicine, holding a Master's in Health Services Management from the University of Cantabria, among other qualifications. His appointment was announced during a meeting chaired by the Health Councilor, César Pascual.

title: Más de 300 recién nacidos han recibido leche materna procedente de donaciones en Cantabria desde 2017
summary: Since 2017, over 300 newborns in Cantabria have received breast milk from donations. This was highlighted during a tribute to the 56 mothers who donated milk in 2023 and 2024, organized by the Cantabria Milk Bank on World Breast Milk Donation Day. The event, which took place at the Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation, aimed to thank the donors and promote this altruistic act. Health Minister César Pascual emphasized the life-saving importance of breast milk donations for babies unable to be breastfed by their mothers. In 2023, 43 women donated over 200 liters of milk, producing more than 2,300 bottles. The donation process, including extraction, pasteurization, and storage, is highly secure, ensuring the milk's quality for the most vulnerable infants, such as preemies or those with specific illnesses. Women in good health and with established lactation can donate, with certain restrictions. The donated milk, which is anonymous and free, is prescribed by medical criteria.

title: José Luis Arroyo regresa a la dirección del Banco de Sangre y Tejidos de Cantabria
summary: José Luis Arroyo has been appointed again as the director of the Blood and Tissue Bank of Cantabria (BSTC) by the Board of Trustees of the Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation, after a public selection process in which his extensive 16-year experience in similar roles was valued. Arroyo, who already directed the BSTC from 2006 to 2022, stood out for leading significant projects such as the expansion of the Tissue Bank, the creation of the Milk Bank, and the Advanced Therapies Production Unit. He has also coordinated regional donation programs and has been a benchmark in quality management, achieving several important certifications. Arroyo has a degree in Medicine and Surgery, specializes in Hematology and Hemotherapy, and holds a doctorate and a master's degree in Management of Health Centers and Services. His return is endorsed by favorable reports from prestigious associations, and his career includes authorship of numerous scientific publications.

title: La Fundación Marqués de Valdecilla renueva el convenio de colaboración con la Asociación Buscando Sonrisas para mejorar la estancia de pacientes pediátricos en Valdecilla
summary: The Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation has renewed its collaboration agreement with the Buscando Sonrisas Association to improve the experience of pediatric patients at the Marqués de Valdecilla University Hospital. This agreement, which continues after a year of previous collaboration, focuses on the humanization of pediatric areas, pediatric emergencies, and pediatric pre-surgical areas. The association, active since 2016 in humanizing spaces for hospitalized children, offers daily activities with volunteers to make the stay of patients and their families more pleasant, in addition to organizing special events and workshops. The hospital has areas designed to minimize the impact of hospitalization on children, maintaining their social integration and offering spaces for recreational and educational activities. The Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation supports the dissemination of these initiatives as part of its Corporate Social Responsibility, seeking to improve society and reduce inequalities.

title: El plazo de consulta de la futura Ley de Salud Pública de Cantabria se cierra este martes
summary: The consultation period for the future Public Health Law of Cantabria is set to close this Tuesday. The new legislation, driven by the Public Health Directorate and developed by the Cantabria Public Health Observatory of the Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation, aims to enhance early disease detection and treatment, and strengthen surveillance and response systems for public health emergencies. This initiative is a response to the needs identified following the Covid-19 pandemic and seeks to improve health factor identification and early disease diagnosis. Additionally, it aims to promote social cohesion, equity, and sustainability within the healthcare system, and improve citizens' health and well-being throughout their lives. The law adapts the national General Public Health Law of 2011 to Cantabria's specificities, providing a legal framework for health promotion, prevention, and restoration within the region's jurisdiction.

title: Valdecilla recibe 2.600 euros de recaudación del recital del Club Rotario Santander-Sardinero para el Proyecto Mentte
summary: Valdecilla receives a donation of 2,600 euros from a recital organized by the Rotary Club Santander-Sardinero. The funds raised will be allocated to the Mentte Project, focused on improving the treatment of young psychiatric patients at the Marqués de Valdecilla University Hospital. The recital, part of the club's charitable activities, took place at the San Antonio Church and was performed by Adamar Early Music. The Mentte Project aims to connect young patients with professionals from various fields to facilitate the development of their talent and creativity. To date, the project has 51 mentors and has carried out nine group mentorships and two individual ones. The Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation acts as a link to channel the funds provided to the project, offering two modes of collaboration: as volunteer mentors or as sponsoring entities.

title: Luis Mariano López, nuevo director de Enfermería de Valdecilla y Rosana García continuará como directora médica
summary: Luis Mariano López has been appointed as the new Director of Nursing at Valdecilla Hospital, while Rosana García will continue in her role as the Medical Director. This decision was made by the new manager of Valdecilla, María Dolores Acón, who has chosen to keep García, who had previously worked closely with Rafael Tejido, and to place López at the forefront of the Nursing Directorate.

title: Valdecilla incorpora a su galería de arte la 'Puerta de Cantabria', de José Antonio Barquín
summary: Valdecilla's art gallery has incorporated 'Puerta de Cantabria' by the late sculptor José Antonio Barquín (1958-2020), now displayed in the Las Tres Torres lobby. This life-size resin reproduction of a manor door, originally intended to be cast in bronze, features 12 reliefs narrating the region's history across various epochs, from prehistory through to modern times. The work highlights significant aspects of Cantabrian life and history, including ancient festivities, medieval times, the era of Trasmiera's crafts and royal shipyards, and emigration to Cuba and Mexico, culminating in the return of the Indianos. With this addition, Valdecilla's gallery now hosts 30 permanent pieces by regional artists, aiming to humanize the hospital space and make it more welcoming, while also celebrating Cantabrian artistic talent.

title: Zuloaga anuncia que Valdecilla será el segundo hospital público del norte con un sistema robotizado de rehabilitación
summary: Valdecilla Hospital in Cantabria, Spain, will become the second public hospital in the northern region to offer a robotic rehabilitation system, following the acquisition of an exoskeleton. This system is aimed at improving high-intensity rehabilitation for patients with muscle paralysis due to brain damage, among other causes. The exoskeleton, expected to be included in the public health service's offerings within four to five months, is part of a project led by the Marqués de Valdecilla Foundation, with a budget exceeding 611,000 euros. Vice President Pablo Zuloaga highlighted the initiative as a significant advancement in treating neurological conditions, which account for 43.8% of chronic disease disability in Spain. The system will cater to both children and adults, reducing the need for patients to travel to other regions for treatment. Currently, only A Coruña in the north offers such a system.

title: Catalunya tiene 2.200 personas en la lista de espera para la pastilla profiláctica contra el VIH
summary: Catalonia has a waiting list of 2,200 people for the HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis pill (PrEP). The Projecte dels Noms-Hispanosida foundation, during the 30th anniversary of the International AIDS Memorial, urged the Health Minister, Manel Balcells, to reduce this waiting time. Currently, the average wait to access PrEP is nine months. PrEP is a prevention strategy involving antiretroviral medication taken before potential HIV exposure to prevent infection, intended for HIV-negative individuals at high risk of exposure. The medication, which is highly effective, uses two active components, emtricitabine and tenofovir, to block HIV from infecting cells. Although PrEP is safe and has low toxicity, it is not suitable for individuals already HIV-positive or those with kidney issues without closer medical supervision. Regular medical checks are recommended for those on PrEP to monitor any side effects and ensure effectiveness.

title: La Fundación ”la Caixa” destina 3 millones de euros a 111 proyectos de entidades sociales de la Comunitat
hco: COMITE CIUDADANO ANTI-SIDA DE LACOMUNIDAD VALENCIANA
summary: The "la Caixa" Foundation has allocated 3 million euros to 111 social entity projects in the Valencian Community, with the aim of boosting the third social sector and supporting nearly 25,000 Valencians in vulnerable situations. Among the selected projects, 36 are located in Alicante, distributed across 11 towns in the province. These projects cover seven areas of action: poverty and social inclusion, disability or mental disorder, socio-labor insertion, health and disease, elderly people, social action, and coexistence and interculturality. The initiative seeks to promote equal opportunities and improve the quality of life, responding to the emerging needs of society. The announcement of the call's resolution was attended by authorities and representatives of some of the beneficiary entities, highlighting the commitment of the "la Caixa" Foundation to advancing towards a fairer society.

title: CaixaBank y Fundación Bancaja entregan ayudas a 20 entidades de la Comunitat para sus proyectos sociales
hco: COMITE CIUDADANO ANTI-SIDA DE LACOMUNIDAD VALENCIANA
summary: CaixaBank and Bancaja Foundation have awarded grants to 20 social entities in the Valencian Community, through their annual 'Coopera ONG' call. In its twenty-first edition, 250,000 euros have been granted to support projects that promote the social integration of people at risk of exclusion. The award ceremony was attended by representatives of CaixaBank, Bancaja Foundation, and the beneficiary entities. The supported projects are expected to benefit directly and indirectly 15,446 people, addressing the needs of various vulnerable groups and promoting socio-labor insertion, social inclusion, psychosocial support, and volunteering. The selected entities work in areas such as addiction care, support for the elderly, immigrants, victims of gender violence, among others.

title: Belisario, Rebeca y el sentido de la vida en la Casa de La Encina para personas con VIH en Burgos
summary: The Encina House in Burgos, a shelter for people with HIV, has been offering support to patients without resources for 21 years, with the financial backing of the Burgos City Council and the Regional Government, and managed by the Citizen's Anti-AIDS Committee. The story of Belisario, a recent resident, is highlighted by the visit of his daughter Rebeca, emphasizing the positive impact of the house on their lives. Encina is recognized for its humane and dignified approach to care, transforming lives marked by HIV and addictions, like that of Rafa, a former drug addict who now expresses himself through art. The house not only offers shelter, food, and medication but also an environment of dignity and love, crucial for the recovery and sense of life of its residents. This approach has allowed people like Belisario to reconcile with their families and face premature aging with support and peace.

title: Crecen las consultas al Comité Anti-Sida Burgos sobre infecciones de transmisión sexual
summary: The Comité Anti-Sida Burgos has seen an increase in inquiries about sexually transmitted infections (STIs) beyond HIV, reflecting a general rise in STIs after COVID-19 restrictions were lifted. The lack of updated data from health authorities on STI rates since 2020 complicates understanding the current situation. The Committee provides educational and informational resources through social media and other channels, addressing concerns about STI management both practically and emotionally. In 2020, diagnoses for syphilis, gonorrhea, and HIV declined due to reduced contact and preventive measures against COVID-19, while chlamydia infections nearly tripled. The Committee also offers anonymous and free HIV testing, with 29 new AIDS cases recorded in Burgos last year, highlighting the ongoing need for awareness and prevention efforts. Additionally, pharmacies have conducted over 1,118 rapid HIV tests since 2010, with 10 positives, indicating a gender disparity in testing uptake and emphasizing the importance of safe sexual practices to prevent STIs.

title: Pruebas rápidas del VIH en la carrera entre castillos de A Coruña
hco: COMITÉ CIUDADANO ANTISIDA DE A CORU
summary: The II Costa Ártabra Race, connecting the castles of Santa Cruz in Oleiros and San Antón in A Coruña on April 21st, will feature a mobile HIV testing unit at the finish line. This initiative, part of a pilot program funded by the Consellería de Sanidade in agreement with the Comité Ciudadano Anti Sida de A Coruña (Casco), aims to bring awareness to HIV and sexually transmitted infections among young people. The program offers information, free protection materials, and anonymous rapid tests for HIV and hepatitis C. Since last summer, under this program coordinated by Saúde Pública, Casco has conducted over a thousand tests and distributed more than 2,000 condoms and informational materials in nightlife areas. Approximately 80% of the participants had never been tested for AIDS before. The race, organized by Casco and the Boxfit association, also aims to raise funds for a quality of life program through inclusive sports, complemented by a medical, social, and sports program involving the AIDS Unit of the Hospital Universitario A Coruña (Chuac) for a year.

title: De castillo a castillo, la carrera que une A Coruña y Oleiros por el VIH
hco: COMITÉ CIUDADANO ANTISIDA DE A CORU
summary: The second Costa Ártabra race will be held on April 21, linking the Santa Cruz castle in Oleiros and the San Antón castle in A Coruña, to aid those affected by HIV. This fundraising event is organized by the Comité Ciudadano Anti Sida de A Coruña (Casco) and the Boxfit association. Its goal is to collect funds for a program aimed at improving life quality through inclusive sports, along with medical, social, and sports programs for a year, involving the Unidad de Sida of the Complexo Hospitalario Universitario A Coruña (Chuac). Casco highlights the program's importance in enhancing life quality for participants and using sports as a prevention method, especially for at-risk groups. A preventive mobile unit will be present at the event's end. The entry fee for the 10-kilometer race is €15 until April 8, then €20 until April 16, with a “solidarity mile” available for €5. Participants will get a commemorative shirt and access to physiotherapy services at the end.

title: La carrera Costa Ártabra destinará beneficios a CASCO
hco: COMITÉ CIUDADANO ANTISIDA DE A CORU
summary: The Costa Ártabra race, which will be held on March 12th covering the municipalities of A Coruña and Oleiros along the seafront, will allocate part of its profits to the A Coruña Citizen's Anti-AIDS Committee. This initiative aims to make visible a project that seeks to improve the quality of life of sick or vulnerable people.

title: Galicia impulsa la prevención y detección precoz de VIH y hepatitis C en zonas de ocio
hco: COMITÉ CIUDADANO ANTISIDA DE A CORU
summary: Galicia has started a project to improve the prevention and early detection of HIV and hepatitis C in vulnerable groups, especially in leisure spots and at big entertainment events. This effort, a partnership between the Health Department and the Citizen Anti-AIDS Committee of A Coruña (CASCO), includes a six-month trial using a mobile unit, ViHxía móvil, with 18,000 euros from the Health Department. The project aims to make rapid testing more accessible for early detection, focusing on those who usually don't use regular healthcare. It will evaluate the possibility of making such screening a permanent and widespread public health action in Galicia to fight HIV and hepatitis C. This initiative is part of Galicia's wider plans to tackle sexually transmitted infections, in line with global goals to end these infections by 2030.

title: Muere el presidente de la asociación zaragozana Omsida, Juan Ramón Barrios 'Jancho'
hco: ASOCIACIÓN PARA LA AYUDA A PERSONASAFECTADAS POR VIH-SIDA OMSIDA
summary: Juan Ramón Barrios, known as 'Jancho', the president of the Zaragoza-based association Omsida, has passed away. His colleagues have praised his natural empathy, listening skills, and his continuous efforts to think of new projects for the common good, highlighting his role as a reference in the fight against discrimination towards the HIV/AIDS community. Barrios was recognized for his activism, which was said to be in his genes, and his desire to help others, which came from the heart. His team's message was filled with emotion, reflecting on the positive impact he had on those around him. Omsida, a non-profit, public utility NGO working in HIV/AIDS care, prevention, and awareness in Aragón since 1993, has lost a significant figure. The organization focuses on supporting those affected by HIV/AIDS, including their families and friends, through a biopsychosocial approach aimed at improving their quality of life and integrating them into society.

title: Apollo Hospitals partners with Boston Children's Hospital to organise paediatric meet
summary: Apollo Hospitals has partnered with Boston Children's Hospital to host PediSync 2023, a pediatric conference in Chennai on November 4-5. Aimed at pediatricians, the event will feature lectures, interactive sessions, and panel discussions by experts including Dr. Aditya Kaza, Dr. Ravi Thiagarajan, and Dr. Kyung Rae Him from Harvard Medical School. The conference will cover topics such as infectious diseases in children, pediatric intensive care, surgical issues, and robotic surgeries in pediatrics. It seeks to highlight the latest in pediatric care and research, encouraging the exchange of knowledge to improve clinical outcomes for children. The conference will also be streamed live to allow participation from pediatricians nationwide.

title: Our Second Opinion Programs give families with complex medical questions access to an expert second opinion from ...
summary: The Second Opinion Program at Boston Children's Hospital offers families with complex medical questions the opportunity to obtain an expert second opinion from their pediatric specialists. This program is designed to provide peace of mind by confirming a child's diagnosis, helping understand treatment options, and confirming the recommended treatment. Families can choose to visit in person or access the same expertise online through a confidential Online Second Opinion Program. For children and adolescents with complex symptoms who lack a clear diagnosis, the Pediatric Diagnostic Program is available to evaluate and diagnose their condition with a team of specialists. The program emphasizes privacy, not sharing confidential medical information with third parties, and encourages reading their Privacy Policy and Terms of Use for more details. It's noted that second opinion programs are not for medical emergencies or immediate treatment guidance.

title: BOSTON CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL JOINS BLUE CROSS BLUE SHIELD OF MASSACHUSETTS' GROUNDBREAKING ...
summary: Boston Children's Hospital has joined Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts' innovative payment program aimed at enhancing health equity. This partnership marks the first time a children's hospital in the nation has engaged in such a contract, focusing on eliminating disparities in care. The program links financial incentives to the achievement of measurable health equity improvements. Boston Children's, known for having one of the largest pediatric primary care organizations in the U.S., will initially concentrate on reducing inequities in child and adolescent well-care visits. This move is part of Blue Cross' broader commitment to addressing health inequities, which includes publishing annual data revealing racial and ethnic disparities in patient care and funding initiatives to eliminate these disparities. Through this collaboration, both organizations aim to make significant strides in eliminating healthcare inequities, particularly for children and families.

title: Boston Children's Hospital and NRG Energy celebrate $1 million milestone, thanks to the Choose to Give program
summary: NRG Energy celebrated surpassing $1 million in contributions to Boston Children’s Hospital through its Choose to Give program, which supports the hospital's Every Child Fund. This fund aids in providing lifesaving treatments and research breakthroughs for children. The program, initiated in 2017, allows NRG customers to contribute by enrolling in a specific electricity plan, with NRG donating $50 upon enrollment and an additional one percent of the customer's annual electricity supply charges. This partnership highlights NRG’s commitment to supporting the health and future of children in Boston, offering customers a simple way to contribute to significant health advancements while securing a fixed electricity supply rate for 12 months. The program is part of NRG's broader efforts, which have resulted in over $15 million in donations to local organizations across the country.

title: Boston Children's Hospital rolls out hybrid 5G network as it plans to unify on Epic
summary: Boston Children's Hospital is transitioning to a unified Epic electronic health record system across all its care sites in 2024, moving away from its current use of both Epic and Cerner PowerChart. In conjunction with this transition, the hospital, in partnership with T-Mobile, is rolling out the first hybrid 5G network within a health system. This network aims to enhance connectivity for healthcare professionals, allowing for seamless access to critical patient data. It is designed to scale and support thousands of devices, extending connectivity beyond the hospital to other provider sites and into patients' homes. The hybrid 5G network is expected to enable future healthcare innovations, including in-home patient care with 5G remote monitoring and AI-based prioritization, ensuring faster decision-making and efficient specialist deployment. This initiative is part of Boston Children's Hospital's effort to improve patient care and operational efficiency through advanced technology.

title: Mikyoung Kim Design's green master plan and gardens at Boston Children's Hospital are designed for healing
summary: Mikyoung Kim Design has developed a "green master plan" and gardens at Boston Children's Hospital, aimed at fostering healing. This project, which has garnered an AN Best of Design Award, includes four open-air gardens, three interior winter gardens, and a revamped main hospital entrance. Initiated with the completion of the Hale Medical Tower, which increased the hospital's bed capacity and green space by 25%, the project's design focuses on stress reduction, mental restoration, and providing spaces for contemplation and escape for patients, their families, and caregivers. The Wishingstone Garden, part of the expansion, features granite benches and raised garden beds to enhance the natural landscape. The healing gardens are designed with stress reduction, social support, privacy, and positive distractions in mind, potentially reducing hospital stay durations. The entry redesign on Longwood Avenue improves wayfinding and hospital identity. The project is fully ADA-compliant and considers neurodiverse patients, offering a variety of spaces surrounded by nature and upcycled materials from the site.

title: About Us | Government Relations
summary: The Office of Government Relations at Boston Children's Hospital collaborates with policymakers at the local, state, and national levels to promote the hospital's objectives of outstanding clinical care, research progress, and training for pediatric providers. This office concentrates on community health initiatives and pursues comprehensive solutions to issues affecting children's health, such as the availability of healthy food and mental health services. It keeps track of healthcare coverage, access, and regulatory conditions, and tackles challenges related to research and the pediatric workforce. In 2022, it broadened its scope by incorporating a Payor Relations Team, which boosts efforts for operational enhancement and patient access through advocacy for payor policies. The hospital champions policies that improve access to healthcare for children, supports scientific research, fosters a robust pediatric workforce, and promotes community health. It motivates public participation via the Children’s Advocacy Network, which involves advocates in dialogue with legislators about children's health matters.

title: Inimmune Collaborates with Boston Children's Hospital to Develop Novel Adjuvants
summary: Inimmune Corporation has partnered with Boston Children's Hospital to develop new small molecule vaccine adjuvants, aiming to enhance the immune response and effectiveness of flu vaccines. This collaboration is supported by a National Institutes of Health contract worth up to $9 million over five years. The project, led by BCH's Precision Vaccines Program, focuses on creating a TLR7/8 agonist adjuvant for protein-based and potentially mRNA vaccines against infectious diseases. Inimmune, specializing in immunotherapeutics and vaccine adjuvants, has recently advanced an allergic rhinitis treatment to Phase I clinical trials. This partnership will combine Inimmune's drug discovery capabilities with PVP's research to develop and evaluate new adjuvants for preclinical proof-of-concept, with the goal of pursuing commercial collaborations for further development.

title: Out-of-network moyamoya care - Boston Children's Answers
summary: A study by Boston Children’s Hospital's Cerebrovascular Surgery and Interventions Center found that high-volume centers offer better outcomes and lower costs for pediatric moyamoya patients, challenging insurers' reluctance for out-of-network care approvals. Moyamoya disease, causing narrowed brain vessels and increased stroke risk, shows improved revascularization outcomes at these centers. Analyzing data from 125 pediatric patients between January 2018 and December 2020, the study highlighted that patients treated at Boston Children's experienced fewer complications and underwent fewer follow-up surgeries compared to those at lower-volume centers. This was partly due to the innovative single-anesthetic bilateral revascularization surgery, now recommended by the American Stroke Association. The study also noted a 42% cost reduction for treatments at high-volume centers by coordinating care with local clinicians, emphasizing the benefits of a partnership care model. This approach not only reduces costs but also minimizes out-of-network insurance exposure and family disruptions, suggesting a reevaluation of referral practices to prioritize high-volume centers for complex, rare conditions like moyamoya.

title: Boston Children's Hospital Named Client of the Year for Creating World-class Central Sterile Processing Department
summary: Boston Children's Hospital has been awarded the "Client of the Year" by Surgical Directions for its exceptional work in revamping its Central Sterile Processing Department (SPD). This recognition highlights the hospital's commitment to innovation, quality, and patient safety. Key initiatives included enhancing customer service, implementing quality assurance and additional OR audits, boosting productivity, fostering teamwork, and focusing on education and training. These efforts have significantly reduced tray errors to nearly 0%, improving patient safety. Boston Children's Hospital's strategic approach and dedication to excellence in surgical care have set a new standard for healthcare institutions globally. This achievement also earned them the Healthcare Sterile Processing Association's (HSPA) Quality Award, further underscoring their commitment to leading-edge healthcare delivery.

title: Hereditary spastic paraplegia: Journey to a treatment
summary: Hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP) is a group of inherited disorders that cause spasticity and muscle weakness, often resulting in the need for a wheelchair by age 10. In 2016, Darius Ebrahimi-Fakhari, a neurology fellow at Boston Children’s Hospital, started researching HSP after encountering two girls with a rare form, SPG47. With no treatments available, the families of the girls began research efforts, leading to the creation of a patient registry and the first comprehensive study of childhood-onset HSP. Ebrahimi-Fakhari's team found a potential oral medication that could treat various HSP forms, including SPG47, by fixing protein transport issues caused by the condition. This progress, combined with ongoing gene therapy trials for other forms, represents a major step forward in treating HSP. These efforts were significantly supported by patient advocacy and partnerships with biotech firms, underscoring the vital role of community and scientific collaboration in tackling rare diseases.

title: Mezzion Pharmaceuticals Announces Dr. Rahul Rathod of Boston Children's Hospital and Harvard Medical School as ...
summary: Mezzion Pharmaceuticals has named Dr. Rahul Rathod, a pediatric cardiology expert from Boston Children's Hospital and Harvard Medical School, as the Global Principal Investigator for the FUEL-2 Phase 3 clinical trial. This study will evaluate the effectiveness and safety of udenafil in teens aged 12-18 who have had the Fontan operation for single ventricle heart defects. Dr. Rathod brings over two decades of experience and over 80 peer-reviewed studies to his role, where he will manage the clinical protocol, execution, and operations across all research locations, and lead the analysis and reporting of the study to the FDA. FUEL-2, backed by Mezzion Pharmaceuticals, aims to be the biggest Fontan clinical trial globally, with 438 participants. Udenafil, a selective enzyme inhibitor, shows promise in improving blood flow and oxygen levels, potentially boosting exercise ability and energy for daily activities in these patients.

title: 75 years of cardiology
summary: The Boston Children's Department of Cardiology, established in 1949 by Dr. Alexander Nadas, is celebrating its 75th anniversary as a global leader in the treatment of both acquired and congenital heart diseases. Initially starting with just one cardiologist, the department has expanded significantly and now includes over 100 pediatric and adult cardiologists, 40 clinical fellows, 12 echocardiogram rooms, and five state-of-the-art catheterization laboratories. The department's development can be divided into two main periods: the early years up to the 1980s, which were characterized by rapid advancements and the introduction of new diagnostic and treatment methods, and the period from the 1980s to today, marked by further innovations in electrophysiology, echocardiography, CT scans, and MRIs, enhancing the precision and safety of cardiac procedures. Collaboration and specialization have been crucial to the department's success, creating an environment that promotes shared knowledge and focuses on patient-centered care. Looking to the future, the department aims to make strides in heart regeneration, tissue engineering, and the development of new approaches to treat challenging congenital heart defects.

title: Innovations aim to halt pacemakers - Boston Children's Answers
summary: Boston Children's Hospital is focusing on reducing the financial and social costs associated with pacemakers for children with heart conditions. The hospital's research indicates an increase in complex heart surgeries leading to a rise in postoperative heart block, necessitating pacemakers. This condition not only imposes a financial burden on families but also causes anxiety among children reliant on these devices. To address these issues, Boston Children's clinicians have developed two innovative approaches aimed at identifying conduction tissue during surgery to potentially decrease the incidence of heart block. One method involves a confocal microscope, which provides high-resolution images to help surgeons avoid damaging conduction tissue. The other is an electrophysiology tool used during surgery to accurately locate conduction tissue, which has already shown success in reducing heart block rates in specific patient groups. These innovations reflect the hospital's commitment to improving patient care by minimizing the need for pacemakers, thereby alleviating both the financial strain on families and the psychological impact on children.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center's Dr. Sameer Patel Named Vice President of the Robert H. Ivy Society of Plastic Surgeons
summary: Dr. Sameer Patel, Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Fox Chase Cancer Center, has been appointed as the Vice President of the Robert H. Ivy Society of Plastic Surgeons for the 2024-2025 term. The society, established in 1954, aims to maintain high standards in plastic surgery and foster medical and surgical research. Patel's election to Vice President was announced during the society's annual meeting in March, where it was highlighted that he would chair the Program Committee for the society's 71st Annual Scientific Meeting next spring. Patel, an Associate Professor in the Department of Surgical Oncology at Fox Chase and a member of several prestigious medical societies, has been recognized as a Top Doctor by Philadelphia magazine in 2023 and 2024. His research focuses on surgical outcomes for head and neck cancer patients and breast reconstruction procedures. Fox Chase Cancer Center is noted for its comprehensive cancer care and research, holding a designation as a National Cancer Institute Comprehensive Cancer Center since 1974.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Welcomes Yash Chhabra
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center is excited to welcome Yash Chhabra, PhD, as an Assistant Professor in the Cancer Signaling and Microenvironment Research Program. Chhabra, joining from the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, will focus his research on the influence of sex disparities in cancer and aging. His work will explore the molecular mechanisms that underlie these disparities in cancer progression and treatment responses, emphasizing the need for treatment strategies that consider the age and sex of patients. This research aims to improve the use of preclinical models, moving beyond the current reliance on young male mouse models. Chhabra, who has published over 20 articles in prestigious journals and has a strong background in research supervision and mentorship, began his tenure at Fox Chase on February 5. Fox Chase Cancer Center, a leading comprehensive cancer center and part of Temple Health, is committed to excellence in cancer treatment, research, and education.

title: 2023 Fox Chase Cancer Center Annual Report - Physician Resources
summary: The 2023 Fox Chase Cancer Center Annual Report emphasizes the power of collaboration in advancing cancer research and patient care. Fox Chase Cancer Center, known for its collegial, supportive environment, focuses on innovative projects and studies in partnership with Temple Health and the Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University. Efforts to enhance clinical trial operations include the creation of a clinical trials council, a new resource allocation system, and improved access to trial information for both patients and providers. These measures aim to increase trial recruitment and optimize resource use. The report highlights the launch of the Fox Chase-Temple Urologic Institute, a significant development in urology care and research. Fox Chase is dedicated to improving quality of life, treatment adaptability, organ preservation, diverse research representation, and prevention for high-risk patients. The center's work is characterized by a multi-faceted approach to cancer treatment and research, underscoring the importance of collective effort across various specialties to make meaningful progress.

title: External Advisory Board
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, PA, features an External Advisory Committee (EAC) composed of nationally and internationally recognized leaders in the cancer field. This committee provides scientific and strategic guidance to the center, particularly in strategic planning for clinical and research programs. The EAC's main role is to evaluate the research enterprise and shared resources of Fox Chase, offering direction for growth. They assist in identifying talented early-career scientists, advise on advanced technology and research trends, and review the research portfolios of faculty members and core facility leaders. The committee is instrumental in supporting Fox Chase's mission to overcome cancer through bold scientific discovery, pioneering prevention, and compassionate care.

title: Philadelphia Magazine Names 133 Fox Chase Cancer Center Physicians 'Top Doctors'
summary: Philadelphia Magazine has recognized 133 physicians from Fox Chase Cancer Center as "Top Doctors" for 2024. This acknowledgment comes from nominations by their professional peers, highlighting the high-quality care and expertise of Fox Chase's doctors. The increase in listed physicians indicates the center's growing reputation in the medical community. Robert Uzzo, MD, MBA, FACS, President and CEO of Fox Chase, stressed the importance of this peer-based recognition, reflecting the center's dedication to comprehensive cancer care. The list features specialists in various fields, emphasizing Fox Chase's status as a leading comprehensive cancer center in the United States, renowned for its extensive research, clinical trials, and patient care. Fox Chase Cancer Center, a part of Temple Health, boasts a long history of excellence in cancer treatment and research, including being one of the first cancer hospitals and a National Cancer Institute Comprehensive Cancer Center.

title: Thirteen at Fox Chase Cancer Center Honored as 2024 Top Nurses by Main Line Today
summary: Thirteen nurses from Fox Chase Cancer Center have been recognized as 2024 Top Nurses by Main Line Today magazine. This accolade, highlighted in the May 2024 issue, acknowledges the exceptional work and dedication of these healthcare professionals in the Philadelphia region. Anna Liza Rodriguez, the Chief Nursing Officer at Fox Chase, expressed that this honor reflects the excellence of the nursing team and underscores the vital role they play at the center. Main Line Today's Excellence in Nursing Awards are peer-nominated and cover various specialties across Chester, Delaware, and Montgomery counties. The selection process involves a review and finalization by the magazine's editorial staff. Michael Reath, Publisher of Main Line Today, emphasized the invaluable contribution of nurses to patient and family care. The honored nurses serve in diverse roles across the healthcare spectrum, evidencing their significant impact on patient care and the broader healthcare community. Fox Chase Cancer Center, a leading institution in cancer research and treatment, is recognized for its high standards in nursing and medical care.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center and the Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University Present Research at the ...
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center and the Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University will showcase 30 research projects at the American Urological Association (AUA) Annual Meeting 2024 in San Antonio from May 3-6. The presentations will cover a range of topics, including the effects of radiation timing on artificial urinary sphincter survival, robotic repair of ureteral obstruction, and the use of Mirabegron for treating refractory neurogenic bladder in pediatric patients with spina bifida. Other studies will discuss practice patterns in pelvic lymph node dissection omission during radical prostatectomy, preoperative indicators for successful robotic ureteral reconstruction, and the impact of prior radiation therapy on inflatable penile prosthesis placement complications. Additionally, the conference will feature discussions on various surgical techniques and management strategies for urological conditions. Fox Chase Cancer Center, a leading comprehensive cancer center and part of Temple Health, is known for its significant contributions to cancer research and treatment.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Invests in Expanding Access to Lifesaving Radiopharmaceuticals for Cancer Patients
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center has announced its investment in Nucleus RadioPharma, aiming to expand access to innovative radiopharmaceuticals for cancer treatment. This collaboration marks a significant step towards developing and distributing targeted therapies that deliver radiation directly to cancer cells. Nucleus RadioPharma's technology is at the forefront of research, with the potential to bring new therapies from clinical trials to commercialization. The partnership includes plans for a manufacturing site and clinical trials involving radiopharmaceuticals. Funded by the Fox Chase Cancer Center Director’s Innovation Fund and other investors, including the Mayo Clinic, this initiative will accelerate research and make these therapies more accessible to patients. Radiopharmaceuticals, capable of treating over 50 types of cancer, offer a promising alternative to traditional treatments and could significantly impact the estimated 1.9 million new cancer diagnoses expected in 2023. This investment underscores Fox Chase's commitment to advancing cancer treatment and making lifesaving therapies available to a broader patient base.

title: Fox Chase Researcher Mitchell Fane Awarded $255000 Grant to Explore Relationship Between Aging and Melanoma
summary: Mitchell Fane, PhD, an Assistant Professor at Fox Chase Cancer Center, has received a $255,000 grant from the Melanoma Research Alliance to explore the link between aging and how the immune system can reactivate metastatic melanoma. This study is in line with Fane's interest in the molecular mechanisms behind cancer cell dormancy and the reactivation of metastasis in aging pre-metastatic niches. The Melanoma Research Alliance, the top nonprofit supporter of melanoma research, funds this project as part of its dedication to forwarding science that could lead to new melanoma treatments, a major public health issue with more than 100,000 cases diagnosed in the U.S. each year. The grant is a component of the MRA's Young Investigator Award program, which also acts as a training ground for early career scientists. Fane's research might change how cancer is modeled in preclinical studies, given that most cancer cases and deaths occur in older individuals, while current models and clinical trials usually target younger people.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center and Temple University Hospital Recertified Under ASCO's Quality Oncology Practice Initiative
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center and Temple University Hospital – Main Campus have been recertified under the Quality Oncology Practice Initiative (QOPI) by QOPI Certification Program LLC, acknowledging their adherence to nationally recognized standards for quality cancer care. This three-year recertification highlights the hospitals' commitment to excellence in outpatient hematology-oncology practices. This achievement is particularly significant as it marks the first time hematology-oncology outpatient services at Temple University Hospital – Main Campus are included. The certification process involved a voluntary comprehensive site assessment against specified standards consistent with national guidelines. The QOPI program, affiliated with the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO), aims to help practices improve the quality of care provided to patients through self-assessment and improvement programs. Fox Chase first achieved certification in January 2020, and this recertification underscores the continuous dedication to high-quality, equitable cancer care.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Opens First New Jersey Location in Voorhees
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center proudly announces the opening of its first New Jersey location in Voorhees, aimed at providing convenient access to its comprehensive cancer care services for patients in the region. Located at 502 Centennial Boulevard, Suite 7, the new office specializes in urologic oncology, benign urologic conditions, plastic and reconstructive surgery, and radiation oncology consults. This expansion responds to the needs of approximately 20% of Fox Chase’s patients who travel from New Jersey to Philadelphia for treatment. The Voorhees location offers a range of services including treatment for various cancers such as prostate, kidney, bladder, and testicular cancer, as well as benign conditions like hematuria and erectile dysfunction. The site boasts a team of experienced providers, including Alexander Kutikov, MD, FACS, and Eric Horwitz, MD, FABS, FASTRO, who bring over 65 years of combined experience and have contributed significantly to over 700 peer-reviewed research articles. This initiative underscores Fox Chase’s commitment to extending its nationally recognized urology department's expertise to more conveniently serve patients, emphasizing both the management of urologic cancers and benign conditions.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Welcomes Dr. Joyce G. Habib
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia has announced the appointment of Dr. Joyce G. Habib as an Assistant Professor in the breast medical oncology program within the Department of Hematology/Oncology. Dr. Habib has a rich background in medical oncology, having earned her medical degree from the American University of Beirut, completed her internal medicine residency and medical oncology fellowship at Baylor University Medical Center, and undergone postfellowship training in clinical research at the Jules Bordet Institute in Brussels. Prior to joining Fox Chase, she held an assistant professorship at the University of Arkansas, focusing on breast cancer, and served as a consulting oncologist in various hospitals and clinics in Beirut and Dubai. Dr. Habib is also the founder of FACEcancer.org, a non-governmental organization aimed at improving cancer literacy and access to care in the Middle East, and serves as an expert consultant for the World Health Organization. She is board certified in internal medicine and medical oncology and is a member of several professional societies.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center and Fels Cancer Institute for Personalized Medicine Faculty Present Research at the 65th ...
summary: Researchers from Fox Chase Cancer Center and Fels Cancer Institute for Personalized Medicine will present six research projects at the 65th American Society of Hematology (ASH) Annual Meeting & Exposition in San Diego, California, from December 9-12, 2023. These presentations will explore topics such as targeting DNA damage response pathways to eliminate myeloproliferative neoplasms, the potential clinical applications of disabling DNA Polymerase Theta in DNMT3A mutated myeloid malignancies, and administering prephase steroids to older patients with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Also, the effectiveness and safety of Elranatamab in black patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma will be examined, as well as the differing functions of ERK2 substrate binding in myeloproliferative neoplasm, and targeted clonal medicine for DNA damage response in eradicating AML. Fox Chase Cancer Center is recognized as a leading comprehensive cancer center in the United States, renowned for its significant contributions to cancer research and treatment.

title: University Hospital to undergo $18M renovation to address capacity concerns
summary: The University of Michigan Health's University Hospital South in Ann Arbor is set to undergo an $18 million renovation to add a 26-bed unit, addressing capacity concerns. This development comes as a result of beds soon to be lost due to the termination of an intra-hospital agreement with Trinity Health Ann Arbor, which will reclaim its 26-bed inpatient unit this fall. The renovation, approved by the university's Board of Regents, aims to offset the loss of capacity and manage high adult inpatient demand, which often exceeds 90%. The new unit will be located on level five of University Hospital South, a space currently utilized for non-clinical purposes, with the renovation funded by health system resources. The design will be managed by Troy-based Integrated Design Solutions, with completion expected by spring 2025.

title: U-M Health, Holland Hospital begin 3-year 'strategic alliance'
summary: The University of Michigan Health and Holland Hospital have started a three-year strategic partnership to improve the availability of specialty care for patients in western Michigan. This collaboration, which is neither a merger nor an acquisition and does not alter the ownership or governance of Holland Hospital, seeks to offer local access to specialized treatments and more options for patients. Holland Hospital, which has 2,060 employees and 189 licensed beds, caters to around 250,000 patients from Ottawa and Allegan counties. The alliance will enable most patient care to be administered locally in Holland or at U-M Health-West in Wyoming, with referrals to U-M Health's main campus in Ann Arbor for highly specialized care. This partnership is expected to enhance the patient experience by providing access to U-M Health specialists and centers for various health conditions. This partnership reflects a wider trend of hospital consolidation in Michigan, driven by financial difficulties and staffing shortages in the healthcare industry.

title: A New Chapter for Michigan | University of Michigan Sparrow
summary: Sparrow Health System, which has served Mid-Michigan for 128 years, has been renamed University of Michigan Health-Sparrow after officially integrating with the University of Michigan Health. This partnership is designed to give Mid-Michigan residents better access to top-tier care, specialized treatments, and cutting-edge technology locally. The collaboration enhances local healthcare, broadens access to specialty care, and upgrades facilities and technology by combining the strengths of both entities. Doctors from the University of Michigan Health will continue working at Sparrow facilities, ensuring the continuity of high-quality care and services. This integration furthers their joint goal of improving health services in Michigan and beyond, focusing on community-centric care and using academic and clinical resources to achieve superior patient outcomes.

title: 2,335 University of Michigan healthcare workers unionize
summary: Over 2,300 healthcare workers at the University of Michigan Medicine have unionized, joining the Service Employees International Union (SEIU). This group includes patient care technicians, phlebotomists, unit clerks, and other patient services workers. Their unionization follows the earlier inclusion of 283 respiratory therapists and technicians in July 2023. Unionization efforts were driven by desires for a stronger voice in the workplace, better pay, benefits, and quality patient care, especially in light of disparities observed during the COVID-19 pandemic between unionized and non-unionized workers. SEIU is also organizing an additional 2,000 workers at Michigan Medicine. This move reflects a broader trend of healthcare workers unionizing to address workplace concerns and improve conditions for both staff and patients.

title: Holland Hospital, University of Michigan Health form strategic alliance
summary: Holland Hospital and University of Michigan Health have formed a strategic alliance to enhance healthcare services in the lakeshore region. This partnership, effective immediately and approved by both organizations' boards, aims to extend specialty medical care offered by University of Michigan Health to Holland Hospital. The three-year agreement will focus on identifying opportunities to support high-quality clinical services locally, aiming to improve access to care, offer patients greater choice and value, and keep care close to home. Despite the alliance, Holland Hospital will remain an independent entity. This collaboration builds on a previous partnership in clinical areas such as neuroscience and is part of Holland Hospital's efforts to expand its market presence in the lakeshore area, including the development of new primary care offices.

title: The D. Dan and Betty Kahn Health Care Pavilion at University of Michigan Health, Ann Arbor, Michigan: First Look ...
summary: The D. Dan and Betty Kahn Health Care Pavilion at University of Michigan Health in Ann Arbor, Michigan, is a significant expansion project set to open in the fall of 2025. This $920 million facility will feature a 264-bed capacity, including a state-of-the-art neurosciences center, specialty services for cardiovascular and thoracic patients, 20 surgical suites, and three interventional radiology suites. Designed to increase the capacity for highly complex inpatient care and improve the availability of single private rooms, the pavilion will also facilitate the conversion of rooms from acute care to intensive care as needed. Spanning 12 stories with five floors dedicated to patient rooms and a separate 24-bed ICU, the top two floors are designed as respiratory infectious containment units. The pavilion aims for environmental sustainability, targeting a 49% reduction in CO2 emissions and LEED Platinum certification, which would make it the largest healthcare project with this designation in the country. The project emphasizes the use of materials and designs that reduce energy and water use, contributing to Michigan Medicine's goal of carbon neutrality.

title: COVID-19 Vaccine Information and Update
summary: The University of Michigan Health is experiencing high demand for the 2023-24 COVID-19 vaccines, leading to quickly booked appointments. They are working to increase appointment availability as supply and staffing permit. The CDC advises that everyone aged 6 months and older should receive the updated vaccine, which targets the most current variants and boosts protection against COVID-19. For those 5 and older, it's recommended to get the updated vaccine at least 8 weeks after any previous dose. Immunocompromised individuals should consult their care team about additional doses. Young children who haven't been vaccinated should receive two or three doses depending on the vaccine, and if previously vaccinated, one dose of the 2023-24 vaccine at least 8 weeks after the last dose. U-M Health offers the Pfizer vaccine, and appointments can be scheduled online or by phone. Patients vaccinated elsewhere are urged to update their records with U-M Health.

title: Street closures coming near University of Michigan hospitals in Ann Arbor
summary: Street closures and restrictions are planned near the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor due to two projects, including a bridge widening. The East Medical Center Drive bridge rehabilitation and expansion, a $14-million project shared between the University of Michigan and the city, is set to begin on March 25. This project has faced opposition due to concerns over pedestrian and cyclist safety, leading to design adjustments. Traffic restrictions on Fuller Road are scheduled between March 25 and April 26, with lane closures during specific hours. Additionally, Glen Avenue will be closed from March 27 to March 30 for crane removal from a construction site. This will affect traffic patterns and detours will be in place. The construction aims to address the bridge's deteriorating condition and improve access to the hospital complex, with completion expected by mid-2025.

title: University of Michigan Health-West eyes opportunities in building statewide system
summary: University of Michigan Health-West is exploring opportunities to expand into a statewide system, according to its President Ronald Grifka. Despite the challenges facing the healthcare industry, Grifka emphasizes the importance of maintaining a focus on delivering exceptional patient care. This initiative reflects the organization's commitment to enhancing healthcare services and accessibility across Michigan, aiming to better serve the community's needs while navigating the complexities of the healthcare landscape.

title: 2,300 workers at University of Michigan Health unionize
