summary: More than 2,300 employees at the University of Michigan Health have unionized, joining the Service Employees International Union Healthcare Michigan. This expansion includes patient care techs, phlebotomists, unit clerks, and patient services employees, adding to the already unionized 283 respiratory therapists and technicians at Michigan Medicine. This move is part of a growing labor movement within the Ann Arbor-based health system, where about 80% of the workforce is now represented by labor unions. Employees have cited the disparities in wages, benefits, and working conditions between unionized and non-unionized workers, especially highlighted during the coronavirus pandemic, as a key reason for unionizing. The union is also making efforts to organize another 2,000 workers at Michigan Medicine. This surge in union membership is seen as a way for workers to have a voice in the workplace and to fight for better pay, benefits, and quality patient care.

title: Clinton | University of Michigan Sparrow
summary: UM Health-Sparrow Clinton, located at 805 S. Oakland Street, St. Johns, MI, is a Joint Commission accredited critical access hospital offering a wide range of medical services. It features an active swing bed program and a certified Level IV Trauma Center. The hospital provides emergency services, diagnostic imaging, surgical services, heart and cancer care, and has a primary care physician practice and a physical therapy and fitness center. Additionally, it supports the community through food distribution, scholarships, health fairs, and partnerships. Recent expansions include a $5.7 million Emergency Services Department, funded partly by community donations. UM Health-Sparrow Clinton has earned the Pathway to Excellence® designation and The Joint Commission’s Gold Seal of Approval® for Primary Care Medical Home Certification. It also celebrates nursing excellence with the DAISY Award. The hospital offers amenities like convenient parking, Wi-Fi, a cafeteria, a gift shop, and a healing garden. Services include cancer and infusion care, cardiac rehabilitation, cardiology, emergency services, fitness center, laboratory services, orthopedics, pharmacy, primary care, pulmonary services, radiology, rehabilitation, sleep center, surgical services, transitional care, and wound care services.

title: Tampa General Hospital to Establish Dr. Jagadamba and Krishna Chivukula Men's Center with $6.5 Million Gift from ...
summary: Tampa General Hospital announced the establishment of the Dr. Jagadamba and Krishna Chivukula Men's Health Center, funded by a $6.5 million donation from the Chivukula family. The center aims to provide comprehensive primary and preventive care for men, complementing the services offered by the USF's Pamela Muma Women's Health Center. It will offer annual visits, priority access for various health care needs, and personalized care plans. The donation, marking the Chivukula family's first to the TGH Foundation, reflects their commitment to health and wellness. Tampa General is currently planning the center's location and aims to begin construction soon, with an opening planned for 2025. The hospital is recognized for its high-quality care and extensive health system, including a wide range of specialized services and community support.

title: TGH chaplain helps patients and staff navigate grief
summary: Chaplain Joon Park has been offering emotional and spiritual support to staff and patients at Tampa General Hospital (TGH) for almost nine years. His distinctive method of grief counseling, shaped by his difficult childhood and Korean background, highlights the significance of accepting loss and sadness together with celebration. Park's latest book, "As Long As You Need - Permission to Grieve," merges personal recollections, hospital anecdotes, and a manual for dealing with grief. Through his efforts and literature, Park seeks to assist people in discovering resilience in their most challenging moments, leveraging his cultural heritage and life experiences.

title: Tampa General Hospital renames children's hospital after 'largest gift ever'
summary: Tampa General Hospital is renaming its children's hospital to Muma Children’s Hospital at TGH following a significant donation from Pam and Les Muma, marking the largest gift in the hospital's history. The exact amount was not disclosed, but it is noted as the most substantial contribution to TGH and the largest ever received by any children’s hospital in the region. This donation is part of a broader effort to transform healthcare, increase access to top-tier medical care across Florida, and promote health and wellness in communities. The Muma Children’s Hospital at TGH will offer specialized services and medical care, including a Level I pediatric trauma center. The Mumas have a long history of supporting Tampa General Hospital and the University of South Florida, with their name already associated with several initiatives and facilities within TGH and USF Health.

title: Introducing the Muma Children's Hospital at Tampa General Hospital: More than a new name, it's advancing care for ...
summary: The Muma Children’s Hospital at Tampa General Hospital (TGH) represents a significant advancement in pediatric healthcare, thanks to the substantial philanthropy of Pam and Les Muma. Their latest donation, the largest ever received by any children's hospital in the region, has enabled the renaming and enhancement of the facility. This state-of-the-art pediatric center, located in the Tampa Bay area, offers comprehensive care for children, from newborns to young adults, covering a range of needs from simple injuries to complex, life-threatening conditions. The hospital benefits from the expertise of TGH and the USF Health Morsani College of Medicine, providing a multidisciplinary approach to healthcare. The Mumas, motivated by the loss of their newborn daughter at TGH in 1973, have been long-time supporters, including funding the Jennifer Leigh Muma Neonatal Intensive Care Unit in 2006. Their contributions support TGH’s mission to offer world-class pediatric care in Florida.

title: Tampa General Hospital Honored as a Leading Industry Innovator by Modern Healthcare
summary: Tampa General Hospital (TGH) has been recognized by Modern Healthcare as one of the ten organizations nationwide in the Innovators Class of 2024 for its significant contributions to healthcare innovation. This recognition highlights TGH's efforts in creating the Tampa Medical and Research District, aimed at improving patient outcomes through a culture of innovation. TGH has collaborated with GE Healthcare to develop the CareComm Command Center, leveraging artificial intelligence and predictive analytics to enhance care coordination, patient safety, and experience. The hospital's $550 million capital commitment supports advanced technology and the development of a comprehensive medical and research district, including a proton therapy center and a Behavioral Health Hospital. This initiative not only advances patient care but also promotes collaboration and innovation across sectors. Additionally, TGH's partnership with Palantir and its venture capital arm, TGH Ventures, further demonstrate its commitment to integrating cutting-edge technologies and fostering innovation within the healthcare industry.

title: Tampa General Hospital breaks ground on tower for surgery, neuroscience and transplants
summary: Tampa General Hospital has initiated construction on a new 12-floor medical tower dedicated to surgery, neuroscience, and transplant services, marking a significant phase in its $550 million master plan. The 565,000-square-foot facility, located adjacent to the hospital's main campus on Davis Islands, is set to open in 2027. Named after the Taneja family, major contributors to the project, the tower will feature 144 beds, 32 operating suites, an expanded intensive care unit, educational spaces, and two floors reserved for future expansion. This development aims to address the hospital's growing need for more beds to serve the community's critically ill patients. The Taneja family's donation is part of a broader $120 million in contributions received by the TGH Foundation over two years.

title: Tampa General Hospital Reveals the "Muma Children's Hospital at TGH," Celebrating a Historic Charitable ...
summary: Tampa General Hospital announced the renaming of its children's hospital to "Muma Children's Hospital at TGH" in honor of Pam and Les Muma's significant charitable contribution. The Mumas, long-time supporters of the hospital, made a historic donation to support pediatric health services, marking the largest gift to any children's hospital in the region. This contribution aims to enhance access to world-class care and promote health and wellness among children in Florida. The Muma Children's Hospital at TGH offers a wide range of specialized services and medical care, including a Pediatric Trauma Center verified as Level I. The hospital's approach integrates addressing children's psychological, social, and developmental needs alongside medical treatment. The Mumas' philanthropy is part of their broader support for Tampa General and the community, reflecting their commitment to improving pediatric healthcare.

title: Tampa General Hospital Employs New Ultrasound Therapy Designed to Treat Life-Threatening Hypertension
summary: Tampa General Hospital has introduced an innovative ultrasound therapy, the Paradise Ultrasound Renal Denervation (RDN) System, to treat patients with life-threatening hypertension. This FDA-approved technology, a first for the region, uses ultrasound energy to target and ablate renal nerves, aiming to lower high blood pressure. The minimally invasive procedure allows most patients to return home the same day. This new method could significantly impact the treatment of hypertension, a condition that contributes to a high number of deaths annually in the U.S. The procedure is specifically designed for patients whose hypertension cannot be managed through traditional therapies. By reducing the activity of sympathetic nerves around the renal arteries, the technology offers a novel approach to controlling this prevalent health issue.

title: Tampa General Hospital Named Top Hospital in Tampa Bay, Recognized as One of Newsweek's World's Best ...
summary: Tampa General Hospital (TGH) has been named the top hospital in Tampa Bay and the third in Florida, marking its sixth consecutive year being recognized as one of Newsweek's World's Best Hospitals. This year, TGH ranked 77th among US hospitals, improving from its previous 84th position. The ranking is based on medical expert opinions, patient experiences, hospital quality metrics, and Patient Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs). Additionally, TGH has received accolades including Newsweek's Greatest Workplaces for Women and Diversity 2024, Forbes' America's Best Large Employers 2024, and U.S. News & World Report's High-Performing Hospitals for Maternity Care among others. Tampa General, a 1,040-bed not-for-profit academic health system, is recognized for its comprehensive care, including Level I trauma and comprehensive burn care, and is a primary teaching hospital for the USF Health Morsani College of Medicine.

title: Tampa General Hospital, Manatee County and ArcherFRS Introduce First-In-The-Nation Program to Deliver Life-Saving ...
summary: Tampa General Hospital, Manatee County, and Archer First Response Systems (ArcherFRS) have initiated a groundbreaking program in the United States for delivering crucial emergency response supplies via drone. This project is designed to improve response times for health emergencies for those eligible to call 9-1-1 within Manatee County, beginning May 1. The drones can carry an automated external defibrillator (AED), NARCAN Nasal Spray, and a tourniquet, greatly enhancing survival rates and health outcomes for people suffering from sudden cardiac arrest, opioid overdose, or severe injuries. This first-of-its-kind program in the country follows rigorous safety protocols and aims to broaden its reach and operating hours with further permissions from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). This innovative method of emergency response marks a significant move towards leveraging technology to save lives and enhance community health services.

title: Tampa General Hospital Completes Acquisition of Bravera Health and Introduces "TGH North"
summary: Tampa General Hospital (TGH) has completed its purchase of the Bravera Health network, introducing "TGH North" as a major expansion of its academic health system into Citrus and Hernando counties in Florida. This incorporation brings together multiple hospitals, emergency rooms, ambulatory surgery centers, and clinics previously managed by Community Health Systems, Inc. into TGH, with the goal of improving healthcare services and accessibility for local communities. TGH North will work in conjunction with the USF Health Morsani College of Medicine to merge clinical care, education, and research, thus providing advanced medical technologies, resources, and treatments. The expansion features TGH Spring Hill, TGH Brooksville, TGH Crystal River, one standalone ER, two ambulatory surgery centers, and ten primary and specialty care clinics. Through this acquisition, TGH's network now encompasses six hospitals, over 150 care locations, and nearly 14,000 team members and providers, delivering sophisticated complex care throughout 23 Florida counties.

title: Tampa General Hospital and Kitson & Partners Announce Partnership to Offer World-Class Care to Residents of ...
summary: Tampa General Hospital (TGH) and Kitson & Partners have announced a partnership to provide world-class healthcare to the residents of Babcock Ranch, America's first solar-powered town. This collaboration aims to integrate Tampa General's leading healthcare services with Babcock Ranch's innovative community, emphasizing technology and innovation in care. A new TGH Urgent Care Powered by Fast Track facility will open at Babcock Ranch in 2025, designed to meet the urgent health needs of the community with a 6,500-square-foot clinic. This initiative addresses the growing demand for local, quality healthcare due to the rapid expansion of Babcock Ranch, which plans for 19,500 residences and 6 million square feet of commercial space. The partnership reflects both organizations' commitment to enhancing community health through advanced and accessible medical services.

title: Tampa General Hospital Recognized as One of America's Greatest Workplaces for Women by Newsweek
summary: Tampa General Hospital (TGH) has been recognized by Newsweek as one of "America's Greatest Workplaces for Women 2024," making it one of fewer than 50 Florida-based employers to receive this honor. This recognition is based on various factors, including compensation, work-life balance, and diversity management. TGH's commitment to creating an equitable workplace is underscored by its significant percentage of female leadership, with 80% of its roughly 600 leaders being women, nearly half of whom hold senior and executive positions. The hospital has actively addressed the needs of its team members through initiatives like the TGH-USF People Development Institute (PDI), which offers free courses in partnership with the University of South Florida Muma College of Business, and provides on-site daycare, among other benefits. This acknowledgment is in addition to TGH's growing list of awards for team member satisfaction, workplace culture, and environment.

title: State Law Names TGH Behavioral Health Hospital One of First Behavioral Health Teaching Hospitals in Florida
summary: The TGH Behavioral Health Hospital, working with the University of South Florida (USF), has been recognized as one of the first behavioral health teaching hospitals in Florida under a new state law. This effort, celebrated by Tampa General Hospital (TGH) and USF, also marks the creation of the Florida Center for Behavioral Health Workforce at USF's Louis de la Parte Florida Mental Health Institute. The legislation seeks to improve access to behavioral health services and tackle the shortage of professionals in this area. The TGH Behavioral Health Hospital, which is currently being built, will function as a cutting-edge facility for both inpatient and outpatient treatment, catering to the needs of patients of all ages. This project is expected to raise the standard of behavioral health care and education in Florida, aiding in the training of medical students and residents with the help of experienced practitioners. The hospital is planned to open in 2025 and will be operated by Lifepoint Behavioral Health, with a focus on evidence-based care. This collaboration represents a major move forward in enhancing mental health services and accessibility in Tampa and surrounding areas.

title: South Broward Hospital District places Lubby Navarro on administrative leave, deactivates credit card
summary: Lubby Navarro, a former Miami-Dade public school board member and current registered lobbyist in the Government Affairs Department at Memorial Regional Hospital, has been placed on administrative leave by the South Broward Hospital District. This action was taken following an emergency meeting concerning Navarro, during which her company credit card was also deactivated. The decision comes in the wake of an investigation into Navarro's use of a school board-issued credit card for personal expenses, allegedly amounting to around $100,000. The South Broward Hospital District board has initiated an investigation into Navarro, focusing on issues such as undocumented receipts. Navarro, who was one of only eight people in the hospital district with a corporate card, is under scrutiny to ensure there was no financial misconduct overlapping with her time on the school board.

title: South Broward Hospital District launches internal probe on former Miami-Dade School Board member Lubby Navarro
summary: The South Broward Hospital District has started an internal probe into Lubby Navarro, a former Miami-Dade School Board member, over claims she misused a work credit card for personal use. Navarro, now facing public corruption charges and on unpaid leave, is accused of spending over $100,000 on unauthorized shopping and travel in 2022 while on the school board. The hospital district is closely examining her spending, with Navarro's lawyer asserting her innocence and calling her a truthful community worker. Miami-Dade County Public Schools Superintendent, Dr. Jose Dotres, plans to increase oversight to avoid such issues, highlighting the need to keep public trust. The timeline for the investigation is still unknown.

title: Broward Health, Memorial Healthcare System break ground on 1st joint facility - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Broward Health and Memorial Healthcare System have started building the first joint freestanding emergency department in Sunrise to meet the healthcare needs of an area known as a "medical desert." The 18,041 square foot facility on a 4-acre site at 9001 W. Oakland Park Blvd. aims to serve about 15,000 patients a year. Broward Health will handle adult emergency care, and Memorial Healthcare System's Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital staff will provide pediatric emergency services. Expected to finish in early 2025, the project is designed by HKS Architects and built by Skanska. It will have a $10.8 million economic impact and seeks to provide quicker patient care with advanced diagnostics and radiology, improving the treatment of critical conditions. This initiative reflects a wider movement in South Florida to create more freestanding emergency departments.

title: Memorial Healthcare System could expand Pembroke Pines facility - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Memorial Healthcare System plans to significantly expand its emergency care facilities in Pembroke Pines, Florida. The expansion involves constructing a new 30,200-square-foot emergency department on a 20-acre site at 801 S. Douglas Road, which will include 20 exam rooms, five triage bays, 16 fast track rooms, and a trauma room, along with CT and X-ray machines. This new facility aims to replace the existing 13,750-square-foot freestanding emergency department, enhancing capacity and care efficiency. The Broward County Commission is set to review a plat change for the project on December 12. The construction is expected to take 13 to 15 months. Additionally, Memorial Healthcare System has recently undertaken other expansions, including opening a cancer care center and primary care centers in the region, and purchasing land for future development focused on wellness and potentially affordable housing.

title: Broward Health buys office building in suburb - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Broward Health has acquired a medical office building in Coral Springs for $11 million, continuing its active involvement in real estate acquisitions and development. The property, located at 9600 W. Sample Road, was sold by Eden Sample LLC, managed by Gideon Harari. The 40,926-square-foot office building, built in 1974 on a 1.34-acre site, was represented by Jonathan Thiel of Berger Commercial Realty. The purchase price reflects a strong demand for medical office space in Broward County, with the property's value nearly doubling from its last sale price of $5.8 million in 2018. Broward Health plans to use the building for medical office space, including retaining its pediatric diabetes center and accommodating third-party medical tenants. This acquisition is part of Broward Health's broader real estate strategy, which includes purchasing another medical office in Pompano Beach and proposing to buy a 10-acre site in Parkland for new developments.

title: Memorial Healthcare finds success with switch to Epic-based telehealth vendor
summary: Memorial Healthcare System, a large public health system in South Florida, has significantly improved its telehealth services by partnering with KeyCare, an Epic-based virtual care company. Previously, Memorial faced challenges with its third-party vendor for on-demand virtual urgent care, including inconsistent patient experiences and quality concerns due to limited data sharing. In January 2023, Memorial adopted KeyCare to provide a seamless virtual care experience, leveraging Epic's interoperability features for better data sharing and integration. This switch has led to reduced wait times to approximately 10 minutes, a decrease in low-acuity visits to office or emergency room slots, and a high net promoter score of 87 for virtual care. The collaboration with KeyCare has enabled Memorial to expand its digital front door, optimize care team capacity, and maintain a strong connection with patients through a nationwide network of virtual care providers. This partnership exemplifies the successful integration of technology to enhance patient care and provider coordination.

title: Technology Helps Memorial Healthcare System Patients Help Themselves
summary: Remote monitoring technology is significantly benefiting patients and healthcare providers at Memorial Healthcare System. Jules Penn, a 73-year-old patient with heart failure, experienced a dramatic improvement in his condition through the use of a CardioMEM sensor implanted in his heart. This sensor allows for the remote transmission of vital data to his cardiology team, enabling early detection and management of potential issues. Memorial Healthcare System has connected with over 800 patients, utilizing various remote monitoring devices that integrate directly with patients' electronic medical records, thereby eliminating the need for manual data transmission. This approach has led to nearly 50% reduction in hospital admissions, over 22% decrease in readmissions, 27% fewer emergency department visits, and increased primary care visits. The system has saved more than $4 million in hospital and emergency services, emphasizing the value of remote patient monitoring in improving patient outcomes and reducing healthcare costs.

title: Solis Mammography partners with public health system to open community-based imaging centers
summary: Solis Mammography, a private equity-backed radiology provider, has partnered with Memorial Healthcare System to open community-based imaging centers in Florida. This collaboration, which began in early 2023, aims to provide convenient access to advanced mammography screening services across South Florida, including in Weston, Plantation, and Hialeah. The partnership initially involved Solis Mammography managing three hospital-based women’s imaging centers in Hollywood and Pembroke Pines. The new centers will offer 3D mammography and flexible scheduling to facilitate early detection of breast cancers. Solis Mammography, founded in 1986 and having expanded significantly after a majority stake sale to Madison Dearborn Capital Partners in 2018, now operates 125 locations across 17 major markets. This expansion aligns with their mission to enhance breast cancer detection and care.

title: Memorial Regional Hospital plans major expansion (Photos)
summary: Memorial Healthcare System is planning a significant expansion of its flagship hospital, Memorial Regional Hospital, located at 3501 Johnson Street in Hollywood. The expansion involves the construction of a new eight-story tower north of the existing one, which will include a new patient drop-off area. The new tower will span 292,662 square feet, primarily housing surgical rooms, critical care beds, and staff facilities, increasing the hospital's total size to 1.18 million square feet. The first floor will feature an outpatient clinic, a lobby, and a gift shop, while the second floor will have 23 surgery rooms and 53 post-op recovery rooms. The third floor will include a pharmacy, conference room, simulation labs, and a rehabilitation facility. The next five floors will each have 30 patient beds, adding up to 150 beds. This expansion is part of Memorial Healthcare System's broader growth plans, including updating its maternity ward and high-risk pregnancy unit and expanding its Emergency Care Center in Pembroke Pines.

title: Memorial Healthcare System could expand Pembroke Pines facility - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Memorial Healthcare System is planning a significant expansion of its Emergency Care Center in Pembroke Pines, with the Broward County Commission set to review a plat change for the 20-acre site. The expansion includes constructing a new 30,200-square-foot freestanding emergency department, which will feature 20 exam rooms, five triage bays, 16 fast track rooms, and a trauma room, along with CT and X-ray machines. This new facility will replace the current 13,750-square-foot emergency department and is expected to provide a larger capacity for patient treatment and more efficient care delivery. Construction is anticipated to take 13 to 15 months. Plans for the existing emergency department, which may be converted into a primary care center, have not been finalized. This expansion is part of Memorial Healthcare System's broader efforts to enhance healthcare services in the region, including recent openings of a cancer care center and primary care centers in various locations.

title: Scripps Health CMO Shares Top 4 Priorities for 2024
summary: Anil Keswani, Scripps Health's Corporate Senior Vice President and Chief Medical and Operations Officer for Ambulatory Care, has outlined the top four priorities for Scripps Health in 2024. These priorities aim to enhance the organization's performance and patient care. Firstly, Keswani is focusing on improving Scripps' financial health by effectively managing costs, especially following the coronavirus pandemic. This includes being financially responsible and optimizing the use of assets, such as reviewing the use of surgical robots to avoid unnecessary purchases. Secondly, promoting operational excellence is crucial, with a focus on adopting artificial intelligence solutions to improve clinical note-taking and patient communication. Thirdly, Keswani is committed to improving access to care and patient engagement through the "Getting to Yes" initiative, which seeks to overcome barriers to patient-provider interactions that arose during the pandemic. Lastly, engaging and developing staff is a priority, recognizing the importance of keeping a motivated and informed workforce during significant changes in the healthcare sector.

title: JPM24: Scripps Health hires former FBI cybercrime lead
summary: Scripps Health, a San Diego nonprofit, has strengthened its cybersecurity by appointing Todd Walbridge, a former FBI cybercrime head, as the senior director of corporate and system safety and security. This action follows a 2021 cyberattack on Scripps Health that led to losses exceeding $100 million in revenue, class-action lawsuit settlements, and impacted surrounding healthcare facilities. Although efforts to bolster cybersecurity continue, the precise method of the breach remains unclear. Scripps Health has also partnered with CrowdStrike for ongoing system surveillance to avert future breaches. The leadership underscores the inevitability and high cost of cyberattacks, encouraging other providers to enhance their cybersecurity resilience. This strategic appointment and emphasis on cybersecurity are in line with Scripps Health's dedication to improving both physical and cyber protection amid growing cyberattack threats and their significant financial and operational consequences.

title: A first of its kind locally, Scripps doctors are now using ultrasounds to monitor IBD
summary: Doctors at Scripps Clinic in San Diego County are the first to use ultrasound technology to monitor patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), including conditions like ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. This innovative approach, led by gastroenterologists Gauree Konijeti, M.D., and Rebecca Matro, M.D., allows for the examination of the disease's progression and the effectiveness of treatments during routine appointments. Unlike traditional methods such as colonoscopies, MRIs, or CT scans, ultrasound exams are non-invasive, requiring no bowel preparation, fasting, or anesthesia. This method not only aids in the timely monitoring of the disease but also enhances patient understanding of their condition by allowing them to view and discuss ultrasound images in real-time with their physicians. Most insurance plans, including Medicare, cover IBD ultrasound exams, making it an accessible option for patient care.

title: Scripps innovation leader sees huge potential for AI
summary: Dr. Sanjeev Bhavnani, a senior cardiologist at Scripps Clinic, highlights the significant potential of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare, emphasizing its role in Scripps Health's AI deployments. He discusses the importance of federal policy and self-regulation for ensuring AI safety in the medical field. Bhavnani's insights come from his experience working with the FDA's Digital Health Center of Excellence and his involvement in clinical AI applications. His perspective underscores the critical need for establishing safety measures and guardrails to navigate the future of AI in healthcare effectively.

title: Healthcare workers protest maternity ward closure outside Scripps Health event
summary: Healthcare workers protested outside the Hotel Del Coronado against the planned closure of Scripps Mercy Hospital's maternity ward in Chula Vista, advocating for the importance of maintaining maternity services in the South Bay area, especially for low-income, women of color who may lack access to transportation. The protest coincided with Scripps Mercy Foundation's Mercy Ball, aiming to appeal directly to donors. Scripps Health intends to consolidate the maternity ward with another in Hillcrest, San Diego, citing the need to meet increasing patient demands in other departments. Critics argue that this move leaves only one maternity unit in the southern part of the county and could endanger lives in obstetrical emergencies due to increased distance. Despite Scripps Health's assurances of ensuring safe emergency labor and delivery services, healthcare workers and some doctors have expressed significant concerns, with some reaching out to the California Department of Public Health for an impact investigation.

title: California healthcare provider's move shows pitfalls of Medicare Advantage
summary: Scripps Health, a major healthcare provider in Southern California, announced it will no longer accept patients enrolled in Medicare Advantage starting next year. This decision affects 32,000 seniors in San Diego, forcing them to find new healthcare options or insurance for 2024. The move highlights a significant downside to Medicare Advantage plans: the lack of guarantee to continue with preferred healthcare providers due to possible network changes. Scripps Health's decision is driven by financial losses exceeding $75 million on Medicare Advantage patients this year, attributed to inadequate payment rates from insurance companies and the high cost of treating sicker patients. The situation underscores the instability in provider networks for Medicare Advantage enrollees, emphasizing the financial and health considerations in choosing between traditional Medicare and Advantage plans. This development has led to a scramble among affected seniors, with options including switching healthcare providers or insurance coverage, despite potential challenges such as higher costs and navigating a complex market.

title: Assess AI/ML needs by clinical importance
summary: Dr. Sanjeev Bhavnani of Scripps Health highlights the significance of integrating AI and machine learning in clinical care, emphasizing the necessity to prioritize developments based on clinical importance. He points out challenges in the clinical adoption of AI/ML technologies, including barriers posed by FDA policies. The discussion reflects on the broader context of healthcare innovation and the need for regulatory frameworks that support the safe and effective implementation of AI tools in clinical settings. This conversation underscores the potential of AI/ML to transform healthcare but also calls attention to the hurdles that must be overcome to realize this potential fully.

title: Scripps Health in Chula Vista closing maternity ward due to patient bed demand
summary: Scripps Mercy Hospital in Chula Vista is closing its maternity ward to reallocate beds to patients needing emergency care, surgeries, and other services due to a rise in demand. The maternity services are being moved to the Scripps San Diego campus in Hillcrest, although pre and post-natal care will still be available in Chula Vista. This decision comes as the hospital's inpatient medical-surgical beds are often fully occupied, while the maternity ward typically uses only half of its beds. The change aims to reduce wait times for emergency and surgical patients and expand cardiac care among other services. The move affects 135 staff jobs, but they will have the opportunity to fill other positions within Scripps Health. The transition, described as a consolidation rather than a closure, will not occur for at least 90 days.

title: Headed to Scripps Health? Masking protocols have changed
summary: Scripps Health in San Diego has reinstated certain face mask requirements due to a rise in COVID-19 and influenza cases after the holidays. The updated protocols mandate that staff, patients, and visitors wear medical-grade masks in direct patient care areas. However, masks are not necessary in non-clinical buildings or most general areas of its facilities. Medical-grade masks are strongly recommended in confined or crowded spaces, such as elevators and waiting rooms. Cloth masks and those with valves are not allowed. Visitors showing flu-like symptoms are advised against visiting. The policy allows COVID-19 patients to have visitors, who must adhere to strict infection control measures, including mask-wearing and eye protection. These visitation rules may change in response to public health recommendations.

title: Scripps Health CEO Calms Disputes By Opening The Books
summary: Scripps Health CEO Chris Van Gorder, after a career-ending injury as a police officer, transitioned into healthcare management, eventually becoming the CEO of Scripps Health. Under his leadership, Scripps faced significant challenges, including a $20 million operating loss and high employee turnover. Van Gorder's approach to resolving disputes and leading the organization involved opening the company's financial books to employees and forming a Physician Leadership Cabinet to involve doctors in decision-making processes. This strategy led to a financial turnaround, generating $240 million in cost savings and significantly increasing profits. Van Gorder emphasized transparent communication and shared decision-making as key to his leadership success, fostering an environment of trust and collaboration among the staff. His leadership during stressful times, including the pandemic and a cyberattack, was noted for its calm and steady approach, helping to navigate Scripps through crises.

title: Two Large Medical Groups Shun Medicare Advantage Plans
summary: Two large medical groups within Scripps Health in San Diego are pulling out of Medicare Advantage contracts for 2024, impacting 30,000 seniors due to low payment rates and prior authorization problems. Scripps CEO Chris Van Gorder pointed to yearly losses over $75 million as the reason for leaving, highlighting the unsustainable financial strain from low payments, denials, and administrative expenses. Scripps will keep accepting traditional Medicare and has MA contracts with its independent physician associations, but those enrolled with Scripps Coastal and Scripps Clinic Medical Group will need to find new doctors or coverage options. This could indicate a broader national trend as healthcare providers reconsider their involvement in MA plans due to financial and operational difficulties.

title: Scripps Clinic Must Pay Almost $7M to Older Docs in Age Bias Case
summary: Scripps Clinic Medical Group in San Diego has been ordered by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) to pay almost $7 million to older doctors impacted by its retirement policy based on age. This policy, introduced in 2014, mandated the retirement of doctors 75 years and older, breaching federal anti-age discrimination laws despite being legal under California state law. The group, with 750 doctors, revoked the policy in 2018 after an EEOC investigation but did not acknowledge any wrongdoing. The settlement is aimed at resolving age discrimination concerns, especially amid debates on the capability of aging doctors. This situation underscores the conflict between state laws permitting mandatory retirement ages and federal laws forbidding age discrimination.

title: Allegheny Health Network to free host cancer screenings in Monroeville next month
summary: Allegheny Health Network is set to host free cancer screenings in Monroeville at AHN Premier Medical Associates on June 8. The screenings will cover a variety of cancers including breast, cervical, colorectal, head and neck, lung, prostate, and skin cancer. For eligibility and more details on the event, individuals are encouraged to visit the specified link. This initiative is part of efforts to enhance cancer detection and prevention in the community.

title: Highmark and Allegheny Health Network announce $1 billion investment in Allegheny General Hospital
summary: Highmark Health and Allegheny Health Network (AHN) announced a $1 billion investment in Allegheny General Hospital, their flagship academic medical center. This investment will fund the construction of a new patient tower for cardiovascular care and a new emergency department. The initiative aims to enhance patient experiences and outcomes, ensure equitable access, and promote wellness through personalized care models. This development is part of a 10-year transformation plan that includes additional construction and renovation projects, extending the Living Health model championed by AHN and Highmark. The new cardiovascular tower, expected to begin construction in early 2025 and open by 2030, will feature over 100 inpatient beds, a dedicated cardiovascular intensive care unit, physician offices, and other amenities. The project will proceed in phases to minimize disruptions.

title: Allegheny Health Network introduces program to treat insomnia
summary: Allegheny Health Network has launched a new program aimed at treating insomnia. This initiative is designed to address the sleep disorder by providing patients with effective, evidence-based solutions. Through this program, individuals suffering from insomnia will have access to specialized care and treatment options tailored to their specific needs. The program aims to improve the quality of sleep for those affected, enhancing their overall health and well-being.

title: New Data from Cedar, Highmark Inc. and Allegheny Health Network Validates that Payer-Provider Collaboration is Key ...
summary: New data from Cedar, Highmark Inc., and Allegheny Health Network highlights the importance of collaboration between payers and providers in enhancing the billing process in healthcare. Despite advancements, consumers still face frustrations with receiving multiple, uncoordinated bills for a single care visit. To tackle this, the partnership utilized Cedar Pay integrated with a Payer Intelligence Layer, leading to a $17 million increase in payments and 90% customer satisfaction. This approach not only simplifies billing for consumers by integrating billing information and insurance data but also increases HSA/FSA utilization by 33% and reduces customer service requests by 11%. The success of this initiative underscores the potential of collaborative efforts in resolving the complexities of healthcare billing, emphasizing the need for a connected financial experience in the healthcare industry.

title: Bio-Rad and Allegheny Health Network Cancer Institute Collaborate to Advance Personalized Monitoring of Solid ...
summary: Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc., a leader in life science research and clinical diagnostics, is collaborating with Allegheny Health Network (AHN) Cancer Institute to enhance personalized monitoring of solid tumor cancers using Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR) technology. This partnership aims to generate clinical evidence for the use of Bio-Rad’s ddPCR technology in molecular residual disease (MRD) monitoring of patients with solid tumor cancer post-curative treatment. MRD monitoring is crucial for detecting both remission and potential relapse in patients. Bio-Rad’s ddPCR technology offers high sensitivity, precision, and absolute quantification, potentially enabling earlier and more accurate molecular response detection compared to other technologies like next-generation sequencing. The collaboration leverages Bio-Rad’s expertise in digital PCR technology and AHN’s cancer care knowledge, clinical data, and patient samples from the AHN Cancer Institute’s Moonshot program. This initiative could lead to improved patient outcomes by facilitating more timely and effective therapeutic interventions.

title: Allegheny Health Network Oncology Experts Dive Into Updates Within the Gynecologic Oncology Space
summary: Experts from Allegheny Health Network (AHN), led by Eirwen M. Miller, MD, provided updates in gynecologic oncology with a focus on endometrial, cervical, and ovarian cancers, during a recent OncLive State of the Science Summit™. They discussed the latest data from the 2023 ESMO Congress and ASCO Annual Meeting, emphasizing the move towards personalized treatment plans. This includes the use of PARP inhibitors, antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs), and the importance of new targets in ovarian cancer. Key updates included the role of tumor testing in endometrial cancer, highlighting the need for molecular profiling in treatment planning, and advancements in cervical cancer treatment, such as combining pembrolizumab with chemoradiation. For ovarian cancer, the focus was on the use of PARP inhibitors, particularly after recent FDA indication withdrawals, except for patients with a BRCA mutation. The summit also discussed the promising role of ADCs and the potential of new targets in ovarian cancer treatment. The event highlighted the rapid progress in gynecologic oncology and the importance of continuous education and clinical trials to improve patient care.

title: Case Study: Allegheny Health Network's ROI with Rev Cycle Solution
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN), a Pennsylvania-based health network generating $4.5 billion in annual revenues, has significantly improved its revenue cycle by investing in the digitization and automation of patient billing. This initiative, aimed at addressing the challenges of uncoordinated bills and unclear communications between patients, payers, and providers, was developed in partnership with Highmark Health. The solution, a financial engagement platform from Cedar, integrates payer, provider, and financial institution data to offer patients a seamless financial experience, including a portal for payment plans and self-service tools. This approach not only caters to customer preferences but also streamlines the billing and insurance process. The implementation of this tool has led to a $17 million increase in patient payments, a 33% rise in the use of HSA/FSA accounts, and an 11% reduction in call center inquiries, indicating both financial success for AHN and improved patient satisfaction.

title: Allegheny Health Network, Healthcare Marketing Impact Awards 2023
summary: Allegheny Health Network won the bronze for Purpose-Led Campaign of the Year among providers and insurers at the Healthcare Marketing Impact Awards 2023. This accolade was for their "Cai and Kate" YouTube series, created to help young children and their caregivers understand emotions, in response to the increasing demand for child behavioral health services. The Pittsburgh-based network, which includes 14 hospitals in New York and Pennsylvania, collaborated with the marketing agency Mower on this project. The series features a staff therapist using a chameleon puppet and colors to teach children aged 3 to 6 how to articulate their feelings and process emotions, aiming also to reduce mental health stigma among adults. The campaign involved various promotional materials, including a themed coloring book, postcards, and in-office posters. Within two weeks of its launch, the series reached 2.5 million people, garnered an estimated publicity value of $6,700, received 43 mentions on social media, and attracted over 32,000 views on YouTube without digital advertising expenditure.

title: Allegheny Health Network Advances Virtual Critical Care Service with Launch of New, In-House 'TeleICU' Program
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN) and Highmark Health have introduced a new 'TeleICU' program to enhance virtual critical care services across western Pennsylvania. This innovative telehealth initiative connects AHN's intensivists and a specialized care team with ICU bedside caregivers at six community-based hospitals in the region, providing 24/7 monitoring and management of critically ill patients. Utilizing FDA-approved eCareManager software from Philips, the program supports continuous ICU patient monitoring through advanced clinical algorithms, real-time monitors, electronic medical records, and two-way audio-visual conferencing. Launched in response to the success of a similar program initiated in 2019 and the demands of the COVID-19 pandemic, TeleICU aims to improve patient outcomes by enabling local hospitals to offer enhanced care with the support of centralized, expert intensivist oversight. Studies have indicated that such telemedicine ICU services can reduce mortality rates and shorten hospital stays. TeleICU is part of Highmark Health's Living Health strategy, which seeks to leverage digital technology to provide convenient, high-quality health care.

title: Health system lands AMA well-being recognition on second try
summary: Allegheny Health Network received silver-level recognition from the AMA Joy in Medicine™ Health System Recognition Program on their second attempt, after initially failing to meet the criteria for bronze-level recognition in 2022. This achievement reflects the health system's commitment to improving physician satisfaction and reducing burnout. AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld highlighted the importance of joy in medicine as a standard for evaluating health systems. Allegheny Health Network, with its 14 hospitals and over 200 primary and specialty care practices, has been actively working to address physician burnout, which saw a peak of 52% in 2022 but decreased to 46% in 2023. Efforts to achieve recognition included following the AMA's roadmap, removing mental health questions from applications, appointing wellness leaders in departments, and allowing physicians to accelerate compliance training. These steps, along with leadership support and collaboration across departments, have been key to their success.

title: Dr Tariq Cheema Discusses Allegheny Health Network's Virtual ICU Program
summary: Dr. Tariq Cheema, division chair of pulmonary critical care sleep and allergy medicine at Allegheny Health Network (AHN), discusses the benefits of the virtual ICU (vICU) program. This innovative program allows critical care to be administered remotely, enabling patients to receive care from the comfort of their homes. It has significantly improved patient outcomes by reducing the length of ICU stays, minimizing the need for patient transfers between hospitals, and decreasing the time patients spend on ventilators. The vICU program has been particularly impactful in supporting peripheral hospitals and enhancing patient satisfaction by allowing patients to remain in their communities while receiving expert care. Additionally, the program has been beneficial for hospitals in rural communities, offering them the expertise of critical care physicians and nurses 24/7, thus enabling these hospitals to manage critically ill patients more effectively and retain them within the community.

title: Allegheny Health Network raises hourly minimum wage to $18
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN) announced it will increase its minimum hourly wage to $18, starting at the end of March. This raise will affect approximately 1,700 employees who are currently earning close to the previous minimum wage of $16 an hour. The wage adjustment is aimed at benefiting those in entry-level positions critical to patient care, such as environmental, dietary services, and patient care technicians. AHN's president, Jim Benedict, emphasized the organization's commitment to valuing its workforce, which plays a crucial role in achieving its mission. Additionally, Highmark Health, AHN's parent company, plans to implement the $18 hourly minimum wage across the organization by the end of the year. AHN, employing about 22,000 people, positions itself as a leading employer in the region, offering competitive compensation and benefits to attract and retain staff.

title: CHOMP announces forgiveness of medical debts incurred during Covid.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula (CHOMP) has announced the forgiveness of 100% of medical debts incurred by patients during the first three years of the Covid-19 pandemic, from 2020-2022. This decision affects 29,000 patient accounts and totals approximately $40 million in patient responsibility. Dr. Steven Packer, president and CEO of Montage Health, highlighted the significant burden of medical debt on households across America and the devastating impacts of the pandemic on Monterey County's individuals, families, and businesses. The forgiveness aims to alleviate financial stress from various community members, including hospitality workers, seniors on fixed incomes, teachers, fieldworkers, and small business owners. CHOMP's action comes amid potential competition from Kaiser Permanente and follows a wrongful termination lawsuit loss, suggesting motives beyond generosity.

title: Montage Health Celebrates Grand Opening of Ohana's Revolutionary Innovative Campus for Youth Mental Health Care
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Montage Health celebrated the grand opening of Ohana, a revolutionary 55,600-square-foot campus in Monterey, CA, dedicated to youth mental health care. Funded by a $106 million donation from philanthropist Bertie Bialek Elliott, Ohana is the largest privately funded youth mental health program in the U.S. The campus offers a holistic approach to treatment, supporting not only the patient but also their family and support network, with services including prevention, early intervention, family care management, outpatient and residential care, and emergency services. Treatments are evidence-based and family-centered, involving multidisciplinary teams and various therapies. The design of the campus, recognized for its innovative features by the American Institute of Architects and Fast Company, aims to promote healing and well-being. Ohana serves patients and families throughout Monterey County and beyond, with plans to expand residential services in spring 2024. The initiative is seen as a critical step in addressing the public health crisis of adolescent mental health.

title: MONTAGE HEALTH SELECTS XEALTH TO DRIVE DIGITAL HEALTH
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Montage Health, a nonprofit healthcare organization in Monterey County, California, has partnered with Xealth, a leader in digital health technology, to enhance its digital health strategy across its system. This collaboration, announced on July 11, 2023, aims to simplify the process for medical providers to utilize Montage Health's digital health portfolio, thereby improving patient experiences. By centralizing tools, leveraging automation, and integrating these into the care team workflows, the initiative will facilitate the faster and easier distribution of mobile apps, patient education, and additional resources to promote greater wellbeing. This approach is expected to not only streamline the distribution of digital health programs, including remote patient monitoring, but also to provide care teams with insights into the performance of each tool with patients. The partnership will initially focus on digital health programs that support orthopedics, behavioral health, patient education, and consumer wellness, aiming to reduce the time-consuming task of finding the right information for patients and improve the ability to measure program impact.

title: CHOMP's future with Aetna still uncertain; state cracks down on insurer violations.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: CHOMP's future with Aetna remains uncertain as the state imposes nearly $5 million in fines on California's seven largest health plans, including Aetna and Anthem, for not meeting the legal threshold of correctly paying 95% of claims. Meanwhile, Anthem Blue Cross has secured a deal with Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula (CHOMP), offering lower co-pays and deductibles to thousands of Monterey County public employees and others. This agreement, effective from January, is attributed to CHOMP's efforts in reducing healthcare costs. Aetna has yet to reach such an agreement with CHOMP, with the latter inviting Aetna to discuss a reasonable cost management approach while maintaining quality. The deal with Anthem benefits those insured by the California Public Employee Retirement System, the Monterey County School Insurance Group, Monterey Peninsula College, and Pebble Beach Company.

title: In 25 years as CHOMP’s CEO, Steve Packer has led a big expansion. He expects AI to play a role in the next 25.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Steve Packer has been the CEO of CHOMP, which is now a part of Montage Health, for 25 years. During his time, he has overseen its growth from a 150-bed hospital to a 250-bed facility. Additionally, the number of services and staff expanded from 1,200 to 2,800 employees. Under Packer's leadership, Montage Health has grown beyond just providing acute care to becoming a more integrated system. This includes Montage Medical Group, MoGo Urgent Care, Ohana, and Aspire Health Plan. Packer, who was a former pulmonary critical care physician, moved into administration after being encouraged by board members. He has dealt with challenges such as the impact of the Affordable Care Act, which significantly increased Medi-Cal enrollment in Monterey County, and issues with inadequate government reimbursement rates for healthcare services. On a personal level, Packer keeps himself healthy through golf, travel, intermittent fasting, and a routine of cardio and weights. Looking forward, he believes AI will have a significant impact on healthcare, enhancing physician-patient interactions and efficiency.

title: Montage Health launches a fund for teachers to seek grants toward health care costs.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Montage Health has started a fund to help teachers in Monterey County with their healthcare expenses. Announced by Montage CEO Steve Packer at the company's yearly meeting, the Montage Health Fund for Teachers will offer grants up to $1,000 for teachers at any educational level in both public and private schools in the county. This effort, initially funded with $5 million by Montage Health and managed by the Community Foundation for Monterey County, aims to reduce the financial strain of healthcare costs, including insurance premiums. The fund addresses the high healthcare costs faced by insured individuals and is part of wider discussions involving teachers' unions, insurance policies, and local healthcare providers. The initiative is expected to launch before the end of the 2023-24 school year, with more information forthcoming.

title: A fired Montage employee wins nearly $10 million in a lawsuit for unlawful retaliation.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: A former Montage employee, Jared Stiver, won a lawsuit against the Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula and Montage Health, receiving $9.95 million in damages for unlawful termination. The jury found that Stiver was terminated in retaliation for reporting violations of patient care regulations and whistleblower protection laws. Stiver, who was hired in 2007 and worked at the Tyler Heart Institute at CHOMP, claimed that administrators retaliated against employees who reported issues related to patient care, billing practices, and regulatory violations. The jury agreed with Stiver's claims, awarding him $4.95 million for lost compensation and $5 million in punitive damages after a three-week trial. Montage Health plans to appeal the decision, stating the verdict does not reflect their values and practices centered on patient care and staff well-being.

title: CHOMP requiring masks during winter respiratory virus season to protect patients, staff and visitors.
hco: COMMUNITY HOSPITAL OF THE MONTEREY PENINSULA
summary: Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula (CHOMP) is implementing a mask mandate for everyone in patient care areas from November 1, 2023, to January 31, 2024, due to the winter respiratory virus season, which now includes COVID-19 and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), among others. This measure aims to protect patients, staff, and visitors. Montage Health, CHOMP's parent company, also recommends masks for patients and visitors in its other facilities but requires them for staff in patient care areas. Dr. Martha Blum, a Montage Health infectious disease expert, emphasized the importance of providing a safe environment for all, especially the medically vulnerable. The mask requirement applies regardless of vaccination status and may extend beyond January 31, depending on the community's respiratory illness status.

title: RI children's hospital employee accused of placing hidden camera in staff bathroom
summary: An employee at Hasbro Children's Hospital in Providence, Rhode Island, was accused of installing a hidden camera in a staff bathroom. The camera, disguised as a USB wall charger, was discovered by another employee who then alerted the Providence police and Lifespan security. Following an investigation, Jason Baker, 47, admitted to the police that the device was his. He was arrested and charged with one count of video voyeurism. Baker was subsequently fired from his position at the hospital and is no longer permitted access to any Lifespan facilities. The incident is still under further investigation.

title: Lifespan urges Rhode Islanders to participate in clinical trials - Providence Business First
summary: Lifespan is actively encouraging Rhode Islanders to participate in local clinical trials, emphasizing the convenience of not having to travel to Boston for experimental treatments. Rhode Island Hospital, a part of Lifespan, ranked 15th nationally in securing NIH grants, with 86 grants totaling $38 million in 2023. Lifespan is conducting 196 active studies on 898 conditions, including cancer and Alzheimer’s. Bharat Ramratnam, Lifespan's vice president of research, highlighted the organization's commitment to improving health without financial incentives in bringing medical devices and interventions to market. Lifespan's clinical trials are crucial for educational purposes and are independent, focusing solely on scientific and academic missions. Ramratnam advises those interested in participating to consult their primary care physician or Lifespan's website. Additionally, a research pact named BIRCH, involving Brown University, Lifespan, and Care New England, aims to enhance biomedical research and the state's economy.

title: Rhode Island Hospital nurse critically injured in assault sues security company
summary: A registered nurse at Rhode Island Hospital, Scott Amaral, is suing Allied Universal Security Services for being severely injured in an attack by a psychiatric patient, George Bower, in the Jane Brown building. Amaral claims the security guards did not stop the attack or intervene properly; one was on her cellphone close by, and another only acted after a hospital employee tackled Bower. Amaral experienced a heart attack and permanent brain damage from the event. Allied Universal has not commented on the lawsuit.

title: Hidden camera found in staff bathroom at Hasbro Children’s Hospital
summary: A hidden camera was discovered in a staff bathroom at Hasbro Children’s Hospital, leading to the arrest of employee Jason Baker, 47, who confessed to placing the device. The camera, disguised as a USB wall charger, was found by a staff member and was located in a bathroom not accessible to patients or the public. Providence police conducted a thorough search of all hospital bathrooms and found no additional devices. Baker has been fired and may face further charges as the investigation continues. The hospital is providing support to affected staff, emphasizing their welfare as a top priority.

title: Mount Sinai Medical Center First to Utilize AI Technology to Treat Complex Aortic Conditions at South Florida's Only ...
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach, Florida, has become the first institution in Eastern Florida to implement a unique AI software, developed through a collaboration between Cydar Medical and Medtronic. This software supports the treatment of complex aortic diseases using minimally invasive endovascular technology. The AI-based Cydar Maps software integrates with Medtronic services to enhance patient care by generating a 3D map of the patient's vascular system, supporting preoperative planning, intraoperative guidance, and postoperative reviews. This technology aims to reduce radiation exposure, simplify workflows, and increase clinician confidence. Dr. Micheal Ayad, Co-Director of the Aortic Center, highlighted the benefits of decreased radiation and dye usage, which lowers the risk of kidney function issues post-surgery. The Aortic Center employs a multidisciplinary approach involving cardiac surgeons, vascular surgeons, cardiologists, and geneticists to provide customized solutions for aortic and endovascular conditions. Cydar Medical's CEO, Paul Mussenden, expressed pride in Mount Sinai's adoption of their product, aiming to make surgeries more predictable and efficient. Mount Sinai Medical Center, established in 1949, is a significant independent teaching hospital in South Florida, known for its Centers of Excellence in various medical fields.

title: Cardiovascular Surgery at the Mount Sinai Hospital Wins Highest Quality National Ratings from Society of Thoracic ...
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: The Department of Cardiovascular Surgery at The Mount Sinai Hospital has received the top three-star ratings from the Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) in every cardiac surgery category for the years 2020-2023. This distinction is based on the STS Adult Cardiac Surgery Database and assesses institutions on quality, safety, and outcomes for five common cardiovascular procedures, indicating superior cardiovascular surgery results. Mount Sinai stands out for its comprehensive excellence across different surgical areas, showcasing the skill of its team and its large number of surgeries. Over 800 member institutions use the STS registry to show their dedication to improving quality in cardiovascular care. Mount Sinai Fuster Heart Hospital is among the world's best and is the top hospital in New York for cardiology and heart surgery. The Mount Sinai Health System is the largest academic medical system in New York City, renowned for its excellent care and medical and health innovations.

title: Mount Sinai Buys Westchester “Small Hospital” Dev Site
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: Mount Sinai Medical Center acquired a development site in Westchester, Miami-Dade County, for $32 million, aiming to expand its healthcare services. The site, previously home to CarLux Miami auto dealership, spans 5.6 acres at 8250 and 8200 Southwest Eighth Street. This purchase is part of Mount Sinai's growth strategy to enhance access to its healthcare brand, as stated by CEO Gino Santorio. The transaction follows an inquiry about the possibility of building a "small hospital" with fewer than 100 beds on the property. Mount Sinai operates 12 locations across Miami-Dade and Monroe counties and is planning to open the Irma and Norman Braman Comprehensive Cancer Center in 2025. This move is indicative of a broader trend of hospitals in South Florida actively engaging in real estate acquisitions to expand their healthcare facilities.

title: South Florida doctor accused of hate crime in 2021 battery avoids prison with plea deal
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: Dr. Jennifer Wright, an anesthesiologist at Mount Sinai Medical Center in South Florida, avoided prison time for a 2021 hate crime incident through a plea deal. The incident involved Wright attacking a Hispanic man outside a supermarket, where she became agitated after he asked her in Spanish to maintain distance due to COVID-19 guidelines. Wright responded by damaging his vehicle with her keys, assaulting him physically, and telling him to return to his country. The attack happened on the day President Joe Biden was inaugurated, and Wright, a Trump supporter, faced hate crime charges. With the plea deal, she admitted guilt to battery and criminal mischief, receiving a sentence of one year of probation and mandatory participation in racial sensitivity and anger management training.

title: BIOTRONIK, INC. Announces First US Implant of Next-Generation Amvia Edge Pacemaker
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: BIOTRONIK, INC. has announced the first U.S. implantation of its next-generation Amvia Edge pacemaker, marking a significant advancement in implantable medical device technology. The procedure was successfully performed by Dr. Raul Weiss at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami, Florida. Amvia Edge is distinguished by its MRI Guard 24/7 feature, the only dedicated, always-on MRI sensor in the market, designed to simplify device management during MRI scans by automatically switching the device to MRI mode and back, eliminating the need for pre- or post-scan programming. Additionally, the device introduces EarlyCheck, which automates pre-discharge checks by sending a device report and IEGM to the BIOTRONIK Home Monitoring Service Center shortly after implantation. Amvia Edge also offers Atrial ATP (aATP) for automatic therapies in response to detected stable atrial arrhythmias, potentially reducing atrial tachycardia burden and avoiding atrial remodeling. This innovation aims to optimize clinical workflows and enhance patient care.

title: America's Best Physical Rehabilitation Centers 2023
hco: MOUNT SINAI MEDICAL CENTER OF FLORIDA INC
summary: Newsweek, in collaboration with Statista, has announced the 2023 rankings for America's Best Physical Rehabilitation Centers, recognizing 280 leading inpatient facilities across the United States. This annual ranking is designed to aid millions of Americans in finding top-tier care for recovery from surgery, chronic conditions, illnesses, or injuries. The selection is based on expert surveys, quality metrics, and accreditation data, highlighting facilities that excel in providing intensive therapy and multidisciplinary care. Additionally, some centers are noted for standout programs in specialized areas such as amputation, brain injury, cancer, spinal cord injury, and stroke rehabilitation. The ranking encompasses over 1,000 inpatient centers nationwide, reflecting the diverse and extensive options available for patients seeking rehabilitation services.

title: Sylvester Brain Tumor Institute Launches to Personalize Brain Cancer Treatment - InventUM
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: The Sylvester Brain Tumor Institute (SBTI) has been launched by the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine to advance personalized treatment for brain cancer, focusing on challenging cases like glioblastoma. Directed by Antonio Iavarone, M.D., with co-directors Macarena de la Fuente, M.D., Ricardo Komotar, M.D., and Anna Lasorella, M.D., SBTI aims to enhance research and clinical efforts in brain cancer care. By fostering collaboration across multiple disciplines, the institute seeks to develop targeted treatments through the study of individual tumors, utilizing patient-derived organoids and xenografts for precision medicine. This initiative is part of Sylvester's broader commitment to addressing hard-to-treat cancers and improving patient outcomes through innovative research and clinical trials.

title: Transformational $50 million gift from Kenneth C. Griffin to boost Sylvester's research footprint
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: The University of Miami announced a $50 million donation from Kenneth C. Griffin to the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, part of the University of Miami Health System and the Miller School of Medicine. This contribution is set to double Sylvester's research capacity, accelerating the development of new therapies, enhancing patient care, and expanding access to clinical trials through a new 244,000-square-foot facility, the Kenneth C. Griffin Cancer Research Building, opening in 2025. This donation, part of the University's $2.5 billion Ever Brighter fundraising campaign, marks Griffin's largest philanthropic gift in Florida and is among the top ten healthcare-related philanthropic gifts in the state over the last decade. Griffin's support is aimed at advancing cancer research and treatment, benefiting families in South Florida and beyond. Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine-Cava and University of Miami officials expressed gratitude for Griffin's generosity, highlighting its impact on the community's fight against cancer and its contribution to making Miami a leader in healthcare excellence.

title: Philanthropist Ken Griffin donates $50M to University of Miami's Sylvester Cancer Center
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Philanthropist Ken Griffin has donated $50 million to the University of Miami’s Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center. This significant contribution by Griffin, CEO of Citadel LLC, will support the construction of a new 12-story, 244,000-square-foot Transformational Cancer Research facility at the Miller School of Medicine’s Comprehensive Cancer Center. The Sylvester Center, which recently renewed its National Cancer Institute designation, making it the only center with such distinction in South Florida, will rename the facility the Kenneth C. Griffin Cancer Research Building. This donation is part of the University's Ever Brighter fundraising campaign, with the building expected to open next year.

title: Kenneth Griffin's $50 Million Donation Elevates Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center's Fight Against Cancer
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Kenneth C. Griffin has donated $50 million to the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, part of the University of Miami Health System and the Miller School of Medicine, aiming to significantly enhance cancer research and treatment in South Florida. Announced on March 5, 2024, this contribution is dedicated to constructing a new 12-story, 244,000-square-foot facility named the Kenneth C. Griffin Cancer Research Building, expected to open in 2025. This facility will double Sylvester's research capacity, accelerate the development of new therapies, improve patient care, and increase access to clinical trials. This donation, the largest philanthropic gift in Florida for cancer research and treatment, is seen as transformative, potentially improving outcomes for cancer patients by enabling innovative research and attracting top-tier talent. The Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, the only National Cancer Institute-designated center in South Florida, underscores its commitment to excellence in patient care, research, and education. Griffin's donation is a significant step in the fight against cancer, offering hope and healing to many.

title: Sylvester Opens Satellite Office in Naples - InventUM
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, part of UHealth – University of Miami Health System, opened its first satellite office outside Southeast Florida in Naples on November 1, 2023. This new facility is the first NCI-designated Cancer Center to serve Naples and the surrounding areas, aiming to reduce the human burden from cancer by improving access to multi-disciplinary care, including clinical trials. The Naples care team offers various patient services, such as appointment scheduling, telehealth visits, and coordination for clinical trial participation. Additionally, Sylvester plans to expand its community outreach in Naples with cancer screenings and education on early detection. The office also aims to provide holistic care addressing the physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs of cancer patients, emphasizing survivorship and supportive care. Furthermore, Sylvester's collaboration with the North Collier Fire Department is part of its efforts to reduce cancer burden through the global Firefighter Cancer Initiative. The Naples office is expected to be a vital resource for cancer support services and research opportunities, particularly benefiting local patients like Lori Breyman, who has been participating in clinical trials for metastatic uveal melanoma.

title: Zubrod Memorial Lecture Spotlights Outstanding Cancer Research - InventUM
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: The 23rd Zubrod Memorial Lecture, held on November 17, was a significant event at the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, University of Miami Miller School of Medicine. It celebrated the legacy of Dr. Charles Gordon Zubrod, a pioneer in chemotherapy and the center's founding director. The lecture featured Laurie Glimcher, M.D., discussing key aspects of human blood development and immune response. Awards were presented to faculty for outstanding research in various categories, including the first Early-Stage Investigator of the Year. Additionally, the event showcased over 100 scientific posters, highlighting the center's ongoing research efforts. This annual lecture not only honors Dr. Zubrod's contributions but also underscores the center's commitment to advancing cancer research and treatment.

title: Mock Drill Tests UHealth's Readiness for a Complex Disaster - InventUM
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: The University of Miami Health System conducted a comprehensive disaster simulation named “Operation Fallen Archangel” to test its emergency response capabilities in conjunction with local, state, and national agencies. The drill, mimicking a terrorist attack, involved a scenario where a small passenger jet crashed into a shuttle bus carrying VIP French dignitaries at the University of Miami’s medical campus. The exercise featured nearly 300 participants, including first responders from 17 different emergency agencies, and used realistic effects to simulate injuries and damages. This drill, one of the most complex to date, aimed to evaluate and improve the readiness for mass casualty incidents, including the evacuation of hospital patients under emergency conditions. The simulation underscored the importance of preparedness for potential disasters, given the medical campus's proximity to Miami International Airport and its high air traffic. Feedback from the exercise will be used to enhance future response strategies and ensure patient safety in real disaster scenarios.

title: Businessman and philanthropist Kenneth C. Griffin celebrated for his landmark $50 million gift to Sylvester
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Kenneth C. Griffin, a prominent businessman and philanthropist, has donated $50 million to the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, which is part of the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine and UHealth—University of Miami Health System. This donation is part of the University's $2.5 billion Ever Brighter fundraising campaign and will help build the 12-story, 244,000-square-foot Transformational Cancer Research Building. This building aims to double Sylvester's research capabilities, improve patient care, and increase access to clinical trials. In recognition of Griffin's donation, the building will be named the Kenneth C. Griffin Cancer Research Building. This contribution is seen as a significant step forward for the cancer center, with the potential to speed up the development of new treatments and make strides towards eliminating cancer. Griffin's donation is considered a critical moment for the community, with the potential to benefit millions in South Florida and beyond.

title: Business leader and philanthropist Ken Griffin makes $50 million gift to University of Miami
