hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Business leader and philanthropist Ken Griffin has donated $50 million to the University of Miami, specifically to the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center. This substantial gift will fund the Transformational Cancer Research Building, now renamed the Kenneth C. Griffin Cancer Research Building, on the Medical Campus. This new 12-story, 244,000-square-foot facility will double the center's research capacity, enhancing efforts to develop new therapies, improve patient care, and expand access to clinical trials. This donation is part of the University's $2.5 billion Ever Brighter fundraising campaign and marks the second $50 million contribution for the research building, the first being made anonymously in 2020. Griffin's donation is seen as transformative, potentially propelling the Miller School of Medicine into the top tier of research-focused medical schools and encouraging more medical students to specialize in oncology. This building symbolizes a commitment to advancing cancer research and treatment, promising a brighter future in the fight against cancer.

title: Community Impact: A Collaborative Approach to Cancer - InventUM
hco: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI HOSPITAL SYLVESTER COMPREHENSIVE CANCER CENTER
summary: Rachelle Theodore, who moved to South Florida from Haiti, became a health advocate after her father's fatal car accident exposed her to healthcare disparities. She founded CLT Business Solutions, focusing on oncology and reducing South Florida’s cancer burden. Theodore joined Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center’s Community Advisory Committee (CAC) in 2022, aiming to align the cancer center with community needs and enhance cancer research and detection. As co-chair, she initiated subcommittees to foster community-academy partnerships, emphasizing early cancer detection. The CAC conducts listening sessions to identify health challenges and bridge gaps between the community and healthcare providers, promoting equitable access to healthcare and research opportunities. Their efforts include advising on less-invasive HPV screenings in Little Haiti, significantly impacted by high cervical cancer rates. Theodore’s work with the CAC and Sylvester’s mobile Game Changer vehicles exemplifies a collaborative approach to addressing cancer prevalence and healthcare inequities in South Florida.

title: Warren General Hospital Notifies 168,921 Patients of September 2023 Data Breach
summary: Warren General Hospital (WGH) in Pennsylvania reported a data breach affecting 168,921 patients to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Office for Civil Rights on November 9, 2023. The breach occurred between September 15 and September 23, 2023, when an unauthorized party accessed WGH's computer systems. This breach compromised sensitive patient information, including names, addresses, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, financial and payment card information, health insurance details, and medical treatment information. WGH has since sent notification letters to those affected, advising them on how to protect themselves from potential fraud or identity theft and discussing their legal options. The hospital detected unusual activity on September 24, 2023, secured its systems, notified law enforcement, and engaged data security specialists to investigate. Warren General Hospital, founded in 1900, is a community hospital with an 87-bed facility and employs over 640 people, generating around $75 million annually.

title: Warren General Hospital suffered data breach potentially affecting employees, patients
summary: Warren General Hospital in northwest Pennsylvania experienced a data breach earlier this year, potentially compromising the confidential information of both current and former patients and employees. The breach was first noticed on September 24, 2023, when suspicious activity was detected in the hospital's network. An investigation revealed that between September 15 and September 23, 2023, an unauthorized individual accessed the hospital's computer systems and downloaded sensitive information, including names, addresses, Social Security numbers, financial and payment card information, health insurance claims, medical diagnoses, medications, lab results, and treatment details. Warren General Hospital has since taken steps to secure their system, notified law enforcement, and is in the process of notifying those potentially affected. They are also advising individuals to monitor their accounts for fraudulent activity and have provided additional security training to prevent future breaches.

title: New equipment: Local contributions help Warren General Hospital purchase ultrasound machine
summary: Warren General Hospital has acquired a new ultrasound machine for its Emergency Room, thanks to funding from the Community Foundation of Warren County, DeFrees Family Memorial Funds, and the Libonati Fund. This point-of-care ultrasound machine is a significant addition, allowing for instant imaging of organs, tissues, and structures inside the body without radiation, enhancing patient care. It enables faster diagnosis of traumatic injuries and cardiac arrests, improves the success rate of IV insertions, reduces patient discomfort and complications, and decreases wait times and costs. The machine supports FAST exams for quick trauma assessment and is critical for guided insertion of central IV lines in critically ill patients, offering a rapid visual assessment of the lung in respiratory illnesses. This advancement is expected to shorten patient discomfort duration and improve treatment outcomes, aligning with the American Board of Emergency Medicine's standard of care for ultrasound-guided insertions.

title: Donate Life Month celebrated at Warren General Hospital
summary: Warren General Hospital, in partnership with the Center for Organ Recovery & Education, transplant recipients, donor families, and others, marked Donate Life Month on March 28 by hoisting the Donate Life Flag. This ceremony underscored the critical role of organ donation, as illustrated by Caleb Hultman's narrative. Hultman, who passed away in June 2020 at 25, became an organ donor, influenced by a relative's heart donation. National Donate Life Month, celebrated every April, seeks to enhance organ donation awareness and pay tribute to those involved in donation and transplantation processes. The theme for 2024, inspired by stars, represents hope and the lifesaving beacon that donation offers. Christine Stone from CORE highlighted a milestone year in 2023, with close to 2,000 transplants and tissue donations, 229 of which occurred at Warren General Hospital. The event also included a grateful testimony from a woman who received a dual corneal transplant at the facility. Since its introduction in 2006, the Donate Life flag has symbolized support, unity, remembrance, and hope for organ donation throughout the U.S. during April.

title: WGH reports first operating loss in five years
summary: Warren General Hospital (WGH) reported its first operating loss in five years, amounting to nearly $1.5 million for the last fiscal year. Despite an increase in service volumes and gross revenue, which led to a slight net revenue increase, expenses rose by approximately 2%, resulting in a 1.5% net loss. The CEO, Rick Allen, attributed the loss to higher costs from employing agency and travel nurses, salary increases, drug manufacturers bypassing government discount programs, and general inflation. This financial downturn comes after a period of profitability following a reorganization in 2018 and contrasts with the static or slightly decreasing expenses seen in the previous five years. Additionally, patient volume increased, with more inpatient and outpatient service days reported. Despite the loss, WGH is performing better than other small hospitals in western Pennsylvania. The hospital also made strategic acquisitions and infrastructure improvements, including acquiring pediatric and OB-GYN services, opening new office spaces, and upgrading technology and facilities.

title: Above and beyond: Berg recognized with DAISY Award while Dunham received Bee Award
summary: Lindsey Berg, a registered nurse at Warren General Hospital, was honored with the DAISY Award for her exceptional care and professionalism, especially in a case involving a young patient's surgery for a large kidney stone. Karin Dunham received the BEE Award for her extraordinary act of kindness, helping a visitor clean a bloodied van outside the hospital, a task beyond her duties in environmental services. Both awards highlight the commitment of hospital staff to go above and beyond in their roles, with the DAISY Award recognizing outstanding nurses and the BEE Award honoring non-nursing staff for exceptional service. These accolades underscore the importance of compassion and dedication in healthcare, celebrating individuals who significantly impact patients and their families.

title: Paula’s Promise donates comfort bags to WGH | News, Sports, Jobs
summary: Paula's Promise, a foundation named the Paula S. Cousins Ovarian and Endometrial Cancer Foundation Inc., recently donated 17 chemo comfort bags to the Warren General Hospital Cancer Care Center. These bags, filled with electric blankets and other items, are intended for patients at the cancer center. This gesture is part of the foundation's broader effort to support individuals battling any form of cancer across northwestern Pennsylvania. The donation aims to provide comfort to patients and remind them that they are not fighting alone.

title: Hospital auxiliary selling tickets for basket raffle | News, Sports, Jobs
summary: The Warren General Hospital Auxiliary is organizing a holiday basket raffle from December 4 to December 8, 2023, in the hospital lobby. Tickets are available for $1 each, and the winners will be selected and notified by phone on the afternoon of December 8.

title: Hospital honors Emergency Room employee with BEE Award
summary: Ashley Taraska, an Emergency Room Patient Care Technician at Warren General Hospital, was honored with the BEE Award for exceptional non-nurse patient care staff. The award, created by the hospital's nursing leadership, recognizes employees who go above and beyond for patients and families. Taraska was nominated by a patient for her compassionate care, making patients feel welcomed and cared for. The BEE Award recipients are nominated by patients, families, and colleagues, and selected by a hospital committee. Winners receive a certificate, pin, gift card, free lunches, a day off, and a Bumble Bee Jasper crystal. The award highlights the hospital's commitment to valuing the extraordinary efforts of its healthcare workers.

title: American Legion serves lunch at hospital | News, Sports, Jobs
summary: The Warren American Legion provided lunch at Warren General Hospital and its satellite locations on Tuesday, serving a total of 91 pizzas, 1,040 wings, and 5 tubs of salad. This event was part of their community service efforts.

title: Bone cancer - Symptoms and causes
summary: Bone cancer is a rare condition that starts in the bones, with the thighbone being the most commonly affected area. It is distinct from cancers that begin elsewhere in the body and later spread to the bones. There are various types of bone cancer, some of which predominantly affect children, while others are more common in adults. The main treatments for bone cancer include surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy, with the choice of treatment depending on the type of cancer, the specific bone affected, and other factors. Symptoms of bone cancer can include bone pain, swelling and tenderness near the affected area, weakened bones leading to fractures, fatigue, and unintended weight loss. The exact cause of most bone cancers is unknown, but it involves changes in the DNA of cells in or near bones. Risk factors for bone cancer include inherited genetic syndromes, certain bone conditions, and previous radiation therapy or chemotherapy for other cancers.

title: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) - Symptoms and causes
summary: COVID-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, emerged at the end of 2019 and quickly became a global pandemic. It belongs to the coronavirus family, which includes viruses causing illnesses like the common cold, SARS, and MERS. COVID-19 spreads primarily through air droplets from coughs, sneezes, or talks, particularly in close contact situations. Symptoms, appearing 2 to 14 days post-exposure, range from mild to severe and include cough, fever, fatigue, loss of taste or smell, and digestive issues. While many recover without serious complications, the disease can be severe or fatal, especially in older adults or those with pre-existing health conditions. Vaccination is key to preventing severe illness, hospitalization, and death. Other preventive measures include good ventilation, physical distancing, mask-wearing, and hand hygiene. Treatments aim to reduce symptom severity. Long-term effects, known as long COVID, affect some individuals. The CDC recommends COVID-19 vaccines for everyone over 6 months old, with updated shots for better protection against circulating variants.

title: Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Cardiovascular Medicine - Overview
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is increasingly being integrated into cardiovascular medicine at Mayo Clinic, enhancing patient care through early risk prediction, diagnosis, and treatment of heart diseases. The clinic's AI cardiology team employs new approaches for better outcomes, such as detecting heart disease, treating strokes more efficiently, and improving diagnostic radiology capabilities. For instance, AI-assisted screening tools have shown high accuracy in identifying left ventricular dysfunction, a condition often symptomless. Additionally, AI technology developed at Mayo Clinic is used in wearable devices like the Apple Watch to detect weak heart pumps. These advancements allow for more effective patient-doctor interactions and decision-making processes. AI operates on neural networks, analyzing vast datasets to identify patterns and predict health issues, thereby supporting the early detection and management of cardiovascular conditions. Mayo Clinic's extensive patient care data and collaborative culture further propel the development and application of AI in healthcare, showcasing potential future innovations such as smart clothing for heart monitoring and AI-compatible medical devices.

title: Congenital heart disease in adults - Symptoms and causes
summary: Congenital heart disease in adults is a condition present at birth that affects the heart's structure, changing how blood flows through the heart. Symptoms in adults may include irregular heartbeats, blue or gray skin tones due to low oxygen levels, shortness of breath, fatigue with activity, and swelling from fluid retention. Causes are not fully understood but may involve genetic changes, certain medications or health conditions during pregnancy, and environmental or lifestyle factors. Risk factors include genetics, maternal rubella, diabetes during pregnancy, and the use of certain medications or substances like alcohol and tobacco. Treatments may involve regular health checkups, medications, or surgery. Complications can include arrhythmias, endocarditis, stroke, pulmonary hypertension, and heart failure. Prevention is challenging due to unknown causes, but genetic testing and screening during pregnancy may help those at high risk.

title: Common questions about measles
summary: Measles is a highly infectious disease that was declared eliminated in the U.S. in 2000 but has seen a resurgence in 2024. It spreads through coughing, sneezing, or talking, with infected droplets that can live on surfaces for up to two hours. Individuals with measles are contagious for about eight days. Symptoms appear in stages over a two- to three-week period, starting with a dry cough, fever, and red, watery eyes, followed by a rash that begins on the face and spreads. Measles is particularly dangerous for children under five and immunocompromised adults over 65, potentially leading to complications like ear infections, pneumonia, or even death. Diagnosis in the U.S. can be challenging due to limited cases. Vaccination is the most effective prevention method, with the MMR vaccine recommended for children starting at 12–15 months and a second dose at 4–6 years. One dose of the MMR vaccine is about 93% effective, while two doses are about 97% effective.

title: Mayo Clinic Minute: What is inflammatory bowel disease?
summary: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) affects over 10 million people globally, with Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis being its two main types. IBD leads to chronic inflammation in the digestive tract and can impact other body areas. Symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, fatigue, weight loss, and stomach and joint pain. While there's no cure or known exact cause for IBD, treatments like anti-inflammatory drugs, immune system suppressors, biologics, antibiotics, nutrition therapy, and surgery are available to manage symptoms. Diet plays a crucial role in symptom management, emphasizing anti-inflammatory foods and antioxidants while avoiding processed foods.

title: Thyroid cancer - Symptoms and causes
summary: Thyroid cancer originates in the thyroid gland, which is located at the base of the neck and produces hormones regulating vital body functions. This type of cancer is often detectable through improved imaging technologies, leading to an increase in diagnosed cases. However, most thyroid cancers are treatable, with a good prognosis for many patients. Risk factors include gender (women are more susceptible), exposure to high levels of radiation, and certain genetic syndromes. Symptoms may not appear in early stages but can include a noticeable lump in the neck, voice changes, difficulty swallowing, and swollen lymph nodes. Diagnosis typically involves a physical exam, blood tests, ultrasound, and possibly a biopsy. Treatment options vary based on the cancer's stage and type but may include surgery, hormone therapy, radioactive iodine, and chemotherapy. Despite the potential for recurrence or metastasis, many thyroid cancers are curable, emphasizing the importance of early detection and treatment.

title: Obstetrics and Gynecology - Overview
summary: The Mayo Clinic Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology provides extensive medical and surgical care for women from adolescence through menopause and beyond, emphasizing a team-based approach with the patient as a partner. It boasts over 55 specialists, making it one of the most esteemed and largest practices worldwide, offering services in Arizona, Florida, and Minnesota, and reaching over 60 communities via the Mayo Clinic Health System. The department creates personalized care plans, utilizing a multidisciplinary team and the latest in diagnostic technology for a broad spectrum of conditions, from standard screenings to intricate surgeries. It is celebrated for its innovative work in simulation training for gynecologic surgery and its proficiency in minimally invasive techniques. The Family Birth Center in Rochester, Minnesota, welcomes around 2,400 newborns each year, with support from perinatal education and the OB Nest program for streamlined prenatal care. Mayo Clinic in Rochester is recognized as one of the top hospitals for gynecology by U.S. News & World Report for 2023-2024.

title: Living-donor transplant - Care at Mayo Clinic
summary: Mayo Clinic offers comprehensive care for patients seeking living-donor transplants, including kidney and liver transplants. With one of the largest transplant practices in the U.S., Mayo Clinic provides an integrated team approach involving surgeons, doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and other healthcare professionals to ensure favorable outcomes for living donors. The process begins with a health history questionnaire, followed by a thorough evaluation including blood tests, physical examination, psychological evaluation, and detailed imaging. Mayo Clinic emphasizes minimally invasive surgery for donor procedures, aiming for less pain and shorter recovery times. The clinic also engages in extensive research to improve donor outcomes and participates in clinical trials. Recognized nationally for its expertise, Mayo Clinic's campuses in Arizona, Florida, and Minnesota are ranked highly for diabetes, endocrinology, and digestive disorders. The clinic supports patients with financial services, insurance guidance, and access to ongoing clinical trials as part of the living-donor transplantation experience.

title: Breast cancer - Care at Mayo Clinic
summary: Mayo Clinic provides specialized, patient-centered care for people with breast cancer, offering a team of experts across various disciplines to create personalized treatment plans. This multidisciplinary approach ensures comprehensive care, considering all patient needs. Mayo Clinic utilizes the latest in diagnostic technology and treatment innovations to improve outcomes, minimize side effects, and support patients' overall well-being. Treatments may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and targeted therapies, often integrated with clinical trials to access cutting-edge options. The clinic emphasizes convenience for patients through coordinated appointments and support services, aiming for effective treatments with minimal disruption to daily life. Mayo Clinic's extensive experience and research in breast cancer care are recognized nationally, making it a trusted center for those seeking treatment.

title: Mayo Clinic Minute: Who should be screened for skin cancer?
summary: Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the U.S., with over 6 million adults treated every year. Mayo Clinic dermatologist Dr. Collin Costello stresses the importance of skin cancer screenings, particularly for high-risk individuals. Although there are no strict national guidelines on how often to get screened, risk factors are key in deciding if one needs screening. A dermatologist can perform a skin check in a few minutes, which could save lives by catching skin cancer early. Dr. Costello recommends that everyone should know their skin well and seek medical advice if they notice any changes, like unusual moles or spots. People at high risk, such as those with a personal or family history of melanoma, previous nonmelanoma skin cancers, individuals over 65, and those who burn easily or have light-colored eyes and hair, should think about getting a skin exam every year.

title: Chronic kidney disease - Diagnosis and treatment
summary: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) diagnosis involves a comprehensive approach that includes discussing personal and family history, physical exams, and various tests such as blood and urine analyses, imaging, and possibly a kidney biopsy. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms, reducing complications, and slowing disease progression. Options vary based on the underlying cause but may include medications for high blood pressure, treatments for anemia, cholesterol-lowering drugs, and dietary changes. Advanced CKD may require dialysis or a kidney transplant. Dialysis can be done through hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis, depending on individual circumstances and preferences. A kidney transplant involves placing a healthy kidney from a donor into the patient's body, requiring lifelong anti-rejection medication. Mayo Clinic offers comprehensive care for CKD, including access to clinical trials, personalized treatment plans, and support for managing the disease.

title: Ventricular tachycardia - Diagnosis and treatment
summary: Ventricular tachycardia (V-tach or VT) requires a thorough diagnosis involving a physical exam, medical history, and various tests at Mayo Clinic. Tests include an electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG), Holter monitor, cardiac event monitor, exercise stress test, and imaging tests like chest X-ray, echocardiogram, cardiac MRI, and CT scans to diagnose and understand the condition. Additional tests such as electrophysiological studies and tilt table tests may be conducted to confirm VT and its causes. Treatment aims to slow the rapid heartbeat and prevent future episodes, involving medications, procedures like cardioversion and catheter ablation, and devices such as implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICD) and pacemakers. Surgery may be required in some cases. Mayo Clinic provides specialized care for ventricular tachycardia, emphasizing patient-centered approaches.

title: Geisinger and Acadia hold groundbreaking ceremony for Danville facility
summary: Geisinger and Acadia Healthcare celebrated the groundbreaking of a new behavioral health hospital in Danville, Pennsylvania, on May 7, 2024. The facility, named Geisinger Behavioral Health Center Danville, is expected to open in spring 2025 and will feature 96 beds. It aims to provide a comprehensive range of behavioral health services including inpatient, intensive outpatient, and ECT treatment programs for adult, pediatric, and adolescent patients. Conditions treated will include anxiety, depression, bipolar disorder, psychosis, and PTSD. This initiative responds to the growing need for accessible, high-quality behavioral health services in central Pennsylvania and supports Geisinger’s mission to serve over 1.2 million people across 45 counties. The hospital will also function as a teaching facility for students and residents from Geisinger’s College of Health Sciences. This project marks the second hospital built in Pennsylvania through the partnership between Geisinger and Acadia, following a similar facility opened in Moosic in August 2023.

title: Geisinger Health Plan and OncoHealth to provide comprehensive cancer support to members
summary: Geisinger Health Plan (GHP) and OncoHealth are partnering to offer comprehensive cancer support to GHP's over 550,000 members. This collaboration will utilize OncoHealth's leading software and services platform to provide oncology value management and virtual supportive care services, ensuring members receive the most appropriate treatment and support throughout their treatment. Services include 24/7 oncology nursing, mental health support, nutrition, and resource navigation. The initiative aims to ease the treatment process for members facing life-threatening diagnoses by fostering a collaborative process with providers and health systems. OncoHealth's solution will also enable GHP to access real-time dashboards for trend analysis and policy development to control oncology drug spending without compromising care. The rollout will begin in May 2024, as part of Geisinger's commitment to value-based care and its broader impact on the state's economy and healthcare education. OncoHealth is recognized for its comprehensive cancer support solutions, serving 18 health plans and 12 million members nationwide.

title: Terry Gilliland named future chief executive officer
summary: Terry Gilliland, MD, has been appointed as the president of Geisinger Health and is set to become the chief executive officer (CEO) following the transition of the current CEO, Jaewon Ryu, MD, JD, to CEO of Risant Health. This announcement was made by Geisinger on March 4, 2024, marking Dr. Gilliland as the eighth CEO in the organization's 109-year history. The Geisinger Board of Directors conducted an extensive national search before selecting Dr. Gilliland, highlighting his passion for Geisinger's mission, innovation in care delivery, and commitment to educating future caregivers as key reasons for his appointment. Dr. Gilliland brings a wealth of experience from various senior roles in healthcare delivery and payer organizations, including his recent position at Cogitativo, and previous roles at Blue Shield of California and Sentara Healthcare. He expressed his honor in leading Geisinger and is set to relocate to Pennsylvania from Steamboat Springs, Colo. Dr. Gilliland's appointment is seen as a strategic move to navigate the healthcare challenges and continue Geisinger's legacy of success.

title: “The Jetsons” foresaw medicine's future. Now it's Geisinger's turn.
summary: Geisinger is leading the way in healthcare innovation by integrating digital technology to enhance patient experiences and outcomes. At the ViVE health technology conference, Rebecca Stametz, Geisinger's vice president of digital transformation, highlighted the health system's focus on offering transparent pricing and lifetime guarantees for certain surgeries. Geisinger aims to improve care delivery through human-centered design and digital transformation, addressing the challenges of an aging population. The organization is also committed to easing the burdens on healthcare professionals by increasing automation. Furthermore, Geisinger has partnered with Best Buy's Geek Squad to implement a care-at-home program that includes remote patient monitoring, demonstrating a blend of technology and human touch in healthcare. The American Medical Association (AMA) supports these advancements as part of its Health System Program, emphasizing the importance of telehealth and remote patient monitoring in the future of medicine.

title: Benefits of Probiotics for Kids
summary: Probiotics, known for their benefits in adult digestive health, also have potential benefits for children, although their effectiveness can vary. Probiotics, which include beneficial bacteria such as Lactobacillus rhamnosus and Bifidobacterium lactis, help maintain a healthy microbiome. Studies indicate they can improve digestion, relieve symptoms of gastrointestinal issues like diarrhea and irritable bowel syndrome, boost immune function, and may even lower the risk of allergies, asthma, and certain autoimmune diseases. However, more research is needed on the effects of probiotics on children's health, as there is evidence suggesting they may be expelled without significant benefit. While generally safe for children, those with compromised immune systems, cancer, or who were born prematurely should avoid them due to infection risks. Side effects such as gas and bloating are usually mild. Experts prefer probiotic-rich foods like yogurt to supplements for children and recommend consulting a pediatrician for specific concerns.

title: Taking steps to save lives with Geisinger
summary: Geisinger is leading the charge against heart disease and stroke by promoting community involvement in the Northeast PA Heart Walk. Ron Beer, Geisinger's interim Chief Operating Officer and event chair, together with Blake Milbrand from the American Heart Association, stress the importance of community participation. Each participant and donation helps fund crucial research, CPR training, medical breakthroughs, and supports equitable health. As Geisinger nears its 100th year, it continues to dedicate itself to its life-saving purpose. This campaign is a step towards creating a healthier, longer-lasting world.

title: 7 Foods That Can Cause Diarrhea
summary: Seven foods that can cause diarrhea include coffee, due to its caffeine and possibly other chemicals; sugar substitutes like aspartame, sucralose, and sorbitol, which can have laxative effects; fast food and greasy foods, which are hard to digest; spicy cuisine, which can irritate the digestive tract; alcohol, which can speed up digestion and irritate the stomach; dairy products, particularly for those who are lactose intolerant; and high-fiber fruits and vegetables, which can cause issues for some people. To avoid diarrhea, it's recommended to track food triggers, consider dietary changes such as choosing dairy-free options or less greasy foods, use digestive enzyme supplements for better digestion of certain foods, and eat smaller meals to reduce digestive system stress. If problems persist, consulting a healthcare provider is advised.

title: Democratize AI now, says Geisinger's medical director of artificial intelligence
summary: Dr. Aalpen Patel, the medical director of artificial intelligence at Geisinger and chair of radiology, stresses the need to make AI accessible in healthcare. He points out the importance of training the healthcare workforce on AI to make the most of its advantages in areas like radiology, population health, and patient care. Geisinger is actively using AI algorithms to enhance healthcare services, including more effective screening for diseases such as colorectal and lung cancer by identifying patients at high risk. Moreover, AI is applied in radiology to improve the detection of conditions like intracranial hemorrhages. Patel also mentions the use of natural language processing to better manage patient care and the effort to establish an AI sandbox for educational purposes. This initiative is intended to increase healthcare professionals' understanding of AI tools, ensuring their efficient and responsible use.

title: GSON Ribbon Cutting
summary: On May 17, Geisinger College of Health Sciences will inaugurate its new School of Nursing building in downtown Lewistown with a ribbon-cutting ceremony. This event highlights Geisinger's initiative to establish an academic hub for excellence in rural healthcare within its western region. Julie Byerley, MD, MPH, emphasized the school's role in pioneering innovations for underserved rural communities. The School of Nursing, according to Rebecca Stoudt, PhD, DNP, is already addressing the local nursing shortage, with the ADN class of 2024 set to join Geisinger's workforce. The ceremony will feature tours and activities at the new facility, located at 111 E. Market St. Geisinger College of Health Sciences, part of the Geisinger family, is dedicated to advancing health education and research, and is the first member of Risant Health, aiming to promote value-based care.

title: Geisinger is now part of Risant Health
summary: Kaiser Permanente has completed its purchase of Geisinger, a healthcare IT pioneer located in Danville, Pennsylvania, becoming the inaugural member of Risant Health. Risant Health, a nonprofit offshoot formed by Kaiser, seeks to encourage the adoption of value-based care nationwide. Geisinger will keep its name and purpose, directing Risant Health's efforts to boost access to value-based care by using the expertise of both entities. Since 2019, Dr. Jaewon Ryu, the CEO of Geisinger, will act as the first CEO of Risant Health, with Dr. Terry Gilliland taking over as Geisinger's president and CEO. Risant Health intends to buy more community-based health systems to broaden and hasten the implementation of value-based care in various settings. This partnership is anticipated to enhance health outcomes, affordability, and accessibility for the communities served by merging Kaiser's comprehensive care experience with Geisinger's initiatives in value-based care.

title: Best Buy's Landmark Partnership With Geisinger Signifies Its Growing Healthcare Ambitions
summary: Best Buy is expanding its healthcare footprint through a partnership with Geisinger, a significant healthcare system, to enhance home care for chronic disease patients. This collaboration leverages Best Buy Health and Geisinger's ConnectedCare365 platform, focusing on using digital and remote patient monitoring tools for better patient outcomes. Best Buy, known for its technology support through Geek Squad, will assist patients in setting up and utilizing these healthcare devices at home. The partnership has already shown promising results, including a 50% reduction in setup time for remote care, a 19% improvement in patient adherence to care plans, and an 18% decrease in technical issues. This initiative aligns with Best Buy's acquisition of Current Health and its broader goal to facilitate healthcare at home, demonstrating significant growth in the remote patient monitoring market and the increasing demand for healthcare-at-home models.

title: Prospective Medical Students Visit Northwestern for Second Look - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University hosted a "Second Look" event on April 11 and 12, 2024, welcoming 150 admitted medical students. This two-day event aimed to give accepted students a comprehensive overview of the medical school, including its campus, curriculum, community, health equity, and inclusion efforts. Attendees participated in symposiums, active learning simulations, and had opportunities to connect with current students, faculty, and affinity group leaders. The event also featured a panel on community engagement and advocacy, highlighting Feinberg and Northwestern Medicine's initiatives to promote health equity and inclusion. Additionally, students enjoyed a reception with Chicago-style dishes, a community brunch, campus tours including the anatomy lab and affiliate hospitals, and breakout sessions on global health opportunities and dual degree programs.

title: Tech can't replace human coaches in obesity treatment
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: A Northwestern Medicine study found that technology alone is insufficient for effective obesity treatment, showing worse weight loss outcomes compared to combining technology with a human coach. The study highlights the ongoing need for low-cost, effective obesity treatments amidst rising healthcare costs due to the obesity epidemic. Despite advancements in technology, human coaches are still necessary for achieving clinically meaningful weight loss, as current technology lacks the capability to fully replace the human touch. The study, published in JAMA, utilized a Wireless Feedback System and compared two treatment approaches in a randomized controlled trial. It revealed that initial treatment with technology alone did not produce satisfactory weight loss, underscoring the importance of human interaction in obesity treatment. The research aims to understand the unique benefits of human coaches and how technology might eventually replicate these advantages.

title: 2023 Year in Review - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: In 2023, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine achieved significant milestones, including a record-breaking $706 million in research funding and awards, enhancing its reputation in advancing human health. The year witnessed groundbreaking scientific breakthroughs across various fields, such as cancer treatment, artificial intelligence in medicine, and the engineering of tiny medical devices. Notable discoveries include a new AI tool for breast cancer treatment, synthetic melanin for wound healing, a novel therapeutic agent for metastatic cancer, and the first device for real-time monitoring of transplanted organs. Additionally, the medical school celebrated academic achievements, including the graduation of the MD Class of 2023, support for medical students pursuing research, and recognition of faculty and student excellence. Feinberg also received national recognition, ranking 13th among research-oriented medical schools, and saw leadership changes in key departments. The establishment of new research centers and partnerships, such as the CZ Biohub Chicago, further highlighted the institution's commitment to innovation and collaboration in biomedical research.

title: Celebrating Match Day 2024 - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Celebrating Match Day 2024 at Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine was a significant event for fourth-year medical students, who found out their residency placements in a ceremony at the Louis A. Simpson and Kimberly K. Querrey Biomedical Research Center. On March 15, students, with their families and friends, felt the excitement of opening envelopes that showed where they would be for their residency training for the next three to seven years. This event, held on the third Friday in March across the U.S., is a key milestone for medical students. The class of 2024 had 135 students match into 23 different ACGME-certified residency specialties, with 68 percent joining top 25 U.S. medical school programs. Popular specialties included internal medicine, pediatrics, anesthesiology, orthopaedic surgery, ophthalmology, and psychiatry. Faculty members were proud and confident in the students' abilities, thanks to the thorough preparation at Feinberg.

title: First-Year Medical Students Welcome New Academic Year at Founders' Day 2023 - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: First-Year Medical Students at Northwestern University celebrated the beginning of the new academic year at Founders’ Day 2023, held at Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago on August 4. This annual event, which marks the official start of the academic calendar, welcomed the class of 2027, honoring the founders of Feinberg School of Medicine. Students, including Ibrahim Mokhtar, expressed excitement and gratitude for the opportunity to study medicine at Northwestern. The ceremony featured speeches from university officials and faculty, emphasizing the school's history, the importance of medical education, and the opportunities for growth and discovery. First-year students donned their white coats for the first time, assisted by second-year students, symbolizing their entry into the medical profession. The event concluded with the recitation of the Declaration of Geneva, reaffirming their commitment to medical ethics. The Founders’ Day reception, sponsored by the Feinberg Medical Alumni Association, provided an opportunity for students, faculty, and guests to celebrate together.

title: Celebrating the MD Class of 2024 - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: The Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University celebrated the graduation of the MD Class of 2024 during its 165th commencement ceremony held at the Aon Grand Ballroom at Navy Pier on May 13, 2024. Azraa Chaudhury, a graduate who is set to begin her residency in Ophthalmology at NewYork Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center, shared her journey from an Emergency Medical Technician to becoming a physician. The ceremony included remarks from Eric G. Neilson, MD, the vice president for Medical Affairs and Lewis Landsberg Dean, and Kathleen Hagerty, PhD, MBA, the Northwestern University Provost. Michael Brown, MD, director of the Jonsson Center for Molecular Genetics and a professor at the University of Texas, Southwestern Medical School, delivered the commencement address, highlighting the challenges and achievements of the class, particularly in the context of starting their education during a pandemic. The graduates recited the Declaration of Geneva, reaffirming their commitment to the medical profession. The event also recognized academic achievements and dual-degree recipients among the graduates.

title: Patient's Gift Supports Precision Medicine and Ataxia Research
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: In February 2024, the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University highlighted the support for precision medicine and ataxia research through a generous donation from Mr. Denning Steven Denning and his wife, Roberta. Denning, a prominent businessman diagnosed with CANVAS—a condition causing cerebellar ataxia and neuropathy—was impressed by the precision medicine techniques developed by neurologist Dimitri Krainc, MD, PhD. This led to their substantial contribution aimed at bolstering Dr. Krainc's program and establishing the Denning Ataxia Center. Dr. Krainc's lab, part of the Simpson Querrey Center for Neurogenetics, focuses on integrating various scientific and medical disciplines to advance personalized medicine. This includes growing patient-specific neurons from skin cells to study disease mechanisms and test potential treatments. Denning's hope is that this research will lead to a therapy addressing the balance issues central to CANVAS, reflecting his commitment to supporting advancements in treating neurological conditions.

title: NUDOCS Program Immerses College Students in Medicine - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: The Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University, through its Office of Diversity and Inclusion, has introduced its largest cohort of 21 diverse undergraduate students to the NUDOCS program. This week-long immersive initiative aims to introduce college students to careers in medicine. In collaboration with the Northwestern Health Professions Advising Office and Weinberg College of Arts & Sciences, NUDOCS serves as a pathway program to inspire and support students interested in pursuing medical careers. Participants start the program by taking the Hippocratic Oath and donning white coats, symbolizing their commitment to the ethical practice of medicine. They gain firsthand experience of a physician's daily life through clinical shadowing and laboratory work, supplemented by discussions with faculty, residents, alumni, and admissions advisors. The program emphasizes mentorship and academic support, guiding students toward becoming patient-centric leaders in medicine.

title: Empowering women in medicine: Media invited to March 8 event in Chicago
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine is hosting its sixth annual Women in Medicine Conference on March 8, International Women’s Day, at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. This event, led by women and focused on women, aims to address and discuss challenges faced by women clinicians and scientists, such as pay equity, lack of leadership positions, and microaggressions from patients. The conference will provide a supportive environment to validate and empower women in medicine by offering tools to overcome these barriers. Sessions will cover topics like negotiation skills and leading in a crisis. Notable speakers include Northwestern’s first woman chair of medicine, Dr. Susan Quaggin, and former director of the Illinois Department of Public Health, Dr. Ngozi Ezike. The event underscores the importance of women in medicine, highlighting that patients of women doctors often feel more heard and have better outcomes, and emphasizes the need for more women in medical leadership and research.

title: Prepping autistic or sound-sensitive kids for cicada noise
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: The periodical cicada, last seen 17 years ago, is set to return this summer, bringing with it a significant noise that can be especially challenging for sound-sensitive children, including those on the autism spectrum. Dr. Rachel Follmer, an assistant professor of developmental behavioral pediatrics at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, emphasizes the importance of preparing these children for the upcoming cicada emergence. She suggests familiarizing them with the insects through photos and sounds, using social stories to set expectations, and having a plan in place for when the noise becomes overwhelming. This could include using headphones, earplugs, or AAC devices to help manage their reaction to the noise. Dr. Follmer advises that all children, not just those on the spectrum, can benefit from preparation due to the general sensitivity children have to loud sounds.

title: Eminent Epidemiologist Mercedes Carnethon Named Chair of Preventive Medicine - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Mercedes Carnethon, PhD, has been appointed as the chair of the Department of Preventive Medicine at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, effective September 1. Carnethon, a distinguished epidemiologist known for her research on cardiovascular and other chronic diseases, has been part of the Northwestern faculty since 2002. Her work focuses on understanding the behavioral, social, and biological factors contributing to morbidity and mortality, with particular attention to diverse population subgroups. Carnethon is celebrated for her mentorship and faculty development efforts within Feinberg and holds leadership positions in several national health organizations. She has published over 395 peer-reviewed scientific articles and leads numerous NIH grants. Her appointment is supported by colleagues and leadership at Northwestern, recognizing her as a talented scientist and leader. Carnethon's educational background includes a master’s degree and PhD from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a postdoctoral fellowship at Stanford University.

title: Feinberg Receives Record-Breaking Research Funding in 2023 - News Center
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: In 2023, Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University achieved a historic milestone by securing $706 million in research funding and awards during the 2022-23 fiscal year, marking a nearly nine percent increase from the previous year and setting a new record for the institution. This funding, which constitutes over 70% of Northwestern University's total research funding, supports a wide range of projects with the potential to significantly advance basic science, clinical research, and translational developments. Over the last academic year, Feinberg faculty published 328 research articles in prestigious journals, a 257 percent increase from 2011. Notable research breakthroughs include discoveries in cancer therapy resistance, lung development, inflammation, and targeted cancer treatments. The National Institutes of Health (NIH) contributed $477 million, over six percent more than the previous year. Feinberg's NIH funding has grown by 129 percent over the last 11 years. Additionally, the school conducted 6,658 clinical trials and studies, led by 694 principal investigators, and saw the establishment of 40 patents and six new start-up companies within the last fiscal year.

title: Uplifting their future colleagues - Northwestern Now
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Project MED, initiated by students at Northwestern University's Weinberg College of Arts and Sciences in 2021, aims to mentor Chicago-area high schoolers, particularly from underserved communities, for careers in health care. Founded by students including Rishi Jain and Irene Quan, the organization has now expanded to include a new chapter at the Feinberg School of Medicine. Project MED operates on a three-pronged approach: learn, lead, and launch, offering educational events, near-peer mentorship, and a database of over 750 opportunities for research, volunteering, or shadowing to help students jumpstart their pre-professional careers. The organization now partners with six area high schools and is exploring expansion to other postsecondary institutions. With a record number of student mentors this year, Project MED continues to grow, aiming to pave the path for future health care professionals and uplift future colleagues.

title: Q&A with Bong-Joon Kim: Institute for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Bong-Joon Kim, MD, PhD, a research fellow at Northwestern Medicine Cardiology and associate professor of cardiology at Kosin University Gospel Hospital in Korea, specializes in echocardiography and heart failure. Introduced to the Institute for Augmented Intelligence in Medicine (I.AIM) by Professors Sanjiv Shah and James D Thomas, Kim is drawn to the use of Augmented Intelligence in medicine. His research interests include diagnosing heart failure more accurately, exploring hemodynamics associated with exercise, the significance of right ventricular function and pulmonary hypertension in heart failure, and the prescription practices of SGLT2i and ARNI post-heart failure guideline updates. Kim values the research opportunities at Northwestern Medicine and is passionate about research, viewing it as crucial to patient care. He faces the challenge of relocating his family but recommends the U.S. for its diversity and equal opportunities. Kim enjoys the Northwestern University campus and Lake Michigan.

title: Faculty Profile
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Nicole Woitowich, PhD, serves as the executive director of the Northwestern University Clinical and Translational Sciences (NUCATS) Institute and is a research assistant professor of Medical Social Sciences at Northwestern. Her research primarily explores the inclusion of sex as a biological variable and the advancement of women in the biomedical research workforce, highlighting how these areas are deeply interconnected. Woitowich's work addresses the historical underrepresentation of women in clinical research and leadership within the biomedical field, aiming to understand how gender impacts research questions, experimental design, and outcomes. As the Executive Director of NUCATS, she oversees programs to support clinical and translational science, aiming to make biomedical research more accessible and equitable. Woitowich values interdisciplinary collaboration and mentorship, drawing inspiration from her mentors and aiming to foster an inclusive scientific community. She emphasizes the importance of making small changes to achieve a significant impact in making the biomedical research enterprise more equitable.

title: Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center earns spot on Newsweek’s list of World’s Best Hospitals
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center (LHAAMC) has been recognized by Newsweek as one of the best hospitals in the United States, ranking 90th out of 412 hospitals nationwide. This ranking is based on an evaluation of medical expertise, patient experiences, and key performance indicators such as patient safety, hygiene measures, and quality of treatment. The assessment involved an online survey of over 85,000 medical experts, public data from patient satisfaction surveys post-hospitalization, and a Statista survey on the use of Patient Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs). Luminis Health, a nonprofit regional health system that includes LHAAMC among other facilities, serves 1.8 million people with 840 licensed beds and over 9,600 team members across more than 100 sites of care.

title: Luminis Health's Deneen Richmond served patients for years. Then she became one.
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Deneen Richmond, a seasoned health care leader and president of Luminis Health Doctors Community Medical Center, encountered a personal health crisis when she received a Stage 3 rectal cancer diagnosis. Despite her broad professional background in the healthcare system, Richmond became a patient herself, undergoing significant abdominal surgery to excise a malignant tumor. Throughout her treatment, which encompassed chemotherapy and radiation, she persisted in leading her hospital, initiating a $300 million fundraising campaign, and striving to enhance healthcare access in her community. Richmond's ordeal has been not only a battle for her life but also a reinforcement of her dedication to improving healthcare delivery and advocating for early detection and better patient guidance within the health system. Her ordeal has motivated her to concentrate more on community needs, health disparities, and the significance of regular screenings, particularly for colorectal cancer, which is increasingly prevalent among younger adults.

title: New medical facility aimed at moms-to-be coming to Prince George’s Co.
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: A new $300 million medical facility, Luminis Health Pavilion, aimed at improving maternal health, has been approved for Lanham, Maryland, in Prince George’s County. The facility is designed to address the high maternal death rate in the county, especially among Black non-Hispanic women, and the fact that 80% of mothers from the county deliver their babies outside of it. Luminis Health Pavilion will focus on women’s health, offering extensive pre- and postnatal care to keep mothers and their babies healthy and close to home. Once at full capacity, the facility expects to deliver over 2,000 babies annually. The plan has been approved by the Maryland Health Commission, with infrastructure work set to begin in early 2024 and completion expected by 2028.

title: Luminis Health AAMC earns third magnet designation
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center (LHAAMC), located in Annapolis, has received its third Magnet designation from the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), placing it in the top 10% of U.S. hospitals to achieve this status. This award is the highest national recognition for professional nursing practice, signifying ongoing dedication to nursing excellence, quality care, high patient satisfaction, and a supportive work environment for nurses. LHAAMC, which serves nearly 2 million people across various regions, first earned the Magnet designation in 2014 and again in 2019. The thorough evaluation by the ANCC involves a detailed application, proof of superior patient and nursing outcomes compared to similar institutions, and an extensive site visit. Luminis Health, encompassing multiple medical facilities and serving a population of 1.8 million, is recognized for its substantial contributions to the community and wide range of care services.

title: Only On 7News: Baby born in Annapolis parking garage delivered by nearby OBGYN
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: In Annapolis, Maryland, a baby girl was born in a hospital parking garage with the help of a nearby OBGYN, Dr. Janelle Cooper. Elsa Antunez, the mother, was on her way to Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center for the birth when her contractions got worse. Dr. Cooper, who was in the parking garage at the time, helped deliver the baby after hearing Antunez's screams. The newborn, named Yesenia Patricia, and her mother are both healthy and were able to go home. This unique birth story highlights an unexpected but successful delivery outside the traditional hospital setting.

title: 4 MD Hospitals Named Among Best For Patient Safety, Experience
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Four hospitals in Maryland have been recognized by Healthgrades for their excellence in patient safety and experience. The 2024 Patient Safety Excellence Award and the 2024 Outstanding Patient Experience Award were given based on an analysis of patient safety measures and patient survey data, respectively. Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis and the University of Maryland St. Joseph Medical Center in Towson were acknowledged for patient safety. Meanwhile, Garrett Regional Medical Center in Oakland and The Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore were highlighted for providing outstanding patient experiences. The awards indicate that these hospitals are among the top in the nation for preventing safety incidents and offering superior patient care.

title: Viral: Doctor Helps US Woman Deliver A Baby In Hospital’s Parking Area
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Elsa Antunez, a 23-year-old expectant mother, experienced an unexpected twist in her birth plan when she had to deliver her baby girl in the parking lot of Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis, Maryland. The incident occurred just as she was about to enter the hospital, but fortunately, Dr. Janelle Cooper, an obstetrician and gynecologist at the hospital, was nearby. Dr. Cooper, along with Jean Andres, the director of Labor and Delivery, who also arrived on the scene, assisted in the delivery. Both the mother and the newborn, named Yesenia Patricia, are in good health. This remarkable story, described as an "unexpected delivery" by the hospital on its Instagram account, highlights the serendipitous presence of the medical professionals who were able to assist at just the right time. Elsa Antunez expressed her gratitude for Dr. Cooper's help, marking a memorable birth story for her daughter.

title: DNP Jean Andres Assists Doctor with a Special Delivery
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Jean Andres, DNP, RN, and the labor and delivery director at Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis, Maryland, assisted Dr. Janelle Cooper in an unconventional delivery in the hospital's parking garage. Andres was alerted by a scream and found Cooper delivering Elsa Artunez’s baby in the backseat of a truck. Artunez’s grandfather had been rushing her to the hospital, but the baby was coming too quickly to move Artunez inside. Andres helped Cooper with the delivery, and they successfully welcomed Yesenia Patricia, a healthy baby girl, into the world. Despite the unusual setting, Andres described the birth as beautiful. Daily Nurse recognized Jean Andres as the Nurse of the Week for her exceptional care and adherence to the hospital's values of Respect, Inclusion, Service, and Excellence.

title: Here’s what happens when a parking garage becomes a delivery room
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: In Annapolis, Maryland, a parking garage at Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center unexpectedly became a delivery room when Elsa Artunez went into labor in the backseat of a truck. Dr. Janelle Cooper, an OB/GYN at the hospital, was arriving for work when she noticed a commotion and instinctively helped deliver Artunez's baby, Yesenia Patricia, in the parking garage. Jean Andres, the hospital’s labor and delivery director, assisted shortly after. Despite the unconventional setting, the birth was smooth and the baby was healthy. This event marked a unique experience for Dr. Cooper, who had delivered babies in various locations around the hospital but never in a parking garage. This incident was not the first emergency delivery in the hospital's parking facility, highlighting the unpredictability and urgency of childbirth.

title: Newborn delivered in Maryland hospital parking garage by nearby OBGYN
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: In Annapolis, Maryland, a woman named Elsa Antunez gave birth to her daughter Yesenia Patricia in the parking garage of Luminis Health Anne Arundel Medical Center on August 23, 2023. Antunez was on her way to the hospital due to strong contractions when Dr. Janelle Cooper, an OBGYN who happened to be in the parking garage, heard her screams and assisted with the delivery. Dr. Cooper, who had delivered many babies inside the hospital but never in such an unconventional location, found the baby's head already emerging when she approached the car. Both the mother and the newborn, who was born with a full head of hair, are healthy and now back home. Antunez expressed her gratitude towards Dr. Cooper for her timely help during the unexpected birth.

title: America's Best-In-State Hospitals 2024 - Maryland
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: America's Best-In-State Hospitals 2024 ranking by Newsweek, in collaboration with Statista, identifies 600 leading hospitals across the United States, focusing on providing local access to top healthcare facilities. This includes 50 state lists and a list for the District of Columbia, with specialized hospitals listed at the bottom of each state list without a rank. The ranking is based on a comprehensive methodology that includes a nationwide online survey of healthcare professionals, patient survey data, hospital quality metrics from Medicare and Medicaid Services, and a PROMs Implementation survey. The Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore tops Maryland's list with a score of 93.06%, followed by Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center and the University of Maryland Medical Center. The ranking aims to help patients find the best care locally and is a reflection of data collected from September 8, 2022, to September 7, 2023.

title: Insurance and Billing
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center offers comprehensive cancer care and treatment, including various patient services like insurance and billing, medical record requests, pharmacy, lodging options, amenities, interpreter services, telehealth, and caregiver resources. Supportive care services provided include cancer rehabilitation, child life specialists, integrative medicine, nutrition, oncoreproduction clinic, pain clinic, palliative care, patient navigators, physical therapy, psychiatry, sexual health, social work, spiritual health, support groups, and survivorship programs. Treatments available encompass blood and marrow transplant, immunotherapy, medical oncology, radiation oncology, surgical oncology, proton therapy, and CRS-HIPEC. The center also focuses on prevention and screening for breast, colorectal, lung, and prostate cancers, alongside genetic counseling and a wellness clinic. Research at Fred Hutch covers areas such as behavioral research, biostatistics, cell and gene therapy, data science, diagnostics, disease prevention, epidemiology, gene regulation, genetics, global health, health economics, hematopoietic transplantation, immunotherapy, infectious diseases, microbiome, survivorship, vaccine development, and virology. The center is involved in clinical trials and offers education and training for patients, healthcare professionals, and students. Fred Hutch emphasizes diversity, equity, inclusion, and offers various ways for individuals to contribute through donations and volunteering.

title: Herpes cure with gene editing makes progress in laboratory studies
summary: Researchers at Fred Hutch Cancer Center have made significant progress in developing a gene therapy for herpes, showing promising results in pre-clinical studies. The therapy, aimed at curing genital and oral herpes, demonstrated the ability to remove over 90% of the herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) infection and significantly reduce viral shedding, suggesting a potential to lower the risk of transmission. The gene editing approach uses a vector and a specially designed enzyme to target and cut the virus's DNA within nerve clusters, effectively damaging it beyond repair. This streamlined method, which is safer and easier to produce, could lead to a more effective treatment for herpes, a lifelong infection affecting billions globally. The study's success in mouse models is a hopeful step toward human clinical trials, with the ultimate goal of offering a cure for herpes sufferers.

title: About Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, an independent, nonprofit organization and UW Medicine's cancer program, is dedicated to eliminating cancer and infectious diseases through innovative research and compassionate care. It offers comprehensive patient care, including a wide range of treatments like blood and marrow transplant, immunotherapy, medical and surgical oncology, and proton therapy, alongside prevention and screening services. The center is renowned for its pioneering work in bone marrow transplantation and immunotherapy, with Nobel Prize-winning research demonstrating the power of the human immune system to cure cancer. Fred Hutch also conducts a vast array of scientific research across various areas, including disease prevention, genetics, global health, and vaccine development. It emphasizes diversity, equity, and inclusion in its mission and values, which are reflected in its commitment to patient care, research, and education. The center provides education and training for a wide range of audiences, from patients to healthcare professionals and students. With a leadership team guided by President Dr. Thomas Lynch, Fred Hutch is focused on groundbreaking discoveries and ethical research to improve patient outcomes and advance the fight against disease.

title: One in five people with cancer participate in medical research studies
summary: A study by Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center and partners, published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, shows that 21.9% of U.S. cancer patients take part in clinical research, much higher than the previously estimated 2%-3% for treatment trials. This research, covering a broad array of study types and care settings, found a significantly higher rate of participation in treatment trials at National Cancer Institute-designated centers than at community sites (21.6% vs. 4.1%). Using deidentified data from the Commission on Cancer, the analysis spanned over 70% of U.S. cancer patients annually and showcased the various clinical studies patients participate in, such as biorepository, registry, genetic, quality-of-life, diagnostic, and economic studies. The results emphasize the need to broaden access to clinical trials, particularly in community settings, to increase patient involvement in cancer research.

title: Request an Appointment
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center offers comprehensive patient care services including various treatments like immunotherapy, medical and surgical oncology, and support services such as insurance and billing assistance, lodging, telehealth, and a range of supportive care services for patients and caregivers. It also focuses on cancer prevention and screening. The center conducts pioneering scientific research across multiple divisions and offers education and training for healthcare professionals and researchers. Additionally, it emphasizes diversity, equity, and inclusion, and provides various ways for individuals to support its mission through donations and volunteering. Fred Hutch operates as an independent organization and serves as UW Medicine's cancer program, committed to providing high-quality oncology care and supporting patients throughout their treatment journey.

title: Honors & Awards
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, renowned for its pioneering scientific research and comprehensive patient care, has received numerous honors and awards, underscoring its leadership in the fight against cancer. Its world-class scientists, including three Nobel Laureates—Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, Dr. Leland “Lee” Hartwell, and Dr. Linda Buck—have made significant contributions to the prevention, detection, and treatment of cancer and other diseases. These contributions have garnered prestigious recognitions such as the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, the Albert Lasker Medical Research Award, and the Gairdner Foundation International Award. Additionally, the center's healthcare providers are annually recognized for their dedication to patient care. Fred Hutch, in partnership with the University of Washington Medical Center, is consistently ranked among the nation's best hospitals for adult cancer treatment by U.S. News & World Report. The center's commitment to excellence is further highlighted by its various educational and training programs, aiming to foster the next generation of scientific leaders.

title: Research Areas
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center focuses on breakthroughs in cancer, HIV, and disease prevention, detection, and treatment through comprehensive research areas. These include behavioral research, biostatistics, cell and gene therapy, cell biology, data science, diagnostics and biomarkers, disease prevention, epidemiology, gene regulation and expression, genetics and genomics, global health, health economics, hematopoietic transplantation, immunotherapy, infectious diseases, microbiome, survivorship, vaccine development, and virology. The center is home to Nobel laureates and over 200 renowned researchers collaborating globally and mentoring future scientists. Key innovations include pioneering bone marrow transplantation and developing targeted treatments and diagnostics, leveraging vast genomic and health data. Research also extends to understanding behavioral choices' impact on disease development and testing interventions, especially among underserved populations. Additionally, Fred Hutch leads in clinical trials and volunteer studies essential for advancing disease research and treatment.

title: Cancers
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center focuses on pioneering scientific research and comprehensive patient care for over two dozen types of cancer, including both rare and common cancers such as leukemia, brain tumors, breast, prostate, colon, and lung cancers. The center's world-renowned scientists employ an innovative, collaborative approach to understanding and eliminating cancer, working on various fronts from studying risk factors and genetic mutations to developing innovative treatments like immunotherapies and HPV vaccines. Key areas of research include identifying environmental and genetic factors underlying cancers, improving early detection, developing personalized treatments, and pioneering significant advances like bone marrow transplantation for leukemia. Additionally, Fred Hutch offers more than 400 treatment trials or volunteer studies, aiming to provide patients with access to advanced treatment options while delivering the best possible care.

title: Medical Record Request
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center offers a comprehensive guide for patients to request their medical records through various means such as mail, fax, or email across different clinic locations, including South Lake Union Clinic, Proton Therapy, Issaquah Clinic, Peninsula Clinic, UW Medical Center - Northwest, Fred Hutch at EvergreenHealth, and Fred Hutch at Overlake Cancer Center. Patients or their authorized representatives need to complete a Release of Information Authorization/Medical Records Request form, available for download or at clinic front desks. This process allows for the release of records to patients, family members, caregivers, or other specified parties for different purposes, such as coordinating care or transferring records between healthcare providers. The service is free when records are sent to patients or their physicians, but fees may apply for records sent to third parties like insurance companies. Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center ensures compliance with Washington state law by responding to requests within 15 working days, prioritizing emergency care needs. Proper identification and specified information are required for processing requests, with options for receiving records in various formats.

title: notifies patients of data security incident | Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center reported a data security incident detected on November 19, 2023, involving unauthorized access to its clinical network until November 25, 2023. The breach potentially exposed patient information, including names, contact details, Social Security numbers, health insurance information, medical records, and clinical data. The center's electronic medical record system was not compromised, and clinics continued to operate normally. Affected individuals are being notified and offered complimentary credit monitoring and identity protection services. Fred Hutch has taken steps to enhance its security measures and is working with law enforcement and a third-party forensic security firm on the investigation. Patients are advised to monitor their account statements and credit reports for suspicious activity. Further assistance and information on identity protection are available through Fred Hutch’s dedicated call center and the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Loggers recognized as national palliative care leader
summary: Dr. Elizabeth Loggers, the medical director for the Supportive and Palliative Care Service at Fred Hutch Cancer Center, has been recognized as an Emerging Leader in Hospice and Palliative Medicine by the American Academy of Hospice and Palliative Medicine. Her interest in palliative care began during her PhD in health services research, focusing on advanced care planning for stroke patients. Loggers, who is also a medical oncologist specializing in sarcoma, emphasizes the importance of palliative care in enhancing the quality of life for patients by addressing symptoms and providing compassionate care. She aims to expand the Supportive and Palliative Care Service at Fred Hutch, increase faculty and staff, enhance services and research, and create a combined oncology/palliative care fellowship funded through philanthropy. Loggers believes in the growth potential of palliative care at Fred Hutch and its significance in the lives of cancer patients and their families.

title: Notice of lost laptop involving Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center is notifying individuals about a lost laptop incident that occurred on October 27, 2023. The laptop, belonging to one of their providers, was lost while traveling and was used to access Fred Hutch email via Microsoft Outlook. Although the laptop was password protected and a remote wipe was initiated, an investigation, including a forensic team, was launched to determine the potential exposure of patient information. The investigation revealed that the provider's email might have contained patient details such as names, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, medical record numbers, patient account numbers, service dates, clinical information, and for some, Social Security numbers. Fred Hutch is mailing notification letters to affected individuals, offering complimentary credit monitoring and identity protection services to those whose Social Security numbers may have been compromised. They urge patients to review their health insurance statements and report any discrepancies. Fred Hutch emphasizes its commitment to safeguarding personal information and is taking steps to prevent similar incidents, including workforce education on mobile device safeguards. Patients with concerns can contact a dedicated call center.

title: Bacteria subtype linked to growth in up to 50% of human colorectal cancers, Fred Hutch researchers report
summary: Researchers at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center have discovered a specific subtype of Fusobacterium nucleatum, a microbe commonly found in the mouth, that plays a significant role in the growth and progression of colorectal cancer tumors. This finding, published in the journal Nature on March 20, 2024, indicates that this bacterium subtype is present in about 50% of colorectal cancer cases studied and is associated with poorer patient outcomes. The study involved analyzing colorectal cancer tumors from 200 patients and found that this specific bacterium subtype, not just any Fusobacterium nucleatum, was elevated in tumor tissues. This microbe was also found in higher numbers in the stool samples of colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy individuals. The discovery opens up new avenues for colorectal cancer screening and treatment, targeting this specific microbe to improve therapeutic outcomes. This work was supported by various research foundations and suggests that microbial cellular therapies could be developed to treat colorectal cancer effectively.

title: McKesson Experts Discuss New Solution to Unlock Specialty Payer Contract Access | Prescribed Perspectives
summary: McKesson has launched Atlas Specialty, a new solution aimed at improving access to specialty payer contracts for pharmacies. This initiative seeks to expand pharmacies' ability to dispense specialty medications and support patients with rare and complex diseases by leveraging strategic relationships with payers and pharmacy benefit managers.
