Atlas Specialty, built on the success of Health Mart Atlas—the nation's largest PSAO, aims to bridge the gap between payers and health system providers, offering select network access, strategic alliances, and contract standardization. This move comes in response to the growing demand for specialty pharmaceuticals, which now account for 55% of net pharmaceutical spending, with significant growth in the autoimmune and oncology segments. The solution is designed to help health systems continue their trajectory in increasing specialty medication dispensation and addressing the challenges of treatment adherence in patients with rare and complex diseases.

title: Health Systems Pharmacy Distribution & Optimization
summary: McKesson focuses on optimizing the pharmacy distribution and financial performance of health systems through a comprehensive suite of services and technology solutions. They offer pharmaceutical distribution, including drug ordering for pharmacies, specialty drugs for physician practices, and vaccines, as well as controlled substance ordering and packaging solutions. McKesson also provides wholesale medical supplies for various healthcare settings and emergency medical products. Their pharmacy services and technology include pharmacy ownership consulting, health systems consulting, software solutions, and automation solutions aimed at improving pharmacy management, operations, and patient adherence. Additionally, McKesson supports drug purchasing management, claims reimbursement, and offers solutions for specialty practices. They extend their services to biopharma, providing supply chain solutions, distribution services, clinical trials services, and patient services. McKesson's approach integrates advanced analytics, supply chain optimization, revenue recovery management, and compliance consulting to improve the clinical and financial outcomes of health systems, aiming for more efficient and profitable operations.

title: Specialty Health Consulting and Tools
summary: McKesson offers a wide range of services and tools for specialty health consulting, such as pharmaceutical distribution, pharmacy services and technology, and biopharma solutions. Their services include drug ordering for pharmacies, specialty drugs for physician practices, plasma and biologics, both brand name and generic drugs, vaccines, and over-the-counter pharmacy products. McKesson also offers packaging solutions, wholesale medical supplies, medical equipment, and flu vaccines. Their pharmacy services include consulting on pharmacy ownership, health systems consulting, software solutions, pharmacy management software, automation solutions, drug purchasing management, and patient adherence programs. Furthermore, McKesson provides technology solutions for oncology clinical management, full-service practice management, supply chain solutions, distribution services, third-party logistics, clinical trials services, specialty pharmacy data, and insights for specialty practices. They focus on improving operational efficiency, financial health, and clinical excellence in specialty practices, offering resources and consulting services to help navigate the complexities of biosimilars and value-based care.

title: RxLightning Closes $17.5M Series A to Accelerate Growth and Remove Barriers to Essential Specialty Medications
summary: RxLightning has completed a $17.5 million Series A funding round led by LRVHealth, with contributions from McKesson Ventures, Novartis, Hearst Ventures, Onco360, and HealthX Ventures. This investment, raising the company's total capital to $20.5 million, will support RxLightning's growth and its mission to simplify the access and affordability of specialty medications. The company offers a comprehensive platform that streamlines the specialty medication onboarding process for healthcare providers, reducing administrative burdens and speeding up patient access to essential treatments. RxLightning's MedAccess Ecosystem connects doctors, patients, pharmacies, and manufacturers, providing transparency and support throughout the medication access journey. This funding will help RxLightning expand its services, infrastructure, and partner base, addressing the complex needs of the specialty medication market, which represents over half of the total drug spending in the U.S.

title: Real-World Data and Real-World Evidence Help Speed Specialty Drug Development
summary: Real-world data (RWD), derived from sources such as electronic health records, insurance claims, and mobile devices, is increasingly being utilized to accelerate the development of specialty drugs, particularly in oncology. This shift is driven by the limitations of traditional clinical trials, which often struggle with patient diversity, accessibility, and awareness. RWD offers a broader and more inclusive perspective, reflecting the actual patient population more accurately. The 21st Century Cures Act, recognized by the federal government in 2016, supports the use of RWD and real-world evidence (RWE) in FDA decisions, highlighting its potential to improve drug development and regulatory processes. By leveraging RWD, researchers can conduct retrospective studies or complement existing trial data, enhancing the evaluation of new therapies' effectiveness and safety. This approach also facilitates precision medicine, allowing treatments to be tailored to individual patients' genetic and environmental backgrounds. McKesson, through its business Ontada, is at the forefront of applying RWD in oncology, contributing to the FDA approval of new treatments and advancing personalized medicine.

title: Igniting a Culture of Diverse Growth and Leadership
summary: Glen Townsend, a software engineer and scrum master at McKesson, has made significant contributions to the company, particularly in the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines and oncology therapies. His journey began with a shift from electronic engineering to information technology after a college project failure, leading him to find his calling at McKesson through an acquisition. Townsend plays a vital role in technical infrastructure projects and was instrumental in setting up distribution centers for COVID-19 vaccine deployment. His personal connection to the mission, driven by his mother's battle with breast cancer, emphasizes the importance of flawless medication delivery. Beyond his technical contributions, Townsend is deeply involved in mentoring and community service, notably through McKesson's Black Excellence - Be Empowered (BE) employee resource group and his fraternity, Alpha Phi Alpha. His efforts focus on promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion within McKesson, mentoring high school students, and leading initiatives for health, wellness, and financial empowerment. Townsend's work reflects his commitment to professional development, community service, and fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace culture.

title: How Biologics Risk-Based Care Meets the Needs of Each Patient | Our Stories
summary: Biologics by McKesson offers a risk-based care program for cancer and rare disease patients, focusing on personalized support to ensure medication adherence and improve health outcomes. Nurse Porscha Scales, a key member of the clinical case educator team, contributes significantly to this care without direct patient interaction. She and her team perform initial assessments, develop care plans, and keep in constant touch with patients for clinical guidance and emotional support. The program customizes its services to meet each patient's specific needs, including side effect management and end-of-life conversations. Scales' personal experience with cancer in her family and pet inspires her to treat patients as family, reflected in her meaningful relationship with a patient, Dan Walsh. Walsh's experience highlights the program's effectiveness in providing holistic care that tackles both the physical and emotional challenges of cancer, leading to his remission.

title: 233000-square-foot pharmaceutical distribution centre opens in Surrey
summary: A 233,000-square-foot pharmaceutical distribution center has opened in Surrey, operated by McKesson Canada. Since March, the fully operational facility has been supplying medications, vaccines, specialty pharmaceuticals, and over-the-counter products to more than 1,300 health care facilities across British Columbia. Every night, it processes over 50,000 orders, employs 180 people, and uses advanced technology and cold chain storage to ensure efficient delivery of medications. A notable aspect of the facility is its specialty pharmacy, which compounds 10,000 products monthly and provides medication to 80% of the province's ophthalmologists, including specialized oncology treatments. Additionally, the center aids patients dealing with insurance complexities for expensive specialty medications, offering timely, complex, and customized care. McKesson Canada operates 13 distribution centers across the country, each equipped with contingency plans for crisis support.

title: Hundreds of UT Health San Antonio students set to graduate this Saturday at spring commencement
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Hundreds of students from UT Health San Antonio are set to graduate at the spring commencement on Saturday, May 18, 2024. This event will celebrate over 1,100 candidates for graduation, including 884 in May and 230 in the summer, from various schools such as the Joe R. and Teresa Lozano Long School of Medicine, Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, School of Nursing, School of Dentistry, and School of Health Professions. The commencement will take place at the Alamodome in San Antonio, TX, with John M. Zerwas, MD, serving as the commencement speaker. Notably, the ceremony will include the first graduates of the nation's inaugural dual degree program in medicine and artificial intelligence (AI), a collaboration between UT Health San Antonio and The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). UT Health San Antonio is recognized for its contributions to health science education, research, patient care, and community engagement, and is designated as a Hispanic-Serving Institution.

title: A long-term ketogenic diet accumulates aged cells in normal tissues, a UT Health San Antonio-led study shows
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: A study led by UT Health San Antonio has found that a long-term ketogenic diet can lead to the accumulation of aged cells in normal tissues, particularly affecting heart and kidney function. The research suggests that while a ketogenic diet can improve certain health conditions, its continuous use without breaks may induce cellular senescence, a state of permanent cell arrest associated with aging and inflammation. However, intermittent ketogenic dieting, incorporating regular breaks from the diet, showed no such adverse effects. This finding indicates the potential benefits of a ketogenic diet might be optimized through planned intervals of diet cessation. The study, involving researchers from various institutions, underscores the importance of moderation and breaks in dietary regimens to prevent long-term health consequences.

title: UT Health San Antonio, 7 collaborators garner $46 million from NIH to move discoveries into practice
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio and seven partners have been awarded $46 million by the NIH to turn scientific findings into effective health solutions, focusing on decreasing health disparities among Mexican Americans, active military, and veterans. This grant, from the Clinical and Translational Science Awards Program, seeks to improve society with clinical advancements. The group, including The University of Texas at Austin Dell Medical School and the Texas Biomedical Research Institute, will utilize the funds over the next five to seven years. This continues UT Health San Antonio's role as the lead for the South-Central Texas CTSA Program hub, with total NIH funding in the area reaching $126 million by 2030. The project will fund larger pilot projects, improve educational programs, and involve the community in health research to promote health equity and reduce disparities. This marks the fourth CTSA grant for UT Health San Antonio, underlining its dedication to fostering health innovation in South and Central Texas.

title: Class of 2024 ready to make lives better
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio's Class of 2024 is preparing for their graduation, reflecting on their educational paths. Out of 1,098 graduates, five students from different schools within the university shared their stories, showing the diversity and enthusiasm of those joining the healthcare workforce. These students come from the School of Nursing, School of Medicine, Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, School of Health Professions, and School of Dentistry. Their experiences underline the university's dedication to academic, research, and clinical excellence, aiming to enhance lives through their future healthcare contributions. UT Health San Antonio remains committed to positively impacting the community and beyond, supported by its mission and various informational and promotional platforms.

title: Researchers at UT Health San Antonio, UTSA, UT Tyler receive $1M grant, partner in improving trauma care using AI
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Researchers at UT Health San Antonio, UTSA, and UT Tyler have been awarded a $1 million grant to collaborate on enhancing trauma care through the development and application of artificial intelligence (AI) tools. This partnership aims to improve decision-making processes among clinicians in trauma care. James Bynum, PhD, a leading figure at UT Health San Antonio, highlighted the potential of this collaboration to advance the field. UT Health San Antonio, a prominent health science university and a Hispanic-Serving Institution, is committed to missions in education, research, patient care, and community engagement, having graduated over 42,550 alumni. The institution is known for its significant contributions to health science, including efforts to improve community health and well-being.

title: UT Health Science Center San Antonio receives $1.5 million to advance cancer and Alzheimer's research
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio (UT Health San Antonio) has received $1.5 million from the William and Ella Owens Medical Research Foundation to fund research on pediatric and pancreatic cancers, and Alzheimer’s disease. This grant will support eight faculty members working on innovative projects to understand and treat these diseases. Their research includes studying genetic risk factors and microglial genes in Alzheimer’s, developing new treatments for pediatric cancers, glioblastoma recurrence, and pancreatic cancer, such as human CAR-T cell therapies. It also examines the effects of environmental factors like air pollution on Alzheimer’s and the role of gene-environment interactions in late-onset Alzheimer’s. This effort highlights UT Health San Antonio’s dedication to advancing medical research and creating new treatments for complex diseases, with a collaborative selection process involving key faculty and researchers.

title: Thinning of brain region may signal dementia risk 5-10 years before symptoms
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Researchers from UT Health San Antonio, along with their peers from the University of California, Davis, and Boston University, have found that the reduction in the thickness of the cortical gray matter in the brain might be a key indicator of dementia, noticeable 5-10 years before symptoms appear. This discovery, based on MRI brain scans of individuals from the Framingham Heart Study and a cohort from California, shows that the thickness of the cortical gray matter could aid in identifying people at a high risk of dementia. This would allow for early therapeutic measures and changes in lifestyle to decelerate the advancement of the disease. The findings, consistent across various racial and ethnic groups, indicate that this biomarker could be beneficial in clinical trials for choosing participants and assessing treatments. Future studies will investigate changeable risk factors associated with cortical thinning, like diet and exercise, providing hope for prevention methods. The study received support from the National Institutes of Health/National Institute on Aging and was published in Alzheimer’s & Dementia: The Journal of the Alzheimer’s Association.

title: establishes Be Well Institute on Substance Use and Related Disorders - UT Health San Antonio
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio has launched the Be Well Institute on Substance Use and Related Disorders, a comprehensive initiative aimed at advancing research, education, and evidence-based treatments for substance use and addiction. The institute incorporates the existing Be Well Texas initiative, expanding its scope to include national research, clinical, and public health programs. It aims to become a premier center for substance use and addiction clinical care and research, focusing on person-centered, interprofessional care, and advancing scientific understanding into practice to improve health outcomes. The institute will support grants, partner with relevant UT Health San Antonio entities, and launch clinical and translational research programs. It seeks to address the significant public health challenge of substance use, which has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic, through innovative research, local networks, and engagement, while also removing stigma and supporting recovery. Jennifer Sharpe Potter, PhD, MPH, serves as the founding director, emphasizing the institute’s commitment to transformational care and the discovery of new treatments.

title: researchers partner with UTSA, use AI to improve real-time coronary imaging - UT Health San Antonio
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio researchers, in collaboration with UTSA, have developed an advanced AI-based imaging tool aimed at enhancing real-time coronary imaging. This innovative tool, a joint effort between Marc Feldman, MD, from UT Health San Antonio, and Paul Rad from the UTSA School of Data Science, allows clinicians to effectively view and assess a patient’s coronary artery. It specifically aids in evaluating plaque build-up and predicting future heart attack risks in real time. This initiative underscores UT Health San Antonio's commitment to advancing medical research, patient care, and education, as highlighted by its role as a leading health science university and a Hispanic-Serving Institution. The collaboration aligns with the university's broader mission to improve lives through excellence in academics, research, and clinical care.

title: Mays Cancer Center: Targeting certain molecular interactions could yield new strategies for treating prostate cancer
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Research at Mays Cancer Center, which is part of UT Health San Antonio, has discovered that focusing on specific molecular interactions, especially the multivalent interactions of androgen receptors (AR), might provide new ways to treat prostate cancer and diseases involving AR. Androgen receptors are proteins that control the development of male characteristics by regulating gene activity. The study, published in Molecular Cell, emphasizes the need to keep these interactions at precise levels for ARs to function correctly and suggests that disruptions in these interactions could cause disease. By targeting AR multivalent interactions pharmacologically, we might be able to create treatment strategies for prostate cancer and similar conditions. This research highlights the vital role of hormone-induced enhancer assembly and the possibilities for new treatments based on molecular insights.

title: Class of 2024 Graduates from NYU Grossman School of Medicine
summary: NYU Grossman School of Medicine celebrated the graduation of 109 new doctors at its 183rd commencement ceremony, held at Carnegie Hall. Dean Robert I. Grossman, MD, emphasized the importance of leadership in healthcare, urging graduates to embody qualities such as vision, courage, humility, and curiosity. Senator Joe Manchin, delivering the commencement address, highlighted the significant responsibility of being a healthcare provider and the impact of serving the community. Student speaker Victor Sanchez, MD, praised the school for its aspirational culture and commitment to addressing healthcare challenges. The class of 2024, which will enter residencies in 22 different specialties, includes graduates from the three-year MD pathway and students who completed dual degrees. Internal medicine was the most popular residency choice. Starting from 2023, all students will graduate in three years with an option for a secondary degree in the fourth year.

title: From the Battlefield to the Operating Room: Navy SEAL Graduates from NYU Grossman School of Medicine
summary: Mason Blacker, an active-duty Navy SEAL, graduated from NYU Grossman School of Medicine after completing an accelerated three-year MD pathway. Inspired to pursue medicine after witnessing a life-saving neurosurgical procedure in Iraq, Blacker prepared for medical school while serving in Afghanistan. NYU's program, unique for its three-year pathway and full tuition scholarship, was ideal for Blacker, who had clear career goals and a background in emergency medical service. Despite personal challenges, including his father's cancer diagnosis, Blacker received support from the school. His father thrived after receiving innovative treatment at NYU Langone’s Perlmutter Cancer Center, thanks to the intervention of Blacker's adviser. After graduating, Blacker plans to specialize in neurosurgery with a focus on traumatic brain injuries, reflecting his dedication to service and excellence in medicine.

title: Meet Dr. Gbenga Ogedegbe
summary: Dr. Gbenga Ogedegbe, a professor at New York University Grossman School of Medicine and director of the Institute for Excellence in Health Equity at NYU Langone Health, has dedicated over 25 years to researching high blood pressure interventions with the support of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI). His work, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa, has led to significant changes in the treatment and management of high blood pressure, contributing to global efforts in reducing health disparities. Dr. Ogedegbe's research not only focuses on high blood pressure and heart disease risk factors but also encompasses studies on blood and sleep disorders, such as sickle cell disease and sleep apnea. With NHLBI funding, he has been instrumental in improving research capacity and reducing heart disease burden in Sub-Saharan Africa, emphasizing the importance of behavioral interventions in managing chronic diseases. His findings have influenced policies and practices in Ghana and Nigeria, enhancing patient outcomes through innovative approaches like motivational interviewing techniques. Dr. Ogedegbe aims to further address socioeconomic factors affecting health and develop strategies for improving heart disease outcomes in Black populations, both in clinical and community settings.

title: Insights from a groundbreaking study reveal near-death experiences of patients
summary: A groundbreaking study led by NYU Grossman School of Medicine, involving 25 hospitals across the US and the UK, has provided new insights into near-death experiences (NDEs) and the resilience of brain activity after cardiac arrest. Published in the Resuscitation journal by Elsevier, the research found that nearly 40% of patients who were revived after their hearts stopped reported memories or conscious thoughts during their ordeal. Contrary to the belief that the brain shuts down within 10 minutes after cardiac arrest, the study discovered signs of normal and near-normal brain activity up to an hour into resuscitation. This challenges the conventional understanding of life after death and suggests that the human brain is more robust and resilient to oxygen deprivation than previously thought. The findings, which include vivid and structured near-death experiences, could revolutionize the field of resuscitation medicine. However, the study also emphasizes the need for further research into the experiences and claims of awareness surrounding death.

title: Grossman receives $1.6 million research grant
summary: The NYU Grossman School of Medicine has received over $1.6 million from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services for health care research. This grant is part of a larger $9 million fund announced by New York congressmember Jerrold Nadler to support healthcare institutions in New York’s 12th Congressional District, including the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Weill Cornell Medicine. The funding will support a variety of research projects at Grossman, including those in cancer, diabetes, and mental health treatment. The NYU Langone Health spokesperson expressed gratitude for the congressman's support, highlighting the potential of this funding to advance medical breakthroughs. Grossman's research includes studies at the Perlmutter Cancer Center, the Diabetes Research Program, and the Department of Psychiatry, aiming to develop new treatment approaches based on their findings.

title: 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations & Scholarship Conference Highlights
summary: The 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations and Scholarship Conference, hosted by NYU Grossman School of Medicine's Educator Community on October 23, 2023, showcased over 55 presentations and workshops, emphasizing medical education advancements. Keynote speaker Adam Rodman, MD, MPH, discussed leveraging AI in medical education, highlighting his role as a medical historian and educational researcher. The event also recognized faculty contributions to medical education and featured sessions on various topics, including the use of ChatGPT for data analysis, educational nudges for residents, and AI in clinical reasoning documentation. Workshops focused on medical education research, narrative medicine, and integrating empathy and equity into medical education. The conference also introduced a Generative AI Prompt-a-Thon for exploring AI's role in medical education. Awards were presented for outstanding poster presentations, demonstrating innovations and impacts in medical education.

title: Artificial Intelligence Tool Detects Sex-Related Differences in Brain Structure
summary: A study by NYU Langone Health researchers has used artificial intelligence (AI) to find sex-related differences in brain structure by analyzing MRI scans. The study showed AI could identify the biological sex of individuals by looking at brain structure and complexity patterns invisible to the human eye. These differences were mainly in the brain's white matter, essential for communication between brain regions. This finding highlights the need to consider sex as a variable in neurological and psychiatric research since men and women differently experience and show symptoms of brain disorders. The AI models in the study, trained on thousands of brain scans from men and women, had a 92 percent to 98 percent correct identification rate. Published in Scientific Reports, the findings suggest AI could offer new insights into how psychiatric and neurological disorders differ between men and women. The research received support from the National Institutes of Health and the United States Department of Defense.

title: NYU Among Top 10 in Selected Fulbright Students
summary: New York University (NYU) has been recognized as a top institution for Fulbright U.S. Student Program scholars, securing a place among the top 10 nationwide. This marks the eighth consecutive year NYU has been named a "Top Producing Institution" by the U.S. State Department program. For the 2023-24 academic year, 27 NYU students and alumni were selected for Fulbright scholarships, tying for 8th in the number of recipients. The selected individuals, including 16 undergraduates and 11 graduate students or recent alumni, represented various NYU schools and programs. They will undertake study, research, and English teaching assistantships in 17 countries across the globe. NYU's achievement reflects the diversity and global engagement of its academic community, as well as the university's commitment to supporting students and scholars in addressing global challenges through the Fulbright Program. NYU is currently recruiting for the 2025-26 Fulbright cycle, encouraging interested students and alumni to apply.

title: Change in Genetic Code May Explain How Human Ancestors Lost Tails
summary: A study by researchers at NYU Grossman School of Medicine, published in Nature, suggests a genetic change might explain why humans and apes lack tails, unlike tailed monkeys. The study compared DNA among these species, identifying a unique DNA insertion in the TBXT gene in apes and humans, absent in monkeys. This insertion, when replicated in mice, led to varying tail lengths, including taillessness. The research highlights the role of an AluY insertion within TBXT's regulatory code, affecting tail development through alternative splicing—a process not previously linked to such a significant physical trait. This genetic alteration is thought to have occurred around 25 million years ago, potentially offering evolutionary advantages despite possible links to neural tube defects in humans. The study, involving multiple researchers and funded by several NIH grants, opens new avenues for understanding the genetic underpinnings of human evolution and development.

title: Brain Mechanism Found to Determine Which Memories Last
summary: A study led by researchers from the NYU Grossman School of Medicine has discovered a brain mechanism that decides which memories will be long-lasting. This mechanism involves neurons in the hippocampus that activate in rhythmic cycles, creating "sharp wave-ripples." These ripples are essential for the consolidation of memories, as events followed by a significant number of sharp wave-ripples are more likely to be replayed during sleep and thus retained. The study revealed that these ripples happen during idle moments following waking experiences, marking certain memories for replay and consolidation while asleep. This finding could pave the way for future studies on modifying sharp wave-ripples to improve memory or lessen the recall of traumatic events. The findings were published in the journal Science on March 28, 2024.

title: NYU Langone Health in the News— Friday, March 29, 2024
summary: NYU Langone Health's recent highlights include a study on memory consolidation during sleep led by researchers at NYU Grossman School of Medicine, which identified sharp wave-ripples as a crucial brain mechanism. Another team found implications of immune checkpoint for the treatment of cancer and autoimmune diseases. The Perlmutter Cancer Center is advancing a phase 3 trial for a metastatic melanoma mRNA vaccine. Research also shows that consuming more than one alcoholic drink a day increases the risk of heart disease in women. A groundbreaking whole-eye and partial face transplant was successfully performed without signs of rejection. A study linked chronic kidney disease parameters with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism after hospitalization. Discussions on various health topics were featured in the media, including the impact of alcohol on heart health, the benefits of vitamin D3, and innovative treatments in ophthalmology and oncology. NYU Langone Health continues to lead in medical research, patient care, and education.

title: Brain Recordings in People Before Surgery Reveal How All Minds Plan What to Say Before Speaking
summary: A study by NYU Grossman School of Medicine, published on March 19 in Brain Communications, explored how the brain plans speech before it is spoken. Researchers analyzed brain recordings from 16 epilepsy patients aged 14 to 43 undergoing pre-surgical mapping at NYU Langone Health between 2018 and 2021. By electrically stimulating specific brain areas and observing speech patterns, they found that pauses in speech, or latencies, offer insights into speech planning. Longer latencies in the inferior frontal gyrus and motor cortex suggest these regions are involved in planning speech, while shorter latencies in other motor cortex areas are linked to speech production. This study, which measured the time between stimulation and speech disruption, adds to the understanding of how different brain regions contribute to speech planning and production. The findings could help refine brain mapping techniques to better protect speech during surgery. Future research aims to explore how these latency patterns apply to other brain functions related to speech.

title: NIH renews COBRE grant for Kansas Institute for Precision Medicine
summary: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) has renewed the Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) grant for the Kansas Institute for Precision Medicine (KIPM) with an $11.4 million award. This funding will support the institute's mission to improve healthcare outcomes by advancing precision medicine, which tailors disease prevention, diagnoses, and treatments to individual genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors. The grant aims to nurture the next generation of physician-scientists in this field by providing junior investigators with financial support, mentoring, and research opportunities. Additionally, it will offer pilot grants to more established researchers. The KIPM, established with the initial COBRE grant in 2019, is unique to Kansas and the surrounding region for its focus on precision medicine and career development for physician-scientists. The renewed grant will also enhance the KIPM's infrastructure, including expanding its research support cores, and aims to double the number of pilot grants offered to four $50,000 grants annually. This funding is expected to bolster the KIPM's contributions to a wide range of health areas and support its goal of becoming a shared resource throughout the region.

title: KU Med executive vice chancellor retires after decade with school - Kansas City Business Journal
summary: Dr. Robert Simari, the executive vice chancellor of the University of Kansas Medical Center, is retiring after over six years in the role and a decade with the institution. During his tenure, he played a pivotal role in the University of Kansas Cancer Center's achievement of being designated as a comprehensive cancer center by the National Cancer Institute in 2022. Simari, a cardiologist and a 1986 graduate of the KU School of Medicine, previously served as vice chairman of the Mayo Clinic's Division of Cardiology Diseases before returning to KU. He was appointed to his executive role by University of Kansas Chancellor Douglas Girod in 2018. Dr. Matthias Salathe, vice chancellor for research and chair of the Internal Medicine Department, has been named interim executive vice chancellor. Simari will remain on the faculty until his retirement on June 30.

title: KU Medical Center researchers working to address lead exposure prevention in southeast Kansas
summary: Researchers at the University of Kansas Medical Center are addressing the issue of lead exposure in southeast Kansas, where lead exposure rates for children are more than double the national average. This region, part of the historical Tri-State District, was a significant producer of lead and zinc for a century, leaving a legacy of contamination from mining activities. The area's children, especially those in rural settings, face serious health risks from lead, which can damage the brain and nervous system, slow development, and cause learning and behavioral problems. Efforts to prevent lead exposure have diminished over the years, with low levels of testing and minimal education at the county level. A recent study highlighted the need for renewed focus on this issue. The Communities Organizing to Promote Equity (COPE) project, led by KU Medical Center faculty, aims to improve health equity, including lead poisoning prevention. A $50,000 grant from the National Center for Healthy Housing will support efforts to increase rural community capacity for lead poisoning prevention and inform policy changes in southeast Kansas. Researchers are also mapping policies related to lead poisoning to understand their impact and to create a policy toolkit for prevention, aiming to make environments safer and address lead exposure across the state.

title: KU Medical Center's COPE program built an infrastructure to execute 'Operation Hydration' throughout Kansas
summary: KU Medical Center's COPE program, initially funded by a 2021 grant to improve COVID-19 testing and response in rural Kansas, expanded its focus to address a severe heatwave in August, launching 'Operation Hydration'. This initiative distributed cold water and ice across Kansas, particularly targeting vulnerable populations during extreme heat conditions with heat indices exceeding 120 degrees. Utilizing the infrastructure and networks established for COVID-19 outreach, COPE mobilized local health equity action teams and community partners to quickly respond to the public health emergency. The effort saw about 21,000 bottles of water distributed in a few days, demonstrating the program's adaptability and impact beyond its original COVID-19 focus. This successful response not only provided immediate relief but also strengthened community resilience and preparedness for future emergencies.

title: KU Medical Center graduates more than 700 students prepared to begin their new careers
summary: KU Medical Center celebrated the graduation of more than 700 students from its schools of Health Professions, Medicine, and Nursing in ceremonies held on May 11, 2024, at Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall in Kansas City, Kansas. The event, which also offered a virtual attendance option, marked the culmination of rigorous academic and clinical training across various healthcare fields. The School of Health Professions graduated 244 students, commemorating its 50th class on the school's 50th anniversary. The School of Medicine awarded degrees to 284 students, with 202 receiving M.D. degrees and 82 earning advanced degrees and certificates in fields like pharmacology and biostatistics. The School of Nursing celebrated 206 graduates, with a mix of bachelor’s, master's, and doctoral degrees. Speakers at the ceremonies emphasized the importance of professionalism, gratitude, and the impact the graduates are poised to make in their respective fields. The graduates, some of whom are entering healthcare after pursuing different initial career paths or overcoming the disruptions caused by the pandemic, shared reflections on their journeys and aspirations for the future.

title: KU medical student publishes study on feline facial expressions
summary: Lauren Scott, a first-year medical student at the University of Kansas School of Medicine, published a study revealing that domestic cats have 276 unique facial expressions for communication. Initially an anthropology major at UCLA, Scott's interest shifted from human to animal communication, leading her to analyze the facial expressions of cats. Under the mentorship of Brittany Florkiewicz, Ph.D., at UCLA, she spent nearly a year recording and studying 53 shorthair cats in a Los Angeles cat café. Using the Animal Facial Action Coding System, they identified various facial movements, such as ear positions and whisker movements, contributing to the cats' distinct expressions. This research, published in the journal Behavioural Processes, challenges the stereotype of cats as aloof, suggesting their remarkable social skills are likely influenced by domestication. Scott's unique path to medical school was inspired by her interest in anthropology and the influence of medical anthropologist Paul Farmer. Her work with cats not only enriched her academic journey but also helped her secure a research position in cancer immunology, shaping her future in medical research.

title: Research at KU Medical Center experiences tremendous growth
summary: Research at the University of Kansas Medical Center has significantly grown, with its federal research portfolio nearly doubling since 2017 and clinical trial revenues increasing by 45% since 2021. In fiscal year 2023, federally funded research spending reached over $120 million, marking an 11.5% average annual growth over six years. Total research spending hit $180 million in 2023, a 50% increase from 2019. This growth spans across its schools of Health Professions, Medicine, and Nursing, with substantial investments in research infrastructure and equipment. Notable achievements include a $27 million NIH grant for the Frontiers Clinical and Translational Science Institute, a $13.8 million National Cancer Institute award, and a $12 million NIH grant for the Kansas Center for Metabolism and Obesity Research. Administrative and policy changes, alongside clinical integration with The University of Kansas Health System, have further supported this expansion, enabling KU Medical Center to enhance its position in conducting large clinical trials and research projects.

title: Kansas Conference Draws Experts in Forensic Investigation
summary: On April 24, 2024, Kansas hosted its inaugural Coroner Medicolegal Death Investigation Conference, attracting professionals from across the state to learn from national and international experts in death investigations. Organized by the KU Medical Center Area Health Education Center in collaboration with the International Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners, the National Network of Public Health Institutes, and the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, the conference aimed to enhance the quality of death investigations in Kansas. It covered a range of topics from the initial call to postmortem examinations and cause of death determinations, with a particular focus on drug toxicity-related deaths amidst the opioid crisis. Attendees received training on identifying decedents, recognizing scene indicators of drug use, and understanding the multi-step process in infant and child death investigations, including the use of reenactment dolls for crimes against children. The event was deemed a success, highlighting a strong demand for such training in Kansas.

title: An $11.5 million grant from NIH launches Implementation Science for Equity Center at KU Medical Center
summary: An $11.5 million grant from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) has been awarded to KU Medical Center to establish the Implementation Science for Equity Center. This initiative aims to address the significant delay—averaging 17 years—in translating research findings from the laboratory to clinical practice, particularly focusing on reducing health inequities. Led by professors Kimber Richter and Christie Befort, the center will develop methods to implement evidence-based practices in clinical care, ensuring equitable healthcare for rural, minority, and underserved populations. This effort is part of the NIH's Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) program, designed to foster biomedical and behavioral research centers through three sequential five-year phases. The Implementation Science for Equity COBRE will support early-career investigators and work on bridging the gap between research and practice with a focus on health equity. Initial projects include interventions for healthy eating in Latino families, support for Latino dementia caregivers, smoking cessation in low-income pregnant women, and preeclampsia prevention strategies.

title: KU Medical Center's 22nd annual K-INBRE symposium recognizes bioscience students from across Kansas and ...
summary: The 22nd annual Kansas IDeA Network of Biomedical Research Excellence (K-INBRE) Symposium, hosted by the University of Kansas Medical Center, celebrated the achievements of 18 undergraduate students from 10 universities across Kansas and Oklahoma. This event aims to inspire students towards careers in bioscience by providing a platform for showcasing their research. Students, under faculty mentorship, presented their work through posters and oral presentations, covering a wide range of scientific endeavors. The symposium underscores the commitment of students and faculty to advancing biomedical sciences and facilitates the exchange of knowledge and collaborative opportunities. Institutions participating included a mix from both states, highlighting the symposium's role in nurturing academic and research talent. The program is supported by an Institutional Development Award from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences of the National Institutes of Health.

title: KU Medical Center announces four-state Heartland Consortium as part of the All of Us Research Program to advance ...
summary: KU Medical Center has announced the formation of the Heartland Consortium, a four-state collaboration involving Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, and Iowa, as part of the National Institutes of Health’s All of Us Research Program. This initiative aims to advance precision medicine by collecting comprehensive health information from over 1 million people across the United States to support future studies and clinical trials on various diseases. With an initial funding of $6.3 million, potentially renewable annually for four years, the consortium seeks to ensure the representation of its regional population in national precision medicine research. The Heartland Consortium, which includes academic medical centers from the University of Kansas, the University of Iowa, the University of Missouri, and the University of Nebraska, will focus on enrolling participants, especially from rural areas and groups historically underrepresented in research. This effort is expected to enhance healthcare by enabling individualized treatment plans based on a person’s biology, behavior, and environment, ultimately benefiting not only the Midwest but the entire nation.

title: Bill Gates, Melinda are proud parents as daughter graduates from medical school. See post
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Bill and Melinda Gates celebrated their daughter Jennifer Gates' graduation from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York. Jennifer, who is 28 years old, completed her MD MPH and shared her achievement on social media, expressing gratitude towards her family, friends, and mentors for their support. Her parents expressed their pride in the comments section of her post. Jennifer is currently a paediatrics resident at the same institution. She previously earned a Master’s in Public Health from Columbia University and a Bachelor’s degree in Human Biology from Stanford University. Jennifer married Nayel Nassar in October 2021, and they welcomed a daughter, Leila, in March of the previous year.

title: 'So Proud Of You': Bill Gates Celebrates Daughter's Medical School Graduation
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Bill Gates and his ex-wife Melinda Gates celebrated their eldest daughter, Jennifer Gates, on her graduation from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York. Jennifer, 28, shared her achievement on Instagram, reflecting on the challenging yet rewarding journey of completing her medical studies, which she described as a childhood dream. She expressed gratitude towards her professors, mentors, friends, and family for their support. Bill Gates praised Jennifer's accomplishment and looked forward to her next steps in residency, emphasizing the luck of her future patients. Melinda Gates also expressed pride in Jennifer's passion, intelligence, and hard work. Jennifer revealed she would be doing her residency in Pediatrics Research at Mt. Sinai. The Gates family, including Jennifer's siblings Rory and Phoebe, maintain a low profile, with each pursuing their academic and professional interests.

title: Mount Sinai Awarded $6.6 Million From National Institutes of Health to Investigate Treatment for Alopecia Areata in ...
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai has received a $6.6 million grant from the National Institutes of Health to explore treatments for alopecia areata in children. Spearheaded by the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, the project will investigate the use of dupilumab in pediatric patients. Alopecia areata, a skin disease causing hair loss, affects over 6.6 million people in the U.S., predominantly children. The study aims to assess the safety, tolerability, efficacy, and durability of dupilumab, a monoclonal antibody already approved for other atopic diseases. The trial will involve 76 children aged 6-17 with significant alopecia, following a 112-week protocol, including a placebo-controlled phase and an open-label phase where all participants receive dupilumab. This research could significantly impact the treatment landscape for alopecia areata, offering hope for long-term, side-effect-minimal solutions.

title: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai names Miriam Merad, MD, PhD, as Dean for Translational Research and ...
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai announced the appointment of Miriam Merad, MD, PhD, as the Dean for Translational Research and Therapeutic Innovation. Dr. Merad, a prominent immunologist, will continue her roles within the institution while aiming to enhance clinical trials and partnerships with the pharmaceutical and biotech industries. Her work has significantly advanced the understanding of immune cells in cancer and inflammatory diseases, and she has been instrumental in pioneering immunotherapy strategies. Dr. Merad's leadership has fostered collaborations across various disciplines, contributing to Mount Sinai's reputation in immunology research. Her research has led to the discovery of new immune cell lineages and targets for immunotherapy, notably in cancer treatment. Dr. Merad joined Mount Sinai's faculty in 2004 and has since received numerous accolades for her contributions to science and medicine.

title: Mount Sinai study identifies genetic link between inflammatory bowel disease and Parkinson’s disease
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Researchers at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai have found a genetic connection between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and Parkinson's disease (PD). The research, led by Meltem Ece Kars, MD, PhD, Yuval Itan, PhD, and Inga Peter, PhD, and published in Genome Medicine, used advanced genomic analysis to identify mutations in the LRRK2 gene as a link between the two conditions and found new genes that may be involved in people with both IBD and PD. The study analyzed data from the Mount Sinai BioMe BioBank, the UK Biobank, and a Danish National Biobank cohort, discovering rare genetic variants and new biological pathways that contribute to the co-occurrence of IBD and PD. These findings open the possibility for developing combined treatment strategies for both diseases and highlight the significance of genetic research in creating personalized medicine for treating patients with IBD and PD.

title: Cellenkos® enters into Sponsored Research Agreement with Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York.
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Cellenkos®, a biotech company specializing in cell therapy for autoimmune diseases and inflammatory disorders, has collaborated with the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, to study CK0804, a myelofibrosis treatment using T regulatory cells from cord blood. Led by Dr. Ronald Hoffman, this partnership seeks to assess CK0804's ability to decrease inflammation in myelofibrosis patients, especially those not responding well to the JAK2 inhibitor ruxolitinib, or as a first-time treatment and in conjunction with other approved treatments. CK0804 is in a phase 1 clinical trial, demonstrating potential in safety, lowering the need for blood transfusions, reducing spleen size, and easing symptoms in myelofibrosis patients. This trial is active in various sites, including Albert Einstein Hospital, MD Anderson Cancer Center, and University of California Davis.

title: Heart Test, Icahn Mount Sinai partner to develop ECG AI algorithms
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Heart Test Laboratories (HeartSciences) and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai (Icahn Mount Sinai) have completed license agreements for developing and commercializing artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms for electrocardiography (ECG). These licenses grant HeartSciences access to a suite of AI-driven ECG algorithms developed by Icahn Mount Sinai, making the institution a shareholder in HeartSciences. The collaboration aims to utilize these algorithms through a cloud-based, hardware-agnostic platform, which would allow integration with various ECG devices worldwide, including HeartSciences' own MyoVista device. This initiative is part of HeartSciences' efforts to advance cardiovascular disease diagnosis and management through AI-ECG technology.

title: At Commencement, Mount Sinai Celebrates Distinguished Service of Kenneth L. Davis, MD, CEO for 20 Years
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: At the 55th Commencement of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, on May 10, 2024, Kenneth L. Davis, MD, was honored for 20 years of service as he became Executive Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees. The event celebrated 191 graduates, noting their medical research and community health contributions, with many continuing their residencies at Mount Sinai. Four researchers, including Dr. Davis, received honorary degrees. The ceremony addressed healthcare challenges, calling for quality and accessibility improvements. Candida Marie Camacho Damian, MD, spoke on resilience and support in the medical field. The Mount Sinai Health System remains dedicated to innovative healthcare and education for a diverse population.

title: Mount Sinai study identifies genetic link bet
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: A study conducted by the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, published in Genome Medicine on May 13, 2024, has discovered genetic links between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and Parkinson’s disease (PD). This groundbreaking research, funded by the Michael J. Fox Foundation, NIH/National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, and the Charles Bronfman Institute for Personalized Medicine at Mount Sinai, suggests new combined therapeutic strategies for treating these conditions. By using advanced genomic analysis, the researchers identified mutations in the LRRK2 gene as a common factor in both diseases, as well as other previously unknown genes that contribute to the comorbidity of IBD and PD. The study analyzed data from the Mount Sinai BioMe BioBank, the UK Biobank, and a Danish National Biobank cohort, revealing significant genetic overlap and suggesting pathways related to immunity, inflammation, and autophagy. These findings open up possibilities for novel treatments targeting both conditions simultaneously, potentially leading to better-targeted therapies and improved patient care.

title: Clinique Partners with Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai to Establish the Mount Sinai-Clinique Healthy Skin ...
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Clinique and the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai have established a philanthropic partnership to launch the Mount Sinai-Clinique Healthy Skin Dermatology Center. This new research center will concentrate on dermatology, particularly investigating the biological aspects of skin aging, skin allergies, and inflammatory skin conditions such as eczema and contact dermatitis. The partnership aims to improve patient lives through scientific research and innovation in allergy science, searching for new treatments for these skin problems. The center will carry out research to discover new topical and systemic treatments to relieve allergic skin conditions, striving to connect basic science with practical clinical applications for healthier skin. Highlighted by Clinique's $5 million commitment over seven years, the partnership will support hiring leading physicians and scientists, and provide resources for advanced equipment and support staff. Research will include all ages, genders, races, and ethnicities, and will also explore the effects of diet, exercise, and stress on skin health. This initiative reflects Clinique's long history of working with dermatologists and its commitment to allergy-tested, dermatologist-driven skincare solutions.

title: Dennis S. Charney
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Dennis S. Charney, MD, is the Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs for the Mount Sinai Health System. He is a globally recognized expert in mood and anxiety disorders and has made significant contributions to the understanding of these conditions and the discovery of new treatments. Since joining the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in 2004, Charney has turned it into a leading medical school by attracting top faculty and securing significant funding from the National Institutes of Health. He has played a key role in developing initiatives focused on health equity, diversity, and gender equity in medicine. Under his leadership, strategic partnerships have been established to advance research and education in areas like precision medicine, immunotherapy, neurosciences, cancer, and cardiology. Charney's research into depression and resilience has resulted in innovative treatments, including using ketamine for treatment-resistant depression. He has received numerous awards for his work and is a prolific author, with over 700 publications.

title: Mount Sinai's Yvette Calderon, MD, MS, Receives Prestigious Award From Society for Academic Emergency Medicine
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Yvette Calderon, MD, MS, Chair of Emergency Medicine at Mount Sinai Beth Israel and Professor of Emergency Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, has been awarded the Sheryl Heron, MD, MPH Legacy Award by the Society for Academic Emergency Medicine’s Academy for Diversity and Inclusion in Emergency Medicine. This award, given at the SAEM Annual Meeting in Phoenix, acknowledges Dr. Calderon's lasting dedication to justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion through her contributions in research, mentorship, and leadership. Dr. Calderon, the first physician from Mount Sinai to receive this honor, has committed her career to combating healthcare disparities and fostering diversity in the medical profession to enhance patient care in New York City. Her initiatives include creating the first multimedia-based HIV testing and counseling program and leading efforts to improve health equity in emergency departments. Furthermore, Dr. Calderon has concentrated on mentoring medical students from underrepresented backgrounds and working to increase their retention and advancement within academic settings.

title: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai Awarded $3.2 Million to Support Free Summer Program For Disadvantaged ...
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai has received a $3.2 million grant from the Health Resources and Services Administration to fund a free summer program for underprivileged students aspiring to pursue a career in medicine. This grant supports a five-year training project as part of the Northeast Regional Alliance (NERA) MedPrep ambassador program, in partnership with Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Columbia University Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Manhattan-Staten Island Area Health Education Center. It focuses on college freshmen and sophomores from New York or New Jersey who are interested in attending medical school, providing a three-year commitment to equip them with essential skills and competencies for succeeding in medical school. Participants will receive a stipend, MCAT preparation, clinical and research opportunities, academic advice, mentorship, training in cultural competency, and wellness programs. Since starting in 2018, the program has assisted around 1,160 students, involving 150 students each summer, with the goal of diversifying the medical workforce and enhancing the ability to care for diverse patient groups.

title: How the Change Healthcare cyberattack is straining providers, and what the government can do
summary: The Change Healthcare cyberattack has significantly disrupted healthcare delivery across the United States, especially affecting oncology providers. The attack on February 21 caused Optum's payment processing to shut down, leading to cancer treatment delays due to stopped financial transactions and manual billing. Providers are facing cash flow issues during this crisis, particularly as they await approval from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to switch to alternative processors, a process taking at least 21 days. The aftermath of the cyberattack has prompted calls for government intervention and financial relief for affected providers from healthcare industry groups. The American Medical Association (AMA) has also requested emergency funds to help with the financial impact. This incident highlights the vulnerability of a consolidated healthcare system to cyberattacks and the importance of having effective crisis management strategies.

title: COA 2024: Back in Orlando With Reimbursement Challenges Topping the Agenda
summary: The Community Oncology Alliance (COA) 2024 conference, themed "Stronger Together," is set to take place in Orlando, focusing on challenges in reimbursement for community providers, particularly in the aftermath of a significant cyberattack affecting prior authorization, claims handling, and payment processes. The conference aims to address these and other ongoing issues, offering sessions on policy, business, clinical, and pharmacy topics to aid practice survival and advocate for policy changes. Highlights include a keynote by Joe Theisman and discussions on navigating formularies, revenue cycle management, and the impact of pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) and direct-and-indirect remuneration (DIR) fees on oncology drug reimbursements. The event also emphasizes the power of advocacy and provides legislative updates, reflecting COA's efforts to highlight and address challenges faced by community oncology practices.

title: COA Supports Bills to Ensure Access to Cancer Medications
summary: The Community Oncology Alliance (COA) has endorsed two bills aimed at ensuring seniors have access to vital medications, including cancer treatments. This move follows COA's lawsuit against the CMS interpretation of the Stark Law, which has been used to restrict the mailing of oral medications to patients by oncologists and urologists. The first bill, the Seniors’ Access to Critical Medications Act of 2023, introduced by a bipartisan group of U.S. Representatives, seeks to amend the Social Security Act to allow the delivery of medications by mail or courier without violating the Stark Law. The second bill, the Protecting Patient Access to Cancer and Complex Therapies Act, addresses concerns over the Inflation Reduction Act's impact on Medicare reimbursement rates for drugs, which could significantly cut payments to providers and potentially close community oncology practices. COA argues these legislative measures are essential to maintain patient access to lifesaving medications and sustain the nation's cancer care system.

title: HIMSSCast: How Karmanos Cancer Institute uses AI to find high-risk breast cancer
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute, part of McLaren Health Care with 16 locations in Michigan and Ohio, is using artificial intelligence (AI) to better assess the risk of breast cancer, especially in identifying patients at high risk early. Dr. Eric Brown highlights the critical role of early detection in improving survival rates and reducing the need for aggressive treatments. The institute employs Volpara's AI-powered software during mammogram screenings to analyze various risk factors and generate both five-year and lifetime breast cancer risk scores. This method has greatly improved the identification process, with 7,000 patients screened and 700 recognized as high-risk. Those at high risk are then referred to the institute's women's wellness program for early diagnosis and treatment or preventative actions. This effort marks a move towards more personalized and effective breast cancer screening and care.

title: Student research in the spotlight at Cancer Biology Graduate Program symposium
summary: The 13th annual Graduate Research Symposium of the Cancer Biology Graduate Program, hosted by Wayne State University School of Medicine and the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute, showcased student research achievements. Peter Dimitrion won the Leonard N. Simons Award for Exemplary Research and Scholarly Achievement for his doctoral dissertation on "Epigenetic Regulation of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis Pathophysiology and Microenvironment by HDAC3." The symposium, initiated in 2009, aims to highlight the work of M.S., Ph.D., and M.D./Ph.D. students. This year, distinguished alumnus Stephanie Blocker, Ph.D., delivered a keynote on her career in academic research. Alexis Wilson received the Mary Lou Zieve Award for Professional Development, focusing her doctoral studies on metastatic prostate cancer. The event featured six oral and 18 poster presentations, with awards for best presentations in both categories.

title: Hundreds of Breast Cancer Survivors to be Celebrated at the Karmanos Cancer Institute and Detroit Tigers' 12th ...
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute, in collaboration with the Detroit Tigers and McLaren Health Care, is set to celebrate the 12th Annual Pink Out the Park event on June 8, during a game against the Milwaukee Brewers at Comerica Park. This event aims to raise breast cancer awareness, celebrate survivors, and honor the memories of those who have battled the disease. Breast cancer survivors will be recognized in a pre-game ceremony, and the first 15,000 fans will receive a special "Pink Out the Park" Tigers jersey. The event will also feature informational booths on breast cancer screenings, opportunities for donations to breast cancer research, and various activities and entertainment options for attendees. A portion of the ticket sales and other fundraising activities during the event will support breast cancer research at Karmanos.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute receives 2024 Women's Choice Awards® for cancer care and patient experience
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute has been awarded the 2024 Women's Choice Awards® for being one of America's Best Hospitals for Cancer Care and for being among the country's 100 Best Hospitals for Patient Experience. This marks the 11th consecutive year Karmanos has received recognition from the Women's Choice Award®, highlighting its commitment to exceptional cancer care and patient experience. Karmanos was specifically lauded for its outstanding cancer care services, mammogram imaging, and minimally invasive surgery. The institute stands out among the top 4% of 4,728 hospitals offering cancer care services in the U.S., attributed to its comprehensive services, low infection rates, and high patient recommendation ratings. Additionally, the Women's Choice Award® also recognized Karmanos Cancer Center's Walt Comprehensive Breast Center and its achievements in minimally invasive surgery. This recognition underscores Karmanos' role as a leader in cancer care, research, and education, furthering its vision of a world free of cancer.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute first to receive new FDA-approved treatment for advanced liver cancer
summary: Karmanos Cancer Institute has become the first in the United States to offer the newly FDA-approved TheraBionic P1 device for treating advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), the most common type of liver cancer. This innovative device, which is used at home, emits low levels of radio-frequency electromagnetic fields to block tumor cell growth without harming healthy tissue. It is designed for patients 18 and older who have not responded to first and second-line therapies. The TheraBionic P1 device, which delivers treatment via a spoon-shaped antenna placed on the patient's tongue for one-hour sessions three times a day, has shown to be effective in reducing tumor growth and is well-tolerated by patients, with no serious adverse events reported. This treatment option is seen as transformative for patients with advanced liver cancer, offering a new hope for extending life and improving quality of life.

title: Surgical Oncologist Joins the Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Flint
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Flint has announced the addition of Dr. Jeffrey Hotaling, a board-certified Surgical Oncologist, to its team. Dr. Hotaling specializes in the surgical management of head and neck cancers, including mouth and throat cancers, as well as melanoma, thyroid, parotid, and sinus tumors. He completed his fellowship in head and neck surgical oncology and microvascular reconstruction at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, PA, and his residency at Loyola University Medical Center in Hines, IL. Dr. Hotaling, who graduated from Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine in Chicago, IL, is committed to improving access to care for cancer patients in Flint. Patients recently diagnosed with cancer or seeking a second opinion can see Dr. Hotaling at the Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Flint, located at 4100 Beecher Road, Flint, MI.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute offers more cancer services and specialists at Roseville medical oncology clinic
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute has improved its services at the Roseville medical oncology clinic, at 30550 Utica Road, by introducing chemotherapy infusion treatments, expanding clinic space, and planning to add a compounding pharmacy. This growth enables three doctors to provide specialized care for various cancers, such as thoracic, head and neck, breast, skin, and gynecological cancers, within the community. The facility now has eight infusion bays with a negative pressure room and a new pharmacy for on-site chemotherapy medication mixing. Opened initially in December 2022, the clinic has expanded to help achieve the Karmanos Cancer Institute's goal of offering comprehensive cancer care services locally. This expansion is part of a larger effort to grow Karmanos' outpatient network, now including 16 locations. Brian Gamble, president of Karmanos Cancer Hospital and the Karmanos Cancer Network, highlights the institute's commitment to providing top-rated doctors and high patient satisfaction at all its facilities.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Macomb Hosts Free Oral Cancer Screening
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Macomb is hosting a free oral cancer screening event for the public on May 13, from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., at 1080 Harrington Boulevard, on the campus of McLaren Macomb hospital. This initiative is part of the efforts by the Karmanos Cancer Network to address the rapidly increasing incidence of oral cancer, which had over 54,000 diagnoses in Michigan last year. The screening aims to identify pre-cancerous tissues, which can be indicative of cancer, through a painless and noninvasive process. Participants with abnormal findings will be referred to a nurse navigator for further consultation with a physician. The screening is particularly significant as oral cancers, often linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV), can affect anyone and might not present any symptoms initially. Risk factors include tobacco and alcohol use, prolonged sun exposure, gender, and race. Appointments are required and can be made by calling (586) 493-7510.

title: Karmanos welcomes new VP of the Karmanos Cancer Network
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute has appointed Doris Ranski-Zazula as the new Vice President of the Karmanos Cancer Network, a part of McLaren Health Care. The Karmanos Cancer Network, one of the largest cancer care and research networks in the United States, has 15 locations with its main hospital in Detroit. Ranski-Zazula, who previously served as the regional director of Cancer Services at Karmanos locations in Flint, Pontiac, and Lapeer, succeeds Lauren Lawrence, who retired after 10 years. Ranski-Zazula aims to continue expanding services and enhancing patient care across Michigan. Her responsibilities include overseeing daily operations, ensuring high-quality care, standardizing workflows, recruiting oncologists, offering clinical trials locally, and developing relationships with partners such as Michigan State University. Brian Gamble, president of the Karmanos Cancer Hospital and Network, praised Ranski-Zazula's familiarity with the network and her background in physician recruitment and business development. Ranski-Zazula has over 30 years of healthcare experience and holds a Master of Science in Health Care Administration from Central Michigan University.

title: Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute and Wayne State University name Boris C. Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., FACP ...
summary: Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute and Wayne State University have appointed Boris C. Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., FACP, as President and Chief Executive Officer, effective August 28, 2023. Dr. Pasche, succeeding Joseph Uberti, M.D., Ph.D., will also serve as Chair of the Department of Oncology at Wayne State University School of Medicine, pending formal approval from the National Cancer Institute (NCI). He is tasked with leading the strategic vision for the institute's future growth, including planning and evaluation, scientific direction, community outreach, and enhancing multidisciplinary clinical cancer care. Dr. Pasche comes from Wake Forest Baptist Health, where he significantly increased NCI funding and faculty numbers, contributing to the renewal of the NCI core grant. His career spans over 30 years in various clinical and academic roles, notably at the University of Alabama at Birmingham and Northwestern University. The Karmanos Cancer Institute, recognized as a Comprehensive Cancer Center by the NCI, is Michigan's largest cancer care provider. It operates 16 treatment centers and manages extensive research and clinical trial programs through its partnership with Wayne State University.

title: Smarter Radiation Therapy Techniques Enhances Personalized Care for Cancer Patients
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute at McLaren Greater Lansing, which is part of the large Karmanos Cancer Network, is bringing in advanced radiation therapy techniques to offer personalized care for cancer patients. These new methods include using the Varian TruBeam™ linear accelerator for accurate treatment of various cancers, stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) for prostate and breast cancers that allows for treatment in fewer sessions with great precision, and lattice radiotherapy for targeting big, bulky tumors without damaging nearby healthy tissues. Moreover, high-dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy is now available for skin cancers, providing a focused treatment option that might prevent disfiguring surgery. These improvements are designed to better plan treatments, shorten treatment durations, and reduce exposure to healthy tissues, thus improving patient care and outcomes.

title: Detroit research team to develop novel strategies to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and overcome barriers ...
summary: A Detroit research team led by Drs. Ann Schwartz and Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer from Wayne State University and the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute has been awarded a five-year, $9.6 million grant by the National Cancer Institute to study genetic variations in cancer risk and outcomes among African Americans. The project aims to improve the identification and clinical management of hereditary and multiple primary cancers in this underrepresented group. The research will involve three major studies focusing on understanding genetic susceptibility, identifying risk factors for multiple primary cancers, and developing strategies to improve genetic testing accessibility for African Americans. This initiative is significant as it addresses the disparities in genetic research and testing, potentially leading to better prevention, screening, and treatment options for African American populations.

title: How Navigators Help Cancer Patients, Their Families During Treatment
summary: Navigators play a crucial role in assisting cancer patients and their families throughout their treatment journey, as highlighted in a webinar hosted by Karmanos Cancer Institute's Office of Cancer Health Equity and Community Engagement and the Macomb County Cancer Action Council. The webinar, titled "Navigating Your Cancer Journey," emphasized the importance of cancer navigators in improving patients' health outcomes. It distinguished between nurse navigators, who manage clinical aspects such as symptom management and medication guidance, and patient navigators, who help overcome social and financial barriers to care. Kimberly Dean, an oncology nurse navigator with over 20 years of experience, shared insights into her role, likening it to an "air traffic controller" for patients, coordinating screenings and addressing social determinants of health. The session underscored the availability of various navigation services across Michigan, particularly through Karmanos and McLaren Health Care locations, to support cancer patients in accessing quality care.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute, Healthcare Marketing Impact Awards 2023
summary: The Karmanos Cancer Institute was awarded bronze for Integrated Campaign of the Year among providers and insurers at the Healthcare Marketing Impact Awards 2023. Partnering with Fusion92, they launched a comprehensive campaign utilizing digital, television, radio, and print media to highlight life beyond a cancer diagnosis and treatment. Focused on the journey of cancer patients, the campaign's central video featured a cancer survivor running backward, culminating in her completing treatment at Karmanos, symbolizing the continuation of life after cancer. The campaign successfully engaged audiences, with high completion rates for both video and audio ads, and generated over 33,000 landing page views on Karmanos' website. This effort aimed to promote a positive outlook among patients and underscore Karmanos’ role in achieving successful cancer treatment outcomes.

title: South Breaks Ground on $200 Million Whiddon College of Medicine Building
