summary: The University of South Alabama recently started building the new Frederick P. Whiddon College of Medicine, a $200 million project expected to finish by 2026. This 250,000-square-foot building aims to increase the number of medical graduates, boost research and innovation, and tackle the expected shortage of healthcare workers by increasing first-year medical student class sizes from 80 to possibly 120. The facility will have modern labs for advanced learning and research. It's a major investment in healthcare education, funded by $145 million from federal funds, the state, and various donors. The Whiddon College of Medicine, one of 158 accredited MD-granting institutions in the U.S. and one of two in Alabama, is known for its impact on underserved regions and training high-quality doctors who often stay in the state.

title: Banner Year
summary: In 2023, the University of South Alabama celebrated its 60th anniversary with significant achievements and developments. Highlights included a $20 million gift for a new performing arts center, increased first-year enrollment by 19%, and the groundbreaking of a new $200 million College of Medicine building to expand class sizes. The university also celebrated the 50th anniversaries of its Colleges of Medicine and Nursing, enhancing its role in healthcare education. The acquisition of Providence Hospital expanded the USA Health system, and the Jaguar Marching Band was promised a new $10 million facility. The university's athletic teams excelled, with the Jaguars winning the Vic Bubas Cup for a record 16th time. Additionally, a significant donation of bayfront property will support marine education and research. Leadership was strengthened under President Jo Bonner, and the university community saw notable achievements, including a historic bowl victory for the football team and undefeated season for the soccer team.

title: Clean Sweep: Honors College Students Take Top Three Places in Poster Competition
summary: Three Honors College students from the University of South Alabama, Dev Mehta, Kaitlyn Riggins, and Suhas Patil, won first, second, and third place respectively in a research poster competition at the Alabama Academy of Science Conference. The competition was held in Jacksonville, Alabama, where they showcased their research in a section for Honors College students statewide. Mehta, a sophomore in biomedical sciences, discussed the contamination risk of orthotic thermoplastics. Riggins, a senior in communications, examined the spread and effects of misinformation about birth control on TikTok. Patil, a sophomore in biomedical sciences and philosophy, researched the impact of blocking WNK lysine-deficient protein kinase on breast cancer. Their accomplishments were recognized by Dr. Doug Marshall, the Honors College dean, who emphasized the value of such research opportunities in improving undergraduates' academic records and supporting their future academic and career goals.

title: Roots of Research
summary: Dr. Tuan Tran, an assistant professor of biology at the University of South Alabama, received a $40,000 grant from the USDA and the Alabama Department of Agriculture and Industries to study Ralstonia solanacearum, a soil-based bacterium causing wilt in crops like tomatoes, peppers, and potatoes. This pathogen is challenging to eradicate and affects a wide variety of crops globally. Tran's research focuses on the genetic diversity of Ralstonia and is part of broader efforts to understand plant-pathogen interactions, with implications for agriculture in Alabama and beyond. His work also includes studying the bacterium Xanthomonas campetris and collaborating on research related to Salmonella enterica. Tran leads the Plant-Microbe Interactions Research Group at South, mentoring students and aiming to inspire future scientists. His background includes a bachelor’s degree in biotechnology and a Ph.D. in plant pathology, with postdoctoral research at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.

title: University of South Alabama Records Growth in Enrollment, Retention
summary: The University of South Alabama has experienced significant growth in both enrollment and retention rates in 2023, registering one of its largest freshman classes ever with a 19 percent increase in first-year student enrollment. The total enrollment has increased by more than 300, reaching 13,768 students. This growth is attributed to the perceived value of earning a degree from the University, as emphasized by President Jo Bonner. The University has also recorded a first-year student retention rate of 76 percent, the second highest in its history, reflecting successful retention efforts through advising and engagement initiatives. Student housing on campus is at a record high, with nearly 2,500 students residing on campus. The academic quality of incoming students is remarkable, with the Class of 2027 having an average GPA of 3.74. There has also been an 8 percent increase in transfer student enrollment and a 5 percent increase in international enrollment. Certain colleges, like the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Computing, have experienced growths of 9 percent and 8 percent, respectively. The University has employed aggressive recruitment strategies in the past two years, including the expansion of scholarships and offering VIP tours to prospective students. This growth occurs at a time when many universities are facing enrollment challenges, positioning the University of South Alabama for future success.

title: Debra Haberstroh: Lung Cancer Screening
summary: Debra Haberstroh's life changed dramatically during the 2023 New Year's holiday when her oxygen level fell to 85 percent, prompting her daughter to take her to the Emergency Room at Martin North Hospital in Stuart, Florida. Initially suspected to have pneumonia, a routine CT scan uncovered a tumor in Debra's right lung. With a history of asthma, lung issues were not new to Debra, but this diagnosis brought her into a new world of medical challenges and treatments. Relying on the expertise of her pulmonologist, Rose Paccione, MD, and a dedicated team from Cleveland Clinic Martin Health, Debra began a treatment journey that included robotic-assisted bronchoscopy for biopsy and staging, led by Michael Marsh, MD. This cutting-edge method enabled an accurate diagnosis and led to a tumor resection surgery in May 2023. Five months after surgery, Debra's recovery has been slow, with no chemotherapy required. With her medical team's confidence in her being technically cured, Debra now eagerly anticipates making the most of her life, with continuous monitoring to prevent the cancer's return.

title: Transplanting the capacity to breathe
summary: A recent panel discussion titled "Breathing New Life," organized by The Times of India in collaboration with IMAS Healthcare and the Cleveland Clinic, emphasized the urgent need to increase lung donations and establish a national registry for lung transplantation. The event featured leading lung transplant surgeons and pulmonologists from the United States, Abu Dhabi, and India, including Dr. Atul C Mehta from Cleveland Clinic and Dr. Sandeep Attawar from KIMS, discussing various aspects of lung transplantation. The discourse covered the importance of patient selection based on global guidelines, the impact of COVID-19 on lung health awareness, the logistical challenges faced by the National Organ and Tissue Transplant Organisation (NOTTO) in India, and the potential of preventative medicine to reduce the need for lung transplants. The panel also highlighted the advancements in technology and the significance of holistic well-being, including yoga and pranayama, in improving lung function post-transplant. This comprehensive dialogue aimed at enhancing global and national lung health through medical advancements, awareness, and preventive measures.

title: Virtual ICU Rounding: Involving Patients' Loved Ones Through Video
summary: Virtual ICU rounding at Cleveland Clinic involves patients' loved ones through video conferencing, allowing them to be more involved in the patient's care despite physical distance. This program, led by Dr. Adi Gerblich, aims to improve communication between the ICU care team and the family, making the ICU environment less intimidating and fostering better understanding and decision-making. The video conferencing setup is simple, requiring only an internet-connected device with a camera. It enables multiple family members, regardless of their location, to participate in discussions about the patient's care. This approach, which predates the COVID-19 pandemic, proved especially beneficial during the crisis by keeping families informed and involved when visitation restrictions were in place. The program emphasizes the importance of clear, compassionate communication, listening, and honesty to help families make informed decisions about their loved one's care.

title: Tattoo Artist and Dad of Three Thankful for Life After Double-Lung Transplant
summary: Joe Crossmon, a 35-year-old tattoo artist and father of three, was diagnosed with interstitial lung disease (ILD) in 2018. Despite initially being in good health, his condition rapidly deteriorated by spring 2022, requiring him to use over 10 liters of oxygen daily. After treatments failed to improve his condition, Joe was admitted to Cleveland Clinic for a double-lung transplant. The surgery, led by Dr. James Yun, was successful despite complications. Joe's recovery allowed him to return home by October 2022, and he continues to run his tattoo business, now free from oxygen tanks. He expresses gratitude towards his donor and the medical team at Cleveland Clinic. Joe's story highlights the challenges and triumphs of dealing with a severe medical condition and the impact of organ donation.

title: 2023 CHEST Conference Highlights
summary: The 2023 CHEST Conference, highlighted by Dr. Aanchal Kapoor alongside Drs. Angel Coz and Colin Gillespie, covered a broad range of topics including procedure simulations, ICU transfusions, and the impact of artificial intelligence in critical care. The conference, well-attended by Cleveland Clinic staff, showcased around 75-80 sessions featuring a multidisciplinary team. Key sessions discussed included mechanical ventilation controversies, sepsis, ARDS, and strategies for difficult-to-ventilate patients, among others. The importance of case-based discussions and networking opportunities was emphasized, with suggestions for submitting future session proposals. The conference also featured wellness sessions and practical advice for attendees to make the most of their conference experience, including signing up early for popular sessions. The deadline for the next conference submissions was noted as November 30, with advice on creating diverse and clinically relevant proposals.

title: What To Know About Opioids | Respiratory Exchange
summary: The Cleveland Clinic's Respiratory Exchange podcast episode on opioids discusses the significant changes in opioid regulation for medical treatment and the ongoing challenges of addiction, particularly with the advent of fentanyl and carfentanil. The episode features discussions on the continued regulation of opioids, the use of naloxone and its limitations in counteracting overdoses, the recommendation to limit opioid use in elderly populations with co-morbidities, and the appropriate use of opioids in certain patient populations. Experts Dr. Deborah Rathz and Dr. Philippe Haouzi highlight the respiratory toxicity of opioids, the magnitude of the opioid epidemic, and strategies for managing opioid-induced respiratory depression. They emphasize the importance of careful opioid prescribing, especially for patients with pre-existing pulmonary conditions, and acknowledge that while opioids present significant risks, they remain valuable for pain management in specific scenarios, such as end-of-life care.

title: Occupational Lung Disease Outcomes
summary: The Cleveland Clinic Occupational Lung Disease Clinic, established in 2021, addresses a wide range of occupational and exposure-related conditions across Northeast Ohio. It is renowned for its management of chronic beryllium disease, prevalent in Ohio, and offers comprehensive 413b examinations for black lung disease, supported by in-house NIOSH certified chest imaging. Additionally, the clinic is involved in NIH-funded research on occupational air pollution in agricultural workers. Data from 2020 to 2022 shows a significant increase in patients screened and treated for occupational lung diseases, highlighting the clinic’s growth and its role in meeting a previously unmet community need. The clinic also engages in educational outreach through podcasts on topics like beryllium exposure, aiming to inform both medical professionals and the general public.

title: Cardinal Health lifts 2024 profit view on demand for costly specialty drugs
summary: Cardinal Health has raised its 2024 profit forecast due to strong demand for high-cost specialty drugs. The company now expects adjusted earnings to be between $7.30 and $7.40 per share, up from the previous forecast of $7.20 to $7.35 per share. This adjustment comes as analysts had anticipated a profit of $7.28 per share. Cardinal Health's pharmaceutical and specialty solutions unit, which distributes branded and generic drugs, specialty medicines, and over-the-counter healthcare products, reported a 9% increase in revenue year-over-year, reaching $50.7 billion in the third quarter. Despite this, total sales of $54.91 billion fell short of the expected $56.06 billion. Additionally, Cardinal Health announced that its contracts with UnitedHealth Group's OptumRx will not be renewed after June, noting that these contracts mainly involved non-specialty medicines and accounted for 16% of Cardinal's total revenue in fiscal year 2023. Nonetheless, Cardinal reported a quarterly adjusted profit of $2.08 per share, surpassing the expected $1.95 per share.

title: Cardinal Health Reaffirms Fiscal 2024 non-GAAP EPS Guidance and Long-term Targets Amidst Nonrenewal of ...
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with OptumRx, expiring in June 2024, will not be renewed. Despite this, the company has reaffirmed its fiscal 2024 non-GAAP diluted EPS guidance of $7.20 to $7.35 and reiterated its long-term segment profit CAGR target of 4% to 6% and consolidated non-GAAP EPS CAGR target of 12% to 14% for fiscal years 2024 to 2026, relative to a fiscal 2023 baseline. This reflects confidence in achieving sustained growth and delivering attractive returns for shareholders. Sales to OptumRx constituted 16% of Cardinal Health's consolidated revenue in fiscal year 2023, with a significant portion coming from the Pharmaceutical Distribution business. The nonrenewal is expected to have a lower impact on operating margin than the overall segment. Cardinal Health also anticipates an average adjusted free cash flow of approximately $2B from fiscal 2024 to 2026, with a temporary dip in 2025 due to the unwinding of negative net working capital from the OptumRx contract. The company plans to offset the impact through new customer wins, specialty growth, and other actions.

title: Cardinal Health, Inc. (NYSE:CAH) Shares Sold by Principal Financial Group Inc.
summary: Principal Financial Group Inc. reduced its stake in Cardinal Health, Inc. (NYSE:CAH) by 4.9% during the fourth quarter, owning 300,046 shares after selling 15,537 shares. The firm's holdings in Cardinal Health were valued at approximately $30,245,000. Other institutional investors also adjusted their positions in Cardinal Health, with new acquisitions and increases in holdings. Institutional investors and hedge funds own 87.17% of the company's stock. Cardinal Health has received mixed analyst ratings, with an average rating of “Moderate Buy” and an average target price of $107.57. The company's stock performance saw shares opening at $99.08, with a market capitalization of $24.13 billion. Cardinal Health reported quarterly earnings of $2.08 per share, surpassing estimates, with a quarterly revenue of $54.90 billion. The company also announced a dividend increase to $0.5056 per share, payable on July 15th to shareholders of record on July 1st.

title: Cardinal Health acquires Olathe medical devices company
summary: Cardinal Health, a worldwide healthcare company, acquired Olathe-based medical devices company Innara Health, known for the NTrainer System, a device that helps with oral feeding in premature and medically complex infants. The acquisition, confirmed in early 2023 but not initially announced, includes Innara's cutting-edge technology, broadening Cardinal's range in pediatric and adult enteral feeding and nutritional delivery. Innara was introduced to Cardinal in 2022 by Outcome Capital, which led to a partnership and later acquisition for an undisclosed sum. This action is in line with Cardinal's aim to improve its healthcare sector product range by utilizing Innara's neonatal care expertise. The acquisition also introduced the NTrainer System 2.0, marking an important advancement in Cardinal's dive into healthcare technologies.

title: Cardinal Health Loses Contracts With UnitedHealth's OptumRX, Stock Slips
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its contracts with OptumRX, the pharmacy benefits provider of UnitedHealth Group, will not be renewed, resulting in a share price drop in intraday trading. The contracts, which expire at the end of June, accounted for 16% of Cardinal Health's revenue in 2023. Despite this setback, Cardinal Health is optimistic about its future, planning to mitigate the impact through new customer acquisitions, specialty growth, and other measures. The company has reaffirmed its adjusted earnings per share (EPS) guidance for 2024 and its long-term profit growth targets for its Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions segments. CEO Jason Hollar expressed confidence in the company's resilience and value proposition. Shares of Cardinal Health were down 5% following the announcement.

title: Cardinal Health, Inc. Issues Voluntary Nationwide Recall of Certain LEADER™ Brand Eye Drops Supplied by Velocity ...
summary: Cardinal Health, Inc. has initiated a voluntary nationwide recall of all lots of certain LEADER™ brand eye drops supplied by Velocity Pharma, LLC. This recall is due to the potential risk of eye infections stemming from insanitary manufacturing conditions discovered at the supplier's facility, including positive bacterial test results in critical drug production areas. The FDA, which does not endorse either the product or the company, has posted this announcement as a public service. The affected products are over-the-counter ophthalmic sterile drops intended for relieving eye irritation, dryness, or redness. To date, there have been three reported adverse events associated with these products. Consumers are advised to stop using the recalled products and may return them to the place of purchase. The recall, conducted with the FDA's knowledge, affects products distributed nationwide to wholesalers and retailers since December 12, 2021.

title: Cardinal Health's stock falls on mixed quarterly results
summary: Cardinal Health Inc.'s stock dropped 2% in premarket trading following the announcement of mixed fiscal third-quarter results, though it raised its full-year profit forecast. The company's net income was $258 million, a decrease from $345 million the previous year. Adjusted earnings per share increased to $2.08 from $1.74, surpassing the FactSet consensus. However, its revenue of $54.9 billion, up 9%, fell short of the anticipated $56.05 billion. Cardinal Health updated its fiscal year 2024 adjusted earnings per share outlook to $7.30-$7.40 from $7.20-$7.35 and offered preliminary guidance for fiscal year 2025 of at least $7.50 adjusted earnings per share. The pharmaceutical and specialty-solutions sector experienced a 9% rise in sales, while the global medical products and distribution sector saw a 4% increase. The company is dealing with challenges due to the non-renewal of drug distribution contracts with UnitedHealth Group's OptumRx, which previously represented 16% of its revenue. Despite these obstacles, Cardinal shares have increased by 1.4% since the beginning of the year.

title: Cardinal Health (CAH) Beats on Q3 Earnings, Ups '24 EPS View
summary: Cardinal Health, Inc. (CAH) reported third-quarter fiscal 2024 earnings, surpassing expectations with an adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $2.08, a 6.7% beat over the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.95 and a 20% increase year over year. However, its revenue of $54.9 billion, a 9% increase from the previous year, fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 1.6%. The company saw growth across all sectors, with notable increases in pharmaceutical revenues and profits, as well as improvements in the Global Medical Products and Distribution Segment and the Other segment, which includes at-Home Solutions, Nuclear and Precision Health Solutions, and OptiFreight Logistics. Despite mixed results leading to a 1.4% pre-market trading drop, Cardinal Health raised its fiscal 2024 EPS guidance to between $7.30 and $7.40, from the previous range of $7.20-$7.35, and provided preliminary fiscal 2025 guidance with an expected adjusted EPS of at least $7.50. The company continues to project growth in its Pharmaceutical segment and expects segmental profit growth across its business units.

title: Artificial Intelligence at Cardinal Health – Two Use Cases
summary: Cardinal Health, a global healthcare services company, is leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance its services and optimize operational efficiency. With a history dating back to 1971 and serving 90% of US hospitals, Cardinal Health has made strategic investments in AI through partnerships with vendors like IBM and Google Cloud. The article highlights two AI use cases at Cardinal Health: improving patient outcomes and reducing costs while enhancing agent efficiency. The first use case involves analyzing Social Determinants of Health (SDoH) with machine learning to create personalized care plans and manage risks, leading to reduced costs and improved quality of life for patients. This initiative, in collaboration with Jvion, integrates clinical and socioeconomic data to provide a comprehensive view of patients' health risks. The second use case focuses on deploying a conversational AI-powered virtual assistant, CHIA, to handle customer inquiries efficiently, thereby saving costs and allowing human agents to focus on more complex tasks. These AI initiatives demonstrate Cardinal Health's commitment to using technology to improve patient care and operational efficiency.

title: Cardinal Health says contracts with UnitedHealth's OptumRx will not be renewed
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with UnitedHealth Group Inc's OptumRx will not be renewed after their expiration at the end of June 2024. Despite losing these contracts, Cardinal Health is optimistic about its future, citing new customer acquisitions and growth in its specialty pharmacy business as ways to mitigate the impact. The company is particularly excited about the integration of Specialty Networks in fiscal 2025, which is expected to bring additional capabilities. OptumRx, a pharmacy benefit manager, plays a crucial role in negotiating prescription drug prices between insurers and drugmakers. Cardinal Health did not provide further details on the non-renewal of the OptumRx contracts.

title: Argus Lowers Cardinal Health (NYSE:CAH) Price Target to $115.00
summary: Argus has reduced the price target for Cardinal Health (NYSE:CAH) from $120.00 to $115.00, maintaining a buy rating on the stock. This adjustment follows similar actions by other brokerages, with Robert W. Baird lowering their target from $134.00 to $128.00 but still rating the stock as outperform. Conversely, Wells Fargo & Company decreased their target to $94.00, assigning an underweight rating. SVB Leerink began covering Cardinal Health with an outperform rating and a $125.00 price objective. Despite a mix of ratings, the consensus among analysts is a Moderate Buy with an average target price of $107.57. Cardinal Health reported quarterly earnings of $2.08 per share, beating estimates, on revenue of $54.90 billion. The company's stock recently saw a slight increase of 0.4%, with a market cap of $24.13 billion. Cardinal Health also announced an increase in its quarterly dividend to $0.5056 per share. Institutional investors hold a significant portion of the company's stock, indicating strong market trust.

title: Cardinal Health to acquire Specialty Networks and its PPS Analytics platform, a technology enabled multi-specialty ...
summary: Cardinal Health announced its plan to acquire Specialty Networks and its PPS Analytics platform for $1.2 billion in cash. Specialty Networks is a technology-enabled, multi-specialty group purchasing and practice enhancement organization that operates in urology, rheumatology, and gastroenterology. This acquisition aims to create increased clinical and economic value for 11,500 specialty providers, including over 7,000 physicians across 1,200 independent practices. It also intends to expand Cardinal Health's capabilities in specialty therapeutic areas and enhance its Specialty business by providing advanced technologies and services that meet critical business and customer needs. The PPS Analytics platform offers valuable insights for diagnostic and therapeutic interventions by analyzing data from various medical systems using artificial intelligence. The transaction is expected to be accretive to Cardinal Health's non-GAAP earnings per share 12 months following the close, subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals.

title: Cardinal Health lowers medical unit profit forecast, shares fall
summary: Cardinal Health has revised its full-year profit forecast for its medical segment downwards from $400 million to $380 million, citing rising transportation and labor costs, along with global supply chain constraints, as the main challenges. This announcement came despite the company posting better-than-expected second-quarter results, which initially boosted investor sentiment. The medical unit, responsible for producing and distributing company-branded medical, surgical, and laboratory products, has been significantly impacted by these inflationary pressures. Consequently, Cardinal Health's shares dropped by more than 5 percent following the news. However, the company raised its full-year adjusted profit forecast for the entire company for the third time, following strong fourth-quarter total sales of $57.45 billion and an adjusted profit of $1.82 per share, surpassing analysts' expectations.

title: Baptist Memorial and Anderson Sign Shared Mission Agreement
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care, based in Memphis, Tennessee, and Anderson Regional Health System (ARHS) in Meridian, Mississippi, have announced a shared mission agreement to merge in January 2024. Baptist Memorial, a not-for-profit health system, operates 22 hospitals in West Tennessee, Mississippi, and East Arkansas, making it the largest health system in Mississippi and the fourth largest employer in the state. The partnership aims to extend Baptist Memorial's faith-based mission into Mississippi, leveraging both organizations' long histories of community-based health care and reputations for high-quality service. The merger will allow Baptist Memorial to serve more than half of Mississippi's population. Despite the merger, Anderson will maintain its operations with local leadership, ensuring that patients continue to receive advanced, high-quality care close to home. The Baptist system employs over 19,100 people and contributed more than $455 million in community benefit and uncompensated care in fiscal year 2022.

title: Baptist Health to manage, then acquire Drew Memorial Health System
summary: Baptist Health, based in Little Rock, has announced a definitive agreement to manage and then acquire Drew Memorial Health System in Monticello, which will become part of the Baptist Health system. This transition includes a 60-bed hospital, two clinics, and home health services, with the Monticello hospital to be renamed “Baptist Health Medical Center-Drew County” in December. The move comes as Drew Memorial sought a system partner to maintain viability and quality health care in the challenging health care environment, especially for rural hospitals. Drew Memorial Health System employs approximately 350 people and offers a range of services including a cancer and infusion center, emergency department, and more. This partnership is seen as a positive development for Drew County and surrounding communities, aiming for a smooth transition with minimal operational disruptions.

title: Baptist Memorial Health Care merges in Anderson Regional Health System - Memphis Business Journal
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care, based in Memphis and the biggest health system in Mississippi, plans to merge with Anderson Regional Health System (ARHS) in Meridian, Mississippi, by January 2024. Baptist Memorial operates 22 hospitals in West Tennessee, Mississippi, and Eastern Arkansas, employing 19,100 people and working with 5,400 doctors. ARHS, with two hospitals, clinics, a cancer center, 2,100 employees, and 300 doctors, will merge with Baptist Memorial. The goal is to spread Baptist Memorial's faith-driven mission throughout Mississippi, using ARHS's regional influence. After merging, they will serve about half of Mississippi's population, or 1.5 million people. Anderson Regional will keep its local leadership post-merger. The merger's details were not shared.

title: Baptist Memorial Health Care to merge with Mississippi-based Regional Health System
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care, based in Memphis, Tennessee, is set to merge with Anderson Regional Health System, located in Meridian, Mississippi, in January 2024. This merger aims to extend Baptist Memorial's faith-based mission to parts of Mississippi, leveraging over two centuries of combined healthcare experience between the two organizations. Both entities are committed to providing exceptional care and believe that their union will enhance the level of care available in the community. Post-merger, Anderson will continue to operate under local leadership, ensuring that patients receive advanced care close to home. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Anderson Regional Health System's mission by benefiting from the resources of a larger health system, thus better meeting patient needs.

title: Baptist Children's Hospital to expand pediatric services
summary: Baptist Children’s Hospital, under the Baptist Memorial Health Care Corporation (BMHCC), is set to begin a $1.2 million expansion of its pediatric services, including ear, nose and throat, orthopedic, and general surgical services. This expansion, supported by a grant, will feature the construction of a new operating room, enabling the hospital to accommodate up to 286 additional surgeries annually. Enhancements will also include a pediatric spine table, a digital X-ray system for fluoroscopy procedures, and a ventilator for respiratory support in Baptist’s pediatric ambulance. CEO Allison Bosse expressed gratitude towards the Baptist Memorial Health Care Foundation for its support and highlighted the alignment with pediatric specialists to identify growth opportunities that benefit the community. The construction is expected to start between January and March 2024, with completion anticipated by mid-summer 2024.

title: Baptist opening 11 new urgent care centers across area
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care is set to open 11 new Baptist Urgent Care Centers in west Tennessee, north Mississippi, and east Arkansas. These centers will operate seven days a week, providing treatment for injuries and illnesses that are not life-threatening. The new locations include Bartlett, Collierville, Germantown (opening mid-March), Jackson, TN, Batesville, MS, Columbus, Horn Lake, Starkville, West Point, Tupelo, and Wynne, Ark. Further details such as exact locations and hours of operation can be found on BaptistUrgentCare.net.

title: Aidin Joins Forces With Baptist Memorial Health Care in the South
summary: Aidin, a leading healthcare technology firm, has announced a collaboration with Baptist Memorial Health Care to serve patients in Arkansas, Mississippi, and Tennessee. This partnership aims to enhance patient care coordination, reduce hospital readmissions, shorten patient stays, and improve overall patient outcomes. Aidin's technology will be implemented in five of Baptist's hospitals to streamline communication, manage referrals more efficiently, and ensure patients are matched with the best post-acute care providers. This collaboration is expected to lead to better patient experiences and outcomes by leveraging Aidin's innovative solutions for care coordination and referral management.

title: Three newly promoted Baptist top execs replace retiring leaders - Memphis Local, Sports, Business & Food News
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care has promoted three executives, Chris Anderson, Ron Wachsman, and Kimberly Young, to replace the retiring leaders Dr. Paul DePriest, Bill Griffin, and David Elliott. The retirees have been credited with leaving the organization stronger, with healthier patients and more engaged providers. This leadership transition was reported by Aisling Mäki in the Daily Memphian.

title: Baptist Memorial announces 10 new urgent care centers | Health | djournal.com
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care has announced the opening of 10 new urgent care centers, with six located in Mississippi in Batesville, Columbus, Horn Lake, Starkville, West Point, and Tupelo. The Tupelo center is situated behind Cracker Barrel at 1154 Cross Creek Dr. Suite 3. These centers are part of an expansion to provide accessible healthcare services, reflecting Baptist Memorial's commitment to enhancing medical care availability in the region.

title: Baptist C-suite retirement Paul DePriest, Bill Griffin, David Elliott
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care is experiencing significant leadership changes with the retirement of three longtime executives: COO/EVP Dr. Paul DePriest and CFO/EVP Bill Griffin, who retired on September 30, and David Elliott, VP and CEO of Baptist Health Services Group, retiring on October 31. To fill these vacancies, Baptist promoted from within, appointing Chris Anderson as COO, Kimberly Young as CFO, and Ron Wachsman as Chief Revenue Officer (CRO), all effective November 1. Anderson previously served as CEO of Mississippi Baptist Health System, which merged with Baptist Memorial in 2017, and was most recently VP of metro market operations. Young has been with Baptist for over three decades, advancing from an analyst to CFO roles at various Baptist hospitals. Wachsman joined Baptist in 2018 and was VP of the revenue cycle before his new CRO role. These changes come as Baptist remains one of the largest health systems and employers in the region.

title: New hope arises as Baptist Memorial offers treatment in battle against heart disease
summary: Baptist Memorial Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, is offering new hope in the fight against heart disease, the nation's top killer, with a novel treatment called Cardiac Contractility Modulation (CCM). This device, resembling a pacemaker, is implanted under the skin and enhances heart contractility by improving calcium cycling, showing immediate effects. It is designed to last about 20 years but requires weekly charging. This innovative treatment has significantly improved the quality of life for patients like Aubretta Bean, who struggled with congestive heart failure and saw no improvement with traditional medications. After receiving the CCM device, Bean experienced immediate relief and has since been able to travel, marking a significant improvement in her mobility and overall health. Baptist Memorial is among the first hospitals in Tennessee to offer this promising treatment to patients.

title: Baptist Memorial Hospital is hosting a Breathe Better Oxford event
summary: Baptist Memorial Hospital is hosting the "Breathe Better Oxford" event today from 10 AM to 2 PM in the hospital's courtyard. This event, organized by the Baptist Cancer Center, is in recognition of November being Lung Cancer Awareness Month. It will feature the mega lungs exhibit along with other innovative technology aimed at raising awareness and education about lung health.

title: 'Grow, Connect, and Be Inspired' at CHEST 2023
summary: The American College of Chest Physicians (CHEST) 2023 annual meeting, themed "Grow, Connect, and Be Inspired," is set to take place at the Hawaii Convention Center in Honolulu from October 8-11. This year's meeting has seen a record number of submissions, with almost 1500 original investigations and nearly 4000 total submissions, indicating high enthusiasm and participation. Despite concerns about recent wildfires in Maui, the event will proceed as planned, supporting local economic recovery through tourism. The meeting will offer a full immersive experience, including a new initiative, the Chest Community Connection, aimed at enhancing pulmonary care in the community. Educational sessions will adopt a problem-based learning approach, focusing on various pulmonary medicine, critical care, and sleep issues. Special events designed to foster professional connections will include a Women in Chest Medicine luncheon and an "Ohana" mixer. Attendees can also enjoy a welcome reception featuring Hawaiian music, dance, and a luau feast.

title: American College of Chest Physicians, Oct. 8-11
summary: The annual meeting of the American College of Chest Physicians was held from October 8 to 11 in Honolulu, attracting worldwide attendees interested in pulmonary medicine, critical care, and sleep medicine. Notable research shared included Christine Lambert, M.D., and her team's study on applying geospatial methods to find people eligible for lung cancer screening, with an estimate of 29.3 million individuals qualifying. Another research by Linda Pham, D.O., indicated that patients suffering from both asthma and eosinophilic esophagitis tend to be hospitalized at a younger age compared to those with only one of these conditions. Furthermore, a study by Andrew Limper, M.D., proposed that a reduced dosage of nintedanib for treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis could lead to outcomes as beneficial as those from the standard dosage. These studies offer significant clinical insights and suggest ways to enhance patient care in the field of thoracic medicine.

title: Sputum microbiome may augur treatment success in NTM-PD
summary: The diversity of the sputum microbiome in patients undergoing treatment for nontuberculosis mycobacterial pulmonary disease (NTM-PD) may predict the success of the treatment, according to research presented at CHEST 2023. The study included 14 patients, with half experiencing treatment-refractory NTM-PD and the other half achieving microbiological cures following antibiotic therapy. Results showed that patients with cured infections had a more diverse sputum microbiome than those with refractory disease. This indicates that sputum microbiome diversity could be a marker for assessing the effectiveness of NTM-PD treatments and for guiding patient care. The study, conducted by Dr. Noeul Kang at Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, South Korea, seeks to further examine microbiome characteristics in untreated patients versus those responding to treatment, highlighting the increasing global impact of NTM-PD and the variable treatment outcomes based on the mycobacterial species involved.

title: Getting ready for Boston | CHEST Physician
summary: CHEST 2024 is gearing up to deliver an exceptional educational experience in pulmonary, critical care, and sleep medicine, building on the success of the previous annual meeting. The Scientific Program Committee met in February at CHEST headquarters in Illinois to finalize the schedule for the event, which will take place in Boston from October 6 to 9. A highlight of the meeting will be a session on the "Black Angels," nurses who were instrumental in curing tuberculosis, featuring Virginia Allen and author Maria Smilios. This session will also showcase a collection from Edward Robitzek, MD, highlighting pivotal TB treatment trials from 1952. Additionally, CHEST 2024 will explore the latest advancements in the field, including the application of artificial intelligence in medicine. The meeting will offer over 200 sessions across eight curriculum groups, catering to a wide audience within chest medicine. Early bird registration opens in May, promising a not-to-miss event for professionals at all levels of their careers.

title: Cardinal Health lifts 2024 profit view on demand for costly specialty drugs
summary: Cardinal Health has raised its 2024 profit forecast due to increased demand for expensive specialty drugs. The company now expects adjusted earnings to be between $7.30 and $7.40 per share, up from the previous forecast of $7.20 to $7.35 per share. This update surpasses analysts' expectations of a $7.28 per share annual profit. The pharmaceutical unit, which distributes branded and generic drugs, specialty medicines, and over-the-counter healthcare products, is a significant revenue source for Cardinal Health. This unit's revenue rose 9% year-over-year to $50.7 billion in the third quarter. Despite this growth, total sales of $54.91 billion fell short of the $56.06 billion analysts anticipated. Additionally, Cardinal Health announced a preliminary 2025 adjusted profit outlook of at least $7.50 per share, compared to estimates of $7.87. The company also mentioned that its contracts with UnitedHealth Group's OptumRx will not be renewed after their expiration at the end of June. Lastly, Cardinal Health reported an adjusted profit of $2.08 per share for the last quarter, exceeding the expected $1.95 per share.

title: Cardinal Health Reaffirms Fiscal 2024 non-GAAP EPS Guidance and Long-term Targets Amidst Nonrenewal of ...
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with OptumRx will not be renewed after their expiration at the end of June 2024. Despite this, Cardinal Health reaffirmed its fiscal 2024 non-GAAP diluted EPS guidance of $7.20 to $7.35 and reiterated its long-term segment profit CAGR target of 4% to 6% for its Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions, as well as a consolidated non-GAAP EPS CAGR target of 12% to 14% for fiscal years 2024 to 2026, based on fiscal 2023. The company expects to offset the impact of the OptumRx nonrenewal through new customer wins, specialty growth, and other actions. Sales to OptumRx constituted 16% of Cardinal Health's consolidated revenue in fiscal year 2023, with the majority being non-specialty bulk shipments. Cardinal Health also anticipates an average adjusted free cash flow of approximately $2 billion from fiscal 2024 to 2026, with a lower-than-average amount in fiscal 2025 due to the unwinding of negative net working capital related to the OptumRx contract.

title: Cardinal Health, Inc. (NYSE:CAH) Shares Sold by Principal Financial Group Inc.
summary: Principal Financial Group Inc. reduced its stake in Cardinal Health, Inc. (NYSE:CAH) by 4.9% during the fourth quarter, resulting in the sale of 15,537 shares. After the sale, Principal Financial Group Inc. owned 300,046 shares of Cardinal Health, valued at approximately $30,245,000. This move is part of a broader trend among institutional investors adjusting their positions in the company. Analyst ratings for Cardinal Health have varied, with one analyst rating the stock as a sell, four as hold, and eight as buy, indicating a generally positive outlook despite some reservations. Cardinal Health's stock performance has been solid, with a market capitalization of $24.13 billion, a P/E ratio of 44.04, and a dividend increase to $0.5056 per share this quarter. The company operates globally, offering healthcare services and products, and has reported a quarterly revenue increase of 8.7% year-over-year.

title: Cardinal Health acquires Olathe medical devices company
summary: Cardinal Health, a global healthcare company, acquired Innara Health, an Olathe-based medical devices company, in early 2023. This acquisition was part of Cardinal Health's investment strategy, as it had previously invested in Innara Health in April 2022. The deal included Innara's NTrainer System, a device designed to help premature infants and infants with medical complications improve oral coordination for feeding. This acquisition expands Cardinal Health's portfolio in pediatric and adult enteral feeding and nutritional delivery. Outcome Capital, a life sciences and healthcare investment banking firm, facilitated the introduction and partnership between the two companies. The financial details of the acquisition were not disclosed. Chris Mathia, the former CEO of Innara Health, expressed satisfaction with the acquisition, highlighting the benefits of having the NTrainer System marketed by a larger, multinational company. Cardinal Health, founded in 1971 and headquartered in Ohio, operates in over 30 countries and reported $167.1 billion in year-to-date revenue as of the third quarter of the fiscal year.

title: Cardinal Health Loses Contracts With UnitedHealth's OptumRX, Stock Slips
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its contracts with UnitedHealth Group's pharmacy benefits subsidiary, OptumRX, will not be renewed, leading to a decrease in its stock price. These contracts accounted for 16% of Cardinal Health's revenue in 2023. Despite this setback, Cardinal Health is optimistic about mitigating the impact through new customer acquisitions, growth in specialty areas, and other strategic actions. The company has reaffirmed its earnings per share (EPS) guidance for 2024 and its long-term financial growth targets. Shares of Cardinal Health dropped 5% following the news.

title: Cardinal Health, Inc. Issues Voluntary Nationwide Recall of Certain LEADER™ Brand Eye Drops Supplied by Velocity ...
summary: Cardinal Health, Inc. has initiated a voluntary nationwide recall of all lots of LEADER™ brand eye drops supplied by Velocity Pharma, LLC due to potential risk of eye infections. This action follows FDA findings of insanitary conditions and positive bacterial test results in the manufacturing facility. The products, intended for over-the-counter use for eye irritation and dryness relief, pose a risk of partial vision loss or blindness due to their direct application to the eyes. To date, three adverse events have been reported. The recall affects products distributed nationwide to wholesalers and retailers since December 12, 2021. Cardinal Health is notifying impacted parties and arranging product returns. Consumers are advised to cease using the products and can return them to the place of purchase. For concerns, contact Sedgwick, Inc. at 1-855-215-4940 or Cardinalhealth7720@sedgwick.com. This recall is conducted with the FDA's knowledge.

title: Cardinal Health says contracts with UnitedHealth's OptumRx will not be renewed
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with UnitedHealth Group Inc's OptumRx will not be renewed after their expiration at the end of June 2024. Despite the non-renewal, Cardinal Health is optimistic about compensating for this loss through new customer acquisitions and growth in its specialty pharmacy business. The company, under the leadership of Debbie Weitzman, CEO of the pharmaceutical and specialty solutions division, looks forward to exploring other market opportunities, including the integration of Specialty Networks in fiscal 2025. OptumRx, a pharmacy benefit manager, plays a crucial role in negotiating prescription drug prices between insurers and drugmakers. Cardinal Health did not provide further details on the termination of the OptumRx contracts.

title: Cardinal Health to acquire Specialty Networks and its PPS Analytics platform, a technology enabled multi-specialty ...
summary: Cardinal Health has announced its plan to acquire Specialty Networks and its PPS Analytics platform for $1.2 billion in cash. Specialty Networks is a technology-enabled organization that enhances practice and purchasing for specialties such as urology, rheumatology, and gastroenterology. This acquisition is aimed at accelerating growth in Cardinal Health's Specialty business by integrating leading-edge technologies, capabilities, and talent to meet critical business and customer needs. It will create value for over 11,500 specialty providers, including more than 7,000 physicians across 1,200 independent practices, by enhancing Cardinal Health’s downstream provider-focused analytics capabilities and service offerings. Additionally, it will support Cardinal Health’s expansion across specialty therapeutic areas and the ongoing development of the Navista™ Network, which focuses on the clinical and operational needs of independent community oncologists. The transaction is expected to be accretive to non-GAAP earnings per share 12 months following its closure, subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals.

title: Argus Lowers Cardinal Health (NYSE:CAH) Price Target to $115.00
summary: Argus has reduced the price target for Cardinal Health (NYSE:CAH) from $120.00 to $115.00, maintaining a buy rating on the stock, according to a report released by Benzinga. Other financial analysts have also updated their ratings and price targets for Cardinal Health, with Robert W. Baird lowering their price target from $134.00 to $128.00 and maintaining an outperform rating. StockNews.com downgraded Cardinal Health from a strong-buy to a buy rating. Evercore ISI raised their price target to $115.00 from $110.00 with an in-line rating, while Wells Fargo & Company reduced their target from $96.00 to $94.00 and assigned an underweight rating. SVB Leerink initiated coverage with an outperform rating and a $125.00 price objective. The company has an average rating of Moderate Buy and an average target price of $107.57. Cardinal Health's stock was up 0.4% at $99.08, with a market cap of $24.13 billion, a PE ratio of 44.04, and a dividend increase to $0.5056 per share announced. Institutional trading accounts for 87.17% of the stock's ownership.

title: Cardinal Health lowers medical unit profit forecast, shares fall
summary: Cardinal Health has lowered its annual profit outlook for its medical division, now anticipating earnings of around $380 million, a decrease from the earlier estimate of $400 million. This revision is due to challenges such as increased transportation and labor expenses, along with global supply chain issues, affecting the profitability of its medical segment that produces and supplies medical, surgical, and laboratory items. Despite these obstacles, Cardinal Health announced robust results for the second quarter, with total revenues reaching $57.45 billion, exceeding expectations. Furthermore, the company has upgraded its yearly adjusted profit projection for the entire organization for the third time to an adjusted profit of $1.82 per share, surpassing the forecasted $1.60 per share. This announcement led to a drop in Cardinal Health's stock value by over 5 percent.

title: VieCure Streamlines Cancer Care by Adding E-Prescribing Solutions from DrFirst
summary: VieCure, a cancer care company, has announced the integration of e-prescribing and medication management solutions from DrFirst, a health technology pioneer, into its clinical decision support system. This integration includes DrFirst's Rcopia, an electronic prescribing platform, and EPCS Gold, a controlled substance prescribing solution. Rcopia offers providers an efficient workflow for e-prescribing, including comprehensive medication history data, allergy and clinical alerts, price transparency, and tools for enhancing patient medication adherence. It also provides access to prescription drug monitoring program databases, aiding in pain management regimen oversight. This collaboration between VieCure and DrFirst aims to enhance patient safety, optimize clinical workflows, and improve medication management, thereby facilitating faster and easier treatment for cancer patients. DrFirst has been recognized for its innovation in healthcare IT, particularly in medication management, and VieCure is known for its AI-driven platform that assists in creating personalized cancer treatment plans.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Bringing the Patient Voice to the Forefront and Addressing Critical Gaps in Equitable Breast ...
summary: The PRIME® Online Activity focuses on enhancing equitable breast cancer care by bringing patient experiences to the forefront and addressing disparities in care for diverse populations, including Black and LGBTQ+ patients. It offers a free online activity available from September 29, 2023, to September 28, 2024, providing 1.0 CME/CE credits across various healthcare professions. The activity, led by experts in the field, aims to employ personalized care principles, assess gaps in breast cancer diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes across different populations, and integrate strategies to support equitable healthcare. It targets oncologists and their teams, emphasizing the importance of shared decision-making and survivorship plans, increasing diversity in clinical trials, and patient-centered care. The activity is accredited by ACCME, ACPE, ANCC, and AAPA, ensuring a wide range of healthcare professionals can participate and benefit from the education provided.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Invests in ImmunoFree
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced a strategic investment in ImmunoFree, a biomedical company focused on eliminating the need for immunosuppressive medications in organ transplantation through stem cell transplant technology. Founded in 2023, ImmunoFree aims to improve transplant recipients' lives by freeing them from the side effects of immunosuppressive drugs. This investment aligns with NKF's mission to advance kidney health and supports the development of patient-centric kidney therapies. ImmunoFree's technology targets expanding transplant access and enhancing quality of life, especially for socio-economically disadvantaged populations. The collaboration underscores the importance of addressing immunosuppression issues in a post-COVID world and represents NKF's commitment to investing in innovative solutions for kidney disease patients.

title: Analysis Showing LUPKYNIS® is a Cost-Effective Treatment for Lupus Nephritis Presented at National Kidney ...
summary: An updated analysis presented at the National Kidney Foundation’s Spring Clinical Meeting 2024 shows that LUPKYNIS is a cost-effective treatment for lupus nephritis (LN), similar to treatments for other conditions like diabetes and hypertension in adult patients. This analysis, backed by Aurinia Pharmaceuticals Inc., uses data from the Enlight-LN registry and AURORA clinical program, showing LUPKYNIS's cost-effectiveness and its consistent efficacy and safety over three years when used with MMF and steroids. The cost-effectiveness was assessed using the ICER Analytics LN model, taking into account the 2023 cost of LUPKYNIS and the treatment duration for non-responders and those with end-stage kidney disease. LUPKYNIS's cost per quality adjusted life year (QALY) and per equal value of life year gained (evLYG) is significantly below the ICER’s willingness-to-pay threshold, proving its economic value in treating active LN, including in disproportionately affected Black, Hispanic, and Latino patients.

title: Everly Health Partners With National Kidney Foundation, Expands Kidney Health Testing Suite
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to enhance education on chronic kidney disease and has broadened its testing suite for diabetes monitoring and kidney health for health plans and employers. This collaboration aims to provide co-branded educational materials on kidney health screening and identify at-risk patients, such as those with diabetes, to whom they will mail a kidney health test kit. The expanded testing suite includes tests for heart and kidney health, diabetes monitoring, and utilizes blood and urine samples to help close Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set measures and increase Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Star Ratings. This initiative is in response to the significant number of Americans affected by chronic kidney disease, many of whom are unaware of their condition, and aims to facilitate early detection and treatment to prevent the progression to more severe stages requiring dialysis or a kidney transplant.

title: NKF's Innovation Fund Invests in ZeitLife to Modernize Kidney Preservation and Logistics
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced an investment in ZeitLife Transplant Innovations, Inc., through its NKF Innovation Fund. ZeitLife is a global medical device company focused on advancing kidney preservation and logistics technologies. This collaboration aims to modernize the kidney procurement and transplant system, addressing urgent challenges in organ transportation and logistics. ZeitLife specializes in preservation fluid and machine perfusion technologies, aiming to facilitate the sharing of organs over longer distances and ensure compliance with clinical evidence. The investment supports ZeitLife's mission to supply organs on demand and aligns with NKF's goals to improve kidney health and patient lives. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, invests in companies developing innovative kidney therapies, with long-term goals of preventing kidney disease, eliminating transplant waitlists, and providing better treatments for dialysis patients.

title: Concerned about high blood pressure? Diabetes? Get a free kidney test kit
summary: The National Kidney Foundation is offering free kidney test kits to individuals at risk of kidney disease, especially those with high blood pressure or diabetes, which are the two main risk factors. This initiative, called "Are You the 33%?", aims to increase awareness about the prevalence of kidney disease. Individuals can get a free test kit by taking the NKF Kidney Risk Quiz through a QR code scan or by visiting their website. Eligible participants will receive a Minuteful Kidney test kit from Healthy.io, enabling them to test their urine at home with a smartphone app and get immediate results. These results can be shared with a doctor. This campaign offers an accessible way for at-risk individuals to check their kidney health and take preventive actions.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Klinrisk to Revolutionize Chronic Kidney Disease Care
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Klinrisk, an AI-based medical device company, through its Innovation Fund to transform the early identification and management of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Klinrisk's lab-based prediction models aim to detect high-risk CKD early, enabling healthcare professionals to intervene sooner and prevent the progression to dialysis, thereby improving patient outcomes. This investment aligns with the NKF's mission to advance kidney health and ensure equitable access to innovations. The collaboration aims to accelerate the adoption of risk-based care models and effective interventions for CKD, especially among underserved populations. The NKF Innovation Fund, established in 2021, focuses on accelerating the funding, development, and commercialization of innovative kidney therapies to prevent kidney disease, eliminate the transplant waitlist, and provide better treatments for dialysis patients.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Announces Investment in Relavo
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced an investment from its Innovation Fund into Relavo, a female-founded company aimed at enhancing home dialysis accessibility. This investment will support the development of PeritoneX®, a technology designed to make peritoneal dialysis (PD) safer by reducing infection risks. PD, a home-based treatment for kidney failure, is underutilized due to infection fears, despite its quality-of-life benefits. PeritoneX® aims to disinfect dialysis tubes internally, reducing infection risks and potentially increasing PD usage. This initiative reflects NKF's commitment to improving kidney disease treatments and supporting innovative solutions to overcome current treatment barriers.

title: The National Kidney Foundation and Healthy.io partner to Increase Access to Testing for Detection of Kidney Disease
summary: The National Kidney Foundation and Healthy.io have partnered to enhance access to kidney disease testing through the "Are You the 33%?" campaign, offering free Minuteful Kidney™ at-home test kits for individuals at risk. This initiative, launched around Kidney Day 2023, aims to facilitate early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD) by utilizing a simple quiz to identify those at higher risk, who can then receive a test kit by mail. Healthy.io's Minuteful Kidney test, the first FDA-cleared smartphone-powered at-home kidney test, enables users to perform an albumin-to-creatinine ratio test using their smartphone camera, promoting early diagnosis of CKD. The campaign targets the 75 million Americans at risk, especially underserved communities disproportionately affected by CKD, to increase awareness and testing, addressing the significant gap in annual ACR testing completion.

title: National Kidney Foundation Recognizes March as National Kidney Month
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) will observe National Kidney Month in March, coinciding with World Kidney Day on March 14, to raise awareness about kidney health and chronic kidney disease (CKD). This time is crucial for promoting KIDNEY EQUITY FOR ALL™, with the goal of ensuring that all kidney patients, especially those from underserved communities who are disproportionately affected by kidney disease, receive high-quality, patient-focused care from diagnosis to transplantation. NKF's efforts include the Kidney Risk Quiz to evaluate disease risk, pushing for the elimination of race from the Kidney Disease Risk Index (KDRI), and promoting equal access to transplants by updating the eGFR equation to a version that does not consider race. These actions have resulted in better screening and care, especially through the CKDIntercept program aimed at high-risk groups. NKF is dedicated to preventing kidney disease, improving patient experiences, and addressing health disparities in kidney care and transplantation.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Diatiro to Advance Kidney Health with New Kidney Pod ...
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Diatiro, a medical technology company, through its Innovation Fund to support the development of Diatiro's Kidney Pod technology. This technology aims to improve kidney transplantation outcomes and address the issue of warming injury during the transplant process by maintaining organs at cold temperatures. Diatiro's Kidney Pod, which has received breakthrough designation from the FDA, could increase the number of viable donor kidneys and enable robotic transplantation. The investment reflects NKF's commitment to advancing kidney health and equity by supporting innovations that can enhance transplant success rates and make treatments accessible to a broader range of patients. This initiative is part of the NKF's broader efforts through its Innovation Fund to prevent kidney disease, eliminate transplant waitlists, and improve treatments for dialysis patients.

title: Joint Statement of the American Society of Nephrology and National Kidney Foundation on the USPSTF Final ...
summary: The American Society of Nephrology and the National Kidney Foundation have raised concerns about the US Preventive Services Task Force's Final Research Plan for chronic kidney disease screening. They believe the focus on screening people without symptoms and at low risk overlooks strong evidence for screening those at higher risk. They are worried because guidelines for people with high blood pressure don't always require tests for albumin in the urine. They highlight that only about 40% of adults with diabetes are getting the yearly recommended tests for albumin in the urine. They are asking the US Preventive Services Task Force to include more high-risk individuals in their screening, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds who might have undiagnosed chronic kidney disease, putting them at risk of heart disease, kidney failure, and death. They think that by widening the scope of screening, more people who have or are at risk of chronic kidney disease will be diagnosed.

title: Everly Health and National Kidney Foundation Partnership Aims to Save Lives Through Early Detection of Chronic ...
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD) through increased education and access to high-quality testing, especially in rural and underserved communities in the United States. With 37 million adults in the U.S. affected by CKD and 90% unaware of their condition, this partnership aims to empower individuals with knowledge about their kidney health, promoting better health outcomes. The collaboration will focus on educating about the importance of early detection and awareness, particularly regarding diabetes and hypertension, which are major risk factors for CKD. Everly Health is also expanding its testing suite for health plans and employers to include comprehensive screenings for conditions impacting kidney health. A pilot program with a national health plan showed the effectiveness of the Kidney Health Tests in detecting kidney health marker abnormalities, potentially preventing the progression of renal diseases. This initiative could lead to better health outcomes for members and financial savings for health plans.

title: National Kidney Foundation
summary: The National Kidney Foundation's Northern Ohio Chapter is actively seeking volunteers for various events and programs across its 32-county region. Established in 1964, the foundation is a leading organization dedicated to the awareness, prevention, and treatment of kidney disease in the U.S. With a focus on addressing major issues faced by individual patients, the foundation encourages public support to positively impact those at risk for or living with chronic kidney disease. Opportunities for involvement include volunteering for Kidney Walks, golf events, patient symposiums, and educational initiatives, among others. Additionally, the foundation highlights ways to support kidney patients through donations and living kidney donations. Key fundraising events like Komedy for Kidneys, Patient Symposium, and the NKF Golf Classic are crucial for raising awareness and funds for the cause. Leadership is provided by Executive Director Anna Tzinis and a diverse advisory board.

title: Texas Pharmacists Want to Keep Their Expanded Vaccination Capabilities
summary: Texas pharmacists are advocating for the permanent ability to administer vaccines to children aged 3 and above, a practice expanded during the COVID-19 pandemic under the Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness Act. This act, expiring in October, initially allowed pharmacists to vaccinate only those 14 and older. The push for permanency is met with opposition from physicians who argue that vaccinations should occur within a medical home to ensure comprehensive care. Texas House Bill 1105, introduced by state representative Four Price, aims to make this expanded authority permanent. Despite opposition, pharmacy advocates argue that pharmacies have played a crucial role in vaccine distribution during the pandemic, improving access and alleviating pressure on overworked physicians. They claim that making these responsibilities permanent would not fragment care but complement it, especially in rural areas with provider shortages. The debate continues as the legislative session progresses, with both sides presenting their arguments on the best approach to vaccination practices.

title: SCRI and AstraZeneca partner to leverage technology in oncology trials
summary: SCRI and AstraZeneca have partnered to enhance the efficiency and delivery of oncology clinical trials through technological integration. This collaboration aims to speed up clinical trial timelines, reduce administrative burdens on sites, and improve patient enrollment processes, particularly in the US. By integrating electronic health record (EHR) data with electronic data capture (EDC) systems via the EHR2EDC (E2E) technology developed by Genospace and SCRI Development Innovations, the partnership seeks to streamline data collection and management. This technological advancement is expected to reduce manual labor, monitoring costs, and improve data quality, thereby accelerating clinical trial decision-making. The initiative will connect over 1,300 physicians and provide access to trials for various tumor types across more than 250 locations in 24 US states, aiming to bring novel therapies to more cancer patients through enhanced trial participation and execution.

title: World Cancer Day 2024: HCA Healthcare's Dr. Dax Kurbegov offers hope for the future of cancer care
summary: On World Cancer Day 2024, Dr. Dax Kurbegov from HCA Healthcare's Sarah Cannon Cancer Institute highlighted the advancements in cancer care, emphasizing the importance of prevention, early detection, and innovative treatments. The American Cancer Society reported a decline in cancer mortality rates over the past 30 years, attributing this success to improvements in smoking cessation, early detection, and treatment advancements. Dr. Kurbegov shared the institute's achievements, including guiding over 30,000 patients in their cancer journeys, treating over 130,000 newly diagnosed cancer patients, and conducting more than 1,000 radiation treatments daily. The Sarah Cannon Cancer Institute, recognized for performing the most allogeneic bone marrow transplants globally, continues to pioneer in cancer care through comprehensive programs and cutting-edge research. Dr. Kurbegov expressed hope for the future, emphasizing the institute's commitment to improving cancer care through risk identification, early detection, and groundbreaking treatments, ensuring high-quality care is accessible to patients close to home.

title: The Caris Precision Oncology Alliance Welcomes Sarah Cannon Research Institute
summary: Sarah Cannon Research Institute (SCRI) has joined the Caris Precision Oncology Alliance (POA), as announced by Caris Life Sciences. SCRI is known for its community-based clinical trials and contributions to cancer therapy advancements. The POA collaboration aims to improve precision oncology and biomarker-driven research. SCRI's integration into the POA allows access to Caris' AI bioinformatics and a large clinico-genomic database, enabling innovative research for better cancer patient outcomes. This partnership matches both groups' goals of advancing cancer therapies and molecular diagnostic methods. The POA network includes 89 cancer centers and research consortia, providing early access to Caris' database and AI platform to set cancer profiling standards. Members can use comprehensive molecular profiling to prioritize treatments and clinical trial opportunities for patients.

title: SCRI and AstraZeneca to collab on cancer clinical trials
summary: SCRI (Sarah Cannon Research Institute) and AstraZeneca have partnered to improve clinical trial processes for cancer research in the U.S. The goal is to speed up trial delivery, reduce the burden on sites, and increase U.S. enrollment. Michele Sample from AstraZeneca emphasized the partnership's ability to make clinical trial participants more diverse and accelerate the inclusion of different groups. SCRI will adopt an integration system to make data collection more efficient by linking Electronic Health Records with Electronic Data Capture across more than 250 locations in 24 states. This system, created together with Genospace, allows for automatic data transfer to a central database, improving efficiency. Since starting in 2004, SCRI has conducted over 600 first-in-human trials, working with a variety of therapeutics and companies.

title: Vivek Subbiah, MD, Joins SCRI to Advance Early-Phase Clinical Research
summary: Vivek Subbiah, MD, has been appointed as Chief of Early-Phase Drug Development at Sarah Cannon Research Institute (SCRI), overseeing the institute's nine drug development units and leading the expansion of early-phase capabilities across SCRI's extensive research network. With a distinguished background from The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. Subbiah brings significant experience in cancer clinical trial design and implementation. He has played a pivotal role in over 300 clinical trials, including first-in-human studies that contributed to several FDA approvals. Dr. Subbiah's appointment is poised to enhance SCRI's contributions to cancer drug development, leveraging his expertise in pediatric and adult oncology to introduce innovative therapies across all age groups. His work aims to facilitate rapid patient access to clinical trials, emphasizing personalized medicine in oncology through SCRI's national and international network.

title: A new cure for sickle cell disease may be coming. Health advisers will review it next week
summary: A new potential cure for sickle cell disease, targeting the genetic root of the disorder, is under review by health advisers to the FDA. The treatment, a gene therapy developed by Vertex Pharmaceuticals and CRISPR Therapeutics, could be the first based on CRISPR gene editing to hit the U.S. market. The therapy aims to enable the body to produce a form of hemoglobin that patients with sickle cell disease lack, by editing DNA in blood cells. Initial results from a pivotal study show promising outcomes, including significant reductions in pain crises. The FDA will consider the therapy's approval in early December, following an advisory committee meeting that will discuss the treatment's safety profile and potential "off-target effects." If approved, this therapy could offer a transformative new option for the approximately 100,000 Americans and millions worldwide affected by sickle cell disease.

title: Dr Garmezy on the Treatment of Patients With Cancer in the Community Setting
summary: Dr. Benjamin Garmezy, a medical oncologist and assistant director at the Genitourinary Research, Sarah Cannon Research Institute, Tennessee Oncology, emphasizes the importance of including cancer patients in the community care setting in clinical trial enrollments. He discusses the challenges faced in the community setting, such as the absence of government funding for clinical trials, which necessitates a careful evaluation of trial protocols considering financial feasibility, potential impacts on clinic flow, and the commitment level of investigators. Garmezy highlights the necessity of understanding operational nuances at diverse sites to optimize trial execution and the advantage of access to electronic medical records for tracking patients' therapeutic journeys. He advocates for a collaborative approach with pharmaceutical and biotech partners, and academic centers to ensure the success of clinical trials by aligning them with the specific capabilities and patient populations in the community setting.

title: Understanding CAR T-Cell Therapy for Blood Cancers: Q&A with Dr. Navneet Majhail
summary: The article discusses the importance of CAR T-Cell Therapy in treating blood cancers, with insights from Dr. Navneet Majhail of the Sarah Cannon Cancer Institute and HCA Healthcare. September is Blood Cancer Awareness Month, highlighting the significance of awareness for the 1.6 million people in the U.S. affected by blood cancers. Dr. Majhail, an expert in blood and marrow transplant and cellular therapy, emphasizes the role of the Sarah Cannon Transplant and Cellular Therapy Network in providing comprehensive care and leading research for blood cancer patients. CAR T-Cell Therapy, a groundbreaking immunotherapy, modifies a patient's T-cells to better fight cancer. It is approved for advanced acute lymphoblastic leukemia, lymphoma, and multiple myeloma, and is under research for other cancers. The therapy involves collecting and modifying a patient's T-cells, then chemotherapy and T-cell infusion, with close monitoring for complications. The article also highlights a remote patient monitoring program to manage side effects, showcasing HCA Healthcare's integrated patient care approach.

title: HCA Healthcare's Sarah Cannon Cancer Institute Implements New Outpatient Model for CAR T-cell Therapy
summary: HCA Healthcare's Sarah Cannon Cancer Institute has introduced a new outpatient model for CAR T-cell therapy, successfully transitioning over 75% of its patients to at-home monitoring. This shift has resulted in saving more than 1,200 hospital bed days for the first 100 patients, with about 20% of patients avoiding hospitalization entirely. The model, piloted at four sites, employs new technology for remote patient monitoring and a comprehensive clinical team to manage patient care outside the hospital. This approach not only benefits patients by allowing them to heal at home but also helps meet the growing demand for cell therapies. The initiative, launched in collaboration with Best Buy Health, uses the Current Health platform for continuous monitoring and 24/7 support. HCA Healthcare plans to expand this model to more sites, aiming to improve patient and caregiver experiences nationwide.

title: Tennessee Oncology Launches the Greco-Hainsworth Tennessee Oncology Centers for Research and Appoints Dr ...
summary: Tennessee Oncology has initiated the Greco-Hainsworth Tennessee Oncology Centers for Research and appointed Dr. Ian Flinn as Chief Scientific Officer. The new centers aim to enhance clinical trial research, leveraging Tennessee Oncology's 35 sites across Tennessee and Northwest Georgia. Dr. Flinn, with over 700 scientific publications and a background as Director of Blood Cancer at Sarah Cannon Research Institute, along with Heather Askew as Executive Director of Research Operations, will lead efforts to broaden research initiatives. The centers are named after Drs. Anthony Greco and John Hainsworth, pioneers in community oncology clinical trials. The initiative seeks to expand access to clinical trials for the state's cancer patients, including those in rural areas, through strategic partnerships and a diverse range of drug development phases, CAR-T therapies, and studies on health equity. Dr. Flinn will also serve as Chief Scientific Officer for OneOncology, aiming to drive innovation in oncology through expanded trial offerings at all Tennessee Oncology sites.

title: For World Cancer Day, Alliance for Cancer Care Equity Advocates to 'Close the Care Gap' as Observance is Honored ...
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
