summary: For World Cancer Day, the Alliance for Cancer Care Equity, in collaboration with the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN), and the National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF), is advocating for policies to 'Close the Care Gap'. They are focusing on three key areas: increasing diversity in clinical trials, enhancing access to cancer screening and early detection, and expanding patient navigation services. These efforts are supported by a congressional resolution, highlighting the importance of addressing disparities in cancer care. The initiative aims to ensure equitable access to cancer treatments and support, emphasizing the need for action to reduce the higher mortality rates among Black Americans and other marginalized groups for various cancers. The campaign marks the final year of the 'Close the Care Gap' effort, aiming to make structural changes in cancer care delivery across the U.S. and urging Congress to support relevant policies to improve cancer care equity.

title: Cancer patients see growing medical debt despite insurance
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A study by the American Cancer Society-Cancer Action Network reveals that despite having insurance, nearly half of the cancer patients and survivors surveyed are burdened with over $5,000 in medical debt. This survey included responses from over 1,000 individuals treated for cancer within the past seven years. Furthermore, almost 70% of these patients have been dealing with this debt for a year or more. The study also highlights a significant disparity in healthcare accessibility, noting that African American and Hispanic cancer survivors are about twice as likely to be denied care due to their financial situation.

title: New Report Shows Cancer Organization Shares Lobbyists with Fossil Fuel Companies
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A report by F Minus reveals that the American Cancer Society’s Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN) employs lobbyists who also represent fossil fuel companies, raising concerns about conflicts of interest and the undermining of public health goals. This connection is seen as detrimental to the fight against cancer and climate change, with the shared lobbyists working in 10 states on behalf of 21 fossil fuel entities. Critics argue that this relationship impedes necessary action on climate policies and exposes the public to increased health risks, including carcinogens linked to cancer. The report highlights specific instances where ACS CAN’s lobbyists have supported legislation favorable to the fossil fuel industry, potentially at odds with the mission to reduce cancer risk. This situation has drawn criticism from health professionals and advocates who see a dangerous conflict of interest in these dual roles, calling for a reevaluation of such partnerships in light of the broader implications for public health and environmental policy.

title: In letter to lawmakers, cancer patient advocates call for more action in fighting drug shortages
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Cancer patient advocates are urging lawmakers to address the ongoing crisis of drug shortages, highlighting the severe impact on cancer treatment. The American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN) has emphasized that the shortage of 16 essential oncology medications, which are crucial for treatment regimens, is forcing doctors to make difficult choices about which patients can receive necessary drugs. Surveys conducted by ACS CAN reveal that 10% of adult cancer patients in active treatment have been affected by these shortages in the past year, with 68% struggling to find substitute medications and 59% experiencing treatment delays. The situation is even more dire for pediatric cancer patients, with nearly 53% affected by shortages. Over 80% of pediatric cancer providers reported experiencing shortages at their institutions. The shortages are also impeding cancer research, as they make it difficult to obtain the drugs needed for clinical trials. The root cause of the shortages is identified as economic conditions in the generic sterile injectable market, where low profit margins discourage investment. ACS CAN calls for comprehensive legislation to address both immediate and long-term issues, proposing solutions like data-driven risk assessment tools, increased FDA resources, and market reforms to ensure reliability and quality in drug production and delivery.

title: Cancer Takes a Lasting Toll on Family Finances
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A new study reveals that 60% of working-age adults diagnosed with cancer experience significant financial strain, highlighting the need for better access to affordable care and paid family medical leave. The research, based on data from the National Health Interview Survey covering 2019-2021, found that a majority of cancer patients and survivors had to miss work, with many missing more than four weeks. Nearly 60% faced financial hardships, including unmanageable medical bills, anxiety, and delayed or skipped care due to costs. The American Cancer Society emphasizes the importance of understanding the impact of cancer on employment and income, especially for those without Medicare coverage. The study calls for legislative action for paid leave and more affordable health coverage options, as well as employer support through sick leave and quality health insurance. The findings were published in CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians on April 23, 2024.

title: Cancer survivors reporting loneliness experience higher mortality risk, new study shows
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A new study by the American Cancer Society reveals that cancer survivors who report feeling lonely have a higher risk of mortality compared to those with low or no loneliness. The research, published in the Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network, analyzed data from cancer survivors aged 50 and older, using the UCLA Loneliness Scale for measurement. Findings showed a dose-response association, with the highest mortality risk in the most lonely group. The study underscores the importance of addressing loneliness in cancer survivorship care, suggesting interventions like mental health counseling and social support programs. With over 18 million cancer survivors in the U.S., expected to rise to 22 million by 2030, addressing loneliness is deemed critical for improving health outcomes. The study aligns with the U.S. Surgeon General’s advisory on the health impacts of loneliness and social connection.

title: PGI doctors develop affordable liver cancer medicine
summary: Doctors at the Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research (PGIMER) in Chandigarh have developed an affordable liver cancer medicine priced at ₹5,000, offering a significant cost advantage over existing treatments that can cost up to ₹10 lakh. This development was shared by Dr. Jaya Shukla during a conference on “Radiopharmaceuticals: Chemistry to precision medicine” at PGIMER. The medicine, which utilizes non-radioactive microspheres for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes, targets liver tumors more effectively by being injected directly into the liver's feeding artery. This approach allows for precise delivery to the tumor site and minimizes side effects. The smaller microspheres developed by Dr. Shukla are designed to penetrate the tumor and remain there, improving the treatment's efficacy. So far, 60 patients have been treated with this method, many of whom have survived for over five years, experiencing an improved quality of life.

title: 10 Top Medical Colleges in India to choose after clearing NEET 2024
summary: Choosing a career in the medical profession in India is highly sought after, with close to 20 lakh students annually appearing for pre-medical entrance tests like NEET to secure a spot in the country's top medical colleges. The article highlights the respect, financial stability, and continuous learning opportunities that come with becoming a doctor, emphasizing it as a noble journey of helping others and making a societal impact. It also lists the top 10 medical colleges in India according to the NIRF 2023 rankings, including their first-year course fees, to guide aspirants in making an informed decision post clearing NEET 2024. These colleges are known for their excellent teaching practices and practical exposure across various medical specializations.

title: PGIMER Recruitment 2024 - Pharmacist Vacancy, Job Openings
summary: The Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research (PGIMER) is recruiting for a Pharmacist vacancy. This opportunity is for candidates who have completed their B.Pharm or D.Pharm. The position is based in Chandigarh, with a monthly salary of Rs. 21,000. There is one post available, and the last date to apply is 10-02-2024. Interested candidates can apply by visiting the PGIMER website. This recruitment highlights PGIMER's role as a leading public medical university and tertiary care hospital in India, known for its extensive educational, medical research, and training facilities.

title: Global Continuing Medical Education (CME) Market Report to 2027: Players Include AffinityCE, Afya, CME Outfitters ...
summary: The "Continuing Medical Education (CME) Market: Global Industry Trends, Share, Size, Growth, Opportunity and Forecast 2022-2027" report indicates that the global CME market was valued at US$ 8.24 Billion in 2021 and is projected to reach US$ 11.98 Billion by 2027, growing at a CAGR of 6.44% during the forecast period. The market involves educational activities aimed at maintaining and enhancing the knowledge, skills, and professional performance of healthcare professionals. It encompasses courses, conferences, online programs, and multimedia materials. The growth is attributed to the rising need for updated medical knowledge due to new infections and diseases, the development of collaborative elements in medical education, and a shift towards online education. Additionally, the expansion of medical institutions and government initiatives for quality education are driving market growth. Key players include AffinityCE, Afya Ltd., CME Outfitters LLC, Coursera Inc., and others. The market benefits from interactive education options, technological advancements, and the flexibility for professionals to learn at their own pace.

title: The Role of Oncology Pharmacists Is Evolving in Early-Stage Breast Cancer Treatment Optimization
summary: The role of oncology pharmacists in the treatment of early-stage breast cancer has significantly evolved, now including optimizing treatment through targeted systemic therapies. Danielle Roman, PharmD, BCOP, emphasized this change at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association (HOPA) Annual Conference 2024. Oncology pharmacists are crucial in selecting therapies based on patient-specific criteria and managing unique adverse effects. Advances in targeted therapies, like CDK4/6 inhibitors with endocrine therapy for hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative high-risk early-stage breast cancer, have changed the treatment landscape. The use of therapies such as pembrolizumab for triple-negative breast cancer and olaparib for patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations highlights this progress. Pharmacists are key in educating healthcare teams on these advancements and in patient counseling, focusing on selecting therapy, monitoring adverse effects, and managing complex treatment regimens.

title: Navigating Operational Challenges With Bispecifics in R/R MM: Insights From HOPA 2024
summary: Kirollos Hanna, PharmD, from Minnesota Oncology and Mayo Clinic College of Medicine, discussed the challenges and recommendations for implementing bispecifics in relapsed or refractory Multiple Myeloma (R/R MM) at the HOPA 2024 Conference. He stressed the importance of establishing external relationships for patient support and proposed three approaches for starting bispecific treatments: large institutions with established procedures, smaller systems forming connections with local practices for initiating and maintaining therapy, and institutions unprepared for bispecific administration risking patient loss. Hanna highlighted the necessity of open communication between systems to address obstacles, such as managing adverse events promptly and ensuring ongoing care. The increasing use of bispecific therapies in hematology and solid tumors calls for the development of processes and communication strategies to provide effective patient care.

title: Pediatric Cancer Survivor Shares How 'Perspective Is Everything'
summary: A pediatric cancer survivor, Kelsey Tainsh, emphasized the importance of perspective during her keynote address at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association Annual Conference 2023. Diagnosed with brain cancer at 5 and experiencing a recurrence and stroke at 15, Tainsh shared how these challenges taught her to appreciate life's beauty and the significance of attitude in facing adversities. Despite the physical limitations from her stroke, Tainsh has embraced gratitude, influencing her current outlook and career. She highlighted the crucial role pharmacists play in supporting cancer patients, not just medically but also by providing understanding and exploring all available options. Tainsh's story underlines the transformative power of perspective and gratitude in overcoming life's hurdles.

title: Students in Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Should Seek Out Opportunities for Research, Mentorship
summary: Students and residents in hematology/oncology pharmacy are encouraged to explore various career paths in the field, stressing the importance of mentorship and research opportunities. Chung-Shien Lee, PharmD, BCPS, BCOP, from St. John's University, addresses common myths about the permanence of career choices in this specialty, noting that interests and career directions can change over time. Lee advises students to actively engage in organizations and find mentors for career guidance. He also emphasizes the importance of participating in clinical research, which is vital for advancing patient care and keeping up with fast-paced changes in oncology. This guidance was offered at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association (HOPA) Annual Conference 2023, with the goal of preparing students for a dynamic and rewarding career in oncology pharmacy.

title: 5 Key Sessions, Interviews at HOPA Annual Conference 2023
summary: The Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association (HOPA) Annual Conference 2023, held in Phoenix, Arizona from March 29 to April 1, offers oncology and hematology pharmacists a comprehensive platform for networking, earning CE and BCOP credits, and attending specialized sessions. These sessions are designed to deepen pharmacists' understanding of the current care landscape, spotlight innovations enhancing patient treatment, initiatives for greater inclusivity in clinical trials and treatments, and the latest in groundbreaking clinical trials. Key highlights include sessions on early-stage breast cancer treatment updates, opioid tapering in cancer survivors, the use of patient-reported outcome tools in assessing cancer patient health and quality of life, addressing health disparities in oncology related to sexual orientation and gender identity, and insights into early-stage clinical trials for non-small cell lung cancer treatments. Coverage and interviews with experts will be available on PharmacyTimes.com, providing exclusive insights into these critical topics.

title: Oncology Pharmacists Should Consider Individualized Treatment Plan for Patients with Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma
summary: Oncology pharmacists play a crucial role in creating individualized treatment plans for patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC), as discussed by Lisa M. Holle, PharmD, BCOP, FHOPA, FISOPP, during the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association Annual Conference 2023. Holle emphasizes the importance of considering a patient's comorbidities, medications, social determinants of health, and goals of care when selecting a therapy. The treatment of mRCC often involves checkpoint inhibitors or immunotherapy, which can cause immune-related adverse events affecting any organ, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) receptor inhibitors, which can lead to side effects like high blood pressure, proteinuria, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Holle highlights the necessity of managing these toxicities effectively and tailoring medication management strategies to individual patient characteristics. Additionally, oncology pharmacists must provide thorough patient education to improve treatment adherence and manage misconceptions about the pharmacist's role in care, particularly in pain management and the correct use of medications.

title: Older Age Associated With Palbociclib Dose Reduction in Patients With Advanced Breast Cancer
summary: A study presented at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association Annual Conference 2024 found that older patients with advanced or metastatic HR+/HER2− breast cancer are more likely to require a dose reduction of palbociclib. The study included 149 patients treated in Montreal, Canada, with palbociclib in combination with letrozole or fulvestrant. It was observed that 37.6% of patients needed a dose reduction, primarily due to advanced age and comorbidities. The most common side effect leading to dose reduction was neutropenia. Median progression-free survival was longer in the dose reduction group compared to the no reduction group (20.4 months vs. 14.1 months). The study highlighted the importance of considering absolute neutrophil count and age over 70 as predictive factors for palbociclib dose reduction to manage treatment-related side effects effectively.

title: New Therapeutic Options Can Prolong Survival in Patients with Mutated Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
summary: New therapeutic options are significantly improving survival rates for patients with mutated non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), as discussed by Whitney E. Lewis, PharmD, BCOP, at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association Annual Conference 2023. Innovations in treatment, particularly in the adjuvant setting for early-stage patients and the metastatic setting, have transformed the NSCLC treatment landscape. Notably, the use of checkpoint inhibitors for patients who have undergone curative resection and adjuvant Osimertinib for those with eGFR mutations have reshaped patient care strategies. Additionally, the PACIFIC study's 5-year overall survival update for adjuvant immunotherapy post-curative intent chemotherapy radiation, and new treatments for traditionally hard-to-treat mutations like STK11 and K1, highlight the progress in NSCLC management. The introduction of tyrosine kinase inhibitors for K-RAS G12C mutations represents a significant advancement, offering new hope for prolonging survival in NSCLC patients.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) provides various resources and programs for oncology professionals via its website and affiliates. These resources include ASCO Connection for member blogs and discussions, ASCO Daily News for conference reports and oncology news, and several journals for clinical oncology research. ASCO Practice Central assists oncology professionals in adapting to the evolving practice landscape, and ASCO Education offers online, on-demand resources for the latest in oncology. CancerLinQ® is a health information technology platform designed to enhance the quality of cancer care by analyzing real-world data. Cancer.Net provides resources for patients and families to make informed healthcare decisions. The Conquer Cancer Foundation supports research for treatments and cures for all types of cancer. The TAPUR Study is a clinical trial investigating the efficacy of targeted anticancer drugs. ASCO also offers opportunities for advocacy, professional development, and networking through its State/Regional Affiliate program, encouraging members to participate both locally and nationally in the oncology community.

title: Watson Clinic Welcomes Additional Physicians and Providers
summary: Watson Clinic in Lakeland, Florida, is excited to announce the addition of new members to their team of healthcare professionals. The new recruits include Dany K. Barrak, MD, MPH, a General Surgery/Surgical Oncology specialist; Logan Blankenship, MD, a Gynecologic Oncology expert; Allison Fojtik, MSN, APRN, a registered nurse practitioner specializing in cardiac care; and Sara Matthews, PA, a physician assistant with expertise in OB-GYN and Female Pelvic Medicine & Reconstructive Surgery. These professionals bring a wealth of knowledge and expertise in their respective fields, enhancing the clinic's ability to provide comprehensive healthcare services. Watson Clinic, established in 1941, is one of the largest multispecialty medical clinics in the southeast, offering a wide range of medical and surgical specialties to the Lakeland community and surrounding areas.

title: Capital Rx Earns Accreditation from the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA)
summary: Capital Rx has been awarded the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) Accreditation in Utilization Management, showcasing its commitment to high-quality consumer protection and customer service improvement. This voluntary accreditation process confirmed that Capital Rx possesses the necessary systems, processes, and personnel to meet NCQA's stringent quality standards. AJ Loiacono, Co-Founder and CEO of Capital Rx, praised the achievement, attributing it to leveraging their enterprise health platform, JUDI®, which played a crucial role in meeting the standards. This accreditation underscores the importance of following objective, evidence-based best practices in utilization management decisions. Capital Rx's JUDI platform is instrumental in redefining technology's role in pharmacy program administration across various plans, incorporating features like an intuitive prior authorization tool to ensure adherence to evidence-based guidelines and timely patient care. NCQA is a private, nonprofit organization dedicated to improving healthcare quality, accrediting a wide range of healthcare organizations and recognizing performance in key areas.

title: Everly Health Selected to Participate in NCQA Virtual Care Pilot to Establish Quality Standards
summary: Everly Health has been chosen to take part in the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) 2023 Virtual Care Pilot, which aims to set quality standards for virtual care. Selected from more than 100 applicants through a competitive process, Everly Health will work with other leaders in digital health to create guidelines for safe, effective, and equitable virtual care. This initiative gives participants a chance to use technology, encourage teamwork, and make a significant difference in virtual patient care. Everly Health, a digital health platform that focuses on diagnosing and managing recurring health issues remotely, seeks to improve health outcomes, lower healthcare costs, and better patient-provider relationships through this effort. This participation is in line with Everly Health's goal to change lives with modern, diagnostics-driven care, offering widespread at-home testing and aiding in the establishment of important quality standards for virtual care.

title: The National Committee for Quality Assurance Recognizes Three NYC Health + Hospitals/Gotham Health Clinics for ...
summary: The National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) has awarded the highest-level Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) designation to three NYC Health + Hospitals/Gotham Health clinics—Bushwick and Greenpoint in Brooklyn, and Gunhill in the Bronx. This recognition underscores the clinics' achievements in enhancing patient health outcomes and satisfaction through improved patient and provider relationships. The PCMH designation is given to primary care practices that excel in providing accessible, communicative, and collaborative care environments, essential for better health results. These clinics have adopted various strategies, such as expanding access through telehealth, identifying high-need patients, fostering data-driven performance improvement cultures, and developing care plans for high-risk patients. Gotham Health, a part of NYC Health + Hospitals, serves over 100,000 New Yorkers annually across five boroughs, focusing on accessible, high-quality, and affordable primary care.

title: Polarean's Xenon MRI to be Featured at Upcoming ATS 2024 Conference
summary: Polarean's Xenon MRI technology will be highlighted at the ATS 2024 Conference, showcasing its XENOVIEW technology's significance in pulmonary medicine. The company will participate as a poster presenter at the Respiratory Innovation Summit in San Diego, aiming to demonstrate the impact of its technology on lung clinicians and pulmonary drug developers. The event is expected to attract over 275 global leaders from various sectors, including startups, venture capital, and academia. Polarean looks forward to further collaborations within the pulmonary medicine community following the summit. The Xenon MRI research at this year's conference will cover various topics across 33 presentations, indicating a growing interest and recognition of the technology's potential benefits in treating respiratory conditions. Polarean emphasizes the importance of these events in promoting its Xenon MRI platform to a wider audience, including clinicians, regulators, investors, and potential pharmaceutical partners, to advance its commercialization strategy.

title: Trevi Therapeutics Announces Abstract Presentation at the American Thoracic Society 2024 International Conference
summary: Trevi Therapeutics, Inc. announced that data from the Phase 2 CANAL trial will be presented at the American Thoracic Society 2024 International Conference in San Diego, CA, from May 17-22. The presentation, scheduled for May 19, will detail the effects of Haduvio™ (oral nalbuphine ER) on reducing cough bouts in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and refractory chronic cough (RCC). Trevi Therapeutics is developing Haduvio, which acts as a dual ĸ-opioid receptor agonist and µ-opioid receptor antagonist, to address chronic cough in IPF and RCC, conditions currently lacking approved treatments. Chronic cough significantly impacts patients' quality of life, and in IPF, it may indicate disease progression. The company highlights the absence of approved therapies for these conditions in the US and emphasizes Haduvio's potential to provide relief for patients suffering from moderate to severe chronic cough.

title: Insmed to Present New Data from Across its Respiratory Portfolio at the American Thoracic Society 2024 International ...
summary: Insmed Incorporated announced its participation in the American Thoracic Society 2024 International Conference, where it will present nine abstracts from its respiratory portfolio. This includes new data from the ARISE study on ARIKAYCE® (amikacin liposome inhalation suspension) for treating Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) lung disease in newly diagnosed or recurrent cases. The presentations will cover both microbiologic outcomes and changes in patient-reported respiratory symptoms. Additionally, Insmed will share data on brensocatib for bronchiectasis and the burden of illness in pulmonary hypertension associated with interstitial lung disease. ARIKAYCE is a novel, inhaled formulation of amikacin, designed to deliver the antibiotic directly to the lungs with limited systemic exposure. Brensocatib is a DPP1 inhibitor being developed for bronchiectasis and other neutrophil-mediated diseases. The conference will take place in San Diego from May 17-22, 2024.

title: Oregon's Providence Health to expand emergency room capacity
summary: Providence Health announced a $177 million expansion of emergency and critical cardiac care at St. Vincent and Portland Medical Centers, aiming to accommodate an additional 50,000 ER visits annually. This expansion is in response to overcrowded facilities and the need to improve patient care and outcomes, particularly in cardiac care. The Oregon Health Authority noted a rise in ER wait times, emphasizing the need for this expansion. The project will increase the number of patient care areas and add new ICU beds, with the goal of reducing wait times, enhancing cardiac care, and improving overall patient experience. The expansion, expected to be completed by 2027, will also include dedicated treatment rooms for substance use and behavioral health crises.

title: PROVIDENCE TO INVEST $177 MILLION TO ADDRESS PORTLAND'S MOST URGENT HEALTH CARE CHALLENGES
summary: Providence plans to invest $177 million to address the most pressing health care challenges in Portland, focusing on improving emergency and critical cardiac care at Providence Portland and Providence St. Vincent Medical Centers, including the Providence Heart Institute. This effort, part of the Tomorrow Starts Today capital campaign, aims to support an additional 50,000 emergency department visits annually and meet the increasing needs of patients with complex cardiac conditions. Over 80% of the funding, or $144 million, will come from donations, making it the largest campaign in the history of Providence Oregon. The investment will also tackle overcrowding and outdated infrastructure in health care facilities, with projects beginning in 2023 and expected to be completed by 2027. Early supporters, including the Bryants and other leading donors, have already contributed over $125 million towards the $144 million goal. This campaign is expected to significantly enhance patient care and emergency services in Portland.

title: Get a Price Estimate
summary: Providence offers a service to estimate the cost of healthcare services for patients, aiming to provide transparency and help in financial planning. Patients can use their MyChart account or search as a guest to get estimates based on their insurance coverage or as uninsured individuals. The website guides users to select their region and preferred hospital to receive care, including options across several states. Financial assistance and counselors are available to make bills manageable, regardless of budget, and a financial assistance program can help with medical expenses. Additionally, healthcare providers are required by law to provide a "Good Faith Estimate" to uninsured or not using insurance patients, detailing the expected cost of services. Providence emphasizes the importance of price transparency in healthcare, offering an online estimate tool and dedicated teams for price inquiries, aiming to reduce surprises and ensure patients are informed about their out-of-pocket costs. Discounts and a financial assistance program are available to eligible individuals to help manage medical expenses.

title: Providence hospitals’ surgeries halved following anesthesiology swap; delays continue
summary: Providence Health & Services' two major hospitals in Portland saw a nearly 50% reduction in surgeries in December and January because of a contentious change to a new anesthesia provider. This change, occurring in late November, resulted in the postponement of hundreds, possibly thousands, of elective surgeries at Providence Portland Medical Center and Providence St. Vincent Medical Center. The new anesthesia contractor could not provide enough trained staff to handle the usual number of surgeries at these hospitals, leading to significant delays that are still impacting patients.

title: Anesthesiologist shortage at Providence raises concerns over private equity
summary: Providence Health & Services is experiencing a shortage of anesthesiologists at two of its hospitals, leading to the cancellation of non-emergency surgeries. This issue began when Providence changed its anesthesiology provider from Oregon Anesthesiology Group (OAG), owned by its anesthesiologists since 1989, to Sound Physicians, backed by private equity. This change has raised concerns about the growing role of private equity in Oregon's healthcare system, with worries that these firms may prioritize profits over patient care. The shortage is expected to continue until the end of the year, affecting surgeries for conditions like retinal detachments and cataracts. State Rep. Ben Bowman is working on legislation to restrict the acquisition of medical practices by private equity and large corporations in Oregon. Despite Sound Physicians increasing its staff to meet demand, the transition has already affected patients and sparked debate on the motivations behind such changes in healthcare contracting.

title: Providence Accused of Retaliating Against Union Drive
summary: Providence Health & Services is accused of firing a physician assistant in retaliation for their involvement in a successful unionization effort among medical providers at the health system’s urgent care clinics in Oregon. The Pacific Northwest Hospital Medicine Association filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board in April, alleging the health system aimed to discourage union activities by terminating the employee. The union drive, which took place from December to February, resulted in 73 physicians, physician assistants, and nurse practitioners joining the union across eight urgent care clinics. Union spokeswoman Myrna Jensen attributed the significant increase in union membership among Providence’s Oregon employees to the health system's failure to provide fair pay despite rising revenues.

title: 63,000 SQFT Building Leased by Providence Health in Portland to be Listed for Sale at $20.9MM
summary: A 63,000 square foot building leased by Providence Health in Portland is set to be listed for sale at $20.9 million. Located at 6410 NE Halsey St and covering about 4.10 acres, this facility is used for distribution, research and development, and patient services by Providence Health and Services – Oregon, part of Providence St. Joseph’s Health. The property, originally built in 1969, includes office space, warehouse areas, and pharmaceutical and R&D labs. It features six dock-high doors and 206 parking spaces. Matthews Real Estate Investment Services is handling the sale, with the current owner being Accretive Realty Advisors. The property benefits from its proximity to major transport links and is less than a mile from Providence Portland Medical Center. Providence has a lease on the property until 2034, having been a tenant since 2008. The building has an assumable loan with a balance of $10.9 million.

title: Providence to Demolish Building A on NE Glisan Campus
summary: Providence Portland Medical Center plans to demolish a three-story building at 5251 NE Glisan Street due to structural issues. The building, constructed in 1988, includes ground-floor parking and two floors of medical office space. It was fenced off for demolition, affecting the sidewalk, parking, and a bike lane. The hospital, owning the entire block, has inquired about a street vacation for NE 52nd Avenue and has plans for expansion, including a proposal for a new building with medical offices and underground parking. The demolition, set for June, aims to remove the unsafe building, with future plans for the site still undecided. Minor disruptions are expected during demolition, requiring detours for pedestrians and cyclists.

title: Providence Oregon's HR chief reflects on tough union negotiations and strike - Portland Business Journal
summary: Beth Lagler, the chief human resources officer for the service area of Providence Oregon, reflected on the challenging negotiations and strike with Oregon's largest nurses union. After eight months of discussions, the nurses conducted a weeklong strike in June, resulting in a contract that offered the highest percentage increases in the region and an additional 40 hours of PTO. Lagler pointed out the inherent tension in negotiations, the effects of changing priorities, and the significant impact of work stoppages on both the community and employees. Despite the obstacles, an agreement was reached that supported the recruitment and retention of nurses. Lagler's main insight was the potential advantage of involving a federal mediator earlier in the negotiation process to help focus on priorities and facilitate an agreement.

title: $10.9 million hospital remodel in Portland building permits | April 22, 2024
summary: A $10.9 million hospital remodel project in Portland has been highlighted in the building permits issued by the Bureau of Development Services. The significant remodel is taking place at the Providence Portland Medical Center, located at 4805 N.E. Glisan St. The project involves extensive demolition and construction work on the first floor to enhance various facilities including exam rooms, a reception area, restrooms, an X-ray room, triage rooms, and more, aimed at improving patient care and hospital operations. Additionally, the project includes an extra $1,300,000 alteration permit under review for installing various systems like terminal units, ductwork, and electrical components. This remodel is part of a weekly list of notable commercial building and facility permits issued in Portland, showcasing the city's ongoing development and infrastructure enhancement efforts.

title: Oregon DOJ goes to court for Providence Health documents
summary: The Oregon Department of Justice (DOJ) has sued Providence Health & Services for not releasing documents about claims of wrongful billing of low-income Oregonians. The biggest hospital network in the state is charged with trying to get more money from poor patients, which might break the state's rules for charity care. Even though Providence has already given 100,000 documents and allowed interviews with 10 witnesses, it's fighting the DOJ's demand for more records, including emails from important people involved. This legal fight is because there's evidence Providence might have charged Medicaid members wrongly and used harsh methods to get payments, including sending some bills to collection agencies. This issue also includes the "RevUp" program by McKinsey & Co, criticized for how it tries to increase collections from the poor. The Oregon DOJ's action comes after a similar investigation in Washington state, which ended with Providence paying a $157.8 million settlement. The Oregon case points out worries about the hospital system caring more about profits than charity care, even though it's a nonprofit with a mission to help the poor.

title: Providence delays surgeries amid anesthesiology shakeup
summary: Providence Portland Medical Center and Providence St. Vincent Medical Center are postponing numerous elective surgeries due to changes in their anesthesiology services. They have switched from Oregon Anesthesiology Group to Sound Physicians, motivated by a lack of providers and the necessity for steady anesthesia services. This adjustment, starting November 22, intends to normalize surgery volumes by early next year. Yet, this alteration has led to surgery postponements for many, including Sue Phillips and her husband, who is awaiting a knee replacement. These delays are inflicting financial and emotional hardships on affected families as they deal with insurance co-pays and deductibles amid uncertainty. Despite the recruitment of 76 new staff members for the anesthesia team, the hospital system is prioritizing urgent procedures until the year's end, resulting in the deferment of many elective surgeries.

title: Providence and Regence BlueCross seal deal on insurance partnership
summary: Providence Health & Services and Regence BlueCross BlueShield of Oregon have successfully finalized a contract, ensuring that Providence remains in the network for Regence insurance patients. This agreement, reached on the last day of their existing contract after extensive negotiations, averts the potential exclusion of over 260,000 Regence-insured patients from the Providence network. The negotiations were tense, with Providence seeking higher charges to offset rising healthcare costs, which Regence initially contested as unrealistic, projecting a $144 million increase in costs. However, both parties have expressed satisfaction with the outcome, emphasizing a sustainable approach to reimbursement rates that benefits members and customers. The specific terms of the agreement remain undisclosed.

title: Antimicrobial Stewardship's Role in Preventing AMR
summary: Antimicrobial Stewardship plays a crucial role in combating antimicrobial resistance (AMR), requiring a multipronged, collaborative approach across various stakeholders and sectors. Sam Aitken, PharmD, president-elect of the Society of Infectious Disease Pharmacists (SIDP), emphasizes the importance of judicious use of antimicrobials and the need for improved infection prevention practices globally. Addressing AMR involves tailored strategies that consider socioeconomic factors and local needs, including tackling poverty and food inequity. The recent World AMR Congress highlighted the urgency of addressing health disparities through increased antimicrobial stewardship. Aitken points out the global nature of AMR, citing the war in Ukraine as an example of how multidrug-resistant infections in one region can have broader implications. His tenure as SIDP president will focus on continuing the society's efforts in antimicrobial stewardship and addressing AMR challenges.

title: American College of Physicians Updates Guideline for Type 2 Diabetes Treatments
summary: The American College of Physicians (ACP) has updated its guidelines for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, focusing on the effectiveness of newer pharmacologic treatments. The updated recommendations, published in the Annals of Internal Medicine, include the use of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonists, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors, dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, and long-acting insulins. Metformin, alongside lifestyle modifications, remains the first line of treatment. However, for patients needing additional therapy, the ACP suggests considering SGLT-2 inhibitors or GLP-1 agonists due to their benefits in reducing all-cause mortality, cardiovascular events, and progression of chronic kidney disease. The ACP recommends against the use of DPP-4 inhibitors as an adjunct to metformin and lifestyle modifications due to a lack of evidence in improving critical outcomes. These recommendations apply to nonpregnant adults with long-standing type 2 diabetes and consider patient values, preferences, costs, and economic burden of care.

title: UAMS doctor named leader of American College of Physicians | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
summary: Dr. Omar Atiq, a medical oncologist at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences' Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute, has been named president of the American College of Physicians, becoming the first person from Arkansas to lead the largest medical specialty organization in the country. Elected as president-elect in 2022, Atiq officially assumed the leadership position in late April, heading an organization with 161,000 members globally. At the age of 62, Atiq has an impressive medical resume, holding a medical degree from Khyber Medical College at the University of Peshawar, Pakistan, and completing his residency and chief residency in internal medicine at the Edward Hines Jr. Veterans Administration Hospital and Foster G. McGaw Hospital of Loyola University in Chicago. He also completed a fellowship in medical oncology and hematology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. Atiq has served in notable roles such as the governor of the American College of Physicians Arkansas Chapter and president and chairman of the Arkansas Medical Society.

title: American College of Physicians issues clinical recommendations for newer pharmacological treatments of adults with ...
summary: The American College of Physicians (ACP) has updated its clinical guidelines for treating adults with Type 2 diabetes, focusing on newer pharmacological treatments. Published in the Annals of Internal Medicine, the guideline advises adding a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor or glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) agonist to metformin and lifestyle changes for those with inadequate glycemic control. These additions aim to lower risks such as all-cause mortality, major adverse cardiovascular events, chronic kidney disease progression, and hospitalization for congestive heart failure. However, the ACP recommends against adding a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor due to insufficient evidence of its benefits in reducing morbidity or mortality. The guideline, based on a systematic review using the GRADE approach, emphasizes shared decision-making, considering the effectiveness, costs, and patient preferences. It underlines the importance of assessing the benefits and harms of newer medications, given their high costs.

title: Heroes Ball to benefit Cancer Support Community
summary: The Heroes Ball, a fundraiser for the Cancer Support Community at Gilda’s Club, is scheduled for Saturday, June 8 at the Double Tree in Henrietta. The event includes a cocktail reception, dinner program, awards, and an afterparty with Atlas Band. The fundraiser aims to celebrate heroes aiding those battling cancer, with all proceeds staying local. News 8's Adam Chodak will emcee the event, and tickets and sponsorships are currently available for purchase.

title: Cancer Support Community Arizona celebrates their 25th anniversary
summary: Cancer Support Community Arizona (CSCAZ) is celebrating its 25th anniversary, having provided invaluable emotional and social support to cancer patients in Arizona. Julie Dunnigan, CEO of CSCAZ, highlighted the organization's commitment to offering over 100 free programs monthly. These programs, which include book clubs, guided meditation, support groups, yoga, and art classes, are designed to aid cancer patients, their families, and caregivers at no cost throughout their cancer journey. This milestone marks a significant achievement for CSCAZ in its mission to support those affected by cancer.

title: VieCure Streamlines Cancer Care by Adding E-Prescribing Solutions from DrFirst
summary: VieCure, a cancer care company, has improved its clinical decision support system by adding e-prescribing and medication management features from DrFirst, a leader in health technology. This upgrade includes DrFirst's Rcopia, a sophisticated electronic prescribing system, and continues the use of EPCS Gold for managing controlled substances. Rcopia provides detailed medication history, clinical warnings, cost details, and tools for ensuring patients follow their treatment plans, making healthcare providers' jobs easier. It also offers access to databases for monitoring prescription drugs, which helps in managing pain treatment plans. The goal of this partnership is to enhance patient safety, streamline clinical processes, and offer better ways to track medication history and patient compliance. DrFirst is known for its innovative approaches to medication management, with its products being widely adopted in the health sector. VieCure uses AI and patient data to create personalized cancer treatment options, aiming to make the treatment process more efficient and improve patient outcomes.

title: 10 Years of Turquoise: American Lung Association Celebrates Milestone of Hope, Encourages Everyone to Take ...
summary: The American Lung Association celebrates the 10th anniversary of its LUNG FORCE initiative during Lung Cancer Action Week and Turquoise Takeover (May 6-12, 2024), aiming to raise awareness and funds to combat lung cancer, the leading cause of cancer deaths in the U.S. The campaign involves illuminating landmarks in turquoise, sharing stories of those affected, and encouraging public participation through activities like LUNG FORCE Walks and social media engagement. Over the past decade, LUNG FORCE has raised over $30 million for lung cancer research, contributing to a significant increase in the five-year survival rate for lung cancer patients. The American Lung Association advocates for early detection through screening, radon testing, and supports research for new treatments, with over 50 new lung cancer treatments approved since 2016. The initiative also emphasizes the importance of clean air and a tobacco-free future as part of its mission to save lives by improving lung health.

title: Low to be honored by American Lung Association for cancer-fighting invention - Research at Purdue
summary: Philip Low, a Purdue University researcher, will receive the Legacy Award from the American Lung Association in Indiana for his invention of CYTALUX, an FDA-approved fluorescent marker that highlights lung cancer cells during surgery. This breakthrough allows surgeons to more effectively differentiate malignant cells from healthy ones, ensuring the complete removal of cancerous tissue, vital for lung cancer patients' survival. Low, with over 700 patents and founder of seven companies, is honored for his significant contributions to fighting lung cancer with this innovative technology. CYTALUX's development showcases Low's dedication to advancing medical technology and enhancing lung disease patients' outcomes. The award will be given at the annual gala in Indianapolis on April 13.

title: American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb underway at Soldier Field
summary: The American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb is happening at Soldier Field, celebrating its 15th anniversary. This event, designed to raise money for lung disease support and promote cleaner air, features participants climbing almost 2,000 stairs. With a fundraising target of $442,000, more than 70% has been raised so far. WGN's team, with members Lourdes Duarte, Alyssa Donovan, and Courtney Spinelli, is taking part in the climb. Donations to support their effort can still be made via the event's website.

title: Asthma Awareness Month: American Lung Association Focuses on Addressing Challenges of Extreme Heat and Asthma
summary: During Asthma Awareness Month, the American Lung Association is emphasizing the need for better management of asthma due to climate change and extreme heat. Recognizing that millions in the U.S. suffer from asthma, a chronic lung disease, the association is focusing on educating healthcare providers and those affected by asthma on how to deal with the challenges of rising temperatures and extreme weather. With climate change causing more frequent and severe heatwaves, increased ozone pollution, and higher allergen levels, managing asthma has become more complicated. The American Lung Association is providing resources like the Asthma Educator Institute and an online course on asthma management guidelines for healthcare professionals, as well as the Asthma Basics course for people with asthma. They are also advocating for the Elijah E. Cummings Family Asthma Act to improve national efforts to tackle asthma and encouraging support for asthma research through donations.

title: American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb underway at Soldier Field
summary: The American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb is happening at Soldier Field, with a WGN team taking part. This event, celebrating its 15th year, seeks to collect money for people with lung conditions and to promote cleaner air initiatives.

title: Olympus Partners with American Lung Association on Patient Education for Lung Cancer Screening
summary: Olympus Corporation of the Americas has partnered with the American Lung Association to provide educational resources on Lung.org aimed at helping lung cancer patients understand the diagnosis and staging process for lung nodules, which is crucial for determining the most effective treatment. This partnership emphasizes the importance of early detection and precise staging in improving survival rates, as lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer death in the United States. Olympus supports the initiative through its pioneering technology, Endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA), which aids in accurately diagnosing and staging lung cancer, thereby facilitating targeted treatments like immunotherapy. The educational resources are designed to empower patients to actively participate in their care by making informed decisions.

title: American Lung Association and LUNGevity Foundation Announce $3 Million Research Partnership to Intercept Lung ...
summary: The American Lung Association and LUNGevity Foundation have announced a $3 million research partnership over three years to fight lung cancer by targeting precancerous cells before they turn cancerous. This effort focuses on enhancing early detection and intervention, potentially transforming treatment and greatly improving patient outcomes. Dr. Avrum Spira and Dr. Steven Dubinett lead the research, employing cutting-edge technologies such as robot-assisted bronchoscopy to gather longitudinal samples. The project, "Intercept Lung Cancer Through Immune, Imaging & Molecular Evaluation InTIME," continues from previous successful efforts to comprehend and stop lung cancer's development by focusing on early molecular and immune changes. Additionally, the partnership aims to speed up research on lung cancer interception and create personalized treatments, supporting LUNGevity's goal to boost survivorship and life quality for those impacted by lung cancer.

title: American Lung Association Celebrates 120 Years of Impact: A Legacy of Advancing Lung Health and Saving Lives
summary: The American Lung Association celebrates its 120th anniversary, marking over a century of advancements in lung health and life-saving efforts. Founded in 1904 by Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau to combat tuberculosis, the organization has significantly impacted public health through education, advocacy, and research. Over the years, it has been instrumental in reducing the U.S. smoking rate, making airline flights smoke-free, and funding research leading to healthcare breakthroughs. The Association now focuses on defeating lung cancer, creating a tobacco-free future, championing clean air for all, and improving the quality of life for those with lung disease. In 2023, it launched the free Patient & Caregiver Network to support individuals with lung disease and their families. The Association continues to address current and future lung health threats, including wildfires, climate change, vaping, COVID-19, RSV, pneumonia, and lung cancer.

title: VSFB Medical Professional Selected as AMSUS Innovator of the Year
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: U.S. Air Force Maj. Stephen Emmerthal, serving as the 30th Medical Group diagnostics and therapeutics flight commander at Vandenberg Space Force Base, was awarded the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States Premier Innovation Award in February 2024. Maj. Emmerthal was recognized for his significant contributions in innovating the Department of Defense's pharmacy crisis response, enhancing collaborative pharmacy support, and pioneering the distribution plan for COVID-19 at-home testing. His efforts have led to process improvements in pharmacy collaboration and advancements in efficiency across government agencies, revolutionizing support and testing for the Department of Defense.

title: VSFB Medical Professional Selected as AMSUS Innovator of the Year
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: U.S. Air Force Maj. Stephen Emmerthal, the diagnostics and therapeutics flight commander at the 30th Medical Group, Vandenberg Space Force Base, has been awarded the 2024 Association of Military Surgeons of the United States (AMSUS) Premier Innovation Award. This award acknowledges Emmerthal's major contributions to military and federal medicine through innovative solutions to complex healthcare delivery and readiness challenges. Out of over 400 candidates, Emmerthal was recognized for his leadership in fostering collaboration and efficiency among government agencies. He notably led his team to overcome a catastrophic flood at Vandenberg's pharmacy by collaborating with Travis Air Force Base to quickly restore pharmacy services. Additionally, Emmerthal developed a COVID-19 at-home testing distribution plan for the Department of Defense, significantly lowering transmission rates and protecting thousands of beneficiaries. His work has established a new benchmark for pharmacy disaster response and federal healthcare innovation, highlighting his commitment to enhancing healthcare delivery and readiness in the military and federal domains.

title: How Many People Have Liver Disease?
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: More than 100 million people in the U.S. suffer from some type of liver disease, with 4.5 million adults (1.8%) diagnosed and an estimated 80-100 million having fatty liver disease, many of whom are unaware of their condition. Liver disease can lead to liver failure and liver cancer if not treated. In 2020, liver disease was responsible for 51,642 deaths in the U.S. (15.7 per 100,000 population), ranking as the 12th leading cause of death. A study in 2016 found different prevalence rates among racial/ethnic groups, with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) being the most common cause across the board. Cirrhosis, which is long-term scarring of the liver, often stems from hepatitis, alcohol abuse, and NAFLD. Risk factors include heavy alcohol consumption, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and family history. Cirrhosis also raises the risk of stroke, with higher mortality rates from liver cirrhosis observed in Black/African American men and women since the 1950s.

title: NAFLD is Now MASLD: The New Nomenclature, At-a-Glance
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: The American Association for the Study of Liver Disease's annual conference, The Liver Meeting 2023, is scheduled from November 10 to November 14. It will discuss the natural history, prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of steatotic liver disease. A major topic will be the new terminology, changing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) to metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) to metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH). The conference will include educational sessions, abstracts, and posters from leading scientists, targeting practitioners at all levels. Highlights include studies on the reduced cirrhosis risk in MASLD and type 2 diabetes patients using GLP-1RAs, the higher risk of MASLD in children with obese parents, and the first federally-funded MASLD research by the American Liver Foundation.

title: Suneetha Narreddy bags IDSA fellowship
summary: Suneetha Narreddy from Apollo Hospitals was granted a fellowship by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA). The society's president, Steven K. Schmitt, commended Dr. Narreddy for her commitment, outstanding leadership, and skills, which have greatly improved shared knowledge, patient care, and public health. Dr. Narreddy stated that this recognition strengthens her lifelong commitment to combating infectious diseases and bettering healthcare results.

title: Measles and Misinformation: The Impact on Public Health
summary: Measles and Misinformation: The Impact on Public Health is a media briefing organized by the Infectious Diseases Society of America to address the U.S. measles outbreaks and the factors contributing to them. The briefing, featuring experts like Joshua Barocas, MD from the University of Colorado School of Medicine, and Sarah Lim, MD from the Minnesota Department of Health, focuses on the short- and long-term health impacts of measles, strategies for protecting infants and young children, and the role of misinformation in fueling outbreaks. The discussion aims to shed light on the challenges and necessary actions to combat measles effectively.

title: Dr. Kelly Keefe Marcoux Appointed to National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners Executive Board
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Dr. Kelly Keefe Marcoux has been appointed to the executive board of the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) and has received the Dr. Judith Lothian Young Alumni Award. With over 30 years of experience in pediatric acute care, she has made significant contributions to pediatric nursing and medicine. Her work focuses on family-centered care, and she has developed the first Pediatric APN Fellowship programs in Developmental Behavioral Pediatrics and Pediatric Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation in the U.S. Dr. Keefe Marcoux's dedication to improving pediatric health care is recognized by her colleagues and the wider medical community. She aims to advocate for pediatric nurse practitioners and improve services for pediatric patients. The Dr. Lothian Alumni award will be presented to her at Seton Hall’s 51st Annual Margaret C. Haley Awards Reception.

title: NAPNAP networking opportunities, navigating artificial intelligence in health care
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: The 2024 National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) National Conference on Pediatric Health Care will be held from March 13-16 in Denver, Colorado. Tracie W. Kirkland, PhD, DNP, stresses the importance of networking and learning from the experiences of others nationwide for both practicing providers and academics. The conference will include discussions on vaccine hesitancy, social determinants of health, and a patient-centered approach to breastfeeding management following AAP guidelines. There will be a significant emphasis on incorporating Artificial Intelligence (AI) in pediatric health care, covering practice, scholarship, and clinical implications. Kirkland points out the critical need to stay updated on new technologies and AI to prepare future nurse practitioners and improve patient care. The conference aims to promote the sharing of knowledge and the use of new technologies in pediatric health care practices.

title: Regena Spratling, PhD, RN, APRN, CPNP-PC, FAANP, FAAN: Highlights From NAPNAP Annual Conference
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Regena Spratling, PhD, RN, APRN, CPNP-PC, FAANP, FAAN, is currently the president of the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) and a professor at the School of Nursing, Georgia State University. The 2024 NAPNAP annual meeting in Denver saw increased attendance and membership, now around 8,000 NPs. Spratling emphasized the positive energy, valuable networking, and the focus on growing membership, conference attendance, and member engagement, including virtual events and a book club. A key issue addressed was pediatric mental and behavioral health, focusing on early suicide and postpartum depression screening during well-child visits. NAPNAP's efforts, such as NAPNAP Partners for Vulnerable Youth, aim to tackle these and other children's health issues. Spratling also highlighted the challenges of pediatric healthcare provider shortages and her research on children needing medical technology, leading to the creation of the COPE-STAR intervention for parents.

title: Emily L Pohl, ARNP - Bio and credentials
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Emily L Pohl, ARNP, is a Pediatric Nurse Practitioner at UF Health Pediatrics – Millhopper. She holds a bachelor's degree in Nursing from Purdue University and a master's degree in nursing from Jacksonville University, obtained in 2018. Prior to her master's degree, she served as a registered nurse in the progressive care unit at Indiana University Health. Her areas of expertise are cardiac arrhythmias, pacemakers, and care after cardiac catheterization. She has been awarded the Patient Safety Award by Indiana University Health Arnett Hospital and was a nominee for the Daisy Award. Dr. Pohl is affiliated with the American Nurses Association and the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners. She is certified as a Family Nurse Practitioner by the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners. Her professional focus is on adolescent development, promoting healthy lifestyles, and conducting well-child visits, with a specialization in Pediatrics as a Nurse Practitioner.

title: 'Kids Off Social Media Act' gets introduced by Sen. Mark Warner
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: The "Kids Off Social Media Act" was introduced by Virginia Senator Mark Warner, along with a bipartisan group of senators, to address the mental health crisis among children and teens related to social media use. The legislation proposes setting a minimum age of 13 for social media usage and bans algorithmically-targeted content to users under 17. It aims to mitigate the harmful effects of social media, such as bullying, eating disorders, and mental health struggles. The Act allows enforcement by the FTC and state attorneys general and requires schools to block social media on federally funded networks. The initiative is supported by various organizations concerned with children's mental health and well-being.

title: NAPNAP Launches Second Phase of CE Courses to Support Pediatric Mental Health
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: The National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) has launched the second phase of its NAPNAP Cares program, introducing additional online continuing education (CE) courses focused on pediatric mental health. This initiative, first initiated in June 2023 with 10 courses, aims to equip pediatric-focused nurse practitioners (NPs) and advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) with the necessary skills to address the increasing mental and behavioral health care needs of pediatric patients and their families. The program now offers a total of 20 courses covering a broad spectrum of topics including sensory processing issues, sleep disorders, health promotion, and anticipatory guidance. These resources are designed to enhance the participants' knowledge and skills in pediatric mental health, promoting positive patient outcomes. The courses are available for free to NAPNAP members for up to a year and can be purchased by non-members. This educational effort comes in response to the rising number of child visits to emergency departments for mental health crises, highlighting the urgent need for specialized care and education in pediatric mental health.

title: Congenital heart disease and associated genetic red flags
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: At the 2024 National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) National Conference on Pediatric Health Care in Denver, Colorado, Jennifer Joiner, MSN, CPNP-AC/PC, highlighted the importance of recognizing genetic red flags associated with congenital heart disease. Joiner emphasized the prevalence of congenital heart disease in pediatrics, noting it accounts for about 40% of pediatric deaths and affects 20% to 30% of neonatal ICU babies. She stressed the critical role of primary care providers in identifying potential genetic components of congenital heart issues through thorough physical exams and patient history. Joiner also introduced OMIM.org, an online resource for diagnosing genetic conditions, encouraging healthcare professionals to utilize it for better patient outcomes. The session aimed to empower primary care providers with knowledge and tools to detect and manage congenital heart disease effectively, emphasizing the importance of genetic counseling for affected families.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Invests in ImmunoFree
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in ImmunoFree, a biomedical company that aims to revolutionize organ transplantation by removing the need for immunosuppressive drugs. Founded in 2023, ImmunoFree is at the forefront of developing stem cell transplant technology to rid transplant recipients of the adverse effects of these drugs, striving for longer and healthier lives. This technology is especially advantageous for socio-economically disadvantaged groups, tackling the problem of sticking to post-transplant medication schedules. ImmunoFree's method is expected to prolong organ life and lower the risks of cancer and other side effects related to immunosuppression, thus improving the quality of life for transplant recipients. This partnership is in line with NKF's goal to promote kidney health and support innovative treatments for those with kidney diseases. The NKF Innovation Fund, started in 2021, is dedicated to speeding up the creation and market introduction of treatments focused on the patient, with the aims of preventing kidney disease, eliminating transplant waiting lists, and enhancing dialysis patient care.

title: Travere Therapeutics to Present at National Kidney Foundation Spring Clinical Meetings and the 61st European Renal ...
summary: Travere Therapeutics announced its participation in upcoming medical conferences, where it will present nine abstracts on rare kidney diseases at the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) Spring Clinical Meetings in California and the European Renal Association (ERA) Congress in Stockholm. The presentations will focus on FILSPARI (sparsentan), comparing its efficacy in slowing kidney function decline against the standard of care in real-world use and clinical trials for patients with IgA nephropathy (IgAN). New findings from the SPARTAN Study evaluating FILSPARI as a first-line treatment for IgAN will also be shared. Additionally, at the ERA Congress, a comparison of two-year efficacy outcomes between FILSPARI and another treatment will be presented. The company emphasizes FILSPARI's potential as a foundational therapy for IgAN, highlighting its superior efficacy over traditional care standards.

title: Everly Health Partners With National Kidney Foundation, Expands Kidney Health Testing Suite
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to enhance education on chronic kidney disease and expanded its testing suite for diabetes monitoring and kidney health for health plans and employers. The partnership aims to distribute co-branded educational materials on kidney health screening and identify at-risk patients for chronic kidney disease, especially those diagnosed with diabetes, by providing them with at-home kidney health test kits. Abnormal test results will prompt follow-up steps from Everly Health. This initiative addresses the significant public health issue of chronic kidney disease, which affects about 37 million Americans, with the majority unaware of their condition. Everly Health's expanded testing suite includes tests for heart and kidney health, diabetes monitoring, and is designed to improve Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set measures and Medicare and Medicaid Services Star Ratings. The effort underscores the importance of early screening and treatment to slow the progression of kidney disease, leveraging the increased acceptance of at-home testing post-COVID-19 pandemic.

title: NKF's Innovation Fund Invests in ZeitLife to Modernize Kidney Preservation and Logistics
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced an investment in ZeitLife Transplant Innovations, Inc. through its NKF Innovation Fund. ZeitLife is a global medical device company focused on advancing kidney preservation and logistics technologies. This collaboration aims to modernize the kidney procurement and transplant system, addressing challenges in organ transportation and logistics. ZeitLife specializes in preservation fluid and machine perfusion technologies, aiming to improve the distribution of organs over longer distances and ensure compliance with clinical evidence. This strategic investment supports ZeitLife's mission to supply organs on demand, aligning with NKF's goals to improve kidney health and transplantation outcomes. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, invests in companies developing innovative kidney therapies, with the long-term goals of preventing kidney disease, eliminating the transplant waitlist, and providing better treatments for dialysis patients.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Klinrisk to Revolutionize Chronic Kidney Disease Care
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Klinrisk through its Innovation Fund to advance the care of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD). Klinrisk, an artificial intelligence-based medical device company, focuses on the early identification and management of high-risk CKD patients through accurate clinical risk prediction and decision support. This investment aligns with the NKF's goal of driving advancements in kidney health and improving health equity and outcomes for kidney disease patients. Klinrisk's lab-based prediction models enable early intervention in CKD, potentially preventing the need for dialysis and improving patient outcomes. The collaboration aims to accelerate the adoption of risk-based care models and ensure timely interventions, especially among underserved populations. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, supports the development and commercialization of innovative kidney therapies with the long-term goals of preventing kidney disease, eliminating the transplant waitlist, and providing better treatments for dialysis patients.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Announces Investment in Relavo
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has funded Relavo through its Innovation Fund to aid the creation of PeritoneX®, a technology aimed at making peritoneal dialysis (PD) safer and more widely available for home use. PeritoneX® is a device that cleans dialysis tubes from the inside, seeking to lower infection risks, a major hurdle for PD's broader use. Despite PD's benefits like reduced costs, improved life quality, and lesser job impact, infection dangers mean only 10% of kidney failure patients undergo this treatment. Peritonitis, a peritoneal membrane infection, affects about 30% of PD patients each year, with half needing hospital care. Relavo's invention, compatible with current PD setups, has proven to cut down bacteria in laboratory tests and looks to decrease secondary infection chances. The NKF Innovation Fund, started in 2022, aims to speed up the introduction and sale of new kidney treatments.

title: The National Kidney Foundation and Healthy.io partner to Increase Access to Testing for Detection of Kidney Disease
summary: The National Kidney Foundation and Healthy.io have announced a partnership aimed at enhancing the detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD) through the distribution of Minuteful Kidney™ at-home test kits. These kits, offered free to individuals at risk of CKD, are part of the "Are You the 33%?" campaign, which includes a one-minute risk assessment quiz available on the NKF's website. The initiative, launched in time for Kidney Day 2023, seeks to educate the public on CKD and encourage early testing. Healthy.io's Minuteful Kidney test, the first FDA-cleared smartphone-powered at-home kidney test, enables users to perform an albumin-to-creatinine ratio test using their smartphone camera, facilitating early CKD detection from home. This partnership addresses healthcare access barriers and aims to increase early detection and treatment of CKD, particularly among underserved communities disproportionately affected by the disease.

title: National Kidney Foundation Recognizes March as National Kidney Month
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) is observing March as National Kidney Month, with a special focus on World Kidney Day on March 14th, to raise awareness about kidney health and chronic kidney disease (CKD). This year, the emphasis is on "KIDNEY EQUITY FOR ALL™," aiming to address health disparities affecting underserved populations in their journey with kidney disease. NKF's initiatives include promoting high-quality, patient-centered kidney care from diagnosis to transplantation for all, especially targeting Black and Hispanic communities who bear a disproportionate burden of kidney disease. Efforts include the Kidney Risk Quiz to assess disease risk, advocating for the removal of race from the Kidney Disease Risk Index (KDRI), ensuring equitable access to transplants by revising the eGFR calculation without racial bias, and targeted screening programs for high-risk populations. These actions are part of NKF's broader mission to improve kidney care and outcomes for everyone, highlighting the importance of community and industry support in achieving kidney equity.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Diatiro to Advance Kidney Health with New Kidney Pod ...
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Diatiro, a medical technology company, through its NKF Innovation Fund to support the development of Diatiro's Kidney Pod technology. This investment aims to advance kidney transplantation and improve health equity by addressing the issue of "warming injury" during transplantation. The Kidney Pod technology, which has received breakthrough designation from the FDA, utilizes advanced materials to keep organs cold throughout the transplant process, potentially increasing the number of viable donor kidneys and improving transplant outcomes. This could also enable robotic transplantation in the future. The NKF's Innovation Fund, established to accelerate the funding, development, and commercialization of patient-centric kidney therapies, supports this initiative as part of its broader goals to prevent kidney disease, eliminate the transplant waitlist, and provide safer treatments for dialysis patients.

title: Everly Health and National Kidney Foundation Partnership Aims to Save Lives Through Early Detection of Chronic ...
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD) to save lives and reduce healthcare costs. This partnership aims to increase awareness and access to quality testing, especially in rural and underserved communities in the United States. With 37 million adults in the U.S. affected by CKD and 90% unaware of their condition, this initiative focuses on educating Americans about CKD and its major risk factors, such as diabetes and hypertension, which contribute to over two-thirds of cases. Everly Health is expanding its testing suite for health plans and employers, offering comprehensive tests for conditions impacting kidney health. The collaboration also seeks to improve healthcare quality measures and member experiences for health plans through enhanced care coordination. A recent pilot program demonstrated the effectiveness of Everly Health's Kidney Health Tests in detecting kidney health abnormalities, potentially preventing the progression of renal diseases.

title: National Kidney Foundation
summary: The Northern Ohio Chapter of the National Kidney Foundation is looking for volunteers for various events and programs in its 32-county area to help with its goal of increasing awareness, prevention, and treatment of kidney disease.
