Since its founding in 1964, and with a revenue of $620,000 in 2022, it is the largest organization in the U.S. focused on kidney disease that centers on patients. There are many ways to get involved, such as Kidney Walks, Golf Classic, Patient Symposium, and educational programs. The foundation also welcomes financial contributions and living kidney donations to aid its crucial programs. Major fundraising activities include Komedy for Kidneys, Patient Symposium, Kidney Walks, and the NKF Golf Classic. The organization is overseen by Executive Director Anna Tzinis and a varied advisory board.

title: Dana-Farber nurses present research and evidence-based studies at 2024 Oncology Nursing Society Congress
summary: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute nurses are participating in the 49th annual Oncology Nursing Society (ONS) Congress from April 24-28, 2024, in Washington, D.C., presenting studies and projects that showcase the integration of clinical knowledge, research, and direct patient care. Two nurses from Dana-Farber, Jessica McDade and Ludmila Svoboda, have been recognized with Extraordinary Healer honors for their contributions to oncology nursing. The conference will feature presentations on various topics, including the impact of post-treatment comorbid diabetes, the use of high-fidelity simulation for education on bispecific antibody-induced cytokine release syndrome, the referral to exercise programs for genitourinary oncology patients, and the nursing care of hemodialysis patients undergoing CAR T-cell therapy. These presentations highlight Dana-Farber's commitment to advancing oncology nursing through research, education, and patient care.

title: Susan O. Koduah, assistant professor reflects on her time as President of Oncology Nursing Society, Northern Virginia ...
summary: Susan O. Koduah, an Assistant Professor of Nursing at the College of Public Health, reflected on her tenure as President of the Oncology Nursing Society's Northern Virginia Chapter. Elected in 2023 after serving as President-elect in 2022, Koduah successfully increased member participation and celebrated the chapter's 40th anniversary. She emphasized the importance of humility and listening to members to enhance organizational success and participation. Koduah's presidency involved organizing celebratory events, acting as a liaison to the national office, chairing quarterly board meetings, coordinating monthly dinner meetings, and writing an end-of-year report for the national office. Her efforts led to a significant increase in attendance at events, including a Gala that attracted over 150 attendees. Koduah attributed her achievements to collaborative efforts, highlighting the value of teamwork in reaching organizational goals.

title: The John Theurer Cancer Center Recognized as 2024 Outstanding Employer by the Oncology Nursing Society
summary: The John Theurer Cancer Center (JTCC) in Hackensack, NJ, has been recognized as the 2024 Outstanding Employer by the Oncology Nursing Society (ONS), highlighting its exceptional support for oncology nurses. Margaret Hopkins, RN, a cancer survivor and nurse at JTCC, praised the center for its educational support, opportunities for professional growth, and the nurturing work environment it provides. This award, particularly meaningful during a time of nursing shortages, underscores JTCC's role as a leading institution where innovative technology and individualized treatment are combined with a caring and highly skilled staff to save lives. The recognition also emphasizes the center's high nurse retention rates, supportive work environment, and commitment to nurse development, including free certification exams and a comprehensive orientation program. JTCC's recognition aligns it with other prestigious institutions, showcasing its commitment to both patient care and the professional growth of its nurses.

title: Sylvester Nurse Next President of the Oncology Nursing Society - InventUM
summary: Jessica MacIntyre, with 20 years of impactful work in cancer care at Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center and in the community, is set to become the president of the Oncology Nursing Society (ONS) in April 2024. She aims to use her presidency to support and empower early-career oncology nurses and nurse practitioners, focusing on mentorship, professional development, and education to prepare them for the future challenges of oncology care. MacIntyre, who has developed significant leadership skills through ONS, contributed to publications, and advocated for advanced practice initiatives, plans to continue promoting an environment where oncology nurses feel valued and equipped to deliver exceptional care. Her passion for nursing was sparked by her grandmother’s battle with metastatic breast cancer, leading her to pursue a career where she could make a difference in the lives of cancer patients and their families. MacIntyre, who has served in various roles within Sylvester, including as a nurse navigator and in dual roles as a clinician and administrator, oversees several clinical programs. She hopes her role as ONS president will bring more visibility to Sylvester, the only NCI-designated cancer center in South Florida, and attract top nursing talent.

title: Horizon CME Brings Best of ASCO® to San Francisco, Dallas, Phoenix and Los Angeles
summary: Horizon CME will host the Best of ASCO® 2024 programs in San Francisco, Dallas, Phoenix, and Los Angeles, bringing the latest oncology scientific findings to healthcare professionals in these cities. These in-person conferences are officially licensed by the American Society of Clinical Oncology® (ASCO®), representing various oncology subspecialties. The annual two-day program aims to share scientific discoveries from the ASCO® Annual Meeting in Chicago, with local agendas organized by oncology clinicians and experts from renowned institutions like Stanford Cancer Center, the Mayo Clinic, and others. Each event will cover in-depth discussions on recent scientific findings and advances in cancer treatment. The conferences are scheduled between July 13 and August 4, 2024, at different venues in the mentioned cities. Registration and accommodation details are available on HorizonCME.com. Horizon CME, founded in 2007, focuses on providing quality continuing medical education to improve patient outcomes.

title: Breastfeeding: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months and suggests continuing it as long as desired, in line with the World Health Organization's advice. The AAP aims to boost the rate of exclusive breastfeeding due to its many health advantages for both the child and the breastfeeding parent. Children benefit from decreased risks of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), infections, chronic illnesses, and higher IQ scores. Nursing parents may see reduced chances of diabetes, hypertension, and some cancers. Breastfeeding creates a special connection through physical closeness and supplies all the necessary nutrition for the baby's growth without the need for extra food or formula in the first six months. However, challenges like societal pressure, workplace support lack, and stigma, particularly regarding public breastfeeding or doing so after the babyhood, exist. The AAP assists breastfeeding parents with advice on effective breastfeeding techniques and overcoming these challenges, advocating for breastfeeding rights and supportive environments.

title: American Academy of Pediatrics
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), founded in 1930 and headquartered in Itasca, Illinois, is a professional membership organization comprising 67,000 pediatricians dedicated to the health and well-being of infants, children, adolescents, and young adults. AAP is a leading advocacy group for children's health and a primary source of health-related information for pediatricians and their patients. It manages HealthyChildren.org, a pediatrician-backed parenting website, and has the world's largest pediatric publishing program, including the scientific journal Pediatrics and the membership magazine AAP News. The AAP also operates a federal affairs office in Washington, DC, and has been recognized as one of the 101 Best and Brightest Companies to Work for in Chicagoland since 2005. The organization encourages professionals to join its team to impact children's health provision in the U.S.

title: Moms with HIV can breastfeed if taking treatment and virus is undetectable, pediatricians’ group says
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics now recommends that mothers with HIV can breastfeed their babies with very low risk if they are on antiretroviral treatment (ART) and have an undetectable viral load. This is a major change from earlier advice, which was against breastfeeding to prevent HIV transmission to the baby. The new guidelines support and counsel mothers who want to breastfeed while on ART, using a harm reduction strategy that focuses on viral suppression. This update reflects new insights and research on HIV transmission, the benefits of breastfeeding, and how effective ART is in lowering transmission risks. The aim is to give mothers with HIV the same choices about feeding their infants as others, promoting safe breastfeeding practices.

title: Patient Care - Epilepsy: National Coordinating Center for Epilepsy
summary: Epilepsy is the most common childhood brain disorder in the United States, affecting 470,000 children and adolescents. The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has been the National Coordinating Center for Epilepsy under the Health Resources and Services Administration Maternal Child Health Bureau since 2013. The Center aims to improve access to coordinated, comprehensive, and quality care for children and youth with epilepsy, particularly those in medically underserved and rural areas. Epilepsy is characterized by recurring seizures due to abnormal electrical and chemical changes in the brain, with various types and severities. Diagnosis usually comes after one or more unprovoked seizures and a likelihood of recurrence not due to other medical conditions. The AAP offers recommendations and resources to help healthcare professionals in diagnosing, treating, and managing epilepsy, striving for high-quality care and support for affected children, youth, and their families.

title: AAP OKs Breastfeeding for Some Moms With HIV on ART
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has updated its recommendations, now allowing some mothers with HIV who are on antiretroviral therapy (ART) and have undetectable viral loads to breastfeed their infants. This change reverses the longstanding advice against breastfeeding for all HIV-positive mothers to prevent virus transmission to the baby. The new guidance is based on evidence showing a very low risk of HIV transmission during breastfeeding under these conditions. Mothers who wish to breastfeed should have initiated ART early in or before pregnancy, maintained a sustained HIV viral suppression, have continuous access to ART, consistently take their medication, and ensure infant antiretroviral prophylaxis is administered. Despite the low risk, it's acknowledged that transmission risk is not zero. The AAP's decision aligns with a joint CDC and HHS panel recommendation and reflects global recommendations, particularly in contexts where breastfeeding offers significant health benefits over formula feeding due to risks of malnutrition, diarrhea, and pneumonia in HIV-exposed infants.

title: US pediatricians group reverses decades-old ban on breastfeeding for those with HIV
summary: A top U.S. pediatricians' group, the American Academy of Pediatrics, has updated its guidelines to allow people with HIV to breastfeed their babies, provided they are on antiretroviral therapy that effectively suppresses the virus. This marks a significant shift from the recommendations set during the early stages of the HIV epidemic in the 1980s. The new guidance is based on evidence showing that the risk of HIV transmission through breast milk can be reduced to less than 1% with effective medication. However, the report also emphasizes that no breastfeeding is the only way to completely eliminate the risk of transmitting HIV to the baby. It also highlights the necessity of exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months to minimize the baby's risk of infection. This change follows similar updates from the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, reflecting advancements in HIV treatment and an understanding of the benefits of breastfeeding for both mothers and their children.

title: The 5 Cs of Media Use
summary: The 5 Cs of Media Use, developed by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), offers a simple framework for pediatricians and healthcare providers to discuss digital media use with families. It encompasses five key concepts: Child, Content, Calm, Crowding Out, and Communication. These principles aim to guide parents in understanding their children's developmental stages, how these stages affect media use, and how to establish healthy media habits at home. The approach is supported by age-specific handouts designed for distribution during well-child visits, providing evidence-based advice tailored to different developmental periods from infancy through adolescence. The 5 Cs are built upon the work of journalist Lisa Guernsey, evolving from her initial Three Cs concept. This initiative is part of the AAP's broader efforts to promote the physical, mental, and social well-being of children and teenagers in the digital age.

title: The American Academy of Pediatrics' new guidelines to help kids slash smart phone screen time
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics has introduced new guidelines known as the 5-C's to help parents manage their children's smartphone usage effectively. These guidelines are a response to studies showing that 53% of children own a smartphone by age 11, highlighting the need for strategies to mitigate excessive screen time. The 5-C's include understanding the Child and their attraction to certain media, being aware of the Content consumed, teaching Calmness as a way to handle emotions without resorting to media, Crowding Out media time with other valuable family activities, and fostering healthy device relationships to counteract peer pressure. Psychologist Dr. Cynthia Toland emphasizes the importance of these steps across different developmental stages, from promoting self-soothing in infants to teaching digital literacy to older children. Excessive screen time is linked to negative impacts on mood, concentration, and developmental activities. The guidelines aim to balance media use with developmental needs.

title: American Academy of Pediatrics Updates Policy Statement on Hearing Risks for Children
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics has updated its policy statement to address the risks of excessive noise exposure in infants, children, and adolescents, highlighting common sources like infant sleep machines and fireworks. Published in the November 2023 issue of Pediatrics, the statement emphasizes the serious public health hazard posed by loud noises, which can be more harmful to children due to their smaller ear canals that intensify higher frequency sounds. The policy advises on the importance of preventing harmful noise exposures from a young age, noting that everyday noises can disrupt sleep, learning, and quality of life. It points out that children and teens' use of personal listening devices at high volumes can lead to hearing loss, tinnitus, or hyperacusis. Recommendations include using protective earmuffs at noisy events, taking breaks from listening devices, and pediatricians providing information on preventing excessive noise exposure during patient visits. The statement also mentions that noise exposure risks are higher in lower socioeconomic groups and highlights the lack of federal regulations to protect against environmental noise hazards in the U.S.

title: How to Keep Your Sleeping Baby Safe: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has updated its policy statement and technical report on safe sleep to help reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and accidental deaths from suffocation or strangulation in infants. Each year, about 3,500 babies in the United States die suddenly and unexpectedly during sleep. The AAP's recommendations for a safe sleep environment include placing babies on their backs for all naps and at night, using a firm, flat sleep surface like a crib that meets safety standards, and keeping soft objects and loose bedding out of the baby's sleep area. Room sharing without bed sharing is advised for at least the first 6 months to decrease the risk of SIDS by up to 50%. Other recommendations include breastfeeding, offering a pacifier at nap and bedtime, avoiding exposure to smoke, alcohol, and illicit drugs during pregnancy and after birth, ensuring regular prenatal care and immunizations, and providing supervised tummy time when the baby is awake. The AAP advises against the use of products not marketed for infant sleep, like Boppy pillows and Dock-a-Tots, and cautions against the use of home cardiorespiratory monitors as a means to reduce SIDS risk.

title: Teen Mental Health: How to Know When Your Child Needs Help
summary: Teen mental health is a critical concern, with many adolescents facing anxiety, depression, and other mental health challenges. More than two years after a national emergency in youth mental health was declared, teenagers continue to struggle. Parents and caregivers may find it challenging to differentiate between normal adolescent behavior and signs of mental health issues. Key indicators that a teen may need more support include mood swings, changes in sleep or eating patterns, withdrawal from friends and activities, academic struggles, and signs of substance use or self-harm. Common mental health conditions affecting teens include ADHD, anxiety, and depression. Substance use is prevalent among teenagers and can exacerbate mental health problems. Social media also plays a significant role in teen mental health, with potential negative effects. Parents are encouraged to have open, judgment-free conversations with their children about mental health and seek support from pediatricians, who can offer treatment options and referrals to specialists. Immediate help should be sought for teens experiencing suicidal thoughts. Promoting positive mental health and resilience through proactive self-care and family activities is also important.

title: Media and Children - Center of Excellence on Social Media and Youth Mental Health
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has established a Center of Excellence on Social Media and Youth Mental Health aimed at creating a healthier digital ecosystem for children and adolescents. This initiative focuses on providing evidence-based education and technical assistance to support the mental health of young individuals as they interact with social media. The Center is led by co-Medical Directors Megan Moreno, MD, MPH, MSEd, FAAP, and Jenny Radesky, MD, FAAP, who are both pediatricians and experts in youth development and media. The Center offers resources like the 5 Cs of Media Use to help pediatricians, parents, and educators build healthy digital habits among children and teens. Additionally, it has developed a Q&A Portal to address questions from various stakeholders and a Youth Advisory Panel to inform its work. The Center also provides tools, tips, and webinars to assist families in managing social media use effectively. This initiative is supported by a grant from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) of the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

title: Helping Kids Build Healthy Active Lives: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has updated its clinical report to help kids lead healthier, more active lives, addressing the challenge of childhood obesity. The report emphasizes the importance of making healthy choices easy for children and families and advocates for supportive community and policy changes. It highlights that a child's health and weight are influenced by more than just nutrition and exercise, including factors like sleep, screen time, emotional and social issues. Practical tips for parents include educating kids about nutrition, prioritizing water as the main drink, limiting ultra-processed foods, creating a family media plan, incorporating physical activity into daily routines, and managing stress. The report also acknowledges the role of environmental factors and the need for support from schools, healthcare systems, and communities to foster healthier lifestyles for children. Pediatricians are encouraged to partner with families to address these issues, offering compassionate support and practical solutions.

title: Hope Foundation trip to India by Newport students
summary: In January 2024, a group of Transition Year students from Newport, accompanied by their teacher Ms. Michelle Flannery, embarked on a cultural and educational trip to Kolkata, India, with the Hope Foundation Immersion Programme. The students, including Jack Creagh, Ronan Fitzpatrick, Eva Skehan, Erin Burke, Ava Jones, Aoibhinn McNamara, Emily Sweeney O’Halloran, Emily O’Brian, Cliodhna Lenihan, and Flora Koves, raised over €25,000 through various fundraising activities such as table quizzes, bake sales, concerts, and more. During their six-day stay, they visited several Hope Foundation projects including residential homes, schools, creches, afterschool programs, and the Hope hospital. They engaged in cultural exchange, playing games, singing, dancing, and learning some Bengali. The trip also included visits to historical sites in Kolkata and participation in cultural activities like learning traditional Bengali dances, dressing in traditional Indian attire, and trying local foods. This trip reinforced the links between the school and India, providing students with invaluable experiences while supporting the Hope Foundation's work with street and slum-connected children in Kolkata.

title: Jeremy Irons appointed special ambassador for Cork-based for Hope Foundation
summary: Jeremy Irons has been appointed as a special ambassador for The Hope Foundation to mark their 25th anniversary. Living in West Cork, Irons has been a long-standing advocate for Hope's work in Kolkata, India, aiming to raise awareness and support for their efforts to transform the lives of marginalized children and their families. Since its inception in 1999, The Hope Foundation has impacted nearly three million people through 56 projects, including education, healthcare, child protection, and vocational training initiatives. Irons, who visited Hope's projects in Kolkata in 2019, expressed his honor in supporting the foundation's significant milestone and urged others to contribute to their cause. Maureen Forrest, founder and president of The Hope Foundation, praised Irons for his multifaceted talents and his ability to influence change, expressing gratitude for having him as an ambassador and friend of Hope.

title: Jeremy in leading role for Hope Foundation
summary: The Hope Foundation has named Jeremy Irons as its Special Ambassador for their 25th anniversary. Irons, an Oscar-winning actor and a long-standing advocate for HOPE's work in Kolkata, India, aims to support the Foundation's efforts in transforming the lives of marginalized children, families, and communities. Over 25 years, HOPE has significantly improved education, healthcare, child protection, and vocational training in Kolkata, running 56 projects including creches, residential care centers, and a hospital, aiding over 3 million people. Irons expressed his honor in serving as Special Ambassador, highlighting the life-changing work of HOPE in providing hope and opportunities to those in need. The anniversary celebrations will showcase the Foundation's achievements and seek continued support for their initiatives.

title: Jeremy Irons becomes ambassador for charity The Hope Foundation | Southern Star
summary: Jeremy Irons has been appointed as an ambassador for The Hope Foundation to celebrate its 25th anniversary. The Foundation, founded by Maureen Forrest in 1999 in Cork city, aims to support street children and their families in Kolkata, India, by providing education, healthcare, child protection, and vocational training. It has initiated 56 projects, including creches, residential childcare centers, and a hospital, benefiting nearly three million people. Irons, a stage and screen star and resident of Skibbereen, expressed his honor in supporting The Hope Foundation, emphasizing the importance of contributing to change and the ongoing need for the foundation's services. Maureen Forrest, the founder, praised Irons for his multifaceted talents and his potential to influence positive change, acknowledging him as a valuable ambassador and friend to the foundation.

title: Spotlight On: Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered (FORCE)
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered (FORCE) is an organization founded by Sue Friedman in 1999 after her own breast cancer diagnosis and discovery of a BRCA2 mutation. Initially focused on BRCA mutations, FORCE expanded in 2019 to support individuals and families affected by various genetic mutations linked to cancer, such as Lynch syndrome and ATM. The organization aims to improve the lives of those facing hereditary cancers through information, resources, and support, including a helpline, peer navigation, online forums, and support groups. FORCE also advocates for laws protecting people with hereditary cancer risks and access to screening, prevention, and treatment options. Additionally, FORCE's XRAY program helps explain hereditary cancer-related research, and they offer a tool for finding clinical trials. They host an international conference, Joining FORCEs Against Hereditary Cancer, to bring together the community for education and networking. Karen Kramer, a senior vice president at FORCE, emphasizes the organization's commitment to ensuring no one faces hereditary cancer alone.

title: Young Breast Cancer Survivors Program | NCCCP
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: In 2019, the CDC began providing funds to eight organizations for five years to help young breast cancer survivors and metastatic breast cancer patients in the U.S. Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer in U.S. women, especially hard for those diagnosed before 45, dealing with many challenges. The goal is to enhance survival and life quality for these individuals through organized support and resources, like educational materials for healthcare providers. These organizations aim to create a network for policy and environmental change, offer education for healthcare professionals, use new technology for learning, and employ patient navigators to improve service access for underrepresented groups. The focus is on young survivors in communities heavily impacted by breast cancer, considering race, ethnicity, income, disabilities, and metastatic breast cancer. The program includes an evaluation to check its effectiveness in providing services, building partnerships, and meeting its goals.

title: Bipartisan Legislation to Expand Genetic Cancer Testing Access Introduced in Congress - U.S
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: Bipartisan legislation titled the Reducing Hereditary Cancer Act was reintroduced in Congress by U.S. Senators Ben Cardin (D-Md.) and Lisa Murkowski (R-Ala.) along with Representatives Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Mariannette Miller-Meeks, Elissa Slotkin, and Larry Bucshon. This bill aims to expand access to genetic testing for Medicare beneficiaries to determine their risk of developing hereditary cancer. Currently, Medicare only covers genetic testing for those already diagnosed with cancer, ignoring family history or known genetic mutations. This legislation is supported by patient advocacy groups, academics, and medical institutions and seeks to cover genetic testing for those with a family history of hereditary cancer mutations and provide coverage for follow-up services like increased cancer screening and risk-reducing surgeries. The goal is to facilitate early detection and prevention of cancer, ultimately saving lives and reducing healthcare costs.

title: The U.S. continuing medical education market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.43% from 2022 to 2028.
summary: The U.S. continuing medical education (CME) market is expected to grow at a 6.43% annual rate from 2022 to 2028. A key trend in CME is gamification, which offers an engaging way to learn that complements remote education without replacing traditional methods. It effectively motivates medical professionals by improving their learning experiences. Health organizations are increasingly using video games for more than entertainment, such as managing chronic diseases and monitoring patient health outcomes in various conditions. The adoption of technologies like ChatGPT is set to change the U.S. CME market, despite challenges in using these technologies. The requirement for healthcare professionals to earn CME credits is a significant market driver. The market is categorized by how it's delivered, who provides it, and the type of providership, with classroom training and non-profit organizations & physician membership organizations (NPOs & PMOs) being major segments. Oncology is the top application segment, showing the high demand for CME in this quickly changing therapeutic area.

title: Chasing Cancer - The Washington Post
summary: The Washington Post's "Chasing Cancer" event highlighted groundbreaking treatments intercepting cancer at stage one and the steady drop in cancer mortality rates in the U.S., despite a cure remaining elusive. Emphasizing that up to 50% of cancers may be preventable, the discussion focused on how lifestyle factors like nutrition, physical activity, and early screenings could significantly reduce cancer risks. The event featured influential figures in cancer research and advocacy, including Dr. Douglas R. Lowy of the National Cancer Institute, Ellen V. Sigal of Friends of Cancer Research, and Dr. Richard Pazdur of the FDA's Oncology Center of Excellence. They addressed innovative treatments, drug policy, and advancements in early detection and prevention. Additionally, discussions on patient autonomy in disease prevention, precision medicine, and the emotional and financial support for families affected by pediatric cancer were highlighted, showcasing a multi-faceted approach to battling cancer.

title: Peach State Health Plan and the Centene Foundation Announce $2.2 Million Commitment to Augusta University
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: Peach State Health Plan and the Centene Foundation have committed $2.2 million to Augusta University to support the expansion of the Medical College of Georgia's 3+ Primary Care Pathway Program and to launch a new loan forgiveness program for dental students at the Dental College of Georgia who commit to practicing in rural and underserved areas of Georgia. This funding aims to address the healthcare provider shortages in rural parts of the state by placing physicians and dentists where they are most needed. The commitment builds on a previous investment of $5.2 million in 2021 for the MCG 3+ Program, which has already seen success in its efforts to combat the rural physician shortage. The new loan forgiveness program for dental students is designed to financially support those who agree to serve in rural Georgia counties, helping to address the significant gaps in dental care access across the state.

title: Best Office/Retail/Mixed-Use - Hub for Community Innovation Augusta (THE HUB)
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: The Hub for Community Innovation Augusta (THE HUB) in Augusta, Ga., has been recognized as the Best Project in the Office/Retail/Mixed-Use category by ENR Southeast 2023. Developed by the Medical College of Georgia Foundation Inc. and constructed by Choate Construction Co., THE HUB aims to revitalize a historic African American neighborhood through its support of local nonprofits. It houses five essential community organizations, including a Boys & Girls Club and a family health clinic, across two buildings, HUB East and HUB West, totaling 51,000 square feet. The project faced financial and logistical challenges, including navigating New Market Tax Credits and the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, but was successfully completed thanks to significant contributions from various stakeholders and over $6 million in funding. This development is expected to serve the underserved communities in Augusta for decades.

title: Peach State Health Plan and the Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University Announce 2023 Peach State Scholars
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: Peach State Health Plan and the Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University announced the 2023 Peach State Scholars, aiming to address Georgia's physician shortage. Nine medical students were selected for the MCG3+ Primary Care Pathway Program, which allows them to complete medical school in three years and enter a primary care residency in Georgia, focusing on serving in rural or underserved areas. The initiative, supported by a $5.2 million donation from Peach State Health Plan and matched funds from the state, seeks to improve access to quality healthcare in underserved regions. The scholars, from various hometowns and with diverse specialties, represent the program's third class since its inception in 2021.

title: MCG researcher secures prestigious grant for research to prevent blindness in premature infants
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: Syed Adeel H. Zaidi, PhD, an assistant research scientist at the Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University, has received a prestigious grant from the Knights Templar Eye Foundation for his groundbreaking research on preventing blindness in premature infants. His research is centered on retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), a prevalent condition in premature or low birth-weight infants that can cause significant vision loss or blindness due to damage to the retina's vascular and neuronal components. Zaidi aims to create a new treatment to lessen this damage by using an FDA-approved drug, difluoromethylornithine (DFMO), to block a harmful enzyme, ornithine decarboxylase 1 (ODC1), found to be overly active in ROP. This grant will fund pre-clinical trials in a mouse model, aiming to repurpose DFMO for clinical trials in ROP infants to protect their vision.

title: Envisioning an ideal model for retail pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Retail pharmacies are evolving to offer more healthcare services like screenings, immunizations, and chronic disease management. This change faces regulatory and operational challenges. The industry, through groups like the National Association of Chain Drug Stores and the National Community Pharmacists Association, is pushing for changes in pharmacy reimbursement and pharmacy benefit management to support this new role. Efforts are focused on improving payment models for pharmacies, particularly for Medicare and Medicaid. The pandemic has shown the potential for pharmacies to provide accessible healthcare, leading to initiatives for pharmacists to offer more services and receive fair compensation. The future vision is for pharmacies to be health hubs, requiring operational changes, more services, and collaboration with healthcare providers. This transformation aims to use pharmacists' expertise to improve health outcomes and make healthcare more accessible, highlighting the need for supportive payment systems and technological advancements.

title: As The World Enters a "Golden Age" of Medicine, Pharmacy Will Be Hugely Impacted, Suggests NACDS President
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: As the world enters a "Golden Age" of medicine, the pharmacy sector is poised for significant changes, according to NACDS President Steven C. Anderson. Speaking at the NACDS Total Store Expo 2023, Anderson highlighted how global tensions and trade issues are impacting drug supply chains, leading to shortages and accessibility challenges. He emphasized the critical role of active pharmaceutical ingredients from China in the global medication supply, warning that any disruption could have widespread effects on healthcare. Additionally, Anderson discussed the transformative potential of technology and machine learning in medicine, suggesting that we are on the cusp of breakthroughs in treating diseases like HIV, cancer, and Alzheimer's. He also outlined the NACDS 2023 initiative, which includes partnerships aimed at enhancing public health and wellness beyond traditional pharmacy services. This initiative seeks to address broader health issues through innovative approaches such as food prescriptions. Anderson's vision for the future of pharmacy involves leveraging technology and collaborative efforts to improve healthcare delivery and outcomes.

title: Former House Speaker Paul Ryan to address NACDS-PAC event
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Former House Speaker Paul Ryan is scheduled to speak at the National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) Annual Meeting's Chain Members and Political Action Committee Breakfast, from April 27 to 30 in Palm Beach, Florida. Ryan, the 54th Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and the youngest in nearly 150 years, will share his views on the current political scene, particularly regarding the 2024 presidential election. He will discuss economic, political, and healthcare issues important to the industry and the country. Ryan has focused on tax code simplification, national defense rebuilding, domestic energy production expansion, criminal justice system reform, and economic opportunity promotion. Post-Speakership, he launched the American Idea Foundation and joined several boards, showing ongoing political and economic influence.

title: NACDS announces 2024 Annual Meeting Business Program speakers
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) has announced the speakers for its 2024 Annual Meeting Business Program, scheduled for April 27-30 in Palm Beach, Florida. Walter Isaacson, a distinguished author, journalist, and professor, will address the audience during the Sunday Business Program on April 28. Arthur C. Brooks, an author, social scientist, and Harvard professor, will speak at the Tuesday Business Program on April 30. Isaacson is renowned for his biographies on influential figures such as Elon Musk and Steve Jobs, among others, and holds a professorship of history at Tulane University. Brooks, a prolific author and the Parker Gilbert Montgomery Professor at the Harvard Kennedy School, has written extensively on happiness and success. Both speakers are celebrated for their contributions to understanding social and political issues, promising to offer valuable insights at the NACDS Annual Meeting.

title: Payer Roundup—Blue Cross Blue Shield Association lawsuit unfolds; Rightway raises $109M; Surescripts reportedly ...
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The text provides a roundup of recent news in the healthcare payer industry as of April 2024. Key points include a lawsuit involving the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association (BCBSA) and Ford Motor, where BCBSA is accused of overcharging for health insurance, leading to a $2.7 billion antitrust settlement. Pharmacy benefit manager Rightway raised $109 million, signaling growth and expansion, particularly highlighted by Tyson Foods switching their drug benefits to Rightway. Electronic prescribing company Surescripts is exploring a sale amidst challenges, including a lawsuit by the Federal Trade Commission over monopoly status. The text also mentions Georgia's potential Medicaid expansion, which could significantly reduce the uninsured rate in the state. Point32Health is removing prior authorization for home health care services for the first 30 days post-hospital discharge to streamline care. Idaho's new bill aimed at reducing prescription drug prices receives praise, and partnerships and acquisitions such as Health Net with Canary Health and StanCorp Financial Group's acquisition of Elevance Health's Life & Disability business are highlighted.

title: NACDS highlights Kroger's participation in NACDS RxIMPACT
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) highlighted Kroger Health's significant participation in the NACDS RxIMPACT grassroots programs, particularly noting their substantial involvement during the 2024 RxIMPACT Day on Capitol Hill. Kroger Health, under the leadership of Colleen Lindholz, brought the highest number of representatives to advocate for pharmacy-related issues, including pharmacy benefit manager (PBM) reform and the advancement of the Equitable Community Access to Pharmacist Services Act. The event saw participation from over 300 advocates from across the United States, representing 39% of NACDS chain member companies and including representatives from 58 pharmacy schools. Lindholz emphasized Kroger Health's commitment to supporting their pharmacy teams through initiatives like Project Passion, which aims to enhance associate well-being and professional development, and highlighted the positive feedback from team members who participated in advocacy efforts for the first time. Additionally, Kroger Health's involvement in other NACDS RxIMPACT programs, such as the Congressional pharmacy tour program, has facilitated direct engagement with lawmakers to advocate for policy reforms beneficial to the pharmacy industry and healthcare provision.

title: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review and The Emerson Group collaborate to celebrate community pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review, and The Emerson Group are collaborating to honor the contributions of community pharmacy and the National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) on its 90th anniversary. A special event is scheduled for December 13 in New York City to celebrate the impact of industry leaders on community health care and the transformation of pharmacies into healthcare destinations over the past 90 years. Notable retailers like Walmart, HEB, Target, Amazon, Walgreens, Kroger, CVS, and Costco will participate. The event underscores the evolving role of retail pharmacy in U.S. healthcare and the importance of retailer-supplier relationships in enhancing patient and consumer care. The December issues of Drug Store News and Chain Drug Review will feature detailed reports on NACDS's history and achievements. Over 500 retailers and suppliers are expected to attend, with several receiving special recognition for their contributions to the industry and communities.

title: NACDS Foundation welcomes three new members to board of directors
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) Foundation announced the addition of three new members to its board of directors during the 2024 NACDS Annual Meeting. The new directors, Claire Biermaas from Cencora, Crystal Lennartz from McKesson, and Jackie Morse from Meijer, will serve a one-year term alongside re-elected veteran directors. The NACDS Foundation focuses on advancing solutions for pressing public health issues and is committed to healthcare transformation through pharmacy education and improving community health and wellbeing. The addition of Biermaas, Lennartz, and Morse is expected to enhance the Foundation's efforts in advancing health equity, access, and outcomes. The Foundation also anticipates its 26th annual dinner in Boston to further support its initiatives.

title: NACDS 2023 TSE Product Showcase
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The National Association of Chain Drug Stores' Total Store Expo 2023, from August 12-14 in San Diego, is a key event for healthcare industry retailers and suppliers. It presents new services and products in pharmaceuticals, health and wellness, and beauty. Highlights include Amici Pharmaceuticals' ophthalmic and oral solutions, Ascend Labs' vancomycin oral solution, Aurobindo Pharma's Timolol Maleate Ophthalmic Gel for glaucoma, and Bausch + Lomb's eye care innovations. Also featured are Boiron’s Arnicare Arthritis Cream, Camber Pharmaceuticals' generic drugs, Cotton Incorporated's 50th trademark anniversary, and Dr. Reddy’s Premama Wellness for women's health. Innovations in hydration from Liquid I.V., sleep aids from Hyland’s Naturals, and vitamins from Nature’s Bounty and Pharmavite are also showcased. This expo offers a significant chance to discover the latest industry innovations and trends.

title: Family Physicians with Value-Based Payment Models Relieve Burnout, According to Study from AAFP with Elation Health
summary: A study by the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) and Elation Health found that family physicians with 75% of their revenue from value-based payment (VBP) models experience less burnout compared to those relying on fee-for-service models. The research, which surveyed 10 primary care practices of various sizes, aimed to identify barriers and innovations for adopting VBP models and their effect on physician burnout. Key findings suggest that infrastructure investment, capitation models, and quality measures significantly impact burnout levels. Practices with capitated models and those with innovative contracts with payers reported less burnout. The study underscores the potential of VBP models to reduce administrative burdens and improve physicians' wellbeing while cautioning about the challenges of implementing these models. Elation Health, supporting the study, emphasizes the importance of tailored solutions to ease the transition to VBP models for primary care practices.

title: Dr. Bredbenner Receives 2024 American Academy of Family Physicians Foundation Family Medicine Leads Emerging ...
summary: Dr. Mackenzie Bredbenner, a Family Medicine Resident at Bayhealth, has been awarded the 2024 American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) Foundation Family Medicine Leads Emerging Leader Institute Scholarship. This opportunity allows her to connect with other medical professionals nationwide, enhancing her leadership skills and advocating for a holistic approach to patient care. Dr. Bredbenner credits her program director, Dr. Vasagar, and advisor, Dr. Bchech, for their encouragement to apply for the scholarship. She aims to use this experience to advance the specialty of Family Medicine and implement positive changes in her community, particularly in Delaware, to contribute to a healthier society.

title: KU School of Medicine-Wichita faculty members, student group earn national honors from American Academy of Family ...
summary: Faculty members and a student group from the KU School of Medicine-Wichita have received national recognition from the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP). Gretchen Irwin, M.D., MBA, and Mark Leiker, M.D., received the AAFP Exemplary Teacher of the Year Award for full-time and volunteer faculty, respectively. Irwin, an associate dean and associate professor, was acknowledged for her contributions to national curricula and leadership programs, and teaching excellence. Leiker, an alumnus and preceptor of the KU School of Medicine-Wichita, was praised for his clinical skills, compassionate care, and mentorship. Furthermore, the school's Family Medicine Interest Group was given the AAFP Program of Excellence Award for the fourth year in a row, recognized for its outreach efforts and influence in promoting family medicine. These awards highlight the school's dedication to outstanding medical education and community service.

title: 'Busy' doctors are now being told by leading medical group it's ok to use ChatGPT to ease workload
summary: A leading US medical group is encouraging doctors to use ChatGPT to manage their workload more efficiently. A recent study found that ChatGPT accurately interpreted and summarized medical studies 98% of the time, making it a useful tool for doctors to stay updated on the latest research across various specialties. The American Academy of Family Physicians believes ChatGPT can serve as an effective screening tool for clinicians. However, researchers caution against relying solely on ChatGPT summaries, especially in high-risk situations, due to rare but significant inaccuracies found in some summaries. Despite these concerns, the integration of AI in healthcare is growing, with many doctors already using it in their practice. This adoption comes amid rising burnout rates among physicians, with hopes that AI technology can alleviate some of the pressures leading to a shortage of doctors.

title: Clements Receives AAFP Family Medicine Award - News Center
summary: Deborah Clements, MD, has been awarded the American Academy of Family Physicians’ Thomas W. Johnson Award for her significant contributions to family medicine education. Clements, who is the Nancy and Warren Furey Professor of Family and Community Medicine and chair of the Department, has been recognized for her career contributions to family medicine, a field where many of her mentors have previously been honored. She has played a pivotal role in enhancing the impact of family medicine in medical education and clinical care, notably through her leadership in expanding postgraduate training in the Chicagoland area. Clements has also been instrumental in integrating the assessment of social determinants of health into patient care, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, through a program that is now implemented across the Northwestern Medicine health system. This initiative aims to connect patients with community resources to address factors like food insecurity and housing instability. Her work emphasizes health equity and the elimination of health disparities. Clements' efforts reflect her commitment to improving patient care and optimizing health outcomes through education and the addressing of social determinants of health.

title: How completing RUC surveys can help you financially
summary: Completing surveys from the American Medical Association/Specialty Society Relative Value Scale Update Committee (RUC) is essential for the financial health of medical practices. These surveys enable the RUC to suggest changes to the resource-based relative value scale to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), affecting Medicare’s physician fee schedule. CMS implements over 90% of RUC's recommendations, affecting Medicare payments, other payers' fee structures, and physicians' employment contracts. The surveys require healthcare professionals to assess the work for new or updated services in terms of time, intensity, and complexity. Participation by family physicians and other healthcare professionals is crucial, as their feedback directly influences payment structures, highlighting the significant role of RUC surveys in determining physician compensation.

title: Astria Therapeutics to Present at Upcoming American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology Annual Meeting
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Astria Therapeutics is set to present its final STAR-0215 Phase 1a healthy subject data at the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, & Immunology Annual Meeting in Washington, D.C., on February 23, 2024. Dr. William Lumry, a Clinical Professor of Internal Medicine at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Dallas, will showcase a poster on "Updated Results from a Phase 1a Trial of STAR-0215 for Hereditary Angioedema." Astria Therapeutics focuses on developing therapies for allergic and immunological diseases, with STAR-0215 being a monoclonal antibody inhibitor of plasma kallikrein for treating hereditary angioedema. Their second program, STAR-0310, targets atopic dermatitis and is in preclinical development.

title: Updated guidelines released for management of atopic dermatitis
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology/American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology issued updated guidelines for managing atopic dermatitis (AD), published on December 17 in the Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology. Derek K. Chu, M.D., Ph.D., and colleagues from McMaster University formulated 25 recommendations for controlling mild, moderate, and severe AD. These recommendations cover the optimal use of topical treatments, dilute bleach baths, dietary avoidance/elimination, allergen immunotherapy, and systemic treatments. Notably, the guidelines advise on shared decision-making and consider patient values and preferences as crucial for optimal recommendations. For uncontrolled AD despite moisturizer use, topical corticosteroids or topical calcineurin inhibitors are recommended, highlighting the safety of topical calcineurin inhibitors for typical use. Crisaborole 2 percent ointment is recommended for mild-to-moderate AD, while topical Janus kinase inhibitors and antimicrobials are not suggested unless necessary. Bleach baths are recommended for moderate-to-severe AD, but not for mild cases. Elimination diets and allergen immunotherapy are also discussed for specific AD conditions.

title: Aadi Bioscience Presents New Subgroup Analysis of Patients with Advanced Malignant PEComa of Gynecologic Origin ...
summary: Aadi Bioscience presented a new subgroup analysis of advanced malignant PEComa (perivascular epithelioid cell tumor) of gynecologic origin treated with nab-Sirolimus at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) Annual Meeting. This analysis, part of the AMPECT trial, showed that patients with gynecologic-origin PEComa experienced efficacy and safety consistent with the overall study population. The trial underpinned the FDA approval of nab-Sirolimus, FYARRO®, for advanced malignant PEComa regardless of mutational status. Over half of the evaluable patients in AMPECT had tumors of gynecologic or retroperitoneal origin. The subgroup had a 37.5% overall response rate to nab-Sirolimus, with responses being rapid and durable, and the safety profile was manageable. Additional data presented at SGO highlighted nab-Sirolimus as a potential approach for mTOR-driven gynecologic cancers. This includes a real-world study on TSC1 and TSC2 inactivating alterations in advanced gynecologic cancers, updates on the PRECISION1 trial, and a Phase 2 study of nab-Sirolimus with letrozole for advanced or recurrent endometrioid-type endometrial cancer (EEC).

title: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F) launch BRIDGES 2.0 Research ...
summary: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F), supported by the Foundation for Women’s Cancer (FWC), have launched the BRIDGES 2.0 Research Initiative. This initiative is a comprehensive two-year clinical trial education program aimed at developing the next generation of researchers in gynecologic oncology. It emphasizes advancements in clinical and translational research, trial methodology, and the execution of real-world clinical trials. Targeting early-career professionals like gynecologic oncologists, medical oncologists, and radiation oncologists, including senior fellows and faculty members with less than ten years of post-training experience, BRIDGES 2.0 offers essential insights into the basics of clinical trial design. The program invites applications from qualified individuals and provides training in grant writing, research funding, and scholarship opportunities. Its goal is to promote innovation, collaboration, and excellence in clinical trial research to improve the care and outcomes of women with gynecologic cancers. Applications are now open, with the program starting in July 2024.

title: ADCs May “Change the World” in Gynecologic Cancer Management
summary: The text discusses the potential impact of new antibody drug conjugates (ADCs) on the management of gynecologic cancers, particularly cervical cancer. Brian Slomovitz, MD, from the Mount Sinai Medical Center, highlighted the significance of these developments at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) 2024 Annual Meeting. He specifically mentioned the promising results of tisotumab vedotin-tftv (Tivdak) from the phase 3 innovaTV 301/ENGOT-cx12/GOG-3057 trial for treating metastatic or recurrent cervical cancer. The trial showed that tisotumab vedotin improved median overall survival and progression-free survival compared to the investigator's choice of chemotherapy. These findings suggest that ADCs like tisotumab vedotin could revolutionize the treatment approach for cervical and possibly other gynecologic cancers with high expression of tissue factor. Slomovitz also indicated ongoing research into other ADCs for ovarian and endometrial cancers, underscoring a broader impact on gynecologic cancer treatment.

title: Nonsurgical management of early-stage endometrial cancer due to obesity: a survey of the practice patterns of current ...
summary: A survey among the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) members found that the majority (71.8%) of gynecologic oncologists provide primary nonsurgical treatment for endometrial cancer in class 3 obesity patients (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2). Choosing nonsurgical methods, like hormonal therapy with a progesterone intrauterine device (preferred by 68.3% for nonsurgical treatment), is not greatly influenced by the doctor's location, practice type, or experience. The survey showed that a BMI of 60–64 kg/m2 is where most oncologists (65.2%) start considering nonsurgical treatment. Despite the common use of these methods, about one-third of respondents don't offer nonsurgical treatment for endometrial cancer solely due to obesity, underscoring the importance of more research to determine the safety and effectiveness of nonsurgical versus surgical treatment in these patients.

title: Dr. Katyayani Papatla joins Gynecologic Oncology Program at Smilow Cancer Hospital
summary: Dr. Katyayani Papatla has joined the Gynecologic Oncology Program at Smilow Cancer Hospital as an Assistant Professor of Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences. She will be serving patients in New Haven, Greenwich, and Stamford. Dr. Papatla earned her medical degree and a master's in public health from the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine. She completed her residency at Temple University Hospital and her fellowship in Gynecologic Oncology at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, where she received awards for her research. Her current research interests include health equity for gynecologic oncology patients. Dr. Papatla is also a member of the Society of Gynecologic Oncology Diversity, Inclusion, and Health Equity Committee.

title: Leveraging Biomarkers to Advance Endometrial Cancer Care
summary: Leveraging biomarkers in endometrial cancer care is becoming increasingly important, as emphasized by Ramez N. Eskander, MD, at the SGO 2024 Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer. Eskander highlighted the phase 3 NRG-GY018/KEYNOTE-868 trial, which showed the effectiveness of pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy in enhancing overall survival for patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer, regardless of mismatch repair status. This supports pembrolizumab's use as a primary treatment. Eskander underlined the growing importance of molecular biomarkers in directing cancer treatment, citing trastuzumab deruxtecan for HER2-positive cases as an example. The trend of identifying biomarkers that predict responses to new treatments is expected to continue, with ongoing clinical trials like the RUBY trial focusing on molecular characterization to guide future research in endometrial cancer management.

title: Gynecologic Oncology May Face a Future of Too Few Cases, Too Many Docs
summary: Gynecologic oncology may soon face a significant challenge with a potential oversupply of specialists relative to the number of new cancer cases. Teresa Boitano, MD, presented research at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology's annual meeting, predicting a 30% decrease in annual new cancer cases per gynecologic oncologist by 2045 if current training levels continue. This equates to an average of one new cancer diagnosis per specialist per week. This projection raises concerns about the sustainability of the current training model for gynecologic oncologists, especially as the subspecialty already experiences a shift towards performing more benign procedures, leading to an "identity crisis". The study suggests reevaluating fellowship numbers and training requirements to ensure specialists remain proficient, particularly as advancements like the HPV vaccine and neoadjuvant chemotherapy could further reduce the incidence of surgeries for cervical cancer. The findings underscore the need for strategic planning in gynecologic oncology training to maintain competency and adapt to evolving cancer care demands.

title: UPSHER-SMITH AND THE NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF STATE PHARMACY ASSOCIATIONS (NASPA) ANNOUNCE ...
hco: NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF STATE PHARMACY ASSOCIATIONS
summary: Upsher-Smith Laboratories, LLC and the National Alliance of State Pharmacy Associations (NASPA) have announced the recipients of the 2023 NASPA Excellence in Innovation Award. This award recognizes innovative pharmacists who have made significant contributions to pharmacy practice, leading to improved patient care or advancement of the profession. The award, sponsored by Upsher-Smith and overseen by NASPA, is presented by over 40 state pharmacy associations annually. Rich Fisher, President and COO of Upsher-Smith, emphasized the importance of acknowledging pharmacists who drive innovation in patient care. Krystalyn Weaver, PharmD, JD, Executive Vice President and CEO of NASPA, expressed gratitude for the partnership with Upsher-Smith and the state pharmacy associations in supporting the award. The announcement highlights the recipients from various states, acknowledging their innovative contributions to the field.

title: Ada professor receives national pharmacists award
hco: NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF STATE PHARMACY ASSOCIATIONS
summary: Karen Kier, a professor from Ada, Ohio, has received the 2024 Bowl of Hygeia Award from the Ohio Pharmacists Association. This award, backed by the National Alliance of State Pharmacy Associations and the American Pharmacists Association Foundation, honors pharmacists for their significant contributions to their communities. Kier has committed her career to education, mentorship, and involvement in pharmacy organizations, showcasing exceptional community service. She obtained her degrees from Ohio Northern University and The Ohio State University and is currently a Professor of Pharmacy Practice and Director of the Drug and Health Information Center at Ohio Northern University Raabe College of Pharmacy. Kier also participates in volunteer activities with Soroptimist International Kenton/Hardin County, Girl Scouts of Western Ohio, local school booster clubs, church groups, and offers training for Basic Life Support (CPR) and Advanced Life Support for various nonprofit organizations.

title: Stay ahead of allergies with these 7 expert tips - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: To effectively manage spring allergies, the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI) recommends starting allergy medications at least two weeks before symptoms typically begin, around mid-February. They provide seven expert tips for reducing exposure to allergens and alleviating symptoms: 1) Keep windows closed to prevent pollen from entering the home and use air conditioning to maintain airflow. 2) Use High-Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in air cleaners and HVAC systems to filter out allergens, ensuring they match the room size and are regularly changed. 3) Change clothes upon returning home to remove pollen and other allergens. 4) Shower before bed to wash off allergens from the body and hair. 5) Know your specific allergy triggers and when allergy season starts in your area to better avoid them. 6) Find the right medication, considering options like nasal sprays or allergen immunotherapy if antihistamines are ineffective. 7) Consult with an allergist for personalized management strategies and treatment. These steps can help individuals stay ahead of allergies and enjoy the spring season.

title: Gailen Marshall installed as ACAAI President
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Gailen Marshall, MD, PhD, from Jackson, MS, was officially installed as the president of the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI) during its Annual Scientific Meeting on November 12, 2023, in Anaheim, California. James Tracy, DO, from Omaha, NE, was elected as the president-elect. The ACAAI also announced other newly elected officers, including Cherie Zachary, MD, as vice president and Kelly Maples, MD, as treasurer. Additionally, Aikaterini Anagnostou, MD, Brian T. Kelly, MD, and Mervat Nassef, MD, were elected as regents for three-year terms. Dr. Marshall has been with the University of Mississippi Medical Center since 2004 and has significantly contributed to the field, including serving as editor-in-chief of the Annals of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology. Dr. Tracy, recognized for his contributions and service, has been practicing for 33 years and holds academic appointments in Nebraska. The ACAAI is a professional medical organization dedicated to improving patient care, education, advocacy, and research in allergy and immunology.

title: You Can Still Register for the 2023 ACAAI Annual Scientific Meeting in Anaheim!
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Registration for the 2023 Annual Scientific Meeting of the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI) is now open. The event will take place in Anaheim, CA, from November 9-13 at the Anaheim Convention Center. It will bring together allergists, pediatricians, researchers, and healthcare professionals from around the world to present and discuss groundbreaking studies and the latest findings on allergy and asthma treatments. The conference will showcase over 400 abstracts on a wide range of topics, such as new developments in mast cell disease, anaphylaxis, food allergy risk assessment, the future of biological treatments, and the patient experience with atopic dermatitis, with a particular focus on mental health discussions with allergists. Media can register in advance until October 27, with options for in-person attendance or online access to a Livestream of the meeting. Registration is free for journalists.

title: Spring Allergies Attack More Than Just Your Nose - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Spring allergies can affect more than just the nose, impacting the eyes, respiratory system, and skin as well. According to the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI), allergens like pollen and mold spores can trigger a range of allergic conditions, including asthma and eczema. Symptoms of nasal allergies include sneezing, itching, and congestion, while asthma sufferers may experience worsened symptoms like wheezing and difficulty breathing. Eczema can flare up due to allergens, and eye allergies may cause itching, redness, and watery discharge. To manage these symptoms, it's recommended to use medications such as antihistamines, nasal corticosteroids, and bronchodilators, avoid allergens, and consult an allergist for a personalized treatment plan, which may include allergen immunotherapy. This comprehensive approach aims to improve the quality of life for those affected by spring allergies.

title: Food Allergies in College 101: Tips to Cope
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Food allergies pose distinct challenges for college students, such as the danger of potentially fatal anaphylaxis. A review in the Annals of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology suggests methods for handling these challenges. Main advice includes being reassessed for allergies before college, preparing in advance for allergy management, learning to use epinephrine auto-injectors proficiently, and clearly communicating allergy requirements to others. College students with food allergies are at higher risk due to inadequate risk awareness and risky behaviors. The article highlights the significance of being prepared and communicating effectively to safely manage college life with food allergies.

title: Flaxseed allergy appearing more frequently – present in foods and other substances
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Flaxseed, known for its health benefits and used as an ingredient in foods and art supplies, is causing allergic reactions more frequently. At the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI) Annual Scientific Meeting, two cases were highlighted: an 18-month-old toddler developed a rash after consuming flaxseed in oatmeal, and an artist experienced severe contact dermatitis from flaxseed oil in paint. These instances underscore the need for awareness about flaxseed as a potential allergen. Diagnosis involved skin prick and patch tests, revealing sensitivities to flaxseed. The growing use of flaxseed in various products calls for further research into its allergenic properties and cross-reactivity with other substances.

title: New Year, New Resolutions to Keep Allergy and Asthma Symptoms Controlled - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: About 50 million people in the United States suffer from allergic conditions, and with the new year, the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) suggests resolutions to help control allergy and asthma symptoms. Recommendations include updating prescriptions and visiting an allergist, especially if appointments were missed due to COVID-19 disruptions. Vaccinations against flu, COVID-19, and Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) are advised, particularly for those with asthma and those at high risk. Mental health is highlighted as crucial for managing symptoms, with suggestions to try calming therapies like meditation. Home improvements to reduce allergens, such as removing old carpets or using HEPA vacuum cleaners, are recommended. Regular exercise, including pre-exercise asthma medication and indoor activities during cold weather, is also encouraged. ACAAI emphasizes the importance of consulting an allergist for proper testing and management of allergies and asthma, offering resources to find local allergists.

title: Study Shows Children with Private Insurance More Likely to Outgrow Food Allergies - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A study presented at the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) Annual Scientific Meeting reveals that children with private insurance are more likely to outgrow food allergies compared to those with public insurance. Specifically, 29% of privately insured children reported outgrowing their food allergies, in contrast to only 12% of publicly insured children. The research involved 188 children, predominantly male, with a racial composition of 51% Black, 32% White, and 16% Latinx. Milk and egg allergies were the most commonly outgrown. The average age at which children outgrew food allergies was five years. This study contributes to the understanding of how children from various racial backgrounds outgrow food allergies, highlighting the disparities in health outcomes based on insurance type.

title: Special Toothpaste May Lower Risk of Allergic Reactions for Adults with Peanut Allergy - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY AND IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A new study presented at the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) Annual Scientific Meeting shows that a special toothpaste for Oral Mucosal Immunotherapy (OMIT) can effectively desensitize adults with peanut allergies. This toothpaste introduces peanut proteins into the mouth, providing a focused and easy way to administer the treatment, which could help people stick to their treatment plan. The study involved 32 adults with peanut allergies, who were given either increasing doses of the peanut toothpaste or a placebo for 48 weeks. The results indicated that all participants treated with the toothpaste tolerated the highest dose without experiencing moderate or severe systemic reactions, mainly having mild and temporary local reactions like oral itching. The adherence rate to the treatment was 97%, with no one stopping the treatment because of the medication, showing OMIT as a safe and practical choice for adults with food allergies. The findings encourage further development of this toothpaste, particularly for children, with more long-term studies planned to assess its ability to provide lasting protection against accidental peanut exposure.

title: APhA announces results of 2024 Board elections
summary: The American Pharmacists Association (APhA) announced the results of its 2024 Board elections. Magaly Rodriguez de Bittner, PharmD, FNAP, FAPhA, from Pasadena, MD, has been elected as the 2025–2026 APhA president-elect. She will succeed Randy P. McDonough in March 2026 during the APhA Annual Meeting & Exposition in Los Angeles, CA. Additionally, Lieutenant Commander Neelam "Nelly" Gazarian, PharmD, MS, from Fairfax, VA, and Scott Tomerlin, PharmD, from Melbourne, FL, were elected to serve a 3-year term on APhA's Board of Trustees starting in March 2025. Anne L. Burns, BSPharm, RPh, from Great Falls, VA, was elected as the 2025–2026 honorary president. All officers will be installed at the 172nd APhA Annual Meeting & Exposition in Nashville, TN, in March 2025.

title: Rutgers Health Faculty Member Selected as an American Pharmacists Association Fellow
summary: Lucio Volino, a clinical professor and director of assessment at the Ernest Mario School of Pharmacy at Rutgers University, has been elected as a fellow of the American Pharmacists Association by its Academy of Pharmacy Practice and Management. This recognition is awarded to 10 fellows annually for their achievements in professional practice and outstanding service. Volino, who has been with Rutgers for 18 years, is honored for his contributions to pharmacy education and community health initiatives, including training students and pharmacists in immunizations and disease testing, and leading over 800 community outreach programs. His work also extends to clinical practice with the Barnabas Health Retail Pharmacy, where he focuses on patient-centered care and medication management services. Volino credits his success to the support of mentors, colleagues, students, family, and friends, and emphasizes the importance of investing in future generations within the pharmacy profession.

title: URI College of Pharmacy staff member is latest APhA Fellow – College of Pharmacy
summary: Matthew Lacroix, a staff member at the University of Rhode Island College of Pharmacy, has been named a Fellow by the American Pharmacists Association (APhA) for his exceptional professional achievements and service. Serving as the Director of Accreditation and Assessment, Lacroix has significantly contributed to the pharmacy profession through his roles in accreditation, education, and professional associations. With a 20-year career that includes positions as a pharmacist, professor, and advisor, he has also been instrumental in the College’s accreditation renewal efforts and has made lasting impacts locally and nationally through his involvement in various pharmacy organizations. His recognition as an APhA Fellow highlights his substantial contributions to pharmacy practice, research, education, mentoring, and advocacy.

title: Lucas Berenbrok was elected as an American Pharmacists Association Fellow
summary: Lucas Berenbrok, an associate professor at the University of Pittsburgh School of Pharmacy, was elected a Fellow of the American Pharmacists Association (APhA) by its Academy of Pharmacy Practice and Management. This prestigious recognition is limited to 10 fellows annually, awarded for exemplary achievements in professional practice and outstanding service in APhA and other organizations. Berenbrok, who holds secondary appointments in the School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences Department of Communication Science and Disorders, co-developed an educational program for community pharmacists on over-the-counter hearing aids. His contributions were acknowledged with the Provost’s 2019 Innovation in Education Award.

title: APhA's cybersecurity recommendations to secure the pharmacy ecosystem and patient safety
summary: The American Pharmacists Association (APhA) has issued cybersecurity recommendations to enhance the security of the pharmacy ecosystem and ensure patient safety. These recommendations were presented to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee during congressional hearings on the Change Healthcare cyberattack. APhA's proposals include mapping the pharmacy ecosystem to identify vulnerabilities, expanding accountability for protecting health information, increasing penalties for breaches, clarifying breach notification requirements, requiring backup systems, ending practices leading to market consolidation, incentivizing cybersecurity standards, establishing a federal cyber-insurance program, and funding cybersecurity in emergency preparedness. APhA aims to work with policymakers to prevent future incidents and maintain continuity of patient care.

title: These 11 doctors are moving medicine forward. Find out how.
summary: The AMA Foundation honored 11 physicians with the 2023 Excellence in Medicine Awards for their contributions to medicine through volunteerism, community engagement, leadership, and dedication to caring for underserved populations. Dr. John A. Johnson, a psychiatrist, was recognized for his extensive work in mental health care across three continents, including founding a mental health center and residential treatment facility. Lynn Jeffers, MD, received an award for her leadership and volunteerism in plastic surgery and her role in COVID-19 response efforts. Joshua Cohen, MD, MPH, was honored for his support of the AMA Foundation and his work in improving LGBTQ+ health care. Jeremy Toler, MD, and Carl Streed Jr., MD, MPH, were awarded for their excellence in LGBTQ health advocacy and care. Mollie Marr, MD, PhD, also received recognition for her efforts in LGBTQ health. Josef Machac, MD, was acknowledged for his volunteerism in providing medical care to those without access to health care in the U.S. Florence Jameson, MD, was celebrated for her work in helping underserved communities access health care. Caitlin Bernard, MD, MSCI, received an award for her advocacy in women's health. Warren Heffron, MD, was honored for his international service in medical practice, education, and research.
