Matthew Wynia, MD, MPH, received an award for his leadership in medical ethics and professionalism.

title: Physicians struggle to keep practices afloat after Change cyberattack
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) has reported significant challenges faced by physician practices following a cyberattack on Change Healthcare. The attack has severely disrupted operations, with 36% of surveyed practices experiencing suspended claim payments, 32% unable to submit claims, and 22% unable to verify patient eligibility for benefits. Smaller practices, particularly those with 10 or fewer physicians, have been hit hardest. Financial strains include 80% reporting lost revenue from unpaid claims, 85% needing to allocate more staff time and resources to revenue cycle tasks, and over half experiencing lost revenue from the inability to charge co-pays. As a result, 55% of respondents used personal funds to cover expenses, 44% couldn't purchase supplies, and 31% struggled to meet payroll. Despite these challenges, only 15% of practices have reduced their operating hours. The AMA emphasizes the dire need for support and reforms to address the fallout from this cyberattack and its impact on patient care and practice viability.

title: Joy in Medicine™ Health System Roadmap
summary: The Joy in Medicine™ Health System Roadmap, provided by the American Medical Association (AMA), is a comprehensive guide designed to enhance physician well-being and mitigate burnout within health systems. This roadmap outlines six pillars crucial for building a positive work environment: Assessment, Commitment, Efficiency of Practice Environment, Teamwork, Leadership, and Support. It emphasizes the importance of measuring physician well-being, organizational commitment to workforce well-being, improving operational efficiency, fostering effective teamwork, leadership development, and cultivating supportive connections among peers. The roadmap serves as a step-by-step guide for health systems to develop and implement well-being initiatives, offering tools, resources, case examples, and submission samples for organizations aiming to achieve Joy in Medicine recognition. This initiative underscores the AMA's advocacy for improving health care delivery by addressing systemic issues that impact physician satisfaction and patient care.

title: In ruling's wake, diversifying medicine requires upstream efforts
summary: The recent Supreme Court decision limiting race-conscious admissions poses significant challenges to diversifying the medical field, a crucial factor for advancing health equity in the U.S. This ruling affects higher education institutions' ability to consider race or ethnicity in admissions, impacting the diversity of the medical workforce. The American Medical Association (AMA) had advocated for maintaining race-conscious admissions, highlighting its effectiveness in achieving diversity. Drs. Sanjay Desai and David Henderson of the AMA emphasize the importance of a diverse physician workforce in eliminating health inequities and improving outcomes for marginalized populations. They advocate for upstream efforts to diversify medicine, starting well before high school, to address educational achievement gaps from early childhood. Despite the ruling, medical educators remain committed to diversifying the healthcare workforce to ensure it reflects the nation's diversity, which is essential for equitable care.

title: 19 VCU health sciences departments and schools ranked in top 50 for NIH funding for public institutions
hco: VIRGINIA COMMONWEALTH UNIVERSITY OFFICE OF SPONSORED PROGRAMS
summary: Nineteen health sciences departments and schools at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) are ranked in the top 50 for National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding among public institutions, highlighting VCU's rise as a biomedical research leader. These rankings, by the Blue Ridge Institute for Medical Research, show the university's major science and medicine achievements. VCU is now 47th among U.S. public research universities, with $464 million in research funding for fiscal 2023, including $118.9 million from the NIH, a 24% increase from last year. Departments like Pathology, the School of Nursing, and Microbiology have notably improved rankings due to more NIH funding. This success emphasizes VCU's dedication to enhancing health sciences research and innovation, benefiting the community and the broader science and medicine field.

title: UCF Professor Honored as Fellow of Gerontological Society of America
summary: UCF Professor Su-I Hou has been honored as a fellow of The Gerontological Society of America (GSA), recognizing her dedication and excellence in the field of gerontology. This prestigious title is the highest level of membership in the GSA, the world's oldest and largest interdisciplinary organization focused on aging research, patient care, and education. Hou, a faculty member at UCF’s College of Community Innovation and Education and the founding director of its School of Global Health Management and Informatics, is celebrated for her impactful work in healthy aging. Her research spans aging-in-community models, cancer screening disparities, global healthcare management, and HIV behavioral studies. Hou is committed to enhancing the quality of life for older adults through evidence-based practices and policies. She will be recognized at the GSA’s annual Scientific Meeting in Tampa, Florida, in November.

title: UNE's Marilyn Gugliucci elected president of The Gerontological Society of America
summary: Marilyn R. Gugliucci, a professor and director of geriatrics education and research at the University of New England College of Osteopathic Medicine, has been elected president of The Gerontological Society of America (GSA), assuming the role in January 2025. The GSA, founded in 1945 in New York City, is a multidisciplinary organization focused on aging research and education, encompassing medical, biological, psychological, and social sciences. Gugliucci has contributed to the GSA by helping to revamp its governance structure and implementing a new system where elected members serve in leadership and mentorship roles. She has also worked on creating student chapters of the GSA at colleges and universities both nationally and internationally. Gugliucci's presidency aims to address ageism, improve the well-being of older adults, and prepare future healthcare workers and researchers. She is known for her Learning by Living research project and her involvement in various boards and committees related to gerontology and health care.

title: VCU recognized as first Pharm.D. program of merit by the Academy for Gerontology in Higher Education
summary: Virginia Commonwealth University's School of Pharmacy Pharm.D. program has been named a Program of Merit by the Academy for Gerontology in Higher Education, becoming the first Pharm.D. program in the U.S. to earn this distinction. The honor recognizes the program's outstanding education in gerontology and geriatrics, largely due to a partnership exceeding 30 years with VCU’s Department of Gerontology in the College of Health Professions. This collaboration has introduced a dual degree Certificate in Aging Studies and a Geriatrics elective, as well as an Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience rotation. Faculty from the School of Pharmacy's Geriatric Pharmacotherapy Program have aligned the Pharm.D. program with AGHE's standards, focusing on the need to prepare students for the increasing demands of the aging population in the U.S. This award underscores VCU's dedication to training future pharmacists in geriatrics and gerontology.

title: COA Supports Bills to Ensure Access to Cancer Medications
summary: The Community Oncology Alliance (COA) has endorsed two bills aimed at ensuring seniors' access to essential cancer medications by challenging CMS' interpretation of the Stark Law, which has been used to restrict the mailing of oral medications by oncologists and urologists. The first bill, the Seniors’ Access to Critical Medications Act of 2023, introduced by a bipartisan group of U.S. Representatives, seeks to allow the delivery of medications by mail or courier and permit family members or caregivers to pick up medications without violating the Stark Law. The second bill, the Protecting Patient Access to Cancer and Complex Therapies Act, responds to the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022's impact on Medicare reimbursement rates, aiming to prevent cuts that COA argues would threaten the viability of community oncology practices. COA's actions, including a lawsuit against CMS, highlight concerns over access to care, especially for patients in rural areas or with transportation difficulties, and the financial sustainability of providing cancer treatments under current regulations.

title: Thought Leaders Converge at National Health Council Leadership Conference to Advance Care for Patients
summary: The National Health Council (NHC) 2024 Health Leadership Conference, titled "The Urgency of Now: Think Patient," took place in Scottsdale, AZ, from February 21-23. It gathered CEOs, senior executives, board leaders from top Patient Organizations, and Partners of Patient Organizations to discuss emerging health care policy issues. The conference aimed to drive patient-centered health policy by bringing together diverse organizations. Key topics included artificial intelligence and "the new normal" in health care, with discussions on creating next-generation patient-centered care. The event featured speakers such as Akilah Watkins, Sunita Mishra, and Brian Anderson, who shared insights on the future of health care, the role of AI, and the importance of including patient perspectives in health care decisions. Additionally, the conference explored advances in medical technology and the political outlook for the 2024 national election, emphasizing the influence of national politics on the health care system.

title: Leading Experts Examine Patient-Centered Health Care Across the Lifespan at National Health Council Science of ...
summary: The National Health Council's 2024 Science of Patient Engagement Symposium focused on patient-centered health care across all ages. Held at the National Press Club, the event gathered over 180 policymakers, researchers, patient advocates, and health care providers to discuss the importance of integrating patient perspectives in medical care. Speakers, including FDA's Namandjé Bumpus and Google's Kapil Parakh, emphasized the need for addressing unique health care needs through technology and AI, and engaging patients directly in research and treatment processes. The symposium aimed to identify barriers to patient engagement and develop best practices to ensure research results are applied equitably, highlighting the significance of considering diverse patient needs in the evolving health care landscape.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA HEARTLAND CHAPTER INC
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America offers comprehensive support and resources for those affected by lupus, including patients, caregivers, children, teens, and healthcare professionals. The organization conducts activities to raise awareness, provides educational programs, support groups, and services, advocates on behalf of those affected by lupus, and raises funds for research and education to improve the quality of life for everyone impacted by the disease. Support groups, available both virtually and in person across the United States, offer a safe environment for individuals to share experiences, seek advice, and find community. The Foundation also facilitates access to local resources, financial assistance, and medical referrals for diagnosis and treatment, aiming to assist anyone newly diagnosed or living with lupus, as well as their caregivers and healthcare providers.

title: Prevent Cancer Foundation to visit Comadre a Comadre in Albuquerque
summary: The Prevent Cancer Foundation and its Congressional Families Program will visit Comadre a Comadre in Albuquerque, which has received a $25,000 grant for its breast cancer education and navigation program for Hispanic/Latina women. The visit aims to highlight the project's work in providing culturally tailored education and support for early cancer detection and navigating women to screening appointments. The program, which plans to reach over 850 individuals, is part of the Foundation's broader efforts to support cancer prevention and early detection across the U.S. through community grants. These efforts include increasing education, risk reduction, vaccination, and screening for various cancers. The Prevent Cancer Foundation is committed to reducing cancer deaths by 40% by 2035 through investments in early detection technologies, community screening, and vaccination access, and public education on cancer prevention.

title: White House declares April 2024 as Cancer Prevention and Early Detection Month
summary: The White House has declared April 2024 as the inaugural National Cancer Prevention and Early Detection Month. This initiative, led by the Prevent Cancer Foundation with the support of 84 organizations, aims to expand access to cancer screenings, promote healthy life habits, and advance innovations to make cancer preventable, detectable, and beatable for everyone. President Joe Biden emphasized the lifesaving potential of early cancer detection and highlighted the administration's efforts to increase awareness and access to routine screenings and affordable care. The month-long awareness campaign will focus on educating the public, inspiring individual and organizational action, mobilizing resources for cancer prevention and early detection, and celebrating progress in cancer research. The Prevent Cancer Foundation is committed to reducing cancer deaths by 40% by 2035 through investments in early detection technologies, expanding access to screenings and vaccinations in underserved communities, and public education on screening and vaccination options.

title: Games Done Quick raises over $2.5 million for the Prevent Cancer Foundation at annual gaming marathon
summary: Awesome Games Done Quick (AGDQ) 2024 successfully raised over $2.5 million for the Prevent Cancer Foundation, marking a significant return to an in-person format after three years of virtual events. Held in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the event attracted 1,600 attendees and hundreds of thousands of viewers worldwide who watched top gamers speedrun their favorite games from January 14 to the early hours of January 21. The funds were primarily raised through small individual donations, totaling more than 36,000 contributions throughout the week. A notable highlight was a Shiba Inu named Peanut Butter completing a speedrun of the 1985 Nintendo Entertainment System game "Gyromite" in 26 minutes and 24 seconds, which helped boost donations. Over its decade-long support of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, AGDQ has funded new research, technologies, education, outreach, and community grants globally. The recent event's success underscores the gaming community's impactful role in advancing cancer prevention and early detection efforts.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) provides various resources and platforms for oncology professionals and patients. It includes ASCO Connection for member blogs and discussions, ASCO Daily News for conference reports, and a suite of journals for clinical oncology research. ASCO Practice Central offers guidance for navigating the oncology practice environment, while ASCO Education provides online, on-demand learning resources. CancerLinQ is a technology platform for learning from patient data to improve cancer care. Cancer.Net offers information for patients, and Conquer Cancer raises funds for research. The TAPUR Study explores targeted anticancer drugs based on genomic variants. Members can join state/regional affiliates for local involvement and advocacy, benefiting from professional development, networking, and continuing education.

title: New Treatments Redefine Asthma Care, Improve Patient Health
summary: New treatments are transforming asthma care, offering patients more personalized options beyond traditional inhalers, such as biologics. A paper by the Alliance for Patient Access, authored by Dr. J. Allen Meadows, emphasizes the importance of these innovative treatments in improving patient outcomes. However, access to these treatments is hindered by barriers like prior authorization, step therapy, exclusionary formularies by pharmacy benefit managers, and copay diversion programs. These obstacles not only delay treatment but also impose significant out-of-pocket costs on patients. The paper advocates for policies that reduce these barriers, highlighting the potential of the right treatment to decrease school absences in children, increase productivity in adults, and reduce emergency room visits, significantly enhancing the quality of life for asthma patients.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides support, education, and resources for individuals affected by lupus across the United States through a network of chapters, offices, and support groups. They focus on increasing awareness, providing educational programs and support services, advocating on behalf of those with lupus, and raising funds for research and education to improve the quality of life for people living with lupus. Support groups, available both virtually and in person, offer a platform for individuals with lupus, caregivers, and others affected to connect, share experiences, and find community support. The Foundation also encourages involvement in research, advocacy, and fundraising events to further the cause and support those affected by lupus.

title: Awards Scientists for Notable Contributions to Lupus Research | Lupus Foundation of America
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America (LFA) has honored two distinguished researchers for their significant contributions to lupus research during the 2023 Evelyn V. Hess Reception. Dr. Maria Dall’Era from the University of California, San Francisco, received the 2023 Evelyn V. Hess Award for her comprehensive research program aimed at improving the understanding and treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and lupus nephritis, as well as identifying biomarkers for these conditions. Dr. May Choi from the University of Calgary was awarded the 2023 Mary Betty Stevens Young Investigator Prize for her work on biomarker discovery and validation in autoimmune rheumatic diseases, focusing on lupus. These awards recognize their exceptional work and impact in advancing lupus research, with both awardees expressing gratitude and a commitment to continuing their efforts towards better understanding and treating lupus.

title: Latest Discoveries in Lupus Research Highlighted at ACR's 2023 Scientific Meeting
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The American College of Rheumatology's 2023 annual meeting showcased significant advances in lupus research, generating excitement in the global lupus community. The Lupus Foundation of America highlighted key research findings, including studies on factors influencing lupus diagnosis time, the effectiveness of a lupus self-care app, support from health education specialists, and strategies to increase minority clinical trial participation. Treatment advancements were reported, with promising results from therapies such as Anifrolumab, Azathioprine, CAR-T Cell therapy, Dapirolizumab pegol, Deucravacitinib, Ianalumab, Litifilimab, Obinutuzumab, Upadacitinib, and Voclosporin, showing significant improvements in lupus management. Additionally, studies focused on disease management, self-management skills, and the burden of cutaneous lupus erythematosus highlighted the importance of quality of life and patient engagement in treatment processes. Advanced technology and machine learning are being utilized to predict neuropsychiatric lupus events, while health disparities in lupus treatment and outcomes continue to be a critical area of research. The LFA remains committed to improving understanding, management, and treatment of lupus, aiming for better patient outcomes and ultimately a cure.

title: Research Accomplishments to be Presented at the 2023 American College of Rheumatology Annual Meeting | Lupus ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America (LFA) will showcase its research achievements at the American College of Rheumatology Convergence 2023 in San Diego, CA, from November 10-15, 2023. Highlights include results from the Research Accelerated by You (RAY®) patient and caregiver registry, the SELF self-care program, and the Health Education Specialist program. Significant findings reveal an average delay of over six years in lupus diagnosis in the U.S., with some groups facing longer waits. The SELF program demonstrated beneficial effects in lupus self-management, and over 2,450 individuals reached out to the LFA for assistance in 2022. The LFA is also working to enhance diversity in lupus clinical trials, showing increased awareness and engagement in Black/African American populations. Furthermore, an international survey underscored the substantial impact of cutaneous lupus erythematosus on quality of life. Eric Morand will introduce a new treatment response measure for systemic lupus erythematosus at the conference. The LFA will post updates from the event on social media.

title: Alicia H. - Diagnosed at age 23
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: Alicia H. was diagnosed with lupus at age 23, with severe symptoms affecting her lungs, heart, and joints, leading to a quick diagnosis. Initially, she thought she was having a heart attack because of heavy chest, difficulty breathing, and stiff, inflamed joints. After being rushed to the ER, tests showed a pleural effusion and pericarditis, suggesting lupus, confirmed by a rheumatologist two weeks later. Despite challenges, Alicia has managed her lupus with medication, family support, and her rheumatologist, maintaining her pharmacy industry career for nearly 10 years. She enjoys spending time with her husband, two cats, art, and anime. Alicia recently volunteered at the Walk to End Lupus event and became an advocate for the Lupus Foundation of America, aiming to spread awareness about lupus, a disease she feels is often overlooked.

title: The Role of Interferon Gene Signature in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The study examines the impact of the type 1 interferon gene signature (IFNGS) on systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), focusing on its influence on disease activity and clinical outcomes. It included 823 participants from 135 centers in 8 countries, monitored every six months for up to 3 years. Based on their gene signature, participants were divided into IFNGS-high or IFNGS-low groups. The results showed that Asian and Black participants were more likely to be in the IFNGS-high group than White participants. Those with a high IFNGS status were diagnosed at an earlier age and showed different patterns of organ involvement. They were also more prone to receive immunosuppressants and/or oral glucocorticoids and to experience hematological, immunological, and skin involvement. The study highlights the significant differences in characteristics and treatment strategies according to IFNGS status in SLE patients, emphasizing the importance of further research to explore the long-term effects of these baseline characteristics.

title: Lupus Awareness Campaign Empowers Black/African American and Hispanic/Latina Women to Stop Ignoring ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America has launched a rebranded Lupus Awareness Campaign titled "Be Fierce. Take Control.™" aimed at young Black/African American and Hispanic/Latina women, who are at a higher risk of developing lupus. This digital awareness initiative seeks to empower these women to recognize and not dismiss symptoms that could be indicative of lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause significant pain, inflammation, and tissue damage. The campaign features powerful imagery and stories of real women with lupus, encouraging those experiencing symptoms to consult healthcare providers for early diagnosis and treatment. Funded partly by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the campaign aims to reduce the average diagnosis time from six years to improve the quality of life and prevent long-term health consequences.

title: Catherine H. - Diagnosed at age 22
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GREATER OHIO CHAPTER
summary: Catherine H. was diagnosed with lupus at age 22 in January 2022, after experiencing a series of misdiagnosed symptoms and life-threatening conditions like pericardial effusion and pericarditis. Her journey to diagnosis was challenging, marked by a drastic shift from being an energetic athlete to struggling with basic tasks due to the unpredictable nature of lupus. Catherine's story highlights the difficulty in adjusting to a new way of life post-diagnosis, including accepting help and managing daily tasks. Despite the hardships, she finds joy in life and gratitude for the small things, supported by medication and a strong network of family and friends. Catherine emphasizes the importance of kindness, support, and not isolating oneself, expressing hope to offer encouragement to others facing similar battles.

title: The New York Jets Go on the Offense at the Lupus Research Alliance 2024 New Jersey "Walk with Us to Cure Lupus"
summary: The New York Jets participated in the Lupus Research Alliance 2024 New Jersey "Walk with Us to Cure Lupus" event at MetLife Stadium, aiming to raise $500,000 for lupus research and increase public awareness about the autoimmune disease. The event, which marks the beginning of Lupus Awareness Month, featured a variety of family-friendly activities, including Jets Fest inflatable rides and meetings with Jets players. The Lupus Research Alliance, with the support of various sponsors including Johnson & Johnson and PNC Bank, has invested over $245 million in lupus research, leading to the testing of more than a dozen potential treatments. The event emphasized the importance of diversity in clinical trials and the potential of engineered cell therapies for lupus treatment. The organization ensures that 100% of donations go directly to lupus research programs, thanks to its Board of Directors covering all administrative and fundraising costs. Participation in the walk was free, with the community encouraged to contribute through donations, advocacy, and involvement in research efforts.

title: With 'innovator award,' Iwasaki will explore possible cause of lupus
summary: Yale immunologist Akiko Iwasaki has received a grant from the Lupus Research Alliance to study the potential cause of lupus with the 2023 Dr. William E. Paul Distinguished Innovator Award. The award provides up to $1 million over four years for innovative lupus research. Iwasaki's research examines the theory that the immune system's response to viruses, especially endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) in our DNA, may initiate lupus. ERVs, which are remnants of ancient viral infections and make up about 8% of the human genome, could trigger autoimmune responses in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) by activating type I interferons and influencing the behavior of autoreactive T cells and B cells. Iwasaki's work aims to uncover how ERVs contribute to inflammation and autoimmune reactions, potentially leading to new treatments for lupus, a complex autoimmune disease affecting millions globally.

title: FDA launches Lupus Treatment Consortium in partnership with the Lupus Research Alliance
summary: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), in partnership with the Lupus Research Alliance (LRA), has launched the Lupus Accelerating Breakthroughs Consortium (Lupus ABC). This groundbreaking public-private partnership aims to tackle the challenges that have hampered the success of lupus clinical trials, a complex and potentially deadly autoimmune disease that mainly affects women and communities of color. By uniting people with lupus, medical societies, industry, academic clinical researchers, scientists, the FDA, and other federal bodies, the consortium aims to solve scientific problems that cannot be addressed by any single organization. The objective is to fast-track the creation of desperately needed lupus treatments by enhancing the evaluation of potential treatments and integrating patient-reported outcomes into the drug development process. Initially, the focus will be on improving measurement tools and refining patient-reported outcome measures to more accurately evaluate treatment effectiveness and its impact on patient-important symptoms.

title: CBS News New York partners with Lupus Research Alliance for New York City Walk to Cure Lupus
summary: CBS News New York has collaborated with the Lupus Research Alliance to host the New York City Walk to Cure Lupus, as part of their #BetterTogether campaign. The event, which took place on a rainy Saturday morning at the Intrepid, was emceed by CBS New York's Natalie Duddridge. Despite the weather, participants showed up with umbrellas to support the cause. Lupus, an autoimmune disease affecting millions globally, presents symptoms that often resemble other conditions, including severe fatigue, skin rashes, hair loss, and achy joints, and can lead to organ failure in severe cases. The walk successfully raised over $300,000, with all donations directly supporting lupus research programs.

title: Jets and Lupus Research Alliance to Host Lupus Awareness Day
summary: The New York Jets and the Lupus Research Alliance are set to host Lupus Awareness Day on December 3, 2023, during the Jets game against the Atlanta Falcons at MetLife Stadium. The event aims to elevate awareness about lupus, a severe autoimmune disease, and to gather funds for research towards new treatments and a cure. Activities include a 50/50 raffle, where proceeds will benefit the Lupus Research Alliance, and recognition of top fundraisers and lupus warriors during the game. The Jets are committed to supporting the Lupus Research Alliance, the leading private funder of lupus research worldwide, which has contributed over $245 million to research projects. The alliance ensures that 100% of donations go directly to research programs, thanks to its board covering all administrative costs. Lupus affects millions globally, predominantly women, especially during their childbearing years, and is more common in women of color. It causes the immune system to attack the body's own tissues, potentially damaging vital organs.

title: LRA awards scientists $600K for work into new treatments for lupus
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) has awarded $600,000 to seven scientists under its Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award (LMTA) for their work on new treatments for lupus. The funding, distributed over three years, aims to support research into molecular pathways or targets that could lead to improved therapies for the autoimmune disease. Three of the awardees are focusing on lupus nephritis, a kidney inflammation caused by lupus, while two are exploring novel therapeutic avenues based on disease mechanisms. One researcher is investigating lupus' impact on pregnancy, and another is working on engineering immune cells as a potential treatment strategy. The LRA's chief scientific officer, Teodora Staeva, highlighted the importance of these investigations in addressing the complex needs of lupus patients and potentially revolutionizing the field. The awarded research covers a range of innovative approaches, including the development of targeted therapies, understanding the role of specific proteins and genetic factors in disease progression, and exploring new treatment strategies for lupus-related conditions.

title: Lupus Research Alliance Announces Recipients of the Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) announced the recipients of the Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award (LMTA), providing up to $600,000 over three years for research into systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The award supports seven investigators focusing on identifying molecular pathways and targets for new or improved therapies. Their research ranges from investigating lupus nephritis and its severe complications, exploring the role of specific proteins and immune cells in SLE progression, to developing targeted treatments that spare healthy cells while eliminating disease-causing ones. This initiative aims to address the complex needs of individuals with lupus by advancing understanding and treatment options, with the ultimate goal of improving patient outcomes and quality of life.

title: Lupus Therapeutics, AbbVie partner for phase 3 trials of upadacitinib in SLE
summary: Lupus Therapeutics and AbbVie have partnered to conduct phase 3 trials of upadacitinib for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) treatment. Announced on October 26, 2023, this collaboration involves Lupus Therapeutics assisting with patient recruitment and trial site activation through the Lupus Clinical Investigators Network. Upadacitinib, marketed as Rinvoq, is approved in the U.S. for conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. This trial aims to expand its use to SLE, an autoimmune disease causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage. Financial terms were not disclosed. Lupus Therapeutics also partnered with Nkarta for developing a CAR NK candidate for lupus nephritis, aiming to enhance lupus treatment options beyond existing therapies like GSK’s Benlysta and AstraZeneca’s Saphnelo.

title: Indian-origin doctor is new chairman of International Myeloma Foundation
summary: S. Vincent Rajkumar, a renowned scientist, clinician, and researcher at Mayo Clinic, has been named the new chairman-elect of the International Myeloma Foundation (IMF), taking over from Brian G.M. Durie. Dr. Durie, a co-founder of the IMF who has chaired it for 33 years, will not run for re-election but will stay involved as Chairman Emeritus. Dr. Rajkumar was chosen unanimously, highlighting his extensive contributions to multiple myeloma research, including his roles on the National Cancer Institute Myeloma Steering Committee, as chair of the myeloma committee, and as editor-in-chief of Blood Cancer Journal. He has led crucial clinical trials for myeloma treatment that led to the U.S. approval of thalidomide and has written more than 480 peer-reviewed articles. His honors include the Jan Waldenstrom Lifetime Achievement Award, the Mayo Clinic Distinguished Investigator Award, and the Robert A. Kyle Lifetime Achievement Award. The IMF, established in 1999, is the foremost and largest global foundation dedicated to multiple myeloma, serving over 525,000 members across 140 countries.

title: 15th International Myeloma Foundation gala raises over $675K
summary: The 15th annual International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) gala, hosted by actor Ray Romano in New York City this April, successfully raised over $675,000. The funds are earmarked for advancing research into myeloma and supporting educational efforts related to the disease. The event was celebrated as a testament to the collaborative spirit within the myeloma community, emphasizing the importance of philanthropy in driving research and innovation towards finding a cure. Highlights included the participation of celebrities such as Tony Danza, Robert Klein, Patricia Heaton, and Alex Meneses, with a portion of the proceeds supporting the Peter Boyle Research Fund and the Black Swan Research Initiative, which aims at finding a definitive cure for myeloma. The gala also recognized contributions from various companies, including Johnson & Johnson and LatentView Analytics, and celebrated advancements in treatment, such as the expanded approval of CAR T-cell therapies Abecma and Carvykti for myeloma patients.

title: The International Myeloma Foundation and Black Swan Research Initiative® Announce the Release of New iStopMM ...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) and Black Swan Research Initiative® have released a study on a new method to decide if bone marrow tests are needed for people with MGUS. This approach uses easy-to-get lab results to see if someone has a high chance of having SMM or a more serious condition, which could help avoid unnecessary tests, save money, and make diagnosing MGUS more efficient. The study, based on data from Iceland, looks promising but needs more checking and shouldn't be the only thing doctors rely on.

title: Lifelong Philanthropist and 17-year Myeloma Survivor John O'Dwyer Elected to the International Myeloma Foundation's ...
summary: John O’Dwyer, a lifelong philanthropist and 17-year myeloma survivor, has been elected to the International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) Board of Directors. With a history of significant contributions to the IMF, including his foundational support for the Black Swan Research Initiative aimed at curing myeloma, O’Dwyer brings extensive experience from both the pharmaceutical industry and nonprofit sector. Having previously served on the IMF Board from 2010-2016, his re-election marks a continued commitment to advancing the mission and goals of the IMF. O’Dwyer's professional background includes over 32 years at Celanese Corporation and leadership roles in various nonprofit organizations, demonstrating a blend of business acumen and philanthropic leadership. Diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2007, O’Dwyer has since been an active participant in his treatment and an advocate for myeloma research and patient education. His election is seen as a significant asset to the IMF, with leaders expressing enthusiasm for his vision and dedication to finding a cure for myeloma.

title: FDA committee votes 12-0 for myeloma trial outcome measure –...
summary: A unanimous 12-0 vote by an FDA committee supports using minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity as an early outcome measure for accelerated approval of treatments in clinical trials for multiple myeloma. MRD negativity, indicating a very low number of cancer cells post-treatment, could allow for quicker approval of therapies by demonstrating likely benefits earlier than current survival outcome measures, which can take up to eight years. The recommendation, praised by researchers and supported by the International Myeloma Foundation, is non-binding, leaving the final decision to the FDA. This approach could significantly reduce the time to approve new treatments, benefiting patients sooner. The use of MRD negativity as an outcome measure also holds promise for accelerating therapy approval in other types of cancer, broadening its potential impact.

title: International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) Launches #MyelomaActionMonth for 2024 March Myeloma Action Month
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) has announced the launch of #MyelomaActionMonth for March 2024, aiming to raise awareness and take action for myeloma to bring hope to patients and care partners. Partnering with the Global Myeloma Action Network (GMAN), the campaign encourages the global myeloma community to share their stories of resilience and hope. Through personal stories and experiences, the campaign seeks to raise global awareness about the disease and strengthen the community's ties. IMF President & CEO Yelak Biru emphasizes the campaign's focus on empowerment, research acceleration, and breaking the silence around myeloma. GMAN, with the support of thirty myeloma patient organizations worldwide, will play a key role in this campaign by encouraging story sharing to build empathy and understanding of the disease. The IMF plans several events throughout March, including Facebook Live sessions with healthcare professionals and the March for Myeloma 5K. The campaign invites everyone to share their myeloma stories using the hashtag #MyelomaActionMonth to create a wave of awareness and support the IMF's mission of improving the quality of life for myeloma patients and working towards a cure.

title: International Myeloma Foundation Celebrates ODAC Meeting Outcome on Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) Testing ...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) celebrates a significant victory as the Oncologic Drug Advisory Committee (ODAC) unanimously voted in favor of using minimal residual disease (MRD) testing as an early endpoint for the accelerated approval of multiple myeloma drugs in clinical trials. This decision, a result of nearly a decade of research by the IMF and its collaborative research group, i2TEAMM, could lead to faster FDA approval of new treatments. MRD testing allows for the precise prediction of progression-free survival and overall survival in multiple myeloma patients, potentially speeding up drug approval processes that traditionally take 9-12 years. This development is seen as a huge win for the global myeloma community, promising to expand treatment options and improve the quality of life for patients with this form of cancer.

title: Dr. Daniel Geynisman Named New Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN--Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Daniel Geynisman has been appointed as the new Editor-in-Chief of JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. With a distinguished history of collaboration with NCCN and over 130 peer-reviewed publications, Dr. Geynisman, an Associate Professor and Chief of the Division of Genitourinary Medical Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center, brings a wealth of experience to the role. The appointment is celebrated by NCCN, highlighting Dr. Geynisman's contributions to cancer care and research, including his involvement in NCCN Guidelines Panels for Testicular Cancer and Wilms Tumor. Under his leadership, JNCCN aims to continue its mission of enhancing cancer care quality through high-impact research and sharing oncology knowledge. His tenure will begin with the June 2024 issue, succeeding Margaret Tempero, MD, and aiming to build on the journal's legacy of publishing significant research and guidelines in oncology.

title: NCCN updates treatment guidelines for high-incidence cancers
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has announced updates to its Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology, reflecting the latest advancements in cancer care. These updates, which include changes to the treatment guidelines for high-incidence cancers such as breast, colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers, are based on evidence-based expert consensus. The updates will be presented at the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference in Orlando, Florida, and online, highlighting the rapid progress in cancer treatment and the importance of keeping healthcare providers informed. The guidelines, which were downloaded over 15 million times in 2023, serve as a critical resource for clinicians worldwide. Key updates include new recommendations for adjuvant endocrine therapy in early-stage breast cancer, testing for POLE/POLD1 mutations in colorectal cancer, perioperative immunotherapy for non-small cell lung cancer, and new chemotherapy options for metastatic pancreatic cancer. The conference will also cover topics such as genetics, vaccination for cancer survivors, and the use of artificial intelligence in oncology.

title: NCCN Guidelines Support Goserelin for Ovarian Suppression in Breast Cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has updated its guidelines to recommend goserelin as an option for suppressing ovarian function in premenopausal patients with hormone receptor (HR)–positive breast cancer. The guidelines now endorse two dosages of goserelin: 3.6 mg injected under the skin every 4 weeks or 10.8 mg every 12 weeks, both recognized as effective for starting ovarian function suppression. This recommendation comes from various international studies, including a phase 3 trial that demonstrated the 10.8 mg dose is just as effective as the 3.6 mg dose in terms of progression-free survival (PFS) and objective response rate (ORR). Furthermore, a real-world study showed that the 10.8 mg dose given every 3 months resulted in a higher rate of estrogen suppression compared to the monthly 3.6 mg dose, with similar overall survival (OS), disease-free survival (DFS), and PFS rates over 5 years.

title: NCCN Policy Summit Encourages Conversation and Action on Sexual Health and Fertility Issues Faced by People with ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) hosted a policy summit focusing on the sexual and reproductive health impacts on cancer patients. The summit, led by NCCN's CEO Crystal S. Denlinger, aimed to address quality of life issues for cancer patients and survivors, emphasizing the importance of discussing sexual health, fertility, and treatment side-effects. Experts highlighted the lack of training among oncologists to talk about these issues with patients, stressing the need for incorporating sexual and reproductive health education into cancer care training. The event featured discussions on overcoming barriers to fertility preservation and the necessity of inclusive care considering gender identity, sexuality, and personal values. Speakers also examined the challenges posed by state laws and regulations on patient access to care, emphasizing the importance of equity and the need for multidisciplinary care. The NCCN plans to focus on advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion in the cancer workforce in its next summit.

title: National Comprehensive Cancer Network Awards Champions for Excellence and Outstanding Contributions in Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) announced its 2024 award recipients, honoring individuals and groups for their significant contributions to cancer care. The awards recognize those who have supported NCCN's mission of improving the quality of life for cancer patients. The recipients include the NCCN COVID-19 Vaccination Advisory Committee, receiving the Outstanding Contribution Award for their rapid development of vaccination recommendations for cancer patients. Darcie Green, awarded the Partners in Cancer Care Award, has been instrumental in advocating for Latino communities in cancer care. Dr. Shaji K. Kumar received the Excellence in Engagement Award for his leadership in the NCCN Guidelines Panel for Plasma Cell Neoplasms. Donna Black was named NCCN Employee of the Year for her role in supporting the NCCN Guidelines Program. These awards were presented at the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference in Orlando, Florida, acknowledging the awardees' leadership, commitment, and dedication to cancer care.

title: New Resource for Selecting Best Treatment Path for Young Children with Cancerous Tumors Published by NCCN
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has published its first set of treatment recommendations for neuroblastoma, a common childhood solid tumor cancer, usually found before age five. Annually, the U.S. sees over 700 cases, with research leading to over 90% survival rates for low and intermediate risk, and about 50% for high risk. The guidelines aim to better high-risk patient outcomes and reduce long-term treatment effects, providing risk stratification guidance and summarizing current treatments, including surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. They will be updated with new information and are part of 87 NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology, available for free.

title: GOSERELIN INCLUDED IN THE NATIONAL COMPREHENSIVE CANCER NETWORK® (NCCN) HEAD AND NECK ...
summary: Goserelin has been added to the National Comprehensive Cancer Network® (NCCN) Head and Neck Cancers Guidelines as a category 2B recommendation for some patients with recurrent, unresectable, or metastatic salivary gland tumors, when surgery or radiation therapy is not viable. This move by TerSera Therapeutics LLC stems from the results of two Phase 2 clinical trials and a retrospective analysis, assessing the effectiveness of goserelin in conjunction with either antiandrogens or immunotherapy. Although the U.S. FDA has not approved ZOLADEX® (goserelin implant) for treating salivary gland carcinoma, the studies indicated that the goserelin combination with other treatments was well-tolerated and showed initial signs of effectiveness. The safety and effectiveness of ZOLADEX for this particular use are yet to be confirmed.

title: Four States and Territories to Participate in NGA Healthcare Workforce Policy Academy
hco: NATIONAL GOVERNORS ASSOCIATION CENTER FOR BEST PRACTICES
summary: The National Governors Association (NGA) is set to collaborate with American Samoa, Oregon, Utah, and Wyoming in the Next Generation of the Healthcare Workforce Policy Academy, aimed at strengthening the healthcare workforce. Selected through a competitive process, these regions will participate in an eight-month initiative focusing on strategic planning and addressing healthcare workforce challenges, including provider shortages exacerbated by COVID-19. The Policy Academy will involve virtual meetings, development of strategic action plans, and ongoing technical assistance, including site visits. It aims to foster cross-agency collaboration, public-private partnerships, and the implementation of new initiatives to address the projected shortage of 139,940 physicians and the 41% increased demand for direct care workers by 2036. The Policy Academy runs from February to September 2024, with outcomes expected to enhance state healthcare workforce strategies significantly.

title: Research!America CEO urges UNMC to spread the importance of research
summary: Mary Woolley, president and CEO of Research!America, emphasized the importance of making health research relatable to the public during the inaugural Bob and Helen Bartee and Family Advocacy of Science Lectureship at the University of Nebraska Medical Center (UNMC). She highlighted the declining federal research funding and waning public confidence in research, urging UNMC's health science professionals to collaborate with elected officials and the public under the principle "I work for you." The event also celebrated the presentation of the Bartee Advocacy of Science Award to Dr. Mark Rupp, chief of infectious diseases at UNMC, for his commitment to community engagement. Woolley advocated for increased community engagement, normalization of science communication by students and faculty, and support for public engagement training. She offered tips for effective communication about science to non-scientists, stressing the importance of storytelling, avoiding jargon, and practicing conversations. Woolley's visit and the award presentation underscore UNMC's culture of advocacy and public engagement in science.

title: Opening Plenary: Molecular Advances Changing Cancer Research
summary: The Opening Plenary at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2024 highlighted the profound impact of molecular advances on cancer research. Christina Curtis and Keith T. Flaherty, who chaired the Program Committee, emphasized the integration of technology with basic science, translation, and clinical science to revolutionize cancer care. Aviv Regev discussed mapping millions of cancer cells to understand human disease better, highlighting the role of single-cell genomics and artificial intelligence (AI) in identifying new treatment strategies. Jakob Nikolas Kather demonstrated how AI could predict tumor responses and patient prognoses from histopathology slides. Benjamin Cravatt explored targeting proteins for drug development, using activity-based protein profiling to find new drug targets. Carolyn Bertozzi focused on targeting glycans on cancer cells to enhance immune responses, using bio-orthogonal chemistry to develop innovative cancer therapies. These presentations underscored the interdisciplinary approaches driving significant advancements in understanding and treating cancer.

title: Experts to Present Leading-Edge Research at the American Association for Cancer Research Annual Meeting 2024 ...
summary: Experts from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) are preparing to showcase their latest research at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2024 in San Diego, California, from April 5-10. The research to be presented will highlight key advancements in the field of cancer, including work on cancer metastasis, immunology, molecular biology, genetics, and the development of new drugs. Highlights include Vinod Balachandran, MD, discussing personalized RNA neoantigen vaccines for pancreatic cancer; Luis Diaz Jr., MD, on tracking residual disease in solid tumors; Dana Pe’er, PhD, on how cancer cells adapt and spread; and Jonathan Yang, MD, on the combined use of AZD1390 and radiation therapy for treating glioblastoma. Other sessions will debunk myths surrounding PSA testing, explore tumor ecosystems, and examine the evolutionary dynamics of whole-genome doubling in ovarian cancer. Selwyn M. Vickers, MD, FACS, President & CEO of MSK, will be recognized as one of the 30 international leaders elected to the prestigious Fellows of the AACR Academy Class of 2024 for his contributions to pancreatic cancer research.

title: Aadi Bioscience to Present Multiple Posters at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting ...
summary: Aadi Bioscience announced its participation in the 2024 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting in San Diego, CA, from April 5-10, 2024. The company, known for its focus on precision therapies for mTOR-driven cancers, will present multiple posters. One poster details the evaluation of nab-sirolimus in combination with fulvestrant or PI3K pathway inhibitors to overcome resistance in breast cancer cell lines. Another poster explores the correlation of nab-sirolimus tumor drug levels with improved tumor suppression in KRAS G12C non-small cell lung cancer xenografts treated with nab-sirolimus in combination with KRAS inhibitors. Aadi Bioscience, a commercial-stage biopharmaceutical company, has received FDA approval and commercialized FYARRO® for treating adult patients with locally advanced unresectable or metastatic malignant perivascular epithelioid cell tumor (PEComa). The company is also conducting clinical trials on nab-sirolimus for other mTOR-driven cancers.

title: BioIVT to Participate at the American Association for Cancer Research Annual Meeting 2024
summary: BioIVT, a leading provider of biospecimen solutions for drug and diagnostic development, announced its participation as an exhibitor at the 2024 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting in San Diego from April 5-10. The company aims to showcase its commitment to advancing cancer research through its extensive portfolio of high-quality, customizable biospecimen solutions. BioIVT offers a large inventory of ethically sourced tissues, biofluids, and primary cells, including DTCs, PBMCs, and Cancer-associated Fibroblasts, to support innovative cancer science and patient care. Additionally, BioIVT has expanded its capacity to deliver fresh human leukopaks in the UK and mainland Europe, enhancing its network of diverse, highly characterized donors. With 11 donor centers and 425 clinical sites globally, BioIVT provides reliable access to a broad pool of donors, ensuring quick collection, processing, and delivery of materials to support precision medicine research and improve patient outcomes.

title: Lilly Announces Details of Presentations at 2024 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting
summary: Eli Lilly and Company announced it will present preclinical data on agents targeting Nectin-4, KRAS G12D, and BRM (SMARCA2) at the 2024 AACR Annual Meeting in San Diego from April 5-10. The data includes a human anti-Nectin-4 antibody with a new topoisomerase I inhibitor, a potent, orally taken KRAS G12D inhibitor selective against wild-type KRAS, and a selective BRM (SMARCA2) inhibitor for BRG1 (SMARCA4) mutated cancers, developed with Foghorn Therapeutics. IND applications for all three are planned for 2024. The company aims to tackle major health issues, including diabetes, obesity, Alzheimer's, immune disorders, and hard-to-treat cancers, with its innovative discoveries.

title: Adela to Present Data from Tissue-Agnostic MRD Assay at the American Association for Cancer Research Annual ...
summary: Adela, Inc. announced its participation in the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2024, where it will present data from its tissue-agnostic minimal residual disease (MRD) assay. This assay is designed for monitoring and early detection of cancer through blood tests, utilizing Adela's proprietary genome-wide methylome enrichment technology. The data will showcase the assay's capability in predicting recurrence in both HPV-positive and HPV-negative head and neck cancers following treatment. Additionally, the analytical performance of Adela's platform will be discussed. Daniel De Carvalho, Ph.D., Adela's Chief Scientific Officer, will chair a Plenary Session and present on new liquid biopsy technologies. Adela plans to commercialize its MRD monitoring product in 2025, aiming to improve treatment decisions across the cancer care continuum.

title: Elevation Oncology to Present Preclinical Proof-of-Concept Data for HER3-ADC Program at the American Association ...
summary: Elevation Oncology announced its plan to present preclinical proof-of-concept data for its HER3-targeting antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) program at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2024. The data underline the ongoing development of the ADC program aimed at treating HER3-expressing cancers. The company is on track to nominate a development candidate in 2024. David Dornan, Ph.D., Chief Scientific Officer, highlighted the clinical validation of HER3 as an oncology and ADC target, noting its overexpression in various solid tumors and association with poor clinical outcomes. Elevation Oncology aims to share data showcasing progress towards developing a differentiated HER3-ADC, with the goal of improving patient outcomes. The presentation details include the session title "Antibody-Drug Conjugates," with the abstract number #3121, scheduled for April 8. Elevation Oncology focuses on developing selective cancer therapies for solid tumors with unmet medical needs, with its lead candidate EO-3021 targeting Claudin 18.2 in a Phase 1 study for advanced solid tumors.

title: Sapience Therapeutics Presents Three Posters at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual ...
summary: Sapience Therapeutics presented three posters at the AACR Annual Meeting 2024, showcasing data on its peptide therapeutics for cancer treatment. The presentations included non-clinical immunotherapy results for ST316, a β-catenin antagonist, and ST101, a C/EBPβ antagonist, alongside preclinical results for JunAP, an AP-1 complex antagonist. ST316 was highlighted for its potential to modify the tumor immune microenvironment and is currently in a Phase 1-2 study for advanced solid tumors. ST101, in a Phase 2 study for glioblastoma, was shown to promote an immune-active tumor microenvironment. JunAP demonstrated effectiveness against cancer cell growth and invasion in triple negative breast cancer and melanoma models. These findings support the therapeutic promise of Sapience's SPEARs™ in targeting difficult-to-drug cancer pathways.

title: Aadi Bioscience to Present New Non-clinical Data Highlighting Combinability of nab-Sirolimus at the American ...
summary: Aadi Bioscience is set to present new non-clinical data at the AACR Annual Meeting, highlighting the combinability of nab-Sirolimus for enhancing anti-cancer effects and overcoming resistance in hormone-driven and non-small cell lung cancers. The data support clinical exploration of nab-Sirolimus in combination with endocrine therapy for endometrioid-type endometrial cancer in a Phase 2 trial. Studies show nab-Sirolimus enhances the cytotoxic effects of fulvestrant in breast cancer cells and, when combined with PI3K pathway inhibitors, can overcome resistance mechanisms. Additionally, nab-Sirolimus showed greater intratumoral concentration and mTOR target suppression when paired with KRAS G12C inhibitors in lung cancer models, suggesting improved clinical outcomes. Aadi Bioscience focuses on developing therapies for cancers with mTOR pathway alterations, leveraging nanoparticle albumin-bound technology with sirolimus. The company has FDA approval for FYARRO® for malignant PEComa and is investigating nab-Sirolimus in various Phase 2 trials for mTOR-driven cancers.

title: National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) Announces 2024 Rare Impact Award Honorees, Emmy Award ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) will celebrate the 2024 Rare Impact Awards on June 8 in Universal City, California, hosted by Emmy Award-winning journalist and NBC News Chief White House Correspondent, Peter Alexander. This event acknowledges the significant contributions of individuals, industry leaders, and companies towards improving the lives of the 30 million Americans living with rare diseases. The honorees include pioneers in genetic research, patient advocacy leaders, and innovative biotech companies that have developed FDA-approved treatments significantly enhancing patient outcomes. Among the awardees are Yann Le Cam for his advocacy in rare diseases, the Hemophilia Foundation of Southern California for community engagement, Representatives Gus M. Bilirakis and Liz Reyer for policy changes, Dr. Jose Abdenur for medical and scientific advancements, and community champions like Jana Monaco, Irfan Patel, Darlene Shelton, and youth champion Abigail Villarreal for their dedication to the rare disease community. The awards ceremony will follow NORD's Living Rare, Living Stronger Patient and Family Forum, providing educational programming for those affected by rare diseases.

title: Cytokinetics Joins Global Initiative to Recognize International Rare Disease Day
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: Cytokinetics has announced its participation in the global initiative to recognize International Rare Disease Day alongside the European Organisation for Rare Diseases (EURORDIS) and the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD). This initiative aims to raise awareness and improve public understanding of rare diseases, highlighting the challenges faced by over 300 million people worldwide living with a rare disease. Cytokinetics is committed to advancing treatments for rare diseases, including obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and to promoting health equity and access to education, support, clinical trials, and care for those affected by rare diseases. Rare Disease Day is observed annually on the last day of February in over 80 countries to advocate for better access to diagnosis, treatment, care, and social opportunities for people with rare diseases.

title: Pharming to be honored as Industry Innovator at National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD®) 2024 Rare Impact ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: Pharming Group N.V. will be honored as an Industry Innovator at the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD®) 2024 Rare Impact Awards for its work in commercializing Joenja® (leniolisib), a first-of-its-kind treatment for activated phosphoinositide 3-kinase delta syndrome (APDS). This recognition comes after the U.S. FDA approved Joenja® for adults and pediatric patients 12 years and older, making it the first and only treatment for APDS in the U.S. The award highlights Pharming's contribution to the rare disease community, given that 95% of rare diseases currently lack therapy options. The approval of Joenja® is seen as a significant advancement for the approximately 500 individuals in the U.S. with APDS, a condition characterized by frequent infections, lymphoproliferation, and autoimmunity. NORD's CEO, Peter Saltonstall, praised Pharming for its innovative approach to treating this rare condition. Pharming's Chief Commercial Officer, Stephen Toor, expressed pride in providing a treatment option for those living with APDS and looked forward to celebrating the achievement with the APDS community.

title: National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) Releases Annual State Report Card, Revealing Trends in Rare ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) released its annual State Report Card, evaluating U.S. states on their support for rare disease patients, focusing on healthcare coverage, access, and affordability. Key findings include the prevalence of inadequate short-term health plans in half of the states, leading to higher costs for comprehensive insurance. Twenty-two states received C grades for limited protections against high out-of-pocket prescription drug costs, with Idaho, Nevada, and Pennsylvania scoring F for lacking any protections. While 10 states have not expanded Medicaid, affecting access to healthcare for many, Georgia and North Carolina made positive strides by expanding access last year. NORD emphasizes the importance of establishing Rare Disease Advisory Councils (RDACs) to address these issues, noting progress with three more states enacting RDAC legislation in 2023, bringing the total to 27. NORD aims to further advocate for rare disease policies and encourages involvement in its Rare Action Network.

title: NORD Expands Advocacy And Support For Rare Disease Patients And Industry
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) is intensifying its advocacy and support for rare disease patients and the biopharmaceutical industry. With over four decades of experience, NORD is focusing on accelerating orphan drug development and enhancing access to treatments through policy reforms and programs. It's leveraging advancements in science, such as genome sequencing and cell and gene therapies, to address the evolving needs of rare disease patients. State-level policy work is expanding, with NORD encouraging more engagement with drug developers. The organization highlights the significant growth in available therapies for rare diseases, from fewer than 40 in 1983 to over 880 today, though noting that less than 5% of known rare diseases have an FDA-approved treatment. NORD is also expanding its Rare Disease Advisory Councils (RDACs) and Rare Disease Centers of Excellence (COEs) to improve diagnosis, treatment, and research. Additionally, NORD is fostering collaboration with the biopharmaceutical industry to ensure patient access to therapies, exemplified by its partnership with Takeda to address treatment gaps and improve patient care standards.

title: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS HOSTS 2023 BREAKTHROUGH SUMMIT
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) is hosting the 2023 Breakthrough Summit from October 15-17 in Washington, D.C., focusing on the challenges faced by the 30 million Americans living with a rare disease. The event will gather over 800 advocates, pharmaceutical companies, regulators, and scientific and medical leaders to discuss critical issues in rare disease patient care and drug development. With more than 7,000 known rare diseases, 95% of which lack an FDA-approved treatment, the summit aims to tackle topics such as the impact of the Inflation Reduction Act, gene editing, AI, equitable access to care, and mental health needs. The summit will feature key figures like Peter Saltonstall, CEO of NORD, and Robert Califf, MD, Commissioner of the U.S. FDA, among others. Rare diseases are a significant public health challenge, with diagnosis often taking five years or more and medical costs being substantially higher compared to non-rare diseases.

title: National Organization for Rare Disorders Launches Education Series to Advance Patient Involvement in Rare Disease ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) launched an educational series titled "Rare Disease Drug Development: What Patients and Advocates Need to Know," in both English and Spanish, aimed at enhancing patient involvement in the drug development process for rare diseases. Developed in collaboration with the FDA and the Critical Path Institute, the series addresses educational needs and gaps identified by patient organizations, advocates, and FDA reviewers. It features a variety of formats including animated videos, expert interviews, and interactive quizzes, covering topics such as the drug development process, stakeholder roles, and natural history studies. The first modules are now available for free, with more to be released in 2024. This initiative underscores the importance of patient and advocacy group participation in research to develop treatments for the over 7,000 rare diseases that largely lack FDA-approved treatments.

title: National Organization of Rare Disorders (NORD) Announces 2023 Rare Impact Award Honorees
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization of Rare Disorders (NORD) has announced the honorees for its 2023 Rare Impact Awards, set to take place on May 4, 2023, at the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery in Washington, DC. This event, marking NORD's 40th Anniversary, will celebrate individuals and organizations that have made significant contributions to the rare disease community. Among the honorees are NORD's founder Abbey S. Meyers, former U.S. Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler, New York Yankees centerfielder Bernie Williams, and clinical geneticist Dr. Ada Hamosh. These awards will also recognize a patient advocacy group focused on diversity, equity, and inclusion, as well as six industry innovators for their FDA-approved treatments for rare diseases. The ceremony aims to honor those who have advanced care, advocacy, and research for rare diseases, reflecting the pioneering spirit of NORD's founders. Tickets and registration are available at rareimpact.org, with early booking recommended due to limited space.

title: Mallinckrodt Recognized as Industry Innovator at National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) 2023 Rare Impact ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: Mallinckrodt plc, a global specialty pharmaceutical company, was honored with an award from the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) at the 2023 Rare Impact Awards, recognizing it as an "Industry Innovator" for its development of TERLIVAZ® (terlipressin). This medication is the first and only FDA-approved treatment for adults with Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS) involving rapid reduction in kidney function, a life-threatening condition requiring hospitalization. Approved on September 14, 2022, TERLIVAZ® represents a significant advancement for patients with HRS, offering a new treatment option where limited ones existed before. The award highlights Mallinckrodt's commitment to addressing the needs of rare disease patients and acknowledges the company's efforts in bringing innovative treatments to the market.

title: National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) Names Pamela K. Gavin as CEO
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: Pamela K. Gavin has been appointed as the new CEO of the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD), taking over from Peter L. Saltonstall, who has been in charge since 2008 and is retiring but will stay on in an advisory capacity. NORD was founded in 1983 and is a leading nonprofit organization for rare diseases, with over 340 member organizations. Gavin, who joined NORD in 2012 as its first COO, has initiated major projects such as the NORD Rare Disease Centers of Excellence, which includes 40 top medical centers. She has also spearheaded the development of IAMRARE®, the Rare Disease Cures Accelerator, and RareLaunch®. Her work has broadened NORD's services, especially its RareCare® assistance programs, which have provided nearly $175 million in aid over the past five years. Gavin is committed to raising awareness of rare diseases as a significant public health issue, focusing on enhancing care, diagnosis, and the development of treatments. Her background is in healthcare safety and delivery, and she has an MBA in Healthcare Management from Northeastern University and a BA in Biology from Smith College.

title: The Galactosemia Foundation and National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) Jointly Publish First "Voice of the ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The Galactosemia Foundation and the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) have jointly published the first "Voice of the Patient" report for the galactosemia community. This report compiles experiences of patients and caregivers with galactosemia, a rare metabolic disease without approved treatments. It aims to inform the FDA and researchers to aid in developing therapies for improving the health and well-being of those affected. The report follows an Externally Led Patient-Focused Drug Development meeting, marking a significant step in advocacy and highlighting the need for innovation in treatment. Galactosemia, potentially fatal in newborns, leads to serious complications across all life stages, underscoring the urgency for treatment options. The report and a recording of the meeting are available for public access, representing a critical resource for the FDA and others in the medical and research communities.

title: National Organization for Rare Disorders Announces More Than $100,000 in Grant Funding Available for Rare ...
hco: NATIONAL ORGANIZATION FOR RARE DISORDERS INC
summary: The National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD) has announced the availability of over $100,000 in grant funding for research on rare diseases. Three new Request for Proposals (RFPs) have been opened for researchers focusing on Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM), Levy-Yeboa Syndrome (LYS), and Megacystis Microcolon Intestinal Hypoperistalsis Syndrome (MMIHS). These grants are supported by the Tyler James Abizeid Foundation, the Maxwell Family, and the MMIHS Foundation, offering up to $35,000, $40,000, and $30,000 respectively. The deadline for initial applications is October 16. NORD’s Research Grants Program aims to provide seed money for scientific and clinical research in areas with limited funding sources. Since 1989, NORD has awarded over 200 grants totaling more than $9 million, leading to two FDA-approved treatments and numerous peer-reviewed publications. This initiative is part of NORD's broader mission to improve care and treatment for the 25-30 million Americans living with a rare disease.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA SOUTHEAST FLORIDA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides comprehensive support for those affected by lupus, including patients, caregivers, children, teens, and healthcare professionals. It offers support services, financial aid, educational programs, and opportunities to participate in research. The foundation has a network of chapters, offices, and support groups throughout the US, engaging in awareness, education, and fundraising for research and education to enhance the life quality of lupus patients. Support groups, both virtual and in-person, serve as a platform for sharing experiences and receiving support. The foundation advocates for lupus patients to further research and improve healthcare policies and encourages community engagement through fundraising and advocacy events. Its website is a resource for finding local support groups, accessing information on lupus, and connecting with the lupus community.

title: Diet And Nutrition With Lupus
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA SOUTHEAST FLORIDA CHAPTER
summary: Eating healthy can significantly impact lupus symptoms and overall health, without requiring a specific "lupus diet." A balanced diet for those with lupus includes a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. For individuals with lupus nephritis, dietary adjustments might be necessary. It's advised to consult a doctor or a registered dietician for personalized nutritional guidance. Vegetarian or vegan diets are acceptable, but vitamin B12 supplementation is necessary for those avoiding animal products. While some believe foods like alfalfa and garlic may exacerbate lupus symptoms, evidence is lacking, and dietary triggers can vary greatly among individuals. A healthy diet also supports bone and heart health, crucial for lupus patients at higher risk for heart disease and osteoporosis. Limiting sodium, saturated fats, and added sugars is recommended to manage or prevent additional health issues like high blood pressure and diabetes. Moderation in alcohol consumption is important, especially since alcohol can interact with lupus medications.

title: The Lupus Sisters: Walking for a Cure
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA SOUTHEAST FLORIDA CHAPTER
summary: Maria and Vivian, sisters affected by lupus, have become active in raising awareness and funds for lupus research through their participation in the Walk to End Lupus Now events. Maria was diagnosed with lupus nephritis in 1992, and years later, Vivian received the same diagnosis along with a coagulation disorder. Despite the challenges, including Maria's initial fear of infertility which was overcome leading to the birth of her healthy daughter, and Vivian's kidney failure which necessitated dialysis and a subsequent transplant, the sisters have been motivated to support others battling lupus. They formed a team named the Lupus Sisters, growing it to over 40 members and raising significant funds for research and development of a cure. Their efforts extend beyond the walks, involving community fundraising and advocacy during Lupus Awareness Month. The sisters emphasize the importance of never giving up in the face of lupus and continue to fight for a cure.

title: School of Pharmacy Team Wins National AMCP Competition for the Second Year in a Row - UConn Today
summary: A team from the UConn School of Pharmacy won the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) National Student Pharmacist Pharmacy & Therapeutics (P&T) Competition for the second consecutive year. The event took place at the AMCP Annual Meeting in New Orleans on April 16th. The winning team, consisting of Gianni Contrera, Ryan Shan, Huiqiao (Melinda) Fan, and Janette Wadolowski, excelled in presenting their case to a simulated P&T Committee, demonstrating superior skills in clinical and economic evidence analysis, cost-benefit assessments, and business insights in the pharmacy field. Their preparation involved drafting a detailed monograph that included literature search, economic analysis, and recommendations for a drug to be included in an insurance formulary plan.
