UConn competed against 47 other schools and their victory highlights the School of Pharmacy’s commitment to excellence in education and preparing students for the challenges of modern healthcare.

title: Mallinckrodt Presents Latest Health Economics Data on Acthar® Gel (Repository Corticotropin Injection) at the ...
summary: Mallinckrodt plc presented new health economics data on Acthar® Gel (Repository Corticotropin Injection) at the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) Nexus 2023, focusing on its cost-effectiveness for treating advanced symptomatic sarcoidosis and its impact on clinical, economic, and real-world outcomes in patients with nephrotic syndrome. The data highlighted Acthar Gel's potential benefits over standard care, showing favorable cost-effectiveness ratios from both payer and societal perspectives over two and three years for sarcoidosis treatment. Additionally, a study on nephrotic syndrome patients treated with Acthar Gel showed significant reductions in corticosteroid use and dosage, although there was an increase in dialysis but no change in renal transplants or complications compared to other therapies. These findings underscore Acthar Gel's value in treating autoimmune and chronic inflammatory conditions, supported by robust clinical evidence and health economics research funded by Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals.

title: Award-Winning Poster Presentations From AMCP 2024
summary: At the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) 2024 annual meeting, several poster presentations were recognized for their contributions to the field, focusing on topics such as health equity, data collection, glucagon-like peptide-1 agonists, and more. These presentations were evaluated based on originality, relevance, clarity, bias, and quality, with awards given in platinum, gold, silver, or bronze categories. Key highlights include a study on linking electronic medical record patient cohorts with consumer social determinants of health (SDOH) data, which showed significant insights into disease-specific patient cohorts beyond demographic data. Another notable presentation detailed the benefits of continuous glucose monitors (CGMs) in diabetes management, demonstrating significant improvements in glycemic control. Additionally, the impact of Zolgensma, a novel gene therapy for spinal muscular atrophy, was showcased, revealing a significant reduction in healthcare utilization among treated patients. Other presentations covered the cost-effectiveness of glucagon-like peptide-1 agonists in treating nondiabetes obesity and the financial burdens associated with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), highlighting the substantial costs and the potential for therapies that slow disease progression to alleviate financial burdens.

title: Optimizing Patient Care in Atopic Dermatitis: The Role of Ruxolitinib and Educational Initiatives for Managed Care ...
summary: At the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy (AMCP) 2024 annual meeting, two significant studies on atopic dermatitis (AD) were presented, focusing on ruxolitinib cream monotherapy and educational initiatives for managed care professionals. Ruxolitinib, a selective Janus kinase inhibitor approved in the US in 2021, was shown to potentially reduce the use of corticosteroids and biologics in patients with moderate to severe AD who had previously used advanced therapies. The study involving 749 patients indicated a 50% reduction in claims for common first-line AD therapies and a significant decrease in oral corticosteroid use post-treatment with ruxolitinib. Additionally, an educational initiative aimed at managed care professionals demonstrated significant improvements in understanding AD's burden and associated conditions, indicating the potential for enhanced patient care through informed best practices. These findings underscore the importance of both innovative treatments and educational efforts in optimizing care for AD patients.

title: AI, ML Can Mitigate Risks, Improve Efficiency Across Managed Care Space
summary: At the AMCP Nexus conference, a session highlighted the application of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) in managed care, demonstrating their potential to mitigate risks and enhance efficiency. AI and ML are being utilized for various purposes including managing new initiatives, monitoring pharmacy claims, and improving customer service. The session provided real-world case studies showcasing the successful implementation of these technologies in managed care practices. These included using ML to correct insulin co-pay errors in compliance with state laws, implementing NADAC pricing methodology to avoid costs, ensuring adherence to new plan designs, and monitoring COVID-19 testing mandates to minimize waste. Despite the promise of AI and ML, concerns about model accuracy persist, emphasizing the importance of human oversight to ensure correct operation.

title: Find support near you
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America offers support, resources, and education to those impacted by lupus, their caregivers, children, teens, and healthcare professionals. It provides support services, health education, financial aid resources, and programs. The foundation raises awareness, offers educational programs and support groups, advocates for those with lupus, and funds research and education to improve life quality for lupus patients. It hosts both virtual and in-person support groups for sharing experiences and finding community support. Furthermore, it participates in research advocacy, fundraising, and advocacy summits to promote the cause, and supports lupus research to enhance scientific knowledge and treatment.

title: Lupus Foundation of America Drives Nationwide Effort to Make Lupus Visible During Lupus Awareness Month
summary: During Lupus Awareness Month in May, the Lupus Foundation of America is set to unite communities to increase awareness and support for lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease affecting millions globally. This initiative aims to shed light on the disease's impact, promote understanding, and raise funds for research, education, and support services. Lupus, which can cause inflammation, pain, and damage to any organ system, is often misunderstood and underdiagnosed, especially since many of its symptoms are not visibly apparent. The disease disproportionately affects women and individuals from specific racial and ethnic backgrounds. Activities throughout the month include sharing lupus stories and resources, focusing on various aspects of the patient journey, and a National Lupus Advocacy Summit in Washington, DC, to advocate for increased funding and better care. The Lupus Foundation of America encourages participation through various means, including social media engagement, fundraising events, and donations, to help make lupus visible and support those affected.

title: HHS Awards $1.9 Million for a National Lupus Outreach and Clinical Trial Education Initiative
summary: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Office of Minority Health (OMH) has awarded over $1.9 million in grants to four organizations as part of its National Lupus Outreach and Clinical Trial Education Initiative. This initiative, running from September 30, 2023, to September 29, 2026, aims to improve clinical trial diversity and reduce health disparities among racial and ethnic minority individuals with lupus by identifying and sustaining effective interventions. The effort addresses the challenges of recruiting participants from these communities for lupus clinical trials by decreasing barriers to recruitment and enrollment, tackling patient mistrust, and increasing awareness of clinical trials' benefits. Lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease predominantly affecting women aged 15 to 44, especially African American women, leads to inflammation and potential permanent tissue damage. The initiative underscores the importance of clinical trials in developing new treatments for lupus.

title: New Investigational Drug for Systemic and Cutaneous Lupus Advancing to Phase I Clinical Trials
summary: Ventus Therapeutics Inc. has developed VENT-03, a pioneering investigational drug targeting cGAS, a receptor implicated in systemic and cutaneous lupus as well as various neuroinflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases. This marks the first time a drug of this kind is entering Phase I clinical trials. The development of VENT-03 has been supported by a Lupus Research Program Idea Award from the U.S. Department of Defense, facilitated by advocacy from the Lupus Foundation of America, which led to the establishment of the DoD Lupus Research Program in 2017. This program has since allocated over $76 million towards lupus research. The Lupus Foundation of America continues to provide updates on VENT-03 as part of its mission to support lupus research and treatment advancements.

title: Boulder Valley biz, gov leaders join Colorado BioScience Association industry outreach effort – BizWest
summary: The Colorado BioScience Association has launched the Colorado Hub for Health Impact, a coalition of almost two dozen groups including businesses, cities, and economic development organizations, many from Boulder Valley, to advance Colorado's biotech industry globally. This campaign, a state-first large-scale joint effort, aims to draw new life-science firms, professionals, and funding to Colorado. The 22-member group will act as the biotech sector's marketing branch, help companies seeking to move or grow in the state find sites, and aid in obtaining incentives and investments. The initiative emphasizes the U.S. 36 corridor between Denver and Boulder as a key biotech center, hosting about a third of the state's biotech firms and research bodies. This move highlights Colorado's cooperative economic development strategy, prioritizing statewide progress over local rivalry, and points out significant investments in labs and flexible office spaces to support major life-science entities.

title: New Consortium Launches Colorado Hub for Health Impact, a National Economic Development Campaign to Attract ...
summary: The Colorado Hub for Health Impact is a newly launched national economic development campaign aimed at positioning Colorado as a leading center for life sciences innovation. Spearheaded by a consortium of over 20 life sciences organizations, economic development groups, local governments, developers, and builders, the initiative seeks to attract high-growth health innovation companies to the state. Highlighting Colorado's strengths, such as its innovation talent, central location, robust infrastructure, collaborative community, reasonable costs, and quality of life, the campaign underscores the state's thriving life sciences community known for its research, development, and commercialization efforts with global patient impact. The partnership, which includes a diverse group of stakeholders, is focused on fostering collaborations and breakthroughs in the health sector, aiming to make Colorado a world-class hub for health innovation.

title: Record levels of funding propel Denver-Boulder to the top of the life sciences market
summary: The Denver-Boulder region is rapidly becoming a major center for the life sciences sector, thanks to a mix of venture capital and government investment, a cooperative research atmosphere, and an increasing demand for laboratory space. This region is drawing firms that are working on cutting-edge medical treatments and technologies. A significant factor in this development is BioMed Realty's purchase of a large complex in Boulder, which it plans to transform into laboratory and technology space to fulfill the growing need. The area's qualified workforce in life sciences is rising much quicker than the national rate, with a 35% increase over the last five years. This expansion is fueled by a robust investment environment, with the Colorado Bioscience Association reporting a notable rise in funding for early-stage companies. The success of the Denver-Boulder area is also linked to its tradition of research and innovation, making it a desirable spot for life sciences firms and startups.

title: Innosphere Ventures, Colorado BioScience Association, and Colorado BioScience Institute Announce the Colorado ...
summary: Innosphere Ventures, Colorado BioScience Association, and Colorado BioScience Institute have announced the selection of eight startup and scaleup companies for the 2023 Colorado Life Sciences Incubation Program. This initiative, supported by state funding from Colorado's Office of Economic Development and International Trade, aims to leverage the expertise and resources of the three organizations to provide a comprehensive support system for life sciences startups. The program offers access to Innosphere's incubation program, CBSA's resources and networking opportunities, and the Institute's leadership programs. The 2023 cohort includes companies like Live Fully, Anzen Pharmaceuticals Corporation, and EnteroTrack, among others, focusing on a range of innovations from healthcare solutions to pharmaceuticals. This program underscores Colorado's commitment to becoming a leading bioscience hub, fostering innovation, creating jobs, and supporting the development of life-saving technologies.

title: Colorado wants to be No. 1 destination for life sciences companies - Denver Business Journal
summary: Colorado is actively working to become the top destination for life sciences companies through a new campaign named the Colorado Hub for Health Impact. This effort emphasizes the state's strengths, such as a highly educated workforce, strategic location, and a track record of successful fundraising, to draw more companies to the region. The campaign builds upon ongoing statewide initiatives to generate high-paying, skilled jobs, particularly in advanced manufacturing and quantum technology. With the life sciences sector in Colorado already experiencing significant growth, including exceeding $1 billion in fundraising for the seventh straight year in 2023, leaders see this as the perfect time to enhance the state's role in health innovation. The endeavor involves nearly two dozen organizations, including the Metro Denver Economic Development Corp. and the Fitzsimons Innovation Community, working to utilize federal funding and the state's existing infrastructure to increase job opportunities and attract additional life sciences businesses.

title: Amos Espinosa Wins American Society of Hematology Minority Hematology Graduate Award
summary: Amos S. Espinosa, a PhD candidate in Experimental Pathology at Yale School of Medicine, has been awarded the American Society of Hematology (ASH) Minority Hematology Graduate Award. This recognition is part of ASH's Minority Recruitment Initiative, aimed at encouraging students from underrepresented communities in the United States and Canada to pursue careers in academic hematology. The award, which provides a $40,000 annual stipend for two years, supports graduate students conducting hematology-focused research. Espinosa's research delves into the molecular mechanisms of cancer development, specifically investigating the leukemogenic mechanism of a rare subtype of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia caused by the RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. Born in the Philippines and having immigrated to California in 2009, Espinosa has progressed through an impressive academic journey, culminating in his current research efforts under the mentorship of Diane Krause, MD, PhD, at Yale. This award will aid Espinosa in advancing his understanding of a rare pediatric leukemia and contribute to the development of targeted treatment strategies.

title: Halia Therapeutics to Present New Preclinical Data at the 65th American Society of Hematology (ASH) Annual Meeting ...
summary: Halia Therapeutics announced it will present new preclinical data at the 65th American Society of Hematology (ASH) Annual Meeting & Exposition in San Diego, California, from December 9-12, 2023. The company will showcase its clinical programs targeting chronic inflammatory and neurological diseases by inhibiting the NLRP3 inflammasome. Halia will display three posters featuring positive data on its lead asset, HT-6184, a drug candidate that targets the protein NEK7 to inhibit NLRP3 inflammasome activity, showing promise in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) indications. The presentations aim to highlight Halia's novel approach and foster collaborations in the hematology field.

title: Genmab Announces Multiple Abstracts to be Presented at the 65th Annual Meeting and Exposition of the American ...
summary: Genmab A/S announced it will present multiple abstracts at the 65th Annual Meeting and Exposition of the American Society of Hematology (ASH) in San Diego, California, and virtually from December 9-12. The presentations will include 18 abstracts in total, with results from four clinical trials on epcoritamab across various treatment settings and patient populations. Key highlights include oral presentations on epcoritamab in relapsed/refractory (R/R) diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and a real-world analysis of R/R large B-cell lymphoma (LBCL). Additionally, initial data from a trial on investigational cancer immunotherapy GEN3014 (HexaBody-CD38) will be presented. Genmab will also host a virtual R&D Update and ASH Data Review on December 12. The accepted abstracts underscore Genmab's commitment to developing epcoritamab as a core therapy for B-cell malignancies, in collaboration with AbbVie.

title: City of Hope scientists present promising new research at ASH annual meeting
summary: City of Hope scientists shared new findings on blood cancer treatments at the ASH annual meeting in San Diego. Their research focused on blood-cancer immunotherapies, personalized DNA vaccines, and strategies to prevent relapse and resistance in CAR T cell therapy. Highlights include a study on BAFFR signaling in B cell tumors, showing promising results with BAFFR CAR T cells in a Phase 1 clinical trial; a Phase 1b/2 study on the bispecific antibody mosunetuzumab combined with polatuzumab vedotin for relapsed lymphoma, showing significant response rates; a clinical trial on a personalized DNA vaccine for asymptomatic lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, indicating slowed cancer growth; and a study on liso-cel CAR T therapy for chronic lymphocytic leukemia and small lymphocytic lymphoma, demonstrating efficacy in treatment-resistant cases. Additionally, research on a chimeric antibody targeting leukemic stem cells in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) showed potential for improved treatment outcomes. These studies highlight City of Hope's commitment to advancing blood cancer treatment.

title: Keros Therapeutics to Present at the 65th American Society of Hematology Annual Meeting and Exposition
summary: Keros Therapeutics, Inc. announced its participation in the 65th American Society of Hematology Annual Meeting and Exposition, where it will present five abstracts from its hematology program. These presentations will showcase additional results from two ongoing Phase 2 clinical trials of KER-050, targeting patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and myelofibrosis. The presentations aim to demonstrate the potential benefits of KER-050 in treating these conditions by modulating TGF-β superfamily signaling, reducing iron overload, and increasing bone-specific alkaline phosphatase in lower-risk MDS patients. KER-050, the lead protein therapeutic candidate, is designed to treat cytopenias, including anemia and thrombocytopenia, in MDS and myelofibrosis patients. Keros is focused on developing treatments for disorders linked to dysfunctional signaling of the TGF-ß family of proteins, with a portfolio that also includes KER-047, KER-012, and KER-065 targeting various conditions.

title: Reimagine Care and CU Innovations Announce Poster Presentation at American Society of Hematology Annual ...
summary: Reimagine Care and CU Innovations announced their participation in the 2023 American Society of Hematology (ASH) Annual Meeting and Exposition with a poster presentation titled “Design of a Patient-Centered Approach to Manage Bone Marrow Transplant Patients and CAR-T Cell Therapy in a Home Setting.” This presentation highlights the results of a clinical study conducted in partnership with the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, focusing on the feasibility and acceptability of using remote patient monitoring (RPM) and digital health technologies for providing oncology care at home. The study found that RPM was both feasible and well-received by patients, making them feel more cared for and enabling early intervention for side effects from treatments like cytotoxic chemotherapy and immunotherapies. Reimagine Care, known for its virtual and in-home cancer care, and CU Innovations, aim to improve patient experiences by integrating innovative technologies and clinical expertise to offer timely support and proactive symptom management. This approach aligns with evolving patient preferences for convenient, real-time communication with their care teams, underscoring the potential of virtual care and RPM in enhancing cancer care delivery.

title: Foresight Diagnostics Presents Four Presentations and Two Posters Demonstrating Accuracy and Utility of PhasED ...
summary: Foresight Diagnostics showcased the precision and utility of its PhasED-Seq™ ctDNA platform for early response assessment in cancer treatment at the 65th American Society of Hematology Annual Meeting. The company presented four presentations and two posters, emphasizing the platform's superior sensitivity and prognostic accuracy for detecting minimal residual disease (MRD) in lymphoma patients compared to the current standard-of-care imaging methods. This breakthrough could potentially shift clinical response assessment from reliance on radiographic imaging to ctDNA measurements, offering earlier and more accurate indicators of treatment response. The research involved collaborations with various partners, including Bristol Myers Squibb and ADC Therapeutics, among others. Additionally, six more studies using the PhasED-Seq platform were reported, further supporting its effectiveness in MRD detection. This advancement is seen as a significant step towards more personalized treatment approaches for cancer patients.

title: Court to weigh patient drug dispute in case involving Publix
summary: An appeals court will hear a case this month involving Publix and insurers versus a state agency and doctors about rules for dispensing medications to injured workers. The dispute centers on whether workers’ compensation insurers must reimburse physicians for dispensing medications directly to patients, a practice opposed by Publix and the insurers who argue that only pharmacies should handle this. The Florida Department of Financial Services, supported by various medical associations, upheld rules allowing healthcare providers to dispense these medications. The case, stemming from disagreements over the workers’ compensation system's operation, touches on broader issues of cost, safety, and the balance of power between insurers, healthcare providers, and patients. Insurers argue physician dispensing could increase costs and health risks, while medical associations defend the practice, suggesting the legislature should address policy concerns. Arguments are scheduled for January 16.

title: Colleyville, TX couple encourages flu vaccine after toddler dies
summary: A couple from Colleyville, Texas, Joe and Jennifer Lastinger, are advocating for flu vaccinations following the death of their 3-year-old daughter, Emily, from an influenza infection in 2004. At the time, the CDC did not recommend flu shots for healthy children of her age, and she was not vaccinated. The couple's tragic loss has motivated them to support Families Fighting Flu, an organization that promotes awareness about the dangers of influenza and the importance of vaccination. Their advocacy aligns with the CDC's observation of "National Influenza Vaccination Week" to encourage vaccinations ahead of the busy Christmas travel season, emphasizing that flu shots are safe and effective for most adults and children over 6 months. Cook Children's Medical Center in Fort Worth noted a decrease in flu cases compared to the previous year, highlighting the ongoing risk and unpredictability of flu season severity.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GEORGIA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides support for individuals affected by lupus through its national network, including chapters, offices, and support groups across the United States. It focuses on raising awareness, providing educational programs and services, rallying support for those affected by lupus, advocating on their behalf, and funding research and education to improve quality of life. The Foundation offers virtual and in-person support groups, resources for diagnosis and treatment, and specialized groups catering to diverse communities and needs, such as the newly diagnosed, caregivers, children, teens, and healthcare professionals. Additionally, it encourages involvement through donations, fundraising events, advocacy efforts, and spreading awareness to help solve the challenges of lupus.

title: Diet And Nutrition With Lupus
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GEORGIA CHAPTER
summary: Eating a balanced diet can greatly affect lupus symptom management and overall health, including the prevention or control of conditions such as high blood pressure or diabetes. Although there is no specific diet for lupus, it is advised to include a variety of healthy foods. This means eating lots of fruits and vegetables, choosing whole grains, opting for healthy proteins, and picking foods high in healthy fats. For those with lupus nephritis, dietary changes might be needed, and seeking advice from a registered dietitian can help. Vegetarian or vegan diets can also work well for lupus patients, provided they consider taking a vitamin B12 supplement. It's crucial to avoid alfalfa because it contains a chemical that could activate lupus symptoms. Keeping bones and heart healthy is important, which includes consuming foods rich in calcium and Omega-3 fatty acids. While some lupus patients may require supplements, consulting a doctor is vital due to possible interactions with lupus medications. Reducing intake of sodium, saturated fats, and added sugars is beneficial in managing or preventing issues like high blood pressure and diabetes. Moderate drinking is recommended, as alcohol can affect how lupus medications work.

title: Lupus Symptoms
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GEORGIA CHAPTER
summary: Lupus is a disease that affects various parts of the body, leading to a wide range of symptoms. Common signs include extreme fatigue, joint pain or swelling, swelling in hands, feet, or around the eyes, headaches, low fevers, sensitivity to sunlight or fluorescent light, and chest pain when breathing deeply. Skin and hair problems such as a butterfly-shaped rash on the cheeks and nose, hair loss, mouth or nose sores, and Raynaud’s Disease (fingers and toes turning white or blue and feeling numb when cold or stressed) are also common. Symptoms of lupus can fluctuate and change over time. It is important to consult a doctor for a proper diagnosis, as lupus shares symptoms with other diseases like arthritis and diabetes. The correct diagnosis ensures appropriate treatment.

title: Awards Five Summer Fellowship Grants to Young Scientists, Supporting Growth of Lupus Research Field | Lupus ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GEORGIA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America has awarded five Gina M. Finzi Memorial Student Summer Fellowship Grants to young scientists for 2023. This program aims to foster the development of the lupus research field by providing funded research opportunities to exceptional undergraduate, graduate, and medical students under mentorship. The 2023 recipients will explore various crucial aspects of lupus research, such as cutaneous lupus, lupus during pregnancy, strategies for patient and clinician communication, cognitive impairment, and insights into the disease and potential treatments. They will receive guidance from seasoned mentors, highlighting the program's importance in nurturing future lupus researchers and promoting the advancement of the next generation in this field. Initiated in 1984, the fellowship commemorates Gina M. Finzi, the late daughter of former Lupus Foundation of America President Sergio Finzi, and offers not just research funding but also mentorship to help shape the recipients' future goals in lupus research.

title: Awarded Grant to Continue to Increase Black/African American Participation in U.S. Lupus Clinical Trials | Lupus ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA GEORGIA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America (LFA) has received a three-year grant from the Office of Minority Health at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, with funding up to $500,000 annually, to increase Black/African American participation in lupus clinical trials. This initiative builds on the success of a 2021 grant that led to the IMPACT+ Program, aimed at enhancing clinical trial enrollment among Black/African American women, who are disproportionately affected by lupus. IMPACT+ seeks to identify and implement effective communication strategies to increase interest and participation in clinical research within this community. The program will also expand the LFA’s Lupus Research Action Network (LRAN), offering education and training on clinical trials to increase research participation. This effort is part of a broader mission to reduce lupus-related health disparities and improve care for the Black/African American lupus community. The project runs from September 30, 2023, to September 29, 2026, marking the third OMH grant awarded to the LFA in seven years for addressing lupus health disparities.

title: American Kidney Fund's New Know Your Kidneys Program Provides Roadmap to Better Kidney Health
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has expanded its Know Your Kidneys program to offer comprehensive, interactive resources for individuals at risk of or living with kidney disease. This initiative aims to guide them from prevention through to post-transplant care. The program is designed to provide a personalized experience, helping users understand their kidney health, the causes of potential kidney diseases, and create a management plan. It emphasizes the importance of knowledge in preventing and managing kidney disease, offering tools and information for better health outcomes. The program specifically addresses health equity and the impact of kidney disease on communities of color, who are at a higher risk for end-stage kidney disease (ESKD). It includes interactive tools for personalized kidney health reports and guidance on discussing kidney disease causes and management plans with healthcare providers. Supported by Otsuka America Pharmaceutical, Inc., Travere Therapeutics, and Novartis, the program's resources are available on the AKF website.

title: VA and American Kidney Fund partnership - VA News
summary: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the American Kidney Fund (AKF) are working together to improve healthcare for Veterans with chronic kidney disease (CKD), which is more common in Veterans than in the general population. Over 40,000 Veterans registered with the VA have kidney failure, and around 600,000 have CKD. This partnership aims to improve healthcare resources via the VHA’s National Center for Healthcare Advancement and Partnerships (HAP). The effort will be overseen by the VHA Office of Kidney Medicine. The AKF focuses on fighting kidney disease and helping those affected at all stages, emphasizing health equity, financial aid, and educational resources. The partnership has provided financial support to over 6,000 Veterans and raised awareness through the Know Your Kidneys campaign, part of a larger effort to offer the best care and support for Veterans managing kidney disease.

title: AKF Releases 2024 American Kidney Fund Report Card
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has released its 2024 State of the States: Living Donor Protection Report Card, assessing all 50 states and the District of Columbia on their legal backing for living organ donors. It grades states on seven aspects of donor protection, like antidiscrimination laws, job-protected leave, tax benefits, and direct payments. The report highlights living kidney donation as the optimal choice for those needing a kidney, but notes six states got an F for lacking donor protections, with only three states earning an A. It points out the big differences in donor support depending on location, especially affecting rural areas, and urges better state laws to aid living organ donors and improve kidney disease care.

title: American Kidney Fund Awards Fellowships to Researchers Studying Acute Interstitial Nephritis and Pulmonary ...
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has awarded Clinical Scientist in Nephrology (CSN) fellowships to Dr. Kavita Mistry and Dr. Marcelle Tuttle for their research in kidney disease. Dr. Mistry, at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, focuses on using single cell sequencing technologies to study acute interstitial nephritis, particularly in cancer patients undergoing immunotherapy. Her goal is to develop non-invasive diagnostic tests and treatments with fewer side effects. Dr. Tuttle, from the Tufts Medical Center Division of Nephrology, investigates the development of pulmonary hypertension in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients, aiming to identify new risk factors and potential treatments. Both projects aim to improve the care and outcomes of kidney patients, addressing the high incidence of pulmonary hypertension in CKD patients and the side effects of cancer immunotherapy on kidneys. Their fellowships are supported by a grant from the Hearst Foundations, contributing to AKF's efforts in fighting kidney disease through research and support for early-career scientists.

title: Doctors raising awareness for new genetic kidney disease
summary: LaVarne Burton and Dr. Silas Norman are working to raise awareness about a newly discovered genetic kidney disease known as APOL1 mediated kidney disease (AMKD), particularly among communities at higher risk. This disease, identified only 14 years ago, involves mutations in the APOL1 genes that significantly increase the risk of rapidly progressing kidney disease, potentially leading to kidney failure. It's estimated that 13% of African Americans carry these mutations, highlighting a significant health equity issue. The American Kidney Fund, along with other health organizations, is engaging in various partnerships to educate and connect people to resources for early detection and management of AMKD. They emphasize the importance of genetic testing for those with non-diabetes related kidney disease, especially within affected communities, as many insurance companies cover these tests.

title: American Kidney Fund Launches National Kidney Health Equity Media Campaign
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has launched a national media campaign to improve kidney health fairness, especially targeting the Black and Hispanic/Latino populations who are disproportionately impacted by kidney failure in the U.S. This effort is part of AKF's Kidney Health for All™ initiative, lasting a year, employing a mix of advertising techniques including TV, streaming, radio PSAs, digital ads, etc., focusing on kidney disease prevention and management. The campaign highlights experts like Dr. Silas Norman and Dr. Pablo Garcia, underlining the critical role of regular health screenings for early kidney disease detection and treatment. Supported by various sponsors, the campaign aims to tackle four main issues: preventing and slowing disease progression, increasing diversity in clinical trials, raising awareness about home dialysis, and enhancing access to kidney transplants for people of color.

title: American Kidney Fund Launches Educational Awareness Campaigns for Two Rare Kidney Diseases
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has initiated educational awareness campaigns for two rare kidney diseases, complement 3 glomerulopathy (C3G) and IgA nephropathy (IgAN), with support from Novartis. These campaigns aim to provide crucial information and resources to patients, helping them understand and manage their conditions. Both diseases involve the immune system's improper function leading to potential kidney failure. The AKF's campaigns offer details on diagnosis, symptoms, management, and coping strategies, including dedicated webpages, educational videos, and a guide for doctor visits. A video series on patient experiences with C3G is also in development to foster community support. These efforts are part of AKF's broader mission to enhance awareness, understanding, and access to resources for people with rare kidney diseases.

title: American Kidney Fund Encourages People to Be APOL1 Aware with First Annual APOL1-Mediated Kidney Disease ...
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) has initiated the first APOL1-Mediated Kidney Disease (AMKD) Awareness Day to raise awareness about this severe genetic condition that mainly affects individuals of western and central African heritage, including Black, African American, Afro-Caribbean, and Latina/Latino groups. With support from Vertex Pharmaceuticals, the campaign seeks to inform the public about how genetic factors affect kidney health, particularly through mutations in the APOL1 gene that greatly increase the risk of developing fast-progressing kidney diseases like focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). The AKF is employing a variety of methods to promote awareness, such as a panel discussion at the National Minority Quality Forum and social media efforts. This day is observed on the last Tuesday of April, within National Minority Health Month, and has garnered additional backing from different organizations and a resolution by Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett.

title: American Kidney Fund Convenes Nation's Kidney Community for
summary: The American Kidney Fund (AKF) is hosting its fifth annual Kidney Action Week from March 18-22, 2024, as a part of its Kidney Month observance. This free online conference is unique in the nation for bringing together over 5,000 participants including patients, caregivers, nephrologists, researchers, and other experts to engage in sessions focused on various aspects of kidney disease. The event aims to equip and empower individuals with the necessary tools to prioritize their kidney health and combat kidney disease, a condition affecting about 1 in 7 Americans, many of whom are unaware of their condition until its advanced stages. Kidney Action Week features daily themed educational content on topics like dialysis, prevention, kidney-friendly eating, and transplant. Additionally, AKF will host a Congressional Briefing to discuss rare kidney diseases, emphasizing the need for increased research, public awareness, and earlier diagnosis. The week is supported by various sponsors, highlighting AKF's commitment to fighting kidney disease and aiding those affected by it.

title: MAIA Biotechnology Abstract Accepted for Poster Presentation at American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 ...
summary: MAIA Biotechnology's abstract on its Phase 2 THIO-101 clinical trial for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) has been accepted for a poster presentation at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 Annual Meeting in Chicago. The trial evaluates the telomere-targeting agent THIO sequenced with cemiplimab in advanced NSCLC patients. The presentation will reveal new efficacy results and discuss the science behind THIO, which is the first of its kind in clinical development for cancer treatment. The poster will be available on the MAIA Biotechnology website on June 3, 2024, the day of the presentation. MAIA Biotechnology focuses on developing targeted immunotherapies for cancer, with THIO as its lead program aimed at improving and extending the lives of people with telomerase-positive cancer cells.

title: Karyopharm Announces Presentations in Endometrial Cancer and Myelofibrosis at the 2024 American Society of ...
summary: Karyopharm Therapeutics Inc. announced their participation in the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology Annual Meeting, where they will present updated data on endometrial cancer and myelofibrosis. The company highlighted a special session on endometrial cancer, focusing on long-term follow-up of selinexor maintenance in TP53wt advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer from the Phase 3 ENGOT-EN5/GOG-3055/SIENDO Study. Additionally, they will present on the phase 3 trial design for selinexor in TP53wt endometrial cancer and two studies on myelofibrosis involving selinexor. Karyopharm’s Chief Medical Officer expressed confidence in selinexor's benefits for patients. XPOVIO (selinexor) is already approved in the U.S. for multiple myeloma and DLBCL, with ongoing investigations in other cancers. The company aims to address high unmet needs in cancer treatment through their research.

title: Cue Biopharma to Present at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting
summary: Cue Biopharma, Inc., a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, will present at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting from May 31 to June 4, 2024, in Chicago, IL. The company will showcase Phase 1 trials of its lead interleukin 2 (IL-2)-based biologics, CUE-101 for recurrent/metastatic head and neck cancer, and CUE-102 for Wilms’ Tumor 1 positive recurrent/metastatic cancers. A Business Update call and webcast discussing the clinical progress and data presented at ASCO will be hosted in June 2024. The presentations aim to highlight Cue Biopharma's innovative approach to selectively modulate disease-specific T cells, leveraging the body’s immune system to fight cancer without broad systemic immune modulation.

title: DPYD Pharmacogenetics: To Opt-in or to Opt-out
summary: The editorial discusses the implementation of a preemptive DPYD testing program for patients planned for systemic fluoropyrimidine treatment at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute. The program, designed to assess the impact of individual genetics on treatment outcomes, particularly for fluorouracil (5-FU) and capecitabine, includes an opt-out option. Despite the potential of pharmacogenetics (PGx) to enhance care and reduce costs, its integration into clinical practice has been slow due to factors like result turnaround time and limited data. The article highlights the complexity of DPYD genetics and the challenges in determining the necessity and extent of dose adjustments based on genetic variants. While universal DPYD testing is advocated to prevent toxicities, the opt-out program at DFCI has significantly changed clinician prescribing habits, with high adoption rates over time. The piece underscores the ongoing debate on the readiness of DPYD testing as a biomarker and the need for further evidence to standardize testing and dosing guidelines.

title: City of Hope to Present New Research at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting 2024 ...
summary: City of Hope, a leading cancer research and treatment organization, will present new research findings at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting 2024 in Chicago. The presentations will cover a range of topics, including stem cell transplantation, blood cancers, and supportive care oncology interventions. Additionally, there will be data on clinical oncology therapies for colon, rectal, kidney, and breast cancers. City of Hope experts are set to present at 64 sessions, including oral abstracts and clinical science symposiums. Highlights include studies on sotorasib plus panitumumab for metastatic colorectal cancer, post-transplant cyclophosphamide-based graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis, glofitamab monotherapy for relapsed/refractory mantle cell lymphoma, and the efficacy of DFF332, an oral HIF2α inhibitor, in advanced clear cell renal cell carcinoma. There will also be discussions on geriatric assessment-directed supportive care via telehealth and the quality of life for older patients with metastatic cancer in Brazil. The meeting will recognize researchers, including City of Hope’s William Dale, recipient of the B.J. Kennedy Geriatric Oncology Award, for their contributions to cancer care.

title: Coherus Announces Presentation at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting
summary: Coherus BioSciences, Inc. announced its first presentation of clinical data for CHS-114 at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting. CHS-114 is a selective anti-CCR8 antibody aimed at depleting regulatory T cells in tumors, potentially enhancing anti-tumor immune responses. Early Phase 1 results show biological effects, including depletion of CCR8+ Tregs without impacting non-CCR8+ Tregs. Coherus focuses on cancer therapies, with an immuno-oncology pipeline complementing its commercial oncology capabilities. It markets several products, including LOQTORZI, UDENYCA, and YUSIMRY. The company is also developing other immunotherapy candidates and plans to file an IND for CHS-1000 in Q2 2024.

title: Nuvation Bio to Present Updated Data on Taletrectinib, a ROS1 inhibitor, at the 2024 American Society of Clinical ...
summary: Nuvation Bio Inc., a global biopharmaceutical company, announced that it will present updated data from the Phase 2 TRUST-I clinical study of taletrectinib at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting. The study evaluates taletrectinib, a next-generation ROS1 inhibitor, in Chinese patients with ROS1-positive non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The presentation will cover the efficacy and safety of taletrectinib in patients with advanced or metastatic ROS1-positive NSCLC. Taletrectinib has received Breakthrough Therapy Designations from the U.S. FDA and China's NMPA for this patient group, and the NMPA has granted Priority Review to New Drug Applications for taletrectinib based on the TRUST-I study results. Nuvation Bio focuses on developing novel therapeutics for unmet needs in oncology, with a portfolio that includes taletrectinib and other candidates targeting different cancer types.

title: TScan Therapeutics Announces Upcoming Presentations at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology Annual ...
summary: TScan Therapeutics, Inc., a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, announced its participation in the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting with two abstracts accepted for poster presentation. The event is scheduled for May 31 - June 4, both in Chicago, IL, and virtually. The presentations will focus on TSC-100 and TSC-101, engineered T cell therapies targeting minor histocompatibility antigens to eliminate residual disease after hematopoietic cell transplantation, and T-Plex, a multiplexed, enhanced T cell receptor-engineered T cell therapy (TCR-T) for solid tumors. The company specializes in developing TCR-engineered T cell therapies for cancer treatment, with TSC-100 and TSC-101 aimed at preventing relapse in hematologic malignancies post-transplantation, and is also working on therapies for solid tumors. Presentation materials will be available on TScan’s website post-event.

title: WVU Medicine officially expands with addition of Grant Memorial Hospital
summary: WVU Medicine has officially incorporated Grant Memorial Hospital (GMH) into its network, expanding its reach to 23 hospitals. This integration, effective from July 1, aims to enhance healthcare services in Grant County and its surrounding areas by providing expanded local services and easier access to specialized care in Morgantown. Albert L. Wright, Jr., the president and CEO of WVU Health System, emphasized the goal of offering comprehensive care close to residents' homes. GMH, serving the Potomac Highlands region and being the largest employer in Grant County, celebrated its 65th anniversary by joining WVU Medicine, a move celebrated by local officials for its potential to boost healthcare quality and accessibility in the region. A formal celebration of GMH's full membership in the WVU Health System is scheduled for July 11.

title: Another West Virginia hospital joins WVU Medicine
summary: Grant Memorial Hospital in Petersburg, West Virginia, has officially become the 19th hospital to join WVU Medicine as of July 1, following an agreement made in 2021. This 24/7 hospital serves the remote areas of West Virginia’s Potomac Highlands, including Grant, Pendleton, Hardy, Hampshire, and Mineral counties. The hospital, which is owned by the Grant County Commission and employs over 350 people, has 25 inpatient beds. Joining WVU Medicine is expected to bring higher levels of care and additional programs and services to the community, enhancing its role as a crucial healthcare provider and the largest employer in Grant County. A celebration of the new partnership is planned for July 11.

title: The Balm In Gilead: Addressing Heart Health and High Blood Pressure in African American Communities
summary: The Balm In Gilead, Inc. aims to reduce health disparities in African American communities via faith-based initiatives in the U.S. and Tanzania. It focuses on disease prevention and health improvement, especially targeting high blood pressure, a common but often neglected issue in these areas. High blood pressure can cause heart disease by decreasing artery elasticity and hindering blood and oxygen flow to the heart. The organization promotes controlling blood pressure with a healthy diet, regular exercise, and smoking cessation. It also educates on diabetes and heart health through partnerships and programs like the Southeast Diabetes Faith Initiative, and raises awareness of peripheral artery disease, supported by resources from The Heart Truth to boost its educational and outreach efforts.

title: National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS Streaming Discussion Series Centers Black Americans
summary: The National Week of Prayer for the Healing of AIDS, scheduled for March 3-9, 2024, will host a live streaming discussion series titled "The Doctor and the Preacher," focusing on the impact of HIV/AIDS on Black Americans. Organized by The Balm In Gilead, Inc., the series will be available on Facebook and YouTube from March 4-6 at 12pm Eastern Time. Dr. Pernessa C. Seele, founder/CEO of The Balm In Gilead, Inc., emphasizes the disproportionate effect of HIV and AIDS on Black communities and aims to explore actions by individuals, congregations, and policymakers. Despite advancements in HIV prevention and treatment, Black Americans account for 43% of new HIV diagnoses while making up just 12% of the US population. The series will feature discussions on the state of HIV in African American communities, current HIV policy trends, and women in HIV research, with various experts and leaders. The Balm In Gilead, Inc. is a 36-year-old organization dedicated to equipping faith communities to serve as health education and support hubs for Black Americans.

title: UF Health oncologist receives clinical investigator leadership award
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: Sherise Rogers, M.D., an assistant professor in the division of hematology and oncology at the UF College of Medicine and a member of the UF Health Cancer Center, has been awarded the inaugural Robert A. Winn Diversity in Clinical Trials: Clinical Investigator Leadership Award by Conquer Cancer, the American Society of Clinical Oncology Foundation, with funding from the Bristol Myers Squibb Foundation. This competitive three-year award supports her leadership development as a clinical investigator, focusing on improving access to cancer research and clinical trials for marginalized groups to address cancer health disparities. Rogers was eligible for this award after completing a two-year career development program, which included training on designing, implementing, and diversifying clinical trials, and conducting research on the intestinal microbiome of pancreatic cancer patients. This work aims to ensure that clinical trials reflect the populations they serve, especially considering the significant disparities in pancreatic cancer outcomes among different racial groups.

title: After more than a decade, ASCO sells CancerLinQ to ConcertAI
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: After more than a decade of development and operation by the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO), CancerLinQ—a technology service for real-world data and quality of care in oncology—has been sold to ConcertAI, a company specializing in real-world evidence and generative AI. The sale, announced on December 11, 2023, aims to provide CancerLinQ with the extensive resources required for its success, beyond what ASCO could offer. CancerLinQ, which has a small team of about 50 staff, manages a network of over 100 cancer centers and oncology practices, and nearly 7 million patient records through integrations with 10 electronic medical record (EMR) systems. ConcertAI plans to invest $250 million in cancer informatics, enhancing the capabilities and reach of CancerLinQ. The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. This move is expected to significantly improve the services offered by CancerLinQ, including quality tools and clinical trial matching, benefiting the oncology community and patient care. ConcertAI has offered employment to all of CancerLinQ’s staff, indicating a commitment to the growth and development of the service.

title: Health Equity
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) is committed to achieving health equity in cancer care through various initiatives and resources for the oncology community. ASCO emphasizes Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI) through its EDI Action Plan, focusing on research, education, and quality care. The organization has created the Center for Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion to incorporate EDI in all its activities. The 2022 EDI Blueprint Report highlights 22 initiatives under ASCO's mission pillars to promote significant change and ensure high-quality, equitable care for everyone with cancer. ASCO also provides resources to tackle health equity issues in cancer research and care and educates patients on health equity via Cancer.Net. Furthermore, it maintains a vast collection of policy and position statements on equity in cancer care and research. ASCO's efforts and resources are dedicated to advancing health equity worldwide, showing a deep and continuous commitment to this essential issue.

title: ASCO Congratulates 2023 Special Awards Recipients
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: ASCO and Conquer Cancer will honor various individuals at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting in Chicago for their significant contributions to the oncology community. These recipients include researchers, patient advocates, philanthropists, teachers, and global oncology leaders who have played pivotal roles in transforming cancer care globally. Among the awardees are Monica M. Bertagnolli, recognized with the Allen Lichter Visionary Leader Award for her leadership roles, including as the 16th Director of the National Cancer Institute. Deborah Schrag receives the ASCO–American Cancer Society Cancer Prevention Award for her work in gastrointestinal cancer and health care delivery. Hans Wildiers is honored with the B.J. Kennedy Geriatric Oncology Award for his contributions to breast cancer research and geriatric oncology. Hagop M. Kantarjian is awarded the David Karnofsky Memorial Award for his impactful research in leukemia. Carmen E. Guerra receives the Excellence in Equity Award for her efforts in diversifying clinical trial participation. David Gerson Poplack is recognized with the Excellence in Teaching Award for his contributions to pediatric oncology education. Angela DeMichele is given the Gianni Bonadonna Breast Cancer Award for her leadership in breast cancer research. Patrick J. Loehrer, Sr, and Jane Perlmutter, alongside Colonel (Ret) James E. Williams, Jr, are acknowledged for their humanitarian and advocacy efforts. Peter C. Adamson receives the Pediatric Oncology Award for his leadership in pediatric drug development. Alan Ashworth is honored with the Science of Oncology Award for his discovery and development of PARP inhibitors. Declan Walsh receives the Walther Cancer Foundation Supportive Oncology Award for innovations in palliative care. Carolyn D. Runowicz and Maria T. Bourlon are recognized with mentorship awards for their roles in supporting women in oncology. The awards highlight the diverse contributions to cancer care, research, and advocacy.

title: Dr Dulal bags ASCO Global Oncology Young Investigator Award [ASCO GOYIA]
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: Nepali doctor Soniya Dulal has been awarded the ASCO Global Oncology Young Investigator Award (ASCO GOYIA) 2023, receiving $50,000 for her research on the clinical and molecular characterization of breast cancer among different ethnic groups in Nepal. This award is given by the American Society of Clinical Oncology, Conquer Cancer Foundation. Dr. Dulal is the first Nepalese medical oncologist to receive this recognition and the Conquer Cancer Foundation, ASCO merit Award for best abstract. She conducted her groundbreaking research in collaboration with Princess Margaret Cancer Center in Toronto, Canada. Dulal, a DM Medical Oncologist and a graduate from NAMS, Bir Hospital, has previously received the UICC Technical Fellowship Award 2019. She is a Life Member of the Association of UICC Fellows and has presented her research internationally.

title: UC alumna appointed interim senior vice president of External Relations and Communications | UCnet
hco: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA
summary: Meredith Vivian Turner has been appointed as the interim senior vice president of External Relations and Communications at the University of California (UC) Office of the President, effective May 17, 2024. This decision, approved by the UC Board of Regents on May 16, 2024, follows a competitive national recruitment process. Turner, a UC Santa Cruz alumna and former president of its alumni board, has a robust background in government relations and communications, with significant experience within the UC system and a history of advocating for public higher education in California. In her new role, Turner will oversee university-wide communications, state and federal governmental relations, and advancement and alumni relations, supporting UC's mission of education, research, and public service. Previously serving as chief of staff of External Relations and Communications, Turner's appointment is part of a strategic move to ensure continuity and leverage her deep understanding of and connections within the UC community. Her annual salary is set at $345,000.

title: Penn Trustees approve 2024-2025 undergraduate charges and financial aid budget | Penn Today
hco: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA
summary: The University of Pennsylvania Board of Trustees has approved a 3.9% increase in undergraduate tuition for the 2024-2025 academic year, setting total charges at $87,860. This includes tuition of $60,920, fees of $7,766, a standard room rate of $12,640, and a meal plan charge of $6,534. Alongside this increase, a record $311 million financial aid budget was approved, marking a 4.5% increase from the previous year to support students with demonstrated financial need. This move is part of Penn's commitment to make education accessible, with 46% of students receiving need-based financial aid, allowing them to attend without loans. The financial aid policy ensures that families earning $75,000 or less receive packages covering tuition, fees, housing, and dining, with those earning up to $140,000 receiving significant aid as well. The average financial aid package is $66,764, covering more than tuition and 75% of the total cost of attendance. The university aims to enable students to graduate debt-free, with only 19% of financial aid recipients borrowing loans, compared to 76% in 2008.

title: Penn names J. Larry Jameson new interim president after Liz Magill's resignation
hco: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA
summary: The University of Pennsylvania has named Dr. J. Larry Jameson as the temporary president after Liz Magill resigned. Magill resigned because of criticism about how she dealt with antisemitism at the university. Although she resigned, she will stay as a tenured professor at Penn's law school. Jameson, who has been part of Penn Medicine since 2011, promised to tackle the university's challenges and stressed the need for a safe and welcoming environment. This leadership change happens against a backdrop of wider issues of antisemitism at the university, underscored by federal probes and public disputes.

title: Incoming AAFP President Optimistic About Family Medicine's Future
summary: Incoming AAFP President, Steven Furr, MD, expresses optimism about the future of family medicine despite facing challenges. In an interview with MedPage Today, Furr, who will soon assume presidency of the American Academy of Family Physicians, outlines his priorities which include addressing the shortage of family physicians, especially in rural and underserved areas, advocating for better reimbursement for family physicians, and reducing administrative burdens that detract from patient care. Furr emphasizes the need for more medical students and residents to enter family medicine to meet the growing demand and the importance of training physicians in communities where they are most needed. He also highlights the role of family physicians in providing comprehensive care and the need for payment systems to reflect this. Additionally, Furr discusses the importance of reducing administrative tasks that hinder patient care and the need for legislative support to improve the practice environment for family physicians.

title: Most Important Guideline Changes of the Year for Primary Care
summary: The article from Medscape, written by Neil Skolnik, MD, on January 17, 2024, outlines the most important updates in primary care guidelines for 2023. Notable changes include a new blood pressure goal set by the American Academy of Family Physicians at <140/90 mm Hg, which is different from the lower targets recommended by the American Heart Association and the American Diabetes Association. This adjustment is based on evidence showing that lower blood pressure targets do not significantly affect mortality or stroke outcomes, although they may slightly reduce the risk of myocardial infarction. COPD guidelines now focus on preventing exacerbations and suggest triple therapy for those with moderate to severe COPD with a history of exacerbations. For depression, the American College of Physicians prefers cognitive-behavioral therapy to medication for mild cases and a mix of treatments for more severe depression. Guidelines for osteoporosis treatment recommend bisphosphonates as the primary treatment for postmenopausal women and a tailored approach for older men. Heart failure management now includes SGLT2 inhibitors as a key treatment for HFpEF. The North American Menopause Society recommends nonhormonal treatments for menopausal vasomotor symptoms, and new rules mandate breast density information on all mammogram reports. Guidelines for fatty liver disease suggest a step-by-step evaluation and treatment method, while the updated Beers criteria recommend against using aspirin for primary prevention in the elderly and favor apixaban for certain conditions. Finally, the article mentions the adverse health effects of vaping, as confirmed by the AHA.

title: Family Physicians with Value-Based Payment Models Relieve Burnout, According to Study from AAFP with Elation Health
summary: A study by the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) and Elation Health discovered that family physicians with 75% of their revenue from value-based payment (VBP) models experience less burnout compared to those using fee-for-service models. The research surveyed 10 primary care practices of various sizes to find barriers to VBP model adoption and its impact on physician burnout. It found that sufficient infrastructure and financial investment are essential for VBP models' success and burnout reduction. Larger practices or those with network affiliations had an easier time with VBP administration due to scale economies. Capitated models, which pay per person rather than per service, were linked to less burnout. The study also underlined the significance of innovative contracts between practices and health plans, highlighting primary care's role in lowering healthcare costs and enhancing patient care quality.

title: KU School of Medicine-Wichita faculty members, student group earn national honors from American Academy of Family ...
summary: Faculty members and a student group from the KU School of Medicine-Wichita have been nationally recognized by the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP). Gretchen Irwin, M.D., MBA, and Mark Leiker, M.D., received the AAFP Exemplary Teacher of the Year Award for full-time and volunteer faculty, respectively. The Family Medicine Interest Group at the school received the Program of Excellence Award for the fourth consecutive year. These awards highlight the outstanding contributions of the faculty and students to family medicine, including developing national curricula and leadership programs, clinical skills, compassionate care, and community outreach. This recognition confirms the school's reputation for excellence in medical education and its impact on the community and the broader field of family medicine.

title: 'Busy' doctors are now being told by leading medical group it's ok to use ChatGPT to ease workload
summary: A leading US medical body is advising doctors under pressure to use ChatGPT to help manage their workload. A study showed ChatGPT could accurately summarize medical studies 98% of the time, making it a useful tool for doctors to stay informed about the latest research and treatment developments without spending too much time reading detailed reports. The technology was particularly effective in specialties like cardiology, neurology, psychiatry, and public health. Although ChatGPT demonstrated high effectiveness in summarizing clinical studies and even passed a medical licensing exam, researchers caution against relying solely on it, especially in high-risk situations, due to the potential for serious inaccuracies. The American Medical Association survey indicated that 38% of doctors are already using AI in their daily practice, and about 90% of hospital systems employ some form of AI. With doctor burnout rates high, the hope is that AI technology, like ChatGPT, can alleviate some of the stress and administrative burden, allowing doctors to spend more time with their patients. However, there remains some public skepticism about the heavy reliance on AI in healthcare.

title: Using an AI Assistant To Reduce Documentation Burden in Family Medicine
summary: The American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) Innovation Lab conducted a study on the impact of Suki, an AI assistant designed for documentation purposes in family medicine. The findings revealed substantial benefits, including a 72% reduction in the time needed for documentation, a 17% decrease in burnout within 30 days, and a 20% increase in practice satisfaction. This study underscores the potential of AI assistants like Suki in enhancing efficiency and improving the work experience for family physicians, highlighting the technology as an "essential innovation" for the field.

title: How completing RUC surveys can help you financially
summary: Completing RUC surveys is essential for financial health in medical practices. The AMA/Specialty Society Relative Value Scale Update Committee (RUC) is key by suggesting adjustments to the resource-based relative value scale to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), impacting the Medicare physician fee schedule. CMS approves more than 90% of RUC's suggestions, affecting physician payments across different payers. RUC depends on specialty societies and healthcare professionals to assess the work needed for medical services through these surveys. The American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP) and others distribute these surveys to collect important data. This process is crucial as many payers adjust their fee structures to align with Medicare, and employment contracts often base productivity on the RBRVS. Thus, participating in RUC surveys directly influences physician payment, underlining the importance for family physicians to take part in this evaluation process.

title: AAFP President Dr. Steven Furr on the State of Family Practice
summary: Dr. Steven Furr, the new president of the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP), discusses the current state and future of family practice. He emphasizes the importance of primary care and family medicine as foundational to healthcare, highlighting the role of family physicians in understanding and addressing social determinants of health. Dr. Furr notes the value of long-term patient relationships and comprehensive care. He discusses the challenges faced by family practitioners, including workforce shortages, bureaucratic hurdles, and the need for better collaboration with specialists, particularly in mental health. The impact of COVID-19 on healthcare workers and the departure of family practice and internal medicine doctors from the workforce are acknowledged. Dr. Furr outlines strategies to attract more medical students to family practice, such as increasing funding for the National Health Service Corps and supporting residencies in underserved areas. He also discusses the importance of reimbursement reforms to make family medicine more financially attractive. Lastly, Dr. Furr highlights the efforts to support rural healthcare and the role of family practitioners as mentors and leaders in the medical community.

title: T.S. Chandrasekar elected Academic Governor of American College of Gastroenterology for India region
summary: T.S. Chandrasekar, Chairman and Chief Interventional Gastroenterologist at MedIndia Hospitals in Chennai, has been elected as the Academic Governor of the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) for the India region. The ACG, an international medical association of gastroenterologists with over 14,000 physician members from 86 countries, was founded in 1932. Dr. Chandrasekar will assume his role during the ACG's Annual Scientific Meeting in Vancouver, Canada, on October 22, 2023, and will serve from 2023 to 2026. His responsibilities include planning and overseeing academic programs, research initiatives, and mentoring, specifically aimed at enhancing the care provided to patients with digestive disorders by Indian members of ACG. Dr. Chandrasekar, who served as the honorary National President of the Indian Society of Gastroenterology in 2016-17, is also an Honorary Distinguished Professor for life at The Tamil Nadu Dr. MGR Medical University since 2021.

title: New guidelines on management of acute pancreatitis released by American College of Gastroenterology
summary: The American College of Gastroenterology has issued new guidelines for managing acute pancreatitis (AP), emphasizing early management to prevent severe complications like organ failure and pancreatic necrosis. Acute pancreatitis, characterized by the acute inflammation of the pancreas, is a leading cause of gastrointestinal-related hospital admissions. The guidelines recommend a practical, evidence-based approach, suggesting initial strategies such as moderately aggressive fluid resuscitation, preferring lactated Ringer's solution over normal saline, and using transabdominal ultrasound to evaluate biliary pancreatitis. For acute biliary pancreatitis without cholangitis, medical therapy is advised over early endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) within the first 72 hours. Prophylactic antibiotics are not recommended for severe AP, and early oral feeding within 24–48 hours is suggested for mild AP, favoring a low-fat solid diet over a liquid-to-solid diet transition. The guidelines, detailed in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, highlight the importance of individualized patient management and referral to specialized centers for those with acute necrotizing pancreatitis to reduce mortality and morbidity.

title: New ACG Guideline on the Management of Acute Pancreatitis and More in the March Issue of AJG
summary: The March 2024 issue of The American Journal of Gastroenterology features new clinical guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) on managing acute pancreatitis, emphasizing early intervention, aggressive hydration, and early feeding with a low-fat solid diet within 24-48 hours of hospital admission. Additionally, it includes a guideline developed with the Society of Abdominal Radiology on imaging for gastrointestinal bleeding, offering recommendations for various scenarios and detailing the advantages and limitations of specific imaging tests. Other highlighted articles cover topics such as colonoscopy, the use of IBD drugs during pregnancy, pediatric Crohn's disease, cirrhosis, IBS, and the association between dietary patterns and the severity of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease among Hispanic patients. The issue aims to guide the delivery of high-quality, compassionate, and evidence-based patient care in gastroenterology.

title: Iterative Health Presents Award-Winning Research on the Benefits of Gastroenterological Technology at the American ...
summary: Iterative Health presented award-winning research at the American College of Gastroenterology Annual Scientific Meeting, showcasing the benefits of Computer-Aided Detection (CADe) devices and AI in gastroenterology. Their studies highlight the effectiveness of CADe devices in increasing adenoma detection during colonoscopies across various patient demographics, enhancing the quality of colorectal cancer screenings. Additionally, the research explored AI's role in improving clinical trial recruitment for inflammatory bowel disease. The awarded study, led by Dr. Aasma Shaukat, emphasized that CADe devices significantly improve adenomas per colonoscopy (APC) rates at both community and academic centers, reinforcing the need for high-quality colonoscopy standards. Iterative Health's findings, including five publications, underline the potential of AI-assisted tools in reducing variability in screenings and advancing patient care in gastroenterology.

title: Valley Hospital receives SCOPY award from American College of Gastroenterology
summary: Valley Hospital received the SCOPY Award from the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) for its work in community engagement, education, and awareness about colorectal cancer prevention. The hospital held events in February and March, including activities at public libraries and malls, giving out free Fecal Immunochemical Test kits to churches, and providing educational lectures and videos. There was a strong emphasis on increasing awareness in the Black community, who have a higher risk of colorectal cancer. The award also highlighted Valley Hospital's Fast-Track Screening Colonoscopy program, which has screened over 1,100 patients since 2018 by letting eligible patients skip a pre-procedure consultation with a gastroenterologist or colorectal surgeon.

title: American College of Gastroenterology, Oct. 20-25
summary: The American College of Gastroenterology's annual meeting was held from October 20 to 25 in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, attracting worldwide attendees, including experts in gastroenterology and digestive diseases. The event featured clinical updates in gastroenterology and hepatology, as well as the newest developments in digestive health and gastrointestinal disorders. Notable research presented includes Wissam Ghusn, M.D.'s study on semaglutide for obesity, which demonstrated significant weight loss and reduced cardiovascular disease risk in patients. Another study by Yuhan Fu, D.O., associated the use of combined oral contraceptives with an increased risk of irritable bowel syndrome. Additionally, Amy Yu, M.D.'s research indicated that low-dose aspirin usage in pregnant women with inflammatory bowel disease does not heighten the risk of disease flare-ups. Other showcased studies involved a noninvasive stool RNA test for detecting colorectal neoplasia, the use of intestinal ultrasound in the management of inflammatory bowel disease, and a digital tool for identifying cancer susceptibility syndromes.

title: Evidence-based approach recommended for acute pancreatitis management
summary: The American College of Gastroenterology has released a clinical guideline in the March edition of the American Journal of Gastroenterology, offering evidence-based advice for treating acute pancreatitis (AP). Written by Scott Tenner, M.D., M.P.H., and his team, it covers managing AP, marked by sudden pancreas inflammation and varying progression in patients. Recommendations include using transabdominal ultrasound for biliary pancreatitis diagnosis, preferring Lactated Ringer's solution for moderately aggressive fluid resuscitation over normal saline, and advising against early endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography in acute biliary pancreatitis unless cholangitis is present. It advises against prophylactic antibiotics for severe AP and fine needle aspiration for suspected infected pancreatic necrosis. Early oral feeding, within 24 to 48 hours, is recommended for mild AP cases, choosing a low-fat solid diet instead of progressing from liquid to solid. The guideline also highlights the need for more research in certain areas, especially in managing infected necrosis without immediate surgery.

title: Chennai gastroenterologist elected academic governor of India region
summary: T.S. Chandrasekar, the chairman and chief interventional gastroenterologist at MedIndia Hospitals, has been elected as the Academic Governor for the India region by the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG). He officially assumed his position during the ACG's annual scientific meeting held in Vancouver, Canada, on October 22, 2023, and will serve for a three-year term. The ACG, an international association of gastroenterologists founded in 1932, comprises over 14,000 physician members from 86 countries. In his role, Chandrasekar will be responsible for planning, implementing, mentoring, and overseeing academic programs and research initiatives to benefit the Indian members of the ACG.

title: Dr. Jonathan Leighton Elected President of the American College of Gastroenterology
summary: Dr. Jonathan A. Leighton has been elected as the President of the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) for 2023-2024.
