He is a Professor of Medicine at Mayo Clinic in Arizona, where he also serves as the Medical Director of the Office of Mayo Clinic Experience and chairs the Office of Joy and Wellbeing. Dr. Leighton has held numerous leadership roles within the Mayo Clinic, including chairing the Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology and serving as Director of the Inflammatory Bowel Disease Clinic. As ACG President, he will lead the Board of Trustees in guiding the College’s work in line with its mission and vision, directing programs including continuing medical education and activities related to health policy issues and clinical investigation. Dr. Leighton, who has been a member of the College since 1991 and became a Fellow in 2008, has also contributed to several committees within ACG. His clinical and research interests focus on inflammatory bowel disease, colorectal neoplasia, diseases of the small bowel, and new technologies for detecting colon polyps and cancer.

title: Official journal of the American College of Gastroenterology | ACG
summary: The text describes the Official Journal of the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG), detailing how to access the site, subscribe to the journal, and receive alerts for new issues. It covers several ACG journals, including Clinical and Translational Gastroenterology and ACG Case Reports Journal. The description includes the types of content available, such as articles on various gastroenterology topics, author guidelines, and details about the editorial board. It also emphasizes the journal's dedication to privacy and the ability for readers to adjust their cookie settings. Furthermore, the journal presents videos and articles on innovative endoscopic techniques and therapies in gastroenterology, highlighting recent research and developments in the field.

title: Affiliates | About Wake Forest
summary: Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, has several affiliates that enhance its academic and community environment. These include 88.5 WFDD, an NPR affiliate and the only public radio station in the Piedmont Triad, broadcasting from the Reynolda Campus. Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist, a leading academic health system, provides medical services. The Graylyn International Conference Center, a historic hotel and modern conference facility, is located on a 1920s estate. The Innovation Quarter is a 200-acre technology park focusing on biomedical, material sciences, and information technology. Reynolda Gardens, once part of the early 20th-century estate of R.J. and Katharine Reynolds, now serves as a recreational and educational space. The Reynolda House Museum of American Art houses a fine collection of American paintings. Reynolda Village offers shopping, dining, and office spaces in buildings that were part of the Reynolds estate.

title: Research Study on Novel Rehab Program for Heart Failure Patients, Led by Wake Forest University School of Medicine ...
summary: Wake Forest University School of Medicine is expanding its research study on a novel rehabilitation program for older heart failure patients to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Chicago. This Phase III study, funded by a $30 million grant from the National Institute of Aging, aims to reduce rehospitalizations and mortality among patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), a common condition in older adults. Led by Dr. Dalane Kitzman, the study involves a team from Wake Forest University, Duke University, and Thomas Jefferson University. The research focuses on a physical rehabilitation intervention tailored to each patient, starting during hospital recovery. Initial findings from a previous Phase II study showed significant improvements in physical function. The current study seeks to enroll 880 patients across 20 sites, with Advocate Christ Medical Center being a key location. This expansion will allow the inclusion of more patients from vulnerable and underserved populations, potentially changing clinical practices and improving health outcomes nationwide.

title: WFIRM leads $40M regenerative medicine initiative for the wounded and beyond
summary: The Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM), part of Wake Forest University School of Medicine, has been selected to lead the Armed Forces Institute of Regenerative Medicine (AFIRM) Consortium. This project, backed by a $40 million grant from the Defense Health Agency over five years, seeks to develop regenerative medicine treatments for battlefield injuries and, ultimately, the wider population. Regenerative medicine utilizes the body's own healing mechanisms to mend or replace damaged tissues and organs. WFIRM has proven its expertise in this area by overseeing two prior AFIRM consortia since 2008, producing over 20 clinical trials for new treatments for burns, limb, genitourinary, facial, and skull injuries. The 2023 initiative, a joint effort between the US Army Medical Research and Development Command (MRDC) and the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium (MTEC), aims to fast-track the creation of clinical products through strong partnerships. Key areas of focus include regeneration of craniofacial and limb tissues, genitourinary/lower abdomen, skin and wound healing, on-demand blood, and cellular treatments for trauma. This consortium, which includes academic and industry partners, strives to bring regenerative medicine solutions to clinical practice for the benefit of injured service members, veterans, and the American public.

title: Research shows human behavior guided by fast changes in dopamine levels
summary: A study by Wake Forest University School of Medicine, published in Science Advances, reveals that dopamine, a neurotransmitter known for its role in positive emotions, also plays a critical role in learning from both positive and negative experiences. This discovery was made through measuring dopamine levels in real-time in participants playing a computer game during deep brain stimulation surgery. The study demonstrates that dopamine levels fluctuate rapidly in response to rewards and punishments, suggesting an optimal teaching signal similar to those used in advanced artificial intelligence. This insight into dopamine's dual role in encoding reward and punishment prediction errors could lead to a better understanding of psychiatric and neurological disorders, challenging the traditional view of dopamine solely as "the pleasure neurotransmitter" and highlighting its importance in a sophisticated system guiding human behavior and learning.

title: Program aims to ignite youth excitement in data science careers | Wake Forest News
summary: Wake Forest University will host the 2nd annual Florence Nightingale Day on April 20, aimed at sparking interest in data science and statistics among middle and high school students in the Piedmont area. This free event will include hands-on activities, like using a catapult to learn about experimental design and creating a classification algorithm for telling cats and dogs apart, to develop analytical and problem-solving skills. It will also feature a panel of statistics career experts to motivate and share their experiences with the youth. The event, highlighting the importance of early statistics and data science exposure, is supported by Wake Forest’s Department of Biostatistics and Data Science at the School of Medicine and the Department of Statistical Sciences at Reynolda Campus, along with Winston-Salem State University. This initiative is in response to the increasing demand for statisticians and data scientists, with job growth in these areas expected to rise by 30 percent from 2022 to 2032.

title: UNCP students gain insight from Wake Forest University School of Medicine visit
summary: UNCP students visited Wake Forest University School of Medicine on March 12, 2024, engaging with faculty and admissions personnel. The visit, organized by the Health Career Access Program (HCAP), included a campus tour, a Q&A session, and a tour of Dr. Ben Bahr’s Alzheimer's Disease Research Lab. Twenty students, primarily in pre-med and pre-health programs, participated, including Vanna Locklear, who expressed her inspiration to pursue medical school as an older student. The visit aimed to introduce UNCP students to Wake Forest's programs and foster recruitment from UNCP, as students from UNCP have traditionally attended health professions programs at other universities. The Wake Forest delegation highlighted their physician assistant, Doctor of Medicine (MD), and biomedical science graduate programs. Dr. Holly Pilson, an alumna of Wake Forest and a Red Springs native, emphasized the visit's purpose to form better partnerships and recruit students from UNCP to Wake Forest.

title: Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist ends 2023 on positive note
summary: Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist concluded fiscal year 2023 with substantial financial growth, reporting significant increases in both core revenue and investment income. The not-for-profit healthcare system, which includes N.C. Baptist Hospital, Wake Forest University Health Sciences, Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center, and their affiliates, saw a turnaround from a $222.9 million loss in fiscal 2022 to $238.4 million in excess revenue over expenses in fiscal 2023. This improvement was largely due to nearly $106 million in investment income, contrasting with a $198.9 million loss in the previous year. Patient service revenue rose by 19.4% to $4.04 billion, and other revenue increased by 8.4% to $1.01 billion. Operating expenses went up by 12.9% to $4.9 billion, with significant rises in personnel costs, supplies, and services. The system also experienced growth in outpatient visits, emergency department visits, inpatient admissions, and operating-room cases.

title: How Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist team member’s heart condition inspired a career in research
summary: Stephanie Bowden, who was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) at 11 and had open-heart surgery at 14, was motivated by her condition to pursue a career in medical research. Currently employed at Wake Forest University School of Medicine, she concentrates on recruiting and retaining participants for clinical studies that affect cardiac health, motivated by her own experiences and a wish to contribute to progress in the area. Her research covers obesity, eating habits, diabetes, and vaccines. Bowden's transition from patient to healthcare professional was shaped by her favorable interactions with healthcare providers at Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center. Despite encountering new obstacles, including her mother's death due to HCM and her own diagnosis with atrial fibrillation, Bowden continues to be dedicated to her research career and to promoting heart health, especially among women, through efforts like the Go Red for Women campaign.

title: New wound healing research by Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine produces full thickness human ...
summary: A groundbreaking study by the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine, published in Science Translational Medicine on October 4, 2023, reveals a significant advancement in skin regeneration and wound healing. The research demonstrates the successful development of bioprinted skin that not only accelerates wound healing but also supports extracellular matrix remodeling, offering hope for complete wound recovery. This study, led by Anthony Atala, M.D., and Adam Jorgensen, M.D., Ph.D., marks a pivotal step in creating full thickness human skin by bioprinting all six major primary human cell types found in skin, using specialized hydrogels as bioink. The multi-layered skin includes the epidermis, dermis, and hypodermis, mirroring normal human tissue layers. When transplanted in pre-clinical settings, the bioprinted skin showed blood vessel formation, skin patterns, and normal tissue formation, alongside improved wound closure, reduced skin contraction, and increased collagen production to minimize scarring. This advancement opens new possibilities for treating burn victims, wounded warriors, and individuals with skin disorders, providing a path towards more natural healing outcomes.

title: Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine awarded $160 million 10-year US National Science Foundation ...
summary: The Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM) has received a $160 million grant from the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) under the NSF Engines Program, designed to promote regional innovation ecosystems. This initiative, spanning 10 years and named the NSF Engines: Piedmont Triad Regenerative Medicine Engine, aims to push forward the field of regenerative medicine by developing new technologies, enhancing workforce skills, and stimulating economic growth in the Piedmont Triad area. The project will see collaboration between WFIRM, Forsyth Technical Community College, North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, the RegenMed Development Organization, and Winston Salem State University. It seeks to tackle unaddressed needs in regenerative medicine such as biomaterials creation, cell biology, and in-space manufacturing, by setting up Innovation, Translation, and Education Cores (ITECs). This funding is expected to greatly benefit job creation, economic development, and the progress of regenerative medicine, with a focus on inclusivity and cultivating a proficient workforce in the sector.

title: Wake Forest University Health Sciences buys Innovation Quarter building for $38 million - Triad Business Journal
summary: Wake Forest University Health Sciences has bought a building in the Innovation Quarter for $38 million after renting it for seven years. The building, at 409 Vine Street, covers 0.76 acres and has a 194,370-square-foot area housing the Bowman Gray Center for Medical Education and Wake Forest University's Wake Downtown campus, which focuses on biomedical sciences and engineering programs. This acquisition from Wexford Winston-Building 60 LLC is a major investment in the Innovation Quarter, an essential part of downtown Winston-Salem's revival, creating $1.7 billion in economic impact for the city and Forsyth County last year. The Innovation Quarter is about to start its second development phase, continuing its role as a leading innovation district.

title: Headwinds and Whirlwinds: The Patient's Journey in Value-Based Cancer Care
hco: ASSOCIATION FOR VALUE BASED CANCER CARE INC
summary: The article discusses the challenges and transformations in value-based cancer care, focusing on the patient journey, cost management, and the shift towards personalized and empathetic care. It highlights the experiences of patients and healthcare professionals navigating the complexities of cancer treatment within a value-based care framework. The narrative underscores the emotional and financial burdens patients face, emphasizing the need for effective communication, empathy, and patient-centric care approaches. The article also addresses the rising costs of oncology care, the impact of social determinants of health, and the importance of integrating value-based practices in oncology to improve outcomes and manage costs. Furthermore, it showcases initiatives to enhance patient care through technology, the consideration of social determinants, and the cultivation of a healthcare culture focused on value and patient-centeredness. The overarching theme is the transformative potential of value-based care in oncology, advocating for a comprehensive approach that balances cost, quality, and patient experience.

title: What Is the ACR20 (American College of Rheumatology) Criteria?
summary: The ACR20 criteria, developed by the American College of Rheumatology, is a system used to measure the improvement of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients undergoing treatment. It assesses a 20% improvement in three out of five factors: patient's assessment of disease activity, physician's evaluation of patient's response to treatment, ability to perform daily activities, pain level, and inflammation based on blood tests. While crucial in clinical trials for new RA treatments, ACR20 is not commonly used in clinical practice, where doctors prefer other measures like the Clinical Disease Activity Index (CDAI) or the Disease Activity Score (DAS-28). The ACR20 is significant for FDA drug approval processes, ensuring that only effective medications reach the market. However, for patient care, rheumatologists focus on different metrics to evaluate treatment efficacy.

title: Robert Schoen Designated Master of the American College of Rheumatology
summary: Robert Schoen, MD, MBA, a clinical professor of medicine and nursing at Yale School of Medicine, has been honored as a Master of the American College of Rheumatology (ACR), one of the ACR's highest recognitions. This prestigious title is awarded to members over 65 who have significantly contributed to the field of rheumatology through scholarly achievements or service. Schoen, a graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, completed his residency in internal medicine at Yale New Haven Hospital and his rheumatology training at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School. He is known for his commitment to patients in New Haven County, maintaining a full-time clinical practice alongside his research on infectious arthritis, currently focusing on chronic chikungunya arthritis in Brazil. Schoen has authored 100 scientific publications and is a Fellow of the American College of Medicine and president of the Connecticut Rheumatology Association. He has also been the course director for the Yale International Rheumatology State-of-the-Art Symposium since 2022.

title: C. Kent Kwoh named American College of Rheumatology Master
summary: C. Kent Kwoh, MD, has been named a Master of the American College of Rheumatology, a prestigious designation awarded to members over 65 who have significantly contributed to rheumatology through scholarly achievement and/or service. As director of the University of Arizona Arthritis Center and the Charles A.L. and Suzanne M. Stephens Endowed Chair in Rheumatology, Kwoh's research primarily focuses on osteoarthritis, aiming to identify risk factors and understand its progression. His work has led to the realization that osteoarthritis comprises a group of similar diseases, potentially paving the way for more personalized treatments. Kwoh, who also serves as chief of the Division of Rheumatology within the Department of Medicine and is a professor of medicine and medical imaging, was recommended for this honor by three past presidents of the ACR, highlighting his significant contributions as an educator, clinical researcher, and volunteer within the field.

title: Management Guidelines | Rheumatoid Arthritis | Clinical Guidance
summary: The text provides comprehensive clinical guidance on managing Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and treatment to minimize radiographic damage, disability, and overall costs. It highlights a shift from the traditional 'therapeutic pyramid' approach to a more aggressive treatment strategy, including early use of methotrexate (MTX), combination therapy, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors, which have shown to reduce morbidity and mortality by mitigating systemic inflammation's cardiovascular risks. The guidelines advocate for early referral to a rheumatologist, initial therapy choices based on disease severity, and a 'treat-to-target' strategy aiming for remission or low disease activity. The American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) guidelines are discussed, focusing on pharmacotherapy, non-pharmacologic management, and the importance of vaccinations in patients with RA. The document underscores the necessity of personalized, aggressive treatment plans and ongoing reassessment to improve long-term outcomes in RA patients.

title: ACR Guidelines for Integrative Approaches to Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis
summary: The American College of Rheumatology (ACR) has released new guidelines for an integrative approach to managing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), emphasizing the use of exercise, rehabilitation, diet, and other non-pharmacological interventions alongside traditional disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). This holistic strategy aims to improve physical function and alleviate pain, with a significant focus on patient-centered care. The guidelines were developed after a comprehensive review of the current evidence, aided by input from a diverse panel of experts and feedback from patients. Among the recommendations, consistent exercise received a strong endorsement, while other suggestions for managing RA through rehabilitation programs, following a Mediterranean-style diet, and considering additional integrative interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy, massage, and acupuncture were conditionally recommended based on their potential benefits and minimal risks. These guidelines are intended to complement existing pharmacological treatments, promoting a shared decision-making process between patients and healthcare providers.

title: American College of Rheumatology Reading Room | Brepocitinib Makes Big Impact in Psoriatic Arthritis
summary: Brepocitinib, a dual inhibitor of JAK-1 and TYK-2, was shown to significantly improve symptoms of Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA) over 52 weeks compared to a placebo. In this phase IIb study with 218 participants, some received a placebo while others received different doses of brepocitinib. By week 16, the 30 mg and 60 mg brepocitinib groups showed significantly better ACR20 responses than the placebo group. Additionally, ACR50 and other disease activity scores showed favorable outcomes up to one year. Brepocitinib had a generally good tolerance and a safety profile in line with previous studies. Led by Philip Mease, MD, the study aimed to investigate the benefits of combining JAK-1 and TYK-2 inhibition, offering a comprehensive PsA treatment, including for skin symptoms.

title: Deborah Dyett Desir, MD '80, Elected President of American College of Rheumatology
summary: Deborah Dyett Desir, MD, an associate professor of clinical medicine (rheumatology) at Yale School of Medicine, was elected President of the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) during its annual meeting on November 14, 2023. As the first African American and first woman of color to hold this position, Desir aims to advance the careers of women in rheumatology, enhance resources for members in solo and small private practices, advocate for increased research funding, support ACR's advocacy efforts, ensure the fiscal health of the College, and continue integrating diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts across ACR's initiatives. With over three decades of experience in clinical medicine, Desir has a history of advocating for diversity in the medical workforce and healthcare equity. She has served on the ACR's executive committee and various other committees, and has been involved in leadership roles within the medical community, including the presidency of the New Haven County Medical Association.

title: Rising BMI Led to Rise in Rheumatic Disease Risk
summary: High BMI significantly increases the risk of developing five different rheumatic diseases, with a stronger risk factor for women, especially in cases of psoriatic arthropathy and gout. This was determined through a study using data from the UK Biobank cohort and employing Mendelian randomization to assess causality. The study found that a one standard deviation increase in BMI raised the incidence rate for rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthropathy, gout, and inflammatory spondylitis. The risk was notably higher for gout in individuals with different baseline BMIs and for osteoarthritis in premenopausal versus postmenopausal women. The findings suggest that interventions to decrease BMI could significantly impact the rates of these diseases, highlighting the importance of maintaining a normal BMI range to prevent gout and possibly other rheumatic diseases.

title: RemeGen to Present Telitacicept Phase III Clinical Trial Results for Rheumatoid Arthritis Patients in a Late-Breaking ...
summary: RemeGen Co., Ltd. will present the Phase III clinical trial results of telitacicept for Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) patients during a late-breaking abstract oral presentation session at the American College of Rheumatology. The study, which was a randomized, double-blind trial, compared the efficacy and safety of telitacicept 160 mg to a placebo in RA patients who had inadequate responses to Methotrexate (MTX). The trial met all its primary endpoints, demonstrating that the telitacicept group had a comparable safety profile to the control group. This presentation is part of ACR Convergence 2023, taking place on November 15 from 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. (PST) at the San Diego Convention Center in California. Telitacicept is a novel fusion protein drug developed by RemeGen for treating autoimmune diseases by targeting and inhibiting the overexpression of two cytokines, BLyS and APRIL, to prevent abnormal B cell differentiation.

title: Yale Advances Rheumatology Research and Practice at American College of Rheumatology Convergence 2023
summary: Yale School of Medicine made significant contributions to the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) 2023 Convergence meeting held in San Diego from November 10-15, 2023. Yale faculty and trainees actively participated, presenting research studies, moderating events, and delivering invited lectures. Notably, Evelyn Hsieh, MD, PhD, co-chaired the ACR Global Rheumatology Summit and moderated sessions focusing on global access to essential medicines and rheumatology research priorities. Clinical Fellow Mario Felix, MD, co-moderated a session on industry collaboration, while Sang T Kim, MD, PhD, discussed biomarkers for steroid resistance in immune checkpoint inhibitor-induced arthritis. Fotios Koumpouras, MD, led sessions on education and wellness inspirations and a case-based primary care curriculum. Additional contributions included presentations on pre-biologic infection screening, mineral metabolism in COVID-19, spondyloarthritis diagnosis and outcomes, and educational interventions for rheumatic disease self-management in Uganda. This engagement underscores Yale's leadership in advancing rheumatology research and practice.

title: NCCN Foundation Announces Recipients for 2024 Young Investigator Awards Honoring Future Leaders of Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) and the NCCN Foundation have announced the winners of the 2024 Young Investigator Awards (YIA), recognizing five early-career oncology investigators from NCCN's Member Institutions for their promising contributions to cancer research. Each awardee will receive up to $150,000 over two years to support their projects, which range from exploring treatment resistance in osteosarcoma to neuroplasticity-based cognitive remediation for cancer-related cognitive impairment. The YIA program, a cornerstone of NCCN's efforts to advance cancer care, has awarded over $11.1 million to 75 researchers since 2011. The results of these studies will be presented at future NCCN Annual Conferences. This year's awards are supported by the NCCN Foundation and various donors, including AbbVie, Daiichi Sankyo, and Pfizer Inc.

title: NCCN Expands Focus on Quality of Life and Supportive Care with New Guides for People with Cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has introduced new guidelines aimed at enhancing the quality of life for cancer patients by focusing on palliative care, managing fatigue, and addressing distress during cancer care. These resources, funded by the NCCN Foundation, are designed to support not only the patients but also their families and caregivers, emphasizing a comprehensive approach to cancer treatment that includes the management of physical and emotional symptoms. Available for free, these guidelines are accessible via NCCN's website or their patient app, providing evidence-based recommendations and encouraging conversations about the patient's needs and values. The guidelines are part of NCCN's broader effort to offer supportive care resources and have been recognized for their quality and reliability in providing cancer care information.

title: NCCN releases new resource to help families understand pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma, part of award-winning patient ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has released a new guide titled "NCCN Guidelines for Patients: Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children," aimed at helping families understand pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma. This guide, part of the NCCN's award-winning patient information series, provides a detailed analysis of treatment options, benefits, and risks associated with care approaches for this highly curable childhood cancer. Available for free online and via the NCCN Patient Guides for Cancer App, this resource is designed to offer up-to-date information and support to families facing a pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosis. The guide is based on the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology, renowned for their comprehensive and regularly updated clinical recommendations. This initiative is part of NCCN's efforts to improve and facilitate quality, effective, and accessible cancer care for all patients.

title: New resource from National Comprehensive Cancer Network breaks the silence on common but lesser-known cause ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has published a new guideline for patients on preventing and treating cancer-associated blood clots, also known as venous thromboembolism (VTE), which is a major cause of death in cancer patients. The guideline, available for free at NCCN.org/patientguidelines, aims to educate patients and caregivers about the risks, symptoms, and treatments of blood clots in cancer patients. It translates medical recommendations into understandable terms and is based on more than 600 peer-reviewed research articles. The guideline highlights that cancer patients are at a higher risk of developing blood clots and emphasizes the importance of awareness and communication between patients and healthcare providers regarding this risk. It also discusses advancements in risk assessment tools and safer, easier-to-use medications for preventing and treating blood clots. This resource is part of NCCN's efforts to improve patient care and support through accessible, evidence-based information.

title: NCCN Summit Navigates Solutions for Financial and Other Cancer-Related Hardships
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) hosted its annual Patient Advocacy Summit to address financial and other hardships related to cancer care. The summit gathered a diverse group of experts, including patients, advocates, policymakers, healthcare providers, and data analysts, to discuss the role of navigation in cancer care. Navigation services were highlighted as crucial for reducing economic burdens and disparities in care. The event featured best practice presentations and introduced an online toolkit for patient navigation resources. Keynote speakers and panel discussions emphasized the importance of holistic care, addressing financial toxicity, and the need for equitable access to cancer treatments. The summit also explored the increasing complexity of cancer care delivery and the essential role of navigators in ensuring patients do not face their journey alone. The conversation touched on the impact of financial hardships on treatment outcomes and the importance of addressing inequities in care to improve outcomes across different demographics.

title: NCCN Foundation Announces 2024 Young Investigator Award Recipients in Cancer Research
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network® (NCCN®) and the NCCN Foundation® have announced the 2024 Young Investigator Award (YIA) recipients, recognizing five promising oncology researchers from its Member Institutions. These awards, part of the NCCN Oncology Research Program, provide up to $150,000 over two years to support innovative cancer research. This year's projects range from exploring treatment-resistant osteosarcoma and pancreatic cancer vulnerabilities to employing deep learning for primary CNS lymphoma analysis, developing novel combination therapy for untreated melanoma, and cognitive remediation for cancer-related impairments. Crystal S. Denlinger, MD, CEO of NCCN, highlighted the significance of supporting emerging researchers to advance cancer understanding and care. The YIA program, with over $11.1 million distributed to 75 researchers since 2011, is a critical investment in the future of oncology, fostering treatment innovation and advancement. The results of these studies are expected to offer valuable insights at future NCCN Annual Conferences.

title: NCCN publishes new resource to help patients understand quick-moving type of breast cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) released a new resource on April 24, 2023, aimed at helping patients understand inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), a rare and aggressive form of the disease. This addition to NCCN's patient resources library provides crucial information on how IBC differs from more common breast cancers in terms of disease progression and treatment approaches. The guidelines detail that treatment for IBC typically involves systemic therapy to shrink the tumor, followed by surgery and radiation therapy. Despite IBC being diagnosed at a younger age and having a propensity to advance rapidly, the guidelines aim to empower patients with knowledge about their treatment options and the improved survival rates in recent years. Available for free online, these patient guidelines, along with other educational materials, are part of NCCN's efforts to improve patient care and support through accessible, expert-vetted information.

title: Annual Comfort Kit Assembly by Barsz Gowie Amon & Fultz Supports Local Cancer Patients
summary: Barsz Gowie Amon & Fultz (BGA&F), in partnership with the HEADstrong Foundation, assembled 180 comfort kits for cancer patients, demonstrating their commitment to supporting individuals and families during challenging times. These kits, which include items like socks, lotion, tissues, gift cards, and activity books, are designed to provide comfort to cancer patients during their hospital stays. The initiative is part of an ongoing relationship between BGA&F, a full-service accounting firm with offices in Media, Delaware County, and Chadds Ford, Chester County, and the HEADstrong Foundation, which offers residential, financial, and emotional support to those affected by cancer. This effort underscores both organizations' dedication to making a difference in the lives of cancer patients, one comfort kit at a time.

title: Hofstra Athletics And HEADstrong Foundation Partner For 27 Challenge
summary: Hofstra University Athletics has partnered with the HEADstrong Foundation for the 27 Challenge, a campaign aimed at raising awareness and funds for cancer-affected lives. The challenge, running from March 11 through April, encourages Hofstra student-athletes to do 27 more of something, as a tribute to Nick Colleluori, a former Hofstra lacrosse player and HEADstrong founder, who wore the number 27 and battled Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. The initiative honors Colleluori's legacy, reflecting his vision of providing support to cancer patients and their families. Since its inception in 2006, HEADstrong has raised over $30 million and assisted more than 30,000 families. Hofstra Athletics, highlighting the leadership of Chase Patterson and the Hofstra SAAC, aims to not only bring awareness to HEADstrong's mission but also to contribute to improving the lives of those affected by cancer.

title: Bombers come together to support lacrosse community cause
summary: The Ithaca College men's lacrosse team is supporting the HEADstrong Foundation this season by shaving their heads to raise funds for families affected by cancer, aiming to raise $30,000 for the Hope Street Foundation, which will then donate to HEADstrong. The initiative has seen 40 of 48 players shave their heads, raising $40,000 so far. The HEADstrong Foundation, founded by Hofstra men’s lacrosse player Nick Colleluori who died of cancer, focuses on raising awareness and funds for cancer research. The Bombers have a personal connection to the foundation through assistant coach Torin Varn, a Hofstra alum. The fundraising effort, organized by first-year midfielder Aidan Friedman, aims to continue in the future. The team's involvement demonstrates their unity and commitment to supporting cancer research and families affected by cancer, enhancing team chemistry and pride in their collective effort.

title: College coach to run over 1,100 miles to support HEADstrong Foundation
summary: The HEADstrong Foundation, a nonprofit based in the Philadelphia area dedicated to improving the lives of those impacted by cancer, has announced the Relentless 27 Run. Ian Farley, a Team HEADstrong ambassador and the head men’s lacrosse coach at Mount Saint Mary College, will run 1,175 miles along the Eastern Seaboard starting July 31 to support the foundation. Farley is motivated by the foundation's effects and the story of its founder, Nicholas Colleluori, and aims to push himself both physically and mentally to aid as many people as possible. The journey will commence in Mount Pleasant, S.C., and conclude in New York City, with Farley taking part in the NYC Ice Cream Social Half Marathon on Aug. 26. The HEADstrong Foundation provides financial, emotional, and residential support to those battling cancer, including services through Nick’s House in Swarthmore.

title: VMI Lacrosse to host HEADstrong Tournament - Virginia Military Institute
summary: The VMI lacrosse program is set to host its second annual Fall HEADstrong Tournament on October 29 at Drill Field #2 on North Post, welcoming Washington & Lee and Hood for a three-way tournament. The event is more than just a series of lacrosse games; it serves as a fundraiser for the HEADstrong Foundation, which provides financial, residential, and emotional support to families affected by cancer. Last year, the event raised over $15,000. The HEADstrong Foundation was founded by Nick Colleluori, a Hofstra University lacrosse player diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma, who passed away in 2006. Since its inception in 2007, HEADstrong has raised more than $24 million and assisted nearly 23,000 families. The tournament emphasizes community and the sport's growth, while also supporting a cause closely connected to the lacrosse community.

title: Lacrosse All Stars and the HEADstrong Foundation Announce Strategic Partnership
summary: Lacrosse All Stars and the HEADstrong Foundation have formed a strategic partnership to support families battling cancer. This collaboration will highlight the HEADstrong Foundation's efforts through the Attack Cancer campaign, involving lacrosse players nationwide in fundraising activities. The campaign, now in its third year, aims to raise $300,000 in 2023, with Team Attack Cancer members already contributing over $40,000. Spearheaded by Ken Clausen, the initiative will feature compelling stories of athletes raising awareness and funds for cancer treatment support. Lacrosse All Stars, established in 2008, focuses on promoting the sport and its stories across various media platforms. The HEADstrong Foundation, founded in 2006 by Nicholas Colleluori, a Division I lacrosse player diagnosed with cancer, has raised over $27 million to support cancer-affected families in the U.S.

title: HEADstrong Foundation Nick Colleluori Classics To Be Held This October At Hofstra
summary: The HEADstrong Foundation Nick Colleluori Classic, an event focused on lacrosse and raising awareness, will be held by Hofstra University's men's and women's lacrosse teams this October at James M. Shuart Stadium. The men's event is set for Saturday, October 7, with teams from Hofstra, Bucknell, Johns Hopkins, Lehigh, and Monmouth participating. The women's classic is on Sunday, October 8, featuring Hofstra, Iona, La Salle, and Long Island University. Both days will feature a HEADstrong Foundation presentation. Additionally, the Hofstra women's lacrosse team will play in other autumn matches, facing Harvard, UMass Lowell, Michigan, and Stony Brook throughout October.

title: What is Attack Cancer?
summary: Attack Cancer is a national campaign by HEADstrong, targeting youth and high school student athletes to support families affected by cancer. Participants pledge their sports performance, like goals or assists, to raise funds. With 1388 student athletes involved, approximately $225,000 has been raised in 2023. Ken Clausen, a notable figure in the lacrosse community and former professional player, oversees the campaign. Additionally, Team Attack Cancer, comprising various age groups, participates in events to raise money. One such team is aiming to raise $40,000 at a Lake Placid event, featuring top high school players committed to prestigious programs. The campaign emphasizes the lacrosse community's involvement but is open to athletes from all sports.

title: Delco Day is back for an 8th time
summary: Delco Day is returning for its eighth year, celebrating Delaware County and raising funds for the HEADstrong Foundation, a local nonprofit aiding families with cancer diagnoses. The event, initiated by the Delco Live podcast in 2016, has evolved from a small gathering featuring punk rock bands to a significant charity event. Scheduled for June 10, in homage to the 610 area code, the entry fee is $6.10. This year's festivities will be held at JT Brewski's in Secane starting at 2 p.m., featuring nine musical acts across two stages. The event also includes a swearing-in ceremony for non-native Delconians and speeches from local officials and previous HEADstrong recipients. The fundraising goal is over $25,000, with state officials expected to declare Delco Day a state holiday.

title: FLCC, MCC play charity lacrosse game to combat cancer
summary: Athletes from Monroe Community College (MCC) and Finger Lakes Community College (FLCC) participated in a charity men's lacrosse game on March 31, 2023, to support the HEADstrong Foundation, which aims to improve the quality of life for those affected by cancer. This event was part of the "Attack Cancer" games, a series designed to allow athletes to contribute to the fight against cancer through their sports performances. Participants wore special "Attack Cancer" shirts during warm-ups to signify their unity in the cause.

title: UVA Wise Opens High-Tech Nursing Center
hco: RECTOR AND VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
summary: The University of Virginia's College at Wise recently opened a $16.6 million, 28,500-square-foot nursing education center to improve nurse training and healthcare in Southwest Virginia. This new center, previously the college's main library, has been updated to feature modern classrooms, skilled-nursing labs, simulation labs, examination rooms, group study areas, offices, and a large lecture hall. Named the Don R. Pippin & John C. Wyllie Hall, it seeks to alleviate the nursing shortage and enhance health outcomes in the area by drawing more students to nursing. The opening was attended by UVA President Jim Ryan, UVA Rector Robert D. Hardie, among others. Nursing students, like senior Sarah Slemp, praised the expanded space and new equipment, noting its benefits to their education and practice.

title: New coalition targets pharmacy benefit managers
summary: A new coalition named "Patients Not PBMs" has been formed to address the rising prescription drug prices and the role of pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs). This group includes patient advocates, business leaders, and independent pharmacists, and aims to advocate for laws that enhance transparency and accountability in the PBM sector. PBMs, which act as intermediaries in negotiating drug prices among manufacturers, pharmacies, and health plans, have faced criticism for increasing healthcare costs and preferring big retail pharmacies. The coalition is backing four proposed laws to regulate PBM activities, such as mandating health insurers to reveal the usage of drug rebates and capping PBMs' earnings from insurers. This initiative follows previous unsuccessful attempts to reform PBMs, despite having been passed by the Senate.

title: Associations Partner to Address Vaccine Uptake
summary: The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases, together with the Association of Immunization Managers, the National Association of County and City Health Officials, and Fraym, a geomapping company, have started a pilot program to understand why U.S. adults resist vaccines for respiratory diseases. They plan to use public data and surveys to create data visualizations showing community attitudes towards vaccines, helping healthcare workers to devise effective communication and strategies to increase vaccine acceptance. This initiative aims to address complex vaccine resistance beyond mere political affiliations, considering issues like racial disparities and access to healthcare. Funded by NFID reserves and led by a steering committee from the participating organizations, the program will test its methods in select communities until the end of 2024, hoping for wider implementation. The ultimate aim is to provide public officials and immunization advocates with specific strategies to raise vaccination rates in diverse U.S. communities.

title: Data-Driven Approach to Increasing US Vaccine Uptake
summary: The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) and Fraym are working together on a trial program to increase vaccine acceptance in the US using data-focused methods. This project is in collaboration with the Association of Immunization Managers (AIM) and the National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO) to offer very specific insights that help public health participants. Its goal is to enhance public health communication and vaccination services by identifying vaccination attitudes, actions, and obstacles. This initiative is part of NFID's wider aim to educate and involve different groups in preventing and treating diseases, tackling the delay in reaching US public health vaccination targets. NFID's dedication includes providing financial support for the trial to boost confidence in vaccines and promote health fairness.

title: Former TN vaccine official settles lawsuit against state for $150K
summary: A former Tennessee state vaccine official, Dr. Michelle Fiscus, settled a federal defamation lawsuit against the state for $150,000. Fiscus was fired in 2021 after promoting COVID-19 vaccination for teenagers during the pandemic's peak. She alleged that state officials made false and defamatory statements about her, questioning her honesty and morality, as part of a smear campaign. The settlement came after both parties agreed to dismiss the case following court-mandated mediation. Fiscus now serves as the chief medical officer for the Association for Immunization Managers. The Tennessee Department of Health and the state's Attorney General's Office declined to comment on the settlement.

title: The Role of Oncology Pharmacists Is Evolving in Early-Stage Breast Cancer Treatment Optimization
summary: The role of oncology pharmacists in treating early-stage breast cancer is changing, with significant progress in targeted systemic therapies shaping the field. Danielle Roman, PharmD, BCOP, emphasizes the growing range of therapies available, each with its own criteria and unique side effects, highlighting the vital role pharmacists play in choosing and managing treatments. Major developments include using CDK4/6 inhibitors with endocrine therapy for hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative high-risk early-stage breast cancer, and using the PD1 inhibitor pembrolizumab for triple-negative breast cancer, among others. The fast evolution of treatment options highlights the importance of pharmacists in educating healthcare teams and promoting patient awareness. Roman recommends focusing on selecting the right patients for each therapy, handling side effects, and managing treatment logistics as key areas for pharmacist involvement in patient counseling and educating the care team.

title: Navigating Operational Challenges With Bispecifics in R/R MM: Insights From HOPA 2024
summary: Kirollos Hanna, PharmD, discussed challenges and strategies for operationalizing bispecifics in relapsed or refractory Multiple Myeloma (R/R MM) at the HOPA 2024 conference. He highlighted three models for initiating bispecifics: large institutions with established processes, smaller systems developing external relationships for patient initiation and maintenance, and institutions not ready for bispecific administration, risking patient loss. Challenges include building relationships for patient support, managing adverse events, and ensuring emergency departments are equipped for complications like cytokine release syndrome (CRS) and immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS). Hanna emphasized the importance of open communication between healthcare systems to develop processes that ensure continuity of care for patients navigating the complexities of healthcare and bispecific therapies.

title: Pediatric Cancer Survivor Shares How 'Perspective Is Everything'
summary: A pediatric cancer survivor, Kelsey Tainsh, emphasized the importance of perspective during her keynote address at the Hematology/Oncology Pharmacy Association Annual Conference 2023. Diagnosed with brain cancer at 5 and facing a recurrence and a stroke at 15, Tainsh shared her journey of recovery, highlighting the role of attitude and perspective in facing life's challenges. Despite the physical limitations from the stroke, she expressed gratitude for her life and the support from healthcare professionals, including pharmacists, who played a significant role in her cancer journey. Tainsh's story underlines the impact of healthcare providers in patient recovery and the power of a positive outlook.

title: Staff Pharmacists Discuss Updated Carboplatin Drug Shortage Mitigation Strategies at the University of Illinois at ...
summary: After carboplatin, a key chemotherapy drug, was reported in short supply in March 2023, staff pharmacists at the University of Illinois at Chicago Oncology Clinic Pharmacy implemented strategies to mitigate the impact on patient care. The shortage, caused by production delays from manufacturers like Accord and Pfizer, prompted the pharmacy to adjust inventory management, prioritize patients, and alter treatment regimens. Strategies included daily inventory assessments, prioritizing patients based on treatment intent, modifying drug regimens, and intensifying procurement efforts, even at significantly higher costs from third-party wholesalers. These measures aimed to maintain patient care amidst the shortage, reflecting the critical role of pharmacists in managing drug shortages in oncology settings.

title: Emerging Treatment Options and Considerations in Waldenström Macroglobulinemia
summary: Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM) is a rare type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by abnormal white blood cells in the bone marrow, with a higher incidence in men and a median diagnosis age of 72. It's marked by lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, bone marrow infiltration, and IgM monoclonal protein presence. Symptoms can include central nervous system involvement, lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly, peripheral cytopenia, and B-symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and significant weight loss. WM may also lead to complications like hyperviscosity syndrome, cryoglobulinemia, and peripheral neuropathy. Treatment primarily involves rituximab, with recent approvals for BTK inhibitors ibrutinib and zanubrutinib. Treatment choice is influenced by disease characteristics, patient and provider preferences, and genomic testing for MYD88 or CXCR4 gene mutations. Pharmacists play a crucial role in recognizing and managing treatment complications, including hyperviscosity syndrome and IgM-related issues.

title: Campaña educativa destaca la prevención del melanoma en Puerto Rico • WIPR
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: For the second consecutive year, health organizations in Puerto Rico have united to promote skin cancer and melanoma prevention through the educational campaign "El Melanoma puede estar en Cualquier Lugar." This initiative responds to a yearly increase of 3.3 percent in melanoma incidence, as reported by the Central Cancer Registry of Puerto Rico. Melanoma, characterized by the uncontrolled growth of melanocytes, is notably dangerous due to its high potential for spread. Bristol Myers Squibb, alongside the Skin Foundation, the Dermatological Society of Puerto Rico, the American Cancer Society of Puerto Rico, the Association of Medical Hematology and Oncology of PR, and the Puerto Rican Cancer League, leads this campaign to educate and raise awareness among the population. In 2021, there were 147 diagnosed cases of melanoma and 22 deaths in Puerto Rico. The campaign emphasizes the importance of sun protection, regular skin examinations, and being vigilant for new moles or changes in existing ones. Treatment options vary by the stage and location of the melanoma, including surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and targeted drug therapy. The Skin Foundation and the Dermatological Society of Puerto Rico urge immediate action to reduce melanoma risk, such as using sunscreen, seeking shade, and avoiding tanning beds. For more information about the campaign and melanoma, visit https://melanomapr.com.

title: Lo mejor de la Convención de Asociación de Hematología y Oncología Médica de Puerto Rico - #MSP
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: The article highlights the best moments of the Medical Hematology and Oncology Association Convention in Puerto Rico, emphasizing the discussion on prostate cancer and new immuno-oncology therapies. It invites readers to visit their website for full coverage of the event, positioning itself as a key resource for healthcare professionals, patients, and anyone interested in the latest developments in medical oncology and hematology.

title: Convención anual de la Asociación de Hematología y Oncología Médica de Puerto Rico
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: The annual convention of the Puerto Rico Association of Hematology and Medical Oncology (AHOMPR) was highlighted by Dr. Alexis Cruz Chacón, who shared insights on the progress in immuno-oncology for treating patients in Puerto Rico. This event serves as a platform for medical professionals, health practitioners, and patients to engage and learn about the latest advancements in oncology. The convention aims to foster knowledge exchange and update healthcare professionals on innovative cancer treatments, emphasizing the significance of immuno-oncology in patient care.

title: Investigan la escasez de tratamientos de quimioterapias para pacientes de cáncer
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: The Health Commission of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico investigates the shortage of chemotherapy treatments for cancer patients, highlighting that the island has only 114 oncologists and hematologists for about 16,000 patients. The executive director of the Puerto Rico Association of Hematology and Medical Oncology, Jocelyn Serrano, mentions that, despite the shortage of medications, there are alternative treatments available, although with possible delays. Roxana Rosario, from the Health Insurance Administration, assures that services and treatments for cancer patients are maintained without interruptions, emphasizing the importance of health care. The president of the Commission emphasizes the need to identify the causes of the shortage and look for alternatives to ensure the health of cancer patients.

title: "Para el cáncer de próstata tenemos variedad de tratamientos que podemos brindar a los pacientes"
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: For prostate cancer, there are multiple treatments available that go beyond chemotherapy and other conventional procedures, as explained by Dr. Liza Vázquez, a hematologist oncologist. These therapies include radical prostatectomy, radiotherapy, cryotherapy, and hormone or androgen suppression therapy, which aims to reduce the levels of hormones that stimulate the growth of malignant cells. Treatments such as chemotherapy and immunotherapy are also mentioned for more advanced cases. Dr. Vázquez emphasizes the importance of early detection of prostate cancer to improve the chances of recovery and offers multiple treatment options. Prostate cancer mainly affects men over 65, especially African Americans and those with a family history, recommending screening tests starting at the age of 60.

title: #ProgramaEspecial | Leucemia y linfoma: diagnóstico y tratamiento
hco: ASOCIACION HEMATOLOGIA Y ONCOLOGIA MEDICA DE PUERTO RICO
summary: The text announces a special program scheduled for Tuesday, June 4, 2024, focusing on the diagnosis and treatment of leukemia and lymphoma. Dr. Christian Rodríguez, a hematologist-oncologist and the president of the Education Committee of the Hematology and Medical Oncology Association of Puerto Rico, will share insights from the annual convention in Río Grande, Puerto Rico. The program aims to inform medical professionals, patients, and health professionals about these diseases. Additionally, the text provides information about the Medicina y Salud Pública platform, which offers news, articles, continuous education, podcasts, and events related to various medical fields for healthcare professionals and patients.

title: Pinnacle buys Texas research group with focus on NASH trials
summary: Pinnacle Clinical Research, part of the LongueVue Capital portfolio, has acquired the South Texas Research Institute (STRI), known for its focus on clinical research into nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). This acquisition gives Pinnacle access to STRI's six standalone and dedicated sites in Edinburg, Texas, specializing in hepatology, particularly nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and NASH. STRI, with two NASH enrollment sites in the U.S., has successfully enrolled diverse patient populations, especially focusing on the Hispanic demographic in the Rio Grande Valley, historically underrepresented in clinical trials. The financial details of the deal were not disclosed. Rashmee Patil, M.D., the founder and CEO of STRI, has been named CEO of the combined business.

title: Affiliates | About Wake Forest
summary: Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, has a network of affiliates that improve its educational and community services. These include 88.5 WFDD, an NPR affiliate and the only public radio station in the Piedmont Triad, located at the Reynolda Campus. Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist, a top academic health system, offers advanced medical treatment. The network also includes the Graylyn International Conference Center, a historic hotel and modern conference facility, and Innovation Quarter, a 200-acre technology park focusing on biomedical, material sciences, and IT. Additionally, Reynolda Gardens, Reynolda House Museum of American Art, and Reynolda Village provide cultural and recreational areas. These affiliates support Wake Forest University's mission and the well-being and development of the wider community.

title: This NC region is a hub for fast-growing tech and science startups
summary: The North Carolina (NC) region, next to the Research Triangle, is becoming a major center for technology and science startups, especially in the life sciences area. Known as the Carolina Core, this region is flourishing with the growth of companies such as Syngenta and the development of the Wake Forest Innovation Quarter, which offers a supportive setting for startups through a mix of offices, labs, and living spaces. The Innovation Quarter plans to double its size, strengthening the region's status as a leading area for life sciences construction. This expansion is backed by a $160 million investment from the National Science Foundation into the Piedmont Triad Regenerative Medicine Engine (REGEN), aimed at enhancing economic growth and creating jobs in the tech and science sectors. The region's attractiveness is also boosted by its quality of life, educational opportunities, and strategic location, drawing talent and investment nationwide and marking its rise as a new economic powerhouse in North Carolina.

title: Research Study on Novel Rehab Program for Heart Failure Patients, Led by Wake Forest University School of Medicine ...
summary: Wake Forest University School of Medicine is expanding its research study on a novel rehabilitation program for older heart failure patients to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn, Illinois. This study, funded by a $30 million grant from the National Institute of Aging, aims to reduce rehospitalizations and mortality in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), a common condition in older adults with limited treatment options. The Phase III study, REHAB-HFpEF, led by Professor Dalane Kitzman, will enroll 880 patients across 20 sites nationwide. Preliminary findings from a previous phase showed significant improvements in physical function from a tailored rehabilitation program starting during hospital recovery. This expansion to Chicago will allow the inclusion of more patients, particularly from vulnerable and underserved populations, potentially changing clinical practice and improving health outcomes.

title: WFIRM leads $40M regenerative medicine initiative for the wounded and beyond
summary: The Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM), under Wake Forest University School of Medicine, has been chosen to lead the Armed Forces Institute of Regenerative Medicine (AFIRM) Consortium. This initiative, backed by a $40 million award from the Defense Health Agency for five years, aims to advance regenerative medicine solutions for battlefield injuries and eventually for public use. Regenerative medicine leverages the body's natural healing processes to repair or replace damaged tissues and organs. WFIRM's leadership in this field is established through its management of two previous AFIRM consortia since 2008, which have resulted in over 20 clinical studies for new treatments addressing burns and injuries to limbs, genitourinary systems, faces, and skulls. The 2023 initiative, supported by the US Army Medical Research and Development Command and the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium, seeks to accelerate the development of clinical therapies in areas like craniofacial and extremity regeneration, genitourinary/lower abdomen, skin and wound healing, on-demand blood, and cellular therapies for trauma, through strong partnerships. This consortium includes academic and industry partners, aiming to improve the lives of wounded service members, veterans, and the general public.

title: Research shows human behavior guided by fast changes in dopamine levels
summary: A study by Wake Forest University School of Medicine, published in Science Advances, reveals that dopamine, a neurotransmitter known for its role in positive emotions, also plays a crucial part in learning from both positive and negative experiences. This discovery was made through a novel approach using fast-scan cyclic voltammetry paired with machine learning to measure dopamine levels in real-time during deep brain stimulation surgery. The research found that dopamine levels fluctuate rapidly in response to rewards and punishments, encoding prediction errors that help the brain adapt its behavior. This process occurs on slightly different timescales for rewarding versus punishing experiences, suggesting separate pathways in the brain for each. These findings could lead to a better understanding of psychiatric and neurological disorders by revealing how dopamine signaling is altered in these conditions. The study was supported by multiple grants from the National Institutes of Health.

title: Program aims to ignite youth excitement in data science careers | Wake Forest News
summary: Wake Forest University is set to host the 2nd annual Florence Nightingale Day on April 20, aiming to spark interest among middle and high school students in the Piedmont region towards careers in statistics and data science. The free event, taking place in Manchester Hall, will feature hands-on activities designed to make statistics and data science interactive and fun, such as experimenting with catapults for experimental design concepts and building classification algorithms. It also offers an opportunity for students to experience a college environment and interact with data science experts, including a diverse panel discussing their career experiences. The program highlights the importance of early exposure to statistics and data science, reflecting on Florence Nightingale's significant contributions to the field. It is co-sponsored by Wake Forest's Department of Biostatistics and Data Science and the Department of Statistical Sciences, in partnership with Winston-Salem State University, aiming for a lasting community impact.

title: Long-lived Single- and Multi-organ Tissue Equivalent (OTE) Platforms to Model the Response of Human Tissues to ...
summary: The Long-lived Single- and Multi-organ Tissue Equivalent (OTE) Platforms investigation aims to model the response of human tissues to various stressors encountered in space, such as space radiation, microgravity, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and ultrafine dusts like lunar regolith. This research utilizes innovative human organ tissue equivalents (OTEs) to gain insight into the biological effects of these stressors on human physiology, focusing on mechanisms and pathways responsible for observed alterations. The ultimate goal is to develop effective countermeasures to protect astronaut health during long-duration space missions. The investigation employs a "body-on-a-chip" (hBoC) model comprising microengineered 3D OTEs of 12 different human tissues, maintained long-term to study drug toxicities and biological responses to spaceflight stressors. This research not only aims to safeguard astronauts but also has Earth applications, such as studying the effects of chronic exposure to environmental stressors and disease progression, which are currently reliant on animal models.

title: Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist ends 2023 on positive note
summary: Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist concluded fiscal 2023 with a positive financial outcome, showcasing substantial growth in core revenue and investment income. This not-for-profit healthcare system, which includes N.C. Baptist Hospital, Wake Forest University Health Sciences, and Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center along with their affiliates, reported a significant turnaround with $238.4 million in excess revenue over expenses. This is a notable improvement from a $222.9 million loss in fiscal 2022. The improvement was largely attributed to nearly $106 million in investment income in fiscal 2023, contrasting with a $198.9 million loss in the previous year. Additionally, the system experienced a 19.4% increase in patient service revenue to $4.04 billion and an 8.4% rise in other revenue to $1.01 billion. Operating expenses also went up by 12.9% to $4.9 billion, with major costs being personnel, supplies, and services. Outpatient visits, emergency department visits, inpatient admissions, and operating-room cases all saw increases in numbers.

title: How Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist team member’s heart condition inspired a career in research
summary: Stephanie Bowden, diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) at 11 and undergoing open-heart surgery at 14, was inspired to pursue a career in medical research due to her condition. Now working as an assistant project manager at Wake Forest University School of Medicine, she focuses on clinical studies that impact cardiac health, including obesity, eating habits, diabetes development, and vaccines. Her personal journey with HCM, including losing her mother to the condition and her own diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AFib), motivated her to contribute to the Go Red for Women campaign to raise awareness about heart disease in women. Bowden's career and advocacy work are driven by her experiences and the desire to improve treatments for heart conditions, reflecting a commitment to advancing medical research and patient care.

title: Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine awarded $160 million 10-year US National Science Foundation ...
summary: The Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine (WFIRM) has received a $160 million grant from the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) through its Regional Innovation Engines program. This 10-year grant will help create an innovation ecosystem in the Piedmont Triad region, aiming to improve workforce development, job creation, and economic growth via regenerative medicine technologies. The effort involves collaboration with WFIRM, Forsyth Technical Community College, North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, the RegenMed Development Organization, and Winston Salem State University. It will focus on creating technologies for tissue and organ regeneration, meeting unmet needs in areas like Development and Manufacturing, Biomaterials, Cell Biology, In-Space Manufacturing, and Workforce Development through Innovation, Translation, and Education Cores (ITECs). The project also prioritizes inclusion and seeks to develop a skilled workforce in the regenerative medicine field.

title: Wake Forest University Health Sciences buys Innovation Quarter building for $38 million - Triad Business Journal
summary: Wake Forest University Health Sciences has bought a building in Innovation Quarter for $38 million after renting it for seven years. The building, at 409 Vine Street, covers 0.76 acres and has a 194,370-square-foot space. It is home to the Bowman Gray Center for Medical Education and Wake Forest University's Wake Downtown campus, which offers biomedical sciences and engineering programs. The building was sold by Wexford Winston-Building 60 LLC, connected to developer Wexford Science + Technology. Innovation Quarter, which is revitalizing downtown Winston-Salem and is centered around the medical school, has brought $1.7 billion in economic benefits to the city and Forsyth County. A second phase of development for Innovation Quarter is being planned, featuring an eye institute from AHWFB as a major addition.

title: A DAY TO 'CHILL': Lupus Jazz Brunch benefits foundation | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
summary: The Lupus Jazz Brunch, benefiting the Lupus Foundation of Arkansas Inc., was held on July 8, 2023, at the Presidential Legacy of Life Center in Little Rock. This event featured performances by the Jose Holloway Xperience and was organized by the foundation's Statewide Talent Show committee. Attendees included Little Rock Mayor Frank Scott Jr., foundation founder Jamesetta Smith, and other lupus warriors. The brunch offered music, a buffet by Flava by Gwen, and encouraged donations to the foundation. Information about the foundation's seventh Statewide Talent Show, with auditions on Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, was also shared. The Lupus Foundation of Arkansas provides various services and programs for those living with lupus.

title: 'Volunteered' Davis enjoys working with lupus group | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
summary: Gale Davis, co-chair of the Lupus Foundation of Arkansas Inc.'s Annual Statewide Talent Show and an advocate for those with lupus, encourages individuals with the disease to reach out for support. Davis emphasizes the importance of making connections with lupus "warriors" who may be hesitant to seek help, stating the foundation's eagerness to assist but noting the necessity for individuals to make their situations known to receive support. Through her involvement with the foundation, Davis aims to foster a supportive community for those affected by lupus, highlighting the foundation's commitment to aiding those in need.

title: Safer Skies Ahead: Congress Approves Legislation Requiring Updates to Airline Emergency Medical Kits
hco: ASTHMA AND ALLERGY FOUNDATION OF AMERICA
summary: The U.S. Congress has passed a law requiring updates to the emergency medical kits on airplanes to include treatments for severe allergic reactions. This move, led by Sen. Tammy Duckworth and backed by the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, aims to protect passengers with serious food allergies. The law mandates that these kits be prepared for severe allergic reactions and calls for a review of their contents every five years. This effort, coinciding with Food Allergy Awareness Week and the 40th National Asthma and Allergy Awareness Month, marks a significant step forward for the safety of travelers with food allergies. The AAFA has been pushing for this change since 2018, highlighting the need for easy access to epinephrine treatments, like auto-injectors, on airplanes.

title: NCPA Recommends Prescryptive AI Pricing to Community Pharmacists Nationwide to Face Ongoing Profitability ...
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) has reiterated its endorsement for Prescryptive AI Pricing, a solution by Prescryptive Health that leverages artificial intelligence to help independent pharmacies optimize cash pricing and thus enhance their competitiveness. Initially recommended in 2022, this AI-driven tool has shown promising results, with a reported gross profit margin of nearly 54% in 2023 for pharmacies utilizing it, a significant increase from the average 21% gross profit margin reported for independent pharmacies in 2022. This tool not only aids pharmacies in facing reimbursement challenges but also in maintaining customer care quality. It offers a strategic advantage in the market by utilizing pharmacies' own data and analytics, providing a sustainable financial model especially vital in the current landscape where high-deductible health plans are becoming more common, and more customers are paying cash for prescriptions.

title: NCPA awards Chapter of the Year to Mercer College of Pharmacy student chapter
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) has awarded the Chapter of the Year to Mercer College of Pharmacy's student chapter for its exceptional commitment and involvement in community pharmacy. Chosen from more than 100 chapters in the U.S. and Puerto Rico, Mercer's chapter stood out in advocacy, event involvement, community service, outreach, and fundraising. Former president Natalie Novak and associate dean for student affairs Dr. Lea Winkles emphasized the chapter's work in supporting independent community pharmacists and informing future pharmacists about this career option. The chapter will receive a $2,000 prize at the NCPA's annual meeting in October. The NCPA represents over 19,400 pharmacies and employs over 240,000 people nationwide.

title: NCPA Introduces Compelling New Business Mastercard Benefit to Support Community Pharmacies
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) has introduced a special new benefit for its members, the NCPA Business Mastercard. This card caters to the pharmacy industry's spending needs, with perks like unlimited 2.25% cash back on all business expenses, 5% cash back on the first $5,000 spent on pharmacy supplies and equipment each year, and a $450 welcome bonus after spending $25,000 on eligible purchases in the first three months. It also allows for an unlimited number of employee cards at no extra cost and enables easy expense management without affecting personal credit scores. The card guarantees a 1:1 rewards redemption rate to prevent rewards devaluation. Managed by Affiniti Finance, Inc., the NCPA Business Mastercard is designed to help community pharmacies save money and manage finances better.

title: NCPA Renews Recommendation of Prescryptive AI Pricing: Empowering Pharmacies with AI-Driven Cash Pricing
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) has reaffirmed its support for Prescryptive Health's AI Pricing, a technology aimed at giving independent pharmacies a dynamic and competitive cash pricing system. This AI solution is designed to help these pharmacies by optimizing cash pricing strategies, improving their competitiveness in the healthcare market. Initially recommended by NCPA in 2022, this renewed support underscores the association's dedication to equipping its members with innovative tools to tackle industry challenges. According to Prescryptive Health, pharmacies using this AI pricing solution in 2023 experienced a significant boost in profitability, with a nearly 54% gross profit margin. This system is especially pertinent today, as the rise in high-deductible health plans increases the number of cash-paying customers, and traditional cash discount cards are becoming financially harmful for pharmacies. By using a pharmacy’s own data and customizable settings, Prescryptive AI Pricing provides a strategic edge in the cash pricing market, says Douglas Hoey, CEO of NCPA.

title: 'This is an emergency': Trade group warns nearly a third of all independent pharmacies will go extinct because of a ...
summary: Nearly a third of independent pharmacies in the U.S. are at risk of closing due to a new rule by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) that affects prescription reimbursements, according to the National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA). This rule, which started on January 1, requires direct and indirect remuneration (DIR) fees to be applied at the time of prescription pickup, with the goal of increasing drug price transparency. However, this has led to lower initial reimbursement rates for pharmacies. A survey by the NCPA of 10,000 pharmacy owners and managers found that 32% are considering closing due to these financial pressures, and a vast majority are thinking about leaving Medicare Part D next year. The NCPA has called on CMS to take action to prevent these closures, highlighting the essential healthcare role pharmacies serve, particularly in rural and underserved areas.

title: NCPA launches company to assist pharmacies with litigation against PBMs over DIR fees
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) has initiated Trust LLC, a firm dedicated to aiding community pharmacies in legal disputes with pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) concerning direct and indirect remuneration (DIR) fees. NCPA argues that these fees breach antitrust laws and have considerably harmed pharmacies financially. Trust LLC will explore and possibly engage in litigation or arbitration for these pharmacies. This development follows a lawsuit by an Iowa pharmacy against CVS Caremark, a leading PBM, regarding DIR fees, a case backed by NCPA.
