Trust LLC has appointed the law firms Berger Montague, Cohen & Gresser LLP, and Baker Donelson to spearhead any legal actions, underscoring the difficulties small pharmacies encounter when individually challenging PBMs due to the steep costs of arbitration. NCPA CEO B. Douglas Hoey stressed the monopolistic nature of DIR fees and the importance of collective legal action for a more equitable chance at justice.

title: NCPA seeks pause on audits, ahead of cyberattack hearing
summary: The National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA) is asking Congress to stop audits on independent pharmacies affected by the Change Healthcare cyberattack. During two congressional hearings, the NCPA stressed the importance of stopping audits, making sure pharmacies get paid for providing medications in good faith during the cyberattack, and avoiding punishment for care or record-keeping problems caused by the cyberattack. NCPA CEO Douglas Hoey criticized UnitedHealth for how it manages healthcare services and its susceptibility to cyberattacks, suggesting that UnitedHealth Group's purchase of Change Healthcare was a mistake. The hearings will feature testimony from Andrew Witty, CEO of UnitedHealth Group, which bought Change Healthcare in 2022.

title: High drug prices and pharmacy deserts: Protesters blame drug middlemen, demand regulation
summary: Protesters, including pharmacists, physicians, patients, and patient advocates, demonstrated outside the headquarters of Express Scripts in St. Louis, blaming pharmacy benefits managers (PBMs) for high drug prices and the closure of independent pharmacies. They criticized PBMs for their practices, such as demanding large rebates from drug manufacturers, lowering pharmacy reimbursement rates, and imposing hefty fees. These practices have led to the shutdown of over 500 independent pharmacies in a year. The protesters called for Congress to pass reform legislation to address these issues. The demonstration is part of a broader effort to highlight the negative impact of PBM practices on small pharmacies and patient care, including the restriction of pharmacy choice and the requirement for patients to try less expensive drugs before those prescribed by their physicians.

title: Sexual abuse prevention program resumes in Orange County schools after stoppage
summary: The sexual abuse prevention program Safe Touch is restarting in Orange County Schools and Chapel Hill-Carrboro City Schools after being paused due to concerns it breached a new state law, Senate Bill 49, known as the Parents' Bill of Rights. This law limits teaching about sexuality to students below the fifth grade. Nonetheless, state officials and the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction have concluded that the program, which aids young children in identifying and seeking help for sexual assault, does not infringe upon the new law. The Orange County Rape Crisis Center offers the program. State Superintendent Catherine Truitt and other officials are finalizing guidance for schools to adhere to the law, with the goal of explaining its effects on such educational initiatives.

title: New York Cancer Foundation raises over $1 million for patients
summary: The New York Cancer Foundation (NYCF) successfully raised over $1 million at its 3rd Annual Raising Hope Gala, aimed at providing financial assistance to cancer patients in the Greater New York Metro Area. The event, under the theme “Hope Grows Here,” saw a significant turnout, with attendees showing remarkable generosity. Jeff Vacirca, CEO of New York Cancer & Blood Specialists and Chairman of the NYCF Board, highlighted the foundation's impact on thousands of patients since its inception. The funds will support cancer patients with day-to-day living expenses, such as rent and utility bills. The gala featured notable guests, including Nigel Barker and a breast cancer survivor who shared her journey. Special honoree Ted Okon was recognized for his advocacy in oncology. The NYCF expressed gratitude towards the 2023 sponsors for their pivotal role in the gala's success.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) offers a wide array of resources for oncology professionals through its different platforms and initiatives. This includes ASCO Connection for member blogs and discussions, ASCO Daily News for summaries of research and news in oncology, and various journals that publish peer-reviewed research in clinical oncology. ASCO Practice Central aids professionals in dealing with the complex practice environment, and ASCO Education provides up-to-date information on advancements in oncology. CancerLinQ® is a health information technology platform designed to enhance the quality of cancer care by leveraging real-world data. Cancer.Net provides resources for patients and their families to help them make informed healthcare decisions. Conquer Cancer, the ASCO Foundation, backs researchers in their quest to find treatments and cures for all types of cancer. The TAPUR Study investigates the application of targeted anticancer drugs. ASCO also promotes participation in state/regional societies for local networking and professional growth, which requires a membership separate from ASCO. These affiliates spearhead advocacy efforts and offer various benefits to their members, including continuing education credits.

title: AMGA Opposes Proposed Medicare Advantage Coding Changes
summary: The American Medical Group Association (AMGA) has opposed the proposed changes in the 2024 Medicare Advantage Advance Notice, which include revising diagnoses and condition categories in the hierarchical condition categories (HCC) model. The changes propose a shift from the IDC-9 to the ICD-10 coding system and the removal of over 2,000 unique codes for various conditions. AMGA argues this would harm providers in value-based arrangements and reduce care access for patients with chronic conditions. AMGA is worried these changes will bring uncertainty to value-based programs, deter provider participation, and could lead to decreased payments to Medicare Advantage plans, impacting both provider reimbursement and patient care access. They have requested CMS to delay the implementation of these changes for sufficient feedback and adjustment by providers and plans. Additionally, AMGA supports the alignment of quality measures across Medicare but urges a reevaluation of the HCC model changes to better assess their impact on health equity and the progress of value-based care.

title: Caris Life Sciences Announces Partnership with Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany to Discover Novel Cancer Targets ...
summary: Caris Life Sciences has announced a strategic partnership with Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany, to speed up the discovery and development of unique antibody-drug conjugates (ADC) for treating cancer. This long-term collaboration will use Caris' advanced molecular profiling and AI technologies to find new cancer targets. Merck KGaA will make an upfront payment and provide research funding to Caris, with potential milestone payments up to $1.4 billion plus royalties. Merck KGaA will also get an exclusive global license to develop, manufacture, and sell ADC therapeutics for chosen targets. This partnership unites Caris' discovery platform with Merck KGaA's ADC expertise to enhance their cancer treatment portfolio and meet unmet needs in cancer care.

title: Caris Life Sciences to Showcase Extensive Research Highlighting the Clinical Value of Comprehensive Molecular ...
summary: Caris Life Sciences announced its participation in the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting, where it will present research from 41 studies across 19 solid tumor types. This research highlights the clinical value of Caris' comprehensive molecular profiling in precision medicine. The studies, conducted in collaboration with biopharma and leading cancer centers, including those within the Caris Precision Oncology Alliance™, demonstrate how Caris' multi-modal database can provide novel insights into cancer, impacting diagnosis, prognosis, care plans, and treatment responses. Caris' efforts in sequencing and data analysis aim to unlock new avenues for tailored therapies to revolutionize cancer treatment. The company's AI-driven platform leverages real-world evidence from over 632,000 clinical cases, including more than 482,000 with matched molecular data, to explore the molecular and immune landscapes of tumors, aiming to improve personalized therapies and patient outcomes.

title: Caris and Merck partner to develop ADCs for cancer treatment
summary: Caris Life Sciences and Merck KGaA have established a multi-year strategic partnership to accelerate the development of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) for cancer treatment. Under the agreement, Merck will gain exclusive global rights to develop, produce, and market ADC therapeutics for specific targets identified through the collaboration. Caris is set to receive up to $1.4 billion in potential milestone payments, in addition to sales-based tiered royalties. The partnership leverages Caris Discovery's extensive molecular profiling capabilities to discover new cancer targets that traditional methods may miss, aiming to advance the next wave of transformational ADC therapeutics. Merck will be responsible for conducting the preclinical and clinical research of the ADC programs. This collaboration represents a significant validation of Caris's multi-omics approach to discovering novel targets for oncology treatments.

title: Pramana and Caris Life Sciences Collaborate to Digitize 1.5 Million Pathology Slides Annually
summary: Pramana, Inc., an AI-enabled health tech company, has signed a multi-year deal with Caris Life Sciences, a precision medicine and AI TechBio leader, to digitize about 1.5 million pathology slides every year. This partnership utilizes Pramana's sophisticated scanning systems and software to create high-quality digital images for Caris Life Sciences. These images are vital for Caris' AI analysis in therapy choices and trial recruitment. The goal of the collaboration is to improve digital pathology operations, with Pramana addressing issues like slide and label inconsistencies and ensuring scans do not miss any tissue. This initiative aids Caris Life Sciences' significant investment in digital pathology, helping to advance precision medicine tools through detailed molecular profiling and cutting-edge AI.

title: Merck KGaA signs $1.4B biobuck ADC deal with Caris
summary: Merck KGaA has entered into a $1.4 billion collaboration with Caris Life Sciences to enhance its oncology pipeline through the development of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs). This partnership leverages Caris' extensive clinical and genomic data, along with its ADAPT Biotargeting platform, to identify new therapeutic targets for cancer treatment. Merck will make an upfront payment and fund research, with Caris eligible for up to $1.4 billion in milestone payments plus royalties on sales of any marketed products resulting from the collaboration. This deal highlights Merck's commitment to expanding its portfolio in oncology by developing novel first-in-class ADCs, complementing its existing ADC, M9140, currently in clinical trials for colorectal cancer.

title: Merck KGaA, Caris Sign Potential $1.4B Deal to Develop First-in-Class ADCs for Cancer
summary: Merck KGaA has entered into a potential $1.4 billion agreement with Caris Life Sciences to discover and develop first-in-class antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) candidates for cancer treatment. As part of the multi-year partnership, Merck KGaA will make an upfront payment and cover research funding, with responsibilities extending to preclinical and clinical research, development, and commercialization. Caris, leveraging its AI and precision medicine capabilities, will receive up to $1.4 billion in milestone payments and royalties, while granting Merck KGaA exclusive global development and commercialization rights. This deal aligns with Merck KGaA's strategy to enhance its oncology portfolio through external collaborations, following a similar ADC discovery deal with Mersana Therapeutics in 2022 and amidst a broader industry trend of significant investments in the promising ADC market.

title: Caris Life Sciences Partners with Moderna To Advance mRNA-Based Cancer Drugs
summary: Caris Life Sciences, a company based in Irving specializing in precision medicine, has started a multiyear partnership with Moderna to improve the development of mRNA-based cancer treatments. Through this partnership, Moderna will use Caris' large anonymous, multimodal data library, which includes whole exome sequencing, whole transcriptome sequencing, and protein analyses, as well as claims data. The goal is to enhance Moderna's cancer treatment pipeline by helping with clinical trial design, finding new biomarkers, and understanding resistance mechanisms. David Spetzler, president of Caris Life Sciences, is excited about working with Moderna to advance cancer treatment with mRNA medicines to better patient outcomes. This collaboration uses Caris' big clinico-genomic database and computing capabilities to help predict how patients will respond to treatments, increasing the chances of success for Moderna's new medicines.

title: Caris Life Sciences to Showcase Research Highlighting the Clinical Value of Comprehensive Molecular Profiling at the ...
summary: Caris Life Sciences is set to present research at the 2024 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting, highlighting the clinical value of comprehensive molecular profiling in cancer treatment. The company, along with collaborators from the Caris Precision Oncology Alliance™, will showcase 10 studies across eight tumor types. Caris President, Dr. David Spetzler, will lead a special session on early cancer detection. The research demonstrates the utility of Caris' AI-enabled whole exome and whole transcriptome liquid biopsy platform, Caris Assure™, in early diagnosis, therapy selection, and minimal residual disease monitoring. The presentations will cover various topics, including the identification of new biomarkers and the immunological characterization of cancers. The findings underscore the importance of large clinicogenomic datasets in improving cancer outcomes. Caris Life Sciences aims to enhance individualized treatment choices, target discovery, and the development of new medicines through comprehensive molecular profiling.

title: Caris Life Sciences and COTA, Inc. Announce Collaboration to Expand Collective Multi-Modal Data Offering
summary: Caris Life Sciences and COTA, Inc. have announced a collaboration to enhance their multi-modal data offerings, aiming to accelerate drug development and improve patient care in oncology. This partnership combines Caris' molecular data, including genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, and imaging data, with COTA's curated clinical data, which documents the treatment journeys and outcomes of cancer patients. The integration of these comprehensive datasets will enable biopharmaceutical companies to leverage a more complete dataset for research and AI-driven therapeutic development. Caris Life Sciences is known for its molecular profiling and AI applications in precision medicine, while COTA specializes in real-world data and analytics in oncology, supporting the development of personalized cancer treatments. This collaboration is expected to provide unprecedented insights into cancer care, optimizing treatments to enhance patient prognosis and quality of life.

title: Caris Life Sciences and Moderna Announce Multi-Year Strategic Partnership to Advance mRNA-Based Oncology ...
summary: Caris Life Sciences and Moderna have established a multi-year strategic partnership to advance mRNA-based cancer treatments. This partnership enables Moderna to use Caris' vast collection of anonymous, multi-modal data, including whole exome and transcriptome sequencing and protein analysis, to improve its cancer treatment development pipeline. The goal of the partnership is to support optimal clinical trial design, discover new biomarkers, and identify resistance mechanisms. Praveen Aanur of Moderna and David Spetzler of Caris Life Sciences are excited about the partnership's potential to enhance cancer treatment with mRNA drugs and its contribution to precision medicine. Caris Life Sciences, recognized for its comprehensive molecular profiling and use of AI, aims to support the predictive modeling of patient responses to treatments and to increase the success rates of Moderna's innovative medicines.

title: Powered by Its Industry-Leading Comprehensive Multi-Modal Database, Caris Life Sciences to Showcase Research at ...
summary: Caris Life Sciences, a leader in precision medicine and AI TechBio, announced its participation in the 2024 ASCO Gastrointestinal Cancers Symposium, where it will present 11 studies across six solid tumor types. These studies, conducted in collaboration with the Caris Precision Oncology Alliance, showcase the utility of Caris' comprehensive multi-modal database in providing novel insights into cancer, which could significantly impact patient diagnosis, prognosis, care plans, and treatment responses. The research findings include potential new biomarkers for EGFRi efficacy in metastatic colorectal cancer, age stratification in cholangiocarcinoma, and a survey of immunogenic tumor neoantigens in colorectal, biliary, and pancreatic cancers. This demonstrates Caris' commitment to advancing precision oncology and improving outcomes for cancer patients through comprehensive molecular profiling and collaboration with leading cancer centers and academic institutions.

title: Caris Life Sciences and Flatiron Health Partner to Create Transformational Real-World Data Offering
summary: Caris Life Sciences and Flatiron Health have partnered to create a comprehensive real-world data (RWD) offering aimed at enhancing biopharmaceutical drug development and patient care. This collaboration combines Caris' extensive genomic, transcriptomic, and imaging data with Flatiron's longitudinal patient data and clinical outcomes. The partnership is designed to equip cancer researchers with a robust, large-scale dataset to advance the next generation of cancer therapeutics. By leveraging Caris' molecular science capabilities and Flatiron's high-quality oncology real-world data, the partnership aims to support biopharma in developing personalized therapeutic interventions and improving cancer patient outcomes. This initiative represents a significant step forward in utilizing large-scale clinico-genomic databases and advanced technologies for precision medicine and drug discovery.

title: Caris Life Sciences to Present at the 42nd Annual J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference
summary: Caris Life Sciences, a leading next-generation AI TechBio company and pioneer in precision medicine, announced its participation in the 42nd Annual J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco from January 8-11, 2024. The company will present at 11:00 a.m. PST on January 9, providing an overview of the business and discussing recent corporate achievements that strengthen its market leadership position. Executives, including Founder and CEO David D. Halbert, will represent Caris, highlighting its development and delivery of innovative healthcare solutions. Caris Life Sciences specializes in comprehensive molecular profiling and advanced AI and machine learning algorithms to revolutionize healthcare and improve human conditions. The company operates globally, with services provided in the U.S., Europe, Asia, and other international markets.

title: Caris Life Sciences to Present Research at the 2024 ASCO Genitourinary Cancers Symposium
summary: Caris Life Sciences will present research from eight studies across four tumor types at the 2024 ASCO Genitourinary Cancers Symposium. This research, a collaboration with the Caris Precision Oncology Alliance, utilizes Caris' AI-driven platform and comprehensive database, which includes over 593,000 lifetime clinical cases, to explore cancer's genetic and immune landscapes. The studies aim to improve diagnosis, prognosis, care plans, and treatment responses. Key findings include differences in prostate cancer metastases, with implications for future drug development. Additional presentations will cover the role of comprehensive molecular profiling in treating genitourinary cancers, showcasing the potential of targeted therapies based on molecular and immune landscapes. Caris Life Sciences is a leader in precision medicine, leveraging molecular science and AI to advance healthcare.

title: Hundreds of cyclists to hit the road in Pittsburgh to raise money for cancer research
summary: Hundreds of cyclists took part in the annual Rush to Crush bike ride in Pittsburgh, raising money for cancer research at the UPMC Hillman Cancer Center. The event had about 800 participants riding distances of 15, 30, and 60 miles. Dr. Kurt Weiss, a cancer survivor and UPMC doctor, emphasized the community's role in supporting cancer research. The goal was to raise about $600,000, with all proceeds going towards research and clinical trials to find a cancer cure. Riders like Callie Fry, who participated in memory of a loved one, were driven by the opportunity to help achieve a cancer-free future, highlighting the event's significance in remembering those affected by cancer and promoting hope and joy.

title: Electronic Survey Helps Integrate Exercise as Standard of Care at UPMC Hillman Cancer Center - UPMC & Pitt Health ...
summary: At UPMC Hillman Cancer Center, a recent initiative led by Dr. Kathryn Schmitz aims to bridge the gap in exercise referral for cancer patients. Recognizing the substantial benefits of exercise for those living with cancer, including improved quality of life and mitigated treatment side effects, the center developed an electronic survey to screen patients for suitable exercise programs. Despite the known benefits, previously only 15% of patients were referred to such programs. This new approach, detailed in a study published in Supportive Care in Cancer, involves offering the survey at patients' second chemotherapy infusion, leading to 45% of participating patients being connected to appropriate exercise or rehabilitation services. The survey categorizes patients into three levels of care based on their responses, significantly increasing the referral rate from the baseline. Schmitz's team is now expanding this program across 59 community clinics in the Hillman Cancer Center network and integrating a streamlined version of the survey into patient medical records for broader impact. This effort underscores the importance of treating the whole patient, not just the cancer, by incorporating exercise into standard cancer care.

title: UPMC Hillman Cancer Center Scientists Study How Telomere DNA is Damaged and Modified
summary: Scientists at UPMC Hillman Cancer Center, led by Dr. O’Sullivan and in collaboration with Dr. Ivan Ahel, conducted a study on how telomere DNA is damaged and modified through ADP-ribosylation. Their research revealed that telomeric DNA undergoes ADP-ribosylation, a process catalyzed by the enzyme PARP1 and reversed by the enzyme TARG1. Utilizing CRISPR to delete TARG1, they demonstrated that without TARG1, DNA-ADP-ribosylation cannot be removed, highlighting its presence on telomeric DNA. The study found that telomere DNA is modified in response to DNA damage and during S-phase, crucial for DNA replication. This modification is closely associated with telomere replication, and its failure to be removed results in telomere structure damage and premature loss of telomeric DNA, negatively impacting genome stability. The findings underscore the importance of ADP-ribosylation in telomere function and suggest potential implications for PARP inhibitor development and cancer treatment. This research, born out of collaborative efforts during the pandemic, opens new avenues for understanding the role of DNA-ADP-ribosylation in cancer and beyond.

title: A Great Cause | News, Sports, Jobs
summary: The Femmes of Rock concert on April 27 at The Reg Lenna Center for the Arts raised $37,000 for cancer care initiatives at UPMC Hillman Cancer Treatment Center, facilitated by the Italian-American Charity Golf Association. The funds will support cancer treatment programs, including the purchase of a new 3D mammography unit for the Women’s Imaging Center at UPMC Chautauqua. The event was organized by Joe Paterniti, who was inspired by a previous performance of the band. The concert featured the Femmes of Rock, a group of four electric string players and a live backing band, performing unique arrangements of classic rock songs. The Italian-American Charity Golf Association has raised over $1.6 million in its 52-year history to fight cancer.

title: New insights could unlock immunotherapy for rare, deadly eye cancer
summary: New research from the University of Pittsburgh, published in Nature Communications, reveals why metastatic uveal melanoma, a rare and aggressive eye cancer, is resistant to conventional immunotherapies. The study found that adoptive therapy, which involves expanding a patient’s T cells outside the body before reinfusing them, can effectively treat this cancer. This breakthrough is significant as it challenges the previous belief that uveal melanoma is a "cold" cancer, with T cells unable to infiltrate the tumors. The research demonstrated that T cells do infiltrate the tumors but remain in a dormant state due to the tumor's suppressive environment. By utilizing adoptive therapy, these T cells can be reactivated to fight the cancer successfully. Additionally, the team developed a clinical tool, the Uveal Melanoma Immunogenic Score (UMIS), to predict which patients will respond to adoptive therapy, potentially improving personalized therapy and avoiding ineffective treatments. This study not only offers hope for treating metastatic uveal melanoma but also lays the groundwork for applying similar strategies to other hard-to-treat cancers.

title: UPMC Hillman Cancer Center breaks ground on expansion
summary: UPMC Hillman Cancer Center has started to expand its Farrell facility, adding a 2,100 sq. ft space for a second linear accelerator (LINAC) machine. This improvement will allow for treatments not previously available to local communities, aiming to better control tumors while reducing side effects. The expansion is in response to growing demand for care at the Farrell hospital, as shown by the treatment of 439 new patients and nearly 8,500 radiation oncology treatments in 2023. Adding a second LINAC machine will greatly enhance the center's ability to treat and research. Dr. Uzoma Iheagwara pointed out the advantages of the expansion, including more treatment options for patients and the start of stereotactic body radiation therapy and stereotactic radiosurgery.

title: Breaking New Ground: Constructing the First UPMC Hillman Cancer Center in Croatia - UPMC & Pitt Health Sciences ...
summary: The first UPMC Hillman Cancer Center in Croatia is being constructed at Zabok General Hospital, marking a significant advancement in cancer care for the region. The groundbreaking ceremony, held on December 21, 2023, saw officials from Croatia and the United States, including representatives from UPMC and local government, celebrate the start of this project, which is expected to open in 2025. The center aims to provide cutting-edge cancer therapies and personalized medicine to people in Krapina-Zagorje County, Croatia, and neighboring countries. This effort is part of UPMC's international expansion, leveraging its extensive experience in cancer care and collaborating with local health ministries and stakeholders. The center will offer comprehensive cancer care, including advanced radiation oncology, medical oncology, and PET-CT diagnostics, benefiting the local and regional population by making advanced treatments and clinical trials accessible locally.

title: Dr. Annie Im: How to Treat Acute Myeloid Leukemia in 2024
summary: Dr. Annie Im from the University of Pittsburgh/UPMC Hillman Cancer Center discusses modern treatment approaches for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in 2024. The commentary highlights the evolution and efficacy of various treatment strategies in managing AML, aiming to provide insights into the latest advancements and their implications for patient care. This discussion is part of a broader range of oncological topics covered, including developments in lung cancer, leukemia, CLL, pediatric B-ALL, LBCL, SCLC, Hodgkin lymphoma, and hematologic malignancies, reflecting ongoing research and clinical trials aimed at improving outcomes for patients with these conditions.

title: Monica Baskin named deputy director of UPMC Hillman
summary: Monica L. Baskin has been appointed as the deputy director of UPMC Hillman Cancer Center, where she will bring her expertise in health equity to the role. This announcement was featured in The Cancer Letter's February 16, 2024, issue.

title: UPMC program offers treatment for post-cancer life
summary: The UPMC Hillman Cancer Center in Williamsport, part of a network in North Central Pennsylvania, has initiated a program aimed at assisting individuals who have survived cancer transition into post-cancer life. Recognizing the unique challenges faced by survivors, such as stress and adjusting to a new reality after undergoing treatments like chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery, the program offers a comprehensive support system. This includes access to nutritionists, physical therapists, and mental health counselors to address the physical and psychological impacts of cancer treatment. Patients receive a one-time, hour-long consultation followed by a tailored therapeutic program that encompasses physical and psychosocial therapy, financial and nutritional guidance, and group sessions offered quarterly. The program is designed to facilitate recovery from the trauma of cancer treatment and improve the overall well-being of survivors. It also provides for the possibility of re-entry into the program if a patient's cancer relapses. This initiative highlights the importance of post-treatment care in enhancing the quality of life for cancer survivors.

title: UPMC cancer center expansion begins in Farrell
summary: The UPMC Hillman Cancer Center in Farrell, Pennsylvania, is undergoing a $9.6 million expansion project. This project includes the construction of a vault for new technology used in external beam radiation oncology treatments, which delivers high-energy x-rays or electrons to tumor regions. According to Heath Skinner, M.D., department chair of radiation oncology, this new radiotherapy can treat a variety of cancer tumors "wherever they are in the body." UPMC Hillman Cancer Center is the only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center in the region. The expansion is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

title: Nurturing Nature - UPMC & Pitt Health Sciences News Blog
summary: Dr. Udai Kammula, director of the Solid Tumor Cell Therapy Program at UPMC Hillman Cancer Center, has dedicated his career to advancing immunotherapy, especially through Adoptive Cell Therapy (ACT). Starting as a surgical oncologist focusing on liver cancer, Dr. Kammula became interested in immunotherapy during a research fellowship with Steven Rosenberg, MD, a pioneer in the field. Despite initial doubts, Dr. Kammula's efforts have led to significant advancements, notably in treating uveal melanoma, a rare and aggressive eye cancer. By extracting tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) from patients, cultivating them in the lab, and reinfusing them into the patients, Dr. Kammula's team has achieved promising results, with an unprecedented 35% of patients showing complete or partial cancer regression. This innovative method is now being applied to other difficult-to-treat cancers, with ongoing trials and research focused on enhancing personalized therapies and broadening treatment options. Dr. Kammula's work demonstrates the power of leveraging the body's immune system to combat cancer, providing new hope to patients facing bleak outlooks.

title: Specialists Are 'Underwater' With Some Insurance-Preferred Biosimilars
summary: Specialists, especially rheumatologists, are experiencing significant financial losses because insurance companies require the use of certain biosimilars that are more expensive than the reimbursement rates. This situation has led many practices and infusion centers to stop providing these biosimilars, causing delays in patient care and higher costs as patients are sent to hospital-based infusion centers, which are much more costly. A survey by the Coalition of State Rheumatology Organizations (CSRO) showed that 97% of the participants were impacted by this, with Inflectra and Avsola being particularly troublesome. This issue has occurred because biosimilar manufacturers give large rebates to insurers for preferred placement on their formularies, creating a gap between the purchase price and the reimbursement amount. The temporary increase in add-on payment from ASP+6% to ASP+8% by the Inflation Reduction Act does not sufficiently bridge the gap between acquisition costs and reimbursement rates, making it difficult for both providers and patients.

title: Dr. Madelaine Feldman
summary: Dr. Madelaine Feldman is a renowned rheumatologist and managing partner at the Rheumatology Group in Metairie. She is recognized for her expertise in formulary construction and her advocacy for patient access to affordable care. Feldman has made significant contributions through her testimony before Congress, the FDA, and the FTC. She holds the position of VP of Advocacy & Government Affairs for the Coalition of State Rheumatology Organizations and serves as a Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine at Tulane Medical School. Her achievements include receiving the American College of Rheumatology Innovation in Clinical Care award in 2022 and being named a Top Woman in New Orleans by City Business.

title: Insurer's foray into AI-based 'shared savings' program creates ethical problems
summary: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Carolina, in partnership with Outcomes Matter Innovations, has launched a voluntary AI-based shared savings program for doctors treating rheumatoid and psoriatic arthritis. The program employs machine learning to recommend two treatment strategies that aim to decrease the use of costly biologics or Janus kinase inhibitors by optimizing methotrexate use or suggesting a break in medication for patients in remission. The objective is to reduce healthcare expenses, with the savings being split between the physicians and the insurance company. However, this raises ethical concerns regarding the potential decline in the quality of patient care. The program has ignited debates among rheumatology advocacy groups who are calling for significant policy changes.

title: In-office infusions at risk with new Medicare Part B reimbursement recommendation
summary: The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MedPAC) recommended changes to Medicare Part B reimbursement that could impact in-office infusions, particularly for rheumatology medications. MedPAC, advising Congress on Medicare policy, proposed “site neutrality” payments and other adjustments aimed at reducing Medicare costs. This includes potentially lowering reimbursements for Medicare Part B drugs, which are administered by providers. Currently, Medicare reimburses these at the average sales price (ASP) plus 6%, reduced to ASP plus 4.3% due to sequestration. The recommendations include giving the Secretary of Health & Human Services the authority to establish a single ASP for drugs with “similar health effects” and to reduce or eliminate the add-on percentage for higher-priced drugs. These proposals have raised concerns among rheumatologists about the potential negative impact on access to in-office infusions for Medicare beneficiaries, arguing that these changes could leave providers and patients “underwater” and jeopardize patient care.

title: Prescription drug affordability boards: Another quick fix with unintended consequences?
summary: Prescription drug affordability boards (PDABs) are emerging as a governmental response to the high costs of medications, aiming to make drugs more affordable for the public. These boards, established by state and federal legislatures, assess drug affordability and can set upper payment limits on drug prices. The first PDAB was created in Maryland in 2019, with several other states following. While PDABs offer a potential solution to drug affordability, concerns exist about their implementation and possible unintended effects, especially on access to provider-administered drugs. Advocacy has led to exemptions for these drugs in places like Washington. However, the effectiveness and impact of PDABs and upper payment limits on drug availability and patient access are still debated and concerning.

title: Combs becomes president of state medical association
summary: Dr. Landon Combs, a pediatrician with Ballad Health from Gray, Tennessee, has become the 170th president of the Tennessee Medical Association (TMA), which represents over 10,000 physicians. He officially took office on April 6 at the association's annual meeting in Murfreesboro, Tennessee. Combs takes over from Dr. Andrew Watson and will hold the position until May 2025, at which point Dr. John McCarley will succeed him. Combs' goals for his tenure include leading the TMA in efforts to protect, empower, and expand the physician community while supporting the principles of organized medicine. He stresses the significance of unity and the concept of family within the association as crucial for effectively advocating for and assisting both physicians and their patients. Combs, who has been a member of the TMA since 1998, has previously occupied various leadership roles in the organization. He obtained his undergraduate degree and completed his pediatrics residency at East Tennessee State University.

title: Lobbying groups spent around $35 million to influence Tennessee lawmakers during the first half of 2023 • Tennessee ...
summary: Lobbying groups spent about $35 million to influence Tennessee lawmakers in the first half of 2023, which is nearly $4 million more than in the same period in 2022 and a 66% increase since 2013. The biggest spender was the Tennessee Medical Association, focusing on a bill concerning Tennessee abortion law. Other significant spenders were the Center for Individual Freedom, the Tennessee Electric Cooperative Association, the Tennessee Hospital Association, and the Tennessee Health Care Association. This increase in spending is linked to the timing of Tennessee's legislative session, usually from January to late April or early May. The spending figures come from filings with the Tennessee Registry of Election Finance, using the middle range of reported expenses.

title: 'This is a basic human right': Tennessee Republican hopes to expand exceptions to the state's abortion ban
summary: A Tennessee Republican lawmaker, Sen. Richard Briggs of Knoxville, is working on a bill to expand exceptions to the state's strict abortion ban. Currently, Tennessee law only allows abortions if the woman's life is at risk. The proposed legislation aims to permit abortions if the mother's fertility is threatened or if the fetus's life is not viable. Briggs, a physician collaborating with Vanderbilt University Medical Center and the Tennessee Medical Association, argues that waiting for a woman's condition to become life-threatening before allowing an abortion could result in her becoming sterile, thereby denying the right to life for potential future children. The bill's specifics, including whether it will list specific medical conditions for an abortion exception or leave it open-ended, are still being decided. Briggs acknowledges the challenge of passing such a bill with a Republican supermajority but frames it as ultimately supportive of the pro-life movement.

title: Op-ed: The disease that kills too many women and how Congress can help change that
summary: Ovarian cancer, a disease that claims around 13,000 women annually, is difficult to detect early, greatly reducing the effectiveness of treatment. The Norma Livingston Ovarian Cancer Foundation, among others, provides support to those fighting this disease, highlighting the importance of early detection as the next best defense. Recent progress in multi-cancer early detection (MCED) tests, which can identify various cancers from a single blood sample, shows promise. However, the availability of these tests, especially through Medicare, is restricted by current limitations on quick coverage for new medical breakthroughs. Representative Terri Sewell is pushing for the Nancy Gardner Sewell Medicare Multi-Cancer Early Detection Screening Coverage Act, which aims to speed up Medicare coverage for these tests once they are approved by the FDA. This bill, backed by a wide bipartisan coalition, could greatly enhance early cancer detection, potentially saving many lives.

title: AFP Alabama recognizes National Philanthropy Day honorees
summary: The Association of Fundraising Professionals Alabama Chapter celebrated National Philanthropy Day by honoring nine individuals and organizations for their significant philanthropic contributions across Alabama. The event, held at Birmingham’s Harbert Center, also recognized eight "Volunteers in Philanthropy." Notable honorees included Dr. and Mrs. Marnix Heersink, recognized as Outstanding Philanthropists for their substantial donations, including a $95 million gift to the University of Alabama at Birmingham. Lori Livingston was awarded for her leadership in ovarian cancer treatment and research through the Norma Livingston Ovarian Cancer Foundation. Jennifer Philpot was named the Outstanding Fundraising Executive for her extensive experience in healthcare fundraising. Kathryn W. Miree received accolades for her work in charitable gift planning and endowments. Chris Biggins was honored with the IDEA Award for his contributions to sports and philanthropy for disabled individuals. Ethan Hill, an 8th grader, was recognized as the Outstanding Youth in Philanthropy for his efforts to support the homeless through his nonprofit. Express Oil Change and Tire Engineers were acknowledged as Outstanding Corporate Citizens for their support of Children’s of Alabama’s Art and Expressive Therapy program. Lastly, Heart Gallery Alabama was celebrated as an Outstanding Charitable Organization for its work in aiding foster children's adoption through professional photography and videography.

title: One-of-a-kind Alabama ovarian cancer car tags provide nearly $1.7 million for ovarian cancer research at UAB
summary: Alabama's unique ovarian cancer car tags have raised nearly $1.7 million for ovarian cancer research at UAB's Heersink School of Medicine. Supported by the Norma Livingston Ovarian Cancer Foundation, Alabama is one of only three states to offer such a car tag. Sales directly support the Division of Gynecologic Oncology's research. At the 20th annual Motherwalk event on May 13, 2023, $120,000 was donated, adding to significant overall contributions. The event raises awareness, celebrates survivors, and remembers those lost to the disease. The Drive Out Ovarian Cancer car tag, created by Charlie Waldrep in memory of his daughter, has boosted research and awareness. These funds have been crucial in advancing research, with hopes for a cure from UAB. NLOCF also offers resources for patients in treatment.

title: Motherwalk 5K to celebrate 20 years of helping women fight ovarian cancer
summary: The 20th annual Motherwalk 5K, scheduled for May 13 at Homewood Central Park, celebrates twenty years of supporting women with ovarian cancer. This event, benefiting the Norma Livingston Ovarian Cancer Foundation, seeks to raise awareness and funds for the disease, impacting 21,000 American women each year. Ashley Thompson, the foundation's executive director, emphasized the need to educate women on the silent symptoms of ovarian cancer, which is often diagnosed in its advanced stages. The Motherwalk has significantly expanded, funding research and the Just A Need program. Proceeds also benefit the University of Alabama at Birmingham's research, working closely with researchers like Dr. Trey Leith and Dr. Warner Huh. The 2023 event features a traditional 5K, a 1-mile fun run, a Virtual 5K, a dove release, and The Memory Mile, displaying photos of women affected by ovarian cancer. The event is open to children and pets, starting at 8 a.m., with online registration available.

title: ‘An Opportunity to Catch Up’: Women’s Health Execs Applaud White House’s $100M Investment
hco: MAGEE WOMEN'S RESEARCH INSTITUTE AND FOUNDATION
summary: Women's health executives and advocates have praised the White House's announcement, made by First Lady Jill Biden, of a $100 million investment into women's health research. This funding, considered significant due to the historical underfunding and understudying of women's health, aims to address areas outside the traditional focus on fertility and pregnancy, including autoimmune diseases and sexually transmitted diseases, which some feel were overlooked. The investment will be managed through the Sprint for Women's Health program by the Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health (ARPA-H). The program has outlined six areas for funding submissions, including Women’s Health at Home and Preserving Ovarian Health Past Reproductive Age, among others. This initiative marks a substantial shift towards recognizing and addressing the broader health needs of women, with submissions for funding opening soon and awards to be issued in September 2024.

title: Local ice cream company creates limited-run flavor benefitting Magee research
hco: MAGEE WOMEN'S RESEARCH INSTITUTE AND FOUNDATION
summary: A Pittsburgh-area ice cream company, Millie’s Homemade Icecream, has collaborated with the Magee-Womens Research Institute & Foundation to introduce a limited-time ice cream flavor named ‘Oh, Baby.’ This special flavor, created to celebrate Mother’s Day, aims to support women’s health research and patient care initiatives at Magee-Womens. The vanilla-flavored ice cream is mixed with frosted birthday cake pieces and rainbow sprinkles, available throughout May at select Millie’s Scoop Shops and some wholesale partners, including Giant Eagle. A portion of the sales from this flavor will be donated to the Women’s Health Impact Fund at Magee-Womens, reflecting both organizations' commitment to enhancing the health and well-being of women and babies.

title: 'Oh, Baby!': Millie's ice cream flavor celebrates Mother's Day, women's health
hco: MAGEE WOMEN'S RESEARCH INSTITUTE AND FOUNDATION
summary: Millie's Homemade Ice Cream has introduced a new ice cream flavor named "Oh, Baby!" to celebrate Mother's Day and support women's health. This initiative is a collaboration with Magee-Womens Research Institute & Foundation. A portion of the sales from this purple vanilla ice cream, which features frosted birthday cake bits and rainbow sprinkles, will be donated to the Women’s Health Impact Fund at Magee-Womens. The aim is to fund women's health research and patient care initiatives. The flavor is available in scoops, pints, and buckets and can be found at local Giant Eagle Market District locations. This collaboration is highlighted as a creative approach to raising awareness and supporting critical research in women's health, as well as celebrating motherhood.

title: Hard Rock Heals Foundation taps Jordin Sparks for monthlong Rock Women's Health campaign – KS95 94.5
hco: MAGEE WOMEN'S RESEARCH INSTITUTE AND FOUNDATION
summary: Jordin Sparks is working with the Hard Rock Heals Foundation on the month-long Rock Women’s Health campaign during Women’s History Month. This effort, also involving Women Who Rock and Gibson Gives, seeks to support the Magee-Women’s Research Institute & Foundation. The campaign began with Sparks performing at the Seminole Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Hollywood on February 28. It aims to empower women and will feature a series of performances by female artists, including a significant event on International Women’s Day, March 8, at the Hard Rock Hotel New York with artists like Bebe Rexha, Jax, and Maren Morris.

title: OneOncology Partners Continue Growth By Adding Practices to National Platform
summary: OneOncology, a leading national platform for independent oncology practices, has announced its continued expansion by integrating three partners who have added local practices and physicians to their network. This growth strategy enhances high-quality cancer care regionally, demonstrating the value independent oncologists find in affiliating with OneOncology. Notable expansions include the Los Angeles Cancer Network adding Pacific Cancer Medical Center, Tennessee Oncology incorporating three physicians from the Maury Regional Medical Group, and Cancer and Hematology Centers merging with Genesee Cancer and Blood Disease Treatment Center. This expansion brings OneOncology's network to 19 practices across 15 states, with a total addition of four large practices and 143 providers in 2023. OneOncology aims to support community oncology practices through various services, ensuring patients have access to superior care while remaining cost-effective compared to hospital settings.

title: Why OneOncology Is Adopting Verily’s Clinical Trial Management System
summary: OneOncology is integrating Verily’s SignalPath, a clinical trial management software, across its 11 community oncology clinics. This move aims to streamline clinical trial management, enhancing health equity by making trials more accessible, especially in underserved areas. SignalPath simplifies trial protocols and facilitates better communication and collaboration between research sites and sponsors, potentially reducing the administrative burden and improving efficiency. OneOncology chose Verily’s platform after a thorough search, valuing its usability and strong partnership support. This integration is expected to enable OneOncology to offer a wider range of trials across various disease types, even in smaller, rural practices, thereby connecting more patients with appropriate trials efficiently.

title: OneOncology and Its Practice Partners Celebrate Five Years of Cancer Care Excellence
summary: OneOncology and its practice partners are celebrating five years of providing exceptional cancer care. Since its inception, OneOncology has significantly expanded, growing from 3 to 18 practice partners, increasing its providers from 225 to 1,000, and boosting the number of cancer care sites from 60 to 320 across 16 states. This growth has enabled the treatment of patients to rise from 158,000 to 606,000 annually. The partnership has focused on strengthening independent community oncology practices by offering high-value services such as lab, pharmacy, radiation, and surgery, among others. Nearly all practice partners now have in-house lab services, and many offer in-house pharmacy and radiation therapy services. OneOncology's clinical team has also enhanced precision medicine services and clinical trials, enrolling over 800 patients in various studies and establishing specialized groups and learning opportunities for physicians. This collaborative effort aims to keep community oncology practices independent while improving patient access to advanced cancer care and maintaining lower costs compared to hospital settings.

title: Verily and OneOncology establish partnership for clinical trials
summary: Verily and OneOncology have formed a strategic partnership to enhance clinical trials, particularly focusing on cancer care. This collaboration aims to increase trial access and participation for new cancer therapies by integrating Verily's clinical trial management software, SignalPath, across OneOncology Research Network sites. The partnership will enable these sites to expedite trials, improve systems infrastructure, collaboration with sponsors, and streamline regulatory processes through next-generation protocol digitization technology. This initiative is expected to simplify the complexities, reduce costs, and save time in conducting clinical trials, ultimately optimizing quality and time with participants. OneOncology plans to further develop connected solutions across its research and care product offerings, continuing its collaboration with Verily. This partnership underscores the importance of technology in advancing clinical trial research and democratizing access to potential cancer treatments.

title: OneOncology Partners with Carolina Oncology Specialists
summary: OneOncology has partnered with Carolina Oncology Specialists to enhance cancer care services in Catawba County. This partnership makes Carolina Oncology Specialists the second in North Carolina and the 21st nationally to join OneOncology. The practice, established in 1983, includes 5 medical oncologists, 14 advanced practice providers, and 65 employees, and is located in Hickory, North Carolina. It offers high-quality, personalized healthcare and maintains strong affiliations with Catawba Valley Medical Center and Frye Regional Medical Center, providing services like infusion, in-office drug dispensing, and laboratory services. This collaboration aims to strengthen oncology services in the region, improve patient care at affordable costs, and maintain the practice's independence. OneOncology, founded by community oncologists, supports community oncology practices through various services, aiming to improve patient access to care at lower costs.

title: Health Care Notes: OneOncology acquires two locations
summary: Nashville-based OneOncology has bought two radiation oncology centers in South Carolina from GenesisCare, adding three radiation oncologists and 40 employees to its Coastal Cancer Center branch. This action aligns with OneOncology's goal to support independent clinics' growth and deliver superior cancer treatment. Moreover, OneOncology oversees 350 care locations and is establishing a new main office. In related news, Onsite Women’s Health has named Melissa Morris as the senior vice president of operations, responsible for over 115 partner sites. Amedisys, a home healthcare provider, has partnered with Patient Choice Laboratories for advanced molecular testing to improve infection diagnosis and treatment, showcasing Amedisys's dedication to top-notch patient care after being acquired by Option Care Health for $3.6 billion.

title: OneOncology taps Verily for clinical trials platform
summary: OneOncology has partnered with Verily to utilize Verily's SignalPath clinical trial management software (CTMS) to enhance the efficiency of clinical trials across OneOncology's network of independent cancer treatment centers in the US. This collaboration aims to accelerate cancer research and improve cancer care by streamlining regulatory processes and improving collaboration with study sponsors. SignalPath, acquired by Verily in 2021, is part of Verily's Baseline clinical research platform, which facilitates easier participation in clinical trials and helps in managing and interpreting study data. This partnership also focuses on addressing the lack of inclusivity and diversity in cancer trials by democratizing access to these trials, aiming to improve health equity. The technology from SignalPath is expected to save time and reduce the cost and complexity of studies by digitizing and systematizing study protocol workflows. This agreement comes ahead of OneOncology's sale to AmerisourceBergen and TPG for $2.1 billion.

title: OneOncology and Coastal Cancer Center Acquire New Radiation Oncology Centers
summary: OneOncology and Coastal Cancer Center have acquired two radiation oncology centers from GenesisCare, located in Conway and Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. This expansion allows OneOncology, a national, physician-led organization with 1000 providers serving over 640,000 patients annually, to enhance its service offerings and accessibility to affordable, quality care. The acquisition includes the transfer of 40 employees and 3 radiation oncologists to Coastal Cancer Center, thereby expanding the center's care spectrum to include radiation oncology. This move is aimed at providing comprehensive cancer care to communities in Horry and surrounding counties. The acquisition also ensures that patients in the region have access to the only community-based radiation treatment centers, featuring advanced technology like linear accelerators for precise treatment while sparing healthy tissue. Jeff Patton, MD, CEO of OneOncology, emphasized the acquisition's role in supporting independent practices and enhancing cancer care in South Carolina.

title: OneOncology Appoints Ian Flinn, MD, PhD as Chief Scientific Officer
summary: OneOncology has appointed Ian Flinn, MD, PhD, as Chief Scientific Officer to oversee its research network, OneR. Dr. Flinn, previously the Director of Blood Cancer Research at Sarah Cannon Research Institute and an associate professor of oncology at Johns Hopkins, has authored over 240 scientific manuscripts. His extensive experience includes leading clinical research and conducting a Clinical Fellowship in Oncology and Hematology at Johns Hopkins. In addition to his role at OneOncology, Dr. Flinn will also serve as Chief Scientific Officer at Tennessee Oncology. Davey Daniel, MD, Chief Medical Officer at OneOncology, highlighted Dr. Flinn's ability to enhance clinical trial programs and his commitment to making trials accessible in community settings. Dr. Flinn aims to improve patient access to clinical trials and advance scientific discovery across OneOncology's network. OneOncology, founded by community oncologists, aims to support independent oncology practices and improve patient care at a lower cost than hospital settings.

title: OneOncology and Coastal Cancer Center Purchase Two Radiation Oncology Centers and Partner with Three South ...
summary: OneOncology and Coastal Cancer Center have acquired two radiation oncology centers in Myrtle Beach and Conway, South Carolina, from GenesisCare. This deal also includes the partnership with three local radiation oncologists and the transition of 40 employees to Coastal Cancer Center. These centers, equipped with linear accelerators for precise radiation therapy, are crucial for maintaining access to community-based radiation treatment in the region. OneOncology, a national platform supporting independent oncology practices, aims to enhance patient care by expanding services and ensuring treatments are more affordable compared to hospital-delivered care. This acquisition aligns with OneOncology's mission to help community oncology practices remain independent and improve cancer care accessibility at a lower cost.

title: Board of Regents gets up-close experience with U of M academic health in action
summary: During their March meetings, the University of Minnesota's Board of Regents got an up-close look at the academic health initiatives at the Twin Cities campus. They toured various health science areas, including immersive training spaces like the Health Science Library Makerspace and Virtual Reality Studio. The visit showcased the University's approach to interprofessional education, aimed at preparing the future healthcare workforce and improving patient care through new discoveries. It also emphasized the importance of state and philanthropic support for advancing academic health, highlighting the need for continuous investment in care, education, and research. Moreover, the Board approved a five-year contract for President-Designate Rebecca Cunningham and discussed other university issues, including public safety updates and policy changes. The next Board meeting is set for May 9-10, 2024.

title: University of Minnesota regents set to choose U's next president
summary: The University of Minnesota's Board of Regents is set to choose the next president by the end of a specific Monday. Final public interviews will be held with the three finalists—Dr. Rebecca Cunningham from the University of Michigan, Laura Bloomberg from Cleveland State University, and James Holloway from the University of New Mexico. The search started in April 2023 after Joan Gabel left. Jeff Ettinger, ex-Hormel CEO, has been the interim president. The finalists have visited the University of Minnesota campuses, engaging in discussions on free speech among other issues. They stressed the significance of free speech and academic freedom, underlining the university's duty in nurturing a place for varied ideas and safeguarding this freedom, even when there are disagreements.

title: Fairview Health Services and University of Minnesota sign Letter of Intent for transformative next chapter of their ...
summary: Fairview Health Services, the University of Minnesota, and University of Minnesota Physicians have signed a Letter of Intent (LOI) for the University of Minnesota to purchase four key academic health facilities, marking a significant milestone in their partnership. This includes the East and West Bank campuses, M Health Fairview Masonic Children’s Hospital, and the M Health Fairview Clinics and Surgery Center. The University of Minnesota Board of Regents approved the LOI, aiming for a complete purchase by December 31, 2027. This decision is part of a multi-year, multi-phased approach for shared management and governance during the transition, ensuring continuity of world-class patient care. This strategic move aligns with the University's mission to advance the health of Minnesotans by ensuring high-quality care, educating the future healthcare workforce, and supporting health care innovations. Fairview Health Services has supported the mission of the Joint Clinical Enterprise since its evolution in 2018, and this purchase is seen as a step towards meeting the current and future needs of patients and the community.

title: Thomas Jefferson University reported financial results through Q3 2024
summary: Thomas Jefferson University reported a $30.5 million operating loss for the first nine months of fiscal 2024, despite generating total revenue of $7.4 billion.

title: Thomas Jefferson University apologizes for graduates' mispronounced names in viral video
summary: Thomas Jefferson University issued an apology after a video showing the mispronunciation of graduates' names during a commencement ceremony went viral. The incident, which particularly affected nursing graduates, led to widespread attention and criticism online. The university's statement explained that the mispronunciations were due to the presenter's reliance on phonetically spelled names on cards rather than the official list. Among the mispronounced names were "Sarah Virginia Brennan" and "Maeve Elizabeth," which were incorrectly announced in a manner that left the graduates visibly confused. The university expressed deep regret for the disappointment caused by the mistake.

title: Jefferson Health, LVHN commit to $14B, 30-hospital merger
summary: Jefferson Health and Lehigh Valley Health Network (LVHN) have signed a definitive agreement for a $14 billion merger, aiming to close in summer 2024, subject to reviews and conditions. This merger will unite 65,000 employees, 30 hospitals, and over 700 care sites, alongside a health plan and clinical research through Thomas Jefferson University. The merger intends to enhance access to quality care, promote continuous research and innovation, and prioritize value-based care. The combined organization aims to build resilience against market challenges and expand Jefferson’s nonprofit insurance plan into LVHN’s strong presence in Pennsylvania's Lehigh Valley. Jefferson Health CEO Joseph Cacchione will continue as CEO, while LVHN CEO Brian Nester will become executive vice president/chief operating officer but remain president of the legacy LVHN. The merger is seen as a strategic move to improve health outcomes and address health disparities, aiming to become Pennsylvania’s second-largest nonprofit system.

title: Thomas Jefferson University apologizes after names mispronounced at graduation ceremony
summary: Thomas Jefferson University issued an apology after a speaker mispronounced several graduates' names at its nursing student graduation ceremony. The errors were attributed to the way phonetic spellings were presented on the speaker's cards. The university expressed regret for the mistake, emphasizing that the ceremony was meant to honor the students' achievements and acknowledging the significance of the day for graduates and their families. The mispronunciations, which included names such as "Mollina -Zabeth- Cap" instead of Molly Elizabeth Camp and "Tha-mo-may" for Thomas, were noted and apologized for during the ceremony. The incident, which occurred in Philadelphia, was widely shared on social media platforms like TikTok and X.

title: Cancer Survivors Park Alliance to host lip sync battle this August
summary: The Cancer Survivors Park Alliance (CSPA) is set to host a lip sync battle event titled "Sync for Survivors" on August 17 at Greenville Theatre to support cancer survivors. The event will feature teams of 4-6 people performing choreographed lip sync routines to their favorite songs, competing for audience votes. This fundraiser aims to bring together business, community, and healthcare leaders for a night of entertainment, aiming to support the thousands of survivors and their families. Funds raised will help expand and enhance programs and events for those touched by cancer. Cancer Survivors Park, which opened in downtown Greenville in 2018, serves as a beacon of hope and healing, offering educational programming and activities. The park and its alliance aim to engage, educate, empower, and enhance the lives of anyone affected by cancer. For more information or to participate, visit SyncforSurvivors.org or contact Kay Roper at the CSPA.

title: Diane Gluck receives inaugural Cancer Survivors Park Alliance Founders Award
summary: Diane Gluck, the founder of Greenville's Cancer Survivors Park, received the first Cancer Survivors Park Alliance Founders Award for her outstanding commitment to the park and cancer survivors' support. The award recognized her work in developing and implementing the park's master plan, which opened in downtown Greenville in June 2018. The park's concept came from Gluck's daughter's senior project in 1999, leading to the creation of the non-profit organization, CSPA, to bring the park to life. Gluck's efforts in securing a location and funding for the park during difficult economic times were emphasized as key to the park's success. She was honored with a charcoal sketch of a blue heron, the park's symbol, and a small bronze statue of it will be made by local artist Charles Pate Jr.

title: Pazdan's Peloton at Cancer Survivors Park celebrates life of Joe Pazdan
summary: Pazdan's Peloton at Cancer Survivors Park celebrated the life of Joe Pazdan, a native of Greenville and founding member of McMillan Pazdan Smith Architecture, who passed away from glioblastoma in April 2023. The event, which took place on April 27, 2024, involved stationary cycling to gather funds for the Cancer Survivors Park Alliance (CSPA), aiming to transform our approach to living with cancer. The Prisma Health Life Center Health & Conditioning club provided 21 stationary bikes, and three spin class instructors offered their services voluntarily. Nearly 80 riders and 16 sponsors joined, raising close to $40,000 to help maintain the park's Beacon of Hope Spire illuminated. Local artist Dorothy Shain created a unique bandana design inspired by the park.

title: Researchers and patients team up to combat rapid aging associated with cancer
summary: Researchers and patients at Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center are working together to study the rapid aging associated with cancer treatments, which could lead to more cancer, infertility, heart disease, and other problems. Joyce Ohm, PhD, a cancer epigenetics expert, and her team are looking into how lifestyle factors can speed up changes in how genes work without changing the DNA itself. This is especially important for young cancer survivors who might face serious health issues later. They're focusing on DNA methylation, a crucial part of this aging process, to find markers in blood samples from young patients, particularly those with Hodgkin lymphoma. The goal is to see how treatments affect this aging and find ways to lessen these effects. There's also a clinical trial looking at how exercise might help breast cancer survivors by slowing down or reversing these changes. This research could improve life for cancer survivors and help understand why more young people are getting cancer.

title: Cancer Survivors Park to host 36th Annual Cancer Survivors Day event
summary: The Cancer Survivors Park Alliance is set to host the 36th Annual Cancer Survivors Day event on June 4th at Cancer Survivors Park in downtown Greenville, starting at 10 a.m. The event will feature a variety of activities including a drum/music therapy session, group survivor and family photo, fly fishing, free family and friends photographs in the Healing Garden, a 360-degree photo booth, hair painting, making cancer ribbons, hope rocks, and Subaru Loves to Care Picnic Blankets. Children's entertainment will include yard games, water activities, and an opportunity to touch the pink fire truck, which all cancer survivors are invited to sign. For more information, individuals can visit cancersurvivorspark.org.

title: 'The Bottom Line Colon Tour' to make stop at Cancer Survivors Park
summary: "The Bottom Line Colon Tour," organized by the Gibbs Cancer Center and Cancer Survivors Park Alliance, is set to visit Cancer Survivors Park on March 31, from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. This community education event features an inflatable colon exhibit, providing participants with an opportunity to learn about the signs and symptoms of colorectal issues and ways to prevent cancer. Staff from the Gibbs Cancer Center will be available to guide attendees through the exhibit and answer questions. For more details, interested individuals are encouraged to visit gibbscancercenter.org.

title: Cancer Survivors Park boardwalk to undergo renovation
summary: The boardwalk at Cancer Survivors Park in Greenville is scheduled for renovation beginning in early April, which is anticipated to last 60 days. Before the renovation, more than 1,700 memorial plaques honoring cancer patients, caregivers, and their loved ones were taken down by volunteers. Even with the renovations in progress, the park will stay accessible to the public.

title: Wear Teal Day and Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month
summary: Wear Teal Day and Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month were highlighted to raise awareness about ovarian cancer, the deadliest gynecological cancer. Celebrated at the beginning of Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month, people are encouraged to wear teal and share information about the symptoms of this disease. Around 22,000 Americans are diagnosed with ovarian cancer annually, with 3,000 cases in Colorado alone. Approximately 330 Coloradans are diagnosed each year, equating to about one diagnosis per day. Early diagnosis can lead to a 93% survival rate within the first five years, but unfortunately, 80% of diagnoses are late, reducing the survival chance to 44% beyond five years.

title: Jodi's Race for Awareness provides avenue for ovarian cancer education, support
summary: Jodi's Race for Awareness, held annually in Denver's City Park, is the second largest ovarian cancer run/walk in the U.S., aiming to support and increase awareness of ovarian cancer, the deadliest gynecologic cancer. The event sees participants wearing teal accessories, carrying signs, and gathering in Team Village to honor those who have fought the disease. It offers a sense of community for survivors, with activities like the Survivor Breakfast fostering encouragement and positivity. The race also serves as a platform for raising awareness about the subtle symptoms of ovarian cancer, emphasizing the importance of early detection since there is no screening test for the disease. Funds raised support the Colorado Ovarian Cancer Alliance's (COCA) various programs, including support groups, financial assistance, and educational resources. Denver7 partners with COCA for the event, highlighting its significance in both education and fundraising efforts for ovarian cancer.

title: West Cancer Foundation provides free wig boutique for cancer patients
summary: West Cancer Foundation offers a complimentary wig boutique specifically for cancer patients. This initiative aims to support individuals undergoing cancer treatment by providing them with free wigs. This service is designed to help patients cope with the hair loss that often results from cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy, thereby boosting their self-esteem and confidence during a challenging period in their lives. The foundation's dedication to offering this service underscores its commitment to the well-being and support of cancer patients, addressing not only their medical needs but also their emotional and psychological well-being.

title: Group of Women will bike 500 miles to raise money for cancer patients
summary: A group of 20 women, part of the She to Sea organization founded in 2022, will bike over 500 miles from Memphis to Seagrove, Florida, to raise money for cancer patients. This initiative supports the West Cancer Foundation, established in 2020 to provide free care to Mid-South cancer patients regardless of their insurance status. The foundation offers various programs, including transportation, free breast cancer screenings, and a beauty boutique, aiming to break barriers to cancer care. The women's journey starts on a Saturday and is expected to conclude by the following Wednesday. They plan to ride regardless of weather conditions, stopping every 20 to 30 miles. She to Sea is open to adding more members for future rides.

title: WE SAW YOU: “Living Legend” — Dr. Lee Schwartzberg
summary: Dr. Lee Schwartzberg was honored at an event at the West Cancer Center, celebrating his contributions to cancer research and care. The event also announced a $3 million capital campaign for the Lee S. Schwartzberg Endowed Research Program, established by West Cancer Foundation, and the dedication of the Lee S. Schwartzberg Research Institute. Schwartzberg, a significant figure in oncology with over 30 years at West Cancer Center, has been instrumental in advancing cancer treatment, particularly in breast cancer, leading to significant improvements in survival rates. The event highlighted his career, starting in New York and moving to Memphis to further his work, and his continued impact in the field now from Reno, Nevada. The Memphis Flyer, a local newsweekly, reported on this event as part of its coverage of local news and events.

title: Butterfly Ball 2023 in aid of the Mid-Western Cancer Foundation
summary: The Butterfly Ball 2023 took place on September 29 at the Radisson Blu Hotel & Spa in Limerick, with the goal of raising money for the Mid-Western Cancer Foundation. This key event in the Mid-West's social calendar supports the Foundation's work in enhancing HSE's regional Cancer Services through equipment purchases, research funding, and ongoing education at the National Cancer Centre at UHL. As cancer cases rise in the area, the Foundation is calling for increased support for patient care. The evening included a Prosecco reception, a four-course dinner, entertainment by the Michael John Ryan String Quartet, and music from Escapade, along with an auction, raffle, and spot prizes to aid fundraising. Distinguished guests like Dr. Denis O’Keeffe, Cllr Gerald Mitchell, and Gordon Kearney showed the community's backing for cancer care in the Mid-West.

title: "Delaware's DNA" Returns: Region's Largest Life Science Conference Will Convene Top Industry Leaders, Investors ...
summary: Delaware's DNA, the region's largest life science conference, is set to convene for its second annual event on May 9, 2024, at the University of Delaware’s Clayton Hall. This full-day event, hosted by the Delaware BioScience Association (Delaware Bio), will bring together national life science industry leaders, investors, new companies, researchers, and policymakers. The conference aims to showcase the growth and diversity of Delaware's life science ecosystem, featuring panel discussions and speakers on various topics, including biomedical research technologies and life science ecosystem development. A highlight of this year’s conference is the "Innovation and Investor Showcase" in partnership with the Innovation Space, presenting some of the region’s most innovative companies and offering networking opportunities with investors. The event promises to connect researchers, investors, and businesses, further building on the momentum of Delaware's life science sector. Over 300 life science professionals are expected to attend, making it a pivotal event for the industry in Delaware.

title: People on the Move: July 14
summary: The Delaware Business Times reported on recent professional movements within the state, highlighting significant hirings, promotions, and appointments. Erica McMullen was appointed as the Senior Vice President and Loan Review Director at WSFS Bank, where she will oversee the bank's loan review function across various sectors. Henry J. Jaffe has joined Pashman Stein Walder Hayden's Wilmington office as a partner in the Bankruptcy, Restructuring & Creditors’ Rights practice, bringing over two decades of experience from Troutman Pepper. Frederick J. Dawson of Dawson Wealth Management LLC was recognized as one of the 200 Fast Growing Advisors to Watch by AdvisorHub. AJ Roop has been added to Potter Anderson & Corroon LLP as Assistant General Counsel and Director of Risk Management. Anika T. Stewart has joined NorthNode Group Counseling as a Substance Use Disorder Counselor. The Delaware BioScience Association announced the election of Tim Mueller, Lakshmi Cyr, Sandra Lewisch, Tracy Shickel, and Shamus Whyte to its board of directors, alongside the reelection of two directors, emphasizing the dynamic professional landscape in Delaware.

title: The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F) and GOG Partners enrolls first patient in for GOG 3068 (HOTT)
summary: The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F) and GOG Partners have initiated the GOG 3068 (HOTT) trial, enrolling the first patient on March 8, 2024. This Phase III Randomized Trial investigates the efficacy and side effects of Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC) with Cisplatin versus no HIPEC, followed by Niraparib maintenance in patients with newly diagnosed Stage III and IV ovarian, primary peritoneal, and fallopian tube cancer. Supported by GSK, the trial is led by Dr. Charles Dietrich at the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center. The HOTT trial aims to evaluate the benefit of HIPEC in a contemporary setting where maintenance niraparib is given and will also assess the impact of homologous recombination deficiency (HRD) status on HIPEC response and the effect of enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) on surgical morbidity.
