It plans to enroll 260 patients across 35 sites in the United States, offering potential advancements in ovarian cancer treatment.

title: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F) launch BRIDGES 2.0 Research ...
summary: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F), with support from the Foundation for Women’s Cancer (FWC), announced the launch of the BRIDGES 2.0 Research Initiative on April 11, 2024. This initiative is an expanded two-year clinical trial education program aimed at cultivating the next generation of investigators in gynecologic oncology. It focuses on advancements in clinical and translational research, trial methodology, and real-world clinical trials implementation. BRIDGES 2.0 is designed for early-career gynecologic oncologists, medical oncologists, and radiation oncologists, including senior fellows and faculty members with less than ten years of experience post-training. The program offers critical insights into clinical trial design fundamentals. The initiative encourages robust participation and is supported by the FWC, along with additional partners such as the Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance (OCRA), AstraZeneca, GSK, Merck, and Seagen. Applications were being accepted as of April 4, with a deadline of May 16, 2024. The selected scholars will start their engagement in July 2024 at the NRG Oncology Semi-Annual Meeting in Denver, Colorado.

title: Thomas J. Herzog, MD, Takes Office as President of the GOG Foundation, Inc
summary: Thomas J. Herzog, MD, became the President of the GOG Foundation, Inc (previously known as the Gynecologic Oncology Group) on July 20, 2023, at the NRG Oncology Summer Meeting. He took over from Larry J. Copeland, MD, who was President for six years and has now become the Immediate Past President. Dr. Herzog is the Deputy Director at the University of Cincinnati Cancer Center and a professor in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the same university. He has been involved with the GOG Foundation for a long time, even serving as its Treasurer from 2014 to 2023. His responsibilities include managing the operations of the GOG Foundation, its corporate membership in the NRG Oncology Foundation, and the GOG-Partners program. Dr. Herzog, with his vast experience in clinical trials and business, aims to uphold and improve the Foundation's position as a top clinical trials network for gynecologic cancers.

title: Thomas J. Herzog named president of GOG Foundation
summary: Thomas J. Herzog has been appointed as the new president of The GOG Foundation Inc., succeeding Larry J. Copeland. Herzog, a distinguished gynecologic oncologist and board member of GOG-F, served as the organization's treasurer from 2014 to 2023 before his presidency. He was also the associate director of the GOG Partners program. Currently, he is the deputy director at the University of Cincinnati Cancer Center and holds the Paul & Carolyn Flory Professorship in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the same university. Herzog has contributed to several prestigious boards and councils in the field of gynecologic oncology. As president, he will lead GOG-F's efforts in clinical trials for gynecologic malignancies, focusing on diversity, operational transparency, translational research, site expansion, and trial efficiencies. He aims to continue the legacy of his predecessors by maintaining the organization's status as a premier clinical trials network.

title: Thomas J. Herzog, MD takes office as The GOG Foundation, Inc. President
summary: Thomas J. Herzog, MD, became the President of The GOG Foundation, Inc. at the NRG Oncology Summer Meeting on July 20, 2023. With a background in clinical trials and business, Herzog has contributed significantly to gynecologic oncology, authoring over 325 peer-reviewed articles. He has held various leadership roles, including Treasurer of GOG-F from 2014-2023, and has been involved in several oncology boards and editorial teams. As President, Herzog aims to enhance the GOG Foundation's role in clinical trials for gynecologic malignancies, focusing on diversity, transparency, research, and training the next generation of clinical trialists. He succeeds Larry J. Copeland, MD, who now serves as Immediate Past President. The GOG Foundation, dedicated to excellence in gynecologic malignancies research, collaborates with NRG Oncology and the GOG Partners program to improve patient care.

title: Health-related quality of life in patients with newly diagnosed advanced ovarian cancer treated with niraparib vs ...
summary: The PRIMA/ENGOT-OV26/GOG-3012 phase 3 randomized trial assessed health-related quality of life in patients with newly diagnosed advanced ovarian cancer treated with niraparib as a first-line maintenance therapy compared to placebo. The study, involving 487 patients on niraparib and 246 on placebo, used several patient-reported outcome measures to evaluate health-related quality of life. Results showed that patients treated with niraparib reported higher (worse) scores for gastrointestinal symptoms such as constipation, nausea/vomiting, and appetite loss compared to those on placebo. However, these symptoms, except for constipation, resolved over time. There was no reported worsening in overall health-related quality of life or in symptoms like fatigue, headache, insomnia, or abdominal pain over time. The study concluded that despite some initial increases in gastrointestinal symptoms, overall health-related quality of life was not worsened in patients treated with niraparib for first-line maintenance therapy in advanced ovarian cancer.

title: RUBY Part 2 trial results: Potentially practice changing results in advanced/recurrent endometrial cancer
summary: The RUBY Part 2 trial, carried out by the GOG Foundation, Inc. and other organizations, demonstrated a notable increase in progression-free survival (PFS) for patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer when treated with dostarlimab along with carboplatin/paclitaxel and niraparib, versus chemotherapy alone. Sponsored by Tesaro Inc., a GSK group company, the trial showed a PFS improvement from 33.7% to 57.0% in the overall study group and from 31.1% to 54.7% in the MMRp/MSS group at 12 months. These findings, presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology’s Annual Meeting, suggest a potentially new standard of care that could significantly prolong PFS for these patients. The safety profile of the combination therapy aligned with those of the individual drugs. This trial marks a cooperative effort among gynecologic oncology groups globally to enhance outcomes for patients with gynecologic cancers.

title: ENGOT-EN6-NSGO/GOG-3031/RUBY trial results: The new standard of care in advanced/recurrent endometrial cancer
summary: The ENGOT-EN6-NSGO/GOG-3031/RUBY trial has established a new standard of care for advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. The study, involving ENGOT, NSGO-CTU, and GOG-Foundation, demonstrates that combining dostarlimab with standard chemotherapy (carboplatin/paclitaxel) followed by dostarlimab monotherapy significantly improves overall survival at 24 months from 56% to 71.3% and progression-free survival in the study population. This represents a significant advancement over the current first-line treatment, offering hope for better long-term outcomes in patients with primary advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. The trial's results, which are considered groundbreaking, were presented at ESMO's Virtual Plenary and the Society of Gynecologic Oncology's Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer, and published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: UAMS awarded $11.48 million for cancer research | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: UAMS (University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences) has been awarded an $11.48 million federal grant to establish a center focused on cancer research over five years. This funding, from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences' Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence program, will support the creation of the Center for Molecular Interactions in Cancer at the Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. Led by Professor Robert Eoff, the center aims to improve understanding of cancer at the molecular level, aiding in insights into its initiation, progression, and treatment. The grant will fund the development of two research cores equipped with specialized cancer research tools, including cryogenic electron microscopy for high-resolution imaging. The initiative also includes artificial intelligence and robotics to enhance research efficiency and features a faculty development program for mentoring junior investigators.

title: UCLA and UAMS teams secure $3.2 million NIH grant for melanoma research
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: A team from UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer and the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute has received a $3.2 million grant from the National Institutes of Health. This grant will support their research in discovering new ways to prevent and combat treatment resistance in all sub-types of cutaneous melanoma, a severe form of skin cancer. Many melanomas exhibit genetic alterations that activate the MAPK pathway, with approximately half possessing specific BRAF mutations that can be targeted by current treatments. However, resistance to these treatments frequently develops, resulting in more aggressive cancer forms. The grant will facilitate the creation of the Melanoma Resistance Evolution Atlas (MREA), which will use tumor samples from biopsies grown in specially bred mice to evaluate combination treatments. The goal of this atlas is to decipher how melanomas develop resistance and to pinpoint new drug targets for upcoming therapies. This research may also aid patients with other cancer types, including lung and colorectal cancers.

title: Arkansan Sees Advanced Cancer Disappear with Experimental Drug Offered at UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer ...
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: Dwight Hamilton, a 58-year-old from Little Rock, Arkansas, experienced complete remission from stage 4 renal cell carcinoma after participating in a Phase 1 clinical trial for an experimental immunotherapy at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. Despite undergoing all standard cancer treatments, including surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and other immunotherapies, Hamilton's cancer had returned multiple times over four years. The new immunotherapy, tested for the first time in humans both at UAMS and 45 other hospitals nationwide, led to the dramatic shrinking of his tumors. After receiving 15 doses over 11 months, his tumors completely disappeared. The UAMS Cancer Clinical Trials Team, under the direction of Michael Birrer, M.D., Ph.D., is conducting nine Phase 1 clinical trials on new cancer drugs. Hamilton continues to receive the immunotherapy every few weeks with no side effects or complications, showcasing the potential of new, targeted approaches to improve outcomes and quality of life for cancer patients.

title: UAMS announces it has raised $30 million toward goal of becoming National Cancer Institute | Arkansas Democrat ...
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) announced it has successfully raised $30 million in private donations to support its goal of becoming a National Cancer Institute. This fundraising milestone was reached with a significant contribution from the family of Chris Fowler, who donated $5 million. Fowler, a throat cancer survivor treated at UAMS in 2011, previously donated $1 million with Kim Fowler in 2021. The donations support the efforts of UAMS' Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute in Little Rock, highlighting the exceptional care and treatment provided by its staff.

title: Distinguished Cancer Researcher, Yong Zhu, Ph.D., Joins UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute Leadership
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: Yong Zhu, Ph.D., a notable cancer epidemiologist, has been appointed as the associate director for population science and translational science at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. Additionally, he will serve as a professor of epidemiology at the UAMS Fay W. Boozman College of Public Health. Zhu's recruitment follows over two decades of leadership at the Yale Cancer Center and Yale University School of Public Health, where he significantly contributed to cancer prevention and global cancer epidemiology. Michael Birrer, director of the Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute, highlighted Zhu's role in addressing the critical need for state-specific cancer research in Arkansas. Zhu aims to advance population-based cancer research through interdisciplinary collaborations, focusing on reducing cancer burden and health disparities in Arkansas. His research includes identifying cancer risk biomarkers and studying circadian factors and small noncoding RNAs in tumorigenesis. Zhu has led numerous National Institutes of Health grants and is widely recognized for his contributions to the field of cancer research.

title: Heflin brothers to again chair UAMS tennis tournament | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: Jay and Marc Heflin are co-chairing the UAMS Health Little Rock Open tennis tournament at Rebsamen Tennis Center, marking their fourth year in this role. The event, scheduled from May 26 to June 2, aims to raise funds for the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences' bone marrow transplant program, a cause close to the Heflins due to their father's battle with myelogenous leukemia and subsequent treatment in Los Angeles. The tournament, a Challenger series event, attracts players ranked between 150 to 350 worldwide and serves as a significant fundraiser, differing from other for-profit tournaments. It is notable for being the second longest-running professional tennis tournament held in the same location, with this year being its 43rd iteration. The Heflins, who own and operate Legacy Termite and Pest Control, have a long history of involvement in the tournament, which was paused during the COVID-19 pandemic but resumed in 2021 with UAMS as the host. The event is free to attend, thanks to sponsorships, and features both singles and doubles matches, with an expected participation of about 120 players from 20 countries.

title: UAMS Hosts National Proteomics Symposium
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) hosted a National Proteomics Symposium at the Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute on February 20 and 21. This event, organized by the IDeA National Resource for Quantitative Proteomics at UAMS, attracted proteomics directors and staff from across the United States, including Puerto Rico. The symposium focused on the analysis of disease-causing proteins, with discussions on state-of-the-art approaches, technology, and best business practices in proteomics. It featured talks on data collection methods, database searching, and bioinformatics, with a notable presentation on mass spectrometry advancements by Khatereh Motamed from Thermo Fisher. Alan Tackett, Ph.D., who established the proteomics national resource at UAMS in 2016, highlighted the importance of protein study in cancer research and therapy discovery. Funded by a $10 million grant from the National Institute for General Medical Sciences (NIGMS), the UAMS program supports thousands of researchers nationwide, analyzing around 10,000 samples annually to aid in developing new therapies for various diseases, including cancer.

title: 30+ Year Leukemia Survivor to Share Story at UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute April 17
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: Mel Mann, a 32-year survivor of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), will share his story at the UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute on April 17. Diagnosed in 1995 and given three years to live, Mann was part of a Phase 1 clinical trial for Gleevec in 1998, a drug that became a landmark in CML treatment, greatly enhancing survival rates. Mann's cancer is now in remission, and he continues his Gleevec regimen. He champions the cause of clinical trial participation, underlining its critical role in advancing cancer therapies. The event is designed to motivate and educate patients, caregivers, and medical professionals about the importance of clinical trials, showcasing UAMS's contribution to pioneering treatments through its Phase 1 Clinical Trial Unit.

title: UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute Achieves $30 Million Fundraising Goal for NCI Designation
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) has successfully reached its $30 million fundraising goal for the Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute to obtain National Cancer Institute (NCI) Designation. This achievement was made possible with significant contributions, including a $5 million donation from the Chris Fowler family. The campaign received 8,700 donations from both Arkansans and donors across the country. Achieving NCI Designation is vital for UAMS and Arkansas, as it provides access to significant federal research funding, the ability to conduct new clinical trials, and is expected to result in a $72 million economic boost for Arkansas, creating approximately 1,500 new jobs over five years. Arkansas has also contributed $170 million towards this goal, and the state has approved a mix of taxes to support the initiative. This accomplishment marks a step forward in improving cancer research and treatment in Arkansas and beyond.

title: Medicine and Sustainability Lecture at UAMS on May 16 to Focus on 'Climate, Biodiversity and People'
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) is set to host the second annual lecture in the Richard and Ellen Sandor Lecture Series on May 16, featuring Stephen T. Jackson, Ph.D., as the speaker. Jackson, a scientist emeritus at the U.S. Geological Survey, will present on "Climate, Biodiversity and People: Actionable Science in a Post-Normal World" at the Walton Auditorium in the UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. The lecture, which aims to address the intersections of climate change, biodiversity, and human impact, is open to the public free of charge, with no registration required. Jackson's career has largely focused on ecological responses to environmental changes over the past 25,000 years, and his work has expanded to include conservation and climate-change adaptation. The lecture series is supported by a gift from the Richard and Ellen Sandor Family Foundation.

title: UAMS Awarded $11.48 Million Federal Grant to Establish Center for Molecular Interactions in Cancer
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) has been awarded an $11.48 million federal grant by the National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) program. This grant, which spans five years, will support the creation of the Center for Molecular Interactions in Cancer (CMIC) at the UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. The CMIC will focus on examining the molecular aspects and interactions that promote cancer using structural biology and high-resolution imaging to gain a comprehensive understanding of cancer's onset, development, and treatment strategies. Under the guidance of Robert Eoff, Ph.D., the center will also improve UAMS's cancer research capabilities by establishing two research cores furnished with advanced equipment for cancer studies. This effort is anticipated to cultivate a network of researchers dedicated to innovating in cancer research, ultimately benefiting Arkansas's population by employing cutting-edge technology and approaches in combating cancer.

title: UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute to Hold Oct. 27 Proton Symposium
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute will host Arkansas's first symposium on proton therapy on October 27, 2023. The event, titled "Proton Therapy: The Forefront of Cancer Treatment," will take place from 8 a.m. to noon in the Walton Auditorium on the institute's 10th floor. It will feature guest speakers James Metz, M.D., and Nancy Mendenhall, M.D., who are experts in radiation oncology from the Abramson Comprehensive Cancer Center and the University of Florida Health Proton Center, respectively. The symposium, which includes breakfast and lunch, will also offer attendees the opportunity to tour the Proton Center of Arkansas in the afternoon. This center represents a collaboration between UAMS, Arkansas Children’s, Baptist Health, and Proton International. The event is free, with options for continuing education credits, and will be livestreamed on Zoom for those who preregister.

title: Radiation Oncologist Ciani Ellison, M.D., Joins UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: Dr. Ciani Ellison, a radiation oncologist specializing in pediatric cancers, has joined the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute. With her expertise in treating children's cancers, including blood cancers and soft tissue sarcomas, as well as gynecological cancers in adults, Dr. Ellison is a valuable addition to the UAMS team. She is one of only two pediatric radiation oncologists in Arkansas, both located at UAMS. An Arkansas native, Dr. Ellison completed her medical degree at the Medical College of Wisconsin, where she also completed her internship in internal medicine and residency in radiation oncology, serving as chief resident. Dr. Ellison sees patients at the UAMS Radiation Oncology Center, which houses the new Proton Center of Arkansas, a facility offering advanced radiation therapy for both children and adults. She also serves as an assistant professor in the Department of Radiation Oncology at the UAMS College of Medicine.

title: UAMS Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute to Offer Lung Screenings on Saturday, Nov. 11
hco: UAMS WINTHROP P ROCKEFELLER CANCER INSTITUTE
summary: The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Winthrop P. Rockefeller Cancer Institute will offer lung cancer screenings on Saturday, Nov. 11, from 8 a.m. to noon. These screenings will be conducted using low-dose CT scans on the 3rd floor of the institute located at 449 Jack Stephens Drive in Little Rock, with free parking available in UAMS Parking Deck 3. Appointments are required and can be made by calling 501-686-6055. The screenings, recommended for current or former smokers who have quit within the last 15 years, adults aged 50 to 80, and those with a smoking history of at least 20 pack-years, take about 15 minutes. Low-dose CT screening is covered by Medicare and most private insurances. This initiative, coinciding with National Lung Screening Day and Lung Cancer Awareness Month, aims to address the low lung cancer screening rates, despite lung cancer being the leading cause of cancer deaths in Arkansas and the United States.

title: Tips for Managing Medical Bills During Cancer
summary: CURE's Speaking Out video series featured Monica Fawzy Bryant from Triage Cancer discussing strategies for managing medical bills after a cancer diagnosis. Key points include understanding one's health insurance policy, especially the provider network and the out-of-pocket maximum. Bryant stressed the importance of challenging insurance denials. She explained the appeals process, often involving an internal appeal with the insurance company and possibly an external appeal with an independent entity. Statistics indicate that although most denied claims are not appealed, about half of the appealed claims are decided in favor of the patient. Bryant also highlighted the importance of self-advocacy with insurance companies and staying organized with all medical bills and insurance documents. Additionally, she mentioned Triage Cancer's resources and educational events that offer further help in navigating legal and financial issues after a cancer diagnosis.

title: iDMentorship365 Program
summary: The iDMentorship365 Program is a year-long initiative designed to support and guide individuals entering the field of infectious diseases (ID). It connects mentees with experienced ID professionals who provide insights, feedback, and advice to help them develop the skills and knowledge necessary for a successful career in ID. The program includes professional development, education, and a focus on the mentee’s future career vision. Benefits of the program include a 1-year electronic subscription to key ID journals, membership in the Infectious Diseases Society of America, access to a mentorship community platform, and various networking opportunities at ID Week. The program aims to prepare a capable workforce to address public health threats through effective mentor-mentee interactions. Applications are open to medical students, residents, and fellows in the U.S., Mexico, or Canada, with matching based on subspecialty interest, experience, and level of medical training.

title: The IDSA Foundation Honors Dr. George W. Counts
summary: The IDSA Foundation has honored Dr. George W. Counts by naming an executive conference room after him, recognizing his significant contributions to patient care, research, and medical education. Dr. Counts, a renowned physician, researcher, teacher, mentor, and leader, has had a profound impact on the field of infectious diseases, particularly in advancing the care of patients of color and mentoring early-career infectious diseases physicians who were underrepresented. His career includes pivotal roles at the University of Washington, the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, and leading clinical trials for HIV drugs at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. He also coordinated the CDC’s National Plan to Eliminate Syphilis, significantly reducing syphilis rates. Dr. Counts founded a networking group to support minority ID professionals, contributing to the IDSA’s goals for inclusion, diversity, access, and equity. In 2021, he received IDSA’s Walter E. Stamm Mentor Award. The IDSA Foundation, established in 2001, supports education, career development, and research in infectious diseases.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Hispanics in ID With Dedication of Hispanics in ID Executive Conference Room
summary: The IDSA Foundation has dedicated its Hispanics in ID Executive Conference Room to celebrate the contributions of Hispanic professionals in the infectious diseases field and to support upcoming generations. The 2022-2023 honoree is Dr. Laila Woc-Colburn, recognized for her commitment to mentoring Hispanic medical students and her achievements in infectious diseases at Emory University School of Medicine. Despite Hispanics making up 16% of the U.S. population, they only represent 6.6% of medical students, highlighting a gap that the IDSA Foundation aims to address by inspiring more Hispanics to enter the medical and infectious diseases fields. Dr. Woc-Colburn's work, particularly in mentoring and establishing connections with Latin American institutions, exemplifies the efforts to increase diversity and inclusion within healthcare. The IDSA Foundation, established in 2001, focuses on career development, education, and research in infectious diseases, promoting advancements in patient care and supporting diverse future leaders in the field.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Dr. Stanley Falkow and Dr. Lucy Tompkins
summary: The IDSA Foundation honored Stanley Falkow, PhD, FIDSA, and Lucy Tompkins, MD, PhD, FIDSA, by dedicating an executive conference room to them. Falkow, known as the father of bacterial pathogenesis, made significant contributions to microbiology, including discovering plasmids and mechanisms of antibiotic resistance. He received numerous awards, including the National Medal of Science from President Obama. Tompkins, a pioneer in molecular epidemiology, has had a long career in infectious diseases at Stanford University. Together, they mentored hundreds of students, significantly impacting medicine and science. The IDSA Foundation, the charitable arm of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, aims to support education, fund research, and develop careers in infectious diseases.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Memory Of Dr. John And Jean Bartlett
summary: The IDSA Foundation honored Dr. John Bartlett and his spouse Jean by dedicating a member lounge in their names, recognizing Dr. Bartlett's pioneering contributions to HIV/AIDS research and his discovery of Clostridium difficile. Dr. Bartlett, who led the Division of Infectious Diseases at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine from 1980 to 2006 and co-founded one of the world's leading HIV/AIDS clinics in 1984, made significant impacts through patient care, research, and mentorship. The dedication event was attended by the Bartletts' children, reflecting Dr. Bartlett's lasting influence. Additionally, the Dr. John G. Bartlett Memorial Education Series has been established to continue his educational legacy. The IDSA Foundation, the charitable arm of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, supports career development, education, and research in infectious diseases.

title: D.A. Henderson Award
summary: The D.A. Henderson Award for Outstanding Contributions to Public Health, initiated in 2017, honors individuals for their lifetime achievements in public health, inspired by Dr. D.A. Henderson's leadership in eradicating smallpox. The 2023 recipient, John F. Modlin, M.D., is recognized for his extensive work in pediatric and infectious diseases, particularly in perinatal viral infections, enterovirus infections, poliovirus immunization, vaccine development, and immunization policy. Dr. Modlin's notable contributions include early clinical observations and studies on perinatal enterovirus infections, significant involvement in antiviral treatment trials for preventing mother to infant HIV transmission, and leading clinical trials that influenced U.S. polio vaccination policy changes in the late 1990s. He also contributed to developing novel oral poliovirus vaccines at the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, supporting the polio eradication initiative. Dr. Modlin has held various leadership roles, including chairing the FDA Antiviral Drugs Advisory Committee and the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, and has authored over 250 peer-reviewed papers.

title: 'Shadowy' nonprofit calls shots at NY Health Dept. with little scrutiny: critics
summary: Health Research Inc (HRI), a nonprofit managed by New York's state health commissioner, has a major impact on the state's health department but is criticized for its lack of openness and legislative oversight. Critics, such as Assemblyman Ron Kim, claim that HRI, with a budget of over $1 billion, acts as a "shadow agency" by managing significant government funds and making important medical decisions without any supervision. Despite having nearly 2,200 employees, including top health officials, HRI insists it is a private organization, not subject to the Freedom of Information Law. The organization's financial statements show a net loss of $17.5 million for the fiscal year ending March 30, 2021, a stark contrast to the $506 million surplus from the year before. Critics and watchdog organizations like Empire Center for Public Policy are worried about HRI's lack of transparency, especially concerning payroll information and compensation practices. This situation underscores the difficulties of delegating public health tasks to quasi-private entities lacking public accountability.

title: Unite For HER Brings Integrative Services to TOUCH, The Black Breast Cancer Alliance's Pre-emptive Breast Cancer ...
summary: Unite for HER has joined forces with TOUCH, The Black Breast Cancer Alliance, to better support Black women in cancer clinical trials by offering integrative services. This partnership focuses on reducing the gap in clinical trial involvement among Black women by providing various supportive services and therapies like nutrition counseling and mental health resources for free. Patients suffering from metastatic breast cancer or recurrent ovarian cancer are eligible to receive therapies valued at $2,000 every six months for life. This effort is a part of the TOUCH Care program and aims to enhance treatment adherence and the overall well-being of its participants, with a goal to raise the clinical trial participation rate of Black women from the current 3%. This collaboration further extends TOUCHBBCA's mission to improve science for Black Breast Cancer and features a nurse navigation service endorsed by The White House Cancer Moonshot program.

title: Unite for HER Supports Cancer Patients Around the Main Line and Beyond
summary: Unite for HER, founded by West Chester native Sue Weldon after her breast cancer diagnosis in 2004, empowers cancer patients by bridging the gap between medical and wellness communities. Initially aimed at the Philadelphia region, the program now serves patients nationwide, offering care packages and a wellness passport for integrative therapies and services to manage treatment side effects. Weldon's initiative focuses on regaining control and confidence for those affected, with a significant impact on women of color and the underserved. The program includes six weeks of fresh vegetables and live cooking classes, supporting patients like Tiffany Reed and Brooke Schneider through their cancer journeys. Unite for HER emphasizes improving quality of life and potentially increasing survival rates for over 5,000 patients dealing with breast cancer.

title: Gymnasts battle breast and ovarian cancer at 16th annual Pink Invitational in Philadelphia
summary: At the 16th annual Pink Invitational in Philadelphia, thousands of young gymnasts gathered to compete and raise funds for Unite for HER, a nonprofit supporting breast and ovarian cancer patients by funding services not covered by health insurance. The event, held at the Pennsylvania Convention Center, saw around 92 teams participate, with each team raising money prior to the competition. Maeve Kessler, an 11-year-old participant, raised over $5,000 in memory of her aunt who passed away from breast cancer. All competitors wore pink leotards, symbolizing unity for the cause. The event, founded by cancer survivor Sue Weldon, aims to educate participants about the disease while raising funds. It is expected to raise around $700,000 for the patients Unite for HER supports.

title: Fred Beans Dealerships Raise Over $21,000 For Unite for HER in Breast Cancer Awareness Month Initiative
summary: Fred Beans dealerships in Southeastern Pennsylvania donated $21,700 to Unite for HER, a nonprofit supporting individuals with breast and ovarian cancers, as part of their Breast Cancer Awareness Month initiative. The funds were raised from a portion of vehicle sales throughout October. The donation was inspired by the support Unite for HER provided to Stacie Crane, a partner of Beans and sales operations manager with Volkswagen of America. The initiative reflects Fred Beans Automotive Group's commitment to community engagement, with plans to focus on combating hunger in December through proceeds from vehicle sales supporting local food pantries.

title: Gymnasts unite to help cancer patients at Pennsylvania Convention Center
summary: Thousands of gymnasts gathered at the Pennsylvania Convention Center to participate in a fundraising event for "Unite for HER," a nonprofit organization founded by breast cancer survivor Sue Weldon. The organization supports those diagnosed with breast or ovarian cancer by providing integrative therapies, including gift cards, massages, cooking classes, and educational resources about their journey. The event, known as the "Pink Invitational," started with 800 participants and has grown to feature more than 4,000 athletes from various locations, raising an estimated half a million dollars this year through donations and sponsorships. Participants, including several cancer survivors who shared their stories, wore matching leotards to symbolize community support for the cause. The funds raised help Unite for HER offer crucial support services to members during their cancer journey.

title: UPenn taps venture capitalist Ramanan Raghavendran to lead board of trustees
hco: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA
summary: Ramanan Raghavendran, a venture capitalist and University of Pennsylvania (Penn) graduate, has been appointed as the new chair of Penn's board of trustees, effective immediately. This follows the sudden resignation of the previous chair, Scott Bok, amid controversy. Raghavendran, who has been a Penn trustee since 2014 and is the managing partner of venture capital firm Amasia, steps into the role during a challenging time for the Ivy League institution. His appointment comes after the resignation of Penn's president, Liz Magill, over her testimony before Congress regarding antisemitism, leading to a leadership shuffle within the university. Raghavendran replaces interim chair Julie Platt and expresses his commitment to supporting Penn's mission and upholding the values of modern civilization through education.

title: Penn Trustees approve 2024-2025 undergraduate charges and financial aid budget | Penn Today
hco: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA
summary: The University of Pennsylvania Board of Trustees has approved a 3.9% increase in undergraduate tuition for the 2024-2025 academic year, setting the total undergraduate charges at $87,860. This includes tuition of $60,920, fees of $7,766, a standard room rate of $12,640, and a meal plan charge of $6,534. Alongside this increase, a record $311 million undergraduate financial aid budget has been approved, marking a 4.5% increase from the previous year. This expansion in financial aid is designed to offset the rise in costs for students with demonstrated financial need, ensuring that 46% of students who receive need-based financial aid significantly benefit. The financial aid program at the University meets 100% of demonstrated need without loans, emphasizing grant funds and work-study. The average financial aid package is $66,764, covering more than the cost of tuition and 75% of the total cost of attendance. The University also continues to support financial wellness among students through programs like Financial Wellness @ Penn.

title: Penn names J. Larry Jameson new interim president after Liz Magill's resignation
hco: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA
summary: Penn has appointed J. Larry Jameson as the new interim president following Liz Magill's resignation due to her controversial comments on Capitol Hill regarding antisemitism on campus. Jameson, who has been with Penn Medicine and the University of Pennsylvania Health System since 2011, is recognized for his leadership and deep understanding of Penn's values. Magill's resignation came after her testimony about antisemitism at U.S. universities, sparking criticism and leading to her decision to step down while remaining a tenured faculty member at Penn's law school. Jameson's appointment is seen as a stabilizing move during a challenging time for the university, emphasizing safety, inclusivity, and the rejection of hate on campus. This leadership change occurs amidst broader scrutiny of Penn's policies on antisemitism, highlighted by federal investigations and public controversies.

title: Warrior Against Multiple Myeloma | Health | thejewishnews.com
summary: Sid Moss, diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2009, was honored with the “Spirit of Hope Award” by the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (MMRF) at the 2023 MMRF Southeast Michigan Walk/Run for his contributions to raising awareness and funds for multiple myeloma research. After his diagnosis and subsequent stem cell transplant in 2011, Moss felt compelled to get involved in the fight against this blood cancer, which affects approximately 25,000 Americans annually. Despite not being curable, multiple myeloma is considered highly manageable with treatments like immunotherapy and stem cell transplants. Moss founded the Cure Multiple Myeloma Corp. (CMMC) and initiated Wine & Dine in the D, an event that has raised over $1.6 million for research since 2010. The event, now in its 13th year, brings together the community, patients, caregivers, and specialists to discuss new treatments. Moss has also established the Ask the Doctor series to educate patients about new drug therapies and the evolving landscape of myeloma treatment.

title: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center
summary: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK), located in New York, NY, is a leading nonprofit hospital and healthcare provider specializing in cancer treatment and research. With a mission to end cancer, MSK employs over 10,001 experts, including physicians and scientists, who are dedicated to personalized and compassionate care. The center is involved in groundbreaking translational and clinical research, driven by discoveries at its own Sloan Kettering Institute. This research is revolutionizing the understanding and treatment of cancer, making significant strides in prevention, diagnosis, and therapy. MSK is also committed to educating the next generation of cancer scientists and clinicians globally. Recognized as one of the top two cancer hospitals in the U.S. for over 30 years by U.S. News & World Report, MSK continues to lead in the fight against cancer with its innovative studies and treatments, as evidenced by its significant presence and contributions to the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting.

title: New Phase 1 Data from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Shows an Investigational Cancer Vaccine May Elicit ...
summary: New Phase 1 data from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center reveals that the investigational mRNA cancer vaccine, autogene cevumeran, may elicit a lasting immune response in pancreatic cancer patients, potentially reducing the risk of disease recurrence post-surgery. The vaccine, developed in collaboration between BioNTech and Genentech, is tailored to each patient's tumor mutational profile, aiming to train T cells to recognize and attack cancer cells. Initial results from the trial showed the vaccine was well tolerated and activated immune cells in half of the patients. Further analysis indicated a significant persistence of vaccine-induced T cells for up to three years, correlating with delayed cancer recurrence in a subset of patients. This ongoing research underscores the potential of autogene cevumeran as a post-surgical adjuvant treatment for pancreatic cancer, with a phase 2 trial currently underway to further evaluate its efficacy and safety.

title: Billionaires Griffin And Geffen Donating $400 Million To Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center—Largest In ...
summary: Billionaires Ken Griffin and David Geffen are donating $400 million to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, marking the largest single gift in the institution's history. Announced on "Good Morning America," the donation aims to support the center's 20,000 staff members, implement new technologies including robotics, and construct state-of-the-art facilities to enhance patient care. The specifics of how the donation will be divided between Griffin and Geffen were not disclosed. This contribution is part of their broader philanthropic efforts, with Griffin having donated over $1.6 billion to various causes and Geffen having made significant donations to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the University of California Los Angeles's medical school, and the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center.

title: Geriatric Oncology Educational Opportunity at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center
summary: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center will host the 3rd annual Geriatric Oncology Symposium for Advanced Practice Providers on April 23, 2024. This virtual, full-day event is aimed at health-care providers who care for older adults with cancer, including physicians, nurses, and interprofessional team members. The symposium, organized by the Division of Advanced Practice Providers and the Geriatric Medicine Service, focuses on equipping participants with essential knowledge for treating older cancer patients. The 2024 symposium will emphasize the psychosocial aspects of cancer care under the theme “Delivering Person-Centered Care,” covering topics like health advocacy, financial toxicity, caregiver support, shared decision-making, and communication strategies. Dr. Carolyn Clancy will give the keynote address, and a patient and family caregiver panel will offer insights into cancer care from their perspectives. Registration is now open.

title: Inclusion & Belonging at Memorial Sloan Kettering
summary: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) emphasizes its strong commitment to equality, diversity, and inclusion, with a zero-tolerance policy for racism, bigotry, and hate. MSK is actively fighting systemic racism, creating better opportunities for people of color, and striving to be more inclusive and diverse. This commitment is seen as crucial to driving innovation and fulfilling their mission of delivering world-class cancer care, research, and education. MSK believes in the importance of a diverse and inclusive culture to provide high-quality care to all patients and their families globally. Their focus includes race, ethnicity, cultural diversity, age, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, the LGBTQ community, religion, and disability. Efforts to foster a supportive environment include increasing education on cancer care and clinical trial participation, diverse hiring practices, and working with diverse suppliers. MSK's Supplier Diversity Program and Employee Resource Networks (ERNs) support their mission by promoting innovation and inclusivity. These initiatives are part of MSK's broader goal to become a more inclusive institution and maintain its reputation in cancer care, research, and education.

title: Experts to Present Leading-Edge Research at the American Association for Cancer Research Annual Meeting 2024 ...
summary: Experts from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) will present their latest research at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2024 in San Diego, California, from April 5-10. The presentations will address cancer metastasis, immunology, molecular biology, genetics, and early drug development. Highlights include Dr. Vinod Balachandran's updates on personalized RNA neoantigen vaccines for pancreatic cancer, Dr. Luis Diaz Jr.'s discussion on monitoring residual disease in solid tumors, Dr. Dana Pe'er's insights into cancer cell adaptation and spread, and Dr. Jonathan Yang's data on the safety and efficacy of AZD1390 with radiation therapy for glioblastoma. Other topics include prostate-specific antigen testing myths, profiling tumor ecosystems, and the evolutionary dynamics of whole-genome doubling in ovarian cancer. Selwyn M. Vickers, MD, FACS, President & CEO of MSK, will be recognized as one of the 30 international leaders elected to the AACR Academy Class of 2024 for his contributions to pancreatic cancer research.

title: MSK Research Highlights, May 10, 2024
summary: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) has released new research findings. One study evaluated unscheduled healthcare interactions among multiple myeloma patients receiving T cell redirection therapies, such as CAR T cell and bispecific antibody therapies, finding nearly 90% had at least one unscheduled interaction, with an average of 3.7 per patient. Another study linked the presence of oral bacteria in feces to gut microbiota depletion, which has implications for cancer patients, suggesting that enhancing healthy gut bacteria could improve patient treatment strategies. Additionally, MSK's adoption of a universal opt-out tobacco treatment referral has shown potential to reduce racial disparities in tobacco treatment access and utilization among cancer patients, with findings indicating higher treatment use among Black and Hispanic patients. These studies highlight the importance of supportive care in cancer treatment and the potential for improving patient outcomes through targeted interventions.

title: MSK Researchers Develop New Open-Source Method To Improve Decoding of Single-Cell Data
summary: Researchers at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center have developed a new open-source computational method called Spectra to improve the analysis of single-cell transcriptomic data. Spectra helps in understanding the complex interactions between cells, such as those between cancer cells and immune cells, which is vital for the progress of immunotherapy treatments. By removing technical noise, Spectra identifies functionally relevant gene expression programs, making it an effective tool for studying large patient cohorts and finding biomarkers and drug targets in immuno-oncology. Spectra, which is freely available to the global research community, was developed under the leadership of Dana Pe'er, PhD, with co-first authors Russell Kunes and Dr. Thomas Walle. This method marks a significant step forward in the single-cell revolution, providing a new way to view the complex biology of health and disease, including the mechanisms of cancer treatment resistance.

title: Location, Location, Location: The Hidden Power of Intracellular Neighborhoods
summary: Molecular and cell biologist Dr. Christine Mayr and her team at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center have discovered significant details about where inside cells messenger RNA (mRNA) translation happens. This could change how mRNA therapies are developed. They found that the cell's cytoplasm, once thought to be a uniform mix, is actually split into different areas that translate specific mRNAs. This division impacts how much protein is made from the mRNA. Their study suggests that mRNA moves to these areas based on size, shape, and interactions with proteins that bind RNA. These insights could help improve or alter protein production in treatments using mRNA. The team, led by Dr. Ellen Horste, used new methods to mark and organize cell parts, showing that different mRNAs are translated in specific cell areas. This builds on Mayr's previous work, including finding TIS granules, a type of cellular structure without a membrane that helps translate mRNA. The findings about where and how mRNA is translated could help make mRNA vaccines and treatments more effective by directing mRNA to the right cell parts for the needed protein production levels.

title: Four Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Researchers Named 2024 Kravis Women in Science Endeavor (WiSE ...
summary: Four researchers from the Sloan Kettering Institute at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center have been awarded the 2024 Marie-Josée Kravis Women in Science Endeavor (Kravis WiSE) fellowship grants. This initiative, now in its fifth year, aims to support women in science and promote gender equity by providing stable funding, mentoring, and professional development opportunities. The 2024 recipients include postdoctoral fellows Vittoria Bocchi and Julia Brunner, and graduate students Melissa Yao and Tzippora Chwat-Edelstein. Their research spans understanding Parkinson’s disease, investigating metabolic pathways in stem cells and cancer cells, exploring cancer progression through extrachromosomal circular DNAs, and studying genomic integrity maintenance. The Kravis WiSE program highlights the importance of supporting female scientists and their contributions to scientific innovation and discovery.

title: Department of Nursing
summary: The Department of Nursing at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) is renowned for its innovation in cancer care, research, mentorship, and training, based on a model of Relationship-Based Care to ensure the best experience for patients, their families, and staff. Led by Tracy Gosselin, PhD, RN, FAAN, the department consists of over 5,400 highly skilled nurses and nursing support staff across 17 MSK facilities, with nearly all holding a bachelor’s degree or higher in Nursing, two-thirds certified in their specialty, and more than 60 with doctoral degrees. MSK nurses are integral in advancing cancer treatment and research, contributing to the development of new guidelines and treatment discoveries. The department has received numerous recognitions, including Magnet recognition for excellence in nursing and various accreditations for its educational programs. It offers comprehensive training and mentorship for nursing staff at all career stages, highlighting its commitment to excellence in oncology nursing and patient care.

title: The Jonathan Peled Lab: Sukanya Sahu
summary: Sukanya Sahu is a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Jonathan Peled Lab, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. After completing her PhD at the International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology in New Delhi, India, where she studied the dysbiosis of gut microbiota in tuberculosis patients, she joined the Peled Lab in 2023. Her current research focuses on understanding the role of gut microbial metabolites in graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

title: Investigational mRNA Vaccine Induced Persistent Immune Response in Phase 1 Trial of Patients With Pancreatic Cancer
summary: An investigational mRNA vaccine, autogene cevumeran, showed potential in inducing a persistent immune response in a Phase 1 trial involving patients with pancreatic cancer, as reported by Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. The vaccine activated immune cells that persisted for up to three years in some patients, correlating with a reduced risk of cancer recurrence post-surgery. Developed through a collaboration between BioNTech and Genentech, this vaccine is tailored to each patient's tumor, targeting neoantigens unique to their cancer cells. Initial results were promising, with the vaccine well tolerated and activating immune cells in half of the treated patients. A Phase 2 trial, aiming to evaluate the vaccine's efficacy and safety in a larger group, is currently underway. This trial involves patients receiving the vaccine alongside an immunotherapy drug and chemotherapy, comparing this regimen to the standard treatment of surgery followed by chemotherapy. This approach represents a significant step forward in the use of customized mRNA vaccines for cancer treatment, particularly for pancreatic cancer, which has limited effective treatment options.

title: Georgia Ovarian Cancer Alliance to host “Shaken, Not Stirred” Gala
summary: The Georgia Ovarian Cancer Alliance will hold its annual "Shaken, Not Stirred" Gala on Saturday, March 9, at the Georgia Aquarium. Doug Barron, the Executive Director, emphasized the event's emphasis on ovarian cancer awareness. This event is a part of the organization's mission to educate and support individuals impacted by ovarian cancer.

title: SYMBIOTIC PARTNERSHIP – Simply Buckhead
summary: Raquel Souza introduced the ancient art of sugaring hair removal to Atlanta by opening the first Sweet Peach Wax & Sugaring Studio in Virginia-Highland in 2012, later expanding to several other locations. Beyond providing beauty services, Souza partnered with the Georgia Ovarian Cancer Alliance to promote early detection of ovarian cancer by distributing educational materials about its signs and symptoms to her customers. Committed to health and safety, she uses all-natural products for sugaring and waxing, replacing talcum powder with cornstarch due to health risks. The sugaring process involves a natural paste that adheres only to hair, not skin, making it a gentler alternative to waxing. Souza also supports various nonprofits, including TurningPoint Cancer Rehabilitation.

title: Israeli Researchers Target Ovarian Cancer
summary: Israeli researchers from Tel Aviv University have made significant progress in ovarian cancer treatment, focusing on aggressive and metastatic cancers resistant to chemotherapy and immunotherapy. The research, led by Professor Dan Peer, utilizes lipid nanoparticles containing RNA to silence a specific protein produced by genetically unstable mutations in ovarian cancer tissues. This approach has shown promising results, with an 80% survival rate in mice, and is expected to move to human trials within two to three years. The research addresses the challenge of recurrent ovarian cancer, aiming to prevent its return after initial treatment. Ovarian cancer, the fifth deadliest malignancy in women, affects one in every 78 females worldwide. The risk is higher among Ashkenazi Jewish women due to a higher prevalence of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. The Georgia Ovarian Cancer Alliance, led by Doug Barron, emphasizes the importance of this research in improving survival rates and the potential for early detection and treatment of ovarian cancer.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Participates in Statewide Gathering to Enhance Cancer Care in ...
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) is participating in the Florida Society of Clinical Oncology (FLASCO) 2024 Business of Oncology Summit & Spring Session in Kissimmee, FL. This event gathers medical providers, patients, payors, and other stakeholders from across Florida to discuss both clinical and non-clinical aspects of community oncology. FCS physicians and senior leaders, including FLASCO President and FCS medical oncologist/hematologist Maen Hussein, MD, and FLASCO State Legislative Chair and FCS medical oncologist/hematologist Paresh Patel, MD, will play significant roles. The summit will address the integration of AI technology in clinical practice, updates in breast and lung cancer treatment, and the integration of bispecifics and CAR-T therapies. It aims to enhance cancer care by navigating current and future challenges in the landscape of cancer care. FCS is known for offering access to numerous clinical trials and has been recognized for its research contributions.

title: Feds fund $45M Rice-led research that could slash US cancer deaths by 50%
summary: The Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health (ARPA-H) has awarded a $45 million grant to a team led by Rice University to develop a new cancer treatment technology. This technology, an implant that can sense and respond, aims to cut U.S. cancer deaths by over 50%. Designed to treat cancers like ovarian and pancreatic, the implant will monitor the patient's cancer and adjust their immunotherapy dose in real-time. This less invasive device is a significant shift from traditional treatments to a more personalized approach. The project, called THOR, involves a team from seven states, 20 research labs, and includes a clinical trial for recurrent ovarian cancer. This effort by ARPA-H could save hundreds of thousands of lives each year.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: ASCO (American Society of Clinical Oncology) provides various resources and programs for oncology professionals across its network of sites and initiatives. It offers platforms like ASCO Connection for member blogs and discussions, ASCO Daily News for research summaries and news, and a collection of journals dedicated to clinical oncology research. ASCO Practice Central helps professionals navigate the complex practice environment, while ASCO Education delivers up-to-date information on oncology advancements. CancerLinQ® is a technology platform that utilizes patient data to improve cancer care. Cancer.Net provides resources for patients and families, and Conquer Cancer supports researchers around the world. The TAPUR Study examines the effectiveness of targeted anticancer drugs. ASCO also promotes professional development, networking, and advocacy through its state/regional affiliate programs, encouraging engagement and participation in local societies to build a strong oncology community. These affiliates spearhead advocacy efforts, offer professional development, and grant continuing education credits.

title: Cancer survivors build community, 'smash away stress' at rage room event in Moline
summary: The NormaLeah Ovarian Cancer Initiative organized an event at Patty's Pummel Palace in Moline on World Ovarian Cancer Day to aid those who have survived ovarian cancer. At this event, survivors took part in breaking items such as bottles and plates using bats, serving as a way to alleviate stress and foster a sense of community. Survivor Michelle Morrison highlighted the importance of valuing life and creating memories, particularly because of the high likelihood of ovarian cancer returning. The goal of this initiative is to increase awareness about ovarian cancer, which impacted around 238,000 women in the United States in 2021.

title: Advancing Precision Medicine: Frederick Health's Landmark, Strategic Collaboration with MEDITECH and ...
summary: Frederick Health, a leading healthcare system in Frederick County, Maryland, has formed a partnership with GenomOncology and MEDITECH to advance its precision medicine program. This partnership includes integrating GenomOncology's Precision Oncology Platform with MEDITECH's Expanse Genomics solution into Frederick Health's Electronic Health Record (EHR) system. This integration allows healthcare professionals at Frederick Health to order genetic tests, analyze results, and recommend treatments based on individual genetic profiles directly through their EHR. This initiative aims to enhance cancer care by providing access to extensive precision oncology data, including clinical trials and approved therapies, thus enabling more informed patient care decisions. Frederick Health, with its team of over 4,000 members and 25 locations, is committed to improving community well-being through advanced healthcare and wellness services. This collaboration is a significant step towards harnessing the power of precision medicine in daily clinical practice, offering improved patient outcomes.

title: Frederick Health Hospital Names 2024 Nurses of the Year
summary: Frederick Health Hospital announced its 2024 Nurses of the Year, honoring two outstanding nurses for their contributions. Jeb Gibson, a Clinical Nurse Specialist, received the Indirect Care Nurse of the Year award for his multifaceted role in the emergency department, demonstrating leadership, compassion, and dedication, especially noted during the pandemic. Ellen Nicodemus, a Registered Nurse in Pediatrics, was awarded the Direct Care Nurse of the Year for her 22 years of experience, leadership, and ability to blend clinical expertise with compassion. Frederick Health, serving Frederick County, includes a hospital, medical group, and other healthcare services, employing over 4,000 team members and striving to impact community well-being positively.

title: Frederick Health adds new electronic records platform to boost precision medicine program
summary: Frederick Health has partnered with GenomOncology to enhance its precision medicine program by integrating Expanse Genomics into its Meditech Expanse Electronic Health Record (EHR) system. This collaboration will enable Frederick Health to order genetic tests, analyze results, and guide treatments based on individual genetic profiles. Additionally, the use of GenomOncology’s Precision Oncology Platform within Expanse Genomics will improve access to comprehensive precision medicine information within the EHR, enhancing decision support capabilities. Frederick Health, employing over 4,000 healthcare professionals, offers a range of healthcare services in Frederick County, including a hospital, medical group, employer solutions, home care, and hospice, across multiple specialties and locations.

title: Frederick Health's journey through technology and compassion
summary: Frederick Health is committed to advancing patient-centric healthcare through innovative health informatics, genomic medicine, and a focus on compassion. The organization leverages MEDITECH Expanse and patient portals to enhance patient engagement, empowering individuals in their care journeys. Efforts to combat clinician burnout include adopting AI solutions like the Dragon Ambient eXperience (DAX) to reduce administrative burdens. Frederick Health's venture into genomics aims to personalize medicine, particularly in oncology, by tailoring treatments to patients' genetic profiles. This approach extends to pharmacogenomics, optimizing medication efficacy and reducing adverse effects. Addressing social determinants of health (SDOH) is also central to their mission, recognizing the impact of factors like transportation, housing, and nutrition on health outcomes. Advanced analytics and dashboards support strategic initiatives and patient outreach, demonstrating the role of data in enhancing healthcare delivery. Frederick Health's integration of technology and data analytics exemplifies the potential for innovation to transform patient care, provider experience, and overall health outcomes.

title: FREDERICK HEALTH AUXILIARY AWARDS FIVE SCHOLARSHIPS TO LOCAL HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
summary: The Frederick Health Auxiliary awarded scholarships totaling $15,000 to five local high school students on April 12, 2023. The recipients were Seraphim Kozlov, Annaelle LeGuellec, Reuben Puthumana, Madison Warner, and Sania Yanpallewar. LeGuellec and Puthumana each received a $4,500 President’s Scholarship. Yanpallewar was awarded the $2,000 Kay Hartman Scholarship, Kozlov received the Richard Kreh Scholarship, and Warner was given the $2,000 Alma Whitehouse Scholarship. The scholarships were funded through the Auxiliary’s Annual Tree of Lights Campaign, memorial donations, individual contributions, and life membership dues. Since its inception in 1979, the program has awarded 265 scholarships totaling $228,500. The ceremony included presentations by Thomas Kleinhanzl, President of Frederick Health Hospital; Harriet Brown, President of Frederick Health Auxiliary; Donna Tisdale, Chairperson of the Scholarship Committee; and Sharon Hannaby, Director of Volunteer Services.

title: Frederick Health Hospital Seeing Increased Patients With Respiratory Illnesses
summary: Frederick Health Hospital in Frederick, Maryland, has reported an increase in patients with respiratory illnesses, which Dr. Kathy Weishaar, the Chief Medical Officer, states is typical for this time of year. The rise in cases includes a variety of illnesses such as COVID, influenza, RSV, viral and bacterial pneumonia, and other viral respiratory illnesses. Despite the increase, the hospital is managing to efficiently process and treat patients. Treatments vary from supportive care like extra oxygen to antibiotics and steroids for bacterial infections and anti-inflammatory needs. Dr. Weishaar emphasizes that the cold weather itself isn't the cause of these illnesses but rather the increased indoor activity and close proximity to others, especially following holidays. She advises getting vaccinations for COVID, flu, and RSV, avoiding close contact with others if sick, and considering wearing a mask to prevent the spread of illnesses.

title: Frederick Health Announces International Certification and Expansion
summary: Frederick Health announced that Family Connects Frederick County has been certified as a Family Connects International (FCI) Community Partner, achieving this milestone in the shortest time since the program's inception. The service offers a 90-minute in-person visit for families, providing health assessments for babies and parents and tailored resources. Since its launch in early 2023, nearly 1,100 families have benefited. The program aims to improve community health outcomes, including higher rates of postpartum visits, reduced postpartum depression, decreased race disparities, lower Child Protective Services investigations, and reduced infant emergency room visits. Starting early 2024, it will expand to serve all birthing families in Frederick County. Frederick Health, encompassing a hospital, medical group, and other healthcare services, supports this initiative as part of its mission to enhance community well-being.

title: Final phase of emergency room opening at Frederick Health, officials hope to mitigate wait times
summary: Frederick Health is concluding its emergency room construction project, valued at nearly $47 million, within the next two weeks. This expansion aims to address the critical healthcare needs of Frederick County's growing population by reducing wait times, which currently average around 30 minutes. The project adds 70 total treatment spaces, an increase of 13 from before, including nine crisis beds for behavioral health needs and a forensics suite for assault victims. With Maryland previously ranking last in ER wait times nationally, this development is significant for the community. The final phase, introducing the last 11 treatment spaces, is set to open on November 20th, marking the end of this multi-year project.

title: Frederick Health Hospice begins offering services at two Montgomery County medical centers
summary: Frederick Health Hospice has started a collaboration with Adventist HealthCare to offer inpatient hospice services at two of its hospitals in Montgomery County, Maryland, located in Rockville and Silver Spring. This partnership aims to provide care for patients nearing the end of their lives at Adventist HealthCare's Shady Grove Medical Center and White Oak Medical Center. Services have already begun at Shady Grove and are expected to start at White Oak later this year. This partnership was formed due to Frederick Health Hospice's need to extend its services in Montgomery County, supported by a certificate of need and also addresses a gap for Adventist HealthCare, which did not have a hospice affiliation before. The project includes sending nurse navigators and nurse practitioners from Frederick Health Hospice to these sites to improve the identification and transition of patients to proper hospice care.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Participation in the Enhancing Oncology Model
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON), in partnership with Thyme Care, has announced its participation in the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM), a new value-based cancer care initiative by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI). This collaboration aims to improve health outcomes and reduce the overall costs of cancer care. The EOM, which started on July 1st, 2023, is a five-year program focusing on quality, access, and cost alignment through care quality incentives, 24/7 patient navigation services, and health equity. Thyme Care will support AON by providing data-driven solutions, analytics, and nurse navigation to ensure high standards of oncology care at reduced costs, addressing care continuum gaps and health equity disparities. This partnership is expected to lead to better patient experiences, outcomes, and lower cancer care costs.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Expansion into Florida with New Community Oncology Practice Serving ...
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON) has expanded into Florida by opening a new community oncology practice, Florida Oncology & Hematology (FOH), in Safety Harbor, serving the Tampa Bay area. This marks AON's growth into its 19th operating state, addressing the nationwide challenge of inaccessible cancer care. FOH, led by Board-certified medical oncologist Dr. Jose Alemar, aims to provide local, affordable cancer care and therapies. The clinic is equipped with three private exam rooms, an on-site infusion room, lab services, in-house pathology services, a specialty pharmacy, and offers financial counseling among other patient support services. Alemar, with over 18 years of experience, specializes in treating various cancers, including rare types. AON, established in 2018, is one of the fastest-growing networks of community oncology practices in the U.S., aiming to ensure the long-term success of community oncology through a physician-led, community-based management model.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Alti Rahman as New Chief Strategy and Innovation Officer
summary: The American Oncology Network, LLC (AON) announced the appointment of Alti Rahman as the new Chief Strategy and Innovation Officer, effective July 3, 2023. With 15 years of experience in healthcare and oncology, Rahman brings significant expertise to AON, a fast-growing network of community-based oncology practices. His role will involve leading the company's business strategy, strategic initiatives, and expanding into new markets across the nation. Rahman, who holds a dual master’s degree in business and healthcare administration and is a Certified Six Sigma Black Belt, previously served as the practice administrator at Oncology Consultants in Houston, Texas. His appointment is expected to help AON continue its growth and success in community oncology, improving cancer care and closing the cancer care gap. AON, recognized by Inc. 5000, partners with physicians and healthcare leaders to enhance the quality of care for patients while transitioning to value-based reimbursement models.

title: Expert: The Growth of the 340B Drug Pricing Program Has Influenced the Landscape of Cancer Care
summary: The 340B Drug Pricing Program, created in 1992 to offer discounted outpatient drugs to qualified healthcare organizations for low-income and uninsured or underinsured patients, has greatly influenced cancer care. Initially, expansion was gradual, but the Affordable Care Act in 2010 caused a rapid increase in participating hospitals. By 2019, the program expanded to 2500 hospitals. Recent adjustments by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) aimed at lowering Medicare payments for 340B drugs, aiding community oncology by reducing financial motives for 340B hospitals to buy community practices and reducing patients' out-of-pocket expenses. However, the proposed 2024 Hospital Outpatient Payment System might negate these advantages. The 340B program has faced criticism for leading to drug shortages and failing to ensure savings are passed to patients, with many hospitals not offering discounts on 340B drugs to low-income or uninsured patients. Despite its expansion and financial benefits to hospitals, concerns remain that the program has not fully succeeded in supporting the most vulnerable patient groups.

title: American Oncology Network part of new altenative payment model
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON) has joined the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM), a new value-based cancer care framework aimed at improving outcomes and reducing the total costs of care. Announced by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation, the EOM focuses on aligning quality, access, and cost through payment incentives, around-the-clock navigation services, and a focus on health equity. AON will partner with Thyme Care, a value-based oncology platform, to facilitate its participation in this model. Thyme Care will offer support and navigation beyond the clinic, helping patients overcome barriers to care. This partnership aims to maintain high standards of oncology care in a cost-effective manner, address health equity disparities, and provide resources for addressing the social determinants of health. Launched in 2018, AON includes 106 physicians and 86 nurse practitioners and physician assistants across 19 states, focusing on physician-led, community-based oncology management.

title: American Oncology Network to Host Investor Presentation Webcast on September 29
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON) has announced it will host an investor presentation webcast on September 29, 2023, featuring CEO Todd Schonherz and CFO David Gould. This presentation aims to outline AON's business model, growth strategy, and unique value proposition. AON, a rapidly expanding network of community-based oncology practices, recently merged with Digital Transformation Opportunities Corp., a special purpose acquisition company. This merger, completed on September 20, 2023, led to AON commencing trading on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "AONC" on September 21, 2023. The webcast will be available for replay on AON's Investor Relations website. AON, established in 2018, comprises 109 physicians and 86 nurse practitioners and physician assistants across 19 states, focusing on the long-term success of community oncology.

title: American Oncology Network, a Rapidly Growing Network of Community-Based Oncology Practices, Receives Strategic ...
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON), a rapidly expanding network of community-based oncology practices, announced a strategic growth investment from AEA Growth on April 28, 2023. Since its inception in late 2018, AON has aimed to support community oncology practices by providing a clinically integrated platform, comprehensive support, and practice management expertise. This partnership is designed to enhance cancer care by offering services such as clinical research, specialty pharmacy, diagnostics, and pathology, along with a dedicated care management team and financial assistance programs for patients. AEA Growth will invest $65 million into AON, acquiring a minority interest, while the company will continue to be majority-owned and governed by licensed oncologists. This investment, which is subject to customary closing conditions, will be used to further AON's mission of supporting community practices and improving patient experiences. AON has shown significant growth, generating over $1.1 billion in revenue in 2022, a 20% increase from the previous year, and currently includes almost 200 providers across 77 locations in 17 states.

title: American Oncology Network Appoints Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board of Managers
summary: The American Oncology Network, LLC (AON) announced the appointments of Dr. Shalin R. Shah as chairman and Dr. Stephen “Fred” Divers as vice chairman of its Board of Managers, effective January 1, 2023. Dr. Shah, a medical oncologist at the Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute, joined the Board in January 2022 and has previously served as vice chairman. He has been involved with various boards in healthcare, technology, and education sectors. Dr. Divers, a medical oncologist at Genesis Cancer and Blood Institute and AON's chief medical officer since May 2022, also joined the Board in January 2022. Both appointments are part of AON's efforts to support community-based oncology practices and improve access to cancer care. AON, established in 2018, is a rapidly growing network supporting the long-term success of community oncology, representing 107 physicians across 18 states.

title: EY Announces Todd Schonherz of American Oncology Network, LLC as an Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2023 Florida ...
