summary: Ernst & Young LLP (EY US) announced Todd Schonherz, CEO of American Oncology Network, LLC (AON), as a finalist for the Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2023 Florida Award. This award, now in its 37th year, honors transformative entrepreneurs and leaders of high-growth companies who contribute to a more equitable, sustainable, and prosperous world. Schonherz was recognized for his entrepreneurial spirit, purpose, growth, and impact, among other attributes. AON, founded in 2018, is a rapidly growing network of community oncology practices that provides local access to quality and affordable cancer care. It addresses significant challenges faced by community practices, ensuring their long-term sustainability and the continued access of patients to high-quality, cost-effective care. AON operates 76 sites in 17 states plus the District of Columbia. Regional award winners will be announced on June 8, with national awards in November and the possibility of competing for the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year™ Award in June 2024.

title: Triple Crown Urology Opens in Hot Springs, Arkansas, and Joins American Oncology Network
summary: Triple Crown Urology has opened in Hot Springs, Arkansas, as the first urology practice under the American Oncology Network (AON). Founded by Drs. Seth Hollenbach, Nathan Littlejohn, and Renee Warford, the practice aims to provide high-quality, comprehensive urological care across southwest Arkansas, including Hot Springs Village, Camden, Mena, Benton, and Arkadelphia. Specializing in diseases and complications of the urinary system and both benign and oncologic urologic issues, Triple Crown Urology employs advanced technology and minimally invasive surgery techniques. Joining AON allows the practice access to additional resources such as a referral physician portal, an in-house specialty pharmacy, intravesical chemotherapy, and patient financial counseling, enhancing their ability to deliver patient-centered care. The partnership aligns with AON's mission to support community oncology and expand its services beyond oncology, demonstrating its commitment to improving patient care across different medical specialties.

title: HMP Global Expands Market Reach with Strategic Acquisition of Drug Channels Institute; Launches Market Intelligence ...
summary: HMP Global has announced its acquisition of Drug Channels Institute, a prominent source of market intelligence for the $1.5 trillion pharmaceutical industry. This strategic move enhances HMP Global's offerings, combining Drug Channels Institute's expertise with HMP Market Access Insights to form a new division. This acquisition, aligning with HMP Global's growth strategy, aims to provide comprehensive solutions and deeper insights into pharmaceutical market access and regulatory issues. Drug Channels Institute, founded by Adam J. Fein, Ph.D., is known for its data-driven insights into pharmaceutical economics and the pharmacy distribution and reimbursement system. The acquisition follows HMP Global's purchase of Proximity Health, LLC, marking a significant step in expanding its healthcare market analysis and intelligence capabilities. Jeff Hennessy, Chairman and CEO of HMP Global, emphasized the investment in this space to drive innovation and address customer needs. Adam J. Fein and Paula Fein will join HMP Global, with Dr. Fein becoming President of Drug Channels Institute.

title: Amplatzer Steerable Delivery Sheath for Complex LAAO | JIC
summary: The Amplatzer Steerable Delivery Sheath, developed by Abbott Cardiovascular, is a novel device designed to improve the success rate of Left Atrial Appendage Occlusion (LAAO) procedures, especially in complex anatomical situations. Traditional methods often have difficulty achieving the right alignment between the delivery sheath and the LAA neck, crucial for effective occlusion. The steerable sheath solves this by allowing the distal end to be angled widely, from 0º to 120º. This feature greatly improves the ability to align correctly with the LAA neck, increasing the chances of complete occlusion and lowering the risk of complications. The device proved its worth in a case where standard methods couldn't achieve proper alignment due to difficult anatomy. By using the steerable sheath, the medical team could adjust their approach angle and successfully perform the occlusion. This development marks a significant advancement in treating patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation, providing a safer and more effective option than oral anticoagulation therapy.

title: Real-World Comparative Effectiveness Assessment Study of a Native Type I Collagen Matrix Plus Polyhexamethylene ...
summary: A study compared the effectiveness of a native type I collagen matrix with polyhexamethylene biguanide (PCMP) versus a cryopreserved cadaveric skin allograft (CCSA) for treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs). Conducted on 989 DFUs, the non-inferiority analysis showed no significant differences in healing rates between PCMP and CCSA at various time points, with a median healing time of 18 weeks for PCMP and 17 weeks for CCSA. The probability of healing was statistically equivalent, confirming PCMP's non-inferiority to CCSA. This suggests both treatments are comparably effective for DFUs, which could help guide clinicians in choosing appropriate therapies.

title: Use of Suprapubic Panniculus for Split-Thickness Skin Graft in Buried Penis Repair
summary: The article discusses the innovative use of suprapubic panniculus for split-thickness skin grafts in repairing buried penis deformity, a condition becoming more prevalent in the United States due to rising obesity rates. It highlights two cases where skin grafts were successfully harvested from the panniculus, avoiding the creation of a second defect which is a common issue when using the anterior thigh as a donor site. This method demonstrated over 95% graft take in both patients, with minimal complications such as a fungal rash and a hematoma, both of which were effectively treated. The use of pannicular skin grafts presents a durable option for buried penis deformity correction, showing significant improvements in patient quality of life postoperatively. This approach also addresses the challenges of finding suitable donor sites in patients with extensive defects or widespread intertrigo, offering a reliable alternative that eliminates concerns associated with other donor sites.

title: Two-Tiered Outpatient Behavioral Care System a Potential Fit for Modern Healthcare Landscape
summary: Ed Jones, PhD, discusses the increasing demand for outpatient behavioral care and the need for innovative care delivery models, including a two-tiered system, to address unmet behavioral health needs. He highlights the challenges of securing adequate funding and navigating healthcare's complex cost management models, particularly the value-based care (VBC) model. VBC, which is not well understood in the behavioral health field, involves funding arrangements that could potentially limit financial risk for health plans but may not adequately fund behavioral health services. Jones argues that the allocation for behavioral care within VBC models is uncertain and may not meet population needs, as health systems might prioritize funding for medical care over behavioral health. He emphasizes the importance of not limiting care to major disorders only and advocates for a more comprehensive approach that includes primary and specialty behavioral care. Jones calls for bold proposals to ensure behavioral health services can meet the vast needs, advocating for a robust presence in primary care and continued provision of specialty services for complex conditions.

title: NBC 10 Skin Check at Roger Wheeler State Beach canceled
hco: PARTNERSHIP TO REDUCE CANCER IN RHODE ISLAND
summary: The NBC 10 Skin Check event scheduled for Friday at Roger Wheeler State Beach in Narragansett has been canceled due to the forecast of stormy weather. The event was part of a series offering free skin cancer screenings, made possible by NBC 10 in collaboration with the Rhode Island Department of Health, Brown Dermatology, the Partnership to Reduce Cancer in Rhode Island, and Lifespan Community Health Institute. The next screening is planned for July 21 at Lincoln Woods Beach. Additional events are scheduled throughout the summer to continue promoting skin cancer awareness and prevention.

title: Five MLS players team up to raise money for cancer patients and families | MLSSoccer.com
summary: Five Major League Soccer (MLS) players have collaborated to support Family Reach, a national nonprofit aiding cancer patients and their families financially. LAFC's Kellyn Acosta and Aaron Long, Paul Arriola of FC Dallas, William Yarbrough from the Colorado Rapids, and Dominique Badji of FC Cincinnati initiated The 5 for 50 Fundraiser aiming to gather $50,000. This fundraiser, active from February 15 to March 15, 2023, seeks to alleviate the financial burdens faced by families undergoing cancer treatments. These burdens often force families into making tough choices between essential needs and medical expenses due to income loss and rising out-of-pocket costs. Family Reach assists by covering critical living expenses such as housing, food, and utilities to support these families during challenging times.

title: MiBA: A New Era in Data-Driven Oncology Insights for a Healthier Tomorrow
summary: MiBA (Meaningful Insights Biotech Analytics), a pioneering healthcare technology company, has been launched to revolutionize oncology, research, and patient care through data analytics. A collaboration between American Oncology Network (AON) and Ascend Technologies Group (ATG), MiBA is led by a team of experts including Todd Schonherz, Mark Moch, Jason Baroff, Scott Newman, and Andrew T. Fisher. The company's platform leverages artificial intelligence to provide healthcare decision-makers with essential data and tools to enhance research, risk evaluation, and cost reduction, thereby facilitating more precise diagnoses and personalized treatment plans. MiBA aims to unlock insights from vast oncology patient data, improving cancer care outcomes. It operates across 25 community oncology practices in 20 states, with plans for expansion. MiBA invites partnerships with healthcare professionals to advance the use of data-driven insights in cancer treatment. For more information, visit www.mibanalytics.com.

title: $1 billion SWFL cancer services network begins trading on Nasdaq
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON), based in Fort Myers, has become the latest publicly traded company in the Southwest Florida region, with its shares starting to trade on the Nasdaq stock exchange on September 21. The company, which involves a network of 200 providers across 30 practices in 20 states, went public following a merger with Digital Transformation Opportunities Corp. (DTOC), a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). AON's IPO was a significant milestone, with shares initially closing at $20.50, though they later dropped to $7.93 by October 6. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about its future, having generated $1.2 billion in revenue and a non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA of $23 million in the 12 months ending in June 2023, even as it reported a net loss of $4.6 million. The merger with DTOC was completed after overcoming challenges, including a significant return of funds to investors, showcasing AON's commitment to growth and serving patients in the cancer treatment market.

title: Research aims to harness technology for improved heart and brain health
summary: The American Heart Association's Strategically Focused Research Network on Health Technologies and Innovation has funded research projects aimed at leveraging technology to enhance heart and brain health. The research, featured in a special issue of the Journal of the American Heart Association, involves the development of digital solutions such as smartphone applications, wearable devices, and artificial intelligence to improve health outcomes, reduce healthcare disparities, and empower individuals in managing their own health. Highlights include the development of an "EyePhone" app for stroke diagnosis, text messaging to encourage physical activity in cardiac rehabilitation patients, mobile health apps to improve physical activity and nutrition for those with high blood pressure, and AI for detecting rheumatic heart disease. These projects represent a significant step towards validating scalable digital solutions for cardiovascular health, emphasizing the importance of technology in advancing healthcare and making it accessible and user-friendly for both healthcare professionals and patients.

title: 2022-2023 Annual Report
summary: The 2022-2023 Annual Report of the American Heart Association (AHA) highlights its commitment to saving lives and enhancing health for all. Marking its centennial year, the AHA has launched a "nation of lifesavers" movement, emphasizing the importance of CPR training, in response to increasing awareness following Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin's on-field cardiac arrest. The report outlines the expansion of CPR awareness and training, particularly through the Resuscitation Quality Improvement Program (RQI), and efforts to address rural health disparities. It also showcases the AHA's advocacy for Medicaid expansion and postpartum coverage, aiming to improve access to care for financially struggling populations. The AHA continues to invest in research, with more than $5 billion allocated to date, focusing on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease. Additionally, the report discusses initiatives to build healthier communities through access to nutritious foods and equitable healthcare services. Advocacy efforts have led to significant policy changes at national, state, and local levels, including Medicaid expansion in various states and increased access to AEDs in schools. Financial highlights and strategic goals for health equity and research are also presented, reflecting the AHA's ongoing mission to be a relentless force for a world of longer, healthier lives.

title: Walk this way – it's quite good for you
summary: Walking is a simple yet effective form of exercise that can significantly improve health, according to experts. Dr. Tiwaloluwa Ajibewa and Dr. Kelley Pettee Gabriel emphasize its benefits for weight control, reducing the risk of heart disease, diabetes, and aiding in the management of heart disease symptoms. Walking at a brisk pace contributes to the recommended 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per week. Although 10,000 steps a day is a popular goal, research indicates that the optimal number of steps varies by age and health goals, with benefits observed at lower step counts. Pace also matters for certain health outcomes, but overall movement is key, regardless of speed. Walking can be done anywhere and adapting to personal preferences and circumstances is important. Urban design affects walking accessibility, highlighting the need for policy to support walkable communities. Starting a walking routine can be simple, and gradually increasing activity is advised. Varying routes and pace can enhance benefits. Walking not only offers physical health benefits but also mental health improvements, underscoring the importance of incorporating it into daily life.

title: National retailers support heart and stroke health through annual Life is Why™ campaign
summary: In February, during American Heart Month and its Centennial year, the American Heart Association (AHA) is partnering with national retailers for the Life is Why™ campaign to support heart and stroke health. The campaign encourages consumers to donate at the point of sale or buy products that contribute to the cause. Companies like AT&T, CVS Health, and Walgreens, along with new supporters like Daily Harvest and Reebok, are participating. The campaign features in-store and online promotions to inspire healthier living and support the AHA's mission. Donations help address heart disease and stroke risk factors, such as tobacco use and high blood pressure. The Life is Why campaign aligns with the AHA's goal for a world of longer, healthier lives and marks its 100th year of lifesaving efforts.

title: American Heart Association names 2024 Atlanta Heart Challenge Chairperson
summary: The American Heart Association has appointed Heather Ross, Vice President of Strategic Communications for Genuine Parts Company, as the chairperson for the 2024 Atlanta Heart Challenge. This initiative aims to mobilize local companies and the community to fight against heart disease and stroke. Ross will lead a team of 12 executives to encourage participation in the Heart Challenge’s various activities such as the Heart Walk, Hard Hats with Heart, and Executives with Heart campaigns. These efforts are designed to raise funds for the American Heart Association while promoting discussions on employee health, corporate involvement, and community wellness. The 32nd annual Atlanta Heart Walk is scheduled for September 21 at Lenox Square. Ross's leadership is expected to significantly contribute to raising awareness and funds for heart disease and stroke in the Atlanta area.

title: Research adds to knowledge about heart disease and stroke in women of all ages
summary: Research highlighted in the Journal of the American Heart Association's 2024 Go Red for Women® issue reveals significant findings on heart disease and stroke in women of all ages, emphasizing sex-specific risks and outcomes. Cardiovascular disease is a leading cause of death for women, affecting nearly 45% of those aged 20 and older in the U.S. Despite this, women constitute only 38% of cardiovascular clinical trial participants. Key studies include the impact of sedentary behavior on older women's heart disease risk, the relationship between schizophrenia and heart disease development, and the influence of maternal dietary patterns on preeclampsia risk. Findings suggest a need for gender-specific care and increased awareness and prevention efforts, especially considering the unique challenges women face at different life stages and the underrepresentation in clinical research.

title: The slowly evolving truth about heart disease and women
summary: The article discusses how our understanding of heart disease in women has evolved, highlighting past misconceptions and advances in research and awareness. Initially, heart disease was considered a man's issue, relegating women to caregiver roles. This was evident in the American Heart Association's (AHA) earlier focus, such as a 1960s conference aimed at helping women support men with heart disease. However, by the late 20th century, it was recognized that heart disease significantly affects women too, challenging the old belief that women were less at risk due to hormone protection until menopause. Research in the 1980s and 1990s began including women, uncovering gender-specific patterns and risks in heart disease. Initiatives like the NIH policy for equitable research inclusion and the Go Red for Women campaign have aimed to increase awareness and improve treatment for women. Despite advancements, there remain gaps in awareness and treatment, with recent studies indicating rising hospitalization rates for heart attacks among younger women and disparities in treatment and outcomes. The article emphasizes the need for ongoing research and education on heart disease in women, including recognizing unique risk factors and ensuring women receive proper care.

title: Heart attack deaths spike during the winter holidays
summary: Heart attack deaths significantly increase during the winter holidays, with research indicating the last week of December as the deadliest period. The American Heart Association highlights the importance of recognizing heart attack signs and reducing risk factors during this time. Studies have shown a 15% overall rise in heart attacks during the holidays, with a 37% spike on December 24th, particularly affecting those over 75 and individuals with diabetes or previous cardiovascular conditions. Factors contributing to this increase include cold weather affecting blood flow, holiday stress, and overindulgence in food and drink. Ignoring warning signs of heart attacks and strokes is a critical concern. The Association urges the public to learn Hands-Only CPR and discuss family health history during gatherings. Additionally, it provides heart-healthy tips for the holidays, emphasizing the importance of moderation, stress management, physical activity, and medication adherence to mitigate heart attack risks.

title: New initiative focuses on oral health clinicians in prevention and early detection of heart disease
summary: The American Heart Association, in collaboration with Delta Dental, has launched the Healthy Smiles, Healthy Hearts™ initiative to improve patient health nationwide by expanding access to integrated care and educating both patients and clinicians about the connection between oral and heart health. This initiative aims to engage oral health clinicians in heart health screening, including blood pressure screenings and referrals to primary care when necessary, to create a new standard of care at dental offices. It highlights the role of oral health professionals in a comprehensive care team to reduce cardiovascular disease risk. The initiative also seeks to educate healthcare professionals and patients on the importance of good oral hygiene for overall health and well-being. This collaborative effort underscores the significance of dental visits as part of a holistic health check for early detection of cardiovascular diseases and other conditions, leveraging the fact that many people visit dentists regularly but not primary care providers.

title: At the AHA, advocacy leads to health impact
summary: The American Heart Association (AHA) has evolved its advocacy efforts since its inception in 1924, addressing public health challenges like inadequate funding for cardiovascular research and tobacco use. In 1981, recognizing the need for direct engagement with policymakers, the AHA established a dedicated government affairs team and an Office of Public Advocacy in Washington D.C. This move marked a significant shift towards advocating for public policies that support the AHA's mission to combat cardiovascular disease. The organization's nonpartisan advocacy is backed by scientific evidence, focusing on issues like tobacco use, access to care, nutrition, and physical activity. Efforts at the federal level initially concentrated on increasing the National Institutes of Health's research budget and combating tobacco use. The AHA's advocacy has expanded to all 50 states, leading thousands of campaigns with the help of over half a million volunteers in the You're the Cure network. Successes include legislation for smoke-free laws, tobacco tax increases, the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act, and raising the federal minimum legal sales age for tobacco products to 21. Additionally, the AHA has championed affordable healthcare through support of the Affordable Care Act and Medicaid expansion, as well as nutrition security by advocating for healthy food accessibility and SNAP benefits. The AHA continues to push for CPR training requirements in schools and aims to address health disparities and advocate for equitable health for all.

title: Navigating Operational Challenges With Bispecifics in R/R MM: Insights From HOPA 2024
summary: Kirollos Hanna, PharmD, from Minnesota Oncology and Mayo Clinic College of Medicine, discussed challenges and strategies for implementing bispecifics in relapsed or refractory Multiple Myeloma (R/R MM) at the HOPA 2024 conference. He highlighted the importance of building external relationships for patient support, outlining three models for initiating bispecifics: large institutions with established processes, smaller systems developing relationships for patient initiation and maintenance, and the challenge of institutions unwilling to administer bispecifics, risking patient loss. Hanna emphasized overcoming barriers through open communication between systems, recognizing the complexity of healthcare and the need for continuity of care. He also addressed the management of adverse events and the necessity for equipped emergency departments, suggesting a collaborative approach to navigate the operational challenges of bispecifics in R/R MM treatment effectively.

title: Emerging Treatment Options and Considerations in Waldenström Macroglobulinemia
summary: Waldenström macroglobulinemia (WM) is a rare blood cancer, accounting for about 1% of non-Hodgkin lymphomas, more prevalent in men, with an average diagnosis age of 72. It is characterized by lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, bone marrow infiltration, and IgM monoclonal protein. Symptoms involve circulating monoclonal IgM paraprotein, involvement of the central nervous system, lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly, peripheral cytopenia, and B-symptoms. Possible complications include hyperviscosity syndrome, cryoglobulinemia, cold agglutinin disease, peripheral neuropathy, amyloidosis, and acquired von Willebrand disease. The primary treatment involves rituximab, with the recent approval of BTK inhibitors ibrutinib and zanubrutinib, although their effectiveness may be influenced by MYD88/CXCR4 genotyping. Pharmacists are vital in identifying and managing treatment complications. The absence of randomized, controlled trials for WM means that treatment selection must consider patient-specific factors, including expected toxicities, disease characteristics, patient and provider preferences, and genomic testing.

title: Warrior Against Multiple Myeloma | Health | thejewishnews.com
summary: Sid Moss, diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2009, began induction therapy immediately. Despite the blood cancer being incurable, it's considered highly manageable with treatments like immunotherapy and stem cell transplants, the latter of which Moss underwent in 2011. Motivated by his diagnosis and recovery, Moss engaged in raising awareness and funds for multiple myeloma research, leading to the founding of his own charity, Cure Multiple Myeloma Corp. (CMMC), which has raised over $1.6 million since 2010. CMMC's efforts include the annual Wine & Dine in the D event, educational panels, and the Ask the Doctor series, aimed at educating and assisting patients in Michigan. For his contributions, Moss was honored with the “Spirit of Hope Award” by the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation (MMRF) at the 2023 MMRF Southeast Michigan Walk/Run. Moss's story highlights the importance of patient involvement in advocacy and research funding for multiple myeloma.

title: Local organization Pink Ribbon Good delivers over one million meals to families battling cancer
summary: Pink Ribbon Good, a local organization, has reached the significant milestone of delivering over one million meals to families throughout the U.S. who are dealing with breast and gynecological cancer. CEO Heather Salazar talks about the organization's mission and her own connection to cancer, which motivated the establishment of the foundation's services. Since 2012, Pink Ribbon Good has been providing meals, house cleaning kits, transportation to treatment, and peer support to women and their families affected by cancer, regardless of their socio-economic status. The organization has broadened its services to various cities and continues to expand, thanks to the commitment of its staff and volunteers. Salazar emphasizes the critical need for these services, as many of the people they help face challenges with food and transportation. Pink Ribbon Good depends on the support of the community, grants, and volunteers to keep up with the growing demand for its services.

title: High school football rivals come together in honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month
summary: High school football rivals St. X and La Salle are coming together for Breast Cancer Awareness Month during their Friday game. This partnership marks a change from their usual rivalry, with both schools planning coordinated themes and wearing special t-shirts to support the cause. St. X will give its proceeds to Pink Ribbon Good, and La Salle is helping Kim Fellinger, a mother from La Salle diagnosed with breast cancer in 2017, through t-shirt sales and donations. Fellinger, who is now in remission, stresses the importance of advocating for one's health. Although they are uniting for this cause, the competition will continue on the field, showing that it's possible to mix rivalry with community support.

title: Pfizer Joins Annual Brunch Run to Support Cancer Support Non-Profit Imerman Angels
summary: Pfizer recently showed its support for cancer patients and survivors by being the main sponsor of the Ninth Annual Brunch Run 5K and Walk organized by Imerman Angels, a non-profit that offers one-on-one support for cancer fighters, survivors, previvors, and caregivers. The event, held at Montrose Harbor, had over 1,025 participants, including walkers, runners, volunteers, and partners. Katrina M. Johnson, Pfizer’s U.S. Director of Advocacy and Professional Relations and a cancer survivor, emphasized the company's commitment to the cause in her opening speech. Pfizer employees formed two teams and raised over $10,000 for Imerman Angels. This partnership reflects Pfizer’s wider commitment to supporting those affected by cancer, as seen in initiatives like the Butterfly Club, a network of Pfizer employees impacted by cancer, aimed at providing support and building community among colleagues facing the disease.

title: Imerman Angels, CLOZTALK get people talking with those who have been there, those who can help
summary: Imerman Angels and CLOZTALK, started by Jonny and Jeff Imerman, are charities focused on helping those fighting cancer and supporting various nonprofits through clothing. Imerman Angels pairs cancer patients with survivors for guidance, helping 3,500 to 4,000 families each year, while CLOZTALK promotes nonprofits by selling quality clothes featuring their logos. Both projects highlight the importance of community and shared experiences in facing challenges. The Imerman Angels Brunch 5K Run/Walk on June 17 at Montrose Harbor, Chicago, is a fundraising event for these efforts, with entry fees of $60 for participants 13 and older, and $30 for those aged 6-12.

title: Cancer support group Imerman Angels beneficiary of comedy show
summary: A comedy show at Mr. G's Restaurant and Lounge in Osceola is set to benefit Imerman Angels, a cancer support group offering one-on-one support. The event, dubbed "Jokes with Jaz," is organized by local stand-up comedian Jason Jastrzembski and his friend Chad Marshall to celebrate over 10 years of friendship and their commitment to supporting cancer awareness. Imerman Angels, founded by Jonny Imerman who himself battled testicular cancer, aims to ensure no one faces cancer alone, having facilitated over 34,000 support matches globally. The comedy night, featuring local comedians alongside stories of cancer battles, seeks to raise $10,000. It highlights the power of laughter and community in facing cancer, with tickets available and donations encouraged through the Imerman Angels website.

title: A Cancer-Stricken Bartender Leads a Charity Effort to Support Imerman Angels
summary: Brad Bolt, a bartender diagnosed with testicular cancer, is leading a charity effort to support Imerman Angels through Heisler Hospitality's venues like Estereo, Sportsman’s Club, and Pizza Lobo. The campaign aims to raise money for cancer charity Imerman Angels in April, inspired by Bolt's personal battle with cancer and his mother's survival of thyroid cancer. Bolt, who has had surgery and is awaiting further treatment, feels energized to help others facing similar challenges. Heisler Hospitality contributes to the cause by donating $1 from sales of special cocktails at their establishments. This initiative is part of Heisler’s Community Cocktails event, which has previously raised $35,000 for various organizations. Bolt's involvement highlights the importance of support and awareness for those affected by cancer, especially within industries that lack automatic health insurance coverage for employees.

title: iDMentorship365 Program
hco: INFECTIOUS DISEASES SOCIETY OF AMERICA FOUNDATION
summary: The iDMentorship365 program is a year-long initiative designed to foster professional development and education in the field of infectious diseases (ID). It connects mentees with experienced ID professionals to guide and support them, offering insights, feedback, and advice to help build successful careers. The program includes benefits such as a 1-year electronic subscription to key ID journals, membership in the Infectious Diseases Society of America, access to a mentorship community platform, and participation in ID Week with a travel stipend. It aims to prepare a skilled workforce capable of addressing public health threats by incorporating professional development, education, and a vision for the mentee's future career. The program matches mentors and mentees based on various criteria and encourages regular meetings and participation in mentorship events. Applications are open to medical students, residents, PharmD students, and fellows in the U.S., Mexico, or Canada, with specific eligibility criteria for mentors.

title: The IDSA Foundation Honors Dr. George W. Counts
hco: INFECTIOUS DISEASES SOCIETY OF AMERICA FOUNDATION
summary: The IDSA Foundation has honored Dr. George W. Counts by naming an executive conference room after him, recognizing his significant contributions to patient care, research, and medical education. Dr. Counts, a respected physician, researcher, teacher, mentor, and leader, has notably advanced the care of patients, particularly those of color, and has mentored many infectious diseases physicians in their early careers, especially those underrepresented in the field. His career includes directing a team at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases from 1989, which supported clinical trials for HIV drugs, coordinating the CDC’s National Plan to Eliminate Syphilis in the U.S. between 1999 and 2002, and serving as a Senior Advisor at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center's HIV Vaccine Trials Unit. Dr. Counts also founded a networking consortium to support minority ID medical professionals, which aligns with IDSA’s goals for inclusion, diversity, access, and equity. In 2021, he received IDSA’s Walter E. Stamm Mentor Award.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Hispanics in ID With Dedication of Hispanics in ID Executive Conference Room
hco: INFECTIOUS DISEASES SOCIETY OF AMERICA FOUNDATION
summary: The IDSA Foundation recently dedicated the Hispanics in ID Executive Conference Room to celebrate the achievements of Hispanic professionals in the infectious diseases field and support the next generation in the field. The 2022-2023 honoree is Dr. Laila Woc-Colburn, recognized for her commitment to mentoring Hispanic medical students. Despite Hispanics making up about 16% of the U.S. population, they only constitute 6.6% of medical students, highlighting a gap that needs addressing to ensure the healthcare workforce reflects the population's diversity. Dr. Woc-Colburn's career, marked by clinical and teaching accolades, exemplifies the positive impact of diversity in healthcare. She has actively worked to empower Latino medical professionals in the U.S. and Latin America, establishing a supportive network. This initiative by the IDSA Foundation aims to promote diversity and inclusion within the healthcare sector, particularly in infectious diseases, by recognizing and celebrating the contributions of Hispanic professionals.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Dr. Stanley Falkow and Dr. Lucy Tompkins
hco: INFECTIOUS DISEASES SOCIETY OF AMERICA FOUNDATION
summary: The IDSA Foundation honored Stanley Falkow, PhD, FIDSA, and Lucy Tompkins, MD, PhD, FIDSA, by dedicating an executive conference room to them. Falkow, known as the father of bacterial pathogenesis, made significant contributions to microbiology, including discovering plasmids and mechanisms of antibiotic resistance, and was a pioneer in DNA cloning. He received numerous awards, including the National Medal of Science from President Barack Obama. Tompkins, Falkow's spouse and a prominent figure in molecular epidemiology, has served as a hospital epidemiologist and professor at Stanford University. The dedication celebrates their contributions to infectious diseases and their legacy in mentoring students and advancing science. The IDSA Foundation, established in 2001, supports education, career development, and research in infectious diseases.

title: IDSA Foundation Honors Memory Of Dr. John And Jean Bartlett
hco: INFECTIOUS DISEASES SOCIETY OF AMERICA FOUNDATION
summary: The IDSA Foundation honored Dr. John Bartlett and his spouse Jean by dedicating a member lounge in their names to recognize Dr. Bartlett's contributions to infectious diseases, especially his pioneering work in HIV/AIDS and the discovery of Clostridium difficile. Dr. Bartlett, who led the Division of Infectious Diseases at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine from 1980 to 2006 and co-founded one of the world's leading HIV/AIDS treatment centers, was celebrated for his extensive mentorship, research, and advancements in the field. The dedication event was supported by many of Dr. Bartlett’s colleagues, friends, and trainees, highlighting his significant impact. Additionally, the IDSA Foundation promotes the Dr. John G. Bartlett Memorial Education Series for further educational outreach. The Foundation, as the charitable arm of the Infectious Diseases Society of America, aims to support career development, education, and research in infectious diseases.

title: ANCO Board Elects Millie Das, MD, to Lead Oncology Association
summary: The Association of Northern California Oncologists (ANCO) has appointed Millie Das, MD, as its new president. Dr. Das, a thoracic oncologist with experience at the Palo Alto VA Medical Center and Stanford Cancer Institute, has been involved with ANCO since 2023, contributing to continuing medical education and patient advocacy. She succeeds Thach-Giao Truong, MD, after his three-year tenure. Dr. Das aims to continue ANCO's advocacy and education efforts to ensure high-quality care for patients. ANCO, founded in 1990, represents hematologists/oncologists in both community and academic settings in Northern California, aiming to deliver the highest quality care to those living with cancer. It is affiliated with the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO), the Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC), and represents hematology/oncology at the California Medical Association (CMA) alongside the Medical Oncology Association of Southern California (MOASC).

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: The text provides an overview of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) and its various programs, resources, and initiatives aimed at supporting oncology professionals and enhancing cancer care. ASCO offers a wide range of services including a family of sites like ASCO Connection, ASCO Daily News, ASCO Journals, and ASCO Practice Central, among others, which provide members with access to the latest research, news, and guidelines in oncology. It also highlights ASCO's educational resources, such as ASCO Education and the CancerLinQ® platform, designed to improve the delivery of care through real-world data analysis. Additionally, the text mentions Conquer Cancer, the ASCO Foundation, which funds research for better treatments and cures. The State/Regional Affiliate program is emphasized as a way for oncology professionals to engage locally and nationally, offering networking, professional development, and advocacy opportunities. The importance of involvement in state/regional societies and the benefits it brings to the oncology community are also discussed.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
hco: MICHIGAN SOCIETY OF HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY
summary: The text provides an overview of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) and its various programs, resources, and initiatives aimed at supporting oncology professionals and enhancing cancer care. ASCO offers a comprehensive suite of resources including ASCO Connection for member blogs and discussions, ASCO Daily News for conference reports and oncology news, and a range of peer-reviewed journals for clinical oncology research. ASCO Practice Central assists oncology professionals with navigating the complex practice environment, while ASCO Education offers timely information and learning opportunities. CancerLinQ® is highlighted as a health information technology platform that aggregates real-world data to improve cancer care quality. Patient resources such as Cancer.Net provide guidance for those living with cancer. The Conquer Cancer Foundation and TAPUR Study are mentioned as key components of ASCO's efforts to support research and improve treatments. The text also mentions ASCO's advocacy work, professional development opportunities, and the importance of involvement in state/regional affiliates to enhance the oncology community and advocate for key issues.

title: Kern County Cancer Foundation to host 'Teaming Up Against Cancer' event at Stramler Park
summary: The Kern County Cancer Foundation will host the "Teaming Up Against Cancer" event at Stramler Park on March 16, 2024, from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. This free, all-day event, previously known as Campout Against Cancer, will feature a survivor ceremony, vendors, food trucks, kids' activities, and a cornhole tournament. Teams of 10 will compete in various fun and low-skill activities to win the “Ultimate Cancer Fighters” Team Cup. Survivors can join for free, and all proceeds will support the Kern County Cancer Foundation in helping local cancer patients with medical bills and providing transportation for children needing treatment outside the area.

title: Kern County Cancer Foundation Brings Christmas Merriment to Children With Cancer and Their Families
summary: The Kern County Cancer Foundation organized a Christmas party for children with cancer and their families as part of their Pediatric Mobile Angel Unit Program. This initiative is crucial as Kern County lacks a pediatric care facility, forcing families to travel to hospitals outside the county for treatment. The foundation assists by providing transportation and financial support, such as gas cards, to ease the burden on these families. The event, aimed at bringing joy and a sense of community to those affected by cancer, featured crafts, a petting zoo, a hot meal, treats, and personalized gifts from Santa. It also offered an opportunity for families to connect, share experiences, and support each other. The foundation's efforts underscore the importance of community support for families dealing with pediatric cancer.

title: 2023 Kern County Cancer Run and Walk to be held at Riverwalk Park
summary: The 2023 Kern County Cancer Run and Walk will be hosted at Riverwalk Park in Bakersfield on September 16, marking a change in location from previous years at Yokuts Park. This event, celebrating its 10th anniversary, will offer free registration to the first 800 participants, with an option to donate or purchase event t-shirts. The 5K run or walk aims to raise funds for the Kern County Cancer Foundation, supporting local cancer patients with their medical bills and aiding children with cancer who need to travel for treatment. All proceeds from the event will directly benefit these causes. For additional information or to register, interested individuals can visit the event's page on RunSignUp.com.

title: SNAP! — Kern County Cancer Run/Walk and Festival
summary: The Kern County Cancer Run/Walk and Festival, which took place on September 16 at The Park at River Walk, was organized by the Kern County Cancer Foundation to collect money for local cancer patients. This event was intended to offer financial help and transportation to those receiving cancer treatment.

title: Annual Cranktones concert helps local families affected by cancer
summary: The Annual Cranktones concert, a cherished holiday tradition for the Guitar Masters family and the Bakersfield community, is set to take place on December 13 at Buck Owens’ Crystal Palace. This event, now in its ninth year, features first-call studio musicians and international touring legends, including Carl Verheyen of Supertramp. The concert supports the Kern County Cancer Foundation (KCCF), with all proceeds aiding local families affected by cancer in covering costs related to cancer care and treatment. Since its inception in 2015, the event has raised over $400,000 for KCCF, significantly impacting patients within the community. Special guests for this year include Sophia James and international violinist Megan Shung, enhancing the musical variety. The Cranktones concerts are crucial for providing financial assistance to Kern County cancer patients, underlining the community's commitment to supporting those in need.

title: 'Teaming Up Against Cancer' hosts event, locals participate and honor survivors
summary: The 'Teaming Up Against Cancer' event brought together the community in Stramler park where businesses set up tents and participants engaged in various activities to compete for the “Ultimate Cancer Fighters” team cup. The event celebrated cancer survivors, who were introduced on stage, and aimed to raise funds for the Kern County Cancer Foundation. The proceeds are dedicated to assisting local cancer patients with their medical bills. Michelle Avila, the Executive Director of the Foundation, highlighted the significant financial support provided to patients, emphasizing the focus on survivorship and treatment. Survivor Melody Saberon Ybarra shared her perspective on life after cancer, stressing the importance of living fully and not procrastinating. The event encouraged donations to support cancer patients and survivors.

title: Boston Herald: Investment in bio-tech has paid off and should be re-upped, Healey says
summary: Governor Maura Healey, speaking at MassBio's State of Possible Conference, advocated for the extension of the Life Sciences Initiative for another decade with a $1 billion investment. This initiative, set to expire on June 30, 2025, has previously fueled Massachusetts' biotechnology sector, attracting $6 billion in private investments and establishing the state as a global leader in life sciences. Healey highlighted the initiative's significant economic impact, deeming it a major success. The proposed "Mass Leads Act" aims to not only continue supporting large tech firms but also assist startups and entrepreneurs facing financial challenges. This move underscores the importance of investing in biotechnology for the state's economic and innovative growth.

title: MassBio testifies in support of H.B. 4459's Life Sciences Initiative reauthorization
summary: MassBio CEO & President Kendalle Burlin O’Connell and Head of Government Affairs Ed Coppinger testified in support of H.B. 4459, the third authorization of the Life Sciences Initiative, before the Joint Committee on Economic Development & Emerging Technologies on May 7, 2024. They highlighted the initiative's success since its inception in 2008 and its reauthorization in 2018, emphasizing its significant impact on Massachusetts' economy and the global patient community. The initiative has positioned Massachusetts as a leading biopharma hub, with a notable increase in the presence of top global pharma companies and a 114% growth in biopharma employment. They argued for the reauthorization to maintain competitiveness, support manufacturing expansions, and continue workforce development. The proposed $1 billion investment over the next ten years aims to sustain Massachusetts' leadership in the life sciences sector, emphasizing the importance of early-stage company support and health equity.

title: 2023 Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion Report
summary: The 2023 Diversity, Equity, & Inclusion Report by MassBio highlights progress and areas needing improvement in the Massachusetts life sciences sector. Gender diversity in leadership roles has seen a 9% increase, with female representation growing at the executive and board levels. Asian employees now constitute 23% of the workforce, significantly above the state average. However, communities of color remain underrepresented, with only 12% of board members being BIPOC. Despite challenging market conditions, 69% of respondents have implemented practices to recruit, retain, and advance diverse employees, with 47% collaborating with affinity organizations. Additionally, 71% believe that more resources could enhance their DEI efforts. MassBio's CEO, Kendalle Burlin O’Connell, emphasizes the importance of maintaining momentum in DEI initiatives, holding themselves accountable through measurable outcomes to reflect the diverse patient populations they serve.

title: BioSpace: Massachusetts Biopharma Job Growth Surpasses that of Other States: Report
summary: The Massachusetts Biotechnology Council, as reported by BioSpace on October 12, 2023, revealed in its 2023 Industry Snapshot that Massachusetts outpaced most other states in biotech and pharmaceutical job growth in 2022. Specifically, research and development (R&D) roles in the state saw an 8.5% increase, surpassing growth rates in California, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey. Biomanufacturing jobs in Massachusetts also grew by 6.3%, higher than in other states like New Jersey, Maryland, and North Carolina. Factors contributing to this growth include strong state government support for the biopharma sector, an effective nonprofit ecosystem providing talent and R&D capabilities, and significant National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding. Additionally, the state benefits from an abundance of lab space, with projections for further expansion, facilitating the sector's growth.

title: Get to know Laura Hamilton, MassBio's new Chief Business Officer
summary: Laura Hamilton has recently been appointed as the Chief Business Officer at MassBio, bringing a diverse background from her origins in Cork City, Ireland, to a significant career shift from financial services to the life sciences sector. A "Triple Husky" from Northeastern University, Hamilton's journey in the life sciences began at MassBio, where she previously served as Director of Business Development, significantly contributing to the organization's growth by recruiting over 700 new members. Her career has spanned various roles, including driving US market expansion for European companies in the life sciences industry. In her new role, Hamilton aims to enhance MassBio's internal business components like Membership, Events, and MassBioHub, while also focusing on external industry engagement and strategic growth areas. Outside of her professional life, she leads the Boston Irish Business Association, enjoys live music, and travels frequently. Hamilton's return to MassBio marks a full-circle moment, highlighting her commitment to advancing the life sciences industry in Massachusetts and beyond.

title: Kendalle Burlin O'Connell Becomes MassBio CEO
summary: Kendalle Burlin O’Connell has been appointed as the new CEO and President of the Massachusetts Biotechnology Council (MassBio®), effective January 4, 2023. With a 14-year tenure at MassBio, most recently serving as President & COO, Burlin O’Connell has played a pivotal role in the organization's growth and is recognized for her commitment to the Massachusetts biotech industry. Her leadership is expected to continue driving the industry's growth, focusing on creating an optimal environment for life sciences companies to innovate and bring new therapies and cures to the global market. Burlin O’Connell has been instrumental in launching initiatives aimed at fostering a diverse and equitable life sciences industry, supporting industry growth, and providing resources across the industry value chain. Her achievements include the expansion of MassBio’s core programs and services, the launch of the MassBioDrive entrepreneurial accelerator program, and the development of the MassBioHub conference and business center. Burlin O’Connell’s influence extends beyond MassBio, earning her recognition as a “Boston Power Player” and several other accolades for her contributions to the life sciences ecosystem and community leadership.

title: SCbio partners with industry powerhouse MassBio to support life sciences growth throughout region
summary: SCbio has partnered with MassBio to launch a member savings and rewards program called SCbio Edge, aimed at supporting the growth of the life sciences industry in South Carolina. This collaboration will allow SCbio members to benefit from MassBio's nearly 40 years of industry leadership through competitive discounts, preferred terms, and personalized customer service on essential purchases. The program promises significant savings for South Carolina companies annually by offering deals from a wide range of vendors, including diverse suppliers. SCbio Edge is designed to help South Carolina’s life science organizations reduce costs on daily operations, thereby enabling them to invest more in tools, technology, and talent to accelerate industry growth in the region. The partnership between these two patient-driven organizations, SCbio and MassBio, is focused on advancing breakthrough science by providing cost savings to life sciences companies of various sizes.

title: MassBio's 2022 Massachusetts Biopharma Funding Report Shows Strong Industry Investment Despite Market Reset ...
summary: The 2022 Massachusetts Biopharma Funding Report by MassBio highlighted a strong investment year for the state's biopharma sector despite economic uncertainties and a market reset. Massachusetts received the second highest total of venture capital (VC) funding for biopharma companies at $8.72 billion, only behind 2021's $13.66 billion. This represents about 25% of the national VC investments in biopharma, indicating the state's significant role in early-stage R&D. Despite a cautious investment approach due to economic conditions, leading to smaller average funding rounds and a closed IPO window, the sector saw a spread of investments across more companies and into new areas outside Cambridge. The state witnessed a few IPOs, with Massachusetts-based companies accounting for 33% of all biopharma IPOs in the U.S. in 2022. However, mergers and acquisitions were down, aligning with national trends. The report underscores the importance of continued investment in Massachusetts' biopharma sector for its growth and innovation potential.

title: Oral cancer advanced treatment options at The James at Ohio State
summary: The James at Ohio State provides advanced treatment options for oral cancer, aiming to enhance patient outcomes. Dr. Catherine Haring of the OSUCCC – James, a national leader in oral cancer care, is featured in the report. The facility is situated at the Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center – Arthur G. James Cancer Hospital and Richard J. Solove Research Institute in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Ohio State nursing graduate follows calling to care for new mothers
summary: Chiara Baker, a nursing graduate from Ohio State University, is dedicated to taking care of new mothers and babies, motivated by her family's own experiences with loss. Baker lost her twin and older sister early on, which influenced her choice of career. She graduated during the COVID-19 pandemic, and her faith was a significant factor in her decision to go into nursing. She specializes in postpartum patient care and labor and delivery, under the mentorship of Annetta Sipes. Baker worked part-time at the Wexner Medical Center and became a full-time nurse there after her graduation. She is furthering her education at Ohio State with the goal of becoming a certified nurse midwife and is interested in doing medical missionary work. Her parents are proud of her career choice, recognizing her passion for taking care of mothers and babies. Baker's story is one of commitment to nursing and her desire to impact the lives of new mothers and their children positively.

title: PharmaEssentia shares rare blood cancer stories in video series
summary: PharmaEssentia has launched a video series titled PV&ME in collaboration with MPN Advocacy & Education International to share stories of individuals diagnosed with polycythemia vera (PV), a rare blood cancer. This initiative follows the U.S. FDA's approval of PharmaEssentia's PV medication, Besremi, almost two years ago and aims to increase awareness and promote patient self-advocacy. The series includes four- to five-minute videos in which patients share their experiences before, during, and after being diagnosed with PV. For example, one patient, Buzz, discusses his ten-year battle with undiagnosed symptoms and the importance of self-advocacy in finding the right doctor. Another patient, Deb, describes her unexpected diagnosis and how her experience with cancer inspired her to begin writing and performing songs. PharmaEssentia's efforts, including this new campaign, are designed to support patients and have contributed to the company's growth, with global net product sales reaching $92.9 million in 2022, the first year following Besremi's approval in the U.S.

title: Planning safety into your summertime activities | UKNow
summary: The University of Kentucky Public Relations and Strategic Communications Office emphasizes the importance of safety during the summer, often called "trauma season" because of the increase in injuries. Dr. Andrew Bernard highlights the importance of safety from the sun, wearing helmets, and staying hydrated to avoid serious or life-changing injuries. Advice includes using sunscreen with a minimum SPF of 15, drinking plenty of water, not leaving children in cars, making sure children wear life jackets near water, not drinking alcohol while boating, and paying attention while driving. Also, wearing seatbelts, using helmets for activities on wheels, being careful with fireworks, and being safe as a pedestrian are important. UK HealthCare, with over 10,000 health care professionals, aims to offer advanced care and contribute to medical progress through research and education, working towards a healthier Kentucky.

title: Huguelet Drive ADA lot impact | UKNow
summary: The Huguelet Drive ADA Lot at the University of Kentucky will be closed on Friday, May 24, 2024, due to the installation of a crane for lifting an air handler unit and a return fan unit in the area. The installation, starting at 8 a.m., is expected to last about eight hours. ADA permit holders are advised to find alternative ADA-accessible parking spaces or use any space in the Hilltop Avenue Garage (PS #2) for the day.

title: UK Staff Senate announces Employee Appreciation Day May 23
summary: The University of Kentucky Staff Senate has announced the annual Employee Appreciation Day, scheduled for May 23, 2024, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. The event will take place outside The 90 at 440 Hilltop Avenue and in the William T. Young Library parking lot, featuring a street fair atmosphere with food, bingo, live music by Zack Attack, caricature artists, yard games, and various activities. The celebration will proceed regardless of the weather, with indoor arrangements for food and vendor tables in case of severe conditions. A new addition this year is the Kentucky Blood Center mobile, which will be on-site to collect blood donations, aiming for a goal of 25 pints. Walk-in donors are welcome, though scheduling is recommended. For those unable to attend in person or seeking extended festivities, virtual activities are available from May 20-22. T-Shirt distribution for campus employees will occur on May 21 at Kroger Field and on May 29 for UK HealthCare employees at Karpf Auditorium. For more information on the event, including parking and transportation, visit the UK Staff Senate website.

title: New well-being tab launches on Canvas, improves access to student support
summary: A new well-being tab has been launched on Canvas at the University of Kentucky to enhance student access to wellness resources and services. This initiative, a collaboration between the Student Government Association (SGA) and the Office for Student Success, aims to support students' mental, physical, financial well-being, and more. The well-being tab, positioned on the left side of the browser, includes a "Get HELP" section for emergency resources, advice, and links to mental health support platforms like Talkspace and TRACS. Talkspace offers confidential text and video chat therapy, while TRACS provides referrals for supportive services and direct clinical support. Additionally, the tab features information on recreation centers, financial literacy programs, supportive communities, and networking opportunities. This effort underscores the University of Kentucky's commitment to holistic student success and well-being.

title: Cancer Support UK receives £5000 from The Cadbury Foundation
summary: Cancer Support UK has been awarded £5,000 by The Cadbury Foundation as part of its 'Your Charity Your Choice' initiative. The donation was made possible through nominations by Mondelēz International UK employees, with the Uxbridge site nominating Cancer Support UK after witnessing the support provided to their colleague, Rebecca Bentinck. The charity offers practical and emotional support to individuals over 18 recovering from cancer, including free Cancer Coach sessions and 'Cancer kits' for patients undergoing treatment. This grant will enable Cancer Support UK to continue its work in assisting people during and after their cancer treatment, ensuring that no one faces cancer alone. The Cadbury Foundation, established in 1935, supports community programs and charity partners, with £65,000 donated across the UK as part of its initiative this year.

title: EXECUTIVE WOMEN’S DAY BROUGHT TO YOU BY NORTHSIDE HOSPITAL RETURNS TO MITSUBISHI ELECTRIC ...
summary: The Mitsubishi Electric Classic presented by Vensure will feature its annual Executive Women’s Day sponsored by Northside Hospital on April 22, 2024. This event, taking place in Duluth, GA, aims to celebrate and empower metro Atlanta's women by focusing on career development, networking, and business innovation. The theme for this year is about creating a sustainable legacy through intentional decision-making, resilience, and innovative thinking. Keynote speaker Sara Irvani, CEO of Okabashi, will discuss the company's commitment to sustainability and stewardship. The day also includes a Power Panel with influential female leaders and a GIRLSGOTDRIVE™ 9-Hole Scramble for select attendees, offering hands-on golf instruction. The event is part of the PGA TOUR Champions event week and will be held at TPC Sugarloaf.

title: Cancer Prevention Month: Iowa experts share tips to lower your risk
summary: During Cancer Prevention Month, Iowa experts, including Kelly Sittig from the Iowa Cancer Consortium and Dr. Mary Charlton, Director of the Iowa Cancer Registry, shared essential tips on lowering cancer risk. Their insights were part of an effort to educate and inform the public on effective cancer prevention strategies.

title: Alcohol listed as important factor in Iowa's rising cancer rates
summary: Alcohol is identified as a significant factor in the increasing rates of cancer in Iowa, according to the 2024 Iowa Cancer Report by the Iowa Cancer Registry. The report highlights that Iowa has the second-highest and fastest-growing rate of new cancer cases in the country, with over 7,000 Central Iowans expected to be diagnosed this year. It specifically focuses on alcohol due to its classification as a carcinogen and its association with various types of cancer, including larynx, mouth, esophagus, throat, breast, liver, colon, and rectum cancers. Dr. Mary Charlton, Director of the Iowa Cancer Registry, emphasizes the dual role of alcohol in both causing DNA damage and blocking the absorption of nutrients necessary for DNA repair. The report also notes Iowa's high ranking for binge drinking and suggests that policy measures like increasing state tax on alcohol could help reduce cancer rates.

title: Medical Groups Faced High Expenses, Staffing Challenges in 2023
summary: In 2023, medical groups encountered significant financial and operational difficulties, as the American Medical Group Association (AMGA) survey revealed. Even though revenue increased by 9.1% since the pandemic, expenses rose by 26.5%, with groups affiliated with systems seeing a median loss per physician of over $249,000. This financial pressure was intensified by persistent staffing shortages, forcing groups to spend on recruitment and retention strategies. To tackle these issues, medical groups have been modifying processes, care models, and making use of telehealth services, whose use has remained steady since the pandemic's height. The survey also pointed out the necessity for better revenue cycle management tools to reduce controllable claims denials, which make up about 17% of total denials. Operational challenges, such as assessing group mix and composition, were noted as areas for potential enhancement to keep providing quality, cost-effective care.

title: MemorialCare Medical Group and Greater Newport Physicians Nationally Recognized for Blood Pressure and ...
summary: MemorialCare Medical Group and Greater Newport Physicians have received the American Heart Association's Get With The Guidelines® - Target: Type 2 Diabetes SM Gold Certificate of Recognition and the Get With The Guidelines® - Target BP™ Gold Plus Quality Achievement Award. These awards recognize their efforts in managing diabetes patients' blood sugar and ensuring accurate blood pressure measurements. They show commitment to cardiovascular health and controlling high blood pressure in over 70% of their adult patients. MemorialCare's ACTIVE Diabetes Program is key in helping patients manage diabetes with education and lifestyle changes. These achievements highlight their dedication to quality care and preventing hospitalizations by managing conditions in primary care.

title: Photos: Fashion show raises more than $175K for Alaska nonprofit
summary: The Trend Alaska fashion show in Anchorage on January 28, 2023, successfully raised over $175,000 for Let Every Woman Know-Alaska, a nonprofit dedicated to providing resources for the prevention of gynecologic cancers. The event showcased the creative works of 16 designers, ranging in age from 15 to 70 and representing various parts of Alaska, from Kotzebue to Ketchikan. The fashion show featured a diverse array of wearable art, including fur-lined garments, parkas, dresses, and accessories like suitcases and an umbrella. A notable moment was when ovarian cancer survivor and retired teacher Mary Rita Ely modeled a fur coat, previously owned by LEWK supporter Ellie Burnett who passed away from ovarian cancer in 2022, which was auctioned for $6,500. The show highlighted the importance of community support in the fight against gynecologic cancers.

title: National Kidney Foundation
summary: The National Kidney Foundation's Northern Ohio Chapter, established in 1964 with a 2022 revenue of $620,000, seeks volunteers for various events and programs across its 32-county region to support its mission. As the largest organization focused on kidney disease awareness, prevention, and treatment in the U.S., it offers numerous volunteer opportunities, including Kidney Walks, Golf Classics, and educational programs. Additionally, it encourages financial donations and living kidney donations to support its life-saving programs. The Foundation also organizes fundraising events like Komedy for Kidneys and the NKF Golf Classic to raise awareness and funds for chronic kidney disease. Leadership is provided by Executive Director Anna Tzinis and a board of advisors.

title: Kidney disease is focus of Patient Symposium, with sessions in person and virtual
summary: The ninth Annual Patient Symposium, focusing on kidney health, will be held both in person and virtually. This free event aims to educate kidney patients, their families, and caregivers about advances in kidney health, including organ and cell transplants from one species to another. Highlighting a significant medical breakthrough, it mentions the first living person receiving a genetically edited kidney from a pig, offering hope to those on dialysis or awaiting transplants. The symposium, organized by the National Kidney Foundation Serving Northern Ohio, will feature virtual sessions from April 23 to 25 and an in-person program on April 28 at the Holiday Inn South in Independence. It addresses the high prevalence of chronic kidney disease in the U.S., with 37 million adults affected, and emphasizes the importance of maintaining kidney health through various measures.

title: Learn how to Weed it G'out at this year's NKF Cleveland Kidney Walk
summary: Brad Marder, M.D., a nephrologist and medical director at Horizon Therapeutics, and Anna Tzinis, M.S., executive director at the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) of Ohio, discussed the link between chronic kidney disease and gout at the 2023 Cleveland Kidney Walk on June 11. They highlighted Horizon's "Weed it G'out" pop-up garden at the event, aiming to educate the public on the connection between the diseases and promote awareness. The initiative encourages community involvement through educational resources available at GoutRevealed.com and KidneyWalk.org/Cleveland, as part of Horizon Therapeutics and NKF Northern Ohio's efforts to engage and inform the broader community about these health issues.

title: Anna Tzinis | 40 Under 40 2023
summary: Anna Tzinis, aged 37, has been recognized in Crain's Cleveland Business's "40 Under 40" for 2023. Originally from Greece and raised in New Jersey, Tzinis moved to Cleveland in 2015 after her husband secured a fellowship, and they decided to make Ohio their home. Professionally, she has significantly impacted the National Kidney Foundation (NKF), where she began as the Development Director for the Northern Ohio office. By the age of 31, Tzinis became the youngest Executive Director in NKF history, leading the regional chapter. Under her leadership, the office's operational budget increased by 190% from 2016 to 2022, expanded its reach to Toledo and Akron, and played a key role in advocacy, leading to a 2022 Ohio law that prevents insurance discrimination against living donors. Recently promoted to oversee the entire state, Tzinis manages three territories, a staff of seven, and seven boards, focusing on raising awareness about chronic kidney disease, organ donation, and transplantation. She is also dedicated to promoting healthy choices, particularly among underserved populations, addressing the higher rates of diabetes and high blood pressure among Black Americans, which are leading causes of chronic kidney disease.

title: Cleveland-area nonprofits seeking donations
summary: The 2023 Crain’s Cleveland Business Giving Guide, presented by the Cleveland Foundation, is designed as a comprehensive resource for community members interested in philanthropy. This guide, produced by Crain’s Content Studio, features information submitted by nonprofits to introduce and familiarize readers with their missions and needs. All featured nonprofits have purchased advertising space in the guide. The Giving Guide covers a wide range of causes including arts and culture, children and families, community development, education, health, and human services, among others. It aims to connect potential donors with various nonprofit organizations in the Cleveland area, highlighting the diverse opportunities for giving back to the community.

title: Volunteer co-chairing CARTI Tux 'n Trees | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
summary: Courtney Head volunteers at the CARTI Cancer Center in Little Rock, specifically in the Gift Shop on Thursdays. The shop is marked by green, vertical signs with the word "Hope" prominently displayed. This volunteer effort is part of Head's role as a co-chair for the CARTI Tux ’n Trees event, which aims to spark hope for cancer patients. This involvement underscores the broader community effort to support individuals battling cancer, highlighting the significance of volunteer work in providing hope and assistance to those in need.

title: Comfort and Joy for CARTI - Little Rock Soirée
summary: Adam and Courtney Head, deeply connected to CARTI's mission of providing accessible cancer care, chaired this year's Tux ‘n’ Trees gala, part of the Festival of Trees events, to support CARTI's Patient Assistance Program. The program aims to remove barriers to treatment by offering support services such as transportation, lodging assistance, and comprehensive counseling. CARTI, serving as a comprehensive cancer care provider in Arkansas, has expanded its services statewide, ensuring that no one goes without necessary treatment. The organization has introduced the state's only cancer-focused surgery center and The Bridge, an on-site support services center, to further support patients and families. The Festival of Trees, including the Sugar Plum Ball, Festival of Fashion, and Tux ‘n’ Trees gala, raises funds for CARTI's mission, with the Heads highlighting the importance of community support in igniting hope for cancer patients during the holiday season and beyond.

title: 2023 Festival of Trees Raises Record $830k
summary: The 47th Annual Festival of Trees, a beloved holiday tradition in central Arkansas, successfully raised a record $830,000 for CARTI's Patient Assistance Program. This program offers vital support services to cancer patients, helping to remove obstacles to treatment. Since its beginning, the festival has donated over $10 million to this cause. The event, led by Adam Head, CARTI's president and CEO, showcased three main attractions: the Sugar Plum Ball, the Festival of Fashion, and the Tux ‘n Trees gala. All money raised from these events goes to the Patient Assistance Program, demonstrating the community's strong support and dedication to helping Arkansas cancer patients and their families, especially during the holiday season.

title: Jason Browning Hired as General Counsel at CARTI (Movers & Shakers)
summary: Jason Browning has been appointed as the general counsel at CARTI in Little Rock, bringing nearly three decades of legal experience in the medical field from his previous role at Wright Lindsey Jennings. Additionally, Rick Long joins Attorney’s Title Group PLLC as the director of northwest Arkansas operations, focusing on business development and closings in the region. Dr. Stephen Broughton has been hired as a cardiologist at CHI St. Vincent in Little Rock after completing his interventional cardiology fellowship at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. Harold Dean is recognized as the Hematology-Oncology Social Worker of the Year by the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, serving at the Myeloma Center at UAMS in Little Rock. Katie Halsell joins Washington Regional's stroke program in Fayetteville with seven years of nursing experience. Dr. Robert H. Hopkins Jr. is named medical director of the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases, and several other professionals have taken on new roles in healthcare, legal, and nonprofit sectors in Arkansas.

title: Delta Dental of Arkansas Foundation awards more than $1 million in grants
summary: The Delta Dental of Arkansas Foundation has awarded over $1 million in grants to enhance oral health across Arkansas. Nearly $502,000 in Community Grants were given to 22 nonprofits and schools, $60,000 in Oral Health Education Grants to two organizations, and about $536,000 in Strategic Initiative Grants for three statewide projects. These grants aim to support oral health initiatives for tens of thousands of Arkansans, focusing on low-income, uninsured, or underinsured individuals. This round of grant-making is notable for the record number of Community Grant applications received and the awarding of the foundation's first-ever Strategic Initiative Grant to increase school-based oral health centers. The grants are part of the foundation's commitment to improving oral health through community partnerships and are awarded based on the ability to meet strategic goals of empowerment, equitable access, and systemic change.

title: Ochsner+to+construct+new+children%E2%80%99s+hospital+in+New+Orleans+after+donation+from+Gayle+Benson
summary: Ochsner Health is set to construct a new 343,000-square-foot children's hospital in New Orleans, named The Gayle and Tom Benson Ochsner Children’s Hospital, following a significant donation from Gayle Benson. The five-story facility, aimed at expanding Ochsner's pediatric care, will be located adjacent to its main campus on Jefferson Highway. This development comes as LCMC Health recently invested $300 million in upgrading its Children’s Hospital uptown. The new hospital is part of Ochsner's commitment to enhance its pediatric program and will feature a children’s-only emergency department, major enhancements to critical care and operating rooms, and a Level IV Surgical Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). Designed with a child-friendly atmosphere, the hospital aims to address the current and projected needs of children and families in the region, offering specialized care for the most complex conditions. Ochsner Children’s Hospital, which currently serves over 100,000 children annually, expects to break ground in mid-2024 and open by late 2027.

title: Positron Corporation Enters into Agreement with Ochsner Clinic Foundation for Clinical Study of its New “Affinity PET ...
summary: Positron Corporation has partnered with Ochsner Clinic Foundation and Dr. Robert Bober for a clinical study of its new PET-CT imaging device, the Affinity PET-CT 4D. The study has received approval from an independent Institutional Review Board (IRB), allowing Positron to pursue an Investigational Device Exemption (IDE) for collecting safety and efficacy data. This clinical study is a step towards obtaining FDA Pre-Market Approval, with patient scans set to begin once the IDE is granted. Positron plans to submit a 510k to the FDA during the trial and aims to complete the study and receive FDA Certification within 60 days. This study is crucial for the commercialization of the Affinity PET-CT 4D, demonstrating its capabilities in cardiology and oncology imaging.

title: Positron Corporation Announces Start of Clinical Study of Affinity PET-CT Device
summary: Positron Corporation, a leading medical device company in molecular imaging, announced the commencement of a clinical study for its Affinity PET-CT imaging device on September 8, 2023. The study, in collaboration with Ochsner Clinic Foundation in New Orleans and led by Dr. Robert Bober, aims to collect critical data on the device's performance and efficacy. This study marks a significant step towards the device's market launch, requiring FDA's Investigational Device Exemption for initial human testing. Positron plans to submit for FDA 510k clearance alongside the study, aiming to validate and commercialize the Affinity PET-CT. This device promises advancements in diagnostic analysis through new software applications and radiopharmaceuticals, positioning Positron to meet growing demands in nuclear imaging.
