title: Official Rules: Pelicans 2024 Baby Crawl Race presented by Ochsner Hospital for Children
summary: The Pelicans 2024 Baby Crawl Race, sponsored by Ochsner Hospital for Children, is open to legal residents of the United States living in Louisiana or within 150 miles of New Orleans, who are parents or legal guardians of infants aged 9-11 months. The contest runs from February 28, 2024, to March 15, 2024. Participants must visit the official website to submit an entry form and a photo of their infant for a chance to be one of the twenty contestants selected based on enthusiasm for the Pelicans, cuteness, and smile. Each contestant gets game tickets, a racing onesie, and Crib Club membership, with the chance for their infant to participate in a crawl race at a Pelicans game. The grand prize includes various toddler toys and a trophy. Entry is free, but contestants must cover their transportation and expenses for attending the game.

title: American Academy of Ophthalmology and FundamentalVR Collaborate on Virtual Reality Initiative to Improve ...
summary: The American Academy of Ophthalmology and FundamentalVR have partnered to launch a Virtual Reality (VR) initiative aimed at enhancing ophthalmic training globally. This collaboration is supported by a $5 million donation from the Knights Templar Eye Foundation for the Pediatric Ophthalmology VR Simulation Program. The initiative seeks to revolutionize pediatric eye care education through VR technology, offering free, specialized training programs on pediatric eye diseases and conditions to ophthalmologists and trainees worldwide. The first phase focuses on creating a simulator for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), allowing users to practice examining patients and performing treatments in a virtual environment. This effort addresses the global need for more practical training opportunities in pediatric ophthalmology, particularly in countries with restrictions on pediatric surgery by residents. Future modules will cover strabismus management among other topics, aiming to improve patient outcomes and elevate the quality of eye care globally.

title: American Academy of Ophthalmology, Nov. 3-5
summary: The American Academy of Ophthalmology's annual meeting was held from November 3-5 in San Francisco, attracting worldwide participants from the eye health field. Highlights included the success of using low-dose atropine eye drops to slow down myopia in children of different backgrounds over three years. A retrospective study also showed that most diabetic patients did not experience worsening retinopathy after beginning treatment with semaglutide. Furthermore, a study stressed the importance of routine retinopathy screenings for children with sickle cell disease due to a high rate of retinopathy in patients younger than 25. These findings aid in the advancement of eye health care, providing new insights into treating myopia, managing diabetic retinopathy, and the critical role of screenings in sickle cell disease to avoid severe eye complications.

title: AAO 2023: Do women in the US face a greater burden from blindness and vision loss?
summary: At the 2023 American Academy of Ophthalmology meeting, Dr. Mary Elizabeth Hartnett presented her research on gender disparities in vision loss and blindness in the United States. Using the IRIS registry database, her study aimed to identify any significant differences in blindness or vision loss between genders. Inspired by worldwide data showing women disproportionately suffer from vision loss, even when age is considered, the research used 2018 data, pre-pandemic, to avoid the impact of decreased eye examinations during the pandemic. It covered various eye conditions and used the WHO's vision loss classification. The results showed women had a higher percentage of vision loss than men, with a 15% increased risk. This trend persisted across all vision loss categories and nearly all eye conditions, except for retinal detachment, highlighting substantial gender disparities in vision loss in the U.S. and echoing the global issue of women bearing a heavier burden of eye diseases.

title: Iantrek reports two upcoming American Academy of Ophthalmology presentations of its breakthrough glaucoma ...
summary: Iantrek, Inc. will present two scientific abstracts at the American Academy of Ophthalmology (AAO) meeting in San Francisco, CA, from November 3-6, 2023. These presentations will showcase the 12-month clinical results of Iantrek's CycloPen supraciliary interventional system, which demonstrated a significant reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP) and glaucoma medication use in patients undergoing cataract surgery. Additionally, Iantrek will report on a novel dual-outflow micro-interventional approach combining trabecular and supraciliary interventions for Open Angle Glaucoma, highlighting its surgical feasibility and safety. These advancements affirm Iantrek's commitment to developing micro-interventional glaucoma surgeries (MIGS) technologies for enhancing supraciliary and trabecular outflow.

title: Nanoscope Therapeutics Announces Presentations at the American Academy of Ophthalmology Annual Meeting 2023
summary: Nanoscope Therapeutics announced its participation in the American Academy of Ophthalmology (AAO) 2023 Annual Meeting in San Francisco, California, with presentations on its gene therapies for inherited retinal diseases and age-related macular degenerations (AMD). Dr. Samuel Barone will present the Multi-Characteristic Opsin platform at the Eyecelerator @ AAO 2023, highlighting its potential to restore vision in patients with advanced retinal degenerative diseases. Additionally, Dr. Stephen H. Tsang will discuss the Phase 2 STARLIGHT trial's end-of-study data for MCO-010 therapy in Stargardt disease patients at the AAO 2023 Annual Meeting. Nanoscope Therapeutics focuses on developing gene-agnostic, sight-restoring optogenetic therapies for patients blinded by inherited retinal diseases, with no existing cures. MCO-010, their lead asset, has shown promising results in clinical trials and received FDA fast track and orphan drug designations for retinitis pigmentosa and Stargardt disease.

title: Semaglutide in T2D: Study Shows No Worsening of Diabetic Retinopathy
summary: A study presented at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Ophthalmology in San Francisco found that most patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) do not experience worsening diabetic retinopathy (DR) after starting semaglutide. The retrospective case series, led by Dr. Zeeshan Haq of Retina Consultants of Minnesota, analyzed 96,432 eyes from patients who initiated semaglutide between January 2013 and December 2021. Results showed that a small percentage of eyes with no or background DR and mild or moderate nonproliferative DR (NPDR) had worsening conditions over time. However, a significant improvement in DR status was observed in eyes with severe NPDR or proliferative DR (PDR) after semaglutide initiation. The study suggests further investigation is needed on semaglutide's impact on high-risk patients and emphasizes the importance of consulting healthcare providers before starting semaglutide for diabetic patients.

title: Negotiations end with no agreement to sell Singing River Health System. What's next?
summary: Months of negotiations between the Jackson County Supervisors and Franciscan Missionaries of Our Lady Health System to sell Singing River Health System ended without an agreement. Despite extensive discussions, both parties could not reach a consensus on selling the health system's hospitals and clinics in Pascagoula, Ocean Springs, Gulfport, and other South Mississippi facilities. Franciscan Missionaries was selected as the preferred buyer in March after a request for proposals, with expectations to close the sale this fall. The decision to sell was made in September 2022, with Raymond James assisting in finding prospective buyers. Ken Taylor, board of supervisors president, expressed intentions to restart the sale process, aiming to ensure high-quality patient care. Laurin St. Pe, Interim CEO of Singing River Health System, and Richard Vath, MD, president and CEO of FMOLHS, both highlighted their commitment to quality care and expressed regret over not reaching an agreement.

title: Singing River Health System Notifies 252k Patients of Recent Data Breach
summary: Singing River Health System, located in Pascagoula, Mississippi, has informed roughly 252,000 patients of a data breach following a ransomware attack. The breach, reported to the Maine Attorney General on January 12, 2024, happened between August 16 and 18, 2023. An unauthorized individual accessed sensitive data, including names, birthdates, addresses, Social Security numbers, and medical information. After an investigation with data security experts, Singing River is notifying affected patients, offering guidance on preventing fraud or identity theft, and explaining their legal rights. Founded in 1931, Singing River Health System operates three hospitals and various medical facilities in Mississippi, employs over 2,200 staff, and has an annual revenue of about $367 million.

title: Mississippi hospital system hit by cyberattack
summary: Singing River Health System in Mississippi, operating three hospitals along the Gulf Coast, has been severely impacted by a cyberattack, forcing the hospital system to take its computer systems offline. This incident, confirmed by the interim CEO Laurin St. Pe, has led to significant disruptions, including delays in patient care and elective procedures. The attack has necessitated a return to paper documentation and has affected services such as radiology exams and laboratory test processing. The MySingingRiver patient app is also offline. The health system is striving to restore operations and continue patient care amidst these challenges. This cyberattack is part of a larger trend, with over 220 attacks on hospitals and health systems reported in the first half of 2023 alone, affecting 40 million Americans. The Joint Commission has issued guidelines for hospitals to mitigate the impact of such attacks on patient care.

title: The bids are in for Singing River Health System sale. When will the buyer be announced?
summary: The Singing River Health System, which includes three hospitals in Pascagoula, Ocean Springs, and Gulfport, along with 30 clinics, is up for sale. Owned by Jackson County and employing about 4,000 people, the health system attracted multiple bids by the Friday deadline, as overseen by the Jackson-based financial firm Raymond James. The Jackson County Board of Supervisors, informed of the offers in an executive session, aims to select the best bid by April 14, keeping the details confidential until then. The sale follows a unanimous decision by the supervisors six months ago to seek proposals for the sale, aiming for a partnership that would invest in and grow the health system. Singing River has a partnership with Ochsner Health, which is expected to have submitted a bid. The financial services firm suggested the hospital could sell for between $158 million to $238 million.

title: Look Up Your Hospital: Is It Being Penalized by Medicare?
summary: Under the Affordable Care Act, the U.S. government lowers payments to hospitals with high readmission rates and those with many infections and patient injuries. Medicare can reduce payments by up to 3 percent per patient for readmissions, with the average reduction being less. Hospitals lose 1 percent of Medicare payments for patient safety penalties during the federal fiscal year, from October to September. Maryland hospitals don't face these penalties because of a different agreement with Medicare. CMS has paused penalties for Hospital-Acquired Conditions for 2023 due to the health crisis but will apply them again in 2024. There are tools to search penalties by hospital name or location, see all hospitals in a state, and organize penalties by fiscal year.

title: Jackson County selects Catholic nonprofit as Singing River hospital's new owner
summary: Jackson County's Board of Supervisors has selected the Franciscan Missionaries of Our Lady Health System, a Louisiana-based Catholic nonprofit, to take over Singing River Health System, a hospital network on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi. This choice came after a thorough process of proposals and bids. Singing River Health System, aiming for stability and growth, found a suitable match in the Franciscan Missionaries, which manages St. Dominic Memorial Hospital in Jackson and nine other facilities in Louisiana. Singing River CEO Tiffany Murdock sees this as a crucial step in ensuring the hospital can effectively serve its staff, patients, and the wider community. Despite achieving financial stability and increased revenue in 2021, the health system has faced hurdles, including the recent halt of labor and delivery services at its Gulfport hospital due to a lack of doctors. The takeover is expected to boost local healthcare investment and enhance community health, in line with both organizations' dedication to ensuring healthcare access for everyone.

title: Jackson County's Singing River Health System to be sold to Louisiana-based Francisan Missionaries of Our Lady ...
summary: Jackson County's Singing River Health System is set to be sold to the Franciscan Missionaries of Our Lady Health System, a Louisiana-based healthcare organization. This decision was announced by the Jackson County Board of Supervisors, with the sale expected to be finalized by Fall 2023. Despite a partnership with Oschner Health, Franciscan Missionaries was chosen for their shared community values and commitment to providing equal healthcare access. The sale includes three hospitals and 30 primary care clinics among other healthcare facilities. Financial details of the sale were not disclosed. The Franciscan Missionaries of Our Lady Health System, founded in 1911, is committed to maintaining high-quality, accessible care for Singing River Health System patients and has a significant presence in Mississippi. This move is anticipated to enhance healthcare services for the employees, patients, and community members served by Singing River Health System.

title: AstraZeneca backs new hyperkalemia public awareness video series from the National Kidney Foundation
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION SERVING NEW ENGLAND
summary: AstraZeneca is supporting a new public awareness video series about hyperkalemia, developed by the National Kidney Foundation (NKF). The series consists of two animated educational videos aimed at increasing understanding of hyperkalemia, a condition characterized by high potassium levels in the blood, often linked to kidney disease. Hyperkalemia can lead to serious heart issues and can be fatal in severe cases. Despite its significance, public awareness about the condition is low. The video series, available in English and Spanish, explains the disorder, its connection to kidney disease, and management and treatment options post-diagnosis, without directly mentioning AstraZeneca's hyperkalemia drug, Lokelma. The initiative highlights the importance of early diagnosis through blood tests and collaborative patient-doctor treatment planning. AstraZeneca acquired Lokelma through its purchase of ZS Pharma and faced delays in bringing the drug to market due to manufacturing issues. Lokelma competes in the hyperkalemia drug market, which has seen modest sales.

title: Kidney Disease Advocates Raise Alarm Over FDA Proposal for Salt Substitutes
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION SERVING NEW ENGLAND
summary: Kidney disease advocacy groups are expressing concerns over a proposed FDA rule allowing food manufacturers to substitute table salt with potassium-based alternatives. This rule aims to reduce sodium intake among Americans, 90% of whom consume too much salt, contributing to chronic diseases. However, for the 37 million Americans with chronic kidney disease, especially those disproportionately affecting people of color, this could be harmful or fatal. These patients often struggle to excrete potassium, leading to dangerous levels in their blood. While the FDA's intention is to combat sodium-related health issues, advocacy organizations like the American Association of Kidney Patients, the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, and the National Kidney Foundation argue that the needs of those with kidney disease must also be considered. They acknowledge the potential benefits of reducing sodium but emphasize the risks of increased potassium for kidney disease patients.

title: These 4 new Louisiana laws aim to help cancer patients
summary: Governor John Bel Edwards of Louisiana signed four new laws aimed at assisting cancer patients in the state, addressing Louisiana's high cancer mortality rate. These laws were advocated for by the Louisiana Oncology Society and Survivor’s Cancer Action during the 2023 legislative session. The laws include Act 324, which expands health insurance coverage for biomarker testing to state employees, aiding in the determination of cancer treatment. Act 110, named the “Cancer Patient’s Right to Prompt Coverage Act,” reduces the time insurance companies can take to approve access to cancer treatments. Act 299 requires insurance companies to cover standard fertility preservation services for cancer patients at risk of infertility due to treatment, effective January 1, 2024. Lastly, Act 42 allows Louisiana driver’s license holders to indicate their wish to be bone marrow donors, effective July 1, 2024. These measures aim to improve access to care and the quality of life for cancer patients in Louisiana.

title: Civitas Networks for Health to Host 2024 Annual Conference in Detroit This October
summary: Civitas Networks for Health is set to host its 2024 Annual Conference from October 15-17 in Detroit, Michigan, under the theme 'Bridging Data and Doing'. The conference aims to unite over 170 member organizations along with health transformation and data professionals nationwide to enhance data sharing and drive meaningful health improvements. Lisa Bari, CEO, emphasizes the conference's focus on practical insights for community health advancement and increased health data interoperability. The event, expecting 600-800 attendees, will feature keynote speakers, panel discussions, and workshops focused on health equity, public health, and addressing social determinants of health through data-informed approaches. Registration is open for those interested in engaging with industry leaders and exploring the latest trends in health IT and interoperability. Civitas Networks for Health is a nonprofit collaborative working towards improving health through information exchange and multi-stakeholder approaches.

title: African American Male Wellness Agency mental health
summary: The African American Male Wellness Agency (AAMWA) has started "Real Men, Real Talk" to tackle mental health problems among Black men, acknowledging the connection between physical and mental well-being. With data indicating suicide as the third most common cause of death for Black men aged 15-24, the AAMWA seeks to alter the story by offering a secure environment for Black men to discuss their experiences and support one another. The program features physical health exams, with 85% of the examined men found to have high blood pressure, often linked to stress, depression, and anxiety. Additionally, the agency has initiated the "Mask Off" campaign, urging men to reveal their genuine selves and promote community resilience and openness. The forthcoming "Real Men, Real Talk" event is planned for February 15 in Columbus, with professional therapists present for additional help. The AAMWA operates in 18 cities nationwide, including Columbus, Cleveland, Cincinnati, and Toledo.

title: African American Male Wellness Agency holds 2024 VIP Breakfast
summary: The African American Male Wellness Agency held its annual VIP Breakfast in Columbus, Ohio, where it received a $3,000 donation. Agency president Kenny Hampton and co-founder John Gregory discussed the importance of health in the Black community, especially among Black men, and highlighted the agency's year-round programs and resources. The event, sponsored by NBC4, also featured central Ohio leaders, including Whitehall Mayor Michael Bivens who shared his fitness journey after battling obesity. Additionally, the upcoming Wellness Walk in August was discussed.

title: Johnson & Johnson expands commitment to advance health equity in the United States
summary: Johnson & Johnson has announced an expansion of its commitment to advance health equity in the United States by collaborating with over 100 community-led health organizations that support historically marginalized communities. This initiative builds on the company's multiyear, multimillion-dollar efforts to improve health equity, addressing disparities in healthcare access, quality, and mortality rates among people of color compared to their White counterparts. The supported organizations work in various capacities, such as improving access to care, diabetes prevention, and enhancing care models to improve health outcomes for communities of color. Additionally, J&J held a Health Equity Innovation Challenge, selecting five local health innovators to receive seed funding and mentorship. The company also continues its "My Health Can't Wait" initiative, focusing on community wellness and addressing specific health inequities. This comprehensive approach aligns with J&J's commitment to closing the healthcare access gap and improving outcomes for marginalized communities in the U.S.

title: Free health wellness event in Houston hopes to reduce health disparities among African American men
summary: A free health wellness event aimed at reducing health disparities among African American men is set to take place at the University of Houston on Saturday, April 27th, 2024. Organized by the African American Male Wellness Agency (AAMWA), the event, named Black Men's Wellness Day, is designed to encourage African American men to get screened for health issues such as high blood pressure, heart disease, and prostate cancer, which are prevalent in their community but often go unchecked. This initiative, a re-imagination of “The Walk to Save Black Men’s Lives,” seeks to inform attendees about their health and promote wellness among African American men. CW39's discussion with the Executive Director Jamail Johnson and Dr. Naddi Marah highlights the importance of the event, the available screenings, and how individuals can participate.

title: Commissioners talk about upcoming Black Men’s Wellness Day
summary: For the 11th consecutive year, a local non-profit in Youngstown, Ohio, the African American Male Wellness Agency, is organizing Black Men’s Wellness Day. The event, aimed at the minority community's health awareness, is scheduled for August 3 at the Covelli Centre. Rev. John-Michael Oliver discussed the variety of programs offered by the agency, emphasizing that the event is more than just a walk. It includes health screenings and resources on fatherhood, mental health, financial literacy, and workforce development, all provided to the community at no cost.

title: African American Male Wellness Walk set for Aug. 19 in Cleveland
summary: The African American Male Wellness Walk is scheduled for August 19 in Cleveland at Wade Oval, marking the 20th anniversary of the National African American Male Wellness Initiative. This free event aims to encourage African American men to prioritize their health to live longer and reduce the health equity gap. It includes a 5K walk and various health screenings such as blood pressure, glucose, cholesterol, HIV, STD/STI, and prostate cancer. Kenny Hampton, the President of the African American Male Wellness Agency, emphasized the importance of men knowing their health status to make necessary changes. The event also features vendors, a kid's zone, and live entertainment, aiming to provide a fun and informative experience for participants.

title: Houston Black men's health agency partners with Johnson & Johnson to boost healthcare in minority communities
summary: Johnson & Johnson has announced a significant investment in over 100 community-based health organizations across the United States, focusing on historically marginalized communities. This includes a partnership with Houston's African American Male Wellness Agency (AAMWA) to address health disparities in the Black community. The initiative, part of the "My Health Can't Wait" program, aims to increase the life expectancy of Black men by focusing on physical, mental, financial health, fatherhood, and research. HIV prevalence among Harris County's Black population was notably higher than its white counterpart in 2019, highlighting the urgent need for targeted health interventions. The program will visit 25 cities nationwide, starting with Houston, where AAMWA will host "Black Men's Wellness Day" at the University of Houston on April 27. This event will offer free health screenings, vendors, live entertainment, and family-friendly activities.

title: Wellness Day Highlights Healthcare Needs Of Black Men
summary: Black Men's Wellness Day, held on April 27 in Houston and other cities, focused on addressing healthcare disparities among Black men. Hosted by the University of Houston, the event featured a "Save Black Men's Lives" 5K walk, health screenings, and over 100 vendors aimed at health, wellness, and connecting Black men with social services. The initiative, driven by the African American Wellness Agency’s Houston office, aims to bring healthcare discussions to the forefront and save lives by offering access to necessary health services. Last year, around 20% of attendees were directed to hospitals for immediate medical issues. The event also highlighted the higher risks Black men face, such as amputations and lower life expectancy compared to other demographics. Partnerships with organizations like Johnson & Johnson provided free screenings to address these disparities.

title: Working to Close the Racial Health Gap Through Meaningful Partnerships and a Community-First Approach
summary: Johnson & Johnson recently launched the My Health Can’t Wait initiative in partnership with two Philadelphia community organizations to address the racial health gap. Established in 2020 as part of Our Race to Health Equity, the program aims to educate and inspire people of color to prioritize their health through expanded outreach, tailored research, PSAs, pilot programs, and wellness events nationwide. The initiative focuses on scaling up efforts to have a larger impact by expanding community initiatives, building additional educational resources for healthcare providers and patients, and fostering collaborations for better health. During its launch campaign, My Health Can’t Wait collaborated with Philadelphia’s Enon Tabernacle Baptist Church East and the National African American Male Wellness Agency (AAMWA) to host community wellness events, offering health education resources and screenings for various conditions. These efforts are part of Johnson & Johnson's commitment to closing the racial health gap through meaningful partnerships and a community-first approach.

title: The Gregorys Have Dedicated Themselves To Uplifting The Black Community
summary: Pamela and John Gregory have established several organizations dedicated to supporting the Black community, earning recognition from President Obama for their impactful work. For over 30 years, they have generated millions of dollars, helped more than 50,000 families, and provided jobs for over 10,000 people of color. Their projects include the National African American Male Wellness Agency, aimed at preventing chronic illnesses in African-American men through complimentary health screenings and wellness support. Additionally, they launched the National Center for Urban Solutions and the Academy for Urban Scholars, which offer workforce training and high school diploma programs, respectively. They also initiated NCUS TEC to provide technology credentials, addressing the employment skills gap for African-Americans in the tech industry. Despite facing obstacles, such as John Gregory's health issues, their dedication to service and community upliftment remains unwavering. Pamela Gregory, as the CFO of their organizations, stresses the significance of philanthropy, education, and self-confidence.

title: Amid syphilis surge, doctors call for more testing during pregnancy
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS
summary: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists has released new guidelines recommending more frequent syphilis testing during pregnancy due to a rise in cases. They suggest a standard blood test at the first prenatal appointment, further tests in the third trimester, and at delivery. This marks a major shift from earlier advice, which only suggested third trimester testing for those in high-risk areas or at risk of syphilis exposure during pregnancy.

title: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologist leader reflects on ripple effects post-Roe v. Wade
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS
summary: The leader of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), Dr. Stella Dantas, talks about the major effects on reproductive healthcare after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade. This ruling stopped nearly 50 years of constitutional rights to abortion, leading to strict laws in about half of the U.S. states. Now, patients often need to travel across state lines for abortion services, especially when their health is at risk, and doctors in restrictive states face legal dangers. Dantas points out the difficulties for underserved communities and the wider impacts on healthcare, including more burnout among medical workers. She focuses on ACOG's long-term goals during her presidency to guarantee complete access to reproductive healthcare and protect it from political interference. The discussion also addresses the outcomes of these restrictions, like delays in care, more travel for patients, and effects on communities when healthcare providers move to states with fewer restrictions. Moreover, Dantas mentions the broader issues of maternal death rates, racial inequalities in healthcare, and the significance of a diverse and cooperative healthcare team.

title: UC Regents file lawsuit against Mattel for alleged violation of $50M contract
summary: The UC Regents have filed a lawsuit against Mattel, Inc., alleging the company breached a $50 million contract intended for the UCLA Mattel Children’s Hospital. In 2017, Mattel pledged the amount, to be paid in annual installments over 12 years, in exchange for naming rights and logo inclusion at the hospital. The funds were meant to enhance pediatric care and support global health programs. Mattel made the initial payment in 2017 but fell short in 2018, paying only $1 million of the $3 million due, citing a significant net loss. Despite agreeing to a temporary suspension of payments at Mattel's request, UCLA Health claims Mattel has since failed to resume payments, even after reporting substantial net income in 2021. The lawsuit seeks to enforce the fulfillment of the pledged amount, with UCLA Health expressing hope for a resolution that respects their long-standing relationship and shared commitment to children's care.

title: Yale New Haven Health moves to sue Prospect to get out of sale
summary: Yale New Haven Health (YNHH) is suing Prospect Medical Holdings to end a contract to buy Manchester Memorial, Rockville General, and Waterbury hospitals in Connecticut. YNHH claims Prospect broke the contract by not paying rent and taxes, letting the facilities worsen, mismanaging assets, and making irresponsible financial decisions. Originally, YNHH agreed to purchase the hospitals for $435 million in 2022. After a cyberattack and learning about Prospect's large debts, Yale wanted to change the price, leading to a stalemate in talks. Prospect accuses Yale of unfairly trying to leave the deal, while Yale says Prospect didn't fulfill its contract duties or fix breaches. The lawsuit seeks to make Prospect negotiate fairly and possibly complete the sale, underlining the hospitals' importance to their communities.

title: Yale New Haven Health System to sue Prospect Medical Holdings
summary: The Yale New Haven Health System is suing Prospect Medical Holdings to end a $435 million hospital buy deal, claiming Prospect didn't meet safety, cleaning, and money rules at three Connecticut hospitals. Complaints include poor handling of medical samples, ignoring infrastructure, and cyberattacks leaking about 110,000 patients and workers' data. Also, Prospect's financial negligence has resulted in unpaid staff wages, piling up debts. The lawsuit aims to prove Prospect broke the Asset Purchase Agreement and free Yale New Haven Health from buying it. Prospect Medical Holdings, which owns 16 hospitals across four states, denies these accusations, highlighting a notable recovery in patient numbers and financial status at the Connecticut hospitals.

title: Dinner Introduces Future Residents to Yale School of Medicine and Yale New Haven Hospital < Yale School of Medicine
summary: The Yale School of Medicine (YSM) and Yale New Haven Hospital (YNHH) hosted the Diversity in the Healthcare Workforce Dinner on February 8, 2024, to introduce future residents to their programs. The event, attended by 200 participants and 107 visiting students from across the country, was aimed at showcasing the values and aspirations of YSM and YNHH. Speakers included Dr. Benjamin Mba, the emcee and vice chair for Diversity, Equity & Inclusion at YSM, and Dr. Stephen Huot, who shared his journey and the importance of shared values in a medical career. Other presenters discussed Yale New Haven Health's commitment to equity and excellence in patient care. The dinner, supported by various clinical departments and offices within YSM and YNHH, highlighted the institutions' dedication to diversity and inclusion in healthcare. This annual event, which began in 2017, continues to grow in popularity, emphasizing the community and support offered to residents and students at Yale.

title: Yale New Haven Health names new president, and more | MED MOVES
summary: Pamela Sutton-Wallace has been appointed as the president of Yale New Haven Health, announced on February 20, 2024. She joined the organization in July 2022 as Chief Operating Officer and has since been instrumental in expanding access to care throughout Connecticut and transitioning the organization towards a broader role as an academic health system. CEO Christopher O’Connor praised Sutton-Wallace for her visionary leadership and commitment to high-quality and equitable care. In addition to her new role, Sutton-Wallace serves on several boards, including Consensus Cloud Solutions, Inc., Carol Emmott Foundation, and Duke University School of Nursing Board of Visitors, and is an active member of the National Association of Health Services Executives. The announcement is part of a series of leadership appointments across various health organizations, including Boston Medical Center and HCA Midwest Health, aiming to enhance strategic, operational, and digital transformations in healthcare.

title: Yale-New Haven Hospital settles 403(b) lawsuit for $1 million
summary: Yale-New Haven Hospital Inc. has settled a class-action lawsuit for $1 million due to high administrative fees and underperforming investments in its $1.7 billion 403(b) retirement plan. The lawsuit, initiated in January 2022, claimed the hospital and its fiduciaries breached the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 by imposing excessive record-keeping and administrative fees. It was alleged the hospital's retirement plan charged $48 per person annually for these fees, whereas similar plans charged less than $35. In March 2023, some allegations were dismissed, but the fee complaints were permitted to go to trial. The settlement benefits both current and former plan participants, with payments made directly to their accounts or via checks and rollovers to qualified plans.

title: Turner Tops Out First Tower of $430 Million Yale-New Haven Hospital Neurosciences Center | Insights
summary: Turner Construction Company celebrated the topping out of the McGivney Tower, the first tower of a $430 million, two-tower Neurosciences Center at Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven, Connecticut. The project marks a significant milestone, with the second tower, Sherman Tower, expected to top out in early 2025. This project, the largest of its kind in state history, will feature a 200,000 square foot McGivney Tower built over the McGivney Advanced Ambulatory Surgical Center. It will include a Radiology and Biomedical Imaging Suite, four patient floors, and a mechanical/electrical room. The two towers will add 204 inpatient beds and focus on innovation in neurosciences, offering care for a range of conditions from movement disorders to neuro-regeneration. An 8,000 square foot healing garden will be located on the fourth-floor roof between the two towers. The project, totaling 507,000 square feet, is expected to be completed in late 2026.

title: CT approves Yale New Haven's acquisition of three hospitals
summary: Yale New Haven Health Services' request to take over three Connecticut hospitals - Waterbury Hospital, Rockville General Hospital, and Manchester Memorial Hospital - has been greenlit by the state Office of Health Strategy. The goal of this acquisition is to guarantee that healthcare services meet the standards of quality, accessibility, fairness, affordability, and cost-efficiency.

title: State permits Yale New Haven Health System to acquire Prospect hospitals
summary: The Connecticut Office of Health Strategy has approved the acquisition of three hospitals by Yale New Haven Health System from Prospect Medical Holdings, a significant move towards completing the transaction. This deal, under discussion since October 2022, will avert the shutdown of Waterbury Hospital, Rockville General Hospital, and Manchester Memorial Hospital, incorporating 700 beds and approximately 4,400 staff into YNHHS. The hospitals will shift from being for-profit to non-profit. The agreement mandates the appointment of an independent monitor, efforts to keep existing staff and honor union contracts, and a focus on community involvement, including a requirement for YNHHS to boost its community benefit spending. This acquisition is designed to maintain local access to crucial healthcare services and save jobs, tackling the financial and operational difficulties the Prospect-owned hospitals have faced, worsened by a cyberattack and poor financial management.

title: Smilow Cancer Hospital at Yale New Haven becomes first hospital in the northeast to offer SCINTIX biology-guided ...
summary: Smilow Cancer Hospital at Yale New Haven has become the first in the northeast to offer SCINTIX biology-guided radiotherapy (BgRT), a groundbreaking treatment using RefleXion's technology for patients with primary and metastatic bone and lung cancers. This innovative approach combines positron emission tomography (PET) imaging with radiotherapy to precisely target cancer cells based on their biological activity, sparing normal tissues. SCINTIX BgRT, delivered by the RefleXion X1 unit, utilizes a radioactive tracer that interacts with cancer cells, producing photonic signals to accurately locate and assess tumors' biological signatures. This technology offers a unique opportunity to treat multiple targets seen in PET scans effectively, addressing a significant challenge in traditional radiation therapy workflows. Approximately 430,000 people are diagnosed annually in the U.S. with tumors in the lungs or bones, making this advancement a significant milestone in cancer treatment.

title: Yale New Haven Hospital announces new president
summary: Katherine Heilpern has been appointed as the new president of Yale New Haven Hospital, amid the hospital's attempts to acquire three Prospect medical hospitals and backlash from closing a daycare facility. Heilpern, with a background as the COO of the Weill Cornell Division at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and 12 years as chair of the department of emergency medicine at Emory University, brings extensive experience to the role. She succeeds Pamela Sutton-Wallace, who becomes president of the entire Yale New Haven Health system. Heilpern's appointment is notable as she becomes one of the few women leading a hospital of Yale New Haven's size in the U.S. She aims to improve patient care by leveraging her clinical experience and fostering collaboration across Yale's medical, public health, and nursing schools. Yale New Haven Hospital employs over 5,000 medical personnel and nearly 15,000 staff members.

title: Yale Fellowship in Endocrinology, Diabetes & Metabolism < Endocrinology & Metabolism
summary: The Yale Fellowship in Endocrinology, Diabetes, and Metabolism is a prestigious and comprehensive training program aimed at developing future leaders in the field. It stands as one of the oldest endocrinology training programs in the United States, boasting continuous National Institutes of Health funding for over 50 years. This fellowship offers an ideal mix of clinical training at a leading academic medical center and research opportunities at a globally renowned research university. Trainees benefit from a broad range of clinical and scholarly experiences, personalized mentoring from distinguished faculty, and the program's unique integration with pediatric endocrinology and endocrine surgery. The fellowship includes rotations in various subspecialty outpatient clinics and provides extensive training in managing a wide array of endocrine and metabolic conditions. There are two training tracks available, with the option to become board-eligible after two years. Applications are accepted through the ERAS Electronic Application and matched via the National Residency Matching Program, with interviews by invitation during selected dates in September and October.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Diabetes & Obesity: Charting Pathways to Effective Co-management in Primary Care
summary: The PRIME® Online Activity titled "Diabetes & Obesity: Charting Pathways to Effective Co-management in Primary Care" is a free, online educational course for healthcare professionals, including doctors, physician assistants, nurse practitioners, pharmacists, and nurses. It started on November 17, 2023, and ends on November 16, 2024, offering 1.5 CME/CE credits for various professions. The course aims to improve the joint management of patients with Type 2 Diabetes and obesity in primary care by incorporating weight loss into treatment plans, identifying candidates for more intensive treatments, making treatment decisions based on current evidence, and using shared decision-making techniques. It promotes effective patient engagement and offers methods for monitoring and managing patient progress. The content, reviewed upon its release, provides insights from a system-wide implementation science initiative and evidence-based methods to improve care according to guidelines, focusing on quick glycemic control and lasting weight loss.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Optimizing Outcomes in Alzheimer's Disease: The Latest Therapeutic Evidence and Shared ...
summary: The PRIME® Online Activity titled "Optimizing Outcomes in Alzheimer's Disease: The Latest Therapeutic Evidence and Shared Decision-Making Strategies" is aimed at neurologists and their care teams, including nurse practitioners, physician assistants, nurses, and pharmacists involved in Alzheimer's disease (AD) care. This no-cost online activity, accessible from December 14, 2023, to December 13, 2024, grants 1.0 CME/CE credit after completion. It emphasizes the need for early and precise AD diagnosis, evaluating the newest clinical trial information on disease-modifying therapies (DMTs), and employing shared decision-making strategies in choosing treatments. The goal is to enhance patient outcomes through early intervention and effective communication regarding AD management, tackling the hurdles of prompt diagnosis, treatment choice, safety concerns, and care accessibility.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Bladder Cancer: Assessing and Incorporating Novel Treatment Strategies
summary: The PRIME® Online Activity titled "Bladder Cancer: Assessing and Incorporating Novel Treatment Strategies" is a free, online educational activity for oncology care teams. It will be available from January 12, 2024, to January 11, 2025, offering 0.5 CME/CE credits for various healthcare professions. The activity focuses on improving bladder cancer diagnosis and management by incorporating new therapies into treatment plans, based on recent clinical trial outcomes and molecular testing guidelines. It highlights the role of effective communication and education in making treatment decisions. The faculty features experts from renowned institutions, with support from educational grants by multiple pharmaceutical companies. This program demonstrates PRIME's dedication to enhancing patient care and has accreditation from several continuing education accrediting organizations.

title: PRIME® Live Meeting - Mock P&T: Examining the Latest Evidence in the Treatment of Perinatal/Peripartum Depression ...
summary: The PRIME® Live Meeting titled "Mock P&T: Examining the Latest Evidence in the Treatment of Perinatal/Peripartum Depression" is scheduled for April 16, 2024, in New Orleans, LA, at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center. This activity is designed for medical and pharmacy directors, pharmacists, and medication therapy management nursing directors working in managed care organizations. It aims to provide an interactive learning experience by simulating a Pharmacy and Therapeutics (P&T) Committee meeting to discuss patient selection challenges based on the latest treatment advancements and research findings in perinatal/peripartum depression (PPD). Esteemed experts will review existing PPD guidelines, novel therapies data, and the balance between clinical effectiveness and financial constraints. The session encourages active participation from attendees in discussions and consensus-building. This CME/CE activity is free of charge and offers 1.25 continuing education credits for physicians, pharmacists, and nurses. It focuses on the consequences of undiagnosed PPD, the role of neuroactive steroids in treatment, and aligning managed care decision-making with current evidence for safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of therapies.

title: PRIME® NASH/MASH: An Action-Based Checklist & Guide for Patients At Risk
summary: The text provides information about PRIME® Education's action-based checklist and guide for patients at risk of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), previously known as non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). This condition is progressive and can lead to serious health complications if not managed actively. The guide aims to support patients in assessing their risk, improving their health, and obtaining specialized care from their healthcare teams. The activity is free, supported by educational grants from Merck Sharpe & Dohme LLC and Pfizer, and is designed to encourage patient engagement in their health management.

title: PRIME® Navigating the Latest Advances in MASH: Diagnostic Approaches & Emerging Treatments
summary: PRIME Education offers a learning lab on Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatohepatitis (MASH), previously known as Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH), featuring clinical case challenges, expert-led videos, and patient checklists to integrate the latest guidelines into care plans. This free activity, supported by Merck Sharpe & Dohme LLC and Pfizer, emphasizes the importance of early detection and risk stratification by primary care and endocrinology teams for patients at risk of progressing to advanced disease. The program also explores recent advances in MASH, including updates to professional guidelines and emerging pharmacotherapies, highlighting the projected increase in prevalence and the current reliance on diet and lifestyle interventions for management.

title: PRIME® Live Meeting - Expert Insights and System-Based Care Trends in Early-Stage NSCLC and Melanoma ...
summary: The PRIME® Live Meeting in Indianapolis, IN, on April 20th, 2024, focuses on the latest trends in system-based care for early-stage NSCLC, melanoma, metastatic bladder cancer, and relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma. It aims to update clinical protocols and workflows with emerging clinical data. The event, suitable for community medical oncologists, hematologists/oncologists, and their clinical teams, will offer insights into biomarker testing for NSCLC, incorporating immunotherapy for melanoma, new evidence in immunotherapy for metastatic bladder cancer, and integrating novel bispecific antibody therapies for follicular lymphoma. Attendees will earn continuing medical education credits and access evidence-based slides. The sessions will cover advancements in biomarker-directed therapies, adjuvant immunotherapy, immunotherapies and combination approaches for metastatic urothelial carcinoma, and bispecific antibody therapies, aiming to close gaps in evidence-based treatment.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Recognizing MASH in At-Risk Patients: Seizing Opportunities for Early Detection
summary: The PRIME® Online Activity titled "Recognizing MASH in At-Risk Patients: Seizing Opportunities for Early Detection" is a free online educational initiative designed for healthcare professionals, including primary care providers, endocrinologists, gastroenterologists, hepatologists, and their teams. It aims to improve the early detection and intervention of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH, formerly known as non-alcoholic steatohepatitis or NASH), a silent disease that often progresses without visible symptoms. The activity, which offers 0.5 CME/CE credits across various professions, emphasizes the importance of identifying patients with risk factors for MASH to support early detection, evaluating disparities in diagnosis and outcomes among underserved populations, and incorporating patient-centered communication strategies. It features expert faculty discussions, patient perspectives, and a downloadable PDF resource to empower patients in their care journey. The activity, released on December 1, 2023, and expiring on November 30, 2024, is accredited by several accrediting bodies and supported by educational grants from Merck Sharpe & Dohme LLC and Pfizer.

title: PRIME® Print Activity - Appropriate Healthcare Interventions in Elder, Child, and Intimate Partner Abuse
summary: The PRIME® Print Activity titled "Appropriate Healthcare Interventions in Elder, Child, and Intimate Partner Abuse" is a continuing education course designed for healthcare professionals, including physicians, nurses, pharmacists, and social workers. Released on December 8, 2023, and expiring on December 7, 2026, this activity aims to address the significant public health issue of family and domestic violence. For a price of $29.00, participants can earn 2.0 CME/CE credits over an estimated duration of 2 hours. The course covers the definitions, risk factors, signs, prevalence, and outcomes of various forms of abuse, including intimate partner violence, child abuse, elder abuse, and neglect. It also provides evidence-based strategies for detection, intervention, and reporting of abuse in patient populations. The program is jointly accredited by several accreditation councils, ensuring a multidisciplinary approach to improving patient care in the context of domestic violence.

title: PRIME® Optimizing Care Continuum in Schizophrenia: Patient-Centered Transitions and Treatment
summary: The PRIME Education initiative offers a comprehensive learning lab designed to enhance the management of schizophrenia care across the inpatient-outpatient continuum. It focuses on the latest clinical evidence for long-acting injectable therapies, guideline recommendations, and strategies for personalized, patient-centered care. This free activity, supported by educational grants from Alkermes, Indivior, Inc., and Janssen Scientific Affairs, LLC, addresses the significant stress and vulnerability patients with schizophrenia face during transitions from inpatient to outpatient care. It highlights the common issue of patients not adhering to their medical management and antipsychotic medications, leading to potential relapses, rehospitalizations, and decreased quality of life. The program aims to improve outcomes by providing the latest information and strategies for managing schizophrenia, emphasizing the importance of long-acting injectable therapies for reducing morbidity and mortality and improving patient adherence.

title: PRIME® Print Activity - NASH/MASH: An Action-Based Checklist & Guide for Patients At Risk
summary: NASH/MASH: An Action-Based Checklist & Guide for Patients At Risk is a free print activity released on December 1, 2023, with an expiration date of November 30, 2024. It is designed for patients at risk for Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), previously known as non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). This progressive condition requires active management to prevent serious health complications. The guide aims to help patients assess their risk, improve their health, and secure specialized care through active collaboration with healthcare teams. The activity is non-accredited and was last reviewed on its release date. Faculty includes Stephen A. Harrison, MD, and Donna M. Chiefari, BSc (Pharm), PharmD, RPh, FASHP, among others, with disclosures of financial relationships with various companies related to gastroenterology and oncology. The activity is part of a Resource Center supported by educational grants from Merck Sharpe & Dohme LLC and Pfizer, and is accessible in multiple languages.

title: PRIME® Enhancing Timely Access to Care for Solid Tumors: 9th Annual Federal Seminar Series
summary: The 9th Annual Federal Seminar Series by PRIME Education focuses on improving timely access to care for solid tumors, including breast, prostate, kidney, lung, bladder, gastric/esophagogastric, and liver cancers. It aims to update healthcare providers in federal and public settings on the most recent evidence for managing advanced solid tumors. The series features webcasts on various cancers, offering practical strategies to enhance knowledge, competence, and confidence in providing care. Topics cover the integration of novel agents, biomarker-driven treatment decisions, and the latest clinical evidence and guidelines. The activity is funded by educational grants from several pharmaceutical companies and is free for attendees.

title: PRIME® Advancing Individualized Care for Advanced HR+/HER2- and Triple Negative Breast Cancer
summary: PRIME® Education offers free continuing medical education (CME/CE) activities focused on advancing individualized care for patients with advanced HR+/HER2- and triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). These educational activities are designed to improve outcomes by applying the latest evidence in treatment sequencing, individualizing treatment plans based on patient-, disease-, and treatment-related factors, and overcoming endocrine resistance in HR+/HER2- breast cancer. Participants can engage in clinical case challenges to test their knowledge and decision-making skills using patient testimonials, test results, exams, and patient-specific factors. The program is supported by educational grants from AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals, Gilead Sciences, Inc., and Merck Sharp & Dohme LLC, and aims to keep healthcare professionals up to date with the evolving treatment landscape, enabling personalized treatment decision-making and improving patient outcomes.

title: Meet Jeff! He is one of Lone Star's newest ambassadors.
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA LONE STAR CHAPTER
summary: Jeff is a new ambassador for the Lone Star Chapter of the Lupus Foundation of America. His journey with lupus began in 2010 during his final year at Salisbury University when a routine doctor's visit revealed a kidney disorder. This diagnosis eventually led to him teaching in South Korea, where his condition worsened, and he was diagnosed with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune diseases. Despite the challenges, Jeff navigated healthcare systems in South Korea and the U.S., advocating for himself and others with lupus. He emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis, especially for men, who are less commonly diagnosed with lupus. Jeff actively raises awareness and funds for lupus research, hoping to find a cure and support those affected by the disease.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA LONE STAR CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides a comprehensive support network for individuals living with lupus and their caregivers across the United States. This network includes local chapters, offices, and support groups offering a range of services such as awareness programs, educational resources, financial assistance, and advocacy. Support groups, which can meet virtually or in person, offer a safe environment for those affected by lupus to share experiences and find community. The Foundation also facilitates access to healthcare professionals and diagnosis and treatment options. Additionally, it raises funds for research and education to improve the quality of life for those impacted by lupus. The Foundation encourages participation in various fundraising and advocacy events and offers resources in both English and Spanish, aiming to solve the "cruel mystery" of lupus.

title: NFL Players Shine a Spotlight on Lupus for the My Cause My Cleats Campaign
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA LONE STAR CHAPTER
summary: For the eighth consecutive year, NFL players are participating in the My Cause My Cleats campaign, using custom-designed cleats to raise awareness for various causes, including lupus. This initiative allows players to spotlight issues close to their hearts during weeks 13 and 14 of the NFL season. Six players have chosen to support the Lupus Foundation of America this year, with some being repeat supporters. Players like Jashaun Corbin, Shaquille Leonard, Jartavius “Quan” Martin, Courtland Sutton, Delarrin Turner-Yell, and Dareke Young are dedicating their cleats to lupus awareness, honoring family members and spreading awareness about the disease. Following the games, there is an option for the cleats to be auctioned, with proceeds going to the selected causes. The Lupus Foundation of America has expressed gratitude towards these players for their efforts in raising awareness for lupus.

title: Diet And Nutrition With Lupus
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA LONE STAR CHAPTER
summary: Eating healthy is crucial for managing lupus symptoms and overall health. There's no specific lupus diet, but a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, healthy proteins, and fats is recommended. For those with lupus nephritis, dietary adjustments may be necessary. A vegetarian or vegan diet is fine for lupus patients, but they should ensure a varied intake of plant-based foods and supplement vitamin B12 if avoiding animal products. Some believe alfalfa and possibly garlic may trigger lupus symptoms, though evidence is lacking. Healthy eating can also reduce risks of heart disease and osteoporosis, with emphasis on calcium and Omega-3 fatty acids for bone and heart health, respectively. Limiting sodium, saturated fats, and added sugars is advised to manage or prevent high blood pressure and diabetes. Alcohol should be consumed in moderation, if at all, due to potential interactions with lupus medications. Supplements might be necessary for some nutrients, like vitamin D, but consulting a doctor before starting any is important.

title: Lupus Symptoms
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA LONE STAR CHAPTER
summary: Lupus is a complex autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, leading to a wide range of symptoms. Common symptoms include extreme fatigue, joint pain or swelling, swelling in hands, feet, or around the eyes, headaches, low fevers, sensitivity to sunlight or fluorescent light, and chest pain when breathing deeply. Skin and hair issues are also prevalent, such as a butterfly-shaped rash on the face, hair loss, and mouth or nose sores. Additionally, Raynaud’s Disease, where fingers and toes turn white or blue and feel numb when cold or stressed, is another symptom. These symptoms can fluctuate and change over time. Lupus shares symptoms with other diseases, making it important to consult a doctor for an accurate diagnosis to receive appropriate treatment. The Lupus Foundation of America offers resources for those affected by lupus, including support services, research participation, and advocacy information.

title: Cedars-Sinai Cancer Welcomes New Vice Chair of Research
summary: Cedars-Sinai Cancer has appointed Indrin Chetty, PhD, as the new vice chair of Research and director of the Medical Physics Division in the Department of Radiation Oncology. Chetty is tasked with leading the development and oversight of radiation oncology physics, including clinical operations, and enhancing research and teaching programs. He brings extensive experience from his previous role at Henry Ford Health in Detroit, where he served in similar capacities. Chetty aims to translate research ideas into patient benefits and is excited about mentoring team members at Cedars-Sinai Cancer. His appointment marks a reunion with his mentor, Benedick Fraass, PhD, a distinguished figure in the field, at Cedars-Sinai. Chetty's research focuses on imaging techniques for predicting treatment outcomes and personalized therapy for cancer patients, incorporating machine learning to improve patient outcomes and safety.

title: Cedars-Sinai Guerin Children's Expert Reelected to Leadership Position of Pediatric Oncology Organization
summary: Cedars-Sinai Guerin Children’s pediatric oncologist, Leo Mascarenhas, MD, MS, has been reelected as the chair of the voting body for the Children’s Oncology Group (COG) for a second five-year term starting April 2024. COG is a National Cancer Institute-funded clinical trials network that includes over 200 leading hospitals and cancer centers across North America, Australia, and New Zealand, focusing on pediatric and adolescent cancer research. Mascarenhas, who has been a COG member for over 25 years and part of its voting body for 17 years, plays a crucial role in appointing leaders, coordinating elections, and serving as a liaison between COG’s scientific and administrative committees. Under his leadership, COG aims to continue making significant progress in cancer research and treatment, contributing to a combined five-year survival rate of 85% for children with cancer. Mascarenhas is recognized for his expertise in treating sarcomas and pediatric solid tumors and has led several clinical trials leading to important treatment advancements. His reelection is seen as a testament to his exceptional leadership in the field of pediatric and adolescent cancer.

title: Cedars-Sinai Develops New Tools to Improve Pancreatic Cancer Patient Care
summary: Cedars-Sinai has created a precision medicine and AI tool called the Molecular Twin Precision Oncology Platform, designed to improve care for pancreatic cancer patients by finding biomarkers that more accurately predict survival than current standard tests. This tool, validated with independent datasets, could help guide treatment for all cancer patients by matching them with the most effective therapies. It analyzes a wide range of biological data from blood and tissue samples and has been especially successful in predicting survival in patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, the most common and aggressive form of pancreatic cancer. According to research published in Nature Cancer, blood proteins are the best survival predictors, surpassing the FDA-approved CA 19-9 test. Cedars-Sinai plans to enhance the platform by adding more patient data and exploring new data types to improve precision medicine further.

title: A Telegram From Your Cells
summary: Cedars-Sinai Cancer researchers have developed an innovative method for analyzing extracellular vesicles (EVs), which are biological "messages" that cells use to communicate. This method, described in a study in ACS Nano, is the first step towards decoding the messages carried by EVs, which could lead to new clinical tests for monitoring disease progression in real time. The technology employs machine learning to categorize EVs based on their features, like membrane composition and cargo, enabling the identification of disease-specific EV "signatures." This breakthrough could transform disease detection and monitoring, including for cancer, by facilitating "liquid biopsy" tests that are faster and less invasive than current techniques. Supported by multiple grants, the research seeks to link specific EV profiles with various diseases and treatment outcomes, representing a significant advance in precision medicine and the potential to enhance patient care.

title: New AI Tool Mines Cancer Patients' Pathology Data
summary: Cedars-Sinai investigators have developed a new artificial intelligence (AI) tool to access and analyze pathology reports in cancer patients' medical records, crucial for understanding the disease but difficult to use due to their scanned PDF format. This AI tool cleans the scans, allowing for the extraction of machine-readable notes with high accuracy. This advancement enables the use of these notes for research, clinical trials, and identifying new disease markers. The method was applied to The Cancer Genome Atlas, resulting in a publicly available dataset from nearly 10,000 cancer patients. This dataset helps train models to extract specific information, such as cancer staging, and is expected to fuel new studies across various specialties. The project, supported by a National Institutes of Health grant, represents a significant step towards precision medicine by making detailed clinical information more accessible for analysis.

title: Cedars-Sinai Launches Singapore Office
summary: Cedars-Sinai International has expanded its global presence by opening a new office in Singapore, marking its third international location. This move aims to enhance global access to Cedars-Sinai's advanced medical expertise and high-quality patient care. The Singapore office will facilitate access for patients and their families to Cedars-Sinai's specialists in areas such as cardiology, oncology, and neurology, among others. It will also support a patient-centric continuum of care by collaborating with local physicians to develop personalized treatment plans. Led by Dr. Steven Tucker, an American medical oncologist with nearly two decades of experience in Singapore, the office is situated in the Novena medical hub. This expansion not only brings Cedars-Sinai's renowned care closer to patients in Singapore but also fosters collaboration and knowledge sharing between U.S. and Southeast Asian medical professionals. Other Cedars-Sinai global offices are located in Mexico City, Mexico, and Shanghai, China, with future locations planned for Qatar, Ecuador, and more.

title: Cedars-Sinai Experts Present New Research at European Cancer Conference
summary: Cedars-Sinai Cancer experts presented their latest research findings at the European Society for Medical Oncology's ESMO Congress 2023 in Madrid, focusing on prostate, lung, kidney, and colorectal cancers. Key highlights included the EMBARK Phase III trial for recurrent prostate cancer, showing two new treatments extended patients' lives without disease progression compared to current standards, without compromising overall quality of life. Additionally, a Phase III trial for advanced non-small cell lung cancer demonstrated that combining chemotherapy with either amivantamab or lazertinib significantly improved progression-free survival and overall response rates over chemotherapy alone. The LITESPARK study on kidney cancer revealed that a therapy combining cabozantinib and belzutifan showed durable antitumor activity, especially in patients previously untreated or treated with immunotherapy. Moreover, a comparative analysis of tumor immune environments in primary and metastatic colorectal cancers was discussed, highlighting differences in immunotherapy response.

title: Closing in on Triple-Negative Breast Cancer
summary: Cedars-Sinai Cancer researchers have found that combining radiation therapy with immunotherapy before surgery could lead to a better immune response against tumors in some triple-negative breast cancer patients. Published in Cancer Cell, this discovery was made by analyzing tumor cells before and after treatment, revealing three different response groups among patients. The study suggests that custom treatments could be more effective for this hard-to-treat cancer, which lacks three common receptors and has few treatment options. While only a small number of patients react to immunotherapy on its own, adding radiation therapy might enhance the effectiveness by increasing immune cells in the tumors. This research sets the stage for future clinical trials and personalized medicine strategies, aiming to identify which patients will benefit most from such treatments through simple methods like blood tests.

title: New Medical Director Appointed at Cedars-Sinai Cancer in Beverly Hills
summary: Hematologist/oncologist Kevin Scher, MD, MBA, with over a decade of experience at Cedars-Sinai Cancer, has been appointed the new medical director of Cedars-Sinai Cancer in Beverly Hills. In his role, Scher aims to ensure the highest standard of care for cancer patients by working closely with the leadership of Cedars-Sinai Cancer and Cedars-Sinai Medical Network. Additionally, he will co-chair the Patient-Centric High-Value Care Committee, focusing on enhancing patient care, safety, and experience while reducing health system costs. Scher, who joined Cedars-Sinai Cancer in 2013, is recognized for his patient-centric approach and his efforts to integrate clinical and academic endeavors at Cedars-Sinai Cancer. His academic qualifications include a bachelor’s degree from Princeton University, an MBA from Columbia Business School, and a medical degree from New York University School of Medicine, followed by a residency at UCLA and a fellowship at City of Hope Comprehensive Cancer Center. Scher is motivated by the progress in oncology, aiming to use new discoveries to improve patient outcomes and provide innovative treatments.

title: Cedars-Sinai Radiation Oncology Earns Top Accreditation
summary: The Department of Radiation Oncology at Cedars-Sinai Cancer has received accreditation from the American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO) Accreditation Program for Excellence. This award emphasizes Cedars-Sinai's dedication to patient safety and high-quality care in radiation oncology at both Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and Cedars-Sinai Radiation Oncology Tarzana. Valid until November 2027, the accreditation affirms the department's commitment to upholding stringent standards in staff training, equipment testing, and patient education. This accomplishment was achieved through the collective efforts of the department's staff, notably including Howard Sandler, MD, the Department Chair, and prominent members like Indrin Chetty, PhD, and John DeMarco, PhD. The accreditation process involved meeting over 200 quality standards and developing more than 60 new policies and procedures to improve patient safety and education.

title: Making Resistant Tumors Vulnerable to Treatment
summary: Cedars-Sinai Cancer researchers have found a way to treat resistant soft tissue sarcomas, a rare cancer type, effectively. The study, published in Nature Communications, identified a new cell subtype that produces a molecular "Velcro" known as CXCL16, blocking T cells from attacking the tumor and making immunotherapy ineffective. By using a glycolysis inhibitor in lab mice, which prevents these cells from consuming glucose, the scientists managed to stop CXCL16 production, enabling T cells to penetrate the tumors and making them vulnerable to chemotherapy. This discovery could pave the way for new treatments for soft tissue sarcomas and other cancers that don't respond to existing therapies. However, since glycolysis inhibitors are unsafe for human use, the team is working on developing a therapy that targets CXCL16 to enhance treatment effectiveness.

title: Predicting Ovarian Cancer Relapse
summary: Cedars-Sinai investigators, Akil Merchant, MD, and Alex Xu, PhD, conducted a study using spatial tissue analysis to identify patterns in ovarian cancer tissue samples that could predict early relapse in patients with high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma, the deadliest form of ovarian cancer. The study, published in Science Advances, utilized imaging mass cytometry to analyze the spatial protein content of the tissue from 42 patients. The findings highlighted the significance of plasma cells' location and their interaction with surrounding cells in determining patient outcomes. Plasma cells associated with lymphoid aggregates led to better outcomes, suggesting effective immune response communication. In contrast, plasma cells near cancer-associated fibroblasts, which hinder immune cell activity, indicated poorer outcomes. This research points towards potential biomarkers and precision therapies for improving survival rates in ovarian cancer patients.

title: New Director of Melanoma Research at Cedars-Sinai Cancer
summary: Bin Zheng, PhD, has been appointed as the new Director of Melanoma Research at Cedars-Sinai Cancer, within the Department of Biomedical Sciences. Zheng, an expert in targeted therapies and immunotherapy for melanoma—the most serious type of skin cancer—aims to develop a comprehensive translational and basic science research program in collaboration with Cedars-Sinai's surgical and medical oncology leadership. His research focuses on melanoma cell metabolism and the tumor microenvironment, exploring resistance mechanisms to current immunotherapies and targeted therapies. Zheng's goal is to improve survival rates for melanoma patients by enhancing treatments through scientific discoveries that could lead to new therapies. He has a PhD in molecular pathology from the University of California, San Diego, and has held positions at Columbia University and Harvard Medical School before joining Cedars-Sinai. Dan Theodorescu, MD, PhD, director of Cedars-Sinai Cancer, expressed enthusiasm for Zheng's contributions to advancing melanoma research and treatment.

title: Breastfeeding: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months and encourages continued breastfeeding after introducing solid foods for 2 years or beyond, aligning with World Health Organization guidance. The AAP aims to increase the number of exclusively breastfed infants up to 6 months. Breastfeeding offers numerous health benefits, reducing risks for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), infections, asthma, obesity, diabetes, leukemia, and improving IQ scores. It also benefits the nursing parent's health, offering protection against diabetes, high blood pressure, and certain cancers. Breastfeeding fosters closeness between parent and child, is cost-effective, and aids in the mother's postpartum recovery. Early initiation, skin-to-skin contact, and lactation counseling can enhance breastfeeding success. Challenges include societal pressures and workplace support. The AAP supports nonjudgmental guidance for all feeding choices, emphasizing the importance of breastfeeding while recognizing the varied goals and needs of families.

title: American Academy of Pediatrics
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), founded in 1930 and headquartered in Itasca, Illinois, is a professional membership organization with 67,000 pediatricians committed to the health and well-being of infants, children, adolescents, and young adults. AAP is a leading advocacy group for children's health and provides pediatricians and their patients with essential health-related information. It also manages HealthyChildren.org, a parenting website supported by pediatricians, and has the largest pediatric publishing program globally, including the scientific journal Pediatrics and the AAP News magazine. The AAP operates a federal affairs office in Washington, DC, and has been recognized as one of the 101 Best and Brightest Companies to Work for in Chicagoland since 2005. The organization encourages professionals to join its team to impact children's health provision in the U.S.

title: Patient Care - Epilepsy: National Coordinating Center for Epilepsy
summary: The National Coordinating Center for Epilepsy, run by the American Academy of Pediatrics since 2013, seeks to improve access to high-quality, comprehensive care for children and young people with epilepsy, particularly in underserved or rural areas. Epilepsy is the most common childhood brain disorder in the U.S., affecting 470,000 children and adolescents. It involves repeated seizures due to abnormal electrical and chemical brain changes, with seizures varying in type and severity. The Center aids healthcare professionals by offering recommendations, guidelines, and resources for diagnosing, treating, and managing pediatric epilepsy. It highlights the importance of preparation, treatment, and teamwork in epilepsy care and provides resources on care coordination, shared decision-making, and telehealth. Funded by the Health Resources and Services Administration, the Center aims to support children and youth throughout their lives.

title: US pediatricians group reverses decades-old ban on breastfeeding for those with HIV
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics has updated its guidelines to allow people with HIV to breastfeed, provided they are on effective antiretroviral therapy that suppresses the virus. This marks a significant change from the longstanding recommendation against breastfeeding due to the risk of HIV transmission to the baby. The new policy reflects advancements in HIV medication that can reduce the transmission risk through breast milk to less than 1%. However, the guidance also notes that the only way to completely eliminate the risk is by not breastfeeding and that exclusive breastfeeding is necessary for the first six months to minimize the risk of HIV transmission. This shift follows similar guidance from the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and aims to support shared decision-making between healthcare providers and patients, without stigma or discrimination.

title: The 5 Cs of Media Use
summary: The 5 Cs of Media Use is a framework developed to assist pediatricians and healthcare providers in discussing digital media use with families. It includes five main components: Child, Content, Calm, Crowding Out, and Communication. This mnemonic helps address media use concerning children's developmental stages and encourages healthy media habits.
