The American Academy of Pediatrics has produced age-specific handouts based on current research to help parents effectively manage their children's media consumption. These materials are part of a larger effort to guide families towards healthy changes in digital media use, inspired by the work of journalist Lisa Guernsey. The initiative focuses on meeting families where they are, improving understanding, and enhancing communication skills for healthier media engagement.

title: The American Academy of Pediatrics' new guidelines to help kids slash smart phone screen time
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics has introduced new guidelines, called the 5-C's, to help parents manage their children's use of smartphones and media. These guidelines are in response to studies showing that 53% of children have a smartphone by age 11. The 5-C's are: understanding the child's individuality and media preferences, being aware of the content they are exposed to, teaching calmness as an alternative to media for emotional management, replacing media time with other valuable family activities, and promoting a healthy relationship between children and their devices. This approach aims to balance media use with other developmental needs such as emotional management, social interactions, and physical activity, while considering the different needs of various age groups. The initiative also looks at the effects of too much screen time on mood, concentration, and overall development.

title: American Academy of Pediatrics Updates Policy Statement on Hearing Risks for Children
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics has updated its policy statement on hearing risks for children, addressing common sources and effects of noise from infancy through adolescence. Published in the November 2023 issue of Pediatrics, the statement emphasizes the serious public health hazard posed by excessive noise exposure. It highlights that children's smaller ear canals amplify higher frequency sounds, making them more susceptible to damage from everyday noises like road traffic and background TV, which can also disrupt sleep, learning, and quality of life. The policy advises against exposing children to loud environments, recommends the use of protective earmuffs at noisy events, and stresses the importance of cautious use of personal listening devices. The AAP also suggests pediatricians discuss noise exposure prevention during patient visits and encourages parents to advocate for quieter spaces in childcare and educational settings. The statement and technical report aim to raise awareness about noise levels and their impact on health, particularly in children and teens.

title: How to Keep Your Sleeping Baby Safe: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has updated its policy statement and technical report on safe sleep to reduce the risk of sleep-related infant deaths, including sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and accidental deaths from suffocation or strangulation. Around 3,500 babies in the United States die unexpectedly during sleep each year. The AAP emphasizes the importance of a safe sleep environment to lower the risk of these tragedies. Key recommendations include placing babies on their backs for all sleep times, using a firm, flat sleep surface, ensuring the sleep area is free from soft objects and loose bedding, and room sharing without bed sharing. The AAP also advises against the use of inclined sleep products and recommends breastfeeding, pacifier use at nap and bedtime, avoiding exposure to smoke, alcohol, and illicit drugs, regular prenatal care, and keeping up with vaccinations and well-child visits. Tummy time is encouraged for awake babies to support motor development. The AAP warns against products claiming to reduce SIDS risk without evidence and advises against home cardiorespiratory monitors as a SIDS prevention strategy.

title: Teen Mental Health: How to Know When Your Child Needs Help
summary: Teen mental health is a critical issue, with many teens struggling with anxiety, depression, and other concerns, especially in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. Parents and caregivers may find it challenging to differentiate between normal adolescent behavior and signs of mental health issues. Key indicators that a teen may need more support include significant changes in sleep, weight, eating habits, loss of interest in activities, withdrawal from friends and family, academic struggles, persistent worries, new or intense sexual activity, signs of substance use, and self-harm. Common mental health conditions among teens include ADHD, anxiety, depression, and eating disorders. Substance use and the impact of social media also play significant roles in teen mental health. Open communication, creating a judgment-free environment, and actively listening are crucial for parents to support their teen's mental health. Pediatricians can offer guidance, treatment options, and referrals to specialists. In cases of suicidal thoughts or actions, immediate help should be sought through crisis lifelines or mental health professionals. Promoting positive mental health and resilience through proactive self-care and healthy habits is essential for both teens and their families.

title: Media and Children - Center of Excellence on Social Media and Youth Mental Health
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has established a Center of Excellence on Social Media and Youth Mental Health to serve as a central, trusted source for evidence-based education and technical assistance. This initiative aims to support the mental health of children and adolescents in navigating social media. Led by co-Medical Directors Megan Moreno, MD, MPH, MSEd, FAAP, and Jenny Radesky, MD, FAAP, the Center is focused on creating a healthy digital ecosystem for young users. It offers resources like the 5 Cs of Media Use to help pediatricians discuss digital media with families, and a Q&A Portal to address questions from parents, teens, educators, and clinicians. Additionally, the Center provides tools for developing healthy digital habits, webinars, and podcasts on social media's impact on youth mental health. Funded by a grant from SAMHSA of the US Department of Health and Human Services, the Center continuously develops new resources to aid in creating a healthier online environment for children and youth.

title: Helping Kids Build Healthy Active Lives: AAP Policy Explained
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has updated its clinical report to assist parents, pediatricians, and communities in fostering healthier, more active lifestyles for children to prevent obesity from infancy through adolescence. The report highlights that maintaining a healthy weight requires more than diet and exercise, underscoring the significance of sleep, responsible technology use, and emotional and social health. It offers practical advice for parents, such as teaching kids about nutrition, choosing water as the main beverage, reducing ultra-processed food intake, establishing a family media plan, integrating physical activity into daily life, and focusing on stress management. Additionally, the report recognizes the obstacles families encounter due to environmental factors and underlines the necessity of support from schools, healthcare systems, and the broader community. Pediatricians are urged to collaborate with families in establishing healthy habits, tackling social health determinants, and delivering empathetic care to children experiencing discrimination, bullying, or societal pressures.

title: RSV: When It's More Than Just a Cold
summary: Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) affects nearly all children by the age of 2, often appearing as a common cold but can severely affect infants, leading to hospitalization. RSV is spread through infected saliva, mucus, or nasal discharge, mainly from late fall to early spring. It is the primary reason for hospitalization in children under one year, with 2-3% of infected infants needing hospital care for breathing support or hydration. New preventative measures include RSV immunization during pregnancy and post-birth immunization for babies and some toddlers. The maternal RSV vaccine, given between 32 to 36 weeks of pregnancy, can lower the risk of infant hospitalization by 57% in the first six months. Nirsevimab, an injectable immunization for infants, can reduce the risk of RSV-related hospitalizations and healthcare visits by about 80%. Symptoms of RSV vary from mild cold-like symptoms to more severe respiratory problems such as bronchiolitis or pneumonia. Treatment is focused on supportive care, as there is no specific cure. Preventative strategies include keeping up to date on vaccinations, reducing exposure to sick individuals, and maintaining good hygiene.

title: Study results confirm Black women with lupus need more monitoring of cervical health
summary: A study by Wayne State University School of Medicine reveals that Black women with lupus require increased monitoring for cervical health due to a higher risk of HPV infection and cervical cancer. Led by Dr. J. Patricia Dhar, the research found that a self-administered method for collecting cervical cells is a more efficient, patient-friendly alternative to traditional Pap smears. The study, involving 30 Black women with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in Detroit, showed a 70% HPV infection rate among participants, with many showing multiple HPV types and a higher frequency of abnormal pre-cancerous Pap smears. The findings underscore the need for enhanced awareness, education, and access to cervical health testing for this high-risk group. The research aims to improve cervical health monitoring and HPV vaccination among Black women with SLE, highlighting the socio-economic and healthcare challenges they face.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA WISCONSIN CHAPTER INC
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides support, resources, and education to those affected by lupus nationwide via its chapters, offices, and support groups. It seeks to raise awareness, offer support services and educational programs, advocate for lupus patients, and fund research and education to enhance life quality for those affected by the disease. Support groups, both virtual and physical, create a safe space for lupus patients and their caregivers to exchange experiences, discover local resources, and get referrals for diagnosis and treatment. The Foundation also promotes participation through donations, fundraising, advocacy, and volunteering, aiming to unravel the "cruel mystery" of lupus.

title: LUPKYNIS Will Continue to Be Refined for Improved Lupus Nephritis Treatment
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA WISCONSIN CHAPTER INC
summary: Aurinia Pharmaceuticals, Inc. has announced that its medication, LUPKYNIS® (voclosporin), intended for the treatment of lupus nephritis (LN), is poised for advancements in its application. The United States Patent and Trademark Office has initiated a method-of-use patent application titled, “Improved Protocol for the Treatment of Lupus Nephritis.” This development opens avenues for new and refined methods of administering the therapy to individuals with active LN, in conjunction with other treatments. LUPKYNIS, which was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 2021, stands as the first FDA-approved oral medication for adults with active LN, a condition that affects up to 60% of people with lupus. This progress marks a significant step forward in the treatment of LN, offering hope for improved patient outcomes.

title: Dr. Daniel Geynisman Named New Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN--Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Daniel Geynisman has been appointed the new Editor-in-Chief of JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. With a distinguished background in medical oncology, particularly in genitourinary oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center, Dr. Geynisman brings extensive experience to the role, including serving on NCCN Guidelines Panels and contributing to over 130 peer-reviewed publications. His appointment is expected to drive further advancements in oncology research and practice guidelines, leveraging his deep expertise and history of collaboration with NCCN. The journal, known for its significant impact on cancer care through high-quality research and updates on clinical practice guidelines, anticipates new growth and continued excellence under Dr. Geynisman's leadership.

title: Fox Chase's Dr. Daniel Geynisman Named Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer ...
summary: Dr. Daniel Geynisman, Chief of Genitourinary Medical Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center, has been appointed Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. Geynisman, also an Associate Professor in Hematology/Oncology, is honored by the role, aiming to further the journal's impact on oncology research. JNCCN focuses on improving cancer care and publishes research on outcomes, quality improvement, and policy, alongside the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology. With an impact factor of 13.4, JNCCN is a top resource in cancer care delivery. Geynisman's previous roles include medical oncology section editor for Urologic Oncology and author of over 130 peer-reviewed publications. He has contributed significantly to NCCN, serving on guideline panels and receiving NCCN research grants. Geynisman completed his medical degree and residency at the University of Pittsburgh, followed by a hematology/oncology fellowship at the University of Chicago, where he also served as chief fellow. His first issue as Editor-in-Chief will be published in June.

title: NCCN Policy Summit encourages conversation and action on sexual health and fertility issues faced by people with ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) hosted an oncology policy summit focusing on the impact of sexual and reproductive health on cancer patients. The event, led by experts, aimed to address knowledge gaps, societal stigma, and the effects of changing policies on patients' quality of life. Discussions covered a range of topics, including gender and sex, intimacy, fertility, reproductive health, and treatment side-effects. The summit emphasized the importance of including sexual and reproductive health in cancer care and training for oncologists. It highlighted the challenges patients face, such as early menopause and infertility, and the need for open conversations and accessible information. The event also touched on the disparities in access to fertility preservation and the complexities of navigating state laws and regulations affecting cancer care. The NCCN aims to improve patient care by advocating for comprehensive, inclusive, and equitable treatment approaches.

title: ArteraAI Prostate Test included in NCCN guidelines
summary: The ArteraAI Prostate Test has been included in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Clinical Practice Guidelines for Prostate Cancer, marking it as the first AI-enabled predictive and prognostic test recommended for localized prostate cancer. This inclusion signifies a major advancement in integrating AI solutions into clinical settings to improve personalized patient care. The test, developed by ArteraAI, utilizes a combination of patient digital images from biopsies and clinical data to predict the benefit of prostate cancer therapy and forecast long-term outcomes. It has received a Level IB evidence rating and a Category 2A recommendation from the NCCN, indicating a uniform consensus on its utility in prostate cancer treatment. Additionally, the test has been shown to be superior in predicting biochemical recurrence, distant metastasis, prostate cancer-specific mortality, and overall survival compared to traditional NCCN risk groups. This development follows ArteraAI's recent announcements about Medicare coverage and $20 million in funding to support the test's international and commercial expansion.

title: National Comprehensive Cancer Network Awards Champions for Excellence and Outstanding Contributions in Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has announced its 2024 award recipients, honoring individuals and groups for their significant contributions to cancer care. Dr. Shaji Kumar, Darcie Green, and the NCCN COVID-19 Vaccine Advisory Committee were recognized for their efforts in improving cancer care and supporting NCCN's mission to help all people with cancer live better lives. The awards highlighted their leadership, commitment, and dedication in various capacities, from providing guidance on COVID-19 vaccinations for cancer patients to advocating for healthcare equity and expanding cancer treatment guidelines. Donna Black was named NCCN Employee of the Year for her role in supporting the NCCN Guidelines Program. The awards were presented during the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference in Orlando, Florida.

title: GOSERELIN INCLUDED IN THE NATIONAL COMPREHENSIVE CANCER NETWORK® (NCCN) HEAD AND NECK ...
summary: Goserelin has been included in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network® (NCCN) Guidelines for Head and Neck Cancers as a category 2B recommendation for specific cases of recurrent, unresectable, or metastatic salivary gland tumors where surgery or radiation therapy is not an option. This inclusion by TerSera Therapeutics LLC is based on the outcomes of two Phase 2 clinical studies and a retrospective analysis evaluating goserelin in combination with antiandrogens or immunotherapy. Although goserelin, marketed as ZOLADEX®, has shown clinically meaningful activity and a well-tolerated safety profile in these studies, it is important to note that it has not been approved by the U.S. FDA for this specific use in patients with salivary gland carcinoma. The recommendation highlights goserelin as a potential treatment option, reflecting its investigational use and the need for further validation of its safety and efficacy for this indication.

title: New Resource for Selecting Best Treatment Path for Young Children with Cancerous Tumors Published by NCCN
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has released its initial guidelines for treating neuroblastoma, a prevalent solid tumor cancer in kids, typically found before age five. Annually, the U.S. sees over 700 cases, posing challenges due to its varied biological and clinical nature. These guidelines aim to help doctors by providing crucial risk categorization details and summarizing existing treatment methods. Part of NCCN's wider efforts to cover almost all cancer types, these guidelines seek to better the prognosis for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma and reduce the long-term effects of treatments. They create a forum for exchanging treatment plans, include comprehensive care, and are updated frequently to mirror new research and clinical trials. Available for free on the NCCN website and app, they highlight NCCN's dedication to improving and making cancer care more accessible.

title: Resource-Appropriate Cancer Care, Including Coexisting Health Issues of HIV and Cancer, to be Addressed During ...
summary: Local and global experts are meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, from May 1-3, 2024, to update clinical practice guidelines for cancer care in Sub-Saharan Africa, with a focus on treating cancer in individuals with HIV. This effort is part of the ongoing work by Allied Against Cancer, a collaboration between the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), African Cancer Coalition (ACC), American Cancer Society (ACS), and Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI). The NCCN Harmonized Guidelines™ for Sub-Saharan Africa aim to improve cancer treatment outcomes by providing evidence-based, expert consensus recommendations tailored to the region's specific needs, including addressing the high prevalence of HIV/AIDS. The guidelines, available free-of-charge, cover various cancers and include updates on prevention and supportive care. They are endorsed by Federal Ministries of Health and leading cancer centers across Sub-Saharan Africa, representing 44% of the population. This initiative reflects a commitment to advancing cancer care and reducing global disparities in access and outcomes.

title: NCCN Expands Focus on Quality of Life and Supportive Care with New Guides for People with Cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has introduced new resources aimed at enhancing the quality of life for cancer patients by focusing on individual care needs and priorities. These resources include the NCCN Guidelines for Patients: Palliative Care, Fatigue and Cancer, and an updated guide on managing Distress During Cancer Care. Funded by the NCCN Foundation, these guides are freely available at NCCN.org/patientguidelines or through the NCCN Patient Guides for Cancer App. They are designed to support patients and their caregivers by providing evidence-based, expert consensus treatment information in an accessible format. The guidelines encourage conversations about the emotional, social, and spiritual needs of cancer patients, aiming to improve overall care and wellbeing. This initiative is part of NCCN's commitment to improving and facilitating quality, effective, equitable, and accessible cancer care.

title: Olverembatinib Included in Newest Guidelines on Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) Management from the National ...
summary: Olverembatinib has been included in the latest National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) management, marking significant recognition for Ascentage Pharma's drug candidate. Approved in China for tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI)-resistant CML patients, olverembatinib shows promise based on Phase I and II trial results, demonstrating high efficacy and manageable side effects. It has shown effectiveness in TKI-pretreated CML, including those with the T315I mutation, offering a meaningful treatment option for challenging cases. Olverembatinib's inclusion in the NCCN guidelines underscores its potential as a valuable CML treatment, reflecting its global clinical impact and the ongoing commitment to addressing unmet needs in cancer therapy.

title: NCCN Foundation Announces Recipients for 2024 Young Investigator Awards Honoring Future Leaders of Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) and the NCCN Foundation have announced the recipients of the 2024 Young Investigator Awards (YIA), recognizing five early-career oncology researchers from NCCN Member Institutions for their potential contributions to cancer treatment. Each awardee will receive up to $150,000 over two years for their research projects, which range from exploring treatment-resistant osteosarcoma and pancreatic cancer to utilizing deep learning for analyzing primary CNS lymphoma on brain MRI, conducting a Phase 2 trial in melanoma treatment, and investigating cognitive remediation for cancer-related cognitive impairment. These awards aim to support and advance the careers of promising cancer researchers, with the results of their studies to be presented at a future NCCN Annual Conference. The funding for these awards is provided by the NCCN Foundation, with additional support from various sponsors. Since 2011, the YIA program has awarded over $11.1 million to 75 researchers.

title: New Findings in JNCCN Illustrate Pathway for Screening High-Risk Individuals for Pancreatic Cancer in PRECEDE Study
summary: The April 2024 issue of JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network presented research from the Pancreatic Cancer Early Detection (PRECEDE) Consortium, emphasizing the potential for improved early detection and prevention of pancreatic cancer. With global incidences of pancreatic cancer on the rise and a current survival rate of only 12%, early detection is crucial. The study revealed that nearly 80% of the 1,759 high-risk individuals completed baseline imaging, showing the feasibility of screening programs. The research also highlighted a higher incidence of pancreatic cysts in individuals at high risk due to family history compared to those with a known genetic predisposition but no family history, suggesting different risks for developing pancreatic cancer. This study underscores the importance of further research to refine screening strategies for high-risk groups, aiming to enhance early detection and improve survival rates for pancreatic cancer patients.

title: NCCN Updates Treatment Recommendations for Breast, Colorectal, Lung, and other Cancer Types Based on ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has announced updates to its Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology for various high-incidence cancer types, including breast, colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers. These updates, based on the latest evidence and expert consensus, aim to keep cancer care providers worldwide informed on the latest innovations in treatment. The NCCN guidelines, which were accessed over 15 million times in 2023, are a crucial resource for oncology practices. The recent updates will be presented at the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference from April 5-7 in Orlando, Florida, and online. These updates include new treatment options for specific cancer types, such as HR-positive early-stage breast cancer, colon and rectal cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, and metastatic pancreatic cancer. Additionally, the conference will cover various topics, including genetics, vaccination for cancer survivors, and artificial intelligence in oncology. The NCCN is a not-for-profit alliance of leading cancer centers focused on patient care, research, and education, striving to improve and facilitate quality, effective, equitable, and accessible cancer care.

title: NCCN Announces Funding for Advanced Prostate Cancer Research Projects
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has announced funding for research projects focusing on advanced prostate cancer. These projects aim to explore the effectiveness of combination therapies that include relugolix, a medication approved for treating advanced prostate cancer. The funding, supported by Pfizer Global Medical Grants and Sumitomo Pharma America, Inc., will aid in developing innovative research to improve care for patients with this condition. The selected research projects are led by investigators from prestigious institutions and are expected to advance scientific knowledge in treating advanced prostate cancer with relugolix-based combination therapies. Approximately $3.5 million will be allocated across all grants, with the projects slated for completion within five years. This initiative underscores NCCN's commitment to fostering innovation and improving patient outcomes in cancer care.

title: Graduation 2024: Congratulations to School of Medicine Graduates!
summary: On May 13, 2024, Duke University School of Medicine celebrated the graduation of 433 students who received degrees in various programs including Health Professions Education Programs and Biomedical Graduate PhD Programs. The ceremony marked the completion of their rigorous education and training. Degrees awarded included Medical Doctor, Doctor of Physical Therapy, Master of Biomedical Sciences, Master of Health Science in Clinical Research, Master of Science in Medical Physics, Master of Science in Population Health Science, Master of Biostatistics, Occupational Therapy Doctorate, and various PhDs in fields like Biochemistry, Biostatistics, Cell Biology, and more. This event also highlighted the inaugural commencement for the Occupational Therapy Doctorate graduates, celebrating their achievement and the program's milestone.

title: Crain's 2023 Health Care Equity event
summary: Crain's Chicago Business hosted its annual Health Care Equity event on September 21, 2023, focusing on equity in health care. The event featured a panel discussion led by Crain's reporter Katherine Davis, with four industry experts: Dr. Ngozi Ezike, president and CEO of Sinai Chicago; Cristy Garcia Thomas, president of Advocate National Center for Health Equity and chief DEI officer at Advocate Health; Ayesha Jaco, executive director of West Side United; and Esther Sciammarella, executive director of the Chicago Hispanic Health Coalition. The discussion aimed to address and explore solutions for health care equity challenges.

title: OJEMDA™ (tovorafenib) Now Available from Onco360 for the Treatment of Patients Six Months of Age and Older with ...
summary: OJEMDA™ (tovorafenib) is now available from Onco360 for patients six months of age and older with relapsed or refractory pediatric low-grade glioma (LGG) that have a BRAF fusion or rearrangement, or BRAF V600 mutation. This FDA approval is under accelerated approval based on response rate and duration of response, with continued approval possibly contingent on further trials. Onco360 has partnered with Day One Biopharmaceuticals to distribute this medication, marking it as the first and only FDA-approved, once-weekly oral treatment for pediatric LGG in children over six months with specific BRAF gene abnormalities. Pediatric LGG represents about 30% of pediatric brain tumors, with up to 75% of these patients having BRAF alterations. The FDA's approval of OJEMDA is based on the FIREFLY-1 clinical trial, which showed a 51% overall response rate in patients. Common side effects include rash, hair color changes, and fatigue among others. Onco360, an independent Oncology Pharmacy, is distributing OJEMDA nationally.

title: Onco360® Celebrates Excellent Patient Care, Reflected by Impressive Net Promoter Score
summary: Onco360®, a leading independent specialty oncology pharmacy in the United States, is celebrating its exceptional patient care services, as evidenced by its impressive Net Promoter Score (NPS) of 94, an 11-point increase from the industry average of 74. The company's Chief Commercial Officer, Benito Fernandez, highlighted Onco360®'s commitment to enhancing the lives of cancer patients through personalized services and specialized teams. The high NPS reflects the trust and satisfaction patients and their families have in Onco360® as their pharmacy provider. Patients have expressed satisfaction with the pharmacy's services, including the timely filling and refilling of prescriptions. Onco360® aims to continue innovating its services to meet patient needs, offering comprehensive support including financial assistance, clinical counseling, insurance verification, and digital support. Onco360® is part of PharMerica Corporation and dispenses nationally through its URAC- and ACHC-accredited pharmacies.

title: FRUZAQLA™ (fruquintinib) Now Available from Onco360 for the Treatment of Adult Patients with Metastatic Colorectal ...
summary: Onco360, a leading independent Specialty Pharmacy, has been selected by Takeda as a pharmacy partner for Fruzaqla™ (fruquintinib), an oral targeted therapy for adults with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) who have previously undergone specific chemotherapies and treatments. Fruzaqla™ is the first and only U.S. approved selective inhibitor of all three VEGF receptor kinases for mCRC, aiming at tumor angiogenesis. This endorsement comes from the positive results of two Phase 3 trials, FRESCO and FRESCO-2, proving its effectiveness and safety. Onco360 is dedicated to enhancing the lives of cancer patients and their caregivers by incorporating Fruzaqla™ into its oncology product lineup. Colorectal cancer is a major cause of cancer mortality in the U.S., with an estimated 153,020 new cases in 2023, and about 70% of CRC patients developing metastatic disease.

title: Onco360 Has Been Selected as the Sole National Specialty Pharmacy Partner for Voydeya® (danicopan)
summary: Onco360, a leading independent Specialty Pharmacy in the United States, has been chosen as the exclusive national specialty pharmacy partner for Voydeya® (danicopan) by Alexion Pharmaceuticals. Voydeya® is an FDA-approved oral, Factor D inhibitor designed for the treatment of adults with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) in combination with C5 inhibitors, Ultomiris® (Ravulizumab) or Soliris® (Eculizumab), specifically for those experiencing clinically significant extravascular hemolysis (EVH). This partnership underscores Onco360's commitment to providing innovative treatment options for PNH patients. Onco360, headquartered in Louisville, Kentucky, is part of PharMerica Corporation and operates nationally through its network of accredited Oncology Pharmacies.

title: Maryland Tech Council Announces 2024 ICON Award Finalists
summary: The Maryland Tech Council (MTC) has announced the finalists for its 2024 ICON Awards, recognizing excellence in the state's technology and life sciences sectors. Winners will be revealed on May 23, 2024, during an event at the Bethesda North Marriott Hotel & Conference Center. This year, a new award named after Pava LaPere, the late Founder and CEO of EcoMap Technologies, will be introduced to honor significant contributions to Maryland's tech and life sciences communities. Finalists include companies across various categories such as Technology Company of the Year, Life Sciences Company of the Year, and Government Contracting Company of the Year, among others. The awards celebrate individuals and companies that have made impactful developments in treatments, systems, and education, affecting millions globally. The Maryland Tech Council aims to position Maryland as the leading innovation economy in technology and life sciences in the U.S.

title: How Carle Health helps develop Unstoppable nurses | Carle.org
summary: Carle Health actively supports the development of nurses at all career stages, offering opportunities for growth and excellence in care. Through their Nurse Residency Program and the Professional Nurse Advancement Program (PNAP), Carle Health empowers new and experienced nurses alike to enhance their skills and advance their careers. The programs are designed to boost confidence, refresh clinical skills, and enable nurses to provide top-notch patient care. Olivia Herges, a recent nursing graduate, exemplifies the drive and dedication Carle Health fosters in its nurses, having quickly applied her learning to real-life emergency care. Teresa K. Novy, DNP, represents the pinnacle of nursing achievement within Carle Health, being the first to reach Level VI in the PNAP, showcasing the system's commitment to professional growth and excellence in nursing. Carle Health celebrates its nursing staff, nearly 5,000 strong, for their unwavering commitment to patient care, highlighting the organization's dedication to training and education that leads to better patient outcomes.

title: New AI tool for sepsis diagnosis gets its start thanks to research at Carle | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has led the creation of a new AI tool, the Sepsis ImmunoScore, designed to detect sepsis early by examining deep biological and extensive clinical data to find patterns in human biological reactions. This breakthrough, which has recently been approved for marketing by the FDA, was developed by Bobby Reddy Jr. and Rashid Bashir of Prenosis, together with Roche Diagnostics, to improve sepsis detection and treatment nationwide. The more patient data the tool analyzes, the better it performs, encouraging early action and potentially saving lives by preventing organ damage and septic shock. Carle's significant contribution to the research and development of this tool highlights its dedication to improving healthcare through new technologies and collaborations.

title: Carle Foundation Hospital opens new pharmacy
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital in Urbana has launched a new pharmacy, CarleRx, located within the hospital premises. This addition aims to provide convenient access to pharmacy services and healthcare for both patients and Carle Health team members. The opening was celebrated with a ribbon-cutting ceremony. CarleRx will operate Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., and on weekends from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., with a half-hour break from 1 to 1:30 p.m. This pharmacy is an extension of CarleRx's services, following the model of their first location at Carle Champaign on Curtis. The service is designed to offer additional support to patients and enhance healthcare access in the region. For more information or to contact CarleRx, individuals can call 217-326-5500 or visit Carle.org.

title: New hospital safety report gives Carle Foundation a ‘C’ and OSF Heart of Mary a ‘B’
summary: The Leapfrog Group released its Fall 2023 Hospital Safety Grades, evaluating nearly 3,000 U.S. hospitals on patient safety and care quality. OSF HealthCare Heart of Mary Medical Center in Urbana received a 'B' grade, while Carle Foundation Hospital, also in Urbana, received a 'C'. The evaluation considers up to 30 metrics, including preventable errors and infections. OSF participated in the survey, but Carle did not, opting to be rated using alternative data sources. The report highlighted strengths and areas for improvement for both hospitals, with OSF scoring high for computerized medication orders and ICU care but low in handwashing. Carle performed well in preventing blood infections but had shortcomings in handwashing, death from treatable complications, and ICU care. Carle’s lower grade this year was attributed to its decision not to participate in the survey, emphasizing that this does not reflect a reduction in care quality. Leapfrog aims to enhance hospital transparency and patient safety, encouraging consumers to consider these grades when choosing a hospital.

title: The newest CarleRx Pharmacy opens at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: The newest CarleRx Pharmacy has officially opened at Carle Foundation Hospital, expanding access to pharmacy resources and enhancing the holistic healthcare experience for patients. Linda Fred, Vice President of Pharmacy Services, highlighted the importance of this addition during the ribbon-cutting ceremony. This new location is designed to provide convenient access for patients to pick up prescriptions on-site and seek assistance with their medication queries. Staffed with pharmacists and pharmacy technicians, it aims to meet the anticipated demand and address recent challenges in accessing retail pharmacy support. The opening hours are Monday through Friday, 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., and Saturday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., with a brief closure from 1 p.m. to 1:30 p.m. This pharmacy, along with the full-service CarleRx location at Carle Champaign on Curtis, demonstrates Carle's commitment to serving community needs at every point of their healthcare journey.

title: Latest Carle Health Way to Be! winners show heart, hard work and dedication to patients | Carle.org
summary: The latest Carle Health "Way to Be!" awards have been announced, celebrating team members who have demonstrated exceptional dedication, hard work, and commitment to patient care. These awards, part of a peer-to-peer recognition program, highlight individuals who embody Carle Health's core values of Excellence, Integrity, Inclusivity, Compassion, and Accountability. Winners this quarter include Kristin Williford for her proactive approach to a team member's health concern, Michelle Elam for her supportive and positive attitude, Marc Shoukry for going the extra mile in his courier duties, Vincent Chau for his compassionate service recovery efforts, Emily Elam for her initiative in improving patient wait times, and Michelle Dalton for her inclusivity in celebrating cultural diversity. These individuals, through their actions, reinforce the strong teamwork and patient-first culture at Carle Health.

title: World-class pediatric care recognized at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has been recognized as a Pediatric Critical Care Center by the state of Illinois, becoming one of only three such centers in downstate Illinois and one of 11 across the state. This recognition, part of the Illinois Pediatric Facility Recognition program, confirms the hospital's capability to adhere to specific evidence-based criteria for offering emergency, critical, and specialty care for children. It emphasizes the hospital's dedication to providing top-notch pediatric healthcare and serving as a safety net for the area's most at-risk patients. The pediatric intensive care unit (PICU), which started in June 2020, provides specialized treatment for critically ill children, including those who require complete respiratory support, intensive medications, and organ dysfunction management. The PICU, together with a wide range of pediatric services, highlights Carle Foundation Hospital's ongoing commitment to delivering advanced pediatric care to the community and the wider region.

title: Filipino nurses, culture at Carle Foundation Hospital marks 20 years with a celebration | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital celebrated the 20th anniversary of directly recruiting Filipino nurses from the Philippines, marking two decades of their significant contribution to the hospital and community. The celebration was designed to mimic a traditional barrio fiesta, complete with traditional Filipino dishes, showing appreciation for the cultural and professional impact these nurses have made. The event highlighted the long history of Filipino nurses in the U.S. and specifically honored the first group of nurses recruited by Carle, acknowledging their role in paving the way for future recruits. The celebration, attended by Carle co-workers, friends, and family, included speeches from Carle’s CEO and Chief Nursing Executive, as well as from the original Filipino nurses. The event underscored the integration of Filipino nurses into the Carle community, not just as employees but as a vital part of the hospital’s culture and excellence in healthcare. Carle Health continues to recruit nurses from the Philippines, emphasizing the ongoing importance of this relationship to the hospital's operations and community.

title: Future gift will transform interior spaces at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: Roger Laramee and his husband, Tim Bayley, have made a significant contribution to Carle Foundation Hospital through their estate plan, establishing the Roger Laramee/Tim Bayley Carle Foundation Hospital Healing Environment Fund. This endowment, the largest gift received by the Carle Health Center for Philanthropy in 2023, aims to transform the hospital's interior spaces to promote the physical, mental, and emotional well-being of patients, visitors, and healthcare team members. Laramee, with a long history in development and philanthropy, and Bayley, an interior designer passionate about the impact of design on health, were inspired to make a difference based on their life experiences and shared values. Their gift will fund renovations and improvements in patient and employee areas, reflecting their belief in the power of philanthropy to make lasting changes in the community.

title: Opportunities for innovation a focus of leading healthcare conference | Carle.org
summary: Foundation Day 2023, hosted by Carle Health, is a healthcare conference aimed at addressing modern health challenges through innovation and care, particularly in Central Illinois. Scheduled for November 2 at the I Hotel and Illinois Conference Center in Champaign, the event encourages idea-sharing, community connections, and continuing education for healthcare professionals. It features a diverse and inclusive array of presenters and attendees from various sectors of healthcare, emphasizing multidisciplinary collaboration. The conference, which has been an annual occurrence since 1956, is open to the public and offers a unique educational opportunity. This year's theme, "From Challenges to Connection: How Opportunities Become Innovation," focuses on transforming healthcare challenges into innovative solutions. More than 300 professionals are expected to attend the free event, supported by exhibitor contributions. Keynote addresses and breakout sessions will explore various topics, including political trends in healthcare, team leadership, patient advocacy, and cultivating an innovative mindset.

title: Carle Foundation Hospital Substance Use Navigators Provide a Bridge to Recovery | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has introduced Substance Use Navigators, a pilot program aimed at aiding individuals struggling with addiction. These navigators, who are Certified Peer Recovery Specialists, offer personal support and resources to patients who arrive at the Urbana Emergency Department following drug overdoses. The program, inspired by the California Bridge Model, emphasizes human connection and the use of non-stigmatizing language. Funded through a State Opioid Response grant, navigators advocate for patients, connect them to community resources, and work to reduce the stigma of substance use. They also assist with practical needs like housing paperwork and child custody cases. Since its inception in December 2022, the program has served over 400 individuals, helping to bridge the gap to recovery by providing links to various treatments and support systems. The navigators, who have personal or familial experience with addiction, undergo extensive training leading to certification by the Illinois Department of Public Health.

title: Nursing Excellence
summary: Carle Health is committed to excellence in nursing, focusing on the well-being of patients, families, and the community. Nurses at Carle Health are motivated to advance their careers through education and training, with support from a pre-paid tuition program and a Clinical Nursing Ladder program that acknowledges their professional achievements. There are also opportunities for leadership and involvement. Nurses at Carle Health are regarded as models of professional nursing, using their skills and empathy to make a difference every day. The organization is dedicated to providing the highest quality of patient care. Carle Health's hospitals, including the Carle Foundation Hospital and Carle BroMenn Medical Center, have received the Magnet® designation from the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), the most prestigious recognition for nursing excellence. This award underlines the positive and supportive work environment that leads to exceptional patient care and results. Carle Health offers various nursing roles within its integrated system, recognized as a Great Place to Work®, and encourages nurses to build long-term careers within the organization.

title: AirLife celebrates 20 years of partnership with Carle Health | Carle.org
summary: AirLife celebrated its 20th anniversary of partnership with Carle Health on October 7, marking two decades of providing critical care in the air for patients requiring transportation to higher levels of care. Operating as a flying emergency room, AirLife's helicopters are equipped with the latest patient care equipment, GPS, satellite tracking, and avionics, ensuring efficient and specialized service delivery. The highly trained flight crews, consisting of EMS pilots, critical care flight registered nurses, and critical care flight paramedics, handle a variety of severe illnesses and injuries across all age groups. They perform hundreds of missions annually across Illinois and Indiana, working closely with specialized NICU and Labor and Delivery Transport Teams to offer the highest quality of care. Throughout the pandemic, AirLife has continued to provide invaluable services to thousands of patients, also engaging in community educational and wellness events to promote safety. This milestone reflects AirLife's commitment to extending Carle Foundation Hospital's critical care services to the surrounding communities, emphasizing their readiness to serve patients whenever and wherever needed.

title: Carle Health celebrates Earth Day with sustainability stewardship initiatives across the system | Carle.org
summary: Carle Health is celebrating Earth Day by launching various sustainability initiatives to benefit the environment, its team, patients, and the communities it serves. These efforts are driven by the knowledge that the health of the environment is closely linked to the health of the population. A significant move towards this goal was the creation of the Sustainability and Environmental Stewardship Council by Carle Health's executive leadership. The council is responsible for creating programs, policies, and efforts to enhance sustainability. The Carle Health Center for Philanthropy has donated $1 million to support these efforts. Activities include improving energy and water efficiency, reducing waste and recycling, making environmentally friendly purchases, and supporting clean energy and sustainable transport. Notably, Carle Health Methodist Hospital is involved in a community solar project to promote renewable energy, and both Carle Foundation Hospital and Carle BroMenn Medical Center are starting food waste prevention and composting programs. These steps highlight Carle Health's dedication to being an environmentally responsible organization and to enhancing the health of both the community and the planet.

title: Ochsner+to+construct+new+children%E2%80%99s+hospital+in+New+Orleans+after+donation+from+Gayle+Benson
summary: Ochsner Health is set to build a new children's hospital in New Orleans, named The Gayle and Tom Benson Ochsner Children’s Hospital, following a significant donation from Gayle Benson. This 343,000-square-foot facility will be located next to Ochsner’s main campus on Jefferson Highway and aims to expand pediatric care in the region. The hospital will feature a children’s-only emergency department, enhanced critical care, operating rooms, imaging capacity, and a Level IV Surgical Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). The design focuses on creating a child-friendly and welcoming atmosphere with themed floors, natural sunlight, and family-friendly amenities. The project, reflecting Ochsner's commitment to pediatric care, is expected to break ground in mid-2024 and open by late 2027.

title: Positron Corporation Enters into Agreement with Ochsner Clinic Foundation for Clinical Study of its New “Affinity PET ...
summary: Positron Corporation has signed a Clinical Study/Research Agreement with Ochsner Clinic Foundation and Dr. Robert Bober for the clinical trial of its new PET-CT imaging device, the Affinity PET-CT 4D. The study has been approved by an independent Institutional Review Board (IRB), allowing Positron to proceed with an Investigational Device Exemption (IDE) to collect safety and efficacy data. This clinical trial is a step towards obtaining FDA Pre-Market Approval. Installation and phantom testing will precede patient scans, with the company aiming to complete the study and receive FDA Certification within 60 days. This study is crucial for the commercialization of the Affinity PET-CT 4D, demonstrating its capabilities in the cardiology and oncology segments of nuclear molecular imaging.

title: Official Rules: Pelicans 2024 Baby Crawl Race presented by Ochsner Hospital for Children
summary: The Pelicans 2024 Baby Crawl Race, sponsored by Ochsner Hospital for Children, is open to legal residents of the U.S. in Louisiana or within 150 miles of New Orleans, LA. Parents or guardians of infants aged 9-11 months can enter. Employees and relatives of the New Orleans Pelicans, NBA Entities, Ochsner, and affiliates cannot participate. The contest is from 2/28/2024 to 3/15/2024. Enter at Pelicans.com/BabyCrawlRace. Twenty contestants will be chosen for their enthusiasm, cuteness, and smile. They get game tickets, a onesie, and Crib Club membership, with a chance for their baby to race. The top prize includes toddler items and a trophy. Prizes are as-is, and the contest is void where prohibited. By entering, you agree to the use of your information and images for marketing and release the organizers from liability. The contest may change or be canceled.

title: Positron Corporation Announces Start of Clinical Study of Affinity PET-CT Device
summary: Positron Corporation has announced the commencement of a clinical study for its Affinity PET-CT imaging device, in collaboration with Ochsner Clinic Foundation in New Orleans, starting September 18, 2023. The study, led by Dr. Robert Bober, aims to gather crucial data on the device's performance and efficacy. This research is essential for FDA approval and the device's subsequent market launch. The study will initially involve phantom testing, followed by human patient imaging upon FDA authorization. Positron aims to submit its findings for FDA clearance to market the Affinity PET-CT, emphasizing its potential to enhance diagnostic analysis with new software applications and radiopharmaceuticals. This step is crucial for Positron’s strategy to penetrate the nuclear imaging market, offering a product that meets the needs of physicians, practices, and patients.

title: How Carle Health helps develop Unstoppable nurses | Carle.org
summary: Carle Health is dedicated to developing skilled and unstoppable nurses by providing opportunities for growth and excellence in nursing practice. The organization supports nurses at all stages of their careers, from new graduates to experienced practitioners seeking to advance their skills and professional standing. Carle Health's Nurse Residency Program in Urbana is nationally recognized for guiding nurses from education to practice, especially targeting nursing students in their final year or nurses returning to bedside care after a hiatus. The Professional Nurse Advancement Program (PNAP) allows nurses to climb the professional ladder by demonstrating their competence and professionalism, based on the American Nurses Association standards and the Carle Professional Nursing Practice Model. This model encourages continuous learning and growth, with the support of the nursing community within Carle Health. Nurses like Olivia Herges and Teresa K. Novy exemplify the dedication and resilience Carle fosters in its nursing staff, contributing to a culture of quality and excellence in patient care. Carle celebrates its nurses, recognizing their crucial role in healthcare and their commitment to providing the best possible care to patients.

title: New AI tool for sepsis diagnosis gets its start thanks to research at Carle | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has started developing a new AI tool for diagnosing sepsis, called Sepsis ImmunoScore, which has recently been approved by the FDA. This tool combines deep biological data with detailed clinical information using algorithms to detect patterns in how the body responds to infection, helping in the early detection and treatment of sepsis. The idea came from discussions between Bobby Reddy Jr., co-founder of Prenosis, and Carle staff, highlighting the need for an effective sepsis diagnosis and treatment solution. The development involved collecting blood samples and biophysical data from 2,000 patients, with Carle being instrumental in the initial data collection and testing. This partnership has resulted in a significant biobank and dataset, enhancing the tool's ability to predict sepsis and support early intervention. Carle continues to work with Prenosis in further clinical studies to improve the tool's effectiveness in clinical settings, showing Carle's dedication to research and enhancing healthcare quality with innovative solutions.

title: Carle Foundation Hospital opens new pharmacy
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital in Urbana has launched its own pharmacy, CarleRx, located within the hospital premises to ensure convenient access to pharmacy services for both patients and Carle Health team members. The opening was celebrated with a ribbon-cutting ceremony. This new facility is an extension of CarleRx's services, following the model of their first location at Carle Champaign on Curtis. The pharmacy operates Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., and on weekends from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., with a brief closure from 1 to 1:30 p.m. For more information, CarleRx can be contacted at 217-326-5500 or through Carle.org.

title: Med School Minute January 2024 | Carle Illinois College of Medicine | UIUC
summary: The Carle Illinois College of Medicine's January 2024 Med School Minute highlights key developments and initiatives. Dean Mark Cohen and Senior Associate Dean Janet Jokela shared their insights on the future of medicine and medical education. The Outstanding Staff Award is being reintroduced to recognize exceptional commitment to the college's mission and values. Academic updates include new appointments in educational assessment and curricular operations. Research achievements feature Al Smith's Kinematic Navigation prototype for neurosurgery, and student teams excelling in health innovation competitions. The college is preparing for several events, including the Health Innovation Research Day and Capstone Presentation Day. New faculty mentorship programs and research in extended reality applications in primary care are underway. Student and faculty achievements are celebrated, including national leadership roles and awards. Diversity initiatives focus on Black History Month and health equity. Upcoming faculty development events aim to foster inclusivity and innovation. The college also emphasizes community outreach and wellness initiatives.

title: New hospital safety report gives Carle Foundation a ‘C’ and OSF Heart of Mary a ‘B’
summary: The Leapfrog Group's Fall 2023 Hospital Safety Grades report awarded OSF HealthCare Heart of Mary Medical Center in Urbana a 'B' grade and Carle Foundation Hospital in Urbana a 'C' grade. The grading system evaluates patient safety and care quality across nearly 3,000 U.S. hospitals using up to 30 metrics, including preventable errors and infections. OSF participated in the survey, whereas Carle did not, leading to its evaluation using alternative data sources. The report highlighted OSF Heart of Mary's strengths in medication ordering and ICU patient care but noted a need for improvement in handwashing practices. Conversely, Carle Foundation Hospital was recognized for its infection prevention efforts but was marked down for handwashing, death from treatable complications, and ICU care. Leapfrog aims to enhance patient safety through transparency, encouraging hospitals to participate in their surveys or be evaluated by publicly available data.

title: The newest CarleRx Pharmacy opens at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: A new CarleRx pharmacy has officially opened at Carle Foundation Hospital, enhancing the hospital's healthcare services by providing patients and Carle Health team members with convenient access to pharmacy resources. Spearheaded by Linda Fred, Vice President of Pharmacy Services, the opening was celebrated with a ribbon-cutting ceremony. This locally-owned pharmacy, modeled after the original CarleRx at Carle Champaign on Curtis, aims to offer comprehensive support for patients, including assistance with prescription inquiries. The addition of this pharmacy is part of Carle's commitment to addressing recent challenges in accessing retail pharmacy support and improving patient care throughout their healthcare journey. The pharmacy operates Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., and weekends from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., with a half-hour closure between 1 p.m. and 1:30 p.m. Another CarleRx location at Carle Champaign on Curtis offers extended hours and drive-thru service.

title: Latest Carle Health Way to Be! winners show heart, hard work and dedication to patients | Carle.org
summary: The latest Carle Health Way to Be! winners exemplify heart, hard work, and dedication to patients. This peer-to-peer program honors employees who embody the organization's values of Excellence, Integrity, Inclusivity, Compassion, and Accountability. Winners include Kristin Williford, for addressing a health and safety concern; Michelle Elam, for assisting a colleague with a project; Marc Shoukry, for delivering crucial medical supplies; Vincent Chau, for his compassionate service recovery; Emily Elam, for improving patient wait times; and Michelle Dalton, for celebrating cultural diversity. These individuals highlight the strong teamwork and exceptional talent within Carle Health, contributing to a culture that prioritizes patient care.

title: World-class pediatric care recognized at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has been named a Pediatric Critical Care Center by the state of Illinois, highlighting its status as one of only three such centers in downstate Illinois and one of 11 across the state. This recognition, part of the Illinois Pediatric Facility Recognition program, celebrates the hospital's dedication to offering emergency, critical, and specialty care for children. It reflects the hospital staff and leadership's commitment and effort in achieving strict quality standards. Carle Foundation Hospital offers pediatric services including a pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) that began operating in June 2020, delivering specialized care for the area's most seriously ill children. This acknowledgment reinforces Carle Health's ongoing commitment to the community and its goal to provide a superior level of pediatric care in east central Illinois.

title: Filipino nurses, culture at Carle Foundation Hospital marks 20 years with a celebration | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital celebrated 20 years of Filipino nurses' contributions to its community and work culture. Two decades ago, Carle began actively recruiting nurses from the Philippines, a practice that has significantly impacted the hospital's staff composition and cultural diversity. The celebration, designed to mimic a traditional Filipino barrio fiesta, featured authentic dishes, speeches from hospital executives, and recognition of the first group of Filipino nurses recruited. These nurses, Annabelle Maylas, Vicente Piccio, Karen Yap, and Thelma Lamera, were honored for paving the way for future Filipino nurses at Carle. The event underscored the Filipino nurses' integral role in enhancing patient care quality and contributing to the hospital's culture. Carle Health continues to recruit Filipino nurses, awaiting new arrivals pending U.S. visa approvals, highlighting the ongoing importance of international nurses to the institution.

title: Future gift will transform interior spaces at Carle Foundation Hospital | Carle.org
summary: Roger Laramee and Tim Bayley have decided to leave a significant estate gift to Carle Foundation Hospital, aimed at transforming the hospital's interior spaces to better support patient healing through design. This donation, the largest received by the Carle Health Center for Philanthropy in 2023, will establish the Roger Laramee/Tim Bayley Carle Foundation Hospital Healing Environment Fund. It is an endowment meant to enhance both patient and employee environments, focusing on mental health and emotional well-being alongside physical healing. The fund reflects the couple's shared commitment to philanthropy and their belief in the impact of thoughtful design on health outcomes. This initiative is particularly influenced by Tim's background in interior design and a personal tragedy that underscored for him the profound effect of one's surroundings on their mental state. The gift aims to create spaces that offer comfort and tranquility to patients and their families during difficult times, fulfilling Laramee and Bayley's desire to leave a lasting legacy that contributes to the community's well-being.

title: Opportunities for innovation a focus of leading healthcare conference | Carle.org
summary: Carle Health is hosting Foundation Day 2023, a healthcare conference focused on innovation, on November 2nd at the I Hotel and Illinois Conference Center in Champaign, Illinois. First held in 1956, this annual event aims to address contemporary health challenges through idea-sharing, community connections, and continuing education. The conference, which is open to the public and particularly targets healthcare professionals from Central Illinois, features a diverse range of participants, including those from clinical, insurance, research, business, and personal healthcare sectors. This year's theme, "From Challenges to Connection: How Opportunities Become Innovation," encourages viewing challenges as opportunities for innovation. The conference will include three keynote addresses and nine breakout sessions on various topics, including patient advocacy, the business of medicine, and diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). More than 300 healthcare professionals are expected to attend the free event, supported by exhibitors. Virtual attendance is available for keynote addresses, with a registration deadline of October 30.

title: Carle Foundation Hospital Substance Use Navigators Provide a Bridge to Recovery | Carle.org
summary: Carle Foundation Hospital has introduced Substance Use Navigators, a pilot program aimed at supporting individuals with substance use disorders. These navigators, trained as Certified Peer Recovery Specialists, provide a personal connection to patients in the emergency department, offering resources, support, and guidance towards recovery. The program, inspired by the California Bridge Model, aims to bridge emergency care with community health services while reducing stigma and barriers to care. Funded through a State Opioid Response grant, navigators assist with various life aspects, including housing and legal issues. Since December 2022, the program has reached over 400 individuals, helping reduce repeated emergency visits for many. The navigators, who have personal or family experience with addiction, undergo extensive training to earn certification from the Illinois Department of Public Health. Their work is pivotal in changing lives by providing continuous support and connecting patients to necessary recovery resources.

title: Nursing Excellence
summary: Carle Health prioritizes nursing excellence, focusing decisions on patients, families, and the community, emphasizing compassion and safety for the best health results. It encourages nurse career development with pre-paid tuition assistance and a Clinical Nursing Ladder for professional growth. Carle Health provides leadership and participation chances for nurses to make significant contributions. Its 2022 Nursing Annual Report emphasizes these points. Carle Health nurses are considered the pinnacle of professional nursing, making meaningful contributions every day. Carle Foundation Hospital and other Carle Health hospitals have the Magnet® designation, the top national recognition for nursing care, supporting nearly 5,000 nurses in various environments. This setting fosters world-class patient care and positive outcomes. Carle Health is acknowledged as a Great Place to Work®, offering many opportunities for nurses in its integrated system, including hospitals, physician groups, and healthcare businesses.

title: AirLife celebrates 20 years of partnership with Carle Health | Carle.org
summary: AirLife celebrated its 20th anniversary of partnership with Carle Health on October 7, marking two decades of providing critical care in the air for patients in need. Operating as a flying emergency room, AirLife transports critically ill or injured patients to Carle Foundation Hospital and other facilities, offering specialized services and care during transport. The team, consisting of experienced EMS pilots, critical care flight registered nurses, and critical care flight paramedics, handles a variety of severe illnesses and injuries across all age groups. AirLife has completed hundreds of missions a year, serving thousands of patients in Illinois and Indiana, even continuing its operations throughout the pandemic. The service emphasizes a strong connection to the community, participating in educational and wellness events and sharing updates through their Facebook page. This milestone reflects AirLife's commitment to extending the scope and reach of Carle Health's critical care services to the surrounding communities.

title: Carle Health celebrates Earth Day with sustainability stewardship initiatives across the system | Carle.org
summary: Carle Health is celebrating Earth Day by launching various sustainability initiatives aimed at supporting environmental health, which is directly linked to population health. These initiatives, supported by a $1 million investment from the Carle Health Center for Philanthropy, are being developed by the newly created Sustainability and Environmental Stewardship Council. Efforts include improving energy and water efficiency, waste reduction, recycling, environmentally friendly purchasing, and promoting clean energy and sustainable transportation. Additionally, Carle Health is participating in the One Healthcare Ecochallenge to encourage sustainable actions among healthcare workers. Projects include a community solar development program and food waste prevention and composting pilot programs at Carle Foundation Hospital and Carle BroMenn Medical Center, respectively. These sustainability efforts aim to reduce environmental impact while improving community and global health.

title: Galveston area EMS provider leading area in administering pre-hospital antibiotics
summary: The Galveston County Health District Emergency Medical Service, in partnership with the University of Texas Medical Branch, has started a new method of giving antibiotics before reaching the hospital to patients with serious wounds like stabbings and broken bones that break the skin. This project, led by Katherine Horton and Nathan Jung, is designed to lower the chance of getting an infection by providing antibiotics ideally within 30 minutes to an hour before surgery, which could cut the risk of infection at the surgery site in half. This approach, which began in late February and early March, uses Ancef, an antibiotic that costs $3 per vial, making it affordable. It also aims to make hospitals more efficient by lightening the load on emergency room staff. This new method is rare in the country and almost unknown in the Galveston-Houston area, making Galveston EMS a possible pioneer in improving care before reaching the hospital.

title: Galveston health officials warn dangers of fake cosmetic injections after CDC alert
summary: Galveston health officials are urging caution following a CDC alert about the dangers of counterfeit or mishandled cosmetic injections, such as botulinum toxin, after a surge in botulism cases across multiple states, including Texas. Recent incidents in the Houston area involved arrests for illegal injections, highlighting the risks associated with receiving treatments from unlicensed or untrained individuals or in non-healthcare settings. Botulism, a potentially fatal illness caused by a toxin, can lead to paralysis and requires immediate medical attention. Symptoms include blurred vision, slurred speech, and muscle weakness. The CDC advises that botulinum toxin should only be administered by licensed professionals in proper healthcare settings to avoid these risks. Individuals are warned against counterfeit products and urged to seek information from reliable sources like the FDA and CDC websites.

title: Shellfish death: Galveston County officials warn residents of Vibrio vulnificus bacteria after man dies from eating raw oysters
summary: Galveston County officials are issuing warnings about the dangers of consuming raw or undercooked shellfish following the death of a man from a rare infection caused by Vibrio vulnificus bacteria. The man, aged between 30 to 40, had eaten raw oysters and had pre-existing health conditions that made him more susceptible to the infection, such as being immunosuppressed and having liver problems. Vibrio vulnificus is found in warm coastal waters and can infect people through raw or undercooked shellfish, especially oysters, or through an open wound. Infections have increased this year due to unusually warm ocean temperatures, but are generally rare and typically affect individuals with underlying health issues like liver disease, immunosuppression, or diabetes. Symptoms of the infection include diarrhea, stomach cramping, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, cellulitis, and blistering lesions. Health officials advise those at risk to avoid consuming raw shellfish and to seek medical advice if they experience any symptoms.

title: Several states issue West Nile virus alerts after detecting cases in residents
summary: Several states in the U.S. have issued West Nile virus alerts after detecting cases among residents, with some resulting in deaths. Georgia, Maryland, and Texas have reported their first infections of the year, and Kansas has classified nearly the entire state as high risk, experiencing 22 cases, including 17 neuroinvasive cases and three deaths. Health officials emphasize the importance of taking precautions against mosquito bites, such as using insect repellent and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. The West Nile virus, first identified in the Western Hemisphere in 1999, is the leading cause of mosquito-borne disease in the contiguous United States. While most infected individuals show no symptoms, about one in five may experience fever and other symptoms, and a small percentage may develop severe, potentially fatal, neurological diseases. There are no vaccines or specific treatments for West Nile virus, with care primarily supportive.

title: Galveston man dies from infection after eating oysters, health officials say
summary: A man from Galveston County, Texas, died from a Vibrio vulnificus infection after eating raw oysters. Health officials said the man, who was between 30 and 40 years old, had pre-existing health conditions that made him more vulnerable to the infection. Vibrio bacteria are naturally found in coastal waters and can cause infections in people who consume raw or undercooked shellfish or have open wounds that come into contact with salty or brackish water. The Galveston County Health District (GCHD) pointed out that such infections are rare but occur more frequently in individuals with certain health problems like liver disease, weakened immune systems, or diabetes. The GCHD also observed a nationwide increase in vibrio infections, linked to unusually high ocean temperatures, with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issuing a warning on September 1 about the spike in deadly infections. Symptoms of a Vibrio infection include diarrhea, stomach cramps, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, and skin rashes.

title: Young Breast Cancer Survivors Program | NCCCP
summary: In 2019, the CDC funded eight organizations for five years to support young breast cancer survivors (YBCS) and metastatic breast cancer (MBC) patients in the United States. Breast cancer is the most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer death among U.S. women, with 9% of cases in women under 45. The initiative aims to enhance survival and life quality for these patients through education, technological methods, and better service access, particularly for underrepresented groups. It prioritizes YBCS from communities heavily impacted by breast cancer, including those from diverse ethnic backgrounds, low socioeconomic status, disabilities, and MBC patients. The effort also includes developing networks for policy and environmental change, educating healthcare providers, and assessing the program's effectiveness and outcomes.

title: With wigs, eyebrows and nipple tattoos, this project helps cancer patients feel like women again
summary: The project Best Face Forward 2.0, run by Sharsheret, a Jewish breast and ovarian cancer organization, provides financial assistance for non-medical services to cancer patients. These services, which are not fully covered by health insurance, include hair preservation therapies, human-hair wigs, and tattooing for nipples and eyebrows, aimed at helping patients deal with mental health, body image, and self-image issues during and after cancer treatment. Since its inception in August 2019, the program has supported nearly 2,000 women, distributing close to $2 million, with an average assistance of $2,500 per patient. These efforts have significantly aided in improving the quality of life for these women, helping them feel like themselves again after the physical and emotional toll of cancer treatment. The program also connects women to other free services offered by Sharsheret, including genetic and mental health counseling, and has expanded to include emergency relief funds for critical needs.

title: Raising awareness for Black men’s health in Columbus
summary: Thousands gathered in Livingston Park, Columbus, for a walk and 5K event organized by the African American Male Wellness Agency (AAMWA) to raise awareness about the mental and physical health of Black men. Founded 20 years ago, AAMWA aims to build community and save lives. This event marks the start of a 15-city tour to promote Black men's health. Participants received health screenings, flu shots, and financial resources. The initiative also includes "Uplift Her," focusing on women's health, addressing higher risks of breast cancer and heart disease among women of color. The agency emphasizes the importance of regular health conversations and screenings. The next event is scheduled for August 19 in Cleveland, and a financial wellness summit will be held in Columbus on October 19.

title: 'Don't try to be macho': 1st annual 5K wellness walk to promote Black men's health at Texas Southern University
summary: The National African American Male Wellness Agency hosted its first annual 5K wellness walk at Texas Southern University to promote Black men's health. The event included wellness screenings for conditions like prostate cancer, blood pressure, and peripheral artery disease. Participants, including Mayor Sylvester Turner, emphasized the importance of prioritizing health and not ignoring bodily signals. Studies show African American men die 12 years earlier than their white counterparts due to socio-economic factors and limited healthcare access. Organizers highlighted the need to address preventable diseases to extend life expectancy among Black men.

title: Five University of Missouri faculty named 2023 AAAS Fellows // Show Me Mizzou // University of Missouri
hco: CURATORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI
summary: The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) has named five University of Missouri faculty members as 2023 Fellows for their distinguished contributions to various scientific fields. The honorees include Jianlin “Jack” Cheng for his work in bioinformatics and AI; Ron Mittler for his research on plant stress responses; Rajiv R. Mohan for his advancements in ophthalmology and molecular medicine; Timothy Trull for his studies in psychology and clinical science; and Christopher Wikle for his achievements in spatio-temporal statistics. These recognitions highlight the faculty's innovative research and collaborative efforts at the University of Missouri.

title: Marjorie Skubic named Curators' Distinguished Professor Emerita
hco: CURATORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI
summary: Marjorie Skubic has been named a Curators' Distinguished Professor Emerita by the University of Missouri System’s Board of Curators.
