Skubic, initially honored as a Curators' Distinguished Professor in 2021, directs the Center to Stream Healthcare in Place (C2SHIP), formerly the Mizzou Center for Eldercare and Rehabilitation Technology (CERT). Her work focuses on developing sensors and devices for home health monitoring, particularly for older adults, and she holds six patents with technologies now used in senior living facilities. Skubic joined the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science in 1997, after a career in industry. She has collaborated with various MU schools, including Medicine, Nursing, Health Professions, and Veterinary Medicine. Additionally, Mizzou Engineering’s Jianlin “Jack” Cheng, Zhiqiang Hu, and Xiu-Feng “Henry” Wan were also named Curators’ Distinguished Professors at the same Board meeting.

title: Claro Puerto Rico volunteers help out at Julia de Burgos women's shelter
summary: Claro Puerto Rico volunteers assisted the Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos shelter for domestic violence survivors by improving its facilities. More than 20 volunteers participated in tasks such as painting, cleaning, gardening, and organizing the food storage room. This effort was part of the lead-up to the "Kilómetros de Cambio" event, a race aimed at raising funds for local shelters supporting women victims of domestic violence. Enrique Ortiz de Montellano, CEO of Claro de Puerto Rico, emphasized the company's commitment to community support and positive societal impact. Lenna Ramírez-Cintrón, executive director of Casa Julia, highlighted the importance of such collaborations in combating domestic violence. The "Kilómetros de Cambio" race involves 28 runners in a relay format around the island over three days to raise awareness and promote action against domestic and gender violence.

title: Psicóloga de 27 años asume la dirección de la Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos
summary: Lenna Ramírez Cintrón, a 27-year-old psychologist, has taken on the role of executive director at Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos as of October 2023. The organization, active for over four decades, ensures the safety and well-being of women, especially those affected by gender-based violence. Ramírez Cintrón is committed to continuing this mission, emphasizing freedom and quality of life for women. The headquarters display symbols of their advocacy, including a green scarf and banners with messages like "my body, my decision" and "not one less," alongside portraits of founders, Mercedes Rodríguez and Mary Anne Maldonado.

title: Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos celebra su tradicional bazar navideño • WIPR
summary: Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos will hold its traditional Christmas Bazaar from December 1 to 3 at the Summit Hills Community Center in Río Piedras. This annual event supports survivors of domestic violence and their children, offering items such as clothing, jewelry, toys, and more in exchange for donations. Executive Director Lenna Marielys Ramírez Cintrón highlighted the organization's 44-year commitment to providing safe spaces and support. Marta Elsa Fernández, board president, explained that donations will help the first shelter for domestic violence survivors in Puerto Rico. The bazaar will be open on Friday from 5 PM to 9 PM, and on Saturday and Sunday from 9 AM to 5 PM. For more information, you can call (787) 374-8348 or (787) 723-3500. Additionally, donations can be made via ATH Móvil, PayPal, and BPPR.

title: Gracias por una nueva oportunidad de vida en Casa Julia
summary: Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos, celebrating 44 years, offers shelter to women and children escaping domestic violence. Led by Lenna Marielis Ramírez Cintrón, the organization provides a safe space during the holidays, alleviating the painful cycle of abuse. Casa Julia houses up to 16 women and their children in two facilities and offers legal, psychological, and housing services. In 2022, they helped 523 people. Additionally, they organize a Christmas bazaar in Summit Hills, San Juan, from December 1 to 3 to raise funds. The event includes the sale of books, clothing, and toys at low prices. Donations are accepted starting November 27.

title: Vivienda anuncia mejoras en la Casa Protegida Julia De Burgos • WIPR
summary: The Secretary of Housing, William Rodríguez Rodríguez, signed a $270,000 agreement with Casa Protegida Julia de Burgos to install solar panels and other equipment in the shelter for women and children at risk of domestic violence. Funded by the Social Interest Housing program under CDBG-DR recovery funds, the project will enhance energy efficiency, repair roofs, and paint the building. It also includes purchasing kitchen equipment to improve the shelter's functionality and sustainability. The initiative aims to create a safe, welcoming environment for families to rebuild their lives. The interim executive director of Casa Protegida, Lenna Marielys Ramírez Cintrón, emphasized the importance of these funds in transforming the shelter into a resilient space for survivors and staff, highlighting the essential service provided in saving lives and combating domestic violence. The program has a $37.5 million budget, covering 18 projects, including multifamily developments and repairs.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Participation in the Enhancing Oncology Model
summary: American Oncology Network (AON) announced its participation in the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM), a new value-based cancer care framework launched by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI). This initiative aims to improve health outcomes and reduce total costs of cancer care. AON will partner with Thyme Care to provide comprehensive cancer care support and navigation services to patients. The collaboration focuses on improving care quality, access, and cost through payment incentives, 24/7 patient-focused care navigation, and addressing health equity. Thyme Care will support AON's clinics with data-driven solutions and additional resources to enhance patient care and reduce barriers.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Expansion into Florida with New Community Oncology Practice Serving ...
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON) has expanded into Florida by opening a new community oncology practice, Florida Oncology & Hematology (FOH), in Safety Harbor. Led by Board-certified medical oncologist Dr. Jose Alemar, the practice is equipped with private exam rooms, an infusion room, on-site lab services, in-house pathology, a specialty pharmacy, and financial counseling. AON CEO Todd Schonherz emphasized the importance of accessible and affordable cancer care. Dr. Alemar, passionate about oncology since childhood, aims to serve the Pinellas County community. AON, founded in 2018, is a rapidly growing network dedicated to preserving community oncology and improving patient care.

title: Expert: The Growth of the 340B Drug Pricing Program Has Influenced the Landscape of Cancer Care
summary: The 340B Drug Pricing Program, established in 1992, aimed to provide discounted outpatient drugs to eligible healthcare organizations to aid low-income and uninsured patients. Initially slow-growing, the program expanded significantly after policy changes linked to Medicaid in 2010, reaching 2,500 hospitals by 2019. The program's expansion has affected community oncology practices, often disadvantaging them due to financial incentives favoring hospitals. Changes in Medicare payment policies in 2018 temporarily reduced these incentives, benefiting community oncology. However, proposed 2024 policies may reverse these changes. The program has also faced criticism for potentially contributing to drug shortages and not always passing discounts to patients. Concerns about transparency and the actual use of savings persist, with calls for accountability to ensure the program meets its intended goals.

title: American Oncology Network part of new altenative payment model
summary: American Oncology Network (AON) announced its participation in the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM), a value-based cancer care framework introduced by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation. Launched in July 2023, EOM aims to improve care quality, access, and cost efficiency through payment incentives, navigation services, and a focus on health equity. AON will collaborate with Thyme Care, a value-based oncology platform, to support its participation. Thyme Care will provide analytics, nurse navigation, and social services to help patients overcome barriers to care. AON's Chief Medical Officer, Stephen “Fred” Divers, M.D., emphasized the importance of this partnership in driving value-based cancer care and achieving better patient outcomes. Thyme Care's capabilities will enable AON to monitor performance and make data-driven decisions. The AON network, established in 2018, includes 106 physicians and 86 nurse practitioners and physician assistants across 19 states, focusing on community-based oncology management.

title: American Oncology Network Announces Texas as New Operating State with Launch of Community-Based Oncology ...
summary: The American Oncology Network (AON) has expanded into Texas with the opening of Lone Star Oncology (LSO) in Georgetown. The clinic, led by Dr. Brian Shimkus, is now accepting patients with various cancers and blood disorders. Dr. Shimkus brings over 20 years of experience and aims to provide high-quality, patient-centered care. AON, a national network of community-based oncology practices, supports local clinics to ensure accessible and affordable cancer care, reducing the need for patients to travel long distances. LSO will offer services including infusion therapy, pathology, oral cancer medications, and financial counseling.

title: American Oncology Network, a Rapidly Growing Network of Community-Based Oncology Practices, Receives Strategic ...
summary: American Oncology Network (AON), a rapidly growing network of community-based oncology practices, has announced a strategic investment of $65 million from AEA Growth. This investment aims to support AON’s mission of enhancing cancer care by providing comprehensive support to oncology practices, including access to clinical research, specialty pharmacy services, diagnostics, and financial assistance programs. AON, which generated over $1.1 billion in revenue in 2022, operates across 77 locations in 17 states with almost 200 providers. AEA Growth will hold a minority interest, while AON remains majority-owned by licensed oncologists.

title: American Oncology Network Appoints Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board of Managers
summary: American Oncology Network (AON) has appointed Dr. Shalin R. Shah as Chairman and Dr. Stephen "Fred" Divers as Vice Chairman of its Board of Managers, effective January 1. Dr. Shah, previously vice chairman, is a medical oncologist with Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute in Tampa, Florida, and has held various board positions in healthcare, technology, and education. Dr. Divers, also a medical oncologist, is affiliated with Genesis Cancer and Blood Institute in Hot Springs, Arkansas, and has served as AON’s chief medical officer since May 2022. Both leaders are committed to advancing community oncology practices and ensuring equitable access to cancer care.

title: EY Announces Todd Schonherz of American Oncology Network, LLC as an Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2023 Florida ...
summary: Ernst & Young LLP (EY US) has named Todd Schonherz, CEO of American Oncology Network, LLC (AON), as a finalist for the Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2023 Florida Award. This award honors transformative entrepreneurs who contribute to building a more equitable and sustainable world. Schonherz was selected by an independent panel of judges based on his entrepreneurial spirit, purpose, growth, and impact. AON, founded in 2018, focuses on providing local access to quality and affordable cancer care through a network of community oncology practices. The company operates 76 sites in 17 states plus the District of Columbia. Regional award winners will be announced on June 8, with national awards to follow in November. Winners will compete for the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year™ Award in June 2024. The Entrepreneur Of The Year program has recognized over 11,000 entrepreneurs in more than 145 cities across 60 countries since its inception in 1986.

title: American Oncology Network to Host Investor Presentation Webcast on September 29
summary: American Oncology Network, Inc. (AON) will host an investor presentation webcast on September 29, 2023, at 8:00 am Eastern Time. The presentation will feature AON's CEO, Todd Schonherz, and CFO, David Gould, discussing the company's business model, growth strategy, and value proposition. AON recently merged with Digital Transformation Opportunities Corp., a healthcare-focused acquisition company, and began trading on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "AONC" on September 21, 2023. The webcast can be accessed via a registration link and will be archived on AON’s Investor Relations website.

title: American Oncology Network Appoints New Board Member
summary: American Oncology Network (AON) has appointed William “Bill” J. Valle to its Board of Directors, effective April 19, 2024. Valle brings extensive experience from leadership roles at Fresenius Medical Care AG and other healthcare organizations. AON’s Chief Medical Officer, Stephen “Fred” Divers, and CEO, Todd Schonherz, expressed enthusiasm about Valle’s addition, citing his expertise and passion for healthcare improvement. Valle emphasized his commitment to enhancing cancer care access and equity. AON, founded in 2018, is a rapidly growing network of community oncology practices, dedicated to innovative, value-based care and improving patient outcomes.

title: Triple Crown Urology Opens in Hot Springs, Arkansas, and Joins American Oncology Network
summary: Triple Crown Urology has opened in Hot Springs, Arkansas, and joined the American Oncology Network (AON). Led by Drs. Seth Hollenbach, Nathan Littlejohn, and Renee Warford, the practice serves southwest Arkansas, specializing in diseases of the urinary system and offering advanced treatments like robotic surgery and Aquablation therapy. This partnership provides Triple Crown Urology with access to AON's resources, including a referral physician portal, an in-house specialty pharmacy, and patient financial counseling. AON leaders Todd Schonherz and Anthony Belott expressed excitement about the collaboration, emphasizing the enhanced patient care and expanded services.

title: Digital Transformation Opportunities Wins Approval for American Oncology Network Merger | DealFlow's SPAC News
summary: Digital Transformation Opportunities (DTOC) announced that its shareholders approved the merger with American Oncology Network (AON). The vote saw 9,931,654 in favor and 14,139 against. AON, a network of community-based oncology practices, has experienced over 60% compounded annual revenue growth since 2019, now generating over $1 billion annually. AON includes 107 physicians and 24 practices across 71 locations in 18 states. DTOC noted that 1,699,558 shares were redeemed for $17,852,818, leaving about $1.5 million in its trust after losing approximately 99.5% of it. DTOC raised $300 million in its March 2021 IPO. The deal's $60 million minimum cash condition was waived, and $65 million in Class C units were agreed to be sold.

title: Hollings nurses take leadership roles in Lowcountry chapter of Oncology Nursing Society, promote participation among ...
summary: Claudia Miller, R.N., and Amy Tamblyn, R.N., from MUSC Hollings Cancer Center have taken leadership roles in the Lowcountry chapter of the Oncology Nursing Society (ONS). Miller, a lung cancer nurse navigator, will serve as president, while Tamblyn, a radiation oncology nurse, will be president-elect in 2024. They emphasize the importance of the oncology certified nursing (OCN) credential, which reflects their expertise in cancer care. Both nurses advocate for participation in ONS, which offers continuing education and networking opportunities. Miller is contributing to an ONS book on nurse navigation, and Tamblyn is involved in developing a certification for radiation oncology nursing. Their involvement aims to enhance nursing practice and support new and less-experienced nurses. The Lowcountry chapter includes diverse nursing professionals and engages in community outreach activities.

title: Dana-Farber nurses present research and evidence-based studies at 2024 Oncology Nursing Society Congress
summary: Dana-Farber Cancer Institute nurses are presenting significant research and evidence-based studies at the 2024 Oncology Nursing Society (ONS) Congress in Washington, D.C., from April 24-28. The ONS Congress is the largest oncology nursing conference in the U.S., focusing on clinical knowledge, research, patient care, and advocacy. Two Dana-Farber nurses, Jessica McDade and Ludmila Svoboda, are recognized as finalists for the Extraordinary Healer award for their exceptional contributions to oncology nursing. Key presentations include studies on post-treatment diabetes, high-fidelity simulation for cytokine release syndrome education, exercise programs for genitourinary oncology patients, and CAR T-cell therapy for hemodialysis patients. These presentations highlight innovative practices and research aimed at improving patient outcomes and nursing education.

title: Susan O. Koduah, assistant professor reflects on her time as President of Oncology Nursing Society, Northern Virginia ...
summary: Dr. Susan O. Koduah, an assistant professor of nursing at the College of Public Health, reflects on her tenure as President of the Oncology Nursing Society, Northern Virginia Chapter (NOVA-ONS). Elected in early 2023, Koduah focused on increasing member engagement and successfully achieved this goal during her term. She emphasizes the importance of listening to members and maintaining humility as key leadership qualities. Her presidency coincided with the chapter's 40th anniversary, and she played a significant role in organizing the celebration. As president, Koduah served as a liaison to the national office, chaired quarterly board meetings, coordinated monthly dinner meetings, and prepared the end-of-year report. Her efforts led to a significant increase in attendance at events, including a well-attended Gala. Koduah attributes her success to collaborative efforts within the organization. The Oncology Nursing Society aims to promote excellence in oncology nursing and enhance cancer care.

title: The John Theurer Cancer Center Recognized as 2024 Outstanding Employer by the Oncology Nursing Society
summary: The John Theurer Cancer Center (JTCC) in Hackensack, NJ, has been honored as the 2024 Outstanding Employer by the Oncology Nursing Society (ONS). This recognition highlights JTCC's exemplary support for its oncology nurses, emphasizing the institution's commitment to innovative technology, individualized advanced treatment, and a nurturing work environment. Margaret Hopkins, a nurse and cancer survivor, praised the center for its extensive educational opportunities and supportive atmosphere. The award underscores JTCC's high nursing retention rates and its encouragement of professional development, including free certification exams and a comprehensive orientation program. Regina Foley and Linda Casey, leaders at JTCC, emphasized the importance of a supportive environment for nursing excellence and career growth. This accolade places JTCC among prestigious institutions like the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, reflecting the center's dedication to both patient care and staff appreciation.

title: The American Diabetes Association Announces the 2024 National Scientific and Health Care Achievement Award ...
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has announced the recipients of the 2024 National Scientific and Health Care Achievement Awards. These awards honor individuals who have made significant contributions to diabetes care and research. Key awardees include Professor Rury R. Holman, who received the Banting Medal for Scientific Achievement, and Dr. Stephen C.J. Parker, who was honored with the Outstanding Scientific Achievement Award. Other notable recipients are Dr. Alvin C. Powers, Dr. Samuel Dagogo-Jack, Dr. Joshua J. Neumiller, Dr. John Buse, Professor Kaushik Ramaiya, and Dr. Viswanathan Mohan. The awards will be presented at the ADA's 84th Scientific Sessions in June. The ADA continues its mission to improve the lives of those affected by diabetes through research, education, and advocacy.

title: The 2024 Update to the American Diabetes Association Standards of Care in Diabetes
summary: The 2024 update to the American Diabetes Association (ADA) Standards of Care emphasizes patient-centered care, person-first language, and updated treatment approaches based on the latest clinical evidence. Key revisions include management of cholesterol, blood pressure, and glycemic status, reflecting reduced insulin prices and glucose monitoring costs. The ADA highlights the importance of confirmatory testing for diabetes diagnosis and differentiating between diabetes types for personalized management. The update also includes recommendations for preventing diabetes onset, assessing comorbidities, and promoting health behaviors and well-being. The ADA advises using advanced technologies for diabetes monitoring and management, such as continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) and automated insulin delivery (AID) systems. The guidelines also address obesity and weight management, risks of adverse events, and management of diabetes in special populations, including older adults, pediatric patients, and pregnant individuals. The ADA's revisions aim to empower people with diabetes and recognize the individual at the center of diabetes care.

title: The American Diabetes Association Is Reevaluating BMI for Weight Management
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has updated its 2024 guidelines, recommending that healthcare providers consider additional measurements of fat distribution, such as waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, and waist-to-height ratio, alongside BMI for managing type 2 diabetes. The ADA emphasizes that weight loss should be a primary goal for individuals with type 2 diabetes, as losing more than 10% of body weight can improve health outcomes and potentially lead to disease remission. The guidelines suggest a tiered approach to weight loss, starting with lifestyle changes (nutrition, physical activity, behavioral therapy), followed by pharmacotherapy, medical devices, and metabolic surgery if necessary. These recommendations aim to provide a more comprehensive assessment of obesity and improve overall health management for people with type 2 diabetes.

title: How Genentech, a diabetes patient group and nonprofits opened eyes in Alabama - San Francisco Business Times
summary: Genentech and the American Diabetes Association (ADA), in collaboration with local nonprofits, launched a pilot program in Birmingham, Alabama, to address diabetic eye care among the Black community. The initiative, supported by community events and mobile vision trucks, aims to increase awareness and screenings for diabetes-related eye diseases, which are preventable in over 90% of cases. The program underscores the systemic health inequities and barriers to care, including limited access to specialists and transportation issues. By leveraging community groups, the partnership seeks to improve eye health outcomes and share successful strategies with other high-risk communities.

title: The American Diabetes Association and DaVita Strengthen Alliance to Tackle Chronic Disease Head-On
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) and DaVita have expanded their collaboration to address chronic disease prevention, particularly diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). This initiative, launched during National Kidney Month, aims to enhance education and awareness about kidney health. Chronic diseases are a leading cause of death and disability in the U.S., with over 38 million Americans living with diabetes, and one in three diabetic adults also having CKD. The partnership focuses on high-need communities, especially among Black and Hispanic populations, to improve health equity. DaVita has contributed $1.5 million to support ADA's initiatives. The efforts include creating accessible educational materials, piloting a registered dietitian program, and sponsoring ADA's State of Diabetes events. The campaign also features activities like a live cooking class for diabetes- and kidney-friendly meals.

title: The biggest diabetes stories out of ADA 2023
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) 2023 Scientific Sessions showcased significant advancements in diabetes technology and treatment. Key highlights include Senseonics' positive data on its 365-day CGM, Dexcom's upcoming glucose sensor for non-insulin users, and Medtronic's MiniMed 780G system showing promising results in adolescents. Insulet announced progress on integrating its Omnipod 5 with Abbott's FreeStyle Libre sensor. Innovations in diabetes reversal were also presented by Fractyl Health and Virta Health. Analysts remain optimistic about the diabetes tech market, expecting continued growth. The event highlighted the ongoing importance of diabetes management advancements and their impact on patient care.

title: The American Diabetes Association Welcomes 2024 Principal Officers and Members to the National Board of Directors
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has announced its 2024 principal officers and board of directors. The 15-member board, consisting of medical, scientific, educational, and business professionals, will guide the ADA's mission to improve the lives of people with diabetes. Key officers include Rhodes B. Ritenour as Chair of the Board, James Tai as Secretary/Treasurer, Dr. Mandeep Bajaj as President of Medicine & Science, and Patti Urbanski as President of Health Care & Education. The ADA aims to advance diabetes research, treatment, and prevention, advocating for over 136 million Americans affected by diabetes or prediabetes.

title: The American Diabetes Association Releases the Standards of Care in Diabetes--2024
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has released the Standards of Care in Diabetes—2024, providing updated, evidence-based guidelines for managing various types of diabetes. The new guidelines include updates on obesity drugs, screening practices, diabetes technology, and the use of teplizumab. Key updates involve new approaches to managing obesity, screening for heart failure and peripheral arterial disease, and the use of new medications for sustained weight management. The guidelines also emphasize hypoglycemia prevention, screening for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, bone health, diabetes technology, and the potential link between COVID-19 and type 1 diabetes onset. The ADA aims to enhance patient outcomes through these comprehensive guidelines.

title: The American Diabetes Association and Genentech Launch a Call to Action for Eye Exams to Prevent Diabetes ...
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) and Genentech have launched the Eye Pledge initiative to encourage annual eye exams for people with diabetes, aiming to prevent diabetes-related vision loss. The program, part of the ADA's Health Equity Now partnership, addresses health disparities in Black and Brown communities. Diabetes-related eye disease affects around 8 million Americans and is the leading cause of vision loss for those aged 18 to 64. The initiative began in Birmingham, Alabama, where diabetes and prediabetes are highly prevalent. The ADA and Genentech are working with community and faith-based organizations to overcome barriers to eye care and promote regular screenings, which can prevent 95% of diabetes-related vision loss. The program's insights will be used to improve care in under-resourced communities nationwide. To participate, visit diabetes.org/EyePledge.

title: American Diabetes Association elevates health technology innovation through inaugural event in Silicon Valley
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) is hosting its 28th Annual Leaders Forum HealthTech Showcase on November 3, 2023, in San Mateo, California. The event aims to connect life science leaders, business professionals, angel investors, and venture capitalists with healthcare startup companies. Over 300 executives from various industries will meet with more than 50 startups focused on unmet medical needs. The event features an Exhibitor Showcase and a luncheon where the top three companies present to a panel of judges and attendees, who then vote for the most innovative startup. The winner receives a $10,000 prize. The showcase highlights Silicon Valley’s innovation and supports ADA’s mission to prevent and cure diabetes. Leading sponsors include Abbott, Wilson Sonsini, MedTech Innovator, and Moss Adams.

title: Trauma Room at Banner North Colorado Medical Center Sees $1 Million Remodel | AHA
summary: Banner North Colorado Medical Center (NCMC) in Greeley has completed a $1 million remodel of its trauma room, enhancing its capacity to serve patients across Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, and parts of Kansas. The upgraded trauma room now features more space, better lighting, and advanced equipment such as rolling cabinets, blanket warmers, and fluid warmers. These improvements aim to enhance equipment accessibility, room adaptability, patient comfort, and overall efficiency. As the only level II trauma center in Greeley, NCMC is equipped to provide comprehensive trauma care, including 24-hour coverage by general surgeons and specialists in orthopedic surgery, neurosurgery, anesthesiology, emergency medicine, radiology, and critical care. Dr. Eric Luehr, trauma medical director at NCMC, highlighted that the remodel will significantly improve the facility's ability to care for the community.

title: North Colorado Medical Center pediatric unit on ‘temporary admission pause,’ spokesperson says
summary: The North Colorado Medical Center's pediatric unit has temporarily halted new admissions due to an acute staffing issue, confirmed by Banner Health officials. The pause began on December 22, 2023, and current patients will continue to receive care, but no new patients will be admitted. This situation has led to concerns about increased medical costs and the burden on other hospitals, as children needing care must be transferred to facilities in Fort Collins, Denver, and beyond. The pediatric unit, which serves children from birth to 18 years, is evaluating the situation daily with the aim of resuming admissions soon.

title: Trauma Room at Banner North Colorado Medical Center Sees $1 Million Remodel
summary: The trauma room at Banner North Colorado Medical Center (NCMC) in Greeley has undergone a $1 million remodel to enhance its capabilities. As a level II trauma center, NCMC serves critical patients from Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, and parts of Kansas. The remodel includes more space, better lighting, and upgraded equipment such as rolling cabinets, blanket warmers, and fluid warmers, aimed at improving patient care and efficiency. The project, completed after a year of planning and four months of construction, was carried out in partnership with Whiting-Turner from Fort Collins. Dr. Eric Luehr, trauma medical director at NCMC, highlighted the importance of these improvements in providing specialized care and managing increased trauma cases. NCMC is the only level II trauma center in Greeley and offers comprehensive emergency services, including 24-hour coverage from general surgeons and specialists. The hospital is part of Banner Health, a nonprofit healthcare system.

title: Banner NCMC pediatric unit to resume inpatient admissions amid staffing concerns
summary: Banner Health's North Colorado Medical Center (NCMC) will resume inpatient admissions for its pediatric unit after a temporary pause due to staffing issues. The pause, in effect since December 22, was caused by an acute staffing shortage. Despite resuming admissions, there are concerns about ongoing staffing problems and the unit's ability to handle high-acuity patients, who will be transported to other hospitals if necessary. Some former and current staff members believe the situation has been downplayed by administrators. The unit offers various services, including neonatal intensive care, but has faced significant staffing challenges, leading to unsafe conditions and staff departures. The reopening has community-wide implications, affecting nearby hospitals due to increased patient loads during the closure.

title: Banner North Colorado Medical Center Celebrates 250th WATCHMAN Procedure
summary: Banner North Colorado Medical Center celebrated its 250th successful WATCHMAN procedure on February 5, 2024. The program, started in 2016, faced initial challenges with older models and reimbursement issues but saw significant progress with the introduction of the Watchman FLX device in 2021. The WATCHMAN implant is a minimally invasive, permanent device designed to reduce stroke risk by closing the left atrial appendage in the heart. The procedure boasts a 95% success rate, aligning with the national average, and typically allows for same-day patient discharge. Banner North Colorado Medical Center, a nonprofit facility in Greeley, Colorado, offers a wide range of healthcare services and is part of the Banner Health system, which operates 33 hospitals across six states.

title: Banner North Colorado Medical Center's Central Sterile Processing Department receives $2.9 million remodel
summary: Banner North Colorado Medical Center’s Central Sterile Processing Department (CSPD) has completed a $2.9 million remodel to enhance efficiency and meet the demands of a level II trauma center. The remodel included new flooring, LED lighting, and advanced equipment like Steris 7053HP washers, cart washers, drying cabinets, and height-adjustable sinks. The Steris 7053HP washers, the first in northern Colorado, reduce manual cleaning time by 25% and use 40-50% less water while producing 18 trays per hour compared to six in the previous model. The project, which took one year of planning and nearly eight months of construction, aims to improve workflow and operational efficiency while adhering to regulatory and quality standards. Banner North Colorado Medical Center, a nonprofit facility, offers a wide range of healthcare services and is part of Banner Health, which operates 33 hospitals across six states.

title: Banner Health North Colorado Medical Center ICU staff recognized with lifesaving award
summary: The ICU staff at North Colorado Medical Center (NCMC) in Greeley, part of Banner Health, has been honored with the American Red Cross's Life Saving Organization Hero of the Year award for their efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic. They saved Jose Graciano, who survived months in a coma and required a double lung transplant. The award was presented at a banquet in Denver, where artist Armando Silva unveiled a painting symbolizing the care provided by the staff. The artwork, depicting hands forming a heart, now hangs at the ICU entrance as a tribute to their dedication. The staff expressed that the most rewarding aspect is seeing patients like Graciano recover and return to their families.

title: North Colorado Medical Center completes $1 million remodel of trauma room
summary: North Colorado Medical Center in Greeley recently completed a $1 million remodel of its trauma room, significantly enhancing its capacity to provide critical care. The upgraded facility now features state-of-the-art medical equipment and improved layout, which allows for better flow and immediate access to essential personnel and resources. According to Eric Luehr, trauma medical director at NCMC, the redesign increases space and accessibility to equipment, ensuring that patients in critical condition receive timely and efficient care upon arrival. The remodel aims to better meet the urgent needs of trauma victims and improve overall patient outcomes.

title: Greeley hospitals welcome leap day babies Thursday
summary: Nine babies were born on leap day at Banner North Colorado Medical Center and UCHealth Greeley Hospital. Leap day occurs on February 29 every four years, with exceptions. Babies born on this day, known as "leaplings," celebrate their birthdays on February 28 or March 1 in non-leap years.

title: Idaho Arthritis Walk returns for 10th annual charity fundraiser
summary: The Idaho Arthritis Walk is returning for its 10th annual charity fundraiser. This event aims to raise awareness about arthritis and its treatments through a 5K/1K run or walk. It is scheduled to take place at 8 a.m. on Saturday, August 26, at Julius M. Kleiner Memorial Park.

title: Nursing Dean a Health Care Hall of Famer
summary: Dean Butch de Castro and Professor Emerita Katherine Camacho Carr have been inducted into the Washington State Nurses Hall of Fame by the Washington State Nurses Association. Dean de Castro, recognized for his contributions to health equity and social determinants research, expressed deep gratitude for this honor. Camacho Carr, one of the first Certified Nurse Midwives in Washington, has significantly advanced nurse-midwifery and nurse practitioner practices, educating numerous students. Established in 1996, the Hall of Fame honors nurses who have transformed the field of nursing in Washington state. The induction highlights the scholarly excellence and professional standards of Seattle University's College of Nursing.

title: Nurses make the difference - WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) celebrates National Nurses Week, recognizing the vital contributions of nurses to healthcare. WSNA acknowledges ongoing challenges such as staffing shortages and workplace violence, and is actively working to address these issues. The association supports nurses in their advocacy efforts for better working conditions, which directly impact patient care. WSNA has a long history of representing nurses since 1908, advocating for safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety. The organization provides resources, education, and representation to help nurses achieve their professional goals. Governor Inslee has proclaimed May 6-12 as Nurses Week in Washington state, honoring the dedication and commitment of nurses. WSNA encourages nurses to join and benefit from their collective voice in improving healthcare standards and policies.

title: Washington nurses union files unfair labor practice charge against PeaceHealth
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association has filed an unfair labor practice charge against PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center, representing 1,465 nurses. The union alleges PeaceHealth violated the National Labor Relations Act by interfering with employee rights and bargaining in bad faith. PeaceHealth denies the claims. The National Labor Relations Board will investigate. The union also accuses PeaceHealth of disparaging the union and threatening employees wearing union insignia. If the Board finds merit, it could negotiate a settlement or hold a hearing. Recent picketing involved off-duty nurses and local officials. Bargaining began after the previous contract expired, with the next session scheduled with a federal mediator. Key issues include wages, sick leave, and pay equity. Past strikes have occurred over similar issues. PeaceHealth states it is committed to fair negotiations. The story is part of Community Funded Journalism by The Columbian.

title: Butch de Castro inducted into the Washington State Nurses Hall of Fame
summary: Butch de Castro, a Filipino American and dean of the College of Nursing at Seattle University, was inducted into the Washington State Nurses Hall of Fame by the Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) on March 21, 2024. The WSNA Hall of Fame, established in 1996, honors nurses who have significantly impacted nursing practice, research, education, and policy in Washington state. De Castro expressed that this recognition exceeds his career aspirations and motivates him to continue advocating for nurses and the communities they serve. Additionally, de Castro serves on the King County Board of Health.

title: WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a leading advocate for nurses in Washington, providing representation, education, and resources to help nurses achieve their professional potential and focus on patient care. Established in 1908, WSNA has been instrumental in advocating for better working conditions, safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety through collective efforts with employers, state agencies, and the Legislature. The association offers various resources including digital materials, white papers, and guides, and supports nurses through initiatives like safe staffing, emergency preparedness, and public health. WSNA also engages in political advocacy, endorsing candidates for elections and maintaining a Political Action Committee (PAC). The organization encourages membership, offering benefits such as professional development and representation. Recent achievements include the successful organization of NICU per diem nurses into the bargaining unit, enhancing their rights and protections. WSNA is accredited by the American Nurses Credentialing Center for continuing professional development.

title: WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a leading advocate for nurses in Washington, providing representation, education, and resources to help nurses achieve their professional potential. WSNA addresses various practice topics, including emergency preparedness, public health, and safe staffing, and offers resources such as white papers and handbooks. The association also engages in union activities, offering updates on local units, contracts, and representation rights. WSNA's Political Action Committee (PAC) supports candidates who advocate for nursing and patient safety. The association emphasizes the importance of unity among nurses, particularly in response to anti-union efforts by the Freedom Foundation, which seeks to undermine worker power. WSNA encourages nurses to stay informed and involved to maintain strong collective bargaining and advocacy efforts. The association has been representing nurses since 1908, striving for better working conditions, fair compensation, and patient safety.

title: Washington State Nurses Association stands in solidarity with…
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) stands in solidarity with striking healthcare workers from the Oregon Federation of Nursing and Health Professionals (OFNHP) at PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center and PeaceHealth St. John Medical Center. WSNA supports OFNHP's demands for safe staffing, living wages, and quality patient care. The strike involves 1,300 frontline workers, and WSNA emphasizes the interconnectedness of working conditions between its members and OFNHP members. Despite collaboration in patient care, PeaceHealth has refused to negotiate with OFNHP. WSNA has filed unfair labor practice charges against PeaceHealth for threatening to withhold health insurance from striking workers, condemning such coercive actions. A hardship fund has been established to support the striking workers.

title: WSNA local unit update
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a prominent advocate for nurses in Washington, providing representation, education, and resources to help nurses reach their full potential and focus on patient care. Since its establishment in 1908, WSNA has successfully advocated for better working conditions, safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety through collective efforts with employers, state agencies, and the Legislature. WSNA offers a variety of resources including digital materials, white papers, and guides, and engages in legislative advocacy to support nursing and healthcare policies. The association also provides continuing nursing education and various volunteer opportunities. Recently, WSNA has shown support for UFCW 3000 tech workers at Sacred Heart Medical Center, emphasizing the importance of solidarity while reminding its members of contractual obligations that prohibit joining strikes. WSNA encourages nurses to support their colleagues during non-work hours and to be aware of their rights regarding overtime.

title: WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) advocates for nurses in Washington through representation, education, and resources. Key activities include promoting safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety. WSNA offers various resources like white papers, handbooks, and digital tools. It also engages in legislative advocacy, endorsing candidates supportive of nursing and healthcare. The association provides continuing nursing education and supports nurses through union activities, including contract negotiations and addressing staffing complaints. WSNA has a historical presence since 1908 and continues to champion professional standards and healthcare improvements. Membership benefits include access to regional nurses associations, educational resources, and opportunities for leadership.

title: Pre-picket bargaining update: WSNA's most recent wage proposal, picket details, and Sip-and-Chat
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a key advocate for nurses in Washington, providing representation, education, and resources to enhance their professional potential and patient care. WSNA has been active since 1908, advocating for better working conditions, safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety. The association offers various resources including digital tools, white papers, and handbooks, and engages in legislative advocacy through the WSNA Political Action Committee (PAC). WSNA is currently negotiating a new contract with PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center, proposing significant wage increases and maintaining a three-year contract term. A picket is scheduled for April 18 to show solidarity and support for the bargaining goals. The association also offers continuing nursing education and opportunities for involvement in legislative issues. Membership benefits include access to regional nurses associations and updates on union news and contracts.

title: WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a key advocate for nurses in Washington, providing resources, representation, and education to enhance their professional capabilities and patient care. Established in 1908, WSNA has a long history of advocating for better working conditions, safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety. They offer a range of services including emergency preparedness, public health resources, and tools for safe patient handling. WSNA also engages in legislative advocacy, endorsing candidates supportive of nursing and healthcare issues for the 2024 elections. Their union activities include handling grievances, ensuring proper compensation, and maintaining contract integrity. WSNA's educational offerings include continuing nursing education and various professional development resources. The association encourages membership to strengthen the collective voice of nurses and improve healthcare standards in Washington.

title: WSNA
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) is a prominent advocate for nurses in Washington, providing representation, education, and resources to help nurses achieve their professional potential and focus on patient care. Since 1908, WSNA has represented nurses, advocating for better working conditions, safe staffing, fair compensation, and patient safety through collaboration with employers, state agencies, and the state Legislature. The association offers various resources, including digital tools, white papers, and guides, and addresses key nursing practice topics like emergency preparedness, public health, and workplace violence. WSNA also emphasizes union news, contracts, and legislative advocacy, including election endorsements and legislative sessions. Members benefit from various opportunities, including continuing education, leadership roles, and involvement in political advocacy. The association encourages membership to strengthen collective bargaining power and improve the nursing profession.

title: Six nurses to be inducted into the Washington State Nurses Hall of…
summary: The Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA) will induct six exceptional nurses into the Washington State Nurses Hall of Fame on March 21, 2024, at the Hilton Seattle Airport & Conference Center. Established in 1996, the Hall of Fame honors nurses who have significantly impacted nursing practice, research, education, and policy in Washington. The 2024 inductees are Katherine Camacho Carr, Butch de Castro, Jennifer Graves, Judi Lyons, Dawn Morrell, and Lynnette Vehrs. These nurses have made notable contributions in various areas, including education, health equity, nursing leadership, legislative advocacy, and clinical practice. The ceremony will celebrate their achievements and contributions to the nursing profession.

title: Nurses at PeaceHealth Southwest in Vancouver to picket April 18
summary: Nurses at PeaceHealth Southwest Medical Center in Vancouver, Washington, represented by the Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA), plan to hold an informational picket on April 18. This action follows 13 unsuccessful bargaining sessions aimed at addressing issues such as staffing, wages, sick time, and workplace violence. Key concerns include safe staffing, as nurses often work without breaks and handle too many patients, and competitive wages, with PeaceHealth Southwest nurses earning the lowest wages in the area. Additional issues involve the proposed removal of extended sick time banks, pay parity for home health and hospice nurses, and the lack of commitment to workplace violence prevention measures. The picket will occur from 6 a.m. to 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. outside the hospital.

title: Virginia Mason nurses to picket outside hospital Oct. 10
summary: Virginia Mason nurses, represented by the Washington State Nurses Association (WSNA), will picket outside the Seattle hospital on October 10, demanding better staffing and protections against workplace violence. This follows 15 bargaining sessions, including ones with a federal mediator. Key issues include unsafe staffing levels and increasing workplace violence, with incidents of patients bringing weapons into the hospital. Nurses have proposed safety measures such as metal detectors and enhanced security, which management has countered with a periodic advisory task force. The hospital has seen significant staff turnover, worsening nurse-to-patient ratios. WSNA advocates for improved working conditions to retain and attract nursing staff.

title: Patients Rising director urges self-advocacy, skills with chronic...
summary: Jim Sliney Jr., director of patient outreach at Patients Rising, emphasized the importance of self-advocacy and education for those with myasthenia gravis (MG) and other chronic diseases at the MG Foundation of America National Patient Conference. He highlighted that empowerment begins with understanding one's disease, learning medical jargon, and navigating the healthcare system. Sliney stressed that patients should actively engage in conversations with healthcare providers and be bold enough to share their experiences. Patients Rising offers resources, including a helpline and educational materials, to assist patients. Networking within the disease community and utilizing patient-support organizations are also crucial for empowerment.

title: Project Nana walk to end breast cancer
summary: Project Nana, a Hampton Roads-based non-profit, organized a walk along the Norfolk waterfront to combat breast and gynecologic cancers. The organization focuses on empowering women over 55 to advocate for better healthcare access and outcomes. The walk was part of a three-day event called the Seasoned Summit, which included workshops and forums. Organizer Vanessa Hill highlighted the participation of cancer patients, survivors, and women who had not visited a gynecologist in years. The event aimed to provide healing, encouragement, and hope. Project Nana also promotes "Take Nana to the doctor week" to further support healthcare conversations for older women.

title: Retina Fellows Forum: Do you live to work or work to live?
summary: Dr. John T. Thompson, MD, FASRS, shared insights on navigating career paths in ophthalmology at the 24th Annual Retina Fellows Forum. He emphasized the importance of understanding personal goals and priorities when searching for a job, highlighting the distinction between living to work and working to live. Thompson discussed various career options, including solo private practice, academic positions, and roles in large healthcare systems, each with its pros and cons. He advised fellows to consider factors such as control over their work, financial and academic success, and the impact of their job on personal life. Thompson also stressed the importance of observing potential colleagues' lifestyles and interactions with patients during interviews. He concluded that while there are no perfect jobs, the demand for skilled retina specialists ensures promising career opportunities.

title: Ovarian Cancer Awareness | Hillary Theakston from the Clearity Foundation visits CBS 8 Mornings
summary: Hillary Theakston from the Clearity Foundation appeared on CBS 8 Mornings to discuss ovarian cancer awareness. Clearity, a national nonprofit based in San Diego, focuses on supporting ovarian cancer patients. They are hosting their annual Teal Women Celebration on Sunday to raise awareness and funds for ovarian cancer research and support services.

title: Clearity Shines Light On 'Silent Killer' On Ovarian Cancer Day
summary: San Diego-based Clearity Foundation is advocating for women to be proactive about their health on World Ovarian Cancer Day. Ovarian cancer, often called the "silent killer," ranks fifth in cancer deaths among women and is frequently diagnosed too late. Clearity's executive director, Hillary Theakston, emphasizes the importance of early detection and self-advocacy. Common symptoms include vaginal bleeding, bloating, and abdominal pain. Clearity, founded by Laura Shawver, offers free personalized education, counseling, and navigation for ovarian cancer treatment. Celebrating its 15th year, the foundation relies on donor support and holds events like the Teal Woman gala to raise awareness and funds. The organization encourages women to seek necessary tests such as pelvic exams and CA-125 blood tests if they experience symptoms. Clearity's digital resources and virtual consultations make their services accessible nationwide.

title: Wisconsin's Pioneering Pathway Seeks to Secure Tech Hub Designation in Personalized Medicine
summary: Wisconsin is seeking designation as a Regional Technology and Innovations Hub in personalized medicine through a proposal to the Economic Development Administration (EDA). The state's consortium, including industry leaders in science, technology, manufacturing, and education, aims to elevate Wisconsin's leadership in biohealth technology. This initiative aligns with the bipartisan CHIPS and Science Act and the EDA's Tech Hubs Program, which supports economic and national security by fostering emerging industries. Wisconsin's biohealth sector, contributing over $32 billion to the economy and employing over 129,000 people, is pivotal in this effort. The designation promises to enhance innovation, attract global companies, and secure the state's role in advanced healthcare technologies.

title: Expert: High Arizona vaccine exemption rate in kindergarten 'just a disaster waiting to happen'
summary: Arizona's high rate of vaccine exemptions among kindergarteners is a significant public health concern, with over 7% exempted from required vaccines, compared to the national average of 3%. This trend, exacerbated by the pandemic, threatens herd immunity, crucial for preventing disease outbreaks. Dr. Bob England, interim executive director of The Arizona Partnership for Immunization, highlights the state's declining vaccination coverage and the challenges in achieving herd immunity. Factors include reduced access to the federal Vaccines for Children program and misinformation. Arizona's flexible exemption policies and the need for improved communication and education are also emphasized to address vaccine hesitancy and improve immunization rates.

title: CCHCI dental vaccine integration program wins statewide award
summary: Chiricahua Community Health Centers, Inc. (CCHCI) in Sierra Vista has won the Arizona Partnership for Immunization Big Shot’s Award for its Dental Vaccine Integration Program. The initiative, founded by Dental Director Brianna Hillier and supported by Immunization Specialist Kim Fruth, has administered over 1,800 vaccines since its inception. The program uses an AccuVax device to dispense vaccines during dental visits, offering a convenient way for patients to receive immunizations without needing a separate appointment. The program's success is attributed to its proactive approach and support from Delta Dental of Arizona, which funds key components like the AccuVax machine and staff positions. The initiative aims to promote whole-body health by ensuring patients are up-to-date with their vaccinations.

title: GSK Awards $1M in COiMMUNITY Initiative Grants to Support Adult Immunization and Health Equity
summary: GSK has awarded $1 million in COiMMUNITY Initiative grants to ten projects aimed at improving adult immunization and health equity in the US. Each project will receive between $50,000 and $175,000 to address barriers to adult immunization. The initiative, launched in June, focuses on increasing immunization rates through grant funding, data transparency, and resource-sharing. The funded projects include efforts to build vaccine confidence among underserved populations, create multilingual educational materials, and support local health departments. GSK aims to support innovative methods to encourage adult vaccination and mitigate health inequities at both local and national levels.

title: Local healthcare non-profit organization receives awards
summary: The Regional Center for Border Health (RCBH) and San Luis Walk-In Clinic (SLWIC) in Yuma County, Arizona, received the Arizona Best Practices and Brightest Stars awards for the second consecutive year. These awards, part of the 27th Annual “Arizona Best Practices and Brightest Stars Awards Celebration” held on April 19 in Mesa, Arizona, included the Arizona Partnership for Immunization Daniel T. Cloud Outstanding Practice Awards. The awards honor healthcare providers achieving a minimum 90% coverage level for their two-year-old and teen patients. RCBH and SLWIC were recognized in the Toddler and Teenager categories. Amanda Aguirre, former State Senator and current President & CEO of RCBH, expressed pride in their team’s commitment to providing high-quality services.

title: Nonprofit raised $20 million for East Bay cancer support center. The next step is breaking ground - San Francisco ...
hco: CANCER SUPPORT COMMUNITY SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA
summary: The Cancer Support Community San Francisco Bay Area has raised $20 million for a new cancer support center in Lafayette, East Bay. The nonprofit was gifted a 6-acre plot near Lafayette Reservoir in 2018 and has been working on designing a 12,000-square-foot facility, nature trails, and a community garden. Despite construction costs doubling post-pandemic, the organization plans to break ground this fall and aims to complete the project by 2025. The center will offer support groups, exercise classes, cooking demonstrations, educational workshops, and social activities for cancer patients and their families.

title: SU2C gives out 7 grants to boost diversity in cancer trials
summary: Stand Up To Cancer (SU2C) is awarding grants to seven community organizations in the U.S. to enhance diversity in early-stage cancer clinical trials. The grants aim to address the underrepresentation of minority groups in oncology trials, as evidenced by 2020 FDA data showing that 73% of cancer trial participants were white, 14% Asian, 6% Hispanic, and 5% Black. The recipients include Equal Hope, Ingalls Development Foundation, Cancer Support Community North Texas, Feonix—Mobility Rising, Triage Center, Praise is The Cure, and The Breathing Room Foundation. These organizations will work with four new research teams under SU2C’s Diversity In Early Development Clinical Trials Program, sponsored by Johnson & Johnson's Janssen pharmaceutical unit, to develop strategies for engaging medically underserved communities.

title: BroadcastMed Announces New Chief Executive Officer and Expanded Leadership Team
summary: BroadcastMed has appointed Charlie Lee as the new Chief Executive Officer and expanded its leadership team to accelerate growth and strengthen its market position. Lee, who joined as Chief Operating Officer in January 2023, brings over 20 years of executive experience. The company has also integrated several new executives, including Karen Auiler as Chief Operating Officer, Lee Schweizer as Chief Digital Officer, Michael Sadowski as Chief Financial Officer, John DuPont as Senior Vice President of Sales, and Karine Malzahn as Vice President of Marketing. These strategic moves follow BroadcastMed's recent mergers with five companies, enhancing its capabilities in providing trusted educational content for the healthcare sector.

title: $1 million donation launches Taylor Cancer Research Center
summary: The Toledo Clinic Cancer Centers and the Taylor Automotive family have announced the creation of the Taylor Cancer Research Center, thanks to a $1 million donation from the Taylor family. This new center, located in Maumee, Ohio, aims to provide groundbreaking clinical trials and innovative cancer treatments not currently available in the region. The facility is dedicated to Julie Fisher Taylor, who passed away from multiple myeloma in 2021. The center will focus on precision therapy, targeting molecular pathways that drive cancer growth without harming other cells. Dr. John Nemunaitis, a leading expert in precision therapy, will direct the center. The initiative seeks to offer advanced cancer treatments locally, reducing the need for patients to travel for care, and aims to honor Julie Taylor's legacy by helping the community. The center is in its early stages, with operations set to begin in February.

title: Cancer patient wills hundreds of thousands to help others
summary: Shelley Jackson, a cancer patient who passed away from acute myeloid leukemia, bequeathed $250,000 to the Cancer Care Alliance Foundation. The donation was formalized by her goddaughter, Sara Jackson, at the Toledo Clinic Cancer Center. Shelley Jackson, a teacher, and her husband, a truck driver, had saved diligently. The funds will support leukemia patients with non-medical expenses during treatment, such as car payments, rent, and utility bills. The foundation aims to provide local access to clinical trials, which had extended Shelley's life. Dr. Rex Mowat, who treated Shelley, received the donation, emphasizing its rarity and significance.

title: Dr Edward Arrowsmith: Trust and Compromise Are Essential in Building Oncology Clinical Care Pathways
summary: Dr. Edward "Ted" Arrowsmith emphasizes the importance of trust and compromise in developing oncology clinical care pathways. As the medical director for pathways at OneOncology and managing partner at Tennessee Oncology, Arrowsmith highlights the necessity of collaboration between payers and providers to create effective care pathways. He notes that physician-led initiatives at Tennessee Oncology and OneOncology ensure legitimacy and consensus in decision-making. The pathways program involves disease-based experts and pharmacists working together to review data and make necessary adjustments. Arrowsmith stresses that pathways should feel personalized to the physicians rather than imposed by external entities. Balancing consistent pathways with specific practice needs involves considering clinical guidelines and making value-based decisions when multiple treatment options are available.

title: Ascension St. Vincent affected by cyber attack to its network
summary: Ascension St. Vincent hospitals in Indiana are among those affected by a cybersecurity attack on the Ascension healthcare network, impacting facilities in at least eleven states. The attack, detected on May 8, has led to complications such as halted pharmacy services, increased wait times due to a switch to paper documentation, and the potential diversion of ambulance patients to other hospitals. Ascension is collaborating with the FBI and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to investigate the breach. Efforts to restore normal operations are ongoing. Cybersecurity expert Santiago Torres-Arias notes the increasing frequency of such attacks on hospitals due to valuable patient data. Johnson Memorial Health, previously affected by a similar attack, emphasizes the need for heightened vigilance and robust security measures.

title: Cyber security event at Ascension hospitals
summary: Ascension hospitals experienced a cyber security incident on May 8, 2024, affecting their technology network systems and disrupting some clinical operations. Ascension advised business partners to temporarily suspend connections to their network as a precaution. The incident was identified as a ransomware attack, and Ascension, with the aid of cybersecurity experts, has been working continuously to address the issue. Although progress is being made, it will take time to fully restore normal operations. Updates on the situation will be provided, and a dedicated website has been established to share information. The priority remains on ensuring safe patient care.

title: Ascension St. Vincent's cyberattack puts Jacksonville on alert
summary: Ascension Health Care's Jacksonville hospitals and clinics are operational but experiencing delays due to a ransomware attack. The attack, detected on May 8, disrupted multiple systems, including electronic health records and patient information portals. Ascension is working with the FBI and cybersecurity experts to investigate and restore systems. Despite the disruptions, all scheduled appointments and surgeries are proceeding, though with potential longer wait times. Patients are advised to bring notes on symptoms and medications. Ascension’s retail pharmacies cannot fill prescriptions, so patients must use other pharmacies. Cybersecurity expert Mini Zeng explains that health care systems are attractive targets due to their valuable data, and recommends robust, multi-layered defenses. The attack on Ascension is part of a broader trend of cyberattacks on large health systems and other industries.

title: Ascension gives updates on what Florida patients can do following ransomware attack on its systems
summary: Ascension has provided updates for Florida patients following a ransomware attack affecting its systems. The attack has disrupted operations across 140 hospitals and other facilities in 19 states. In Florida, doctor’s offices, urgent care centers, and walk-in clinics are open but experiencing delays due to the lack of computerized records. Ascension Rx retail pharmacies cannot fill prescriptions, so patients must seek alternatives. Emergency rooms remain operational, and patients with elective surgeries should proceed unless advised otherwise. Ascension is working with cybersecurity experts and the FBI to restore systems and determine if sensitive information was compromised. Patients are advised to freeze their credit as a precaution.

title: Ascension hospitals are open despite ransomware attack
summary: Ascension hospitals in Florida remain operational despite a ransomware attack on May 8, 2024. The attack affected electronic records and the MyChart patient portal, necessitating a switch to paper-based records. Emergency rooms and scheduled procedures are ongoing, but patients might experience longer wait times and delays. Ascension Sacred Heart and St. Vincent’s hospitals are accepting patients, and patients are advised to bring notes on symptoms and medications. Ascension's retail pharmacies cannot fill prescriptions, so alternative arrangements are needed. The health system is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity agencies to address the issue. Ransomware attacks have increased in the healthcare sector, with the Russian-linked Black Basta group potentially responsible for this breach.

title: Health care system that runs St. Vincent’s in Birmingham reports ‘disruption’ from possible ‘cybersecurity in
summary: Ascension Health, which operates St. Vincent’s Birmingham and five other facilities in the Birmingham area, reported a possible cybersecurity incident causing disruption to clinical operations. Detected on May 8, unusual activity on select network systems prompted an immediate investigation and remediation efforts. Access to some systems has been interrupted, but care teams have procedures to ensure patient care continues safely. Ascension Health advised its business partners to temporarily suspend connections to its environment and has enlisted Mandiant, a third-party expert, to assist in the investigation. Relevant authorities have been notified, and the health care system will inform affected individuals if any sensitive information is compromised.

title: Ascension hospitals in Indiana affected by national cyberattack
summary: Ascension St. Vincent hospitals in Indiana, part of a 140-hospital national chain, are experiencing operational disruptions due to a cyberattack detected on Wednesday. The hospital network is investigating the breach and has activated remediation efforts, affecting system access. Patients will be informed if their appointments are impacted. The health industry has seen a significant rise in cyberattacks, with hospitals increasingly targeted due to the valuable data they hold. Major health systems have been investing more in security to mitigate these threats, but the frequency and severity of attacks are escalating. Patients are advised to stay informed about data protection practices at their healthcare providers but should not withhold health information due to breach concerns.

title: Cyberattack hits Ascension St. Vincent hospital, officials say
summary: Ascension St. Vincent hospital's computer system was targeted by a cyberattack, as confirmed by hospital officials. The network encompasses 140 hospitals, but it's uncertain if the Evansville location and its facilities were affected. Ascension leaders have informed authorities and initiated procedures to minimize the impact on patients. If any sensitive data was compromised, the company will notify those affected.

title: 'Making progress' | Ascension provides update on effects of recent cyberattack
summary: Ascension St. Vincent is making progress in restoring systems after a recent ransomware attack. While hospitals, physician offices, and care sites in Indiana remain operational, some hospitals are diverting ambulance services. Emergency rooms are open and accepting walk-ins. Elective and non-elective surgeries, as well as diagnostic imaging and treatments, continue as scheduled, but patients may face delays due to the use of manual systems. Ascension's retail pharmacies in Indiana cannot fill prescriptions currently, and patients are advised to bring their prescription details to appointments. Ascension emphasizes its commitment to patient safety and quality care during this period.

title: Ascension hospitals are experiencing a cyberattack. What to know
summary: Ascension hospitals across the United States are experiencing disruptions due to a suspected cyberattack. The health system detected unusual activity on select technology network systems early Wednesday afternoon. Ascension has not disclosed the exact nature of the attack but confirmed that charting, scheduling, and prescription writing systems are down. The impact is still under investigation, with similar disruptions reported in Wisconsin, Texas, Oklahoma, Indiana, and Michigan. It is unclear if there has been a data breach; Ascension has pledged to notify and support anyone affected. Ambulances are diverting new patients to other hospitals to ensure ongoing patient care. Ascension has engaged cybersecurity firm Mandiant to assist in the investigation and remediation efforts. The organization has recommended that business partners temporarily suspend connections to its environment as a precautionary measure. Updates will be provided as more information becomes available.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Participates in Statewide Gathering to Enhance Cancer Care in ...
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) is participating in the Florida Society of Clinical Oncology (FLASCO) 2024 Business of Oncology Summit & Spring Session in Kissimmee, FL. The event brings together medical providers, patients, payors, and other oncology stakeholders to discuss evolving topics in community oncology. Key participants include FLASCO President and FCS oncologist Maen Hussein, MD, who will open the event, and Paresh Patel, MD, who will moderate a panel on legislative impacts on oncology care. Discussions will cover AI technology in clinical practice, updates in breast and lung cancer treatment, and new therapies like bispecifics and CAR-T. FCS leaders hold various positions within FLASCO, emphasizing their commitment to enhancing cancer care through collaboration and innovation.

title: Navigating Decision-Making for Lymphoid Malignancies: How MRD Testing Can Help
summary: Minimal residual disease (MRD) testing is crucial for informed decision-making in treating lymphoid malignancies, as emphasized by Dr. Georges Azzi. MRD testing helps detect, count, and track cancer cells during and after treatment, providing insights into patient outcomes and treatment adjustments. Dr. Azzi uses next-generation sequencing (NGS) for its accuracy and depth, particularly in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), and multiple myeloma. Despite its benefits, MRD testing is underutilized in community oncology due to limited awareness and perceived costs. Dr. Azzi advocates for broader adoption of MRD testing to enhance precision medicine and improve patient care.

title: Baptist Health Foundation names 6 to board
summary:
Baptist Health Foundation has appointed six new board members to support its mission. The foundation, established in 1963, operates a statewide system with approximately 11,000 employees and 12 hospitals. The new members are:

1. Matthew Blaylock: President of Blaylock Heating & Air, involved in education and community support.
2. Cara Butler: Associate attorney at Mitchell Williams, specializing in employment and workplace issues.
3. Jimmy Hammock: Former materials manager at Meritor, Inc., with extensive leadership experience.
4. Tonya Hooks: Senior investigator with the Arkansas Crime Victims Reparations Board, active in community service.
5. Kelly Imhoff: Marketing director at Harrison Energy Partners, with a background in public relations and marketing.
6. Elizabeth Machen: Executive VP at Simmons Bank, overseeing marketing and communications.

These members bring diverse expertise to the board, enhancing the foundation's efforts in healthcare and community service.

title: Bolo Bash co-chairs bring fresh ideas to fundraiser | Arkansas Democrat Gazette
summary: Danielle Collie and Elizabeth Machen, co-chairwomen of the Baptist Health Foundation’s annual Bolo Bash Reception & Luncheon, are introducing fresh ideas to the fundraiser. Scheduled for October 19, 2023, the event aims to raise $250,000 for the expansion and renovation of the Baptist Health Breast Center-Little Rock. The luncheon will feature a menu by chef Chester Wright and a speech by Olympic gymnast Nastia Liukin. A VIP reception with Liukin will occur the night before. This year's event also includes a revamped silent auction with curated items and a custom bolo necklace. Tickets are available for $300 for the luncheon and $85 for the reception.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation Seeks Volunteers To Help Cancer Patients In Need
summary: The Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation is seeking volunteers to support cancer patients at their Wellington clinic. Volunteers will provide non-medical assistance, including companionship, refreshments, and helping with non-medical tasks. To volunteer, individuals must complete an online application, phone interview, criminal history check, drug/nicotine screening, health screening, and provide proof of certain immunities. An annual influenza vaccine is also required. Volunteers must commit to at least three hours per week for six months and be at least 18 years old with a valid driver’s license. The foundation supports cancer patients with financial assistance for essential expenses, allowing them to focus on recovery. Interested individuals can call, email, or apply online.

title: Las Meninas Sculpture Project benefits Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Foundation
summary: The Las Meninas Sculpture Project benefits the Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Foundation. Charley Belcher visited the Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute in Trinity to cover the story. The project aims to support the foundation through its artistic endeavors.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Appoints Joel Grossman, MD and Maen Hussein, MD to Executive Board
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) has appointed Dr. Joel Grossman and Dr. Maen Hussein to its Executive Board, effective January 1, 2024. Dr. Grossman, who joined FCS in 2003 and serves as Division Chief of Oncology and Hematology for NCH Healthcare System, has previously served three terms on the FCS Executive Board and is active in community activities. Dr. Hussein, who joined FCS in 2011, is a prominent cancer researcher and advocate for clinical trials, currently serving as President of the Florida Society of Clinical Oncology (FLASCO) board of directors. FCS CEO Nathan H. Walcker emphasized the importance of their expertise in guiding the institute's strategic priorities. FCS is renowned for its participation in clinical trials and has been recognized nationally for its contributions to cancer research and patient care.

title: Sister Hazel Announce Sixth Annual Lyrics for Life Charity Fundraiser Event
summary: Sister Hazel has announced their sixth annual Lyrics for Life charity fundraiser event, "An Evening of Making Music Matter," scheduled for March 2, 2024, in Gainesville, FL. The event aims to raise funds for STOP! Children’s Cancer, Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation, and other children's cancer charities. Held at the Curtis M. Phillips Center, the evening will feature an intimate concert by Sister Hazel with special guest Pat Monahan of Train. Tickets are available for $150, with sponsorship packages offering additional perks. Lyrics for Life, founded by Sister Hazel's Ken Block, has raised over $3.5 million for pediatric cancer charities.
