The organization unites musicians and celebrities for concerts and auctions to support cancer research and patient care. The event also includes a cash bar and reserved seating for concert ticket holders. More information and tickets can be found on their website.

title: ME STRONG races back to DeLand in support of cancer patients in 2024
summary: ME STRONG will host its annual 5K race in DeLand on February 3, 2024, to support cancer patients. The event, started in 2011 by friends of Linda Ryan after her recurrent cervical cancer diagnosis, has become a significant fundraiser. Partnering with The Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation, last year’s event raised over $250,000 for local patient grants. The race, now managed by a coalition of Florida Cancer Specialists and local DeLand Rotary Clubs, continues to attract participants and spectators from Central Florida and beyond. For more information or to register, visit MESTRONG.net.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Announces Bradley Monk, MD as Medical Director of Late-Phase ...
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) has appointed Bradley Monk, MD as Medical Director of Late-Phase Clinical Research, effective January 1, 2024. Dr. Monk, who is board-certified in gynecologic oncology and obstetrics and gynecology, brings extensive experience in clinical research. He co-founded the GOG-Partners Foundation, advancing clinical and scientific research in gynecologic malignancies. Dr. Monk has led numerous groundbreaking studies, authored over 400 peer-reviewed articles, and presented his findings at various forums. He will leverage his expertise to expand FCS's late-phase clinical trials, aiming to bring new cancer therapies to patients.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation brings Hollywood to the Hyatt
summary: The Florida Cancer Specialists Foundation hosted its annual Party Under The Stars fundraiser on February 25 at the Hyatt Regency Sarasota, featuring a Hollywood theme. Attendees, including supporters and medical professionals, dressed in glamorous Hollywood-inspired outfits. The event aimed to support the foundation's mission of providing financial aid to cancer patients for expenses like mortgages and car payments. The evening included a social hour, speeches by emcee Allison Imre, a live auction by Chris Marchand, and a mission moment with Executive Director Lynn Rasys, concluding with drinks and dancing.

title: Ann's Heart Of Phoenixville Gets Crucial $1 Million Federal Grant
summary: Ann's Heart, a crucial nonprofit in Phoenixville, PA, has received a nearly $1 million federal grant through the Community Project Funding passed by U.S. Congress. This grant will enable Ann's Heart to purchase and renovate their downtown campus, securing a permanent home for their services and other nonprofits in Chester and Montgomery Counties. The funds will help address housing and food insecurity, mental and behavioral health support, and isolation among vulnerable community members. Renovations will include ADA compliance improvements like ramps, lifts, and new restrooms. U.S. Rep. Chrissy Houlahan and U.S. Sen. Bob Casey were instrumental in obtaining the funding.

title: Fields presented two awards
summary: Denise Fields, a local pharmacist from Ripley County, was honored with two awards at the Indiana Pharmacy Association's Annual Meeting. She received the Beyond Dispensing Award and the Indiana Society of Health System Pharmacy's Fellowship Award. Dr. Fields, who works at Ever North's Cummins LiveWell Center in Columbus, has over 30 years of experience. She is board certified in Advanced Diabetes Management and Lifestyle Medicine and holds numerous professional certifications. Dr. Fields is involved in team-based healthcare and patient advocacy, having held leadership roles in several pharmacy associations. She has also contributed to initiatives like the Indiana Pharmacy Practice Advancement Initiative Task Force.

title: Hettinger-Riddell named Distinguished Young Pharmacist
summary: Kate Hettinger-Riddell, a local pharmacist and lecturer at Purdue University College of Pharmacy, received the Distinguished Young Pharmacist Award from the Indiana Pharmacy Association. This accolade honors a member who has earned a pharmacy degree within the last decade and demonstrated outstanding practice. Riddell, who obtained her PharmD from Butler University in 2020, completed a PGY-1 Community-Based Pharmacy Residency and a Community Practice Research Fellowship at Purdue. She also holds an MS in Health Services, Outcomes, and Policy. As the Managing Network Facilitator for the Community Pharmacy Enhanced Services Network Indiana, and president of the Indiana Academy of Independent Pharmacists, Riddell works part-time at Cowan Drugs in Lebanon. Her advocacy for health education and community outreach has significantly impacted public health, earning her this prestigious award.

title: Mercy mergers St. Luke's foundation into its local charity arm
summary: Mercy Health Foundation Greater Toledo has merged with the former St. Luke’s Foundation after McLaren closed St. Luke’s Hospital. The merger aims to honor St. Luke’s legacy and support community health initiatives in the areas previously served by St. Luke’s Hospital. Tim Koder, president of Bon Secours Mercy Health Foundation, expressed excitement about continuing St. Luke’s heritage and integrating its board members into the Mercy Health Foundation. Three St. Luke’s Foundation board members have joined Mercy's board, and the Mercy Health Foundation will manage the St. Luke’s Hospital Legacy Fund for services in Lucas, Wood, Fulton, Henry, and Defiance counties. Mercy has also incorporated 22 former McLaren St. Luke’s health providers and approximately 400 support staff into its organization following the acquisition of St. Luke’s facilities and assets from McLaren.

title: Mercy Health Foundation Southeast to host Wine and Chocolate Pairing event
summary: Mercy Health Foundation Southeast Ambassadors will host a Wine and Chocolate Pairing event on February 17 at the Cape Girardeau Country Club to mark American Heart Month. The event, starting at 6 p.m., includes live music, hors d’oeuvres, a silent auction, wine pull, and house-made dark chocolates paired with wines. Proceeds will benefit the Heart Strong Fund, which provides essential supplies for people with congestive heart failure and donates Automated External Defibrillators (AEDs) to community groups. Tickets are $50 each and available online. For more information, contact the foundation at (573) 519-4924.

title: Mercy Health Foundation Gala to be held next month
summary: The Mercy Health Foundation of Clark and Champaign Counties will host its annual gala on December 2, focusing on women's health, including the birthing center at Mercy Health – Springfield Regional Medical Center. Kristy Kohl McCready, the Foundation's President, emphasized the event's role in bringing the community together to support local healthcare. The funds raised will enhance maternal health services, including new medical equipment and facility upgrades. The event at Champions Park will feature cocktails, a gourmet dinner, music, dancing, and auctions. Tickets are available at foundation.mercy.com/SpringfieldGala2023, and further details can be obtained by contacting the Mercy Health Foundation.

title: Forward Together: SoutheastHEALTH Joins Mercy
summary: SoutheastHEALTH has officially joined Mercy after receiving regulatory approvals, with new Mercy signage appearing across southeast Missouri. This partnership aims to expand Mercy's value-based care approach along the I-55 corridor, enhancing patient access and focusing on preventive care to improve health outcomes and reduce costs. Mercy Hospital Southeast in Cape Girardeau and other SoutheastHEALTH facilities have been renamed under the Mercy brand. The transition includes integrating Mercy's electronic health record system, Epic, by fall 2024, providing seamless care and online services through the MyMercy portal. Public celebrations and community roundtables are planned to engage with local residents. Mercy, a large, multi-state health care system, emphasizes its commitment to providing high-quality care and community benefits, including significant investments in southeast Missouri.

title: OPINION | Carin Schoppmeyer: Charity Ball's record funding goes to Mercy Health Foundation Fort Smith; Cherokee ...
summary: The Mercy Health Foundation Fort Smith received a significant boost when Cherokee Nation Deputy Chief Bryan Warner announced an $8 million investment towards a new cancer treatment center during the Charity Ball on December 8 at the Fort Smith Convention Center. This donation, part of the Cherokee Nation's support for the foundation's early 2024 campaign, aims to establish a modern, free-standing, state-of-the-art cancer center. The Charity Ball event also set a fundraising record, highlighting the community's strong support for the initiative to combat cancer in an unprecedented manner.

title: I spent 13 years raising funds and awareness of bowel cancer, and now I have it myself
summary: Micheál Sheridan, CEO of Mercy University Hospital Foundation, dedicated 13 years to raising funds and awareness for bowel cancer, only to be diagnosed with the disease himself. He emphasizes the foundation's role in enhancing patient experiences and supporting families financially affected by illness. Micheál initially led the foundation from 2007, significantly boosting donations and collaborating closely with healthcare professionals. After a brief stint with an air ambulance charity, he returned to his CEO role. His personal battle with bowel cancer has deepened his understanding of patient needs and the importance of blood donations. The foundation's new cancer care center, set to open soon, aims to provide a supportive space for patients and their families.

title: SoutheastHEALTH has changed names to Mercy Hospital Southeast
summary: SoutheastHEALTH has officially changed its name to Mercy Hospital Southeast, marking an expansion of the Mercy health system into southeast Missouri. This change is part of a strategic agreement signed in August 2023, aimed at enhancing healthcare delivery and patient access in the region. The transition includes rebranding hospital signage and integrating SoutheastHEALTH staff with Mercy's team. Mercy plans to implement its electronic health record system, Epic, across all facilities by fall 2024, providing comprehensive patient care and online services through the MyMercy portal and app. The SoutheastHEALTH Foundation will now be known as Mercy Health Foundation, while the SoutheastHEALTH College of Nursing & Health Sciences retains its name but joins the Mercy system. Mercy's president and CEO, Steve Mackin, emphasized the focus on value-based care and improving patient health outcomes.

title: OPINION | Carin Schoppmeyer: O’ Night Divine Mercy Charity Ball brings in $1.2 million to boost mom and baby care
summary: The O' Night Divine Charity Ball, held on December 2 at the Rogers Convention Center, successfully raised over $1.2 million for the Mercy Health Foundation Northwest. This event, now in its 30th year, aims to support the care of mothers and babies. Key representatives from Walmart, including Kevin and Michelle McAuliffe, Maurice and Maya Bowie, and Corey and Nicole Bender, participated in the fundraiser, highlighting the community's commitment to enhancing healthcare services.

title: Independent Rx Forum: Legal Frontiers and Updates From NCPA
summary: In the latest episode of the Independent Rx Forum, hosted by Jack Mozloom from the National Community Pharmacists Association (NCPA), legal developments affecting independent pharmacies are discussed with Matthew Seiler, RN, Esq, NCPA's general counsel. Key topics include a new class action lawsuit with potential implications for independent pharmacies, updates on Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and Department of Justice (DOJ) merger guidelines, and the role of the NCPA Trust in safeguarding pharmacy interests. The episode also highlights the importance of engaging with State Attorneys General to address legal matters impacting independent pharmacies.

title: THERESA TOLLE NAMED 2023 NCPA WILLARD B. SIMMONS INDEPENDENT PHARMACIST OF THE YEAR
summary: Theresa Tolle, owner of Bay Street Pharmacy in Sebastian, Florida, has been named the 2023 NCPA Willard B. Simmons Independent Pharmacist of the Year. The award, presented at the NCPA Annual Convention and Expo, recognizes pharmacists for exemplary leadership and commitment to independent pharmacy. Tolle, a second-generation pharmacist, offers various patient services and leads a community-based residency program. She is actively involved in local, state, and national pharmacy associations and holds leadership roles in several organizations, including the Florida Pharmacy Association and the American Pharmacists Association. Tolle's contributions extend to her community, where she chairs the Board of Trustees for Sebastian River Medical Center and participates in local initiatives.

title: Spring Allergies Attack More Than Just Your Nose - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Spring allergies affect not only the nose but also the eyes, respiratory system, and skin. Pollen, mold spores, and other airborne particles can trigger nasal allergies, asthma, eczema, and eye allergies. Managing these interconnected allergic responses is crucial for improving quality of life. Nasal allergies cause sneezing and congestion, asthma flares lead to wheezing and difficulty breathing, eczema worsens with environmental allergens, and eye allergies cause itching and redness. Effective management includes using medications like antihistamines and nasal corticosteroids, avoiding allergens, and consulting an allergist for personalized treatment plans, including immunotherapy.

title: For Parents of Kids with Food Allergies, Social Media Can Bring Support -- and Stress
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Parents of children with food allergies often turn to social media for advice, but the information they find can be both helpful and misleading. A study published in the Annals of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology found that 93% of surveyed parents use online search engines, with Facebook being the most popular platform. Parents seek tips on managing allergies, recognizing symptoms, and finding support groups. However, the study highlighted that not all online information is reliable, and 43% of parents do not discuss this information with their child's allergist. The study emphasized the importance of consulting board-certified allergists for trustworthy information. While professional organizations and medical societies are seen as credible sources, information from other parents and celebrities is often less trusted. The study underlines the need for parents to critically evaluate online information and rely on expert advice for managing their child's food allergies.

title: Gailen Marshall installed as ACAAI President
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Dr. Gailen Marshall, MD, PhD, of Jackson, MS, was installed as president of the American College of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (ACAAI) during its Annual Scientific Meeting in Anaheim, CA, on November 12, 2023. Dr. James Tracy, DO, of Omaha, NE, was elected president-elect. Other elected officers include Cherie Zachary, MD, as vice president and Kelly Maples, MD, as treasurer. Regents elected for three-year terms are Aikaterini Anagnostou, MD, MSc, PhD, Brian T. Kelly, MD, MA, and Mervat Nassef, MD. Dr. Marshall, a long-serving member of the ACAAI, has held numerous academic and editorial positions and received several awards. Dr. Tracy, a board-certified allergist and immunologist, has also been recognized for his contributions to the field. The ACAAI, founded in 1942, is a professional organization dedicated to patient care, education, advocacy, and research in allergy and immunology.

title: You Can Still Register for the 2023 ACAAI Annual Scientific Meeting in Anaheim!
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The 2023 Annual Scientific Meeting of the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) will take place in Anaheim, CA, from November 9-13 at the Anaheim Convention Center. The event will bring together allergists, pediatricians, researchers, and healthcare professionals globally. Attendees will explore groundbreaking studies and the latest research in allergy and asthma treatments. Advance media registration is open until October 27, and a media badge is required for in-person attendance. A Livestream option is available for those unable to attend in person, with registration closing on November 8. The meeting will cover topics such as mast cell disease, food allergies, biologics, and mental health in atopic dermatitis patients. Media attendees can conduct interviews with key researchers and presenters. For more information, contact Hollis Heavenrich-Jones at ACAAI.

title: Climate change and the future of allergic disease management
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The December issue of the Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology, by the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI), addresses the impact of climate change on allergic diseases. It highlights the role of allergists in managing conditions such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, and atopic dermatitis, which are exacerbated by global warming. Articles discuss the lengthening pollen seasons, increased atopic diseases due to global fires and dust storms, and the disruption of the epithelial barrier leading to heightened T2 inflammation. Dr. David Stukus emphasizes the critical role allergists play in helping patients affected by climate change.

title: AAAAI/ACAAI Joint Task Force Issue Guideline Updates for Atopic Dermatitis Management
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The 2023 guidelines from the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (AAAAI) and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) Joint Task Force provide updated recommendations for managing atopic dermatitis (AD). These guidelines, intended for healthcare professionals involved in AD care, focus on five key areas: optimal topical treatments, the efficacy of elimination diets, the safety of dilute bleach baths, the use of allergen immunotherapy, and systemic treatments, including phototherapy. The guidelines emphasize personalized care, considering patient values and preferences, and recommend specific treatments based on disease severity and patient response. The guidelines also highlight the importance of correct diagnosis, patient education, trigger avoidance, and proper medication adherence. They advise against certain treatments like systemic corticosteroids and emphasize the need for future research to address gaps in evidence, particularly regarding the safety of AD medications during pregnancy and breastfeeding.

title: New Year, New Resolutions to Keep Allergy and Asthma Symptoms Controlled - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) suggests New Year’s resolutions to help manage allergy and asthma symptoms. About 50 million Americans suffer from these conditions. Key recommendations include: scheduling a check-up with an allergist to update prescriptions; getting vaccinated against respiratory viruses like flu, COVID-19, and RSV; managing stress through calming therapies; improving home environments by removing dust-collecting items or using HEPA vacuums; and maintaining regular exercise routines, with precautions for asthma sufferers. Consulting an allergist can provide personalized plans for better health management. Visit AllergyAndAsthmaRelief.org for more information.

title: Flaxseed Allergy Appearing More Frequently – Present in Foods and Other Substances - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Flaxseed, increasingly popular for its health benefits, is causing more allergic reactions, both through ingestion and skin contact. Two cases presented at the ACAAI Annual Scientific Meeting highlight this issue. An 18-month-old developed a rash after consuming oatmeal with flaxseed, indicating an IgE-mediated reaction. A skin prick test confirmed allergies to various nuts and seeds, including flaxseed. Another case involved an artist with severe hand dermatitis from using oil paints containing linseed/flaxseed oil. Patch testing confirmed flaxseed as the allergen. These cases underscore the need for awareness of flaxseed as a potential allergen in both food and non-food products.

title: Double Duty Spring Cleaning: Keep Healthy and Tidy - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Spring cleaning can be beneficial for those with allergies and asthma by helping to remove allergens from the home. The American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology (ACAAI) suggests several tips for effective cleaning: avoid opening windows to prevent pollen from entering; control moisture to reduce mold; vacuum frequently to remove pet dander; change air filters regularly; and wash bedding and stuffed animals weekly. When working outdoors, wear protective gear and wash thoroughly afterward. Despite efforts, allergy symptoms may persist, so consulting a board-certified allergist is recommended for proper diagnosis and treatment. For more information, visit AllergyAndAsthmaRelief.org.

title: Study Shows Children with Private Insurance More Likely to Outgrow Food Allergies - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A study presented at the ACAAI Annual Scientific Meeting indicates that children with private insurance are more likely to outgrow food allergies compared to those with public insurance. The research, part of the FORWARD study, found that 21% of the 188 children examined outgrew at least one food allergy, with milk and egg allergies being the most commonly outgrown. Specifically, 29% of children with private insurance outgrew their allergies versus 12% with public insurance. The study highlights the importance of understanding factors contributing to the development of tolerance to food allergies. Additionally, a case study demonstrated the benefits of baked egg oral food challenges in adolescents with severe egg allergies.

title: Special Toothpaste May Lower Risk of Allergic Reactions for Adults with Peanut Allergy - ACAAI Public Website
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A new study presented at the ACAAI Annual Scientific Meeting demonstrates that a specially formulated toothpaste can be used for Oral Mucosal Immunotherapy (OMIT) to help desensitize adults with peanut allergies. This method delivers allergenic peanut proteins to specific areas in the mouth, showing potential for food allergy desensitization due to its targeted delivery and ease of use. The study involved 32 adults, aged 18-55, in a 3:1 ratio of active treatment to placebo. Results showed 100% tolerance to the highest dose without moderate or severe systemic reactions. Adherence was high at 97%, with no dropouts. OMIT appears to be a safe and convenient option for food allergy treatment, supporting further development for pediatric use.

title: Fundación Puertorriqueña de Enfermedades Reumáticas y su compromiso con la salud de los pacientes boricuas
summary: The Puerto Rican Foundation for Rheumatic Diseases (FER), established in 2009, has significantly improved the quality of life for many Puerto Rican patients with rheumatic conditions. The non-profit organization, supported by the Puerto Rican Association of Rheumatologists, focuses on education, research, and patient well-being. Over the years, FER has organized numerous events, such as health fairs and educational programs, to empower patients with knowledge and tools to manage their conditions effectively. Key initiatives include the "Reuma Expo" and various symposia, which have provided valuable information on diseases like lupus, fibromyalgia, and arthritis. The foundation also emphasizes the importance of early symptom identification and access to treatment, enhancing patient care and support. Through these efforts, FER continues to create a positive impact on the lives of individuals with rheumatic diseases in Puerto Rico.

title: Lumbago y ciática: qué es, síntomas y tratamientos de las enfermedades reumáticas
summary: Lumbago, commonly known as lower back pain, is pain in the lumbar region caused by issues with the spine's structures such as ligaments, muscles, discs, and vertebrae. It affects about 85% of people at some point, usually benign. Acute lumbago lasts less than 6 weeks, while chronic lumbago persists longer. When pain extends to the lower limbs, it is termed lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica if it reaches the heel or foot, suggesting nerve root damage. Causes include mechanical issues and inflammatory diseases like ankylosing spondylitis, with aggravating factors being inactivity, poor posture, physical labor, and obesity. Symptoms vary by cause, with mechanical pain worsening when standing and inflammatory pain often occurring at night. Diagnosis involves physical examination and possibly imaging if pain persists. Treatment includes short rest, gradual physical activity, heat application, massage, and medications like paracetamol or NSAIDs. Regular exercise and strong core muscles are crucial for prevention and management.

title: Llega ReumaExpo2023: el evento cumbre de la Fundación Puertorriqueña de Enfermedades Reumáticas
summary: ReumaExpo 2023, organized by the Puerto Rican Foundation for Rheumatic Diseases (FER) in partnership with Revista Medicina y Salud Pública, is set to take place on October 15, 2023, at the Hotel La Concha Renaissance San Juan Resort. This annual event aims to educate and raise awareness about rheumatic conditions, focusing on personalized medicine for effective treatment. The agenda includes discussions on nutrition, alternative therapies, and specialized management of various rheumatic diseases like arthritis, fibromyalgia, and gout. Dr. Oscar Soto Raíces, a key organizer, invites patients to participate both virtually and in person. FER has been instrumental in empowering patients with rheumatic diseases through education and support over the past 14 years, impacting many in Puerto Rico. ReumaExpo provides a multidisciplinary approach to managing these conditions, integrating mental health, nutrition, and exercise into patient care.

title: Sé parte de las iniciativas de Fundación FER - BrandStudio
summary: Fundación FER, a non-profit organization founded in 2009 in San Juan, Puerto Rico, is dedicated to improving the quality of life for patients with rheumatic diseases. Led by rheumatologists, the foundation offers education and tools for patients to better manage their conditions. It has organized events such as symposiums, ReumaExpo, and radio programs to raise awareness and educate about rheumatic diseases. It has also financially supported pediatric groups and collaborated with other organizations to facilitate access to treatments, especially after natural disasters like Hurricane Maria. During the COVID-19 pandemic, it adapted its activities to digital formats to continue its educational mission.

title: Llamado a la acción ante las enfermedades reumáticas
summary: Dr. Oscar Soto-Raíces, president of the Puerto Rican Foundation for Rheumatic Diseases, highlights the importance of personalized medicine in treating rheumatic diseases like arthritis and lupus. Precision medicine allows for specific treatments tailored to each patient's individual needs, improving efficacy and reducing adverse effects. Genomics plays a crucial role in this personalization, providing detailed information about risks and treatment responses. The ReumaExpo 2023 event aims to raise awareness of these advances and encourage active patient participation in their treatments. Soto-Raíces emphasizes the need for greater Puerto Rican representation in clinical studies and stresses the empowerment of patients to improve their quality of life and treatment adherence.

title: Artritis reumatoide, fibromialgia o gota: condiciones que se abordarán integralmente en ReumaExpo Oeste
summary: ReumaExpo Oeste, organized by the Puerto Rican Foundation for Rheumatic Diseases (FER), will take place on March 3, 2024, at the Aguada Convention Center. The event will address conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, fibromyalgia, and gout through comprehensive discussions involving various medical and wellness fields. Key speakers include Dr. Oscar Soto Raíces, Dr. Noemi Varela, Melissa Ly Merced-Gómez, Dr. Ángel E. Alemán Rivera, Dr. Braulio Quintero, and others. Topics will cover individualizing arthritis management, the neuropsychological impact of fibromyalgia, physical rehabilitation, the effects of high uric acid levels, lupus, psoriatic arthritis, osteoarthritis, and the impact of rheumatic diseases on sexuality. The event will be live-streamed on the social media platforms of Revista Medicina y Salud Pública and Fundación FER.

title: Miopatías: : qué es, síntomas, diagnóstico y tratamiento
summary: Myopathies are a heterogeneous group of diseases characterized by deficits or abnormalities in muscle groups. Their origins and treatments are diverse, involving multiple factors such as nerve impulses, muscle membrane excitability, and protein interactions responsible for muscle contraction. Symptoms include progressive muscle weakness, loss of muscle tone, delayed motor skills, drooping eyelids, difficulty blowing, and involuntary muscle cramps. Diagnosis often begins with rheumatologists due to initial symptoms of pain and functional limitations in muscle groups. Treatment involves high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressive drugs like cyclophosphamide, azathioprine, and methotrexate, improving patients' quality of life.

title: ¡Comenzó Reuma Expo 2023 de la Fundación FER!
summary: Reuma Expo 2023, organized by the Puerto Rican Foundation for Rheumatic Diseases, has commenced. This event, led by the foundation, focuses on educating attendees about managing various rheumatic diseases such as arthritis. Participants can engage in live Q&A sessions during the special broadcast. The event is a platform for doctors, health professionals, and patients to connect and learn.

title: Síndrome Antifosfolípido (SAF)
summary: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS) is a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by the production of autoantibodies that affect coagulation factors, increasing the formation of clots in veins and arteries. Common symptoms include thrombosis and pregnancy complications, such as recurrent miscarriages, reduced fetal growth, prematurity, and pre-eclampsia. Other symptoms may include thrombocytopenia, heart valve disease, epilepsy, and transverse myelitis. Diagnosis is based on the presence of thrombosis or pregnancy complications along with positive antiphospholipid antibodies in at least two tests separated by 12 weeks. Treatment varies by type: oral anticoagulation for thrombotic and low-dose aspirin and heparin for obstetric. In specific cases, corticosteroids, hydroxychloroquine, immunomodulators, human immunoglobulins, or plasmapheresis may be used.

title: Dolores de espalda podrían ser primeras señales de Espondilitis Anquilosante
summary: Ankylosing spondylitis is an autoimmune condition that affects the spine and large joints, often diagnosed in young men from the age of 20. Back pain, especially in the morning, is a characteristic symptom. Dr. Amarilis Pérez de Jesús highlights the importance of early diagnosis through physical exams, patient history, and genetic tests like HLAP27. Without treatment, the condition can cause spinal fusion and loss of functionality. Treatments include anti-inflammatories, sulfasalazine, and interleukin inhibitors, along with physical therapy to maintain joint movement.

title: Nurse Practitioners Predict Doc Shortages, Care Access to Loom in 2024
summary: Nurse practitioners (NPs) are anticipating significant provider shortages and increased patient demand in 2024, according to the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP). The shortage is leading to longer appointment wait times, with some patients waiting up to two months. This issue is exacerbated by the growing senior population, which is expected to increase healthcare demand significantly. AANP highlights that NPs are well-positioned to address these challenges, especially in primary care and mental health screenings. With over 385,000 licensed NPs in the U.S., 90% trained in primary care, they are crucial in filling the gaps, particularly in rural areas. AANP urges healthcare leaders and policymakers to expand the scope of practice for NPs to ensure efficient and effective patient-centered care.

title: UAMS' Leonie DeClerk, Ph.D., DNP, APRN, Selected as Fellow of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners
summary: Leonie DeClerk, Ph.D., DNP, APRN, a clinical associate professor at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) College of Nursing, has been named a 2024 inductee into the Fellows of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP). This prestigious recognition honors nurse practitioners for their exceptional achievements in education, policy, clinical practice, or research. DeClerk was noted for her contributions to health policy and education, including efforts to improve healthcare access in Arkansas. She collaborates with organizations like the National Organization of Nurse Practitioner Faculties and the Arkansas Nurse Practitioner Association. DeClerk will be inducted at the AANP national conference in June 2024 and is the only inductee from Arkansas this year.

title: Nurse Practitioner Profession Grows to 385,000 Strong
summary: The American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP) announced that the number of licensed nurse practitioners (NPs) in the U.S. has grown by 8.5%, reaching 385,000 in 2023. This growth is celebrated during National Nurse Practitioner Week, highlighting the significant contributions of NPs to the healthcare system. NPs provide high-quality care across various settings, including clinics, hospitals, and private practices, and are essential in addressing healthcare needs, especially in underserved areas. The profession is recognized for its commitment to improving health outcomes and combating disparities. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects a 45% growth in the NP profession by 2032.

title: University of Phoenix College of Nursing Faculty Leadership Selected for Prestigious Fellows of the American ...
summary: Dr. Sun Jones from the University of Phoenix College of Nursing has been selected for the 2024 Fellows of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (FAANP) program. This prestigious recognition honors her leadership in education, research, policy, and practice. Dr. Jones, a bilingual family nurse practitioner, has significantly contributed to her community and the nursing profession. She founded the Arizona Korean Nurses Association and the Korean American Nurses Foundation, focusing on the well-being of Asian and Pacific Islander communities. Her efforts during the COVID-19 pandemic earned her commendations, and she received the March of Dimes HEROES IN ACTION Leadership Award in 2022. Dr. Jones will be inducted into the FAANP program at the 2024 AANP National Conference in Nashville, Tennessee, joining an elite group of nurse practitioners dedicated to advancing the profession and improving health care globally.

title: Cleveland Clinic Names New Chief Pharmacy Officer
summary: Cleveland Clinic has appointed Lindsey B. Amerine, Pharm.D., as the new Chief Pharmacy Officer, starting February 26. Dr. Amerine joins from UNC Health, where she served as Interim Chief Pharmacy Officer and Vice President of Pharmacy. She will oversee enterprise pharmacy initiatives and lead over 1,500 pharmacy professionals in Ohio and Florida. Dr. Amerine has extensive experience in pharmacy operations and has held leadership roles at UNC Health and the University of North Carolina Eshelman School of Pharmacy. She has been active with the American Society of Health-System Pharmacists (ASHP) and has received numerous awards. Dr. Amerine aims to continue innovating Cleveland Clinic's pharmacy services.

title: Cleveland Clinic and IBM Unveil First Quantum Computer Dedicated to Healthcare Research
summary: Cleveland Clinic and IBM have unveiled the IBM Quantum System One, the first quantum computer dedicated to healthcare research, at Cleveland Clinic. This marks a significant milestone in their 10-year Discovery Accelerator partnership aimed at accelerating biomedical discoveries using high-performance computing, AI, and quantum computing. The partnership, initiated in 2021, seeks to advance biomedical research and generate new treatments for diseases like cancer, Alzheimer's, and diabetes. The collaboration also includes educational initiatives to train a future workforce in data science, machine learning, and quantum computing. The project is part of Cleveland Clinic's Global Center for Pathogen & Human Health Research, supported by a $500 million investment.

title: The Howley Foundation Makes $12 Million Gift to Double Number of Nurse Scholars at Cleveland Clinic
summary: The Howley Foundation has donated over $12 million to Cleveland Clinic to double the number of nurse scholars in its ASPIRE initiative, starting in fall 2023. This program, now renamed to honor the Howley name, aims to increase diversity in healthcare, address opportunity gaps, and reduce health disparities. The initiative targets local high school and college students, offering a pathway from high school to a bachelor’s degree in nursing at Ursuline College, with opportunities to work at Cleveland Clinic facilities. The program, launched in 2017, has been supported by over $20 million from The Howley Foundation and other donors. It celebrated its first five graduates in December 2022, with more expected by 2024. The program also includes pathways for other healthcare careers. Cleveland Clinic is accepting applications from high school juniors until October 1, 2023.

title: Cleveland Clinic and its Community Partners Team Up to Host Men's Health Challenge
summary: Cleveland Clinic, in collaboration with community partners, hosted a Men’s Health Challenge at the Langston Hughes Community Health & Education Center on June 1, 2023. The free event aimed to address the health disparities among African American men, who are at higher risk for conditions like asthma, diabetes, heart disease, obesity, and stroke. Over 100 attendees participated in preventive screenings, vaccinations, and health resources. The event emphasized brotherhood and included partners such as the Case Western Reserve University School of Dental Medicine, Cleveland Cavaliers, and local Black fraternities. Additional activities featured a cooking demo, haircuts, educational workshops on entrepreneurship and financial literacy, and employment opportunities at Cleveland Clinic. The Langston Hughes Center focuses on free health education, primary care, prevention, and wellness programs to improve community health. Cleveland Clinic is a nonprofit academic medical center known for its medical breakthroughs and comprehensive care.

title: Cleveland Clinic and IBM Unveil First Quantum Computer Dedicated to Healthcare Research
summary: Cleveland Clinic and IBM have unveiled the first quantum computer dedicated to healthcare research, the IBM Quantum System One, at Cleveland Clinic. This milestone is part of their 10-year Discovery Accelerator partnership aimed at accelerating biomedical discoveries using high-performance computing, AI, and quantum computing. The quantum computer will help researchers identify new medicines and treatments more quickly by solving complex problems beyond the capabilities of current supercomputers. The partnership also focuses on developing educational programs to train a future workforce in data science, machine learning, and quantum computing. This initiative supports Cleveland Clinic's Global Center for Pathogen & Human Health Research and aims to create jobs and boost the economy.

title: Arthritis Foundation and Cleveland Clinic to Build National Osteoarthritis Imaging Center for Clinical Trials
summary: The Arthritis Foundation has chosen Cleveland Clinic to establish the National Osteoarthritis Imaging Center (OIC) for clinical trials. This center will serve as the largest repository for imaging data related to post-traumatic osteoarthritis, aiding in treatment and care. The OIC will coordinate imaging for future multicenter osteoarthritis clinical trials in the U.S., providing a centralized hub for data interpretation and analysis. The first phase, funded by a $2.5 million grant, will involve building infrastructure to gather and archive images nationwide. Researchers will benefit from standardized, high-quality imaging data, facilitating new treatments and better patient care. The OIC aims to develop new imaging techniques and biomarkers for early detection and treatment of osteoarthritis. Additionally, it will investigate the effects of metformin on post-traumatic osteoarthritis, particularly in younger patients, to understand and manage the condition better. Cleveland Clinic, a renowned nonprofit medical center, will lead this initiative.

title: Cleveland Clinic Launches New Quantum Innovation Program for Start-up Companies
summary: Cleveland Clinic has introduced the Cleveland Clinic Quantum Innovation Catalyzer Program to support start-up companies in healthcare and life sciences. The program will select up to four early- and growth-stage companies through a competitive application process, providing them with a 24-week immersive experience. Participants will gain access to the IBM Quantum System One computer, space on Cleveland Clinic’s campus, opportunities to collaborate with clinicians and researchers, and participation in the Quantum Working Group on Healthcare and Life Sciences. The program includes educational offerings and culminates in a graduation and demo day. This initiative is part of Cleveland Clinic’s partnership with IBM aimed at advancing biomedical research through quantum computing. The application process is open, with proposals due by January 15 and selections made by March 15. The program starts in April.

title: Integrating the Humanities into the Medical School Curriculum is a Smart Idea
summary: The podcast episode discusses the integration of medical humanities into the medical school curriculum at the Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine. Katherine Burke, the Director of Medical Humanities, explains how incorporating humanities enhances the student experience by offering opportunities for reflection and meaning-making in the challenging journey of becoming a physician. The humanities include literature, history, philosophy, and the arts, which help students understand health and illness from different perspectives. Burke highlights various programs, such as poetry sessions and community projects, that connect medical students with the community and foster empathy. The episode also addresses common misconceptions about medical humanities and emphasizes the importance of administrative support for such initiatives. Overall, integrating humanities is seen as a valuable tool in combating burnout and promoting a well-rounded medical education.

title: Cleveland Clinic unveils IBM quantum computer for research
summary: Cleveland Clinic and IBM have unveiled the first quantum computer dedicated to biomedical research, marking a significant milestone in their 10-year partnership. This IBM-managed quantum computer, installed on-site at Cleveland Clinic, aims to accelerate healthcare research and biomedical discoveries. It is the first onsite private sector IBM-managed quantum computer in the U.S. Cleveland Clinic plans to receive the next-generation IBM 1,000+ qubit quantum system in the coming years. The partnership also includes the development of the Discovery Accelerator center to advance healthcare and life sciences research using IBM's hybrid cloud, AI, and quantum computing technologies. Financial terms were not disclosed. Quantum computing, which leverages quantum mechanics, holds promise for revolutionizing healthcare by solving complex problems faster than traditional supercomputers. The collaboration aims to address scientific bottlenecks and find new treatments for diseases like cancer, Alzheimer's, and diabetes. The initiative is part of a broader effort to boost research and create jobs in Cleveland.

title: Mental Health Concerns in College Students
summary: College students face significant mental health challenges due to transitions, stress, and lifestyle changes. Dr. Susan Albers highlights a mental health crisis in higher education, supported by data from Gallup and Lumina Foundation, showing high dropout considerations due to emotional stress. Factors contributing to this crisis include academic pressure, financial stress, fear of the future, loneliness, physical health concerns, substance use, and trauma. College athletes are particularly vulnerable due to sleep deprivation, time constraints, and fear of seeking help. Tips for managing mental health include prioritizing basic needs, staying connected with support networks, joining student organizations, knowing available resources, registering with disability services if needed, focusing on controllable factors, and seeking help when necessary. Taking a medical leave may be necessary for severe cases. Despite challenges, resources are available to support students' mental well-being.

title: Howley Foundation gifts Cleveland Clinic $12M for nursing scholarships
summary: The Howley Foundation has donated over $12 million to the Cleveland Clinic to expand its nursing scholarships. This funding will double the number of scholarships available through the ASPIRE initiative, now renamed the Howley ASPIRE Nurse Scholars Program. The program targets local high school and college students, aiming to increase diversity in healthcare and address opportunity gaps. Students start as high school juniors and can earn scholarships to pursue a Bachelor of Science in Nursing at Ursuline College. They also gain practical experience as patient care nursing assistants at Cleveland Clinic. After graduation, they have the opportunity to work as registered nurses at Cleveland Clinic facilities. The program, launched in 2017, has been supported by the Howley Foundation and other donors, with a commitment to promoting diversity, inclusion, and equity in healthcare.

title: Cleveland Clinic nursing program provides new opportunities for high school students
summary: The Cleveland Clinic offers the ASPIRE Nurse Scholars Program to high school juniors interested in healthcare careers. Sponsored by the Howley Foundation, the program aims to diversify the nursing workforce by providing students with experience at the Cleveland Clinic. The program, which began in 2017, partners with Tri-C and Ursuline College, allowing students to earn a bachelor's degree and receive a college scholarship. Successful graduates like Ayanna Lewis, now a coronary ICU nurse, highlight the program's impact. ASPIRE is recruiting its 8th cohort for spring 2024, with 15 graduates expected next year.

title: App May Pave Way to Treatments for No. 1 Dementia in Under-60s
summary: A UC San Francisco-led research team has developed a smartphone app that could significantly aid in the early detection and treatment of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), the leading cause of dementia in individuals under 60. This app uses cognitive tests that are as sensitive as traditional neuropsychological evaluations to identify early signs of FTD in genetically predisposed individuals before symptoms appear. The app's ability to facilitate remote monitoring could enhance participation in clinical trials and improve early-stage treatment effectiveness. The study, published in JAMA Network Open, indicates that this technology could eventually replace many in-person visits for monitoring treatment effects, thus accelerating the development of therapies for FTD. Researchers collaborated with Datacubed Health to incorporate tests of executive function, speech, and movement, collecting rich data to aid in early diagnosis and symptom monitoring. This innovation addresses a significant barrier in FTD research and treatment.

title: A Blood Test Shows MS Worsening 1 to 2 Years Before it Happens
summary: A new study from UC San Francisco reveals that elevated levels of the biomarker NfL in blood tests can predict worsening disability in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients one to two years before symptoms appear. This research, published in JAMA Neurology, is the first to quantify the timeframe during which central nervous system damage occurs before disability worsens. Elevated NfL levels were linked to up to a 91% higher risk of disability worsening with relapse within a year and up to a 49% higher risk without relapse nearly two years later. The findings suggest that early interventions during this period could prevent or delay severe MS symptoms. The study involved data from nearly 1,900 patients across the US and Switzerland. Future research will explore therapies to halt disease progression during periods of elevated NfL.

title: Opinion | UCSF expansion could create MIT of the West in San Francisco
summary: Evan Zimmerman suggests that expanding the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) into a full university with law, science, and engineering programs could transform San Francisco into a college town akin to MIT's influence in Boston. This expansion could boost the local economy and attract talent. UCSF, already a biotech powerhouse and the second-largest public employer in the Bay Area, could merge with UC Law School SF and expand its graduate science programs. This approach leverages existing infrastructure and successful branding, making it a quicker and more viable option than starting a new university from scratch.

title: Breakthrough Drug Helps Children with New-Onset Type 1 Diabetes
summary: A new study from UC San Francisco shows that the immunotherapy drug teplizumab helps children recently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes by reducing their need for supplemental insulin. Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system destroys insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells. Teplizumab helps preserve these cells, making diabetes management easier. Approved by the FDA in 2022, teplizumab had previously been shown to delay the onset of type 1 diabetes in at-risk individuals. The recent phase 3 PROTECT trial demonstrated that children treated with teplizumab maintained more beta cell function and required less insulin than those given a placebo. The study suggests expanding teplizumab use beyond at-risk individuals to those newly diagnosed. Researchers are exploring further applications and additional treatments to enhance its effectiveness.

title: ACC.23 emerges as a return to normalcy for the cardiology community
summary: ACC.23, the 2023 annual meeting of the American College of Cardiology, marked a significant return to normalcy for the cardiology community after the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Held in New Orleans, the event saw a high turnout, with more professional attendees than in 2019, the last pre-pandemic meeting. The conference featured crowded expo floors, packed session rooms, and extensive hands-on training sessions. Attendees appreciated the renewed sense of community, face-to-face interactions, and the opportunity for professional networking. The number of vendor booths also increased compared to 2019, including new AI vendors. Face masks were largely absent, reflecting widespread vaccination among attendees.

title: CorVista Health to Present New Data on the Use of Machine Learning as a Non-Invasive Point-of-Care Rule-out Test ...
summary: CorVista Health will present new data on using machine learning for a non-invasive point-of-care rule-out test for heart failure at the ACC 2024 conference. The data highlights the CorVista System's ability to detect elevated left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) with high sensitivity and specificity, offering a non-invasive alternative to current invasive methods. The CorVista System, already FDA-approved for coronary artery disease and pulmonary hypertension, aims to improve cardiovascular disease diagnosis, especially in underserved populations. This system provides rapid, actionable results without radiation or invasive procedures, enhancing care in low-resource settings.

title: American College of Cardiology (ACC) Program Set for Cardiac Oncology Conference, “Advancing the Cardiovascular ...
summary: The American College of Cardiology (ACC) is hosting the Cardiac Oncology Conference titled “Advancing the Cardiovascular Care of the Oncology Patient” from February 9-11, 2024, at the Heart House in Washington, D.C. This interdisciplinary event aims to provide clinicians and researchers with tools to enhance cardiovascular health in cancer patients. The conference will feature sessions, including a plenary by Dr. Laleh Amiri Kordestani from the FDA, and a joint session with the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO). The program targets cardiologists, oncologists, and other healthcare professionals involved in cancer patient care.

title: Spotlight on Lp(a) Risks, Low Testing Prevalence, and Potential Treatments at Cardiology Meeting
summary: At the American College of Cardiology's annual meeting, Novartis Pharmaceuticals launched an educational campaign to encourage cardiologists to screen for lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)], a significant cardiovascular biomarker. Despite its prevalence, Lp(a) testing remains low, with only a small percentage of patients being screened. Novartis is leading the development of treatments targeting Lp(a), including pelacarsen, which aims to reduce cardiovascular events. Research presented at the conference highlighted Lp(a) as an independent risk factor for cardiovascular diseases, including heart failure and coronary artery disease. Testing rates are increasing, driven by clearer guidelines and growing awareness. However, disparities exist, with Black and South Asian populations showing higher Lp(a) levels but lower testing rates. While no specific Lp(a)-lowering drugs are currently available, ongoing trials and existing lipid-lowering therapies like PCSK9 inhibitors and omega-3 fatty acids are being explored to manage elevated Lp(a) levels.

title: New Drug Class, Exercise Advised for Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
summary: The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) have released new guidelines for managing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), an inherited condition causing heart muscle thickening. The guidelines emphasize collaborative decision-making and updated treatment recommendations for both adults and children. HCM affects about 1 in 500 individuals, often going undiagnosed. New treatments include cardiac myosin inhibitors, the first FDA-approved drugs targeting heart muscle thickening. Exercise, particularly low to moderate intensity, is now recommended for HCM patients, with some potentially returning to competitive sports. The guidelines also focus on risk assessment for sudden cardiac death (SCD) and include pediatric-specific recommendations.

title: Hackensack University Medical Center Recognized for Excellence from the American College of Cardiology
summary: Hackensack University Medical Center has been recognized by the American College of Cardiology (ACC) for its excellence in cardiac care, particularly in the cardiac catheterization lab. The center, part of Hackensack Meridian Health, was awarded Cardiac Cath Lab Accreditation with PCI, reflecting its high standards in treating patients undergoing diagnostic catheterizations and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) procedures. This non-surgical therapy, also known as coronary angioplasty, involves using a balloon to open blocked coronary arteries. The accreditation was based on a thorough onsite evaluation of the staff's capabilities in patient assessment, sedation, infection control, radiation safety, and procedural coordination. The hospital's commitment to improving patient outcomes is evident through standardized procedures and enhanced communication with patients and their families. Elizabeth A. Maiorana of Hackensack Meridian Health emphasized the importance of this recognition in providing high-quality cardiovascular care to New Jersey residents.

title: Lupus LA Unveils 2024 Patient Advocacy Panel Members to Amplify Voices and Drive Change
summary: Lupus LA, a nonprofit organization dedicated to combating lupus, has announced its inaugural 2024 Patient Advocacy Panel. This panel aims to amplify voices and drive change by sharing authentic lupus stories to highlight the disease's severity and aid in discovering its cause and cure. The initiative, led by new Board Co-Chairs Stacey Uberstine and Maurissa Tancharoen Whedon, includes patient leaders who will work closely with Lupus LA to share their experiences and insights. The panel will play a crucial role in shaping public perception, promoting Lupus LA's events, and extending the organization's impact.

title: Medicare Drug Price Negotiation: How to Ensure Access & Equity
summary: The 2022 Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) has led to significant savings in healthcare costs for millions of Americans by extending Marketplace affordability, capping insulin costs, eliminating out-of-pocket vaccine expenses, and improving access to affordable prescription drugs. Starting in 2026 for certain Part D drugs and 2028 for certain Part B drugs, the federal government will negotiate prices with drug companies. The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) identified the first 10 drugs for these negotiations. Policymakers, patient advocates, providers, and academics are concerned about ensuring access and equity in these negotiations, particularly for older adults, people with disabilities, and underserved communities. An event by The Hill will discuss these issues with health officials, lawmakers, and advocates.

title: Wait before expanding drug board’s power
summary: Maryland's Prescription Drug Affordability Board (PDAB), established in 2019, aims to reduce health care costs by setting upper payment limits (UPLs) on certain high-cost drugs. However, there is concern that expanding the board's authority before it has proven effective could harm patient access to necessary medications. Critics argue that UPLs might lead to lower reimbursement rates for providers, causing them to stop carrying certain drugs, especially in poorer areas. This could force patients to travel farther for medication or switch to less effective treatments, exacerbating health challenges and increasing future medical costs. Maryland lawmakers are urged to halt efforts to expand the PDAB's power until it demonstrates success in lowering costs without compromising patient care.

title: What Your Doctor Doesn't Know About Muscle Loss
summary: A study in the Journal of American Geriatric Society reveals that most physicians are not familiar with sarcopenia, a condition causing rapid muscle loss in older adults. Only 20% of internists and family medicine physicians are very familiar with the term, compared to 70% of geriatricians. Sarcopenia affects 10-20% of older adults, leading to falls, hospitalization, and increased need for long-term care. Symptoms include muscle weakness and difficulty performing daily activities. Treatments focus on addressing underlying causes, exercise, and nutritional interventions. An online survey showed that awareness and clinical practice integration are low, with only 8% of physicians using the term and 24% utilizing standardized definitions. The study calls for a unifying consensus definition and diagnostic criteria. The Aging in Motion Coalition and the Alliance for Aging Research emphasize the need for increased awareness and research on sarcopenia.

title: Your first prenatal visit: what to expect
summary: Your first prenatal visit is crucial for the health of both you and your baby. Schedule it as soon as you find out you're pregnant, ideally between eight to ten weeks. During these visits, you will receive guidance on weight management, exercise, nutrition, and overall health. Tests will be conducted to monitor your baby's growth and development and to identify any potential risks or complications. Dr. Elizabeth Brown, an OB/GYN at Sanford Health, emphasizes the importance of early prenatal care to ensure a healthy pregnancy. Prenatal visits typically involve a review of your health history, physical exams, and various screening tests. Patients are encouraged to prepare questions and discuss any concerns with their healthcare provider. Establishing early care helps in reducing potential complications and promoting a healthy birth.

title: Sanford Health launches Flu vaccination drive in Dickinson
summary: Sanford Health is hosting flu vaccination events in Dickinson at the Sanford Health West Dickinson Clinic's Community Room, 2615 Fairway St., every Wednesday from September 20 to October 11. Vaccinations are available for adults and children aged six months and older. Appointments are recommended but not mandatory; most insurances are accepted. Bring insurance cards and wear adjustable clothing. The flu vaccine is the most effective way to protect against influenza, especially for high-risk groups. For more information or to schedule an appointment, visit mysanfordchart.org or call 701-456-6001.

title: Small-town librarian fights cancer in North Dakota
summary: Jackie Walby, a librarian in South Heart, North Dakota, was diagnosed with Stage III colon cancer after a routine check-up revealed a mass. She has been undergoing surgery and chemotherapy at Sanford Health. Despite the challenges, Walby receives strong support from her community and healthcare providers. Her treatment includes traveling to Sanford Bismarck for surgery and receiving chemotherapy at a closer clinic in Dickinson, reducing travel time. The local community has rallied around her, raising funds and offering emotional support. Walby is nearing the end of her treatment and looks forward to celebrating her final chemotherapy session by ringing the bell, a symbolic gesture for cancer patients. Her story highlights the importance of community support and accessible rural healthcare.

title: After more than a decade, ASCO sells CancerLinQ to ConcertAI
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) has sold its real-world data and quality of care technology service, CancerLinQ, to ConcertAI, a company specializing in real-world evidence and generative AI. The sale, announced on December 11, 2023, aims to provide CancerLinQ with the necessary resources to succeed, which ASCO could not sustain alone. Despite the sale, ASCO will continue to collaborate with ConcertAI, ensuring access to the data for future use. ConcertAI plans to invest $250 million in cancer informatics, leveraging CancerLinQ’s extensive network of cancer centers and patient records. All CancerLinQ staff will be offered positions at ConcertAI.

title: Abramson Cancer Center Researchers Receive Top ASCO Awards
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: Two researchers from the Penn Medicine Abramson Cancer Center, Angela DeMichele, MD, and Carmen Guerra, MD, have received prestigious awards from the American Society for Clinical Oncology (ASCO). Dr. DeMichele, recognized for her significant contributions to breast cancer research, received the Gianni Bonadonna Breast Cancer Award. Her work includes the development of palbociclib, a targeted therapy for certain breast cancers. Dr. Guerra was honored with the ASCO Excellence in Equity Award for her efforts in promoting equity, diversity, and inclusion in oncology, including programs that increased Black patient participation in clinical trials. Both awards will be presented at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting in Chicago.

title: ASCO Congratulates 2023 Special Awards Recipients
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: ASCO and Conquer Cancer will honor researchers, patient advocates, philanthropists, teachers, and global oncology leaders at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting in Chicago for their contributions to cancer care. The awardees include Monica M. Bertagnolli, Deborah Schrag, Hans Wildiers, Hagop M. Kantarjian, Carmen E. Guerra, David Gerson Poplack, Angela DeMichele, Patrick J. Loehrer, Sr, Jane Perlmutter, Colonel (Ret) James E. Williams, Jr, Peter C. Adamson, Alan Ashworth, Declan Walsh, Carolyn D. Runowicz, and Maria T. Bourlon. These individuals have significantly advanced cancer research, treatment, and patient advocacy, and their achievements will be recognized with various prestigious awards. The awards highlight their dedication to improving cancer care and patient outcomes globally.

title: Hudis: ASCO had the vision, but was low on resources CancerLinQ required
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) initiated CancerLinQ, a real-world data and quality of care technology service, inspired by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Despite limited resources, ASCO's vision was to utilize electronic medical records to consolidate data and improve cancer care. Initially, CancerLinQ faced significant technical and financial challenges. Over the years, it evolved into a unique non-profit venture, integrating data from over 100 cancer centers and 10 EMR systems. On December 11, 2023, ASCO announced the acquisition of CancerLinQ by ConcertAI, a company specializing in real-world evidence and generative AI. This acquisition aims to enhance CancerLinQ's mission and provide better services to oncology practices and patients.

title: Dr Dulal bags ASCO Global Oncology Young Investigator Award [ASCO GOYIA]
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: Dr. Soniya Dulal, a Nepali medical oncologist, has been awarded the ASCO Global Oncology Young Investigator Award (ASCO GOYIA) 2023 by the American Society of Clinical Oncology and the Conquer Cancer Foundation. The award, which includes a $50,000 grant, recognizes her research on the clinical and molecular characterization of breast cancer among different ethnic groups in Nepal. Dr. Dulal is the first Nepalese recipient of this award and the ASCO merit Award for best abstract. She expressed her happiness in conducting pioneering research on breast cancer in Nepalese women in collaboration with Princess Margaret Cancer Center in Toronto, Canada. Dr. Dulal is also noted for receiving the UICC Technical Fellowship Award in 2019 and is a Life Member of the Association of UICC Fellows. She has presented her research at various international conferences and participated in ESMO meetings.

title: Dr. Richard Boxer appointed to National Cancer Advisory Board
hco: CONQUER CANCER FOUNDATION OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY
summary: President Biden has appointed Dr. Richard Boxer to the National Cancer Advisory Board, which guides the National Cancer Institute's research direction. Dr. Boxer is a clinical professor of urology at UCLA's David Geffen School of Medicine and has developed telemedicine protocols, including a tele-urology clinic. A three-time cancer survivor, he has served as an attending urologist at Veterans Affairs hospitals in Los Angeles and Miami for 16 years. Additionally, Dr. Boxer has been a health policy advisor to the White House and represented the U.S. at the World Health Organization. He recently served on the board of directors of the American Society of Clinical Oncology’s Conquer Cancer foundation.

title: Low to be honored by American Lung Association for cancer-fighting invention - Research at Purdue
summary: Purdue University researcher Philip Low will be honored by the American Lung Association in Indiana on April 13 for his invention of CYTALUX, a fluorescent marker that aids in the surgical removal of lung cancer cells. Low, a distinguished professor at Purdue, developed CYTALUX to help surgeons identify and remove all malignant cells, crucial for lung cancer patient survival. The FDA-approved marker is a significant advancement in lung cancer treatment. Low will receive the Legacy Award at the association's annual gala, recognizing his contributions to ending lung cancer. He is also the founder of On Target Laboratories, which licensed CYTALUX's intellectual property from Purdue. Low's work has led to over 700 patents and the creation of seven companies. The gala aims to raise funds and awareness for lung cancer. The American Lung Association focuses on improving lung health and preventing lung disease through research, education, and advocacy.

title: American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb underway at Soldier Field
summary: The American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb is taking place at Soldier Field, Chicago. Celebrating its 15th anniversary, this event involves participants climbing nearly 2,000 stairs to raise funds for lung disease research and cleaner air initiatives. The fundraiser aims to collect $442,000, with over 70% already achieved. WGN’s Lourdes Duarte, Alyssa Donovan, and Courtney Spinelli are among those participating. Donations can still be made at action.lung.org.

title: American Lung Association in Hawaii hosts annual Outstanding Mother Awards
summary: The American Lung Association in Hawaii hosted its annual Outstanding Mother Awards. Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer deaths in women, with rates increasing by nearly 80% over the past 40 years.

title: Worst U.S. cities for air pollution ranked in new American Lung Association report
summary: The American Lung Association's latest "State of the Air" report reveals that nearly 39% of Americans live in areas with unhealthy air pollution levels, a significant increase from previous years. This report, based on data from 2020 to 2022, highlights the adverse effects of wildfire smoke and ozone on air quality. Bakersfield, California, tops the list for worst particle pollution, followed by several other cities in California, Oregon, and Arizona. Los Angeles remains the worst for ozone pollution. The report underscores the disproportionate impact on communities of color and notes that climate change exacerbates air quality issues despite regulatory efforts.

title: Asthma Awareness Month: American Lung Association Focuses on Addressing Challenges of Extreme Heat and Asthma
summary: May is Asthma Awareness Month, and the American Lung Association is focusing on the challenges posed by extreme heat due to climate change. Asthma, a chronic lung disease affecting over 26 million Americans, can be exacerbated by high temperatures, leading to increased hospitalizations and deaths. The Association aims to educate healthcare professionals and asthma patients on managing asthma during extreme weather through various resources, including professional courses, free online education, and support networks. They also advocate for legislative support to enhance asthma control programs and encourage donations to support ongoing research and initiatives.

title: American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb underway at Soldier Field
summary: The American Lung Association's Fight for Air Climb at Soldier Field is taking place on Sunday morning. WGN has a team participating in the event, which involves climbing stairs and raising funds. This fundraiser, now in its 15th year, aims to support individuals with lung diseases and advocate for cleaner air.

title: Olympus Partners with American Lung Association on Patient Education for Lung Cancer Screening
summary: Olympus Corporation of the Americas has partnered with the American Lung Association to enhance patient education on lung cancer screening. This collaboration aims to provide lung cancer patients with comprehensive resources on lung nodule diagnosis and staging, available on Lung.org. Accurate staging is crucial for precise treatment, and early detection significantly improves survival rates. Olympus supports these educational efforts to empower patients to make informed decisions about their care. The company has pioneered technologies like endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA), aiding in targeted cancer treatments such as immunotherapy.

title: American Lung Association and LUNGevity Foundation Announce $3 Million Research Partnership to Intercept Lung ...
summary: The American Lung Association and LUNGevity Foundation have announced a $3 million research partnership aimed at intercepting lung cancer. This collaboration focuses on early detection and intervention to prevent precancerous cells from developing into cancer. Leading scientists, including Dr. Avrum Spira and Dr. Steven Dubinett, will use advanced technologies like robot-assisted bronchoscopy to collect samples and study the molecular and immune mechanisms of lung cancer. The partnership builds on previous successful collaborations and aims to significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for lung cancer patients. The initiative seeks to revolutionize lung cancer treatment through early detection and personalized care.

title: New Report Highlights Benefits of California Clean Air Policies
summary: The American Lung Association's report, "Living and Breathing in California: Health Benefits of Clean Air Programs," highlights the significant health benefits of California's recently approved clean air policies. These policies, targeting on-road vehicles, off-road equipment, and other pollution sources, are projected to save over 20,000 lives and provide $200 billion in public health benefits by 2050. The report emphasizes the need for robust implementation and continued investment in clean air and zero-emission transportation infrastructure. The policies are particularly beneficial for low-income and minority communities, reducing cancer risks and other health disparities. The American Lung Association urges state and federal support to ensure these policies achieve their full potential.

title: Scientists Discover Surprising Details about Xylazine in Combination with Fentanyl | Newsroom
hco: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL
summary: Scientists at the UNC School of Medicine, led by Zoe McElligott, PhD, discovered that xylazine, an animal tranquilizer, activates kappa opioid receptors in the brain, similar to how fentanyl activates opioid receptors. This finding explains why naloxone, a treatment for opioid overdose, triggers severe withdrawal symptoms in individuals using fentanyl combined with xylazine. Previously, xylazine was thought to only bind to α2-adrenergic receptors. The research, published in Addiction Neuroscience, highlights the need for different strategies to manage withdrawal symptoms from fentanyl and xylazine. The study involved rigorous experiments with mice and collaboration with other researchers, including Bryan L. Roth, MD, PhD, who confirmed xylazine's action on kappa opioid receptors. This discovery has significant implications for future drug scheduling and treatment approaches.

title: EveryLife Foundation Announces Scientific Workshop on 'Ultra-Rare' Diseases
summary: The EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases has announced a Scientific Workshop on 'Ultra-Rare' Diseases to be held on May 21, 2024, in Washington, D.C., with virtual and in-person attendance options. The workshop will address the challenges in developing therapies for ultra-rare diseases and explore the need for a formal definition. Despite legislative efforts like the Orphan Drug Act, many rare diseases lack FDA-approved treatments. The event aims to discuss therapy development hurdles, regulatory processes, and funding, and to evaluate current disparities in therapy development. Experts from various sectors will participate to inform policy and regulatory frameworks. Registration is free, and media inquiries are welcome. The Foundation advocates for policies that foster innovation and remove barriers to treatments for rare disease patients.

title: ‘Empowering': Rare Disease Week on Capitol Hill to draw calls for change
summary: Rare Disease Week on Capitol Hill aims to advocate for better healthcare access for rare disease patients. Participants, including patients like Nell Choi, seek to reform "fail first" insurance policies, promote the Accelerating Kids' Access to Care Act, and reauthorize the Rare Pediatric Disease Priority Review Voucher Program. The event, hosted by the Rare Disease Legislative Advocates, part of the EveryLife Foundation, brings together over 700 advocates to share their stories and push for legislative changes. Key priorities include improving cross-state care access for children on Medicaid and addressing step therapy protocols.

title: Early Rare Disease Diagnosis Could Save as Much as $500000 per Patient
summary: New research by the EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases highlights that early diagnosis of rare diseases could save up to $500,000 per patient. The study analyzed costs associated with seven rare diseases, including adrenoleukodystrophy and Duchenne muscular dystrophy. It found that early intervention, particularly through newborn screening, can significantly reduce medical costs and productivity losses, ranging from $86,000 to $517,000 per patient. Timely diagnosis can prevent prolonged diagnostic processes and improve health outcomes by enabling early, optimal treatments. The findings underscore the need for faster diagnostic strategies and broader rare disease screening for newborns, which have shown substantial economic and health benefits, as evidenced by initiatives like California's Project Baby Bear. The study builds on previous research indicating the extensive financial and personal impact of delayed diagnoses on families and the healthcare system.

title: Bipartisan team proposes legislation to improve access to off-label drugs
summary: A bipartisan team of congressional representatives has proposed the Providing Realistic Opportunity To Equal and Comparable Treatment for Rare (PROTECT Rare) Act, aimed at improving access to off-label drugs for people with rare disorders like cold agglutinin disease (CAD). The act, endorsed by several rare disease advocacy organizations, would allow Medicare and Medicaid to consider data beyond FDA approval, such as peer-reviewed studies and clinical guidelines, for coverage decisions. It also mandates private insurers to expedite reviews for formulary exceptions and appeals for rare disease treatments. This legislation seeks to alleviate the burden on patients, particularly those in underserved communities, by ensuring access to necessary off-label treatments, which are often not covered by health insurance despite their proven benefits.
