title: EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases Welcomes Michael Pearlmutter as CEO
summary: The EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases has appointed Michael Pearlmutter as its new CEO. Pearlmutter brings over 13 years of leadership experience, notably from the Cerebral Palsy Alliance Research Foundation (CPARF), where he significantly expanded research and fundraising efforts. His appointment aligns with EveryLife Foundation's vision to double its budget and reach within the next 5-7 years, focusing on innovative science policies, including gene and cell therapies, and the use of AI and big data. Pearlmutter's personal experience with a rare disease enhances his commitment to the foundation's mission. The foundation aims to advocate for policies that foster innovation and remove barriers to life-saving treatments for rare disease patients.

title: California medical geneticist treats ultra-rare disorders
summary: Dr. Emil Kakkis, a California medical geneticist, focuses on treating ultra-rare diseases, conditions affecting fewer than 6,000 people. Inspired by his family's legacy of service, Kakkis developed an enzyme-replacement therapy for mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS1) with Dr. Elizabeth Neufeld at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center. Despite initial funding challenges, Kakkis' breakthrough came when the Ryan Foundation, created by the parents of an MPS1 patient, funded his trial. The successful treatment led to FDA approval, transforming the life of patient Ryan Dant, who now leads a normal adult life. Kakkis founded Ultragenyx, a biopharmaceutical company, and the EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases to advocate for science-driven legislation. He emphasizes the importance of fighting for equitable treatment for rare disease patients, celebrating the advancements in rare disease treatments.

title: Millburn High School Junior Receives National Teen RareVoice Award by the EveryLife Foundation
summary: Samantha Rose, a junior at Millburn High School and resident of Short Hills, received the 2023 National Teen RareVoice Award by the EveryLife Foundation for Rare Diseases. This award recognizes her exceptional advocacy efforts in the rare disease community, particularly her impact on policy changes improving the lives of rare disease patients. Inspired by her mother’s battle with Complex Regional Pain Syndrome, Rose has been actively involved in advocacy, including serving on the Board of Education Liaison Committee, and raising over $26,000 for the Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy Syndrome Association. She has also participated in congressional advocacy and biomedical research, combining her passion for science with her commitment to making a difference.

title: Senator Amy Klobuchar raising awareness on rare diseases
summary: Senator Amy Klobuchar is raising awareness about rare diseases affecting Americans. In a virtual press conference, she was joined by representatives from Mayo Clinic and the Every-Life Foundation for Rare Diseases. Klobuchar highlighted that over 10,000 rare diseases impact 30 million Americans, but the FDA has approved treatments for fewer than 5% of them. She praised Mayo Clinic's leadership in personal medicine and its ability to identify rare disorders, emphasizing the importance of spreading this expertise to unlock the mysteries of rare diseases and find treatments. Rare disease advocate Abbey Hauser, who has Classical Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, also participated. Klobuchar serves as the Co-Chair of the Rare Disease Congressional Caucus.

title: Orange County Meals on Wheels Kicks Off 'March for Meals'
summary: Orange County Meals on Wheels has launched its annual "March for Meals" campaign to raise awareness and support for its services. Volunteer Madeline Mitchell delivers meals every Monday in Chapel Hill, emphasizing the importance of both nutrition and social interaction for the elderly. Executive Director Rachel Bearman highlights that many people are unaware of the diverse needs of the aging population unless they participate in delivery routes. The mission of Meals on Wheels extends beyond providing food; it also aims to reduce social isolation among seniors. The campaign encourages community leaders and volunteers to join delivery routes to better understand and support the organization's work.

title: Caron Trumbo left the Roanoke Valley to find a job in biotech. Now she's an evangelist for its growing biotech sector.
summary: Caron Trumbo, vice president for operations at the Virginia Biotechnology Association, is a key advocate for Roanoke's burgeoning biotech sector. After leaving Roanoke Valley to pursue education and career opportunities in biotech, Trumbo returned to find a transformed professional landscape. The region now boasts significant advancements, including the Verge alliance, Fralin Biomedical Research Institute, and increased municipal support. Virginia Bio, where Trumbo works, plays a crucial role in fostering biosciences statewide. Trumbo's efforts, along with those of other leaders, have significantly contributed to the region's growth in biotech and life sciences, making it an attractive hub for scientific research and innovation.

title: Virginia Bio-Connect - The Success of Virginia’s First Statewide Collaborative Life Sciences Initiative
summary: Virginia Bio-Connect, Virginia's first statewide collaborative life sciences initiative, concluded successfully at the end of 2023. Launched in April 2021, it was funded by the Virginia Growth and Opportunity Foundation and led by the Virginia Biotechnology Association. The initiative aimed to foster a more connected life sciences ecosystem, support early-stage companies, and drive workforce development. Collaboration among the five regional BioHubs (Charlottesville, Coastal Virginia, Northern Virginia, Greater Richmond, and Roanoke/Blacksburg/Lynchburg) was key. The project introduced the STEM2VA internship program, hosted networking events, and created a resource portal. It also established a life science mentorship program, which has already helped create new companies and jobs. The initiative’s success is attributed to the collaborative efforts and will continue beyond the grant through sustained partnerships and funding.

title: Big Pharma pushes Youngkin to veto bill establishing a Prescription Drug Affordability Board
summary: Big pharmaceutical companies are pressuring Virginia Governor Glenn Youngkin to veto House Bill 570 and Senate Bill 274, which aim to establish a Prescription Drug Affordability Board (PDAB) to review and limit prescription drug costs. Youngkin, who campaigned on reducing drug prices, faces a decision by April 8. Despite strong public support for the PDAB, pharmaceutical companies argue it would hinder investment in drug research and development. They have contributed significantly to Youngkin's political campaigns. In response, community groups and legislators have launched the "Make Medicine Affordable" campaign to advocate for the bills. If signed, Virginia would join seven other states with similar boards.

title: Biotechnology trade groups urged Youngkin to veto bills creating a Prescription Drug Affordability Board in Virginia
summary: Biotechnology trade groups in Virginia are urging Governor Glenn Youngkin to veto bills that propose the creation of a Prescription Drug Affordability Board. The board would have the authority to cap medication prices if deemed excessively high. Delegate Karrie Delaney, who authored the House bill, argues that this initiative could provide significant savings for Virginians. However, the Virginia Biotechnology Association contends that such a board would hinder investment in research and development and potentially limit access to existing medications. Delaney refutes these concerns, suggesting that pharmaceutical companies often spend more on marketing than on drug production. Governor Youngkin has yet to review the letter from the association but will consider any legislation that reaches his desk.

title: 3 Reasons You Can't Miss This Year's BioHealth Capital Region’s 2023 Events This September
summary: The BioHealth Capital Region is hosting several key events this September at the US Pharmacopeia in Rockville, MD. The 9th Annual Forum, 8th Annual Crab Trap Competition, and 6th Annual Investment Forum will feature industry leaders discussing topics like bio-ecosystem growth, international partnerships, and biomanufacturing. The Crab Trap Competition on September 20 will showcase innovative health solutions, attracting global applicants and esteemed judges. On September 21, the Investment Conference will offer a platform for investment and partnerships, bringing together entrepreneurs and investors to explore funding opportunities from pre-seed to Series A. These events provide unparalleled networking, learning, and investment opportunities in the biohealth industry.

title: Mozart Therapeutics Presents Preclinical Data for MTX-101, a Novel Bispecific CD8 Treg Modulator for Treatment of ...
summary: Mozart Therapeutics presented preclinical data for MTX-101, a novel bispecific CD8 Treg modulator for treating autoimmune diseases, at the American College of Rheumatology Convergence 2023. The data showed that CD8 Treg cells in rheumatological autoimmune diseases exhibit decreased functional protein expression and reduced responsiveness compared to healthy donors. MTX-101 selectively binds to CD8 Treg cells, enhancing their ability to kill self-reactive CD4 T cells by blocking inhibitory KIR. This prevents self-reactive CD4 T cell expansion and inflammation without unwanted immune activation or increased pro-inflammatory cytokines. Non-clinical safety studies indicated that MTX-101 is well-tolerated at doses up to 50 mg/kg. The findings support MTX-101's potential in treating autoimmune diseases by restoring CD8 Treg function and reestablishing immune balance.

title: Diana Abdueva, PhD: Novel Blood-Based Assay Differentiates Seropositive and Seronegative Rheumatoid Arthritis ...
summary: Diana Abdueva, PhD, CEO and founder of Aqtual, presented a novel blood-based assay at the American College of Rheumatology’s 2023 Convergence. This assay differentiates seropositive and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA) from healthy individuals and those with other inflammatory diseases or osteoarthritis. Abdueva highlighted the challenge of selecting appropriate RA therapies due to economic burdens and the trial-and-error process. On average, RA patients change therapy every 8 months, indicating a need for predictive biomarkers. Aqtual aims to develop the first test for RA therapy selection across multiple drug classes, with ongoing clinical trials and a vision to launch by Q1 2025. The company also plans to expand into other autoimmune conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease and lupus, integrating patient-reported outcomes into their development cycle.

title: New Tool for Managing Nociplastic Pain in People With Rheumatic Diseases
summary: A review in Arthritis Care & Research highlights strategies for managing nociplastic pain in patients with rheumatic diseases. Nociplastic pain, characterized by altered nociceptive processing, often accompanies conditions like fibromyalgia and irritable bowel syndrome. The review emphasizes the importance of patient education, validating pain experiences, and understanding that pain may not always stem from inflammation. Pharmacologic treatments with some evidence include low-dose tricyclic antidepressants, SNRIs, and gabapentinoids. Non-pharmacologic interventions such as exercise, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and sleep improvement are recommended. Social support and tracking self-management behaviors are also crucial for effective pain management.

title: Management Guidelines | Rheumatoid Arthritis | Clinical Guidance
summary: Management guidelines for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) emphasize early diagnosis and treatment to reduce radiographic damage, disability, and overall care costs. Early and aggressive interventions can improve morbidity and mortality rates. Traditional treatment paradigms, like the 'therapeutic pyramid,' have shifted to more aggressive and early use of therapies such as methotrexate (MTX), combination therapy, or tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors. Early referral to a rheumatologist is crucial for accurate diagnosis and effective treatment. Initial therapy often includes NSAIDs and corticosteroids, with DMARDs introduced if symptoms persist. Disease/risk stratification helps tailor treatment, with aggressive RA requiring prompt and intensive management. The "treat-to-target" strategy aims for remission or low disease activity by adjusting therapy based on disease activity. Updated ACR and EULAR guidelines provide comprehensive recommendations for pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic management, emphasizing the importance of vaccination in patients with RA.

title: ACR Guidelines for Integrative Approaches to Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis
summary: The American College of Rheumatology (ACR) has released new guidelines for integrative treatments for rheumatoid arthritis (RA), complementing existing pharmacological recommendations. These guidelines emphasize the importance of exercise, rehabilitation, diet, and other integrative interventions alongside disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). The recommendations include 28 integrative interventions, with only one being strong and the rest conditional. Key areas covered are exercise (aerobic, aquatic, resistance-based, mind-body), rehabilitation (occupational and physical therapy), and diet (Mediterranean-style). Additional recommendations include self-management programs, cognitive behavioral therapy, massage, acupuncture, and thermal modalities. Chiropractic therapy and electrotherapy are conditionally discouraged. The guidelines are designed to support shared decision-making between patients and clinicians.

title: 2022 ACR Guideline Update for the Prevention and Treatment of Glucocorticoid-Induced Osteoporosis
summary: The 2022 ACR guidelines update for preventing and treating glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIOP) includes new medications, abaloparatide and romosozumab, and details on combination and sequential therapies. Recommendations include fracture risk assessment for adults on glucocorticoid therapy, risk stratification, and tailored treatment strategies. For those on glucocorticoids, maintaining adequate calcium and vitamin D intake, engaging in weight-bearing exercises, and avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol are advised. The guidelines emphasize reassessment of fracture risk every 1-2 years and continuing osteoporosis therapy for high-risk individuals. Special considerations are provided for populations at very-high risk and those discontinuing glucocorticoid therapy.

title: UWI Alumna Becomes First Black Woman Named Master of the American College of Rheumatology
summary: Dr. Gail S. Kerr, a University of the West Indies (UWI) alumna, has become the first Black woman to be named a Master of the American College of Rheumatology. Her achievement was highlighted by UWI's Director of Alumni Relations, Celia Davidson-Francis, and celebrated by UWI Chancellor Emeritus Sir George Alleyne. Dr. Kerr, a distinguished student who graduated with honors and received several academic awards, completed her postgraduate training in the U.S. and Jamaica. She is currently the Chief of Rheumatology at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center and Howard University Hospital in Washington, D.C. Dr. Kerr's research focuses on systemic vasculitis, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and spondyloarthritides. She has been recognized for her efforts to reduce health disparities among ethnic minorities and has received numerous awards. Dr. Kerr continues to support her alma maters and participates in various professional and community activities.

title: The insidious US measles resurgence should terrify us all
summary: The resurgence of measles in the U.S. is alarming, with cases in early 2024 being 17 times higher than the previous three years' average. Measles, a highly contagious and potentially deadly disease, was nearly eradicated in the U.S. but is making a comeback due to low vaccination rates. Vulnerable groups include young children, pregnant women, and immunocompromised individuals. The Adult Vaccine Access Coalition urges Congress to increase funding for the CDC’s National Immunization Program to $1.6 billion to strengthen vaccine infrastructure and prevent outbreaks. Vaccine skepticism and barriers to adult immunization exacerbate the issue. The consequences of not addressing this resurgence could be severe, with high treatment costs and preventable suffering.

title: Patricia D'Antonio
summary: Patricia M. D’Antonio is the Vice President of Policy and Professional Affairs for The Gerontological Society of America (GSA) and a board-certified geriatric pharmacist. She directs GSA’s policy initiatives, develops relationships with aging organizations, and represents GSA on multiple policy coalitions. D’Antonio co-chairs the Adult Vaccine Access Coalition, presides over the Protecting Access to Pain Relief board, and serves on several federally focused coalitions. She is also the Executive Director for the National Center to Reframe Aging, which aims to improve public perceptions of aging. Additionally, she is part of the leadership team for the Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research National Coordinating Center, supporting diverse researchers in aging and health disparities. Before GSA, she was the Executive Director for the District of Columbia Board of Pharmacy and Program Manager for the Pharmaceutical Control Division. She holds degrees from Duquesne University and Temple University, with a residency at The Philadelphia Geriatric Center.

title: Payer Considerations for RSV Vaccine Coverage
summary: Experts discuss the financial considerations for RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus) vaccine coverage from a payer perspective. They emphasize the importance of proactive measures for early vaccine coverage, especially if the RSV season peaks earlier than usual. The FDA is expected to review RSV vaccine candidates soon, with ACIP recommendations anticipated to influence coverage guidelines. Medicare coverage, particularly under Part B and Part D, plays a significant role in vaccine accessibility. Advocates push for equal access through both parts to reduce barriers and promote health equity. The discussion highlights the complexities of Medicare navigation and the need for broader access to ensure patients can receive vaccinations comfortably and conveniently.

title: University of Colorado Denver | Anschutz Medical Campus Regains Hispanic-Serving Status
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The University of Colorado Denver | Anschutz Medical Campus has regained its Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) status from the U.S. Department of Education, a designation initially announced in 2021. This status is held by fewer than 600 institutions nationwide and requires at least 25% Hispanic undergraduate full-time enrollment. As the fourth institution in Colorado and the only R1 institution in the Rocky Mountain Region to achieve this status, CU Denver | Anschutz is now eligible for various grant opportunities aimed at student success and faculty support. The designation enables the campus to receive federal grants for minority-serving institutions and gives faculty an advantage when applying for other federal grants. This follows a significant funding announcement by the Biden-Harris administration to support Hispanic and Latino students. Chancellor Donald M. Elliman highlighted the importance of this designation in fostering future health leaders who represent diverse communities.

title: The University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus Selects Dr. John H. Sampson as Dean of the School of Medicine ...
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: Dr. John H. Sampson has been appointed as the new Dean of the School of Medicine and Vice Chancellor for Health Affairs at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, effective July 1, 2024. Sampson, previously the senior vice president of Duke University Health System and Duke Health Integrated Practice, brings over two decades of clinical and academic leadership. He succeeds Dr. John J. Reilly, Jr., who led the institution through significant growth and innovation during his nine-year tenure. Sampson's extensive background includes nearly 300 peer-reviewed publications and recognition as the highest NIH-funded investigator in his field.

title: CU Anschutz names new dean of medicine
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: John Sampson, currently a senior vice president at Duke University Health System, has been appointed as the new dean of the School of Medicine at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, starting July 1. He will also serve as vice chancellor for health affairs. Sampson, who is a distinguished professor of neurosurgery, has authored nearly 300 peer-reviewed publications and is a leading NIH-funded investigator in his field. He succeeds John Reilly, who is retiring after nine years. The Anschutz campus includes two major hospitals and numerous health professional schools, handling over 2 million patient visits annually.

title: Partnership Forms to Explore Quantum Computing for Healthcare
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus (CU Anschutz) and Atom Computing have partnered to explore quantum computing applications in healthcare. This collaboration aims to leverage quantum computing to address complex healthcare challenges, such as improving access to medical facilities in underserved regions, enhancing AI and machine learning for rare condition detection, and predicting drug effectiveness. Both organizations are part of Colorado’s Elevate Quantum, a federally designated Regional Technology Hub. Through workshops, CU Anschutz scientists are learning to program Atom’s quantum hardware, while Atom’s team gains insights into healthcare applications. This partnership represents a significant step toward advancing biomedical innovation and improving healthcare through quantum computing.

title: Palantir Partners with University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus to Establish the All of Us Research Program's ...
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: Palantir Technologies has partnered with the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus to create the Center for Linkage and Acquisition of Data (CLAD) as part of the NIH's All of Us Research Program. This initiative aims to enhance scientific discoveries and precision medicine by integrating diverse data types with participant information. The collaboration will securely process and link health care claims, mortality data, and environmental data to improve understanding of health and disease. Palantir’s software will ensure data security and quality, facilitating the research program's goals. The partnership builds on previous collaborations and aims to improve health outcomes through advanced data integration and analysis.

title: Earth Day Celebration - Sustainability
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The University of Colorado Denver and the CU Anschutz Medical Campus emphasize sustainability to ensure resource availability for future generations. Key initiatives include waste diversion, emission reduction, and environmental education. Upcoming events like Bike to Work Day on June 26th and Earth Day on April 22nd promote community engagement in sustainability efforts. The campus has significantly reduced its carbon footprint by replacing metal halide fixtures with LED lighting, enhancing efficiency and safety. Additionally, a free e-waste recycling event will be held for Earth Day 2024. The university's commitment to sustainability extends to various programs and challenges aimed at conserving energy, water, and fuel. For more information or to get involved, contact Jarrett Smith, the Sustainability Manager.

title: Researchers Describe Tools to Better Understand CaMKII, a Protein Involved in Brain and Heart Disease
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: Researchers at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus have identified three classes of drug inhibitors that can mitigate the harmful effects of the protein CaMKII, which is implicated in Alzheimer's disease and heart conditions. Published in Cell Reports, their study provides a comprehensive overview of CaMKII and its inhibitors, aiming to make these tools accessible to a broad range of scientists. CaMKII is essential in learning and memory but can cause problems if misregulated. Previous research by the team showed that inhibiting CaMKII can protect against the effects of amyloid-beta plaques in Alzheimer's. The review offers insights and guidelines for non-specialists to understand and utilize these inhibitors, potentially advancing the treatment of brain diseases.

title: First Lady Visits Ludeman Family Center for Women’s Health Research
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: First Lady Jill Biden visited the Ludeman Family Center for Women’s Health Research at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus on April 20, 2024. The visit highlighted the importance of research in women’s health and sex differences, part of the White House Initiative on Women’s Health Research. Biden emphasized the historical underfunding and understudy of women’s health. Colorado Lt. Gov. Dianne Primavera and Aurora Mayor Mike Coffman joined Biden in a roundtable discussion. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Ludeman Center focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and mental health, impacting women's health significantly. The center has funded over 100 researchers and invested nearly $3 million in research. Researchers discussed the disparities in treatments and outcomes for women, particularly in diabetes and heart failure. The initiative aims to further support and raise awareness of women's health research.

title: Forbes Ranks the University of Colorado Denver | Anschutz Medical Campus Among America’s Best Employers
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The University of Colorado Denver | Anschutz Medical Campus has been ranked among Forbes America’s Best Large Employers for 2024. This recognition highlights the campus's commitment to providing exceptional patient care, leading research and innovation, and a supportive learning environment. Factors evaluated included benefits, employee recognition, opportunities for advancement, and workplace pride. Adrienne Howarth-Moore emphasized the importance of investing in employees. Teri Engelke acknowledged the progress made towards making CU Denver a top workplace. The University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus is a leading academic medical campus, while CU Denver offers a wide range of degree programs and contributes substantially to the Colorado economy.

title: CU Anschutz Moves Up in This Year’s U.S. News & World Report Rankings
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus has achieved significant improvements in the 2024-2025 U.S. News & World Report rankings. The CU Skaggs School of Pharmacy advanced five places to 15th among 141 programs, placing it in the top 10% nationally. The Colorado School of Public Health rose to 16th, up from 17th, reflecting steady progress since its founding in 2008. The CU College of Nursing’s online Master’s in Nursing program tied for 14th place, with its Midwifery program ranked 3rd. The CU Physical Therapy program moved up two spots to 11th out of 245 programs. These rankings underscore the university's commitment to excellence in education, research, and healthcare.

title: The Colorado Center for Personalized Medicine Highlighted as a Leader in Precision Medicine in Research and Clinical Care
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: The Colorado Center for Personalized Medicine (CCPM) at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, in partnership with UCHealth, has been recognized for its leadership in precision medicine. A recent study in the American Journal of Human Genetics highlights CCPM's achievements in using genetic information to advance both research and clinical care. CCPM has returned genetic results to over 30,000 patients, aiding in personalized treatment plans. The center's biobank includes over 235,000 participants and supports extensive research in genomics. CCPM's work in pharmacogenomics helps tailor medication choices based on genetic profiles, improving patient outcomes in various medical fields. The center aims to expand its participant base to enhance genomic data and health outcomes through national and international collaborations.

title: Finding Balance
hco: UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO ANSCHUTZ MEDICAL CAMPUS
summary: Emily Fivekiller, a student at the University of Colorado College of Nursing, has managed to balance her education, work, and volunteering despite a challenging upbringing. Growing up homeless in rural California, she was inspired to pursue a career in healthcare by compassionate care providers at free clinics. Initially aiming to become a doctor, she earned a BA in biology and a Master’s in Public Health. Working as a senior clinical scientist at the Barbara Davis Center, the COVID-19 pandemic reignited her passion for nursing. Enrolled in the Traditional (TRAD) program, she balances her job and studies, appreciating the program's flexibility. Fivekiller also volunteers at the DAWN Clinic, which serves underserved patients, and emphasizes the importance of adapting learning methods and seeking help from faculty. Her story highlights resilience and dedication to both her professional and personal growth.

title: Do You Have Achy Joints? These Foods Or Drinks Could Be To Blame.
summary: Certain foods can exacerbate arthritis and joint pain due to their inflammatory properties. Dr. Grace Wright and Dr. Francisco Contreras recommend minimizing ultra-processed foods and drinks, cured or processed meats, fried foods, gluten (for those sensitive), and alcohol. These items can trigger inflammation, worsening symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and gout. Conversely, an anti-inflammatory diet rich in leafy greens, nuts, fatty fish, and fruits like berries and oranges is beneficial. The Mediterranean diet, which includes whole grains, vegetables, and unprocessed foods while minimizing meat and processed foods, is particularly effective. This diet not only helps manage joint pain but also promotes overall health, reducing the risk of chronic diseases like heart disease and diabetes.

title: Are Breast Implants a Problem if You're Getting a Mammogram?
summary: Breast implants do not pose a problem when getting a mammogram, according to Dr. Ariane Martinez, a diagnostic radiologist at Baptist Health Miami Cancer Institute. Women with implants should follow the same annual screening recommendations starting at age 40, or earlier if at higher risk. Christina McDonald, a mammography clinical specialist, emphasizes that women with implants should still get regular mammograms, which involve eight views instead of the usual four. Minimal compression is used to avoid discomfort. Women should inform scheduling staff about their implants for appropriate appointment timing. Monthly self-breast exams are crucial, starting at age 20, to detect any changes or new lumps. Annual mammograms remain essential for early detection, and additional screening tools are available if needed. Baptist Health supports women through their breast health journey, offering mammograms at various diagnostic locations.

title: In pilot, generative AI expected to reduce clinical documentation time at Baptist Health
summary: Baptist Health South Florida is piloting a generative AI system to reduce clinical documentation time, particularly for cardiologists who face significant documentation burdens. The AI integrates medical transcription technology with large language models to generate clinical notes quickly from patient conversations. This system aims to cut documentation time to just two to five minutes post-visit, enhancing clinical productivity and reducing provider burnout. The AI solution, which leverages AWS HealthScribe, Azure OpenAI, Snowflake, and DataRobot, is expected to offer time savings, improved productivity, and cost efficiency. Clinicians verify the AI-generated summaries to ensure accuracy, maintaining the integrity of patient records.

title: Fujitsu and Baptist Health South Florida transform operating room scheduling with newly launched solution to boost ...
summary: Fujitsu and Baptist Health South Florida have introduced a solution to improve operating room (OR) scheduling, enhancing utilization rates and financial health in surgical services. The innovation, part of Fujitsu's Uvance Healthy Living portfolio, addresses inefficiencies in surgical block time. Leveraging Fujitsu's Digital Annealer, the solution offers a SaaS application for perioperative executives, providing tailored, data-driven recommendations to optimize OR schedules. Trials showed a 37% increase in available prime-time minutes, equating to 231 new full-day blocks. The solution includes a generative block scheduling wizard for hypothetical scenario analysis, aiding decision-making and improving patient care by reducing wait times and increasing surgery volumes.

title: Baptist Health Foundation Announces Historic $50 Million Gift from Kenneth C. Griffin
summary: Baptist Health Foundation has received a historic $50 million donation from Kenneth C. Griffin, founder of Citadel and Griffin Catalyst. This is the largest single donation in the nearly 65-year history of Baptist Health South Florida. The funds will advance neurological care and research through the expansion of the Baptist Health Miami Neuroscience Institute, including the construction of the new Kenneth C. Griffin Center. This new facility will house state-of-the-art laboratories and provide space for researchers and clinicians to collaborate, aiming to address the rising incidence of neurological diseases. The gift is expected to propel Baptist Health into a new era of clinical and research excellence, enhancing patient care and innovation in neuroscience.

title: Baptist Health Buys Dev Site Near The Shops at Pembroke Gardens
summary: Baptist Health South Florida has acquired a 4.75-acre vacant site near The Shops at Pembroke Gardens in Pembroke Pines, Florida, for $13.2 million. The nonprofit plans to develop a three-story medical facility with an emergency room and medical offices, expected to open in fall 2026. The land was formerly part of The Edison office campus, developed by TPA Group, which purchased it in 2017. This acquisition follows Baptist Health's recent sale of a 21-acre site in Homestead for $14 million.

title: Baptist Health and FIU join forces to elevate care, address doctor shortage and boost medical research in South Florida
summary: Baptist Health and Florida International University (FIU) have announced a collaboration to enhance physician training, research, and patient care in South Florida. Baptist Health, the region's largest not-for-profit healthcare system, and FIU, a public research university, aim to address the doctor shortage and elevate medical research. The partnership will see Baptist Hospital become a statutory teaching hospital, expanding medical education programs and clinical research. This collaboration builds on over a decade of joint efforts, including clinical rotations and residency programs. The alliance is expected to attract specialized physicians, advance medical care, and provide free healthcare services to underserved communities. The initiative is seen as a transformative step in reshaping healthcare in the region, with a long-term impact on medical training and research.

title: Graduate Medical Education with Baptist Health Academics
summary: Baptist Health Academics, established in 2020, aims to attract, educate, and retain exceptional healthcare talent for the South Florida community. The institution supports a variety of educational programs, including residencies, fellowships, allied health, business, medical, nursing, pharmacy, and spiritual care. They also offer student and visitor programs, such as job shadowing, externships, student rotations for school credit, scholarships, and certificate programs. Baptist Health emphasizes a culture of quality and dedication, which has earned them recognition on Fortune’s “100 Best Companies to Work For” list 20 times. Annually, they educate 9,000 students and residents and have awarded $44 million in nursing student scholarships. The majority of resident physicians, 85%, continue their careers with Baptist Health after graduation. The organization promotes life in South Florida as a vibrant, multicultural community and underscores the importance of philanthropy in enhancing patient care.

title: Baptist Health South Florida eliminates 190 jobs; fiscal 2023 earnings - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Baptist Health South Florida has eliminated 190 leadership and non-clinical positions through voluntary separation and other labor reduction measures. This move, part of efforts to avoid duplication and improve efficiency, resulted in $15 million in separation costs but is expected to save on salaries long-term. Despite these reductions, labor costs increased by 4.5% over the prior year. The hospital system reported an operating loss of $9.7 million for fiscal 2023, compared to a $4.3 million gain in 2022, largely due to reduced CARES Act funding. However, net income improved to $318.8 million from a $725.9 million loss the previous year, driven by better investment income. Revenue grew to $5.49 billion, with increases in hospital admissions, emergency room visits, and urgent care visits. Baptist Health plans $1.1 billion in capital investments over the next two years and has partnered with Florida International University for a potential clinical facility.

title: Brain & Spine Care | Baptist Health
summary: Baptist Health South Florida's Brain & Spine Care provides comprehensive neurological care through the Marcus Neuroscience Institute and Miami Neuroscience Institute. They offer advanced treatments for conditions like brain injuries, tumors, epilepsy, and Alzheimer's. The institutes utilize cutting-edge technology and research to perform minimally invasive and complex surgeries. A significant $50 million donation from Kenneth C. Griffin will fund the expansion of the Miami Neuroscience Institute, enhancing neurological care. The team includes neurologists, neurosurgeons, and pain management specialists. They participate in clinical trials to improve patient outcomes. Baptist Health is recognized for its compassionate care and award-winning facilities, offering services across Palm Beach to Miami-Dade counties. They accept a broad network of health insurance plans and provide resources for patients and healthcare professionals.

title: Lupin collaborates with Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company and COPD Foundation
summary: Mumbai-based pharma company Lupin has partnered with the US-based Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company and the COPD Foundation to improve access to medication for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients. This collaboration will make Lupin's Tiotropium Bromide Inhalation Powder, 18 mcg/capsule, more accessible to COPD patients in the US. This product is the only generic equivalent to Spiriva HandiHaler by Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals. COPD affects over 15 million adults in the US and is the fourth leading cause of death. The partnership aims to reduce the disease burden by enhancing access to essential medication.

title: Lupin Collaborates with Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company and COPD Foundation to Expand Access to Medication ...
summary: Lupin Pharmaceuticals has partnered with Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company and the COPD Foundation to improve access to medication for COPD patients in the US. This collaboration will provide Tiotropium Bromide Inhalation Powder, 18 mcg/capsule, the only generic equivalent to Spiriva® HandiHaler®, to enhance treatment affordability and availability. COPD affects over 15 million adults in the US and is the fourth leading cause of death. The initiative aims to meet the significant demand for affordable respiratory treatments. Leaders from Lupin, Cost Plus Drugs, and the COPD Foundation emphasize the importance of making medications accessible and affordable to improve patient health outcomes.

title: This COPD action plan is my weapon against exacerbations
summary: For individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), preventing exacerbations is crucial. Caroline Gainer emphasizes the importance of a COPD action plan, which includes monitoring symptoms, getting vaccinations, and being vigilant about changes in mucous secretions. The COPD Foundation and the American Lung Association offer free downloadable action plans. Gainer uses the COPD Foundation's plan to track her symptoms daily, identifying "Green Days" for normal conditions, "Yellow Days" for problematic symptoms requiring action, and "Red Days" for urgent care. This structured approach has provided her with confidence and clarity on managing her health, highlighting the necessity of having a plan to effectively handle COPD symptoms.

title: Lupin pens deal for greater US access to Spiriva generic for COPD...
summary: Lupin Pharmaceuticals has partnered with Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drugs and the COPD Foundation to expand access to a generic version of Spiriva HandiHaler for COPD patients in the U.S. This generic, tiotropium bromide dry powder, is used with the LupinHaler device and offers a more affordable alternative to the brand-name medication. Cost Plus Drugs will mail 30-count boxes of the generic for $361, significantly lower than the typical $500 cost of Spiriva HandiHaler. The generic version, approved in the U.S. in June and also available in Canada, is intended for maintenance treatment and not for sudden COPD symptom exacerbations. This collaboration aims to provide quality, affordable treatment options, enhancing the lives of COPD patients by making essential medications more accessible.

title: Plant-based diet may halve emphysema risk for young smokers
summary: A new U.S. study suggests that young adults who smoke or have smoked can halve their risk of developing emphysema by adhering to a nutritionally rich, plant-based diet. The study, published in the Journal of the COPD Foundation, highlights the importance of diet in reducing the risk of chronic lung disease among smokers. The research, based on data from the CARDIA Lung Study, found that those with a high adherence to a plant-centered diet had a 56% lower risk of developing emphysema. This association was independent of smoking history, suggesting that a plant-based diet could be a complementary strategy to smoking cessation for preserving lung health.

title: Thomas Jefferson University reported financial results through Q3 2024
summary: Thomas Jefferson University reported a $30.5 million operating loss for the first nine months of fiscal 2024, despite generating total revenue of $7.4 billion.

title: Thomas Jefferson University Graduation Pronunciations Go Awry
summary: The announcer at Thomas Jefferson University's graduation ceremony struggled to pronounce common names such as Elizabeth, Allison, and even Thomas, causing a stir on social media. TikTokers shared videos of the event, highlighting the numerous pronunciation errors. The announcer later apologized, attributing the mistakes to phonetic spellings on the graduates' cards. Despite the apology, many found the errors baffling and entertaining, with some questioning the announcer's competence and others wondering if the event was a skit. Reactions ranged from amusement to anger, with some attendees feeling disrespected and others expressing concern for the announcer's well-being. The incident has sparked widespread discussion online.

title: Thomas Jefferson University apologizes for graduates' mispronounced names in viral video
summary: Thomas Jefferson University has issued an apology after a video of graduates' names being mispronounced during a commencement ceremony went viral. The incident occurred when the presenter failed to refer to the names in the book and relied instead on phonetic spellings on speaker cards, leading to significant errors. Graduates, including Sarah Virginia Brennan and Maeve Elizabeth, experienced their names being jumbled, which caused visible confusion and disappointment. The university acknowledged the mishap and expressed deep regret for any distress caused to the graduates during this important milestone.

title: Thomas Jefferson University issues apology for mispronouncing graduates' names
summary: Thomas Jefferson University issued an apology after a speaker mispronounced graduates' names during its nursing program's commencement ceremony in Philadelphia. The announcer, using phonetic spellings from cards, awkwardly mispronounced basic names such as Thomas, Stephanie, Jessica, and Sarah. A video of the incident went viral, amassing over 7 million views and even catching the attention of Jimmy Fallon. The university quickly apologized on social media to the students and their families, explaining that the mispronunciations were due to the phonetic spellings on the speaker's cards. They emphasized that this mistake does not reflect their respect for the students or their achievements.

title: Jefferson Health, LVHN commit to $14B, 30-hospital merger
summary: Philadelphia-based Jefferson Health and Allentown-based Lehigh Valley Health Network (LVHN) have signed a definitive agreement for a $14 billion merger, aiming for a summer close pending reviews and conditions. This merger will combine 30 hospitals, over 700 care sites, and 65,000 employees, and will also include a health plan and clinical research with Thomas Jefferson University. The merger is intended to enhance access to high-quality care, promote innovation, and provide value-based care. Jefferson Health CEO Joseph Cacchione will lead the combined entity, while LVHN CEO Brian Nester will become executive vice president and chief operating officer. The merger seeks to improve financial stability, reduce care costs, and expand services, particularly for underserved populations. The new system will become Pennsylvania’s second-largest nonprofit health system.

title: The 2024 Update to the American Diabetes Association Standards of Care in Diabetes
summary: The 2024 update to the American Diabetes Association Standards of Care emphasizes patient-centered care and person-first language. Key changes include updated screening and treatment approaches based on the latest clinical evidence. The guidelines focus on individual preferences, care costs, and treatment burdens. Revisions cover cholesterol, blood pressure, glycemic status management, and the reduced price of insulin and glucose monitoring devices. The ADA also highlights the importance of confirmatory testing for diabetes diagnosis and differentiating between diabetes types for personalized management. Recommendations include using teplizumab to delay type 1 diabetes onset, incorporating community paramedics, and emphasizing diabetes self-management education. Updates also address comorbidities, glycemic assessment, and the use of diabetes monitoring technologies. The ADA promotes inclusive language and patient empowerment, stressing early CGM use for type 1 diabetes patients and tailored obesity treatments. Special population guidelines include personalized care for older adults, pediatric patients, and pregnant individuals.

title: Tour De Cure team raises funds for American Diabetes Association
summary: The Beer Coasters Cycling Team participated in guest bartending at Fattey Beer Company in Rochester to raise funds for the American Diabetes Association (ADA) as part of the Tour De Cure Finger Lakes event. The event, which will officially start on June 8, aims to support diabetes research and awareness. One dollar from every beer or wine sold, along with tips collected during the bartending event, was donated to the ADA. Team captain Mike Ritchie mentioned that the event has moved locations over the years, now starting in the Finger Lakes region, which presents a hilly terrain for participants.

title: The American Diabetes Association Announces the 2024 National Scientific and Health Care Achievement Award ...
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has announced the recipients of the 2024 National Scientific and Health Care Achievement Awards. The awards honor individuals who have made significant contributions to diabetes research, prevention, and treatment. Key recipients include Professor Rury R. Holman for the Banting Medal for Scientific Achievement, Dr. Stephen C.J. Parker for the Outstanding Scientific Achievement Award, and Dr. Alvin C. Powers for the Albert Renold Award. Other notable awardees are Dr. Samuel Dagogo-Jack, Dr. Joshua J. Neumiller, Dr. John Buse, Professor Kaushik Ramaiya, and Dr. Viswanathan Mohan. The awards will be presented at the ADA's 84th Scientific Sessions in June.

title: physiatrist helps write first American Diabetes Association guidelines to include disability management - UT Health San ...
summary: Monica Verduzco-Gutierrez, MD, a professor at UT Health San Antonio, contributed to the first American Diabetes Association (ADA) guidelines that include disability management for diabetes care. The updated 2024 ADA Standards of Care guide now recommends assessing diabetes patients for disabilities during each medical visit and referring them to specialists if needed. This inclusion addresses the increased risk of disabilities among diabetes patients, such as lower-body functionality issues. The guide also considers social determinants of health, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic status, noting higher amputation rates among minority groups and those in underprivileged areas. Verduzco-Gutierrez's work is particularly significant for San Antonio, a city with a high diabetes prevalence. The guidelines aim to improve the overall care and quality of life for diabetes patients by addressing their comprehensive health needs.

title: Leapfrog Group, American Diabetes Association team up to recognize hospitals
summary: The Leapfrog Group and the American Diabetes Association (ADA) are collaborating to recognize hospitals that provide exceptional care for diabetes patients. Leah Binder, CEO of Leapfrog, emphasizes the importance of this new program, which aims to spotlight hospitals making extra efforts for diabetes care. The initiative will not penalize hospitals that don't meet the criteria but will encourage them to improve. Robert Gabbay of the ADA highlights the significant risks diabetes patients face during hospital stays, noting that 30% of hospitalized Americans have diabetes. The program will assess hospitals' adherence to ADA standards and Leapfrog's safety data, with the first recognitions announced next spring. This effort aims to improve patient safety and care quality for hospitalized diabetes patients.

title: UK researcher featured on cover of American Diabetes Association's annual report
summary: Brittany Smalls, Ph.D., from the University of Kentucky, is featured on the cover of the American Diabetes Association’s (ADA) 2023 Annual Report. Smalls, an associate professor in the UK College of Medicine, focuses on helping rural Kentuckians, especially in Appalachia, manage diabetes. Her research targets intergenerational households that share a high risk of type 2 diabetes, with prevalence in Kentucky's rural areas reaching 23%. With an ADA award, Smalls is expanding her research to include entire families at risk. Her pilot health intervention leverages family social support to promote nutrition and physical activity, providing tailored six-month lifestyle plans and ADA-backed recommendations. The ADA, committed to advancing diabetes research since 1952, has awarded over $955 million to researchers. The organization aims to improve the quality of life for Americans living with diabetes through advocacy, education, and program development.

title: The American Diabetes Association Announces New Diabetes Primary Care Alliance to Support Diabetes Care
summary: The American Diabetes Association (ADA) has announced the formation of the Diabetes Primary Care Alliance, in partnership with the DARTNet Institute. This national network of nearly 2,000 primary care practices aims to improve health outcomes for people with diabetes by promoting evidence-based standards of care. The Alliance will work with primary care leaders and institutions to integrate the latest advances in diabetes care. A key component is the ADA DARTNet Institute Alliance for Diabetes, which will use aggregated health data to enhance care delivery. The initiative will focus on type 2 diabetes and related conditions, particularly in under-resourced and diverse communities. The ADA has awarded a grant to DARTNet to support these efforts, which include engaging community health workers to improve diabetes outcomes. The collaboration aims to transform diabetes care and improve the lives of those affected.

title: Two GOP lawmakers in Kansas joined a Democrat to push back against false claims about vaccines • Kansas Reflector
summary: Two Kansas Republican lawmakers, Rep. John Eplee and Sen. Kristen O’Shea, joined Democratic Rep. Melissa Oropeza to advocate for vaccines and counter misinformation at a Statehouse rally. They emphasized the safety and necessity of vaccines, urging colleagues to maintain current statutes. Despite false claims from anti-vaccination groups, vaccines have been proven safe and effective. Kansas requires vaccines for schoolchildren, including for polio and measles. Sen. Mark Steffen introduced anti-vaccine bills to prevent discrimination based on vaccine refusal and limit local quarantine authority. O’Shea, serving on the same committee as Steffen, called for vaccine advocates to participate in hearings, stressing the importance of informed health decisions for children. She highlighted that pro-vaccine views should not be partisan.

title: Immunize Kansas Coalition highlights women's health at Spanish-language predominant conference in Kansas City
summary: The Immunize Kansas Coalition (IKC) hosted Entre Mujeres: The Health of Women, the first predominantly Spanish-language conference in Kansas City, to enhance health equity among diverse communities. Supported by 15 sponsors and exhibitors, the event attracted 200 attendees and reached tens of thousands through media and digital campaigns. A bus from Garden City Community College facilitated transport for women from across Kansas. The program featured prenatal and infant care initiatives, cancer prevention education, survivor stories, and motivational sessions. Dr. Sharla A. Smith, an associate professor at the University of Kansas Health System, emphasized the importance of equity. Graduate student Stephania Lopez highlighted the empowerment felt by black and brown attendees. The event also provided on-site HPV vaccinations, administered by Caritas Clinic and the National Association of Hispanic Nurses Kansas City Chapter. Executive Director Geovannie Gone credited partnerships for overcoming barriers to transportation, language, health misinformation, and vaccine access.

title: GOP House, Senate negotiators attempting one more bite at anti-vaccination apple • Kansas Reflector
summary: Republican House and Senate negotiators in Kansas are attempting to pass a bill that would limit the authority of the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) and county health officials to issue public mandates during infectious disease outbreaks. The proposed legislation would prevent mandates and instead issue recommendations. It also seeks to block requirements for COVID-19 vaccinations for school and childcare enrollment. Democrats on the negotiation committee oppose the bill, citing public health risks. The bill also excludes a House proposal to legalize fentanyl test strips and form a task force on opioid fatalities. Health organizations and some lawmakers criticize the bill for undermining vaccination policies and public health protections.

title: Gone appointed to Governor's Council on Wellness
summary: Geovannie Gone has been appointed to the Governor’s Council on Wellness, adding to her extensive experience in healthcare and community outreach. She has previously worked with United Healthcare and Genesis Family Health, where she contributed to community health initiatives and the implementation of KanCare. Her work with the Immunize Kansas Coalition involved collaborating with the Kansas Department of Health and Environment to combat vaccine-preventable diseases. Gone aims to leverage her new role to address the needs of underserved populations, particularly refugees and immigrants, and to enhance wellness programs across Kansas. She is also focused on learning from other wellness initiatives and improving school nutrition and physical activity programs. Excited about her appointment, Gone looks forward to advocating for Southwest Kansas and ensuring resources and support reach rural communities. She encourages public engagement and feedback to better serve the community's health needs.

title: Minnesota woman who's had 4 kidney transplants shares story to inspire others
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION OF MINNESOTA INC
summary: Jennifer Cramer-Miller, a Minnesota woman who has undergone four kidney transplants over 20 years, shares her story to inspire others on World Kidney Day. Diagnosed with a severe autoimmune kidney disease called focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) shortly after college, she faced kidney failure and dialysis. Her first transplant came from a donor family, followed by three more transplants from her mother, husband, and another donor. Despite the challenges, Cramer-Miller has led a fulfilling life, including starting a family. As the board chair of the National Kidney Foundation Minnesota, she advocates for kidney health awareness and encourages others facing similar struggles. Her book, "Incurable Optimist: Living with Illness and Chronic Hope," details her journey and aims to provide hope to those dealing with kidney disease.

title: New Analysis on Hypertension Treatment to be Presented as Late-Breaking Research at National Kidney Foundation ...
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION OF MINNESOTA INC
summary: A new analysis comparing chlorthalidone (CTD) and hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) will be presented at the National Kidney Foundation Spring Clinical Meetings. The study, titled "Treatment with Chlorthalidone vs Hydrochlorothiazide and Renal Outcomes: The Diuretic Comparison Project (DCP)," led by Dr. Areef Ishani, followed over 12,000 participants for an average of 3.9 years. It found no significant difference in renal outcomes between the two medications, including primary composite renal outcomes like serum creatinine doubling, eGFR decline, or kidney failure requiring treatment. Both medications showed similar efficacy in preserving kidney function, providing reassurance for their use in managing hypertension without compromising renal health. The NKF Spring Clinical Meetings serve as a platform for nephrology professionals to learn, network, and present research, focusing on translating science into practice. The National Kidney Foundation aims to eliminate preventable kidney disease and address inequities in kidney care.

title: MedicareOnDemand Now a “Preferred Program” of Both the Medical Association of Georgia and the Texas ...
summary: MedicareOnDemand (MOD), an online platform for matching Medicare insurance options with plans accepted by providers, has been designated a preferred program by the Medical Association of Georgia (MAG) and the Texas Independent Osteopathic Physician Organization (TIOPA). This endorsement is part of an effort to help healthcare providers retain their Medicare patients amid industry disruption. MOD simplifies the process for seniors to compare and enroll in Medicare plans that their providers accept, ensuring continuity of care. The platform, created by MedicareCompareUSA, also offers assistance from licensed insurance agents.

title: New Georgia Law Reins in NP, PA Use of 'Doctor' in Clinical Settings
summary: A new Georgia law requires healthcare providers to specify their licenses or educational degrees in advertisements, name badges, and patient interactions. Advanced practice registered nurses (NPs) and physician assistants (PAs) with doctoral degrees using the title "doctor" must clearly state they are not medical doctors or physicians. This law, effective July 1, aims to ensure patients are informed about who is providing their care. Supporters argue it promotes transparency, while critics believe it restricts healthcare professionals from fully communicating their qualifications. Similar legislation exists in New Jersey. Violations could lead to legal actions from professional licensing boards.

title: Florida surgeon general Joseph Ladapo questioned as measles cases spread
hco: FLORIDA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS INC
summary: Florida Surgeon General Joseph Ladapo has defied CDC recommendations amid a measles outbreak in Broward County, resulting in eight cases, including two new ones in children. The outbreak began at Manatee Bay Elementary School, where six children were initially infected. Ladapo's stance allows parents to decide whether their children attend school, contradicting federal advice that exposed, unvaccinated children should isolate for three weeks. Health experts criticize Ladapo's approach, emphasizing that isolation and vaccination are crucial to containing the highly contagious disease. Measles, preventable by the MMR vaccine, poses severe risks, especially to young children and unvaccinated individuals.

title: Menstrual history could be required for high school sports in Florida
hco: FLORIDA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS INC
summary: Officials in Florida are considering a controversial change that would require high school girls who participate in sports to disclose their menstrual history to school officials. Currently, these questions are optional on the preparticipation physical evaluation form. Dr. Tommy Shechtman, a pediatrician and past president of the Florida Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics, argues that this information is not necessary for athletic departments and may violate HIPAA regulations. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends physical examinations for student-athletes but advises that medical forms should be kept confidential and not shared with schools or sports organizations. The Florida High School Athletic Association, which governs athletics at public schools in the state, has not yet commented on the proposed change.

title: Florida Subpoenas Medical Associations Over Trans Youth Care
hco: FLORIDA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS INC
summary: The Florida House has passed legislation barring physicians from providing gender-affirming care to minors. State lawmakers are now subpoenaing medical associations, such as the Florida chapters of the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Psychiatric Association, for materials justifying their support of gender-affirming care. Florida Rep. Randy Fine, a sponsor of several anti-LGBTQ+ bills, signed the subpoenas and shared them on social media, criticizing the care as harmful. Florida House Speaker Paul Renner questioned the consensus among medical professionals regarding gender-affirming care. Organizations like the World Professional Association for Transgender Health and the Endocrine Society cite research supporting the benefits and safety of gender-affirming care for trans youth, warning against barriers to such treatments. The medical associations have not commented on the subpoenas.

title: INFLUENCE Magazine's most powerful people in Florida health care politics
hco: FLORIDA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS INC
summary: INFLUENCE Magazine highlights the most powerful figures in Florida health care politics, encompassing lawmakers, lobbyists, CEOs, nonprofit leaders, and medical school deans. These influencers play critical roles in shaping policies on Medicaid eligibility, gender-affirming care, and doctor reimbursements. They have navigated complex issues like the pandemic, transgender care, and insurance legalities. Notable individuals include Mike Anway of PhrMA, Steve Bahmer of LeadingAge Florida, Doug Bell of Metz Husband & Daughton, and Ron Book, a prominent lobbyist. Others like Bo Boulenger of Baptist Health South Florida and Jason Brodeur of the Florida Senate also hold significant influence. This diverse group impacts how Floridians access and pay for health care, emphasizing the complexity and importance of health care policy in the state.

title: Do You Have Achy Joints? These Foods Or Drinks Could Be To Blame.
summary: The article discusses foods and drinks that can exacerbate arthritis and joint pain due to their inflammatory properties. It highlights five types of food to minimize: ultra-processed foods and drinks, cured or processed meat, fried food, gluten (for those sensitive to it), and alcohol. These foods can trigger inflammation, worsening conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and gout. Instead, an anti-inflammatory diet, such as the Mediterranean diet, is recommended. This diet includes leafy green vegetables, nuts, fatty fish rich in omega-3 fatty acids, and fruits high in antioxidants. Adopting such a diet can help manage joint pain and improve overall health.

title: Quanta™ to Present Highly Anticipated Real-World Evidence at the American Society of Nephrology (ASN) Kidney ...
summary: Quanta Dialysis Technologies will present real-world evidence from its Home Run™ study at the American Society of Nephrology (ASN) Kidney Week 2023. The study evaluates the efficacy and safety of the Quanta™ Dialysis System for home hemodialysis (HHD). Initial clinical data will be shared during a poster session on November 2. Results indicate the system's ease of integration into home settings and its suitability for various demographics. Of the 32 participants, 93% opted to continue using the system, highlighting its potential long-term benefits. The Quanta Dialysis System, already approved in the UK, has submitted for FDA clearance in the US.

title: Research presented at the American Society of Nephrology meeting
summary:
The annual meeting of the American Society of Nephrology (ASN), held from Nov. 2 to 5, 2023, in Philadelphia, showcased significant research in nephrology. Key studies included:

1. Amit Garg, M.D., found that a multicomponent intervention did not significantly increase steps toward kidney transplantation compared to usual care, impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.
2. Michelle Rheault, M.D., demonstrated that sparsentan, a novel drug, significantly reduced proteinuria in patients with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) compared to irbesartan.
3. Katherine R. Tuttle, M.D., showed that the combination of aldosterone synthase inhibitor BI 690517 and empagliflozin reduced albuminuria in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
4. Brad Rovin, M.D., found that sparsentan significantly reduced proteinuria and preserved kidney function better than irbesartan in IgA nephropathy patients.

These findings contribute to advancements in kidney disease treatment and management.

title: Deidra C. Crews, MD, ScM, FASN, to Become Next President of the American Society of Nephrology
summary: Dr. Deidra C. Crews, MD, ScM, FASN, will become the next president of the American Society of Nephrology (ASN) on January 1, 2024. She will lead an organization of nearly 21,000 health professionals from 140 countries dedicated to combating kidney diseases. Dr. Crews is a Professor of Medicine and Epidemiology at Johns Hopkins University and serves as Associate Director for Faculty Development in the Division of Nephrology and Deputy Director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Equity. Her research focuses on health disparities, particularly in kidney disease. She has received numerous awards and has served on various ASN committees. Dr. Crews aims to enhance kidney-related research, innovation, care, and policy, emphasizing the elimination of disparities in access to care and outcomes. The ASN Kidney Week is the world's premier nephrology meeting, gathering around 12,000 professionals globally to exchange knowledge and discuss advancements in the field.

title: Deidra Crews Named Next President of the American Society of Nephrology | Johns Hopkins Center for Health Equity
summary: Deidra C. Crews, MD, ScM, FASN, has been named the next president of the American Society of Nephrology (ASN), starting January 1, 2024. Crews, currently the deputy director for Johns Hopkins Center for Health Equity, aims to advance kidney-related research, innovation, care, and policy during her one-year term. A distinguished nephrologist, Crews has authored over 200 articles on chronic kidney disease and health equity. She also co-leads the Johns Hopkins O’Brien Center to Advance Kidney Health Equity and is a professor at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. Crews has received several honors, including the Johns Hopkins University President’s Frontier Award and the ASN Distinguished Leader Award. As ASN president, she plans to focus on eliminating health disparities in kidney disease care and outcomes, empowering patients, and supporting healthcare professionals. The ASN represents nearly 21,000 health professionals from 140 countries dedicated to combating kidney diseases.

title: 5 Key Sessions, Interviews at ASN 2023 Kidney Week Annual Meeting
summary: Pharmacy Times will cover the American Society of Nephrology’s (ASN) 2023 Kidney Week Annual Meeting in Philadelphia from November 2-5, 2023. This event, returning to Philadelphia after nine years, will host 12,000 professionals and feature various educational and clinical sessions. Key topics include managing hypertension during pregnancy, healthcare disparities affecting the LGBTQ+ community, advancements in wearable and implantable bio(artificial) kidneys, the role of artificial intelligence in nephrology, and the impact of nutrition and exercise on chronic kidney disease and dialysis patients. Follow Pharmacy Times for exclusive session coverage and expert interviews.

title: ASN Kidney Week Returns to Philadelphia to Highlight Latest Innovations, Issues in Renal Care
summary: The American Society of Nephrology (ASN) Kidney Week 2023 will be held in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, from November 2-5. This event will gather thousands of clinicians and investigators to discuss the latest innovations and issues in renal care. Key topics include the role of artificial intelligence (AI) and digital health in nephrology, advancements in nephrocardiology, multi-omics, and genetic testing. Sessions will address disparities in nephrology, such as healthcare equity and social determinants of health. Presentations will also cover diabetic kidney disease, chronic kidney disease, nephrology in various populations, and new technological innovations like AI for predicting acute kidney injury outcomes. The conference aims to equip attendees with the latest knowledge to advance clinical practice and research in nephrology.

title: Yale Contributions Shape ASN Kidney Week 2023 < Yale School of Medicine
summary: Yale's Section of Nephrology made significant contributions to the American Society of Nephrology's Kidney Week 2023 in Philadelphia, with over 12,000 attendees. Dr. Mark Perazella, as co-chair, played a crucial role in shaping the event, which included early programs, scientific sessions, and educational symposia. The conference covered various nephrology topics, including genetics, nephrocardiology, renal pathology, and kidney transplantation. Special sessions focused on health equity and LGBTQ+ health. Dr. Whitney Besse also contributed by designing sessions on the genetics of kidney disease. Many Yale faculty members participated as abstract reviewers, speakers, and moderators, showcasing their research and expertise. The event emphasized diversity and inclusion, featuring both established experts and rising stars in nephrology.

title: Alpine Immune Sciences Presents Initial Clinical Data on Povetacicept in Autoimmune Glomerulonephritis in a Late ...
summary: Alpine Immune Sciences presented initial clinical data on povetacicept for autoimmune glomerulonephritis at the American Society of Nephrology Kidney Week 2023. Low-dose povetacicept (80 mg) administered subcutaneously every four weeks was well tolerated and significantly reduced urine protein to creatinine ratio (UPCR) by over 50% in patients with IgA nephropathy (IgAN), with most achieving remission. A higher dose (240 mg) is currently being explored. The company plans to initiate a pivotal phase 3 IgAN study in the second half of 2024. Povetacicept is a dual antagonist of BAFF and APRIL cytokines, crucial in autoimmune disease pathogenesis. The RUBY-3 study demonstrated promising results, supporting further clinical development. Alpine Immune Sciences will host a virtual investor call and webcast to discuss these findings.

title: Mallinckrodt to Present Data on TERLIVAZ® (terlipressin) for Injection in Adult Patients with Hepatorenal Syndrome ...
summary: Mallinckrodt plc will present data on TERLIVAZ® (terlipressin) for injection in adult patients with hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) at the American Society of Nephrology (ASN) Kidney Week 2023 in Philadelphia. Three scientific abstracts, including one oral and two poster presentations, will detail clinical research findings on TERLIVAZ's therapeutic effects. The presentations will cover the impact on patient care, key HRS endpoints, and patient comorbidities. TERLIVAZ is FDA-approved to improve kidney function in adults with HRS experiencing rapid kidney function reduction. The studies, part of the Phase III CONFIRM clinical trial, will be presented by Dr. Juan Carlos Q. Velez and Dr. Hani M. Wadei, focusing on serum creatinine improvement, HRS reversal, and renal replacement therapy in patients with fluid overload.

title: American Society of Nephrology Applauds the Ways and Means Committee for Advancing the Kidney Patient Act (Hr ...
summary: The American Society of Nephrology (ASN) commends the House Ways and Means Committee for advancing the Kidney PATIENT Act (HR 5074), which aims to maintain Medicare Part D coverage for oral-only medications essential for over 500,000 dialysis patients. The bill, passed with a 41-1 vote, ensures continued access to these medications through pharmacies, which are better equipped to promote at-home adherence. The legislation includes a 2-year extension of Part D coverage and mandates a report to Congress for future considerations. ASN President Deidra C. Crews praised the bipartisan effort and emphasized the importance of this step in patient care. The bill will next be reviewed by the House Energy and Commerce Committee. ASN, established in 1966, continues to advocate for kidney disease prevention, treatment, and cure.

title: Unity Consortium Marks Adolescent Immunization Action Week (AIAW) with activities to help Parents and Adolescents ...
summary: Unity Consortium is promoting Adolescent Immunization Action Week (AIAW) from April 1-5, 2024, to encourage parents and adolescents to stay updated on recommended vaccines. The initiative addresses the importance of preventive health and combats vaccine misinformation, which has led to vaccine hesitancy. Unity's TASK strategy advises using credible resources, consulting healthcare providers, scheduling appointments, and knowing vaccination locations. Activities include public service announcements, a comprehensive digital campaign, and a webinar featuring notable speakers. Unity emphasizes the critical role of adolescent immunization in community health and offers resources to support these efforts. For more information, visit unity4teenvax.org.

title: GSK Awards $1M in COiMMUNITY Initiative Grants to Support Adult Immunization and Health Equity
summary: GSK has awarded $1 million in COiMMUNITY Initiative grants to support adult immunization and health equity. Ten projects across the US will receive between $50,000 and $175,000 each to address barriers to adult immunization. The initiative, launched in June, aims to increase adult immunization rates through grant funding, data transparency, and resource-sharing. The grants support innovative approaches to boost vaccination, such as building vaccine confidence in underserved communities, creating multilingual educational materials, and developing resources for pharmacists and local health departments. GSK plans to continue investing in solutions to address adult immunization challenges.

title: Popular ArthritisPower® Patient Registry Expands Conditions and Becomes PatientSpot™
summary: The Global Healthy Living Foundation (GHLF) has rebranded its ArthritisPower® Patient Registry to PatientSpot™, expanding its focus to support individuals with various chronic conditions. Originally launched in 2014 to aid those with rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases, ArthritisPower has evolved to a broader platform under the new name, providing education, patient-centered research, and advocacy. PatientSpot is now an FDA-approved Class 1 medical device, emphasizing patient-centered decision-making and incorporating advanced technologies like AI for better health data management. The platform aims to empower patients by offering a secure repository for health data, enhancing therapeutic protocols, and fostering a comprehensive chronic disease community.

title: COVID-19 Vaccine Hesitancy: What Your Patients Want You to Know
summary: Shilpa Venkatachalam, PhD, and Shubhasree Banerjee, MD, discuss factors influencing COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy among patients with autoimmune rheumatic diseases. Despite 65% of the US population being fully vaccinated, these patients show significant hesitancy due to various concerns. Venkatachalam, director at Global Healthy Living Foundation, emphasizes the importance of tailored messaging and effective communication between patients and healthcare providers to improve vaccine uptake. The discussion highlights the need for clinicians to address specific patient concerns and behaviors to enhance vaccination rates among this vulnerable group.

title: Community Pharmacy Is Working to Define Itself
summary: Community pharmacy, an established concept, continues to evolve in defining its role. Melissa S. McGivney, PharmD, emphasizes that while retail pharmacy focuses on business models, community pharmacy centers on patient services and community roles. Corporate pharmacies also qualify as community pharmacies but operate under different business frameworks. The ACT Pharmacy Collaborative and AACP are pivotal in enhancing community pharmacy practices. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated public awareness and access to pharmacists, highlighting the industry's adaptability. Technological advancements and changes in physical spaces have furthered patient care.
