Naana Danquah Jefferson, motivated by her mother's experience with lupus, has been actively participating in lupus awareness walks and is now a board member of the Lupus Foundation of America-Texas Gulf Coast. The foundation aims to educate the public, advocate for better medical care, and raise funds for research. Despite its prevalence, lupus remains under-recognized, often misdiagnosed, and misunderstood, necessitating greater public education and financial support to improve patient outcomes and advance research efforts.

title: Put On Your Purple for World Lupus Day at Houston City Hall
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA TX GULF COAST CHAPTER
summary: The Texas Gulf Chapter of the Lupus Foundation of America is hosting "Put On Your Purple for World Lupus Day" at Houston City Hall on Friday, May 10, 2024, at 7:00 pm. Houston City Hall will be illuminated in purple to raise awareness for lupus. The event is free and open to the public. This listing is part of 365 Things to Do in Houston, which provides information on events and activities in the Houston area. The event organizers sponsored the listing to include detailed information and visuals.

title: Statement on the Passing of Former Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson | Lupus Foundation of America
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA TX GULF COAST CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America expressed sorrow over the passing of former Congresswoman Eddie Bernice Johnson, who died on December 31 at age 88. Johnson, the first nurse elected to Congress and the first African American and woman to chair the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, served as the Congressional Lupus Caucus Co-chair from 2015-2023. Her extensive background in health and research enabled her to champion lupus research and education, notably establishing the Lupus Research Program within the Department of Defense. Mary Crimmings, Interim CEO of the Lupus Foundation, praised Johnson's dedication and impact on lupus research.

title: MLB's diversity VP Billy Bean leads team for leukemia & lymphoma society at Citi Field
summary: Billy Bean, MLB’s senior vice-president for diversity, equity & inclusion, led a team for the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (LLS) at the Big Climb event at Citi Field on May 18, 2024. The event aimed to raise awareness and funds for blood cancer research. Participants climbed the iconic upper-tier steps of the Mets' stadium, experiencing a high-energy environment. The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society collaborated with Bean, who eagerly supported and led the initiative. The event featured various activities, including a powerful opening ceremony, group marches, and a medal presentation for participants. The Mets were away playing the Marlins, concluding their series with a win but losing 2-1 overall. The LLS Big Climb also included fun activities for all age groups, making the awareness drive memorable. The Mets currently stand third in the NL East with a 21-25 record, trailing behind the Phillies and Dodgers in the wildcard race.

title: Local Leukemia & Lymphoma Society holds annual fundraiser for blood cancer research
summary: The local chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society in Cincinnati held its annual fundraiser to support blood cancer research, providing new hope for patients. Despite progress, more research is needed for long-term survival. The event featured survivors like Maddie Havera, diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia at age two, and Kate Schroder, diagnosed over a decade ago. Scott Carroll shared his experience with Hodgkin’s lymphoma from 1996. Advances in treatment, partly funded by such events, have significantly improved over the decades. Specialists like Dr. Edward Faber, Dr. Akash Mukherjee, and Dr. Doug Flora highlighted advancements in cancer drugs, immune system harnessing, and precision medicine. The goal is to increase the number of survivors like Havera. The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society seeks support from families and businesses for the Light the Night walk on October 3.

title: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) Data and Presence at ASH Showcase Latest Blood Cancer Treatment ...
summary: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) will showcase recent blood cancer treatment breakthroughs at the 65th Annual American Society of Hematology (ASH) Meeting from December 9-12, 2023, in San Diego. LLS will present new research findings and support over 200 researchers and 15 Therapy Acceleration Program (TAP) partners. Key highlights include data from the Pediatric Acute Leukemia Master Clinical Trial (PedAL) and Beat AML® Master Clinical Trial, which are transforming treatments for acute leukemias. Additionally, the LLS National Patient Registry will provide insights into cardiotoxic adverse events in chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients. LLS’s Equity in Access program will present findings on the impact of health insurance on blood cancer outcomes. The event will also feature presentations from TAP partners on innovative therapies for various blood cancers.

title: Builders FirstSource Raises More Than $1 Million for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society at Annual Charity Event
summary: Builders FirstSource raised over $1 million for The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) during its Annual Charity Event held on May 9-10, 2024, in Las Colinas, TX. Since partnering with LLS in 2006, the company has contributed more than $11 million towards research, patient support, and advocacy. Dave Rush, President and CEO, emphasized the company's commitment to supporting those affected by blood cancers. The event featured Hall of Fame Basketball Coach Roy Williams, who highlighted the importance of teamwork and collaboration. The event attracted sponsorship from numerous notable companies. Builders FirstSource aims to raise at least $2 million for LLS in 2024 through various fundraising initiatives, including LLS’s Light The Night® walks. The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society is dedicated to curing blood cancers and improving the quality of life for patients and their families by funding research and providing support services.

title: $5 million grant supports innovative immunotherapies against blood cancers – Washington University School of ...
summary: Researchers at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis have received a $5 million grant from the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) to support the development of new immunotherapies for blood cancers. The team science program, led by Todd Fehniger, MD, PhD, and Brad Kahl, MD, aims to foster collaboration among researchers to enhance innovative translational studies. Two projects will focus on genetically engineering immune cells to target cancer cells, while the third will develop personalized cancer vaccines. Each project includes early-phase clinical trials at Siteman Cancer Center. The grant also funds four resource cores to support these projects.

title: How you can give back to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society this weekend
summary: This weekend, you can support the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) by attending a fundraiser hosted by 2024 Visionary of the Year nominee Alex Cetti at D&D Ranch in Madera. LLS aims to find cures for various cancers and support patients and their families. Sandy Cetti from Team "Cetti Crew for a Cure" discussed the event's significance.

title: Rgenta Therapeutics Joins The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society Therapy Acceleration Program®
summary: Rgenta Therapeutics has been selected by The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) to join its Therapy Acceleration Program (TAP), receiving strategic funding to advance its RNA-targeting small molecule therapeutics for hematologic malignancies. Highlighted at the 65th ASH Annual Meeting, Rgenta is developing a pipeline of oral, small-molecule RNA-targeting medicines, focusing initially on oncology and neurological disorders. The company's platform targets MYB, an oncogenic transcription factor, to address historically undruggable targets. LLS's investment aims to accelerate the development of these therapeutics, which could significantly impact treatment for blood cancer patients.

title: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society Awards $65 Million in New Funding for Blood Cancer Research
summary: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) has announced $65 million in new grants to 78 research teams across seven countries, expanding its academic research portfolio to over $240 million. This funding supports nearly 300 top scientific investigators at prestigious institutions. LLS’s Therapy Acceleration Program (LLS TAP) also has $40 million invested in partnerships with biotech companies to develop novel treatments. LLS has invested over $1.7 billion in research over 75 years, contributing to major breakthroughs in blood cancer treatment. The new grants focus on immunotherapy, precision medicine for acute myeloid leukemia, pediatric cancer treatment, and chronic myelomonocytic leukemia. LLS is also committed to advancing health equity and early detection of blood cancer.

title: Jasper Health and The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society® (LLS) Collaborate to Support Blood Cancer Patients
summary: Jasper Health and The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) have formed a strategic collaboration to support blood cancer patients and their caregivers. This partnership aims to enhance access to free care navigation, education, and resources tailored to the needs of blood cancer patients. By combining their expertise, Jasper Health and LLS seek to improve patient outcomes and quality of life. Jasper Health, a healthcare technology company, is dedicated to transforming cancer care navigation, while LLS focuses on curing blood cancers and improving the lives of patients and their families.

title: Bringing Light to The Darkness of Cancer: BeiGene Named National Partner of Survivorship and Hope for The ...
summary: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) has announced a three-year partnership with BeiGene, Ltd., a global oncology company. BeiGene will serve as the National Presenting Sponsor of Survivorship & Hope for LLS's Light The Night events, which support blood cancer patients and their families. These events, held across North America, feature participants carrying illuminated lanterns to symbolize the fight against cancer. BeiGene's involvement underscores its commitment to patient-first values and support for blood cancer research, patient education, and outreach programs. The partnership aims to advance survivorship research, provide educational resources, advocate for public policies, and empower patients and caregivers through online platforms.

title: 2024 Oncology Nurse Advisor Summit Shatters Attendance Records
summary: The 9th Annual Oncology Nurse Advisor (ONA) Summit, held virtually from March 21-24, 2024, saw record attendance with over 2,200 healthcare professionals, a 60% increase from the previous year. The event, accredited by Haymarket Medical Education (HME) and the National Association for Continuing Education (NACE), featured sessions on various oncology topics and offered up to 23.25 ANCC or AANP contact hours. New additions included a Hematology Intensive session and a Real Solutions Virtual Poster Gallery. The Summit's content was reviewed by the Oncology Nursing Certification Corporation (ONCC) for recertification points. The event was supported by sponsors like Regeneron Pharmaceuticals and educational grants from companies including Bristol Myers Squibb and Merck. Select sessions will be available on-demand via myCME.

title: Haymarket Media launches American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine
summary: Haymarket Media has launched the American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine (AJEM), a peer-reviewed journal focused on cannabinoid-based medicines. Acquired by Haymarket in March, AJEM will now include original research, daily news, in-depth analysis, and editorials. The journal will also feature AJEM Live, which offers podcasts, video shorts, and conference coverage. Ken Watkins, founder and brand director of AJEM, emphasized the journal's role in bridging the knowledge gap between medical professionals and cannabis science. Since its debut in 2019, AJEM has been a valuable resource for endocannabinoid research, providing information not typically covered in medical school. Mike Graziani, president of Haymarket’s Medical Communications Group, affirmed that AJEM will continue to offer the latest advancements and best practices in the field.

title: Haymarket Media US Announces Key Leadership Transitions
summary: Haymarket Media US announced key leadership transitions. Donna Santarpia retired as CFO after 10 years, with Chris Borella named her successor. Borella brings over 25 years of financial leadership experience from WPP companies. Additionally, Tammy Chernin will move to SVP, Strategic and Scientific Services, while Jamie Alexander will become General Manager at PRIHealthcare Solutions. Steve Madden will transition to VP, Business Media Content, and Denise Robbins will take over as VP, Digital Publishing and Media for the Business Media Group. These changes aim to foster innovation and growth within the organization.

title: Cardiology Advisor Institute CME and Resources for Clinicians
summary: The Cardiology Advisor Institute is a community offering cardiology CME/CE courses, resources, and news for healthcare professionals. It provides educational materials, including webinars, spotlight courses, and recommended courses on various cardiology topics. Featured courses address issues such as ageism in cardiology and the role of transcatheter interventions in mitral valve disease. The institute collaborates with Haymarket Medical Education (HME) to deliver top-quality, independent continuing education programs. HME aims to enhance clinical performance and patient outcomes through engaging and actionable education. The Cardiology Advisor also offers daily news, conference coverage, and practice management information, empowering healthcare professionals with up-to-date cardiology knowledge. Additionally, the website includes various learning centers, video and podcast channels, and interactive content to support ongoing professional development.

title: The American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine Officially Launches Under the Haymarket Media US Banner
summary: The American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine (AJEM) has officially relaunched under Haymarket Media US after its acquisition in March 2023. This move aims to broaden access to high-quality, peer-reviewed content on cannabinoid-based therapy for healthcare professionals (HCPs). AJEM will continue to deliver the latest advancements in endocannabinoid medicine through various mediums, including original research, news, feature articles, podcasts, and conference coverage. Ken Watkins, AJEM's founder, emphasizes that this partnership will bridge the knowledge gap between medical and cannabis fields, ensuring that medical cannabis science reaches the doctors who need it most. The journal, a trusted source since 2019, seeks to improve evidence-based cannabinoid medicine practice by educating HCPs on the endocannabinoid system (ECS). As part of the Haymarket Medical Network, AJEM is set to thrive as a reliable resource for advancements and best practices in the field.

title: Haymarket Media Acquires the American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine
summary: Haymarket Media, Inc. has acquired the American Journal of Endocannabinoid Medicine (AJEM), a peer-reviewed journal focused on cannabinoid medicine. This acquisition aims to expand access to high-quality, trusted content on cannabinoid-based therapy for healthcare professionals (HCPs). AJEM addresses a knowledge gap in the medical community, as physicians are often not trained in the endocannabinoid system (ECS) despite needing to care for patients using cannabinoid-based treatments. The journal will join the Haymarket Medical Network, benefiting from its digital expertise to deliver relevant clinical content. The acquisition aligns with Haymarket’s mission to educate and inform the medical community, reinforcing its leadership in this emerging therapeutic area.

title: Pulmonology CME: Top 10 Free Online Courses in Q1 2023
summary:
MyCME offers free online Pulmonology CME courses for Q1 2023, covering various respiratory diseases. Key courses include:

1. Management of Mycobacterium Avium Complex Infections, focusing on diagnosis, treatment, and patient communication.
2. Ideal PAH Patient Care, detailing treatment guidelines and telehealth potential.
3. Individualizing PAH Treatment, emphasizing diagnostic measures and personalized care.
4. Minimizing Lung Consequences of Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency, discussing screening, genetics, and treatment.
5. Interprofessional Care in CF-ILD, covering multidisciplinary approaches and patient care.
6. COPD management, highlighting guidelines, treatment strategies, and patient access to therapy.
7. Addressing disparities in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis management.
8. Impact of EGPA on Quality of Life, focusing on detection and management.
9. DOACs for Pediatric VTE, discussing latest data and dosing considerations.
10. Personalized Management of Idiopathic Hypersomnia, emphasizing treatment approaches and patient needs.

title: Racism, Medicine, and Medical Education: The Legacy of Abraham Flexner
summary: Jim Anderson discusses the historical roots of racism in medicine, focusing on Abraham Flexner and his 1910 Flexner Report. Flexner, known as the father of modern medical education, recommended reforms that closed many medical schools, including those for Black students. His report emphasized higher standards and scientific methods but also contained racist and sexist views, suggesting Black students should be trained only to protect White people from disease and questioning women's capabilities in medicine. The long-term effects are evident today, with underrepresentation of Black physicians and gender disparities in the medical profession. Reflecting on this legacy is crucial for addressing current healthcare inequities.

title: Diet And Nutrition With Lupus
summary: Healthy eating is crucial for managing lupus symptoms and overall health. There is no specific "lupus diet," but a balanced diet with a variety of healthy foods is recommended. Key dietary tips include eating plenty of fruits and vegetables, choosing whole grains, incorporating healthy proteins, and consuming foods with healthy fats. For those with lupus nephritis, certain food restrictions may apply. Vegetarian or vegan diets are acceptable but may require vitamin B12 supplements. Avoiding alfalfa and possibly garlic is suggested due to potential symptom triggers. Essential nutrients for bone and heart health include calcium and Omega-3 fatty acids. Limiting sodium, saturated fats, and added sugars can reduce the risk of high blood pressure, heart disease, and diabetes. Alcohol should be consumed in moderation and discussed with a doctor due to possible interactions with lupus medications.

title: Lupus Foundation of America Drives Nationwide Effort to Make Lupus Visible During Lupus Awareness Month
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America is leading a nationwide initiative during Lupus Awareness Month in May to raise awareness about lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease affecting millions globally. The Foundation aims to highlight the disease's impact, advocate for increased research funding, and provide educational programs and support services. Lupus is often misunderstood and misdiagnosed, disproportionately affecting women and certain racial and ethnic groups. Throughout May, the Foundation will share personal stories and resources, focusing on different aspects of the patient journey each week. A key event is the National Lupus Advocacy Summit in Washington, DC, which seeks to secure more research funding and improve care access. The Foundation encourages participation through sharing information, wearing purple on World Lupus Day, hosting fundraisers, and making donations. The initiative aims to enhance awareness, drive research, and improve the quality of life for those affected by lupus.

title: NIAMS-Funded Clinical Trial Featured on Lupus Foundation Podcast - Research Horizons
summary: Hermine Brunner, MD, MSc, MBA, and Prasad Devarajan, MD, from Cincinnati Children’s Hospital, were featured in the Lupus Foundation of America's podcast "My Lupus Living Room." They discussed their NIAMS-funded clinical trial, the Pediatric Lupus Nephritis Mycophenolate Mofetil (PLUMM) Study, which focuses on personalized precision dosing of the immunosuppressive drug Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF). The trial aims to determine the most effective dosing method for achieving optimal drug levels in the body. The study integrates clinical and translational research into daily care, enhancing its impact through direct interactions with children and families affected by lupus.

title: Announces Two New Members to its National Board of Directors | Lupus Foundation of America
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America has announced the addition of two new members to its National Board of Directors: Brian Antonsen, Senior Vice President at McKinstry, and Theresa Juday, Executive Director of Special Product Innovation for CVS Health. Both will contribute leadership to the Foundation’s mission to raise awareness and resources for lupus. Ms. Juday, diagnosed with lupus in 1997, has been an active supporter, leading lupus walk teams and serving on various advisory boards. Mr. Antonsen has supported the Foundation since 2014 and founded the GBQ golf tournament fundraiser. Both are committed to improving the quality of life for those affected by lupus. Mary T. Crimmings, Interim CEO, expressed enthusiasm for their addition, citing their leadership experience and dedication as valuable assets to the organization.

title: Awards Four Grants to Support and Advance Childhood Lupus Research | Lupus Foundation of America
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America has awarded four grants under the Michael Jon Barlin Pediatric Lupus Research Program to support childhood lupus research. The 2023 recipients are Dr. Joyce Chang, Dr. Cuoghi Edens, Dr. Linda Hiraki, and Dr. Ram Raj Singh. These researchers will focus on various aspects of pediatric lupus, including cognitive dysfunction, reproductive planning, genetic factors contributing to anxiety and depression, and identifying cellular and molecular abnormalities in pediatric lupus nephritis. The program, established in 2006, aims to address the severe impact of lupus on children and improve their quality of life.

title: Awards Scientists for Notable Contributions to Lupus Research | Lupus Foundation of America
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America (LFA) honored two researchers at the 2023 Evelyn V. Hess Reception for their significant contributions to lupus research. Dr. Maria Dall’Era, from the University of California, San Francisco, received the 2023 Evelyn V. Hess Award for her work in advancing the understanding and treatment of lupus, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and lupus nephritis. Dr. Dall’Era leads an integrated research program and is involved in various studies, including the CDC-funded California Lupus Epidemiology Study. Dr. May Choi, from the University of Calgary, was awarded the 2023 Mary Betty Stevens Young Investigator Prize for her early career achievements in lupus research, focusing on biomarker discovery and the prevention of autoimmune diseases. Dr. Choi leads the CatalystDx research laboratory and biobank and holds several leadership positions within lupus research initiatives.

title: Research Accomplishments to be Presented at the 2023 American College of Rheumatology Annual Meeting | Lupus ...
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America will present its research accomplishments at the 2023 American College of Rheumatology Annual Meeting in San Diego from November 10-15. Key studies include the RAY® registry identifying a six-year delay in lupus diagnosis, the SELF program enhancing self-management skills, and the HES program addressing educational needs. Additional research highlights include increasing minority participation in clinical trials, understanding the burden of cutaneous lupus, and developing a new treatment response measure for SLE. These efforts aim to improve diagnosis, treatment, and quality of life for lupus patients, with ongoing updates shared on social media.

title: Congress Set to Approve Millions in Lupus Funding
summary: The House of Representatives has approved a fiscal year 2024 spending package that includes $22 million for lupus research and education programs. This package allocates $10 million to the National Lupus Patient Registry at the CDC, $10 million to the Lupus Research Program at the Department of Defense, and $2 million to the National Lupus Training, Outreach, and Clinical Trial Education Program at the Office of Minority Health. The bill now awaits Senate approval and the president's signature. If enacted, lupus advocates will have secured over $103 million in federal funding in the past five years, advancing lupus research and treatment development. The Lupus Foundation of America encourages continued advocacy efforts, highlighting the importance of the Congressional Lupus Caucus and its co-chairs in these achievements.

title: World Lupus Federation Global Survey Finds 91% of People with Lupus Report Using Oral Steroids to Treat Lupus
summary: A global survey by the World Lupus Federation found that 91% of people with lupus use oral steroids for treatment. The survey included over 7,700 participants from more than 100 countries. It revealed that 75% of respondents have used steroids for over a year, and 27% for over a decade. Additionally, 43% reported taking higher-than-recommended doses, and 58% took maximum dosages. A significant concern is the long-term effects of steroid use, with 96% of respondents worried about these effects. Side effects such as diabetes, heart disease, and osteoporosis were common, with 60% experiencing at least one major side effect. The survey underscores the need for safer lupus treatments and better patient-centered care, as 39% of respondents felt their input on dosage decisions was not considered. The findings aim to raise awareness ahead of World Lupus Day on May 10.

title: New Blood Test Poised to Revolutionize Care for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
summary: AMPEL BioSolutions has introduced LuGENE®, a groundbreaking blood test aimed at revolutionizing the care for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This test predicts SLE flares before they occur and provides detailed information on individual disease abnormalities, facilitating faster and evidence-based treatment. Utilizing predictive artificial intelligence, LuGENE® detects genetic biomarkers in the blood associated with inflammation or immune dysfunction, allowing for personalized treatment plans. Historically, SLE treatment has been a trial-and-error process due to the disease's complexity and variability among patients. LuGENE® helps identify specific lupus subsets, enabling physicians to quickly determine the most effective treatment and reduce flare risks. This innovation promises to improve the quality of life for lupus patients, many of whom suffer significant income loss due to disease complications. The test is currently available at study sites across the U.S., supporting ongoing research and comparison with standard laboratory features.

title: FDA Approves a Phase 1 Trial for Investigational Therapy, CB-010, for Lupus Nephritis Treatment
summary: The U.S. Food & Drug Administration has approved a Phase 1 study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CB-010, an investigational CAR-T cell therapy for lupus nephritis (LN). The GALLOP study, set to begin by year-end, will also assess CB-010 for extrarenal lupus. CAR-T cell therapy targets B cells, which are involved in lupus disease activity. CB-010 specifically targets the CD19 protein on B cells and uses engineered T-cells lacking the PD-1 protein to enhance performance. Encouraging results have been seen in relapsed or refractory B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Follow the Lupus Foundation of America for updates.

title: New Potential Predictive Biomarker for Lupus Nephritis
summary: A new study published in Lupus Science and Medicine has identified potential predictive biomarkers for lupus nephritis (LN), a lupus-related kidney disease. Researchers focused on neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) remnants, specifically Elastase-DNA and HMGB1-DNA complexes, to predict renal outcomes and identify patients needing aggressive therapy. The study involved an exploratory cohort of 92 participants and an LN cohort of 109 participants. Findings revealed that NET remnants were 36% higher in those with active LN compared to those with active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) without LN. Participants with higher baseline levels of NET remnants were less likely to achieve remission and more likely to progress to severe renal impairment over 24 months. The study suggests that these NET remnants could serve as biomarkers for adverse renal outcomes, response to therapy, and decline in kidney function following LN flare. Further research is needed to understand NETosis's role in LN.

title: Awarded Grant to Continue to Increase Black/African American Participation in U.S. Lupus Clinical Trials | Lupus ...
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America (LFA) has received a three-year grant of up to $500,000 annually from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Minority Health. This funding aims to increase Black/African American participation in lupus clinical trials. The grant builds on the success of a 2021 grant that led to the creation of the IMPACT+ Program, which focuses on reducing barriers to clinical trial enrollment for Black/African American women, who are disproportionately affected by lupus. IMPACT+ aims to identify effective communication strategies and expand the Lupus Research Action Network (LRAN) to enhance clinical trial participation. This initiative is part of LFA's ongoing efforts to address lupus health disparities and improve care through research, education, and advocacy.

title: Find support near you
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA NORTH CAROLINA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America provides extensive support and resources for individuals affected by lupus through its national network of chapters, offices, and support groups across the United States. The organization focuses on raising awareness, offering educational programs, and advocating for those with lupus. It also supports research and provides community-based resources, virtual and in-person support groups, and referrals for medical assistance. Various specialized support groups are available, including those for specific communities such as Asian, Hispanic, and Black women, as well as groups for caregivers, children, and newly diagnosed individuals. The foundation encourages participation in research, advocacy, and fundraising activities to improve the quality of life for lupus patients.

title: The Wellington CBD Continues to Support the Community by Giving Back to the Lupus Foundation of America, North ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA NORTH CAROLINA CHAPTER
summary: The Wellington CBD, an upscale CBD retail experience in Charlotte, has announced its sponsorship and participation in the 2023 North Carolina Lupus Educational Summit on August 5th. The event, hosted by the Lupus Foundation of America, North Carolina Chapter, aims to provide education and support for those affected by lupus. The Wellington CBD will offer free hemp cannabinoid education, samples, and Q&A sessions. Linsey Beford, the owner, highlights the potential of CBD in reducing lupus symptoms through its anti-inflammatory properties. The event will feature discussions led by medical experts. The Wellington CBD has been recognized for its community support and high-quality CBD products.

title: Awards Five Summer Fellowship Grants to Young Scientists, Supporting Growth of Lupus Research Field | Lupus ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA NORTH CAROLINA CHAPTER
summary: The Lupus Foundation of America awarded five young scientists the 2023 Gina M. Finzi Memorial Student Summer Fellowship grants. These grants support mentored research experiences for undergraduate, graduate, and medical students in lupus research. The fellowship aims to cultivate future lupus researchers, focusing on areas like cutaneous lupus, lupus and pregnancy, patient-clinician communication, cognitive impairment, and treatment pathways. The recipients, mentored by experienced lupus investigators, include Mia Barron (University of Rochester/University of South Carolina), Felix Chin (Perelman School of Medicine), Carolin Sophia Coenen (Yale School of Medicine), Fatima Debek (Krembil Research Institute), and Kathryn Sullivan (University of Alabama-Birmingham). The program, established in 1984 to honor Gina M. Finzi, has a legacy of producing distinguished lupus scientists. This initiative underscores the importance of investing in young scientists to drive future lupus research and innovation.

title: Policymakers, Patients, and Industry Join National Minority Quality Forum to Raise Alarm of Cancer Care Disparities in ...
summary: The National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF) and CEO Roundtable on Cancer presented a report to the White House Cancer Moonshot team, highlighting significant cancer care disparities in minoritized communities. The report reveals that 56% of people of color live near carcinogenic sites, increasing their cancer risk. Systemic barriers also result in lower cancer screening rates for Black, Hispanic, Asian, and AIAN populations, leading to late-stage diagnoses. The NMQF announced a multi-year initiative to address these disparities through public-private partnerships in 10 majority-minority communities. Collaborative efforts with local and national stakeholders aim to enhance cancer prevention, early detection, and treatment for these vulnerable populations.

title: CEO Roundtable on Cancer and National Minority Quality Forum Collaborate on Cancer Stage Shifting Initiative
summary: The CEO Roundtable on Cancer (CEORT) and the National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF) are collaborating on the Cancer Stage Shifting Initiative (CSSI) to address cancer care inequities in marginalized communities. This initiative aims to bring President Biden's Cancer Moonshot to these areas, focusing on early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer. CSSI will align cancer care clinical protocols with payment models to reduce disparities. The Cancer Moonshot, launched in 2016 and revived by Biden in 2020, seeks to cut cancer deaths by 50% over 25 years, enhance prevention, improve data sharing, and accelerate new therapies. This collaboration leverages CEORT's programs and NMQF's research to improve cancer care accessibility and outcomes in underserved neighborhoods.

title: How Can Cancer Risk Be Cut in Communities Exposed to Toxins?
summary: A high rate of lung cancer and other cancers in Houston's Fifth Ward is attributed to creosote contamination from the Union Pacific Railroad in the 1950s. The primarily Black and Hispanic community faces significant health challenges due to this exposure. The National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF) is addressing these issues by proposing a Cancer Stage Shifting Initiative, which includes early cancer screenings, access to modern therapies, and a financial model to support these interventions. The initiative aims to improve cancer care in medically underserved communities and advocate for policy changes to ensure equitable access to cancer treatment and prevention.

title: Puckrein: Will Medicaid’s proposed price rule harm patients?
summary: Gary Puckrein discusses the potential negative impacts of proposed changes to the Medicaid Drug Rebate Program (MDRP) on patients. Medicaid is a crucial program for over 85 million Americans, including a significant portion of minority and low-income individuals. The proposed rule would redefine the "best price" for drugs, potentially leading to government savings. However, Puckrein raises concerns that these changes could reduce access to care, dissuade investment in new treatments, and ultimately harm Medicaid beneficiaries, who often have higher rates of disabilities and chronic conditions. He urges policymakers to carefully evaluate the clinical effects of these changes before implementation, emphasizing the principle of "first, do no harm."

title: Minority communities face higher environmental risks for cancer: Report
summary: A new report by the National Minority Quality Forum and CEO Roundtable on Cancer reveals that minority communities face higher environmental cancer risks. The study highlights "Cancer Alley" in Louisiana, where a significant concentration of petrochemical facilities exposes predominantly Black residents to elevated cancer risks. It found that 56% of communities of color live near carcinogenic waste sites, and these communities often lack access to modern cancer care. Historical segregation and zoning laws have contributed to these disparities. The report calls for a new initiative to improve cancer diagnostics and care in underserved areas, in partnership with the White House.

title: Congratulations to Gilbert Gonzales, assistant professor of medicine, health, and society on being named one of the ...
summary: Gilbert Gonzales, assistant professor of medicine, health, and society at Vanderbilt University, has been recognized as one of the National Minority Quality Forum’s 40 under 40 Leaders in Health for 2023. This accolade highlights individuals who are making significant contributions to diversifying and improving the healthcare marketplace. NMQF President and CEO, Gary Puckrein, praised the winners for serving as positive role models for future leaders in minority health.

title: For World Cancer Day, Alliance for Cancer Care Equity Advocates to 'Close the Care Gap' as Observance is Honored ...
summary: For World Cancer Day, the Alliance for Cancer Care Equity (ACCE) advocates for closing the care gap, emphasizing three key policy areas: increasing diversity in clinical trials, improving access to cancer screening and early detection, and expanding patient navigation services. The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN), and National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF) are collaborating on these initiatives, supported by a congressional resolution. Despite progress, significant disparities in cancer outcomes persist, particularly among Black and Native American populations. The ACCE continues to push for legislative support to address these inequities and improve cancer care delivery in the U.S.

title: BCBSA Offers Health Equity Guide to Standardized SDOH Data Collection
summary: The Blue Cross Blue Shield Association (BCBSA), in collaboration with the National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF), has called for the healthcare industry to standardize the collection of social determinants of health (SDOH) data to address health equity gaps. They emphasize the importance of collecting race, ethnicity, language (REL), and sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI) data to identify disparities and implement evidence-based interventions. Current SDOH data collection methods are outdated, contributing to health inequities. BCBSA and NMQF recommend updating the Office of Management and Budget's (OMB) Statistical Policy Directive No. 15, which has not been revised since 1977. The updated directive should include clear requirements for REL and SOGI data collection, align with industry interoperability standards, and incorporate input from diverse stakeholders. The goal is to enforce mandatory, uniform data standards across all government agencies and private healthcare sectors by 2024 to better address health disparities.

title: New Coalition Addresses Health Equity Challenges through Inclusive Data Collection
summary: The National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF), Blue Cross Blue Shield Association (BCBSA), and 17 partner organizations have formed the Data Equity Coalition to address health equity challenges by standardizing data collection on race, ethnicity, language, sexual orientation, and gender identity. This initiative aims to improve health outcomes by ensuring more accurate and representative data, addressing disparities in health care for underserved communities. The coalition will advocate for policy changes, including updates to the Office of Management and Budget's Statistical Policy Directive No. 15, to ensure comprehensive data collection and uniform adoption across government and private sectors. This effort is expected to enable targeted solutions and improve health equity for all communities.

title: The New York Jets Go on the Offense at the Lupus Research Alliance 2024 New Jersey "Walk with Us to Cure Lupus"
summary: The New York Jets are participating in the Lupus Research Alliance's 2024 New Jersey "Walk with Us to Cure Lupus" event at MetLife Stadium on May 4. Around 1,500 supporters aim to raise nearly $500,000 for lupus research and awareness. The event kicks off Lupus Awareness Month with speeches from notable figures, including LRA President Albert T. Roy and representatives from Johnson & Johnson, Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, and the New York Jets. Activities include family fun, Jets player meet-and-greets, and various attractions. The LRA, chaired by Robert Wood Johnson, has funded over $245 million in lupus research, with numerous therapies currently in testing. The organization emphasizes the importance of diverse representation in clinical trials. The event is free, and all donations directly support lupus research. The LRA encourages community involvement through fundraising, advocacy, and participation in clinical research.

title: FDA launches Lupus Treatment Consortium in partnership with the Lupus Research Alliance
summary: The FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research has partnered with the Lupus Research Alliance to launch the Lupus Accelerating Breakthroughs Consortium (Lupus ABC). This public-private partnership aims to address challenges in lupus clinical trials by bringing together patients, medical societies, industry, academic researchers, and federal agencies. Lupus ABC will focus on refining measurement tools to better evaluate treatment impacts and incorporating patient-reported outcomes to recognize the effects of treatments on symptoms that matter most to patients. Lupus is a complex autoimmune disorder affecting various organs and disproportionately impacts women and communities of color. The consortium seeks to advance therapeutic development for lupus by defining common challenges and facilitating impactful approaches.

title: CBS News New York partners with Lupus Research Alliance for New York City Walk to Cure Lupus
summary: CBS News New York partnered with the Lupus Research Alliance for the New York City Walk to Cure Lupus, held on a rainy Saturday morning at the Intrepid. The event is part of the CBS2 #BetterTogether campaign, aiming to support community initiatives. Despite the weather, many participants joined the walk with umbrellas. Lupus, an autoimmune disease, affects millions globally, with symptoms ranging from severe fatigue to organ failure. Andrea O'Neill, vice president of the Lupus Research Alliance, highlighted the disease's impact. All donations from the walk go towards lupus research, with over $300,000 raised so far.

title: Jets and Lupus Research Alliance to Host Lupus Awareness Day
summary: The New York Jets and Lupus Research Alliance will host Lupus Awareness Day on December 3, 2023, at MetLife Stadium during the Jets vs. Falcons game. This event aims to raise awareness and funds for lupus research. The Jets 50/50 Raffle will benefit the Lupus Research Alliance, with fans able to purchase tickets from three hours before kickoff until the start of the fourth quarter. Representatives from the Lupus Research Alliance will be honored at the game, including top fundraisers from the ManyOne Can Walk with Us to Cure Lupus program. Lillian Mendez, a top fundraising team captain and lupus warrior, will serve as an honorary team captain. The Lupus Research Alliance has committed over $245 million to lupus research, with 100% of donations supporting research programs due to their Board of Directors funding all administrative costs. Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting women, especially women of color, during their childbearing years.

title: Stacie Bell, PhD: Lupus Therapeutics and AbbVie to Join Forces for Promising Lupus Treatment Program
summary: Stacie Bell, PhD, executive vice president of Lupus Therapeutics, discussed their partnership with AbbVie for a phase 3 clinical program of upadacitinib in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Lupus Therapeutics will assist with participant recruitment and site activation through the Lupus Clinical Investigators Network (LuCIN) across North America. Bell emphasized AbbVie's strong reputation as a patient-focused research organization and the importance of involving North American experts. The collaboration aims to accelerate the study process and patient recruitment, with hopes for positive clinical trial outcomes. AbbVie will work with regulatory authorities to advance to the next development stage. This partnership represents an opportunity to evaluate a new potential treatment for lupus, offering hope and possible benefits to patients. Bell highlighted that collaboration and relationship building are key to advancing lupus care and developing new treatments.

title: LRA awards scientists $600K for work into new treatments for lupus
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) has awarded $600,000 each to seven scientists under its Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award (LMTA) to investigate molecular pathways or targets for new lupus treatments. The research focuses on various aspects of lupus, including lupus nephritis, novel therapeutic frontiers, lupus' impact on pregnancy, and engineering immune cells for treatment. Three researchers will explore lupus nephritis, targeting kidney inflammation and fibrosis. Other projects include developing CAR-T cell therapies that spare healthy B-cells, targeting neutrophil extracellular traps for antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy, and investigating therapeutic antibodies and genes for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The LRA aims to revolutionize lupus treatment by funding innovative research, ultimately seeking better diagnostics, treatments, and a cure for lupus.

title: Lupus Research Alliance Announces Recipients of the Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) has announced the recipients of the Lupus Mechanisms and Targets Award (LMTA). This award grants up to $600,000 over three years to researchers investigating molecular pathways and targets to develop new or improved therapies for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The award aims to address the incomplete understanding of lupus and its complications. The seven recipients will explore various approaches, including spatial transcriptomics for lupus nephritis, the role of protein S100A4 in kidney fibrosis, genetic and environmental factors in nephritis, CAR-T cell therapy for targeting harmful B cells, therapeutic targets for antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy, blocking B cell activation, and the role of PARP7 in reducing type I interferon induction. The LRA is dedicated to transforming lupus treatment through innovative research, fostering scientific talent, and driving discovery toward better diagnostics and a cure.

title: Lupus Accelerating Breakthroughs Consortium Announces expanded partnership with US FDA at first anniversary ...
summary: The Lupus Accelerating Breakthroughs Consortium (Lupus ABC), managed by the Lupus Research Alliance (LRA), announced an expanded partnership with the U.S. FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER) during its first anniversary meeting. This collaboration aims to accelerate the development of engineered cell therapies for lupus, a complex autoimmune disorder. Launched in March 2023, Lupus ABC is a public-private partnership involving patients, advocates, industry, clinicians, researchers, and government stakeholders. It focuses on personalized treatments and has already initiated projects like the Treatment Response Measure for SLE and Lupus Patient-Reported Outcomes. The inclusion of CBER will enhance the development and evaluation of CAR-T cell therapies, offering hope for potentially curative treatments. This partnership underscores the commitment to improving lupus outcomes, particularly for communities disproportionately affected by the disease.

title: Shaun Jackson Receives $3 Million Lupus Research Alliance Team Award
summary: Dr. Shaun Jackson, a principal investigator at Seattle Children’s Research Institute, has received a $3 million, three-year Global Team Science Award from the Lupus Research Alliance. This grant, the largest given by LRA, supports a multidisciplinary team aiming to improve the diagnosis and treatment of pediatric lupus nephritis, a severe kidney involvement in lupus patients. The research team, led by Dr. Elena Hsieh and including collaborators from multiple institutions, will investigate immune cell abnormalities and genetic changes in pediatric lupus nephritis patients. The project involves analyzing kidney biopsy samples from diverse racial/ethnic groups to identify molecular, cellular, and structural changes associated with disease progression. Dr. Jackson, an expert in pediatric nephrology and rheumatology, will co-lead the immunological and kidney imaging studies, aiming to discover genetic drivers of childhood-onset lupus nephritis and improve personalized treatments.

title: Lupus Therapeutics, AbbVie partner for phase 3 trials of upadacitinib in SLE
summary: Lupus Therapeutics has partnered with AbbVie to conduct phase 3 trials of upadacitinib for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Lupus Therapeutics will assist with patient recruitment, trial site activation, and engagement through its Lupus Clinical Investigators Network. SLE is an autoimmune disease causing inflammation and tissue damage. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Upadacitinib, marketed as Rinvoq, is already FDA-approved for several conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis. Lupus Therapeutics is also collaborating with Nkarta on developing NKX019 CAR NK therapy for lupus nephritis. Current SLE treatments include GSK’s Benlysta and AstraZeneca’s Saphnelo.

title: Lupus Research Alliance Gala Raises Millions for Research to Transform Treatment
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) hosted its annual Breaking Through Gala, raising $2 million for lupus research. The event featured performances by pianist Chloe Flower and was emceed by Emmy Award-winning TV host Tamron Hall. Hall emphasized the importance of raising awareness and funds for lupus, a complex autoimmune disease that disproportionately affects women of color. LRA President Albert T. Roy highlighted the collective effort to fund cutting-edge research for better treatments. The iconic Empire State Building was lit in purple and red to mark the occasion. Honorees included David Kies, recognized for his dedication to lupus research inspired by his daughter's struggle with the disease, and Louis A. Shapiro, for his contributions to lupus treatment advancements. The event underscored the importance of community support in driving research and finding a cure for lupus.

title: A Special Supplement on Hot Topics in Primary Care 2023
summary: The "Special Supplement on Hot Topics in Primary Care 2023" published in The Journal of Family Practice provides updates on key primary care topics. It covers subjects including IBS-C and CIC management, acute pain, continuous glucose monitoring, early intervention in Type 1 diabetes, early life nutrition, insomnia management, new paradigms for CKD management in T2D, optimized management of cardio-renal-metabolic conditions in T2D, reducing cardiopulmonary risk in COPD, reducing ischemic stroke in diabetes, and the use of ICS and fast-acting bronchodilators in asthma. The supplement allows readers to earn up to 4 CME credits upon successful completion of evaluations. Video summaries and links to individual articles are also available.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Invests in ImmunoFree
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced a strategic investment in ImmunoFree, a biomedical company focused on eliminating the need for immunosuppressive medications in organ transplantation. Founded in 2023, ImmunoFree is developing stem cell transplant technology to improve the quality of life for transplant recipients by reducing the side effects of immunosuppressive drugs. This innovation aims to prolong organ life and reduce the risk of cancer and other complications. The collaboration aligns with NKF's mission to advance kidney health and improve transplant outcomes, particularly for socio-economically disadvantaged populations. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, supports early to mid-stage companies developing patient-centric kidney therapies to prevent kidney disease and eliminate the transplant waitlist.

title: Analysis Showing LUPKYNIS® is a Cost-Effective Treatment for Lupus Nephritis Presented at National Kidney ...
summary: An updated analysis presented at the National Kidney Foundation’s Spring Clinical Meeting 2024 demonstrated that LUPKYNIS (voclosporin) is a cost-effective treatment for lupus nephritis (LN), aligning with other treatments for diabetes, blood pressure, and hyperlipidemia. The analysis, based on the ICER Analytics TM LN model, showed that LUPKYNIS is substantially below the willingness-to-pay threshold of $150,000, with incremental costs of $88,076 per QALY and $77,643 per evLYG. Additional data from the Enlight-LN registry and the AURORA clinical program highlighted its efficacy and safety, particularly in reducing proteinuria and glucocorticoid exposure. The findings support LUPKYNIS as a viable treatment option for LN, especially for populations disproportionately affected by the disease, such as Black, Hispanic, and Latino patients.

title: Everly Health Partners With National Kidney Foundation, Expands Kidney Health Testing Suite
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to enhance education about chronic kidney disease. They are also expanding their diabetes monitoring and kidney health testing suite for health plans and employers. Everly Health, a digital health company based in Austin, Texas, offers remote diagnostics and health management through brands like Everlywell, Natalist, and Everly Health Solutions. The partnership will provide co-branded educational materials and kidney health test kits to at-risk patients identified by Everly’s health plan customers. The new testing suite includes tests for heart and kidney health, diabetes monitoring, and uses blood and urine samples. This initiative aims to improve early detection and treatment of kidney disease, thereby reducing severe outcomes like dialysis or transplants. Chronic kidney disease affects about 37 million Americans, with significant healthcare costs. Everly Health hopes to improve these statistics through their expanded testing suite and partnership.

title: NKF's Innovation Fund Invests in ZeitLife to Modernize Kidney Preservation and Logistics
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced an investment through its Innovation Fund in ZeitLife™ Transplant Innovations, Inc. ZeitLife is a global medical device company focused on modernizing kidney preservation and logistics. This collaboration aims to enhance kidney transplantation and health equity. ZeitLife leverages specialized engineering, clinical insights, and advanced technologies to address challenges in organ transportation and logistics. Their work includes developing preservation fluid and machine perfusion technologies to improve the sharing of organs over longer distances. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, supports early to mid-stage companies developing innovative kidney therapies, with goals to prevent kidney disease, eliminate transplant waitlists, and improve dialysis treatments. This strategic investment aligns with NKF’s mission to advance kidney health and improve patient outcomes.

title: Concerned about high blood pressure? Diabetes? Get a free kidney test kit
summary: The National Kidney Foundation is offering free kidney test kits for individuals at risk of kidney disease, particularly those with high blood pressure or Type 2 diabetes. One-third of U.S. adults face these risk factors. The campaign "Are You the 33%?" aims to raise awareness. To get a free kidney test kit, scan the QR code to take the NKF Kidney Risk Quiz. If eligible, you'll receive a Minuteful Kidney test kit from NKF's partner, Healthy.io, delivered to your door. You can test your urine in five minutes using a smartphone app and get immediate results to share with your doctor. More information is available at minuteful.com, and inquiries can be sent to testkits@kidney.org. Published on August 09, 2023.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Klinrisk to Revolutionize Chronic Kidney Disease Care
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Klinrisk through its Innovation Fund to enhance chronic kidney disease (CKD) care. Klinrisk, an AI-based medical device company, aims to improve early identification and management of high-risk CKD through accurate clinical risk prediction. This investment aligns with NKF's mission to advance kidney health and ensure equitable access to innovative treatments. Klinrisk's predictive models enable early intervention, potentially preventing dialysis and transforming patient outcomes. The collaboration focuses on accelerating risk-based care models, particularly for underserved populations. NKF's Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, supports early to mid-stage companies developing patient-centric kidney therapies, aiming to prevent kidney disease, reduce transplant waitlists, and improve dialysis treatments. In the U.S., 37 million adults have CKD, with significant risk factors including diabetes, hypertension, and family history. The NKF is dedicated to awareness, prevention, and treatment of kidney disease.

title: National Kidney Foundation Innovation Fund Announces Investment in Relavo
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has announced an investment in Relavo through its Innovation Fund to further develop the PeritoneX® technology. This technology aims to improve home dialysis safety by disinfecting dialysis tubes to reduce infection risks, thus addressing a significant barrier to the utilization of peritoneal dialysis (PD). PD offers advantages such as lower costs and better patient outcomes compared to in-center dialysis but is underutilized due to infection fears. Relavo's PeritoneX® device aims to make PD safer and more accessible, particularly for patients with limited transportation or those in rural areas.

title: The National Kidney Foundation and Healthy.io partner to Increase Access to Testing for Detection of Kidney Disease
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) and Healthy.io have partnered to enhance access to kidney disease testing. As part of the "Are You the 33%?" campaign, they will distribute Healthy.io's Minuteful Kidney™ at-home test kits for free to at-risk individuals. This initiative, launched on March 9, 2023, aims to raise awareness and promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD). The Minuteful Kidney test, which uses a smartphone camera, is the first FDA-cleared at-home test for CKD. It enables early detection by allowing patients to test for albumin in urine, a key indicator of CKD, from home. This partnership addresses barriers to healthcare access, especially in underserved communities, and aims to reduce the progression of kidney disease through early intervention.

title: National Kidney Foundation Recognizes March as National Kidney Month
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) recognizes March as National Kidney Month, emphasizing the importance of kidney health and addressing chronic kidney disease (CKD). The organization highlights disparities in kidney care, particularly among Black and Hispanic populations, who face the highest rates of kidney disease and mortality. NKF's KIDNEY EQUITY FOR ALL™ initiative aims to ensure equitable access to high-quality kidney care from diagnosis to transplantation. Key efforts include the Kidney Risk Quiz, advocating for the removal of race from the Kidney Disease Risk Index (KDRI), and promoting equitable access to transplants. The CKDIntercept program targets high-risk populations for screening and care. NKF's initiatives strive to eliminate inequities in kidney care and improve outcomes for all patients. For more information, visit www.kidney.org.

title: National Kidney Foundation's Innovation Fund Invests in Diatiro to Advance Kidney Health with New Kidney Pod ...
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has invested in Diatiro through its Innovation Fund to advance kidney health using Diatiro's Kidney Pod technology. This technology aims to improve kidney transplantation by addressing 'warming injury' during the procedure, increasing the number of viable donor kidneys, and enhancing transplant outcomes. The Kidney Pod maintains organs at cold temperatures throughout the transplant process and has received FDA breakthrough designation for expedited development. This investment aligns with NKF's goals to improve health equity and outcomes for kidney disease patients. The NKF Innovation Fund, launched in 2021, supports early to mid-stage companies developing innovative kidney therapies.

title: Joint Statement of the American Society of Nephrology and National Kidney Foundation on the USPSTF Final ...
summary: The American Society of Nephrology and the National Kidney Foundation have expressed concerns regarding the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) Final Research Plan for chronic kidney disease (CKD) screening. They argue that focusing only on asymptomatic, low-risk individuals could overlook significant evidence supporting screening for at-risk populations. They highlight that current clinical practice guidelines for hypertensive populations, which list albuminuria testing as optional, are overstated. Additionally, only about 40% of adults with diabetes receive recommended annual albuminuria screening. They urge the USPSTF to expand its approach to increase CKD diagnosis, particularly among high-risk individuals from disadvantaged groups.

title: Everly Health and National Kidney Foundation Partnership Aims to Save Lives Through Early Detection of Chronic ...
summary: Everly Health has partnered with the National Kidney Foundation to promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD) through increased education and access to high-quality testing, especially in rural and underserved communities in the U.S. CKD affects 37 million American adults, with 90% unaware of their condition. The collaboration aims to raise awareness about CKD and its major risk factors, diabetes and hypertension, which contribute to over two-thirds of cases. Everly Health is also expanding its testing suite to include comprehensive screenings for diabetes, high cholesterol, and high blood pressure, aiming to improve health outcomes and reduce healthcare costs. The initiative includes a pilot program distributing kidney health tests to over 10,000 members, showing effectiveness in detecting kidney health marker abnormalities and potentially preventing disease progression.

title: National Kidney Foundation
summary: The National Kidney Foundation’s Northern Ohio Chapter is seeking volunteers for events and programs across its 32-county region. Founded in 1964, the foundation focuses on the awareness, prevention, and treatment of kidney disease in the U.S. Volunteers can participate in activities such as Kidney Walks, Golf Classic, Patient Symposium, and educational presentations. The foundation also encourages writing note cards for dialysis patients, involving students in educational programs, and supporting patients through Amazon Smile. Additionally, individuals can join various committees or advocacy efforts and donate financially or consider becoming a living kidney organ donor. Key fundraising events include Komedy for Kidneys, the Patient Symposium, Kidney Walks, the NKF Golf Classic, and The Big Ask: The Big Give workshops. Executive Director Anna Tzinis leads the organization, supported by a Board of Advisors.

title: Vasculitis Awareness Month putting focus on community voices
summary: Vasculitis Awareness Month, observed in May, aims to highlight the voices of those affected by vasculitis, a group of rare autoimmune diseases causing blood vessel inflammation. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) is a specific type where antibodies damage small blood vessels. The campaign includes personal stories, social media activities, and an interactive calendar of daily challenges, aimed at raising awareness and support. The Vasculitis Foundation, alongside partners like Amgen and GSK, is spearheading these efforts, emphasizing early diagnosis and effective treatment. Events include webinars, support group meetings, and fundraising activities, all designed to educate and connect the community.

title: Navigating Vasculitis and its Mimics, with Anisha Dua, MD, MPH
summary: Anisha Dua, MD, MPH, discusses the complexities of diagnosing vasculitis and its mimics, emphasizing the importance of accurate diagnosis due to the potent medications involved. Vasculitis, a multisystemic condition, presents with diverse clinical manifestations that can be mimicked by other diseases such as infections, malignancies, and collagen vascular diseases. Dua highlights the necessity of a comprehensive evaluation, including history, physical examination, blood tests, radiology studies, and biopsies, to differentiate vasculitis from its mimics. She underscores the importance of an open-minded approach and a multidisciplinary team in managing these cases. Dua also points out the challenges in diagnosing specific types like CNS vasculitis, where mimics include lymphoma and reversible cerebral vasoconstrictive syndrome. Ongoing research aims to improve diagnostic tools and treatment regimens, reflecting the evolving understanding of vasculitis. She encourages persistence in evaluation and management, demonstrating the dynamic nature of advancements in this field.

title: Vasculitis Awareness Month reminds 'you are not alone' | ANCA...
summary: May is Vasculitis Awareness Month, promoting the theme "Navigating the unknown: You are not alone." The Vasculitis Foundation has organized various activities, including an interactive calendar with daily challenges (#VAM2023), social media campaigns, and a live webinar. Vasculitis is a rare autoimmune disease causing inflammation in blood vessels, potentially damaging organs and tissues. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) affects small blood vessels due to self-reactive antibodies. The foundation highlights patient and care partner heroes through collectible trading cards and encourages sharing personal "Victory Over Vasculitis" stories. Other events include support group meetings, a virtual trivia tournament, and the International Vasculitis Symposium in July. Educational resources and donation opportunities are also available, with matched donations up to $6,500. This year's awareness month is sponsored by Amgen and GSK.

title: Mifepristone 24 hours before misoprostol for second-trimester abortion cuts induction time by 3 hours
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS
summary: A study presented at the 2024 American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists meeting found that administering mifepristone 24 hours before misoprostol for second-trimester abortion reduces induction time by 3 hours compared to a 12-hour interval. The median induction time was 9.5 hours for the 24-hour regimen versus 12.5 hours for the 12-hour regimen. There were no significant differences in patient satisfaction or adverse events between the two groups. This finding suggests that a 24-hour mifepristone-to-misoprostol interval can provide more efficient and patient-centered care without compromising safety.

title: Wolters Kluwer and The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists announce plans to launch O&G Open
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS
summary: Wolters Kluwer and The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) are launching O&G Open, a new open access journal dedicated to evidence-based obstetrics and gynecology care. This peer-reviewed online journal aims to provide immediate, worldwide distribution of articles on relevant topics, building on the reputation of the existing Obstetrics & Gynecology journal. The initiative responds to the growing demand for open access publications, offering unrestricted, free-of-charge access to research. O&G Open will serve as a global educational resource, supporting authors in meeting funders' requirements and advancing the field by disseminating emerging data. ACOG, a leading organization in women's health, emphasizes the importance of equitable and exceptional care. Wolters Kluwer, a global leader in professional information services, supports this venture by leveraging its expertise in healthcare and regulatory compliance.

title: DeSpir Logistics First to Be Accredited by HDA and PCSC Good Distribution Practices (GDP) Accreditation Program
summary: DeSpir Logistics has become the first company to achieve the Healthcare Distribution Alliance (HDA) Good Distribution Practices (GDP) Accreditation, administered by the Pharmaceutical Cargo Security Coalition (PCSC). This accreditation sets the highest standards for handling and transporting healthcare goods. DeSpir Logistics specializes in temperature-controlled and high-value cargo, ensuring the safe transportation of life-saving products. This milestone underscores DeSpir's commitment to maintaining the integrity and security of pharmaceutical items throughout the supply chain. The GDP guidelines align with stringent European standards, emphasizing safe storage, transportation, and distribution of medicinal products.

title: Data Issues Abound as DSCSA Deadline Nears
summary: The Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA) deadline on November 27, 2023, requires trading partners to add serialized pharmaceutical product data to transaction information. Despite progress, significant challenges remain in connecting data systems among manufacturers and distributors. A survey revealed that many manufacturers and distributors are not yet fully prepared, risking supply chain disruptions and potential drug shortages. The Healthcare Distribution Alliance (HDA) has urged the FDA to provide exemptions on a case-by-case basis to avoid broad enforcement discretion. HDA also recommends a stabilization period for fine-tuning processes. Collaboration and communication between stakeholders are crucial for achieving compliance and enhancing supply chain security.

title: Indiana organization receives grant to address language, financial barriers to adult immunization
summary: The Indiana Immunization Coalition received a grant from Glaxo-Smith-Kline to address language and financial barriers in adult immunization. This grant is part of an initiative to support community-based organizations in improving vaccine access. The Coalition plans to use the funds to provide interpreters and cover vaccine costs, targeting immigrant communities who may avoid health services due to language barriers and fear of government affiliation. Additionally, they aim to develop educational materials in languages like Spanish and Haitian Creole. The organization is also collaborating with community members to find effective ways to deliver vaccine education and connect people to services.

title: 'Free and accessible' | Campus | purdueexponent.org
summary: Purdue University, through its College of Pharmacy and the Interdisciplinary Women's Reproductive Health Collaborative (IWRHC), hosted a free vaccine clinic at the Córdova Recreational Sports Center. The clinic aimed to provide accessible immunizations, including HPV, meningitis, and flu vaccines, to students and the broader community. The initiative, supported by the Indiana Immunization Coalition, involved extensive planning and volunteer efforts from pharmacy students and faculty. The clinic not only facilitated vaccinations but also served as a platform for data collection and research on vaccine awareness and decision-making. The next clinic is scheduled for October 19, offering various vaccines including the COVID booster.

title: Statement from Biocom California and MassBio on America's Biotechnology Leadership and National Security
summary: Biocom California and MassBio emphasize the importance of maintaining U.S. leadership in biotechnology for national security. They advocate for expanding domestic pharmaceutical research and manufacturing to ensure access to innovative medicines, particularly for smaller companies dependent on federal support. Both organizations commit to working with policymakers and industry leaders to promote innovation and protect national security. Biocom California, representing over 1,700 members, focuses on public policy, industry networking, STEM education, and value-driven purchasing programs. MassBio, with 1,600+ members, aims to advance life sciences in Massachusetts through policy advocacy, education, and industry services.

title: Mr. Biotech: Dan Gober Has a Vital Mission
summary: Dan Gober, the new executive director of Biocom Los Angeles, aims to boost the region’s bioscience industry and its microclusters. Replacing Stephanie Hsiesh, Gober previously worked with bioscience startups and pharmaceutical companies. His focus includes fostering collaboration among microclusters, enhancing local government support for life science companies, and attracting venture capital. Gober highlights the organic development of microclusters around research centers like UCLA, USC, and Caltech. He emphasizes the challenge of creating a unified megacluster due to geographical spread but notes Biocom’s efforts in facilitating industry leader forums. Recent successes include regulatory reforms in Pasadena, making it easier for life science companies to operate. Gober’s goals for Biocom also involve increasing member companies and showcasing the value of their resources and advocacy. He believes that initiatives like the new California Immunology Center at UCLA will attract national attention and investment to the Los Angeles bioscience sector.

title: Aspen Neuroscience Cofounder Dr. Andrés Bratt-Leal Receives 2023 Biocom California Life Science Catalyst Award
summary: Dr. Andrés Bratt-Leal, co-founder and senior vice-president of research and development at Aspen Neuroscience, has been honored with the 2023 Biocom California Life Science Catalyst Award. This award recognizes young innovators in the California life sciences sector who are making significant contributions to human health through research and entrepreneurship. Dr. Bratt-Leal's work focuses on developing personalized induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology for treating Parkinson's Disease (PD). His efforts, alongside his team, have advanced the field of stem cell research, culminating in the FDA's clearance for Aspen's Investigational New Drug application for ANPD001, paving the way for clinical trials.

title: Zoning barriers and limited space: How biotech can expand on L.A.'s Westside - L.A. Business First
summary: Limited space and zoning barriers are hindering the growth of the biotech industry on Los Angeles' Westside. Demand for life-science space has outpaced supply, particularly in areas like Culver City and Santa Monica. Industry professionals, including Biocom California panelists, emphasized the need for readily available R&D spaces to foster a biotech ecosystem. Appia Bio CEO JJ Kang highlighted the challenges of finding suitable facilities, while Gensler's Ryley Poblete stressed the importance of clustering biotech companies near research hubs like UCLA and Caltech. The panelists called for zoning changes and state or city incentives to attract and retain biotech companies. UCLA's acquisition of the Westside Pavilion for an immunology research center was noted as a significant development.

title: BioSpain breaking records
summary: BioSpain 2023, held in Barcelona, is set to break records with over 2,100 attendees, 220 exhibitors, and 4,700 partnering meetings. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the event highlights the significance of biotechnology in addressing global challenges such as climate change, sustainable food production, and healthcare. Ana Polanco, President of Asebio, emphasized the need for improved regulations to enhance access to therapeutic innovations in Spain. The event also underscores Barcelona's ambition to become Europe's leading biotech hub, supported by international collaborations. Spanish biotech has grown significantly, with nearly 900 companies contributing to the economy through investments, job creation, and research. In 2021, the sector's impact on GDP was €11,183 million, with substantial investments in R&D and a high percentage of researchers in the workforce. The industry's growth is evidenced by Spain's strong position in global biotechnological scientific production.

title: Biocom California Institute Partners with Regional Workforce Development Board NOVAworks to Support the Life ...
summary: Biocom California Institute, a non-profit supporting life science innovation, has partnered with NOVAworks, a regional workforce development agency, to assist the life science workforce in the San Francisco Bay Area. This collaboration aims to support both employees and employers in the life science sector, particularly those undergoing career transitions due to layoffs. Initiatives include educational content about job opportunities in the life sciences, programs through local educational institutions, mentorship, and connecting NOVAworks clients with expanding life science companies. The partnership seeks to leverage Biocom's industry connections to help companies navigate workforce changes and access available resources.

title: UCLA's New Research Center Could Be The Biotech Boost The LA Area Needs
summary: UCLA's acquisition of the former Westside Pavilion mall for $700M, with $500M from the state, will transform it into a biotech hub, potentially boosting LA’s life sciences industry. The 587K SF property, now called One Westside, will house the UCLA Center for Quantum Science and Engineering and the new California Institute for Immunology and Immunotherapy. Dan Gober of Biocom California and Allan Glass of HATCHspaces believe this development could attract companies and research funding to LA, leveraging the area's existing infrastructure and proximity to the E Line transit corridor. Despite challenges in the life sciences real estate market, this project could position LA as a rising biotech hub.

title: NFID Celebrates 50th Anniversary with Gala Honoring Public Health Heroes
