summary: The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) celebrates its 50th anniversary with a gala in Washington, DC on September 14, 2023. Founded in 1973 by visionaries like Dr. John P. Utz and Dr. Richard J. Duma, NFID aims to raise awareness about infectious diseases. Initially concerned with the scarcity of research funding, NFID has since focused on educating both the public and healthcare professionals about immunization and infectious disease prevention. The organization hosts various educational programs and public outreach initiatives, including conferences and webinars. NFID is unique as it is not a membership organization but a foundation dedicated to education. Its Board of Directors includes diverse professionals, reflecting its inclusive approach. The 50th anniversary gala will also launch the 1973 Society to honor major donors. NFID continues to play a crucial role in public health education and advocacy.

title: Annual Conference on Vaccinology Research: Challenges, Breakthroughs, and the Future of Vaccines
summary: The Annual Conference on Vaccinology Research, hosted by the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases, covered key topics including COVID-19 vaccine development, the quest for a universal influenza vaccine, and advancements in respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) prevention. Dr. William Schaffner highlighted the rapid development of COVID-19 vaccines, the importance of effective communication to combat vaccine hesitancy, and the need for easy access to vaccines. The conference also discussed the potential of a universal flu vaccine to simplify immunization processes and the excitement around newly licensed RSV vaccines. Behavioral science's role in vaccine acceptance and the inspiration provided by women leaders in vaccinology were also emphasized. Looking ahead, the future of vaccinology may extend beyond infectious diseases to areas like Alzheimer's and opioid addiction. The overarching goal remains the prevention and elimination of diseases through effective vaccination strategies.

title: UAMS' Robert H. Hopkins Jr., M.D., Named Medical Director of National Foundation for Infectious Diseases
summary: Robert H. Hopkins Jr., M.D., a professor at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS), has been appointed as the medical director of the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID). Hopkins, known for his decision-making and communication skills, will continue his roles at UAMS while focusing on expanding NFID programs, building vaccine confidence, addressing health equity, and increasing disease prevention awareness. He will also serve as the chief medical spokesman for NFID and a liaison to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. His appointment comes at a critical time, given the challenges of misinformation and the opportunities presented by effective vaccines.

title: Data-Driven Approach to Increasing US Vaccine Uptake
summary: The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID), in partnership with technology company Fraym, has launched a pilot project aimed at increasing vaccine uptake across the US. This initiative, supported by the Association of Immunization Managers (AIM) and the National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO), seeks to provide hyperlocal insights to public health stakeholders. The project aims to map immunization attitudes, behaviors, and barriers to help target messages and resources effectively within communities. NFID has a longstanding commitment to educating the public and healthcare professionals about the importance of vaccines and aims to use data to enhance public health outreach and service delivery.

title: Flu, Covid vaccination rates decline, new survey data show
summary: Vaccination rates for flu and Covid-19 have declined since the pandemic's onset, with a new survey by the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases indicating many Americans plan to skip these vaccines this fall. Only about 20% of Americans are concerned about contracting flu, Covid, or RSV. Approximately 43% of U.S. adults are uncertain or do not plan to get a flu shot, and only 40% intend to get an updated Covid shot. The survey highlights concerns about side effects, vaccine distrust, and perceived inefficacy as reasons for this hesitation. CDC Director Mandy Cohen emphasized the importance of vaccinations, sharing her personal commitment to getting vaccinated. Federal officials are working to address issues in vaccine distribution and insurance coverage. Rebuilding public confidence in vaccines is seen as crucial to preventing severe health outcomes and maintaining healthcare capacity.

title: NFID Announces 2024 Recipients of Prestigious Awards
summary: The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) announced the 2024 recipients of its prestigious awards. Seth F. Berkley, MD, will receive the Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter Humanitarian Award for his work in global health and equitable vaccine access, notably leading Gavi and co-creating COVAX. Ighovwerha (Igho) Ofotokun, MD, MSc, will receive the Maxwell Finland Award for Scientific Achievement for his research on HIV and his efforts to address systemic inequities in research. Grace Lee, MD, MPH, will receive the John P. Utz Leadership Award for her leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic as chair of the US Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. The awards will be presented at the NFID Awards Gala in September 2024 in Washington, DC.

title: Experts Urge Vaccination as Measles Cases Rise
summary: Experts from the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) urge the public to stay updated on the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccination due to a rise in measles cases in the US. As of February 2024, 41 cases have been reported across 16 states. Measles was declared eliminated in the US in 2000, but cases still occur due to international travelers and unvaccinated communities. Measles is highly contagious and can lead to severe complications, including pneumonia, seizures, brain damage, and death. Two doses of the MMR vaccine provide 97% protection and lifelong immunity. Unvaccinated individuals exposed to measles should receive the vaccine within 72 hours to prevent the disease. NFID emphasizes the importance of vaccination to prevent the spread of measles.

title: 3 Things To Know on World Pneumonia Day
summary: World Pneumonia Day on November 12 aims to raise awareness about pneumococcal disease, which causes serious conditions like pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis. Annually, 150,000 people in the US are hospitalized for pneumococcal pneumonia, with a 5% mortality rate. Despite these statistics, only 22% of US adults are concerned about infection. High-risk groups, including older adults and those with chronic health conditions, are often unaware of the need for vaccination. The National Foundation for Infectious Diseases (NFID) and the American Lung Association emphasize the importance of pneumococcal vaccination to prevent these diseases. Vaccines are recommended for young children, older adults, and individuals with certain health conditions. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for serious infections. The NFID and American Lung Association encourage discussions with healthcare professionals about vaccination to protect against pneumococcal disease.

title: Repeat COVID-19 vaccinations elicit antibodies that neutralize variants, other viruses – Washington University School ...
summary: A study by Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis found that repeat COVID-19 vaccinations with updated versions promote antibodies that neutralize various virus variants and related coronaviruses. Despite the end of the COVID-19 global public health emergency, the virus continues to evolve, leading to new variants. The World Health Organization recommends annual vaccine updates to counteract this. Concerns exist that prior immunity might interfere with responses to new vaccines, as seen with flu vaccines. However, the study shows that prior immunity to SARS-CoV-2 enhances the development of broadly neutralizing antibodies. These findings suggest that periodic re-vaccination could help build a stock of antibodies that protect against emerging variants and related coronaviruses. The study indicates that regular updates to COVID-19 vaccines might provide substantial protection against future coronavirus pandemics.

title: KU Med executive vice chancellor retires after decade with school - Kansas City Business Journal
summary: Dr. Robert Simari, the executive vice chancellor of the University of Kansas Medical Center, has retired after over six years in the role and a decade with the institution. Simari, a cardiologist and 1986 graduate of KU School of Medicine, previously served as vice chairman of the Mayo Clinic's Division of Cardiology Diseases before returning to KU in 2014 as executive dean of the medical school. He became interim executive vice chancellor in 2018 and was later appointed to the position. Under his leadership, the KU Cancer Center achieved Comprehensive Cancer Center status in 2022. Simari will remain on faculty until his official retirement on June 30. Dr. Matthias Salathe, vice chancellor for research and chair of the Internal Medicine Department, has been named interim executive vice chancellor.

title: NIH renews COBRE grant for Kansas Institute for Precision Medicine
summary: The Kansas Institute for Precision Medicine (KIPM) has received a renewed $11.4 million COBRE grant from the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, part of the NIH. This five-year grant aims to enhance patient outcomes by supporting and training new physician-scientists in precision medicine, which uses genetic, environmental, and lifestyle information for disease prevention, accurate diagnoses, and effective treatments. The grant will provide financial support, mentoring, and research funding to junior investigators and offer pilot grants to established researchers. The KIPM, created with an initial COBRE grant in 2019, is the only research center in Kansas focused on precision medicine and career development for physician-scientists. The renewed grant will also expand KIPM’s research infrastructure, including cores for data science, biobanking, and biomedical engineering, to make them self-sustaining shared resources.

title: KU Medical Center researchers working to address lead exposure prevention in southeast Kansas
summary: Researchers at KU Medical Center are addressing lead exposure prevention in southeast Kansas, where children have elevated blood-lead levels (EBLL) more than twice the national average. This region, part of the historic Tri-State District, has a legacy of lead contamination due to past mining activities. Efforts at lead prevention have declined, with inadequate testing and education. The Communities Organizing to Promote Equity (COPE) project, led by Christina Pacheco and her team, aims to improve health equity and received a $50,000 grant to enhance rural lead poisoning prevention. They plan to map existing policies, study successful regulations from other states, and create a policy toolkit to drive legislative action.

title: KU Medical Center's COPE program built an infrastructure to execute 'Operation Hydration' throughout Kansas
summary: KU Medical Center’s COPE program developed an infrastructure to launch ‘Operation Hydration’ in response to a severe August heatwave in Kansas. This initiative, supported by a 2021 COVID-19 prevention grant, mobilized local volunteers and community health workers to distribute cold water and ice, aiding vulnerable populations. The extreme heat, with indices reaching up to 130 degrees, posed significant health risks, particularly to outdoor workers and the homeless. COPE's pre-existing network, originally focused on COVID-19 testing, facilitated rapid deployment and effective community outreach. Volunteers distributed approximately 21,000 bottles of water, providing crucial relief and preventing heat-related emergencies. This effort highlighted the program's adaptability and the importance of community partnerships in public health emergencies. The COPE grant, now in its third year, continues to enhance health knowledge and self-sufficiency among Kansans, particularly in rural areas, by addressing various community needs.

title: KU Medical Center graduates more than 700 students prepared to begin their new careers
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center graduated nearly 750 students from its Schools of Health Professions, Medicine, and Nursing on May 11, 2024. The ceremonies, held at Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall in Kansas City, Kansas, were attended by friends and family and also livestreamed. Dean Abiodun Akinwuntan highlighted the 50th anniversary of the School of Health Professions. The School of Medicine saw 202 students receive M.D. degrees, with 82 earning advanced degrees and certificates. Keynote speaker Mark Meyer, M.D., encouraged graduates to embrace their careers with professionalism and gratitude. Jean Foret Giddens, Ph.D., addressed 206 nursing graduates, emphasizing the quality of their education. Graduates reflected on their unique journeys, including overcoming the challenges of the pandemic and pursuing diverse paths in their education and careers.

title: KU medical student publishes study on feline facial expressions
summary: Lauren Scott, a first-year medical student at the University of Kansas, published a study revealing that domestic cats have 276 unique facial expressions used for communication. Initially conducted as an undergraduate anthropology project at UCLA, Scott recorded and analyzed 53 shorthair cats using the Animal Facial Action Coding System. Her research, supervised by Brittany Florkiewicz, highlights cats' social skills, contradicting their aloof stereotype, and suggests domestication influences these expressions. Scott’s interest in medical anthropology was inspired by Paul Farmer's work, leading her to UCLA for its science-focused anthropology program. Her feline research experience contributed to her securing a cancer immunology research position at UCLA. Scott chose KU Medical School for its focus on structural inequalities and diverse patient care, aiming to continue research in oncology.

title: Research at KU Medical Center experiences tremendous growth
summary: KU Medical Center has seen significant growth in its research efforts, nearly doubling its federal research portfolio since 2017 and increasing clinical trial revenues by 45% since 2021. In fiscal year 2023, federally funded research spending reached over $120 million, with total research spending hitting $180 million, a 50% increase since 2019. The School of Health Professions' research portfolio has grown over four times since 2016, now exceeding $20 million. The School of Nursing has also expanded its research, securing substantial funding and addressing critical health issues. The School of Medicine has received large grants from the NIH and other agencies, enhancing its research capabilities. Administrative and policy changes, along with clinical integration with The University of Kansas Health System, have further accelerated research growth, positioning KU Medical Center to lead multicenter clinical trials and achieve significant advances in health sciences.

title: Exploring the Future of Health Care: KU Medical Center Introduces Innovative Health Career Exploration Day
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center's Area Health Education Center (AHEC) will host Health Career Exploration Day on April 10, 2024. This event aims to inspire aspiring health care professionals through an immersive experience in various health care careers. About 120 students will participate in activities like orthopedic research, respiratory therapy, and clinical laboratory science rotations. They will also interact with admissions representatives and network with experienced health care professionals. Led by Tina Goosz-Garetson, the event aims to showcase the breadth of health care professions and inspire future health care leaders. Invitations will be sent in mid-March, and interested parties can contact Tina Goosz-Garetson for more information.

title: Wichita Biomedical Campus, a partnership between the University of Kansas and Wichita State University, moves from ...
summary: The Wichita Biomedical Campus, a collaboration between the University of Kansas and Wichita State University, has moved from planning to reality. The groundbreaking ceremony for this $300 million, 471,000-square-foot facility in downtown Wichita included leaders from both universities and state officials. The campus will house the Wichita campuses of KU School of Medicine and School of Pharmacy, as well as health professions students from Wichita State and WSU Tech. It aims to provide advanced laboratories, technology, and simulation rooms for hands-on training. The facility will foster collaboration among future doctors, nurses, physical therapists, and emergency medical technicians, enhancing education and healthcare in Kansas. The first phase is expected to open in spring 2027. Funding comes from various sources, including $190 million from the Kansas Legislature and $15 million from the Kansas Department for Aging and Disability Services. This project is seen as a significant step toward improving health care and education in the state.

title: An $11.5 million grant from NIH launches Implementation Science for Equity Center at KU Medical Center
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center has received an $11.5 million grant from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to establish the Implementation Science for Equity Center. This center aims to bridge the gap between research and clinical practice, particularly focusing on reducing health inequities in rural, minority, and underserved populations. The center will be part of the NIH's Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) program. Led by Kimber Richter and Christie Befort, the center will support and mentor early-career investigators in implementation science, ensuring equitable health care delivery. Initial projects include interventions for Latino caregivers, smoking cessation for low-income pregnant women, and preeclampsia prevention among Black women.

title: Ovarian Cancer Awareness | Hillary Theakston from the Clearity Foundation visits CBS 8 Mornings
summary: Hillary Theakston from the Clearity Foundation visited CBS 8 Mornings to discuss ovarian cancer awareness. Clearity, a San Diego-based national nonprofit organization, focuses on ovarian cancer and hosts its annual Teal Women Celebration.

title: Clearity Shines Light On 'Silent Killer' On Ovarian Cancer Day
summary: The Clearity Foundation, based in San Diego, is raising awareness about ovarian cancer, often termed the "silent killer," on World Ovarian Cancer Day. The foundation emphasizes the importance of early detection and encourages women to advocate for their health when experiencing symptoms like vaginal bleeding, bloating, abdominal or pelvic pain, and feeling full quickly. Founded in 2008 by ovarian cancer survivor Laura Shawver, Clearity provides personalized education, counseling, and navigation for ovarian cancer treatment and clinical trials. The organization offers free services and relies on donor support. In May, Clearity celebrates Teal Revolution month, urging supporters to raise awareness and funds. Their annual Teal Woman gala will be held in September. Ovarian cancer is the fifth leading cause of cancer deaths among women, with an estimated 19,710 new diagnoses and 13,270 deaths expected this year.

title: Cancer Facts & Figures 2024
summary: The American Cancer Society's "Cancer Facts & Figures 2024" provides comprehensive data on cancer incidence, mortality, and survival rates, including estimates of new cases and deaths by cancer type and U.S. state for 2024. The report highlights cancer risk factors, early detection, and treatment options. A special section focuses on cancer in LGBTQ+ populations, addressing risk factors, screening prevalence, and efforts to reduce disparities. The publication serves as an educational companion to the scientific paper "Cancer Statistics 2024" in the journal CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians. The report aims to inform and guide cancer prevention and care efforts.

title: American Cancer Society and Sleep Number Win Golden Halo Award for Best Intersectional Initiative
summary: Sleep Number Corporation and the American Cancer Society (ACS) received the 2024 Golden Halo Award for Best Intersectional Initiative from Engage for Good. This award honors their collaborative efforts in integrating sleep science with cancer prevention and care, marking a significant achievement in corporate social responsibility. Their initiatives include incorporating Sleep Number’s sleep data into cancer research, engaging communities in cancer prevention through partnerships like the NFL-supported Crucial Catch campaign, and enhancing sleep experiences for cancer patients at ACS Hope Lodge® communities. This partnership aims to address the interconnected needs of individuals across sleep and cancer care, demonstrating the power of intersectionality in tackling complex social issues.

title: American Cancer Society spokesperson talks benefits of new study
summary: The American Cancer Society has initiated the largest population study focused on black women and cancer, aiming to enroll over 100,000 participants. The study, led by spokesperson Chris Draft, who lost his wife to lung cancer, seeks to improve health outcomes and prevent future cases. It will gather data from black women aged 25-55 across 20 states to understand environmental and social factors affecting cancer. Co-investigator Dr. Alpa Patel emphasized the need for equal opportunities in cancer prevention, detection, treatment, and survival. The study highlights that black women have the highest cancer death rates and shortest survival times in the U.S.

title: “Change the Odds” Brings Pfizer Together with the American Cancer Society to Bridge the Gap in Cancer Care ...
summary: Pfizer has partnered with the American Cancer Society (ACS) to launch the "Change the Odds: Uniting to Improve Cancer Outcomes" initiative, aimed at addressing disparities in cancer care. This three-year initiative, supported by a $15 million commitment from Pfizer, focuses on improving health outcomes in medically underrepresented communities in the U.S., starting with breast and prostate cancer. The collaboration seeks to provide no- and low-cost screenings, cancer prevention resources, and support services, particularly targeting racial and ethnic minorities in urban areas and residents of rural areas who face limited access to quality care.

title: The American Cancer Society and Color Health Announce Expansion of a Comprehensive Cancer Care Solution
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) and Color Health have announced an expansion of their comprehensive cancer care program. This initiative aims to support employees and union members through all stages of cancer, from screening to survivorship. The program includes clinical teams for abnormal screenings, specialized care for high-risk individuals, and integrated support for those in treatment and survivors. A pilot study showed significant improvements in screening adherence and participant satisfaction. The program also features a Virtual Cancer Clinic offering swift diagnostics and robust patient support, including mental health services and logistical assistance. This expansion addresses the need for holistic cancer care, emphasizing early detection and continuous support.

title: American Cancer Society's Relay For Life helps raise funds for cancer patients
summary: The American Cancer Society’s Relay For Life is an event aimed at raising funds for cancer patients. This event helps support those battling cancer by generating financial resources.

title: Drink brand backed by Chicago athletes partners with American Cancer Society
summary: A drink brand, CoCo5, which is backed by Chicago athletes, has partnered with the American Cancer Society. Jim Reynolds, the owner of CoCo5, discussed the partnership with CBS 2’s Ryan Baker. This collaboration aims to support cancer research and awareness efforts.

title: American Cancer Society's Road to Recovery Program
summary: The American Cancer Society’s Road to Recovery Program in Richmond, Va., aids community members who wish to help cancer patients and their families. Dee Kannon, a Volunteer Driver and Cancer Survivor, along with Elizabeth Ballard, Senior Development Manager, discussed the program's benefits. For more information, call 1-800-227-2345 or visit www.cancer.org/drive.

title: 2024 Cancer Facts & Figures Cancer | 2024--First Year the US Expects More than 2M New Cases of Cancer
summary: In 2024, the U.S. is expected to see over 2 million new cancer cases for the first time, with around 611,000 projected deaths. Despite a 30-year decline in overall cancer death rates due to advances in smoking cessation, early detection, and treatments, incidences of many common cancers are rising. This increase is largely attributed to an aging population and higher diagnoses of cancers like breast, prostate, endometrial, pancreatic, kidney, and melanoma. Notably, cancer is affecting younger individuals more, with a significant rise in colorectal cancer among those under 50. Racial disparities persist, with Black men and American Indian and Alaska Native populations experiencing higher cancer death rates. The LGBTQ+ community also faces unique cancer risks, but data on this group is limited. The American Cancer Society emphasizes the need for targeted efforts to address these disparities and improve cancer outcomes for all.

title: American Cancer Society Launches New Program that Provides Individualized Assistance to Those Impacted by Cancer
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) has launched ACS CARES (Community Access to Resources, Education, and Support), a new program providing individualized, non-clinical support to cancer patients and caregivers via a mobile app and trained volunteers. The program aims to mitigate barriers to care, deliver reliable information, and offer emotional support. It includes features like personalized cancer-related information, one-on-one connections with volunteers, and direct access to ACS cancer information specialists. Additionally, trained volunteers are placed in oncology clinics for in-person support. A $1 million commitment from the Deloitte Health Equity Institute will help expand the program, focusing on multicultural engagement and increasing volunteer recruitment at historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, and rural health systems. This initiative is part of ACS's broader strategy to improve patient navigation and health equity.

title: American Cancer Society launch VOICES of Black Women study in Illinois
summary: The American Cancer Society has initiated the VOICES of Black Women study in Illinois, the largest population study focused on cancer in Black women. This 30-year behavioral and environmental study aims to enroll over 100,000 Black women aged 25 to 55 from diverse backgrounds across 20 states. The study seeks to understand the multi-level drivers of cancer incidence, mortality, and resilience within this demographic. It will gather data on environmental and social factors influencing health outcomes. Dr. Deepa Cyriac emphasized that the study aims to address health disparities and improve survival rates for Black women, who currently have the highest death rate and shortest survival for most cancers among any racial or ethnic group in the U.S.

title: 110th Anniversary
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) is celebrating its 110th anniversary, marking over a century of advancements in cancer research, patient support, and advocacy. Founded in 1913, ACS has significantly contributed to early cancer detection, reduced smoking rates, and increased survival rates. Key milestones include the adoption of the Pap test, the discovery of chemotherapy, and the establishment of the Hope Lodge™ and 24/7 cancer helpline. ACS has funded groundbreaking research, leading to a 33% decline in cancer mortality since 1991. The organization continues to support cancer patients and their families, advocate for policy changes, and strive for diversity in the cancer workforce.

title: To Drive a Deeper Understanding of Cancer Disparities, American Cancer Society Launches Largest U.S. Population ...
summary: The American Cancer Society has launched the VOICES of Black Women® study, the largest U.S. population study focused on cancer risk and outcomes among Black women. The study aims to enroll over 100,000 Black women aged 25-55 from diverse backgrounds and income levels across 20 states and D.C. This long-term study will collect data on behavioral and environmental factors to understand cancer disparities and improve health outcomes. The study is led by researchers Dr. Alpa Patel and Dr. Lauren McCullough and emphasizes collaboration with Black communities and health experts. Recruitment began in October 2023, with participants providing informed consent and periodic survey responses over 30 years.

title: American Cancer Society Updates Lung Cancer Screening Guideline: Nearly Five Million U.S. Adults who Smoke and ...
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) has updated its lung cancer screening guidelines to reduce deaths from the disease, recommending yearly low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) scans for individuals aged 50 to 80 who smoke or formerly smoked with a 20-year or greater pack-year history. This update, published in the ACS journal, expands the eligibility criteria from the previous guidelines set in 2013. The changes include lowering the starting age from 55 to 50, reducing the pack-year history requirement from 30 to 20, and removing the years-since-quitting criterion. The ACS emphasizes the importance of consulting healthcare providers about the benefits and risks of screening and encourages smoking cessation.

title: Researchers develop “game-changing” blood test for stroke detection
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Researchers from Brigham and Women's Hospital have developed a new blood test that can quickly and accurately identify large vessel occlusion (LVO) strokes, a severe type of ischemic stroke. The test combines blood-based biomarkers (GFAP and D-dimer) with a clinical score (FAST-ED) to detect LVO strokes with 93% specificity and 81% sensitivity. This advancement could enable faster, life-saving interventions, particularly mechanical thrombectomy, which is crucial for LVO stroke treatment. The study, published in "Stroke: Vascular and Interventional Neurology," demonstrates the test's potential for use in prehospital settings, especially in low- and middle-income countries where advanced imaging is scarce. Further trials are planned to evaluate the test's performance in ambulances and its ability to expedite stroke patient triage. The research was supported by Innovate UK and private funding.

title: Privacy Incident At Brigham And Women's Hospital 29 March
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Brigham and Women's Physician Organization (BWPO), part of Mass General Brigham, is notifying individuals of a privacy incident involving patient data. The incident traces back to Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, which discovered in January 2024 that a 2019 file containing BWPO patient data was backed up on its server by an employee who worked part-time for BWPO. This file was accessed by an unauthorized third party during a cybersecurity ransomware attack on Harvard Pilgrim between March 28, 2023, and April 17, 2023. The incident did not affect BWPO or Mass General Brigham's systems.

title: Brigham and Women's Hospital Develops Virtual Reality Hospice, Palliative Training Partnership
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston has partnered with Jolly Good Inc. to create a virtual reality (VR) training program aimed at enhancing communication skills for professionals in hospice and palliative care. This program, called the Palliative Care Communication Training VR, immerses clinicians in realistic scenarios to help them develop compassionate communication skills with seriously ill patients and their families. Dr. Kei Ouchi, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School, emphasized the importance of such training for providing quality, patient-centered care and reducing clinical errors. The VR program offers a scalable, cost-effective solution for time-pressed clinicians to practice high-stress scenarios and improve their communication skills. Jolly Good Inc., founded in Tokyo in 2015, specializes in VR and AI programs for medical education and partners with institutions like Harvard University.

title: AI pharmacist? Brigham study tests how new tech can help manage patient meds
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Brigham and Women's Hospital is collaborating with FeelBetter, an AI company, to enhance patient medication management. The AI tool aims to help doctors and pharmacists oversee complex prescription regimens, ensuring patients are on the safest and most effective treatments. Dr. Lisa Rotenstein, leading the study, highlights the challenge of manually tracking multiple medications for patients with chronic conditions. FeelBetter's AI analyzes health records to identify problematic drug combinations and streamline treatments. The AI flags high-risk patients for review by a care team, who then inform patients of necessary medication adjustments. The study aims to improve the quality of life for patients by reducing hospital visits and managing chronic diseases more effectively.

title: Researchers find gene that may put Black Americans at higher risk for heart failure
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Duke University have identified a gene variant that may increase the risk of heart failure and death among Black Americans. This variant, present in 3% to 4% of Black Americans, heightens the risk of heart failure starting in their 60s and death in their 70s. Carriers of this gene tend to die 2 to 2.5 years earlier than expected. With nearly half a million Black Americans over 50 carrying this gene, an estimated million years of life could be lost. The researchers stress the importance of awareness and monitoring for those at risk.

title: Brigham and Women's Hospital names new chief medical officer - Boston Business Journal
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Dr. Charles A. Morris has been appointed as the new chief medical officer (CMO) of Brigham and Women's Hospital, Brigham and Women's Faulkner Hospital, and the Brigham and Women's Physicians Organization, effective immediately. Morris, who has been with Brigham for 20 years, previously served as interim CMO following Dr. Sunil Eappen's departure. He has held various leadership roles, including program director for the Division of General Medicine Primary Care Residency and associate medical director of primary care. During the first year of the Covid-19 pandemic, Morris was co-incident commander, ensuring patient safety. He holds an undergraduate degree from Princeton University and attended medical school at Case Western School of Medicine. Dr. Robert Higgins, president of Brigham and Women's Hospital, praised Morris's strategic leadership and dedication to the community. Morris expressed his honor and eagerness to collaborate with the hospital's leadership.

title: Brigham and Women’s Hospital President Robert Higgins to Step Down | News
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Brigham and Women's Hospital President Robert S.D. Higgins is stepping down after two years in the role. He will become the president and chief academic officer at Rush University in Chicago, where he previously chaired the cardiothoracic surgery department from 2003 to 2010. Mass General Brigham President Anne Klibanski praised Higgins for his contributions to the hospital, including advancing service line integration, diversity and inclusion efforts, and establishing the urology department. Giles Boland, executive vice president of Mass General Brigham, will serve as interim president. Higgins expressed pride in the hospital's achievements and excitement about his new role in Chicago.

title: Mass General Brigham to Expand Hospital-at-Home Services
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Mass General Brigham is expanding its hospital-at-home program to three community hospitals in Massachusetts: Brigham and Women's Faulkner Hospital, Newton-Wellesley Hospital, and Salem Hospital, starting mid-September. This expansion follows authorization from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. Established in 2022, the Home Hospital program combines efforts from Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women's Hospital to provide acute-level care at home. The program has cared for over 3,000 patients and plans to increase its capacity to serve 45 patients daily. Patients receive daily in-home or virtual visits from medical professionals and have access to various services, including intravenous fluids, medications, laboratory testing, and remote patient monitoring. The expansion aims to shift about 10 percent of inpatient care to patient homes over the next five years. The future of hospital-at-home services remains uncertain as the CMS waiver is only extended through December 31, 2024.

title: Remembering Dr. Howard Hiatt, A PIH Mentor and Global Health Champion
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Dr. Howard Hiatt, a global health leader and mentor to Partners In Health co-founders Drs. Paul Farmer and Jim Yong Kim, passed away at 98. He significantly impacted global health through his roles at Harvard and PIH, co-founding the Division of Global Health Equity at Brigham and Women’s Hospital. Dr. Hiatt was instrumental in changing global policy on drug-resistant tuberculosis and securing substantial funding for PIH projects. He also supported the founding of PIH’s sister organization, COPE, on Navajo Nation. Known for his kindness and commitment to service, Dr. Hiatt's legacy continues through the many lives he improved and inspired.

title: Brigham and Women’s Hospital study finds AI can streamline detection of common heart disease with ‘much higher ...
hco: THE BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL INC
summary: Researchers at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, in collaboration with Keio University in Japan, have developed an artificial intelligence (AI) model to improve the detection of atrial septal defect (ASD), a common congenital heart disease. ASD often goes undiagnosed due to its mild symptoms and the high cost and inaccuracy of current screening methods. The AI model uses electrocardiogram (ECG) data to detect ASD with a sensitivity of 93.7%, significantly higher than traditional methods. Early detection is crucial to prevent serious complications such as atrial fibrillation, stroke, and heart failure. The AI model shows promise as a key tool for early ASD screening.

title: Darrin Akins named vice president for research at OU Health Sciences Center
hco: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER
summary: Darrin Akins has been appointed as the vice president for research at the OU Health Sciences Center, pending approval by the OU Board of Regents. Akins, an expert in Lyme disease, has been with the OU Health Sciences Center since 1998 and has secured over $58 million in research funding from the NIH. He has also served as associate vice president for research since 2021 and has been a principal investigator for a $19 million NIH award aimed at enhancing biomedical research in Oklahoma. OU President Joseph Harroz Jr. praised Akins for his international recognition and significant contributions to research. Akins will continue his research on Lyme disease in his new role.

title: ACCC Changes Name to Association of Cancer Care Centers
summary: The Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC) has rebranded as the Association of Cancer Care Centers for its 50th anniversary, reflecting its future in cancer care. Founded in 1974, ACCC is the largest advocacy and resource organization for oncology professionals, providing education, resources, tools, and conducting research and quality improvement projects. The name change signifies the organization's commitment to inclusivity and comprehensive care, aligning with its members' and patients' diverse needs. ACCC President Olelekan Ajayi and President-Elect Nadine Barrett emphasized that the new name positions the organization for future growth.

title: ACCC National Oncology Conference to Focus on Reimagining Innovation in Cancer Care
summary: The 40th National Oncology Conference by the Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC) will be held in Austin, Texas, from October 4-6, 2023, focusing on the theme "Reimagining Innovation." Key topics include workforce burnout, value-based care, patient experience, and women's leadership in oncology. Preconference sessions on October 4 will address financial advocacy, value-based care, and clinical updates. The conference will feature poster presentations on various topics such as food insecurity and health disparities. A notable session on October 6 will discuss women's leadership in oncology. Over the three days, there will be 30 sessions, including presentations from ACCC Innovator Awards winners. Networking opportunities will be available throughout the event.

title: Pennsylvania Hospital Shows That Community Cancer Centers Can Conduct Phase I Clinical Research
summary: Pennsylvania Hospital has shown that community cancer centers can successfully conduct Phase I clinical research, usually reserved for academic institutions. Tara Perloff, Oncology Clinical Research Program Manager at Penn Medicine Abramson Cancer Center, discussed this at the ACCC's National Oncology Conference. The hospital's program has enrolled over 75 participants, proving that community settings can replicate such trials. Key differences include the lack of subspecialized research departments, requiring a unique infrastructure. Integrating pharmacists into the research team from the start is crucial for success. This model benefits patients with travel restrictions, allowing them to access innovative treatments locally.

title: UH cancer scientist's passion leads to national changes, community award | University of Hawaiʻi System News
summary: Christa Braun-Inglis from the University of Hawaiʻi Cancer Center received the 2024 David King Community Clinical Scientist Award by the Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC). She was honored for her dedication to cancer research and education, particularly her efforts to help advanced practice providers (APPs) participate in clinical trials. Her work has led to national policy changes that expand the roles of APPs in National Cancer Institute (NCI) clinical trials, aiming to improve diversity and optimize cancer care delivery. Braun-Inglis’ research focuses on breast cancer and enhancing the engagement of APPs in clinical research. She was recognized at the 2024 ACCC Awards Ceremony in Washington, D.C. The award honors the late Dr. David K. King, a former ACCC president known for his commitment to quality cancer care.

title: Wake Forest’s Nadine Barrett named ACCC president; 2024-2025
summary: Nadine J. Barrett, senior associate dean for community engagement and equity in research at Wake Forest University School of Medicine and Atrium Health, has been named president of the Association of Cancer Care Centers (ACCC) for the 2024-2025 term.

title: Dr. Daniel Geynisman Named New Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN--Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Daniel M. Geynisman has been appointed as the new Editor-in-Chief of the JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. Dr. Geynisman, Chief of the Division of Genitourinary Medical Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center and Associate Professor in the Department of Hematology/Medical Oncology, has a long history with NCCN. He has served in various roles, including as a Member on the NCCN Guidelines Panels and as a medical oncology section editor. Dr. Geynisman will succeed Dr. Margaret Tempero and aims to continue enhancing the journal's impact on oncology research and practice guidelines.

title: Fox Chase's Dr. Daniel Geynisman Named Editor-in-Chief for JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer ...
summary: Dr. Daniel M. Geynisman, Chief of the Division of Genitourinary Medical Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center, has been appointed Editor-in-Chief for the JNCCN—Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. The NCCN is a nonprofit alliance of leading cancer centers focused on patient care, research, and education. Dr. Geynisman expressed his honor and excitement to lead JNCCN, aiming to enhance its legacy of practice-setting guidelines and research contributions. Crystal S. Denlinger, CEO of NCCN, welcomed Dr. Geynisman, highlighting the journal's role in oncology knowledge sharing and its growing impact factor. Dr. Geynisman has an extensive background in oncology, with over 130 peer-reviewed publications and significant contributions to cancer care and research. His first issue as Editor-in-Chief will be published in June. Fox Chase Cancer Center is a leading comprehensive cancer center in the U.S., known for its research, clinical care, and educational contributions.

title: NCCN Policy Summit encourages conversation and action on sexual health and fertility issues faced by people with ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) hosted an oncology policy summit focusing on sexual and reproductive health issues faced by cancer patients. The summit addressed the impact of knowledge gaps, societal stigma, and changing policies on the quality of life for cancer patients. Key topics included gender and sex, intimacy, fertility, treatment side effects, and the importance of inclusive care. Experts emphasized the need for better education and training for oncologists to discuss these issues with patients. They also highlighted the challenges in accessing fertility preservation and the importance of addressing sexual health in comprehensive cancer care. The summit featured discussions on the impact of state laws on patient access to care and equity issues related to gender, race, and location. The next NCCN policy summit will focus on diversity, equity, and inclusion in the cancer workforce.

title: Meet Five Future Leaders of Cancer Research Honored by NCCN
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) and the NCCN Foundation announced the winners of the 2024 Young Investigator Awards (YIA) on April 15, 2024. The awards recognize promising new oncology researchers from NCCN’s Member Institutions, providing up to $150,000 over two years for each recipient. The 2024 awardees are Zachary Burke (osteosarcoma research), Alexander Muir (pancreatic cancer), Andreas Rauschecker (CNS lymphoma), James Smithy (unresectable melanoma), and Jennifer Vega (cognitive impairment in cancer patients). The YIA program aims to support emerging cancer researchers and advance cancer care. Results from these studies will be presented at future NCCN conferences. The program, which has awarded over $11.1 million since 2011, is supported by the NCCN Foundation and additional sponsors.

title: ArteraAI Prostate Test included in NCCN guidelines
summary: The ArteraAI Prostate Test has been included in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Clinical Practice Guidelines for Prostate Cancer, marking it as the first AI-enabled predictive and prognostic test recommended for localized prostate cancer. This test is used for patients with NCCN low-, intermediate-, or high-risk disease and combines digital biopsy images with clinical data to predict therapy benefits and long-term outcomes. The NCCN guidelines classify the test with a Level IB evidence rating and a Category 2A recommendation, highlighting its effectiveness in improving patient care. The inclusion follows Medicare coverage approval and a $20 million capital funding to support ArteraAI’s growth. The test's predictive capabilities were validated through multiple phase 3 trials, showing significant improvements in outcomes like biochemical recurrence and overall survival. The recognition underscores the importance of innovative tools in personalized treatment strategies for prostate cancer.

title: National Comprehensive Cancer Network Awards Champions for Excellence and Outstanding Contributions in Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) announced its 2024 award recipients for outstanding contributions to cancer care. Honorees include Dr. Shaji Kumar, Darcie Green, and the NCCN COVID-19 Vaccine Advisory Committee. Dr. Kumar received the Excellence in Engagement Award for his leadership in expanding cancer care guidelines. Darcie Green, Executive Director of Latinas Contra Cancer, was honored with the Partners in Cancer Care Award for her advocacy in eliminating cancer care disparities. The NCCN COVID-19 Vaccine Advisory Committee, comprising 36 experts, was recognized for their rapid and effective guidance during the pandemic. Donna Black was named NCCN Employee of the Year for her significant administrative support. The awards were presented at the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference in Orlando, Florida.

title: GOSERELIN INCLUDED IN THE NATIONAL COMPREHENSIVE CANCER NETWORK® (NCCN) HEAD AND NECK ...
summary: Goserelin has been included in the NCCN Head and Neck Cancers Guidelines as a category 2B recommendation for treating recurrent, unresectable, or metastatic salivary gland tumors when surgery or radiation therapy is not an option. This decision is based on Phase 2 clinical studies and a retrospective analysis showing the combination of goserelin with antiandrogens or immunotherapy demonstrates clinical benefit and disease control. However, ZOLADEX® (goserelin implant) has not been approved by the U.S. FDA for treating salivary gland carcinoma. Goserelin's safety and efficacy for this specific use are still investigational.

title: New Resource for Selecting Best Treatment Path for Young Children with Cancerous Tumors Published by NCCN
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has published its first set of treatment recommendations for neuroblastoma, a common pediatric solid tumor. These new guidelines emphasize risk stratification to improve treatment outcomes and include multimodality treatment recommendations for high-risk cases. Neuroblastoma primarily affects children under five, with over 700 cases annually in the U.S. The guidelines aim to help clinicians by providing detailed information on diagnosis, molecular drivers, and treatment options, including surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. The guidelines are available for free on the NCCN website and app, supporting ongoing efforts to enhance patient care and minimize long-term treatment effects.

title: NCCN Expands Focus on Quality of Life and Supportive Care with New Guides for People with Cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has introduced new patient guidelines focused on enhancing the quality of life and supportive care for cancer patients. These resources include the new NCCN Guidelines for Patients: Palliative Care, Fatigue and Cancer, and an updated guide on managing distress during cancer care. These guidelines aim to improve overall well-being by addressing physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs. The resources are available for free on NCCN.org and via the NCCN Patient Guides for Cancer App. The NCCN Foundation funds these guidelines, which are based on the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines, ensuring they are evidence-based and expert-reviewed.

title: New Findings in JNCCN Illustrate Pathway for Screening High-Risk Individuals for Pancreatic Cancer in PRECEDE Study
summary: New research in the April 2024 issue of JNCCN highlights the effectiveness of the Pancreatic Cancer Early Detection (PRECEDE) Consortium in screening high-risk individuals. Nearly 80% of the 1,759 high-risk participants completed baseline imaging, potentially leading to earlier detection and improved survival rates. The consortium recommends categorizing high-risk individuals based on family history, genetic mutations, or both. The study also found a higher incidence of pancreatic cysts in those with a family history compared to those with genetic predispositions. Further research is needed to refine screening protocols and improve early detection.

title: NCCN Updates Treatment Recommendations for Breast, Colorectal, Lung, and other Cancer Types Based on ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has updated its treatment recommendations for various cancer types, including breast, colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers, based on emerging evidence. These updates are part of the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology, which are frequently updated and widely used by cancer care providers globally. The latest changes will be presented at the NCCN 2024 Annual Conference in Orlando, Florida, from April 5-7, and online. Key updates include new guidelines for HR-positive early-stage breast cancer, POLE/POLD1 mutation testing for colon and rectal cancer, a new immunotherapy option for non-small cell lung cancer, and new chemotherapy options for metastatic pancreatic cancer. The guidelines were accessed over 15 million times in 2023, demonstrating their importance in oncology care. The conference will also cover topics like genetics, vaccination, AI in healthcare, and drug shortages.

title: NCCN Announces Funding for Advanced Prostate Cancer Research Projects
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Oncology Research Program has announced funding for innovative research projects on advanced prostate cancer treatments involving relugolix. This medication, an oral GnRH antagonist, is used for androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) in advanced prostate cancer. The research aims to explore combination therapies with relugolix to improve treatment outcomes for various stages of prostate cancer. Funded by Pfizer Global Medical Grants and Sumitomo Pharma America, Inc., the selected projects include studies from Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Winship Cancer Institute of Emory University, Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center of Northwestern University, and OU Health Stephenson Cancer Center. These projects will be completed within five years, with a total funding of approximately $3.5 million. The NCCN ORP supports innovation in oncology research and collaboration among its member institutions.

title: NCCN 2024 Annual Conference Shares Cancer Care Updates for Practical, Immediate Use in Practice
summary: The NCCN 2024 Annual Conference, held in Orlando and online, attracted over 1,700 oncology professionals. The event featured clinical and administrative updates aimed at improving cancer care globally. Key sessions included discussions on Lynch syndrome, drug shortages, and nearly 200 poster abstracts showcasing new research. The conference emphasized practical applications for enhancing patient-centered care, with insights from both providers and patients. Topics covered included updates to NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines, vaccination recommendations for cancer survivors, and the role of AI in oncology. Networking opportunities and expert-led tours further enriched the experience for attendees.

title: Millions could be harmed by sudden decoupling of Chinese CDMOs
summary: The Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) has warned U.S. lawmakers that a sudden decoupling from Chinese Contract Development and Manufacturing Organizations (CDMOs) could harm millions of patients. A recent BIO survey revealed the biopharma industry's heavy reliance on Chinese CDMOs, with 79% of respondents having at least one contract with them. The survey indicated that switching to alternative providers could take up to eight years, posing risks to drug access and increasing costs. Despite these challenges, BIO CEO John Crowley emphasized the need to reduce dependence on Chinese CDMOs for national security. The proposed BIOSECURE Act aims to cut ties with certain Chinese biotech companies, which could further impact the industry. The survey highlighted potential delays in drug R&D and the need for a coordinated effort to enhance U.S. biomanufacturing capabilities.

title: Biotech trade association to split with China's WuXi AppTec
summary: The Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), a global trade association for biotech companies, is separating from Chinese member WuXi AppTec. This decision aligns with BIO's new stance supporting proposed U.S. legislation that limits business with certain Chinese biotech firms due to national security concerns. WuXi AppTec, which has opposed the legislation, announced it is ending its BIO membership. Following the news, WuXi AppTec's shares dropped significantly in both Hong Kong and Shanghai. The U.S. Senate committee recently approved a bill prohibiting federal contracts with WuXi AppTec, aiming to protect Americans' health and genetic data from foreign adversaries.

title: Takeda is fourth big company to leave BIO since December
summary: Takeda Pharmaceuticals has exited the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), becoming the fourth major company to do so since December. A Takeda spokesperson confirmed that the decision aligned with the end of the company's fiscal year in March 2024. Other companies that have recently left BIO include Pfizer, UCB, and WuXi AppTech. WuXi's departure was unique, as it followed BIO's opposition to a bill that would impact WuXi's business in the U.S. Subsequently, the chair of the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party requested the Justice Department to investigate whether BIO was lobbying for the Chinese Communist Party, leading BIO CEO John Crowley to ask WuXi to leave the organization.

title: US legislation to benefit small molecule drug innovation
summary: Two key legislations have been passed in the US to support small molecule drug innovation and the biotech sector. The bipartisan Ensuring Pathways to Innovative Cures (EPIC Act) aims to remove a punitive penalty on small-molecule medicine development, addressing a section of the US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). This act is seen as crucial for incentivizing innovation in small molecule drugs, which are vital for patient accessibility. Additionally, legislation to restore immediate R&D expensing was passed, allowing businesses to deduct R&D expenses in the same taxable year, thus removing financial barriers for smaller biotech companies. These legislative changes are considered significant steps forward for US pharmaceutical innovation, research, and development, enhancing patient access to critical medicines.

title: Admiral William McRaven to Keynote 2024 BIO Convention
summary: Admiral William McRaven, a retired U.S. Navy four-star admiral and former Chancellor of the University of Texas System, will keynote the 2024 BIO International Convention on June 5 in San Diego. McRaven, renowned for his leadership and military accomplishments, including the capture of Saddam Hussein and the raid on Osama bin Laden, will discuss leadership, global events, and the national security importance of biotechnology with BIO CEO John Crowley. McRaven will emphasize the strategic imperative for the U.S. to bolster biotechnology capabilities to safeguard the nation and global society. The convention gathers over 15,000 leaders in biotechnology innovation.

title: 'By hook or by crook': BIO CEO urges biotechs to be flexible on funding to survive tough times
summary: Rachel King, interim CEO of the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), urges biotech companies to persevere through tough financial times by exploring all funding options, including grants and equity debt. King, who has led BIO since November 2022 following the resignation of the previous CEO, emphasizes a long-term perspective and data-driven optimism despite industry challenges like IPO slowdowns and layoffs. BIO is advocating for changes to the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), particularly concerning drug pricing reforms and pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs), to ensure innovation isn't stifled. King hopes for bipartisan cooperation to shape policies beneficial to biotech innovation.

title: Takeda ditches industry trade group BIO following exits by WuXi AppTec, Pfizer and UCB
summary: Takeda Pharmaceuticals has decided not to renew its membership in the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), following similar exits by WuXi AppTec, Pfizer, and UCB. Takeda made this decision after a routine review of its trade association participation, aiming to refine its focus and continue advocating for patient-first policies and global healthcare improvements. This marks the fourth departure from BIO since December, with WuXi AppTec leaving after BIO supported the BIOSECURE Act, which aims to prevent adversarial biotech companies from receiving public funding. WuXi AppTec's exit was notable due to the company's alleged ties to Chinese government officials. Pfizer and UCB left BIO in December and January, respectively, while AbbVie, Teva, and AstraZeneca did not renew their memberships with the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) in 2023, following the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act.

title: The Shifting Landscape of the Life Sciences Job Market
summary: The biotech industry is facing a significant downturn, marked by a 60% drop in a major biotech stock index since early 2021, leading to widespread layoffs and a sharp decline in job postings. By early 2023, layoffs had doubled compared to the previous year, with 107 companies reducing staff. The pandemic's overfunding, broader market recession, and investor caution have led to reduced permanent hiring and increased contract spending. Companies are scaling back research pipelines and focusing on development programs with rapid advances. The industry is seeing a trend towards less reliance on fully outsourced models and a greater focus on employee retention. Future trends may include larger pharma companies acquiring smaller biotechs, forced mergers, and a skills gap due to increased remote work. A coherent resourcing strategy, including partnering with external specialists, is essential for companies to navigate the ongoing recession and prepare for future market improvements.

title: Pfizer plans to depart BIO - STAT
summary: Pfizer plans to exit the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), a significant trade association in the biotech industry. This move is seen as a setback for BIO, which represents a range of members from small biotech startups to large pharmaceutical companies. BIO recently announced John Crowley, a rare disease advocate and biotech executive, as its new CEO. Rich Masters, BIO’s Chief Public Affairs and Marketing Officer, expressed disappointment over any company's departure due to economic challenges but emphasized that it does not affect BIO’s mission of protecting patients and medical innovation in the U.S.

title: WuXi Biologics withdraws from 2024 BIO convention amid worsening geopolitical tensions
summary: WuXi Biologics and WuXi AppTec have withdrawn from the 2024 BIO International Convention due to geopolitical tensions and a U.S. biosecurity crackdown on Chinese manufacturers. This was confirmed by the Biotechnology Innovation Organization. The withdrawal follows scrutiny from U.S. lawmakers who proposed the BIOSECURE Act to block "foreign adversary biotechs" from federal funding, specifically mentioning WuXi AppTec and other Chinese genomics companies. WuXi Biologics, though not listed, is involved in the controversy. The company is committed to compliance and supporting global customers. The BIO trade group supports the BIOSECURE Act to protect U.S. biotechnology from global competitors, especially China. Other Chinese CROs and CDMOs will still attend.

title: After Pfizer's exit, UCB splits from industry trade group BIO
summary: UCB has decided to leave the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) following Pfizer's recent exit and AbbVie's departure in late 2022. UCB, which will remain part of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA) and the National Pharmaceutical Council, made this decision after a routine evaluation of its association memberships. The company aims to continue engaging effectively within the healthcare ecosystem and policy environment. These exits follow the industry's challenges during the summer of 2022 when the Inflation Reduction Act was passed. BIO has also seen changes, including the appointment of John Crowley as CEO. Despite this, UCB had a successful 2023 with several FDA approvals for its drugs and anticipates significant sales growth.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Announces Formation of Healthcare Analytics Company
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) has announced the creation of a new healthcare analytics subsidiary named Vita Nova Insights, LLC. This entity, wholly owned by FCS' management services organization, Core Ventures, aims to enhance oncology research and patient outcomes through precision oncology insights and real-world evidence. Vita Nova Insights leverages advanced data curation, data science, artificial intelligence, and analytics to provide unique insights for the development of cancer therapies. Over the past year, the team has conducted numerous real-world evidence studies with leading pharmaceutical companies. The platform supports FCS physicians by providing comprehensive data analysis and real-time treatment options, thereby optimizing patient care and enabling efficient clinical research.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Annual Report Recognized with Gold Healthcare Digital Marketing Award
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: The Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) 2022 Annual Report has received a Gold Award in the 4th Annual Healthcare Digital Marketing Awards. The report, titled "Embracing Innovation and Collaboration to Advance and Transform Cancer Care," was produced by FCS's in-house marketing team. FCS Vice President of Marketing, Michelle Robey, and CEO, Nathan H. Walcker, expressed pride in the team's creativity and dedication. The awards received over 1,000 entries from various U.S. healthcare institutions, judged by a panel of healthcare marketing professionals. The full list of winners is available on the HDMA Awards 2023 website.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Clinical Research Driving Progress to Cure Cancer
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) will present over a dozen abstracts at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) 2024 Annual Meeting in San Diego. FCS's extensive clinical research program, featuring more than 160 clinical trials across 32 clinics and three Drug Development Units in Florida, has contributed to the approval of many new cancer drugs in the U.S. FCS's research includes studies on advanced solid tumors, metastatic breast cancer, and prostate cancer, among others. The AACR meeting will showcase these findings, highlighting FCS's role in advancing cancer treatment and improving patient outcomes.

title: New Case Study Highlights Community Oncology Practices as Preferred Site of Service Over Hospitals and Academic ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: A new case study by Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute highlights community oncology practices as the preferred site for cancer treatment over hospitals and academic centers. The study reveals that community oncology practices offer significant advantages in personalized care, convenience, accessibility, and cost-effectiveness. These practices prioritize patient-centric approaches, reducing travel times and related expenses, which enhances patient adherence to treatment regimens. The cost-effectiveness is achieved by avoiding the overhead expenses of large hospital systems and maintaining close relationships with insurers. Additionally, community oncology practices foster collaboration with academic institutions and hospitals, promoting innovation and continuous improvement in cancer care delivery. The study advocates for a more inclusive, patient-centric healthcare system that celebrates diversity and innovation.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Presents Innovations in Patient Care at Oncology Nursing Society ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) will present innovations in patient care at the Oncology Nursing Society's 49th Annual Congress in Washington, DC. This event is the largest global gathering for oncology nursing. FCS submissions, which include high-scoring abstracts, aim to empower nurses to enhance patient care. Colleen Lewis, FCS Vice President of Nursing & Research, emphasized the diverse roles of oncology nurses and their impact on patient outcomes. The presentations cover various topics such as remote triage and behavioral health therapy telehealth. Selected abstracts will be published in the Oncology Nursing Forum. Several FCS nurses received scholarships to attend the Congress. FCS President Lucio N. Gordan highlighted the essential role of oncology nurses in ensuring high-quality patient care and fostering change. FCS is known for its extensive clinical trials and innovative treatments, celebrating its 40th anniversary in 2024.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Best Practices Program Improves Treatment Response and Survival for ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) developed a best practices program that improved treatment response and survival for patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) treated with selinexor. The study, published in Current Oncology, showed that the program optimized treatment by educating providers on dosing guidelines and toxicity management, ensuring patient adherence, and proactively managing adverse reactions. The retrospective study compared outcomes of 41 patients treated under the program with 68 patients treated before its implementation. Results indicated reduced treatment failure, increased treatment duration, and fewer dose-limiting toxicities. FCS emphasizes a comprehensive approach to cancer care, integrating clinical and supportive teams to enhance patient outcomes.

title: No Solution in Sight, Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute, Core Ventures Forge Ahead in Race to Recover ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: In response to the nationwide Change Healthcare shutdown, Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) and Core Ventures have swiftly established new systems to process medical claims and maintain patient care. With more than $300 million spent monthly on medications, FCS leveraged existing partnerships to transition from Unlimited to Availity as their clearinghouse. This move sets a precedent for other community oncology practices. FCS CEO Nathan H. Walcker emphasized the urgency due to the financial crisis posed by the shutdown. Core Ventures, housing FCS's ancillary services, played a crucial role in restoring insurance and claims processing. FCS collaborated with national partners to expedite solutions, ensuring community oncology practices can continue operating. FCS remains dedicated to supporting oncology practices across the U.S., leveraging their extensive resources and industry relationships to navigate this crisis.

title: Mahdi Taha, DO, FACOI, FACP is Lead Author of Case Study Demonstrating Importance of Genomic Testing in Early ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Dr. Mahdi Taha, DO, FACOI, FACP, a medical oncologist and hematologist at Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute, is the lead author of a case study published in JCO® Precision Oncology. The study emphasizes the critical role of genomic testing in the early identification and treatment of cancer, particularly metastatic prostate cancer. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) revealed a BRCA2 mutation in an 85-year-old patient, which was pivotal for his treatment and alerted his daughter to her own breast cancer risk. The study demonstrates how identifying genetic mutations can guide targeted treatments and potentially save lives by informing family members of inherited cancer risks.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Implements Contingency Plan to Overcome National Clearinghouse ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) has implemented a contingency plan to address the disruption caused by a cyberattack on Change Healthcare, the nation's largest prescription clearinghouse. The attack, which began on February 21, 2024, halted prescription processing, affecting over 900,000 physicians, 67,000 pharmacies, and 5,500 hospitals, including FCS. In response, FCS and its pharmacy, Rx To Go, have integrated new processing systems and are working directly with patients and insurers to ensure continuity of care. Despite the challenges, FCS remains committed to patient care, leveraging resources to mitigate the impact and restore normal operations.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Partners to Host One-of-a-Kind Educational Offering for the Nation's ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) is partnering with Research to Practice® to host the Third Annual National General Medical Oncology Summit in Miami from March 22-24, 2024. This summit aims to provide a comprehensive educational experience for medical oncologists. Hundreds of physicians from across the U.S. will engage with internationally recognized cancer experts and clinical investigators to discuss new data, promising treatment strategies, and key perspectives on enhancing patient care management. FCS leaders and physicians will present and moderate sessions on various oncology topics, offering insights from the community oncology side. The event supports clinicians in delivering high-quality, advanced care and treatment to achieve the best patient outcomes.

title: Carrum Health and Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Partner on Breast Cancer Treatment Model
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) has partnered with Carrum Health to provide high-quality, cost-effective breast cancer care in Florida. This value-based care model will offer patients a bundled package for breast cancer treatment, including chemotherapy, radiation, and symptom management, with two years of coverage. The partnership aims to reduce costs for employers while ensuring patients receive advanced oncology treatments. Carrum Health's network of rigorously vetted Centers of Excellence will support this initiative, offering pre-negotiated bundled prices and dedicated care navigators. This collaboration marks FCS's first application of a bundled payment methodology for cancer care, with plans to expand to other cancer types in the future.

title: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute Innovations in Precision Oncology Informatics Showcased at World ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute (FCS) Senior Vice President & Data Officer Trevor Heritage, PhD, will present at the Precision Medicine World Conference 2024 in Santa Clara, CA. He will discuss the development of FCS PRECISE™, an innovative precision oncology platform. This system aggregates and standardizes genomic variant data from next-generation sequencing (NGS) tests, aiding in precision oncology decision-making. FCS has analyzed over 57,500 patient cases and identified 64,000 clinical trial matches. The institute is recognized for its extensive clinical trials and contributions to new cancer drug approvals in the U.S. Celebrating its 40th year in 2024, FCS is known for its excellence in patient care, innovative research, and advanced treatments.

title: New Clinical Study Identifies Personalized Treatment Options for Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer With Plasma ...
hco: FLORIDA CANCER SPECIALISTS & RESEARCH INSTITUTE LLC
summary: A new clinical study co-authored by Dr. Ernesto Bustinza-Linares from the Florida Cancer Specialists & Research Institute has identified personalized treatment options for metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) using plasma proteome testing. Published in the American Society of Clinical Oncology Journal, the study introduces a machine-learning test called PROphet, which analyzes pretreated plasma proteomic profiles to determine protein inhibitor levels in patients. This method allows for the identification of targeted treatment options, leading to optimized patient outcomes. The study highlights the limitations of current NSCLC treatment guidelines and emphasizes the importance of personalized oncology care.

title: Nurse Practitioners Predict Doc Shortages, Care Access to Loom in 2024
summary: Nurse practitioners (NPs) foresee significant doctor shortages and access to care issues in 2024 due to workforce shortages, long appointment wait times, and increased patient demand, particularly from the aging Baby Boomer population. The American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP) highlights that NPs are well-positioned to fill these gaps, especially in primary care and mental health screenings. With over 385,000 licensed NPs in the US, 90% of whom are trained in primary care, they play a crucial role in addressing these challenges. AANP emphasizes the need for expanding NP scope of practice to ensure efficient and effective patient-centered healthcare. They note that 102 million Americans live in primary care shortage areas, and long wait times often lead to patients not receiving necessary care. AANP urges healthcare leaders and policymakers to prioritize policies that enhance healthcare access and efficiency.

title: UAMS' Leonie DeClerk, Ph.D., DNP, APRN, Selected as Fellow of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners
summary: Leonie DeClerk, Ph.D., DNP, APRN, a clinical associate professor at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) College of Nursing, has been named a 2024 Fellow of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners. This prestigious recognition honors nurse practitioners for exceptional achievements in education, policy, clinical practice, or research.
