DeClerk's nomination highlighted her contributions to health policy and education, notably her efforts to enhance healthcare access in Arkansas by removing legislative barriers for nurse practitioners. She collaborates with organizations like the National Organization of Nurse Practitioner Faculties and the Arkansas Nurse Practitioner Association. DeClerk credits UAMS for supporting her professional endeavors over the past decade. The fellowship program involves members volunteering their expertise in various capacities to advance the nurse practitioner role. DeClerk will be formally inducted at a ceremony during the national conference in Nashville, Tennessee, joining 33 new fellows and over 900 existing members.

title: Nurse Practitioner Profession Grows to 385,000 Strong
summary: The American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP) announced that the number of licensed nurse practitioners (NPs) in the U.S. has grown to 385,000, an 8.5% increase from 2022. This announcement coincides with National Nurse Practitioner Week, celebrating NPs' contributions to patient health and the healthcare system. NPs provide high-quality, accessible care across various settings, including clinics, hospitals, and nursing homes, and are critical in addressing healthcare disparities and improving health outcomes. The profession is recognized for its rapid growth, with the Bureau of Labor Statistics projecting a 45% increase by 2032. NPs are essential in primary, acute, and mental health care, and their role is highly regarded, topping U.S. News & World Report's "2023 Best Jobs That Help People" and "2023 Best Health Care Jobs" lists.

title: University of Phoenix College of Nursing Faculty Leadership Selected for Prestigious Fellows of the American ...
summary: Dr. Sun Jones, a faculty member at the University of Phoenix College of Nursing, has been selected for the 2024 Fellows of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (FAANP) program. This prestigious fellowship recognizes her exceptional contributions in education, research, policy, and clinical practice. Dr. Jones, who serves as the Systematic Plan for Evaluation and Curriculum Evaluator, will be inducted alongside other notable nurse practitioners at the 2024 AANP National Conference. Her work extends beyond academia, contributing to community health and mentoring students. Dr. Jones' selection highlights her leadership and dedication to advancing nurse practitioner roles and healthcare.

title: Nurse practitioners fill critical health care gaps
summary: Nurse practitioners (NPs) are increasingly vital in addressing healthcare gaps, making up about 40% of primary care providers in the U.S. With approximately 385,000 NPs nationwide, their numbers have doubled in the last decade. Unlike registered nurses (RNs), NPs can order tests, perform diagnoses, and prescribe treatments. In 27 states and the District of Columbia, NPs can practice independently after extensive clinical experience, which allows them to serve underserved areas. Despite some opposition from the American Medical Association, studies show NPs provide comparable care to physicians, particularly in preventive treatments, reducing medical costs. With a projected shortage of primary care doctors, the role of NPs is crucial in maintaining the healthcare system.

title: Aadi Bioscience Announces Poster Presentations on Nab-Sirolimus at the International Gynecologic Cancer Society ...
summary: Aadi Bioscience announced its participation in the International Gynecologic Cancer Society (IGCS) 2023 Annual Global Meeting with e-poster presentations. The focus is on a Phase 2 trial investigating nab-sirolimus combined with letrozole for treating advanced or recurrent endometrioid-type endometrial cancer (EEC). This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this combination, given the significant role of mTOR pathway alterations in EEC pathology. Prior studies have shown promising results with mTOR inhibitors and letrozole in endometrial cancer patients. Additionally, an encore presentation on the PRECISION1 trial, which targets malignant solid tumors with TSC1 or TSC2 alterations, will also be featured. Aadi Bioscience specializes in precision therapies for genetically defined cancers and has received FDA approval for FYARRO®, aimed at treating advanced malignant perivascular epithelioid cell tumors (PEComa). More details can be found on Aadi's website and the IGCS meeting site.

title: PFS, QOL Benefits Seen With Pembrolizumab/Chemoradiation in Cervical Cancer
summary: The phase 3 KEYNOTE-A18 trial demonstrated that pembrolizumab combined with chemoradiation is well tolerated and does not negatively impact the quality of life in patients with advanced cervical cancer. This combination treatment showed a trend towards improved overall survival and a significant progression-free survival (PFS) benefit, particularly in patients with stage III to IVA disease. However, this benefit was less pronounced in patients with FIGO 2014 stage IB2 to IIB disease. The trial involved over 1060 patients globally, leading to international standardization of this treatment approach. No significant differences in patient-reported outcomes were observed, indicating the regimen's tolerability. These findings support the FDA's approval of pembrolizumab with chemoradiotherapy for stage III to IVA cervical cancer.

title: T-DXd Tied to Encouraging Survival in HER2-Expressing Gyn Cancers
summary: A phase II trial, DESTINY-PanTumor02, demonstrated that trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd; Enhertu) shows promising survival outcomes in heavily pretreated HER2-expressing gynecologic cancers. Median progression-free survival (PFS) was 5.9 months for ovarian cancer, 7.0 months for cervical cancer, and 11.1 months for endometrial cancer, with respective overall survival (OS) of 13.2, 13.6, and 26 months. Patients with the highest HER2 expression (IHC 3+) had the best outcomes, with an overall response rate (ORR) of 61%, median PFS of 11.9 months, and median OS of 21.1 months. Safety concerns included pulmonary adverse events, particularly interstitial lung disease (ILD), necessitating proactive monitoring and management. The study was sponsored by AstraZeneca in collaboration with Daiichi Sankyo.

title: Dostarlimab Plus Chemo Demonstrates 31% OS Improvement in Advanced Endometrial Cancer
summary: A combination of dostarlimab-gxly (Jemperli) and chemotherapy (carboplatin/paclitaxel) demonstrated a 31% improvement in overall survival (OS) for patients with primary advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer, regardless of microsatellite instability (MSI) status. This finding emerged from the ENGOT-EN6-NSGO/GOG-3031/RUBY trial presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology 2024 Annual Meeting. The median OS for the dostarlimab group was 44.6 months compared to 28.2 months for the placebo group. The study showed significant OS benefits across different subgroups, including those with mismatch repair-deficient (dMMR)/MSI-high tumors and proficient mismatch repair (pMMR)/microsatellite stable (MSS) tumors. The trial included 494 patients, and the results suggest dostarlimab plus chemotherapy could become a new standard of care for this patient population. Safety findings indicated that treatment-emergent adverse effects were manageable, with most being grade 1 or 2.

title: Maintenance Selinexor May Boost PFS in TP53 Wild-Type Advanced Endometrial Cancer
summary: Maintenance therapy with selinexor (Xpovio) significantly extends progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with TP53 wild-type advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer, according to the SIENDO trial. Data showed a median PFS of 27.4 months for patients treated with selinexor versus 5.2 months for those on placebo. Particularly strong results were observed in patients with mismatch repair proficient (pMMR) disease, where PFS was not reached compared to 4.9 months with placebo. Preliminary survival data also indicated a positive overall survival trend. Selinexor, an oral selective XP01 inhibitor, reactivates tumor suppressive proteins and is FDA-approved for multiple myeloma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The most common adverse events were nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, with some patients experiencing neutropenia, nausea, and thrombocytopenia. The study was supported by Karyopharm.

title: Mixed Results for Tiragolumab/Atezolizumab Combo in PD-L1+ Recurrent Cervical Cancer
summary: The combination of tiragolumab, an anti-TIGIT monoclonal antibody, with atezolizumab (Tecentriq) in treating PD-L1-positive recurrent cervical cancer showed mixed results in the phase II SKYSCRAPER-04 trial. The overall response rate (ORR) for the combination was 19.0%, surpassing the historical benchmark of 14.6% but failing to achieve the significant improvement target of ≥21%. Higher ORRs were observed in patients with high PD-L1 expression. A post hoc analysis indicated a slightly higher ORR in patients with measurable disease. The combination was well tolerated, with only 3% of patients discontinuing treatment due to adverse events. Progression-free survival averaged 2.8 months for the combination versus 1.9 months for atezolizumab alone. Overall survival was similar between the two groups. The study supports further exploration of dual targeting of TIGIT and PD-L1 in cervical cancer.

title: International Gynecologic Cancer Society Announces Inaugural Uterine Cancer Awareness Month
summary: The International Gynecologic Cancer Society (IGCS) has declared June as the inaugural Uterine Cancer Awareness Month, aiming to raise awareness, promote research funding, and improve access to care for uterine cancer. Collaborating with over 25 global partner organizations, the initiative addresses the sixth most common cancer in women worldwide, which is notably prevalent in high-income countries. Despite its impact, uterine cancer research is significantly underfunded. The IGCS, alongside advocacy groups such as ECANA and FORCE, seeks to reduce disparities in care and enhance community education on risks and symptoms. The initiative also emphasizes the need for more research funding and better treatment options, particularly for underserved populations. The IGCS encourages the global community to participate in awareness activities and support efforts to improve outcomes for uterine cancer patients.

title: Anti-TIGIT Drug Fails to Lift Response Rates in Cervical Cancer Trial
summary: The phase II SKYSCRAPER-04 trial combining the anti-TIGIT monoclonal antibody tiragolumab with atezolizumab (Tecentriq) for treating PD-L1-positive recurrent cervical cancer did not improve overall response rates compared to atezolizumab alone. The single-agent atezolizumab showed a response rate of approximately 15.6%, consistent with previous PD-1 agent studies. Despite the addition of tiragolumab not showing statistical benefit, there was a higher response rate, indicating some potential. The trial highlighted the importance of including patients with measurable disease by RECIST criteria and having independent review assessments to avoid bias. Dr. Ritu Salani emphasized that while this combination may not be effective for this patient population, it doesn't close the door on TIGIT inhibitors entirely, suggesting the need for further research to find the right combination or patient cohort.

title: Bispecific Antibody Shows Clinical Activity in Recurrent Ovarian Cancer
summary: A phase I study at the International Gynecologic Cancer Society meeting showed that the bispecific antibody ubamatamab, alone or with the PD-1 inhibitor cemiplimab, was effective and well-tolerated in recurrent ovarian cancer patients. Led by Dr. Roisin O'Cearbhaill, the study involved dose-escalation of ubamatamab up to 800 mg and cemiplimab up to 250 mg weekly. Clinical responses were noted at various dosages, with common adverse events being pain and cytokine release syndrome. The objective response rate (ORR) for ubamatamab monotherapy was 14.3% by RECIST criteria and 33.3% by CA-125 criteria. The combination therapy showed ORRs of 18.2% and 22.7%, respectively. An ongoing phase II study aims to refine dosing and further evaluate the combination's anti-tumor activity. The study was sponsored by Regeneron.

title: Jennifer Vega receives NCCN Foundation Young Investigator Award - VUMC News
summary: Jennifer Vega, PhD, a cognitive neuroscientist and research instructor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, has received the 2024 National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Foundation Young Investigator Award. She is one of five recipients of this prestigious award, which provides up to $150,000 in funding over two years. Her research focuses on neuroplasticity-based cognitive remediation for persistent cognitive impairment related to cancer and chemotherapy. Vega earned her doctorate in Neuroscience from Vanderbilt University in 2018, where her dissertation investigated nicotine as a treatment for cognitive impairment in cancer survivors. The NCCN Foundation has awarded over $11.1 million to 75 researchers since 2011 through this program. The award aims to support emerging talent in cancer research, with results from the recipients' studies to be presented at a future NCCN Annual Conference.

title: NCCN Foundation Announces Recipients for 2024 Young Investigator Awards Honoring Future Leaders of Cancer ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Foundation has announced the recipients of the 2024 Young Investigator Awards, recognizing five early-career oncology researchers for their potential contributions to cancer treatment. The selected researchers, from various NCCN Member Institutions, will receive funding of up to $150,000 over two years. The awardees include Dr. Zachary Burke, Dr. Alexander Muir, Dr. Andreas Rauschecker, Dr. James Smithy, and Dr. Jennifer N. Vega, each focusing on different aspects of cancer research. These awards aim to support and advance the careers of promising new researchers in oncology.

title: Meet Five Future Leaders of Cancer Research Honored by NCCN
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) and the NCCN Foundation announced five winners for the 2024 NCCN Foundation Young Investigator Awards (YIA). These awards recognize promising oncology researchers from NCCN’s Member Institutions, providing up to $150,000 in funding over two years per awardee. The 2024 recipients are Zachary Burke, Alexander Muir, Andreas Rauschecker, James Smithy, and Jennifer Vega, each working on innovative cancer research projects. The YIA program aims to advance cancer care by supporting emerging researchers. Results from their studies will be presented at future NCCN conferences. Since 2011, the NCCN Foundation has awarded over $11.1 million to 75 researchers through the YIA program. The announcement was made on April 15, 2024, on the NCCN website.

title: Limited Submission Opportunity: National Comprehensive Cancer Network Foundation 2024 Young Investigator Award
summary: Vanderbilt University is inviting applications for the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Foundation 2024 Young Investigator Award (YIA). This award provides $150,000 over two years for early-career investigators in oncology, with additional travel funding for the 2026 NCCN Annual Conference. The award aims to support innovative research improving cancer care quality and accessibility. Eligible candidates must be in their first full-time appointment at Vanderbilt, hold a relevant medical or scientific degree, and have no overlapping funding. Applications, including a research plan, budget summary, support statement, and CV, must be submitted by November 17, 2023. The final nominee will submit a full proposal by January 24, 2024. For more information, contact Jenn Beiner at jenn.beiner@vumc.org.

title: NCCN releases new resource to help families understand pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma, part of award-winning patient ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has released a new publication, "NCCN Guidelines for Patients: Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children," aimed at helping families understand pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma. This resource, available for free online, provides detailed information on treatment options, benefits, risks, and follow-up care for one of the most curable childhood cancers, with survival rates of 90% or higher. The guidelines are part of the award-winning NCCN Guidelines for Patients series, which translates expert clinical guidelines into patient-friendly formats. These resources have been recognized for their reliability and have won multiple awards. The NCCN Foundation supports these efforts, ensuring accessible, up-to-date information for patients and caregivers. The guidelines are available in multiple languages and formats, including digital and print versions.

title: New resource from National Comprehensive Cancer Network breaks the silence on common but lesser-known cause ...
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has released new patient guidelines on blood clots and cancer, addressing the significant but under-discussed issue of cancer-associated venous thromboembolism (VTE). Cancer patients are nine times more likely to develop blood clots, which are a leading cause of death among this group. The guidelines, based on extensive research and expert consensus, aim to educate patients and caregivers on recognizing, preventing, and treating blood clots. They are available for free download on NCCN's website and app, with printed versions available on Amazon. The guidelines simplify medical recommendations using images, charts, and suggested questions for healthcare providers. Experts emphasize the importance of discussing blood clot risks and symptoms with doctors. The NCCN continues to provide high-quality patient information on various cancer-related issues, contributing to better patient care and awareness.

title: NCCN Foundation Announces 2024 Young Investigator Award Recipients in Cancer Research
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network® (NCCN®) and the NCCN Foundation® have announced the recipients of the 2024 Young Investigator Awards (YIA), recognizing five promising oncology researchers from its Member Institutions. These awards, part of the NCCN Oncology Research Program (ORP), provide up to $150,000 over two years to support innovative cancer research projects. This year's recipients are working on diverse projects, including treatment-resistant osteosarcoma, pancreatic cancer vulnerabilities, deep learning for CNS lymphoma analysis, novel melanoma therapies, and cognitive remediation for cancer-related impairments. Crystal S. Denlinger, MD, CEO of NCCN, highlighted the importance of supporting emerging researchers to advance cancer understanding and treatment. Patrick Delaney, Executive Director of the NCCN Foundation, emphasized the YIA program's role in fostering the next generation of oncology researchers. Since its inception in 2011, the YIA program has distributed over $11.1 million to 75 researchers, contributing significantly to cancer research advancements.

title: NCCN publishes new resource to help patients understand quick-moving type of breast cancer
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) has released new guidelines for patients with inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. These guidelines, available for free at NCCN.org/patientguidelines, help patients understand the unique nature and treatment of IBC. The guidelines include information on systemic therapy, surgery, and radiation, emphasizing early detection and treatment. The NCCN also provides additional resources such as webinars, videos, and translations to support patients and caregivers. The initiative seeks to empower patients with accessible, expert-vetted information for better management of their diagnosis and treatment decisions.

title: 'All hands on deck' needed to navigate oncology drug shortages, says expert panel
hco: NATIONAL COMMUNITY ONCOLOGY DISPENSING ASSOCIATION INC
summary: A virtual town hall by the National Community Oncology Dispensing Association (NCODA) addressed the ongoing oncology drug shortages, highlighting the significant impact on clinical practice and patient care. Experts discussed the causes, including quality issues and manufacturing delays, particularly affecting chemotherapy drugs like cisplatin, carboplatin, and methotrexate. The FDA has been working to increase supplies and authorized new manufacturers. ASCO responded by forming a Drug Shortage Advisory group and providing clinical guidance. Future prevention efforts focus on quality management and legislative advocacy to require manufacturers to report potential supply disruptions to the FDA.

title: AI Has Significantly Advanced, Changed the Management of Colorectal Cancer
hco: NATIONAL COMMUNITY ONCOLOGY DISPENSING ASSOCIATION INC
summary: AI has significantly advanced the management of colorectal cancer, as highlighted by Arturo Loaiza-Bonilla, MD, during the 2023 NCODA International Spring Forum. AI's integration in oncology has led to improved cancer diagnosis, personalized treatment, and cost-effective care. The shift from traditional cancer classification to using biomarkers for prognosis and therapy prediction has been pivotal. Advances in biomedical technologies, such as next-generation sequencing and multi-omics analysis, have further enhanced cancer treatment. AI's potential includes optimizing drug sequencing and improving real-time data updates. However, challenges remain in organizing vast amounts of data and effectively integrating AI into healthcare practices. Despite these challenges, the use of AI in colorectal cancer care is becoming increasingly relevant, offering better outcomes and personalized attention for patients.

title: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy can eliminate need for regional nodal irradiation in breast cancer
summary: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy can potentially eliminate the need for regional nodal irradiation (RNI) in breast cancer patients whose lymph node-positive disease converts to lymph node-negative after treatment. The NRG Oncology/NSABP B-51/RTOG 1304 clinical trial, presented at the San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium, found that skipping RNI did not increase the risk of disease recurrence or death five years post-surgery. The study included 1,641 patients, showing similar outcomes for those who received RNI and those who did not. This suggests that patients may safely omit RNI, avoiding associated complications without adversely affecting oncologic outcomes. Follow-up for long-term outcomes continues.

title: Leadership Spotlight: ASTRO President Discusses Top Priorities, Key Advancements in Radiation Oncology
summary: Howard Sandler, MD, FASTRO, President of the American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO), discusses advancements in radiation oncology, emphasizing personalized and patient-centered treatments. He highlights the use of MRI and PET imaging for precise radiation targeting, reducing morbidity and improving cancer control. The PACE-B trial's findings on ultrashort radiation treatments for prostate cancer are noted as a significant advancement. Sandler also underscores ASTRO’s efforts in promoting health equity through the Health Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (HEDI) council and diverse clinical trials. Looking forward, he mentions the potential of targeted radiopharmaceuticals and flash radiation. For early career oncologists, he advises balancing professional and personal life. His top priorities as ASTRO President include enhancing clinical trial diversity, working with Congress on value-based reimbursement, and promoting well-being among radiation oncologists.

title: Retrospective Data Show Real-World Disparities in Black vs White Patients With Endometrioid Endometrial Carcinoma
summary: A study presented at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer revealed significant real-world disparities in outcomes between Black and White patients with endometrioid endometrial carcinoma. Data from the SEER program showed that Black patients had a higher 5-year cancer-related death rate (14.4%) compared to White patients (7.2%). Black patients also had a higher non-cancer death rate and worse overall survival probabilities. Propensity score matching and analysis of various cohorts, including the National Cancer Database and NCI-sponsored trials, confirmed these disparities. Black patients were less frequently enrolled in clinical trials and exhibited fewer mutations in certain genes, although immune checkpoint inhibitors should still be considered. The study highlighted the need for additional research on molecular features, societal factors, and inclusive drug development strategies to address these disparities.

title: Julie Bauman, Stephanie Blank to lead NRG Oncology Cancer Prevention & Control Committee
summary: Julie Bauman and Stephanie V. Blank have been appointed as the chair and vice chair, respectively, of the NRG Oncology Cancer Prevention & Control Committee.

title: Thomas J. Herzog, MD takes office as The GOG Foundation, Inc. President
summary: Thomas J. Herzog, MD has been appointed President of The GOG Foundation, Inc. during the NRG Oncology Summer Meeting on July 20, 2023. Dr. Herzog, a gynecologic oncologist, has a rich background in clinical trials and previously served as Treasurer and Associate Director of the GOG Partners program. He is also Deputy Director of the University of Cincinnati Cancer Center. Dr. Herzog succeeds Larry J. Copeland, MD, who will continue as Immediate Past President. The GOG Foundation focuses on clinical and translational research in gynecologic malignancies. Dr. Herzog aims to advance initiatives in diversity, operational transparency, translational research, site expansion, and trial efficiencies, while mentoring the next generation of clinical trialists. The GOG Foundation collaborates with NRG Oncology and operates the GOG Partners program to enhance clinical trial opportunities outside the National Cancer Institute framework.

title: Eleftherios P. Mamounas, MD, on Locoregional Irradiation, Axillary Lymph Node Involvement, and Conversion to ...
summary: Eleftherios P. Mamounas, MD, from Orlando Health Cancer Institute, discusses the primary outcomes of the NRG Oncology/NSABP B-51/RTOG 1304 study. The study focuses on locoregional irradiation in patients who initially presented with biopsy-proven axillary node involvement and became pathologically node-negative after undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

title: These 4 new Louisiana laws aim to help cancer patients
summary: Gov. John Bel Edwards signed four new laws in Louisiana to assist cancer patients. These laws, advocated by the Louisiana Oncology Society and Survivor’s Cancer Action Network, aim to improve access to care and reduce insurance barriers. Act 324 expands health insurance coverage for biomarker testing, crucial for determining cancer treatment. Act 110, the “Cancer Patient’s Right to Prompt Coverage Act,” shortens the review time for insurance companies, allowing quicker access to necessary procedures, drugs, and tests. Act 299 mandates insurance coverage for fertility preservation services for cancer patients undergoing treatments that may cause infertility. Act 42 allows individuals with a Louisiana driver’s license to indicate their wish to be bone marrow donors, with their information shared with the National Marrow Donor Program. These laws are set to enhance the quality of life and treatment outcomes for cancer patients in Louisiana.

title: HealthTree Research Hub Launched in Myeloma
summary: HealthTree Foundation has launched the HealthTree Research Hub for multiple myeloma, an online portal designed to connect patients and researchers to accelerate cures. This innovative platform provides access to real-world data (RWD) from over 14,000 myeloma patients, including electronically imported EHR data and patient-reported outcomes. The data is validated by HealthTree medical professionals, ensuring accuracy and completeness. Researchers can perform various studies using this data, facilitated by R-studio tools. The initiative aims to overcome traditional RWD challenges and enhance research efficiency. HealthTree Research Hub plans to support over 100 research projects in the next 20 months and will also conduct beta research in lymphoma, leukemia, and MPNs in 2024. Researchers and patients are encouraged to participate, with patient data anonymized to maintain privacy.

title: HealthTree Foundation Announces Launch of HealthTree Research Hub in Multiple Myeloma
summary: HealthTree Foundation has launched the HealthTree Research Hub, an innovative online portal that facilitates real-world data (RWD) research for multiple myeloma. The portal provides researchers access to anonymized data from over 14,000 myeloma patients, including EHR data, patient-reported outcomes, and demographics. This data is validated by HealthTree medical professionals, enabling comprehensive and constantly updated datasets. Researchers can use the portal for data mining, chart reviews, and surveys, with tools provided for in-depth analysis. The initiative aims to accelerate cures by overcoming traditional RWD challenges and fostering collaboration between patients and researchers. The Hub will support over 100 research projects in the next 20 months and expand to other blood cancers in 2024.

title: HealthTree Foundation Cure Tour
summary: HealthTree Foundation is launching its Cure Tour this summer to meet multiple myeloma patients in their hometowns. The tour aims to promote research and provide local resources for myeloma and other blood cancer patients. Cities will be chosen based on the presence of myeloma doctors collaborating with HealthTree. A call for research proposals is open from March 1-31, 2024, and selected projects will be announced in April and May. Events will feature introductions to the HealthTree Cure Hub, presentations by local doctors, and support for patients to join the Hub. Tour dates will be posted on the HealthTree Foundation website, and the tour is expected to last over two years. Audrey Burton-Bethke, the Editor for HealthTree Foundation, emphasizes the importance of these events in improving patients' quality of life and advancing towards myeloma cures.

title: HealthTree Foundation Launches Enhanced Technology Platform
summary: The HealthTree Foundation, a global nonprofit based in Lehi, Utah, has relaunched its enhanced technology platform aimed at uniting patients and researchers to cure diseases. The new HealthTree 2.0 platform, introduced on October 23, 2023, supports 42 diseases, expanding from its initial focus on multiple myeloma and acute myeloid leukemia. The foundation aims to double its patient base to 25,000 and raise $5 million for myeloma research. Keynote speakers at the launch event include notable figures in the medical field such as Dr. Fred Appelbaum, Dr. Rafael Fonseca, and Dr. Jeffrey Wolf. The event, sponsored by Bristol Myers Squibb, will be live-streamed from Deer Valley, Utah, and is designed to inspire and educate attendees. HealthTree Foundation, founded in 2012 by Jenny and Paul Ahlstrom, provides personalized support, education, and a patient data portal to drive medical breakthroughs.

title: HealthTree Foundation Announces Launch of HealthTree 2.0 on Oct 23
summary: HealthTree Foundation will launch HealthTree 2.0 on October 23, 2023, expanding its innovative technology and patient participation model to accelerate cures for myeloma and all blood cancers. The event will be held at the Montage hotel in Deer Valley, Utah, and livestreamed online. Keynote speakers include Dr. Fred Appelbaum, Dr. Rafael Fonseca, and Dr. Jeffrey Wolf. HealthTree 2.0 will introduce 14 new software "cure tools" focusing on personalized support, patient connections, and a powerful data portal called HealthTree Cure Hub. This initiative aims to transform patients into active contributors to cancer research through real-world evidence and participation in surveys and studies. The launch marks the beginning of HealthTree’s second decade, promising enhanced support and research potential for blood cancer patients and caregivers.

title: TALVEY, a Bispecific Antibody for Myeloma Patients
summary: TALVEY (Talquetamab) is the only approved bispecific antibody targeting GPRC5D, designed to attract the innate immune system to kill myeloma cells. HealthTree University offers a video detailing TALVEY's mechanism, side effects management, administration, and dosing schedule. The program includes over 500 videos covering myeloma basics, treatment options, genetic testing, and more, created by top myeloma doctors. Leonardo Garcia, the video production manager, ensures high-quality, accurate content to aid patients. HealthTree also organizes events like the Cure Tour and 5K/1M runs to support blood cancer research. Subscriptions to the HealthTree Community newsletter provide updates on multiple myeloma news, stories, clinical trials, and expert events. HealthTree Foundation, a 501(c)(3) organization, offers various resources, including webinars, podcasts, and clinical trial finders, to support myeloma patients and their families.

title: Contribute to Myeloma Research with RWD
summary: If myeloma patients cannot join clinical trials due to various barriers, they can still contribute to research by sharing their medical records with HealthTree Cure Hub. Over 14,000 myeloma patients have already donated their data, aiding researchers in obtaining accurate information for blood cancer studies. Patients can also participate in surveys and studies on HealthTree Cure Hub, which influence healthcare practices. Additionally, patients are encouraged to stay informed about research opportunities, share information within their communities, and ask doctors to submit research proposals. Audrey Burton-Bethke, the Editor for the HealthTree Foundation, emphasizes the importance of patient participation in accelerating myeloma research.

title: What is the Myeloma Coach Program?
summary: The Myeloma Coach program, offered by the HealthTree Foundation, is a free service designed to assist multiple myeloma patients by connecting them with experienced volunteers. These volunteers, who are either myeloma patients themselves or caregivers, provide support in finding specialists, understanding financial resources, and utilizing online tools for better disease management. The program emphasizes the importance of guidance from those who have navigated the complexities of myeloma, including diagnosis shock, treatment options, and preparation for stem cell transplants. The service is available nationwide, and individuals can also volunteer to become coaches, dedicating at least 8 hours per month for up to a year.

title: Real World Velcade Data in Newly Diagnosed Myeloma
summary: A study presented at ASH 2023 by Dr. Fieke Hoff examined real-world prescribing patterns and outcomes of Velcade (bortezomib) in newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. The study analyzed data from 2,522 patients between 2017-2022, revealing that 36.8% received twice-weekly dosing and 63.2% received once-weekly dosing. The findings showed no significant difference in progression-free or overall survival between the dosing schedules. The authors highlighted that once-weekly dosing results in less peripheral neuropathy and requires fewer clinic visits. They suggested that once-weekly Velcade should be considered the standard of care for newly diagnosed myeloma patients. This study underscores the importance of real-world data in informing treatment strategies.

title: For Newly Diagnosed: Setting Up Your Expectations For Having Myeloma
summary: The text provides a comprehensive guide for newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients, detailing the complexity of the disease, treatment strategies, and side effects. Dr. Jason Chen offers insights on patient care, staging, and survival rates. Multiple myeloma, the second most common blood cancer, is incurable but manageable with various treatments. The Revised International Staging System (R-ISS) is used for staging, determining low to high risk. Survival rates depend on risk level, treatment, age, comorbidities, and eligibility for stem cell transplants. Common treatments include drug combinations like RVD, DRD, CyBorD, and DaraRVD. Side effects are managed with supportive care medications, and a stem cell transplant is recommended if the patient is healthy. The guide encourages patients to seek further information and support through HealthTree resources.

title: 2023 Tax Filing Prep for the Myeloma Community
summary: The text provides guidance for the myeloma community on preparing for 2023 tax filings, emphasizing the importance of maximizing tax breaks related to medical expenses. It advises gathering receipts for out-of-pocket medical costs, including premiums, travel for treatment, and other deductible expenses like dental, vision, home modifications, and alternative medicine. The text highlights the benefit of itemizing deductions if they exceed 7.5% of adjusted gross income and lists specific deductible costs. It also mentions that grants from pharmaceutical companies or non-profits do not need to be claimed as income and suggests additional tax benefits like charitable donations and Health Savings Account contributions. Finally, it encourages early preparation for 2024 taxes by keeping thorough records and considering financial adjustments throughout the year.

title: Does Dex Cause Cataracts in Myeloma Patients?
summary: Dr. Rahul Banerjee presented research at the 20th Annual International Myeloma Society meeting on the link between dexamethasone (Dex) treatment and cataracts in myeloma patients. As an assistant professor at the Fred Hutchinson Research Center, he collaborated with the HealthTree Foundation to study this connection. Dr. Banerjee observed that many myeloma patients reported vision issues, prompting a study of over 200 patients' anonymized data. Findings revealed that cataracts are common among myeloma patients, with nearly half developing them within a year of starting treatment, often involving steroids like dexamethasone. A clear link was found between the severity of cataracts and both the duration and dose of Dex exposure. Dr. Banerjee emphasized that these findings suggest Dex significantly contributes to cataract development, beyond just aging. Further research is planned to better understand these effects and improve patient care.

title: BioNJ Announces Lineup for BioPartnering Conference
summary: BioNJ will host its 14th Annual BioPartnering Conference on May 14, 2024, at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. Sponsored by J.P. Morgan, Johnson & Johnson, and Morgan Lewis, the event will bring together life sciences executives, investors, academic collaborators, and business development professionals. The conference will feature one-on-one partnering, industry connections, exhibits, company pitch presentations, plenary sessions, and networking opportunities. Key sessions will cover industry trends, biotech and pharma partnerships, AI in biopharma, and venture capital shifts. Notable speakers include Tyler Bryk, Samuele Butera, Kim Cato, and others. Attendees can schedule appointments with BD professionals from major biopharma companies. The event aims to foster innovation and collaboration in the life sciences sector. Registration details are available on BioNJ.org.

title: BioNJ Celebrates Innovation and Life Sciences at Annual Dinner Meeting
summary: BioNJ hosted its 31st Annual Dinner Meeting and Innovation Celebration in East Brunswick, attracting over 700 attendees to honor innovation and life sciences in New Jersey. Debbie Hart, president and CEO of BioNJ, praised the collaborative spirit of the state's life sciences community. Governor Phil Murphy highlighted New Jersey’s significant contributions to novel drug approvals and emphasized ongoing initiatives to foster innovation, such as the Innovation Evergreen fund and SciTech Scity. BioNJ announced Emer Leahy as its first female board chair. Awards were presented, including the Dr. Sol J. Barer Award to William H. Lewis and the Heart of BioNJ Awards to Lisa Salberg, Amadou Diarra, and Mark Peters. Innovator Award Honorees were recognized for their FDA drug approvals, including companies like AbbVie, Bristol Myers Squibb, and Pfizer.

title: BioNJ's BioPartnering Conference Moving to the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City
summary: The 14th Annual BioNJ BioPartnering Conference will be held at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City on May 14, 2024. This move aligns with the New Jersey Economic Development Authority's $20 million investment in an innovation hub at Liberty Science Center's SciTech Scity. The conference, which fosters partnerships and investment opportunities in the life sciences sector, will feature 1-1 partnering, company pitches, exhibits, and networking. Key partners include J.P. Morgan, Johnson & Johnson Innovation, and Morgan Lewis. Jersey City's Mayor Steven Fulop and Liberty Science Center's CEO Paul Hoffman expressed enthusiasm for the event, highlighting the city's growing reputation as a hub for science and technology innovation. Applications for company pitch presentations will open on January 16, 2024.

title: BioNJ Announces Lineup for BioPartnering Conference
summary: BioNJ will host its 13th Annual BioPartnering Conference on April 18, 2023, at The Palace at Somerset Park, NJ. Returning in person after three years, the event will gather life sciences executives, investors, academic collaborators, and business development professionals for networking, partnering, company pitches, exhibits, and plenary sessions. The conference, supported by partners like J.P. Morgan and Johnson & Johnson Innovation, aims to strengthen the life sciences ecosystem and support medical innovation. It will feature a full-day agenda, including a networking reception and sessions with industry leaders. Attendees will also see presentations from the winners of BioNJ's Health Equity in Clinical Trials MBA Case Competition and have opportunities to meet representatives from renowned institutions. Registration costs $395 for BioNJ members and $495 for non-members.

title: ACCC National Oncology Conference to Focus on Reimagining Innovation in Cancer Care
summary: The ACCC's 40th National Oncology Conference will be held in Austin, Texas, from October 4-6, focusing on "Reimagining Innovation" in cancer care. Key areas include workforce burnout, value-based care, patient experience, and promoting women leaders. Olalekan Ajayi, PharmD, MBA, is the new ACCC president. Preconference sessions will cover financial advocacy, value-based care, and clinical updates. The event will feature poster presentations on various topics, including health disparities and workplace wellness. A notable session, "Women Leaders in Oncology," will discuss the underrepresentation of women in healthcare leadership. The conference will include 30 sessions, with six presentations from ACCC Innovator Award winners. Networking opportunities will be available throughout the event.

title: Pennsylvania Hospital Shows That Community Cancer Centers Can Conduct Phase I Clinical Research
summary: Pennsylvania Hospital has demonstrated that community cancer centers can successfully conduct Phase I clinical research, as shown by their program at the Penn Medicine Abramson Cancer Center. This initiative, discussed at the ACCC National Oncology Conference, highlights the benefits of providing clinical trials in community settings, particularly for patients with travel restrictions. Tara Perloff, Oncology Clinical Research Program Manager, emphasizes the importance of integrating pharmacists into the research team and creating a tailored infrastructure for community practices. The program has enrolled over 75 patients, proving that community centers can replicate this model effectively. Key differences between academic and community research settings include the lack of subspecialized departments in community centers, which necessitates innovation and adaptability. The involvement of pharmacists from the feasibility stage and their role in patient education are crucial for the program's success. This model offers more accessible trial options for patients, ensuring they receive advanced treatments close to home.

title: UH cancer scientist's passion leads to national changes, community award | University of Hawaiʻi System News
summary: Christa Braun-Inglis from the University of Hawaiʻi Cancer Center received the 2024 David King Community Clinical Scientist Award from the Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC) for her dedication to cancer research and education. Her efforts to assist advanced practice providers (APPs) in overcoming barriers to clinical trial participation led to national policy changes. Braun-Inglis' research focuses on expanding APP roles in National Cancer Institute (NCI) clinical trials, increasing diversity, and optimizing cancer care delivery, particularly in breast cancer. Her work prompted ACCC to endorse a survey for APPs and clinical trials, resulting in policy changes that integrate APPs into the NCI Community Oncology Research Program. She was honored at the 2024 ACCC Awards Ceremony in Washington, D.C.

title: Wake Forest’s Nadine Barrett named ACCC president; 2024-2025
summary: Nadine J. Barrett, senior associate dean for community engagement and equity in research at Wake Forest University School of Medicine and Atrium Health, has been named president of the Association of Cancer Care Centers (ACCC) for the 2024-2025 term.

title: Cancer Centers Look to Precision Medicine Stewards to Navigate Biomarker Testing Hurdles
summary: Cancer centers are increasingly employing precision medicine stewards to manage biomarker testing, a complex and essential component of personalized cancer treatment. Melissa Cruz-Tanner, who began as a patient navigator at Astera Cancer Care, highlighted the initial challenges in biomarker testing, such as lack of patient education and insurance coverage. Cruz-Tanner's role evolved to include ordering tests, managing clinical data, and ensuring timely results, which proved to be a full-time job. Over time, Astera developed a team of navigators and support staff to handle these tasks more efficiently. Precision medicine stewards, also known as molecular processors, are vital in coordinating lab appointments, managing insurance authorizations, and ensuring test results are integrated into electronic health records promptly. The Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC) is promoting the adoption of these roles through educational campaigns, aiming to demonstrate their value in improving patient care and reducing financial burdens.

title: 19th annual Sandy Sprint 5K in Center City, Philadelphia raises over $279K for Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation
hco: SANDY ROLLMAN OVARIAN CANCER FOUNDATION INC
summary: The 19th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run-walk in Center City, Philadelphia, raised over $279,000 to support ovarian cancer research. The event benefited the Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation and included a survivor ceremony at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Action News' Gina Gannon hosted the event for the sixth consecutive year.

title: Butterfly mural unveiled in Philadelphia's Old City neighborhood ahead of 20th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run/walk
hco: SANDY ROLLMAN OVARIAN CANCER FOUNDATION INC
summary: A new mural featuring a teal butterfly has been unveiled in Philadelphia's Old City to raise awareness about ovarian cancer ahead of the 20th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run/walk. The mural, symbolizing hope and resilience, includes words like "mom," "friend," and "wife." Robin Cohen, who cared for Sandy Rollman, founded the Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation after Rollman died from ovarian cancer at age 32. The foundation aims to fund research for new treatments. The mural was completed by artist Sarah Fogg, whose mother also died from ovarian cancer. The Sandy Sprint will take place at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: 19th annual Sandy Sprint 5K in Center City, Philadelphia raises over $279K for Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation
hco: SANDY ROLLMAN OVARIAN CANCER FOUNDATION INC
summary: The 19th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run-walk in Center City, Philadelphia, raised over $279,000 on Saturday to support ovarian cancer research. The event benefitted the Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation and included a survivor ceremony on the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. For the sixth consecutive year, Action News' Gina Gannon served as the host.

title: Butterfly mural unveiled in Philadelphia's Old City neighborhood ahead of 20th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run/walk
hco: SANDY ROLLMAN OVARIAN CANCER FOUNDATION INC
summary: A new mural featuring a teal butterfly has been unveiled in Philadelphia's Old City to raise awareness about ovarian cancer ahead of the 20th annual Sandy Sprint 5K run/walk. Organized by the Sandy Rollman Ovarian Cancer Foundation, the event aims to fund research and advance treatments for ovarian cancer, a disease with no early detection screening. Robin Cohen, who founded the organization after her patient Sandy Rollman died at 32, emphasizes the mural's symbolism of hope and resilience. Artist Sarah Fogg completed the mural in memory of her mother, who also succumbed to ovarian cancer.

title: MAIA Biotechnology Abstract Accepted for Poster Presentation at American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 ...
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: MAIA Biotechnology announced that its abstract on the Phase 2 THIO-101 clinical trial has been accepted for poster presentation at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 Annual Meeting. The trial evaluates the telomere-targeting agent THIO combined with cemiplimab in advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. The presentation is scheduled for June 3, 2024. MAIA’s CEO, Vlad Vitoc, expressed pride in presenting at ASCO and highlighted the innovative nature of THIO. The abstract will be available online prior to the conference, and the poster will be published on MAIA’s website on the presentation day.

title: Coherus Announces Presentation at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: Coherus BioSciences, Inc. announced the first presentation of clinical data for CHS-114, a highly selective cytolytic anti-CCR8 antibody, at the 2024 ASCO Annual Meeting in Chicago. The presentation will cover preliminary results from a Phase 1 dose escalation study in patients with advanced solid tumors. CHS-114 targets CCR8+ regulatory T cells in tumors, sparing normal tissue, and has shown promising results in preclinical studies, including reduced tumor growth and enhanced antitumor activity when combined with anti-PD-1 treatment. Coherus focuses on developing innovative cancer therapies and has a robust immuno-oncology pipeline.

title: Reply to R. Sun et al | Journal of Clinical Oncology
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: The authors respond to R. Sun et al.'s comments on their study about pathologic lymph node (LN) regression in esophageal adenocarcinoma. They acknowledge the suggestion to use Uno's C-index instead of Harrell's C-index for survival prediction due to concerns with censored data. However, they defend the use of Harrell's C-index, noting its widespread acceptance and implementation in clinical studies. The study found that all classifications of LN regression (complete, partial, and poor/no response) provided similar prognostic value for survival, regardless of the index used. The chosen 3-point classification system showed high reproducibility and ease of reporting, with significant interobserver agreement. The authors agree that further research is needed to improve model performance and identify additional prognostic variables. They emphasize the importance of LN regression analysis in providing prognostic information beyond current staging systems, aiding in clinical decision-making for adjuvant treatment planning.

title: Cue Biopharma to Present at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: Cue Biopharma, Inc., a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, announced it will present an oral abstract and poster at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting in Chicago from May 31 to June 4, 2024. The presentations will focus on Phase 1 trials of CUE-101 for recurrent/metastatic HPV16+ head and neck squamous cell cancer and CUE-102 for Wilms’ Tumor 1 positive recurrent/metastatic cancers. An oral abstract on CUE-101 will be presented by Dr. Douglas R. Atkins on June 4, 2024, and a poster on CUE-102 by Dr. Nataliya Uboha on June 1, 2024. The company will also host a Business Update call and webcast in June 2024 to discuss clinical progress and data presented at ASCO.

title: Aadi Bioscience Announces Poster Presentations at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO ...
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: Aadi Bioscience announced its participation in the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Gastrointestinal (GI) Cancers Symposium in San Francisco, CA, from January 18-20, 2024. The company will present posters highlighting a real-world analysis of GI cancer patients with TSC1/2 alterations, revealing unmet medical needs. The study found that 1.4% of 138,671 patients with GI cancers had TSC1 or TSC2 alterations, with higher occurrences in liver, colorectal, and pancreatic cancers. The findings suggest that genetic mutations in tumors with TSC1/2 alterations are similar to those in tumors without these alterations. Aadi Bioscience is also presenting ongoing trials, including the PRECISION 1 study, which is enrolling patients with solid tumors harboring TSC1/2 alterations. More information is available on the ASCO GI meeting website. Aadi Bioscience focuses on precision therapies for genetically defined cancers and has commercialized FYARRO® for treating certain malignant tumors.

title: Predictive Oncology Announces Abstract Accepted for Presentation at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology ...
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: Predictive Oncology Inc. announced that its abstract has been accepted for presentation at the 2024 American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Annual Meeting in Chicago, IL, from May 31 to June 4, 2024. The abstract, titled "Using Artificial Intelligence-Powered Evidence-Based Molecular Decision-Making for Improved Outcomes in Ovarian Cancer," highlights a study conducted in collaboration with UPMC Magee-Womens Hospital. The study used multi-omic machine learning models to predict survival outcomes in women with high grade serous ovarian cancer, demonstrating improved predictive accuracy compared to clinical data alone. The presentation will be delivered by Dr. Brian Christopher Orr on June 3, 2024.

title: Biomica to Present at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 Annual Meeting
hco: AMERICAN SOCIETY OF CLINICAL ONCOLOGY INC
summary: Biomica Ltd. will present preliminary data from its Phase 1 study of BMC128 at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2024 Annual Meeting. The study involves combining BMC128 with immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) immunotherapy for patients with non-small cell lung cancer, melanoma, or renal cell carcinoma who previously progressed on immunotherapy. The presentation will take place on June 3, 2024, at McCormick Place in Chicago and will also be available virtually. BMC128 is a live bacterial consortium designed to enhance immunological therapeutic responses. Biomica, a subsidiary of Evogene Ltd., focuses on developing microbiome-based therapeutics for various diseases.

title: INTERVIEW: Celebrating 25 Years of Progress Against Cancer
summary: The Minnesota Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MOCA) is celebrating 25 years of progress against cancer with its annual Black, White, and Teal Gala in April. The event, which includes a reception, dinner, raffles, a photo booth, silent and live auctions, and games, aims to support cancer research. 5 EYEWITNESS NEWS anchor Brett Hoffland interviewed ovarian cancer survivor Deb Runkle about the gala. The April 13 event is already sold out, but more information about MOCA can be found online.

title: MN Ovarian Cancer Alliance celebrates 25 years
summary: The Minnesota Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MOCA) is celebrating its 25th anniversary of supporting research and community assistance. Their major annual fundraiser, the Black, White and Teal Gala, will be held on April 13. Although tickets are sold out, supporters can still contribute via donations at mnovarian.org or participate in the silent online auction starting April 10. Deb Runkle, an ovarian cancer survivor and Gala Committee Member, appeared on FOX 9 Morning News with her family, who will perform at the gala.

title: MOCA is looking forward to 10th Anniversary Light Duluth Teal Gala
summary: MOCA is celebrating the 10th Anniversary of the Light Duluth Teal Gala, a fundraiser for the Minnesota Ovarian Cancer Alliance. The event will be held on Saturday, September 23rd, at the DECC. Kris Greer, a Duluth native and ovarian cancer survivor, highlighted the significance of a decade of raising awareness and supporting women and families in the Northland. The gala has raised nearly half a million dollars for research on early detection, better treatments, and a potential cure for ovarian cancer. Landmarks will be lit teal during the weekend to mark the occasion. Tickets are available at https://mnovarian.org/light-duluth-teal/.

title: Breast cancer fund provides help for patients, research
summary: The Hurwitz Breast Cancer Fund, part of the Unity Campaign, provides crucial support for breast cancer patients and research at the James M. Stockman Cancer Institute in Frederick. Ryan Britt, a patient at the institute, benefits from technology and equipment funded by this initiative. The Unity Campaign, celebrating its 10th anniversary, supports various local nonprofits through the United Way of Frederick County. The campaign runs until March 20, and donations can be made via Unityfrederick.com or by texting Unity 2024 to 71777. This fund aids in enhancing treatment capabilities and supports ongoing cancer research.

title: Experts Highlight Their Biggest Takeaways from the 2023 SOHO Annual Meeting
summary: At the 2023 SOHO Annual Meeting in Houston, Texas, experts presented the latest emerging data, changing treatment approaches, and next stages of research across various hematologic malignancies. Key opinion leaders shared their biggest takeaways, including significant developments in myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia, advancements in CAR T-cell therapies, bispecific antibodies, and novel immunotherapies for multiple myeloma. The meeting facilitated nuanced discussions on treatment approaches and data interpretation among clinicians. Emerging immunotherapy agents and their potential combinations for lymphoma treatment were also highlighted.

title: Is Additional Treatment Needed Pretransplant in R/R AML?
summary: The debate at the Society of Hematologic Oncology (SOHO) meeting focused on whether patients with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML) should undergo allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (alloHCT) without achieving complete remission. Johannes Schetelig, MD, presented findings from the ASAP trial, indicating that patients who proceeded directly to alloHCT without complete remission had similar survival outcomes to those who received intensive salvage induction therapy first. This approach also resulted in fewer severe adverse events and shorter hospital stays. Conversely, Ronald B. Walter, MD, PhD, argued that achieving minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity before transplant is crucial for better post-transplant outcomes. Studies support that MRD-negative patients have significantly better survival rates. The debate highlighted differing views on the necessity of pre-transplant intensive therapy, with calls for further research to optimize treatment strategies.

title: Intensity of Consolidation Chemotherapy Does Not Impact Survival in Older Patients With AML
summary: Researchers found that the intensity of consolidation chemotherapy does not impact survival outcomes in older patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who undergo allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (SCT). The study, presented at the SOHO 2023 Annual Meeting, involved 130 patients aged 60 or older in first complete remission (CR1). The study compared relapse-free survival (RFS) and overall survival rates between those who received intensive versus nonintensive consolidation chemotherapy. Results showed no significant difference in 2-year RFS and overall survival rates between the two groups. Additionally, nonrelapse mortality and graft vs host disease rates were similar. Cytogenetic risk was identified as a prognostic factor, with patients having adverse cytogenetics showing lower 2-year RFS rates. The study's retrospective nature was noted as a limitation.

title: Multidisciplinary Team Is 'Critical' in Providing CAR T Therapy for Blood Cancers
summary: During the 2023 American Society of Hematology (ASH) Annual Meeting and Exposition, Dr. Andre Goy emphasized the importance of a multidisciplinary team in administering CAR T-cell therapy for patients with hematologic malignancies. He highlighted that collaboration among pathologists, immunologists, specialized oncologists, and ICU teams is crucial for effective treatment and management of toxicities. CAR T-cell therapy is seen as a durable option that can potentially cure a significant portion of patients, offering quicker recovery compared to transplants. Goy noted that while CAR T therapy has become more manageable with fewer toxicities, it should be administered within the right context and supported by a specialized care team.

title: ctDNA May Play Role in Large Cell Lymphoma Detection
summary: Recent studies suggest that pretreatment levels of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) may be prognostic in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Dr. Mark J. Roschewski highlighted at the 2023 Society of Hematologic Oncology Annual Meeting that ctDNA could supplement traditional CT/PET scans for detecting active lymphoma at the end of treatment. ctDNA offers advantages such as higher sensitivity and specificity for tumors, providing quantitative metrics. However, challenges include the presence of non-tumor DNA and low ctDNA quantities. Studies showed ctDNA's ability to detect early molecular response, which correlates with improved outcomes. The PhasED-Seq test, developed by Roschewski, identifies phased variants, enhancing sensitivity and accuracy in measuring tumor presence. Data from six studies indicated that ctDNA was prognostic for both frontline and salvage therapies, with significant event-free survival rates for patients showing molecular responses. This suggests ctDNA's potential as a valuable tool in lymphoma management.

title: Orca-T Shows Survival Benefit in Elderly Hematologic Malignancy Population
summary: A study presented at the 2023 American Society of Hematology Annual Meeting showed that Orca-T therapy combined with myeloablative chemotherapy offers similar relapse-free survival (RFS) rates for elderly patients with hematologic malignancies as it does for younger patients. The phase 1b study indicated a 12-month RFS of 82.3% in patients aged 55 and older, compared to 84.8% in younger patients. The 1-year overall survival (OS) was 95.5% for older patients and 100% for younger ones. Orca-T demonstrated potential as a reduced toxicity alternative to conventional allogeneic transplants, with a 0% non-relapse mortality rate in both groups. The study involved patients aged 18-75 with acute leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome, and chronic myeloid leukemia, all of whom had adequate organ function and a Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation–specific Comorbidity Index of 4 or less. Orca-T is currently being compared to standard-of-care therapy in the ongoing phase 3 Orca Precision-T trial.

title: TALVEY, a Bispecific Antibody for Myeloma Patients
summary: TALVEY (Talquetamab) is the only approved bispecific antibody targeting GPRC5D, designed to attract the innate immune system to kill myeloma cells. The HealthTree Foundation provides educational resources on TALVEY, including its mechanism, side effects, administration, and dosing schedule. HealthTree University offers over 500 videos on various myeloma topics created by top myeloma doctors, covering basics, treatment options, genetics, and patient care. The foundation also organizes events, clinical trials, and community support for myeloma patients.

title: HealthTree Research Hub Launched in Myeloma
summary: HealthTree Foundation has launched the HealthTree Research Hub, an online portal designed to connect multiple myeloma patients and researchers to accelerate cures and facilitate real-world data (RWD) research. The hub provides access to data from over 14,000 myeloma patients, including electronically imported EHR data and patient-reported outcomes. This data is validated by HealthTree medical professionals, ensuring accuracy and completeness. The platform allows researchers to perform data mining, chart reviews, and surveys, providing tools like R-studio for data analysis. The initiative aims to support over 100 research projects in the next 20 months and invites researchers to submit proposals. The hub also plans to extend its beta research projects to lymphoma, leukemia, and MPNs in 2024. Patients are encouraged to connect their medical records, participate in surveys, and stay informed through the HealthTree News Site, especially during Myeloma Awareness Month.

title: HealthTree Foundation Announces Launch of HealthTree Research Hub in Multiple Myeloma
summary: HealthTree Foundation has launched the HealthTree Research Hub, an innovative online portal designed to facilitate real-world data (RWD) research for multiple myeloma. This tool provides researchers with access to anonymized data from over 14,000 myeloma patients, including electronic health records (EHR), patient-reported outcomes (PRO), and demographics. The data is validated by HealthTree medical professionals, ensuring accuracy and completeness. The Research Hub enables various research activities such as data mining, chart reviews, and synthetic control arm comparisons. Researchers can access the data through a secure login and use R-studio tools for analysis. The initiative aims to support over 100 research projects in the next 20 months and will expand to include lymphoma, leukemia, and MPNs research in 2024.

title: Interview Myeloma Specialist, Dr. Gurbakhash Kaur
summary: Dr. Gurbakhash Kaur, a myeloma and amyloidosis specialist at UT Southwestern Harold C. Simmons Cancer Center, discusses their comprehensive myeloma program which includes non-immunotherapy and immunotherapy treatments such as CAR-T, bispecifics, and targeted therapy. Non-immunotherapy targets cancer cells directly, while immunotherapy uses the body's immune system to fight cancer. UT Southwestern's research program aims to include underrepresented communities in clinical trials, working with Parkland Health to qualify patients for trials at either hospital. Dr. Kaur emphasizes the importance of participating in clinical trials for access to new treatments and contributing to advancements in myeloma research. HealthTree for Multiple Myeloma supports patients in navigating their journey and provides resources and information about clinical trials and treatments.

title: HealthTree Foundation Announces Launch of HealthTree 2.0 on Oct 23
summary: HealthTree Foundation announced the launch of HealthTree 2.0 on October 23, 2023. This global non-profit organization uses advanced technology to connect patients and researchers to accelerate cures for blood cancers. HealthTree 2.0 will expand its successful model from multiple myeloma to all blood cancers. The event, titled "Using Technology and Revolutionary Approaches to Cure Cancer," will be hosted at the Montage hotel in Deer Valley, Utah, and livestreamed online. Keynote speakers include Dr. Fred Appelbaum, Dr. Rafael Fonseca, and Dr. Jeffrey Wolf. HealthTree 2.0 aims to provide personalized support, patient connections, and a robust patient data portal called HealthTree Cure Hub, transforming patients into active contributors to cancer research. The initiative also includes six new regional communities to enhance research participation. The launch marks a new era of patient empowerment and research potential.

title: Contribute to Myeloma Research with RWD
summary: HealthTree Foundation provides an alternative for myeloma patients who cannot participate in clinical trials by contributing their real-world data (RWD). Patients can connect their medical records to HealthTree Cure Hub, joining over 14,000 others to aid myeloma research. This data is reviewed anonymously, enhancing the accuracy of research. During Myeloma Awareness Month, HealthTree encourages patients to stay informed via their News Site, participate in surveys and studies, and share research opportunities with their doctors. The foundation emphasizes the importance of RWD in advancing myeloma treatment and finding a cure. Audrey Burton-Bethke, the article's author, is passionate about educating and supporting the myeloma community.

title: What is the Myeloma Coach Program?
summary: The Myeloma Coach program, offered by the HealthTree Foundation, is a free initiative designed to assist multiple myeloma patients by connecting them with experienced patient and caregiver volunteers. These volunteers, known as Myeloma Coaches, help patients navigate their diagnosis, find myeloma specialists, access financial resources, and utilize online tools to improve their quality of life. Coaches come from diverse backgrounds and have personal experiences with myeloma, either as patients or caregivers. The program aims to provide support and guidance through the complex journey of living with multiple myeloma. It also offers opportunities for myeloma patients and caregivers to volunteer as coaches, providing training and a rewarding experience.

title: Is Multiple Myeloma Genetic?
summary: Multiple myeloma is not generally considered a genetic disease, though having a family member with the condition slightly increases one's risk. The increased risk may be influenced by environmental or other factors rather than direct genetics. Genetic testing for myeloma is not typically conducted in families, especially for children. Risk factors for developing myeloma include age (most patients are diagnosed over 65), gender (slightly more males are affected), race (Blacks are 2-3 times more likely to develop it), obesity, and precursor conditions like MGUS and smoldering myeloma. The PROMISE study by Dana Farber and Johns Hopkins aims to understand why family members and African Americans are more prone to myeloma by inviting blood sample donations from these groups. The study seeks to enroll 50,000 participants to explore the progression from precursor conditions to active myeloma.

title: Real World Velcade Data in Newly Diagnosed Myeloma
summary: A study presented at ASH 2023 by Dr. Fieke Hoff examined real-world prescribing patterns and outcomes of Velcade (bortezomib) in newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. The analysis, which included 2,522 patients from the Flatiron Health database (2017-2022), compared once-weekly and twice-weekly dosing. Results indicated that 36.8% received twice-weekly dosing while 63.2% received once-weekly dosing. No significant difference was found in progression-free survival or overall survival between the two dosing schedules. The study highlighted that once-weekly dosing led to less peripheral neuropathy and required fewer clinic visits, suggesting it should be considered the standard of care. The importance of personalized treatment strategies in myeloma care was emphasized, blending science with patient-specific considerations.

title: What are the most recent myeloma statistics?
summary: Observational data from the U.S. National Cancer Institute’s SEER shows the multiple myeloma survival rate has stabilized at 59.8% from 2016 to 2020. In 2023, there were 35,730 new myeloma cases (1.8% of all new cancer cases) and 12,590 deaths (2.1% of all cancer deaths). Advances in drugs over the past 20 years have improved survival rates, with recent FDA approvals for CAR T therapies and bispecific antibodies for relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma. SEER data indicates higher survival rates in younger patients, but myeloma is most frequently diagnosed in those aged 65–74. Updated statistics are needed to reflect recent breakthroughs.

title: Dhingra joins panel laying out path to universal health care in WA - Sen. Manka Dhingra
summary: Senator Manka Dhingra joined a panel at the Binaytara Foundation’s Summit on Cancer Health Disparities to discuss Washington's progress towards universal health care. Dhingra emphasized that health care is a right and highlighted Washington's achievements, including the Washington Health Benefit Exchange, expanded Apple Care, and state subsidies, which have reduced the uninsured rate to 4.7%. Despite these advances, many still lack coverage. The panel, moderated by Manisha Bhattacharya and Aaron Goodman, included notable health care leaders who discussed universal health care as a solution to U.S. health care disparities. Washington's efforts include the Affordable Care Act, Cascade Care, and subsidies for low-income residents. The state has also tackled prescription drug prices through legislation and established the Universal Health Care Commission to explore paths to universal coverage.

title: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F) launch BRIDGES 2.0 Research ...
summary: The Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) and The GOG Foundation, Inc. (GOG-F), with support from the Foundation for Women’s Cancer (FWC), have launched the BRIDGES 2.0 Research Initiative. This expanded two-year clinical trial education program aims to cultivate early-career gynecologic, medical, and radiation oncologists by focusing on clinical and translational research advancements, trial methodology, and real-world clinical trials implementation. The program targets oncologists with less than ten years of experience post-training, including senior fellows and faculty members. Applications are being accepted until May 16, 2024, and the selected cohort will begin in July 2024. The initiative is supported by various industry partners and aims to advance care and outcomes for women with gynecologic cancers.

title: The Foundation for Women's Cancer Named "Partner-of-Choice" by The Institute for Surgical Excellence Receiving ...
summary: The Foundation for Women's Cancer (FWC) has been named the "Partner-of-Choice" by the Institute for Surgical Excellence (ISE) and received a $155,555 donation. This contribution is part of the 2024 launch of Move4Her, FWC's annual fundraising campaign, aimed at raising funds for research, education, and awareness of gynecologic cancers. The donation was collected through ISE's "Tee-off for the Cure" event at Torrey Pines, La Jolla, California. The ISE hosted educational sessions and fundraising activities, highlighting advancements in medical technologies like AI and surgical robotics. The events culminated in a gala honoring contributions to cancer care. The Move4Her campaign, now in its fifth year, has been recognized for its impact and aims to break fundraising records to support women's cancer research and awareness.

title: Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance hosts annual Time to Teal event
summary: The Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance will host its annual Time to Teal event on May 12, 2024, in downtown Ann Arbor to raise awareness and funds for ovarian cancer. The event features a 5k run and a one-mile fun run/walk, along with an art demo by chalk artist David Zinn and photo opportunities with characters from Neverland Entertainment and Wolverine Blasty. This marks the thirteenth year of the event, traditionally held on Mother's Day, initiated by co-founder Pam Dahlmann in memory of her mother. The event supports the organization's efforts, including providing support totes, facilitating support groups, and advocating for research funding. The ultimate goal is to develop an early detection test for ovarian cancer. Registration starts at 7 a.m., with the races beginning shortly after. More information and online registration are available on the Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance's website.

title: 'Time to Teal' 5K brings ovarian cancer awareness to streets of Ann Arbor
summary: The "Time to Teal" 5K race in Ann Arbor, organized by the Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MIOCA), aims to raise awareness and funds for ovarian cancer. Scheduled for May 12, the event coincides with Mother’s Day and will take place throughout downtown Ann Arbor. Nearly 13,000 women in the U.S. are expected to die from ovarian cancer, with 19,000 new diagnoses anticipated in 2024. MIOCA, founded in 2011 by Pam Dahlmann, promotes early detection, improved treatments, and provides resources for survivors and families. The race includes various activities, medals, and treats for participants. Registration costs $40 until May 11, with higher fees on race day.

title: Communities across Michigan tie teal ribbons, spreading awareness of ovarian cancer with MIOCA
summary: The Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MIOCA) launches an annual awareness campaign, Tie Michigan Teal, every September to raise awareness about ovarian cancer. This initiative involves volunteers tying teal ribbons on lamp posts across over 60 cities and 14 campuses in Michigan, including Mt. Pleasant, Flint, Elk Rapids, Port Huron, and Midland. The campaign aims to educate the public about ovarian cancer symptoms and the importance of genetic history. This year, Mt. Pleasant participated for the first time, with volunteers tying around 100 ribbons downtown. Mid Michigan College also joined the campaign by setting up displays and encouraging students to participate. MIOCA, founded in 2011, focuses on promoting early detection, providing resources and support, advocating for better treatment, and funding research. Ovarian cancer, often called “the silent disease,” is expected to affect 19,710 women in the U.S. this year, with around 13,270 deaths. More information can be found at MIOCA.org.

title: Time to Teal Mother's Day 5k and Fun run/walk to support MIOCA
summary: The Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MIOCA) is hosting its 12th Annual Mother's Day Time to Teal event on May 14, 2023, in Ann Arbor, Michigan, with options for in-person and virtual participation. The event includes a timed 5k and a fun run/walk, aiming to celebrate women and raise ovarian cancer awareness. Registration fees range from $30 to $45, with survivors receiving a 50% discount. Participants can also purchase optional t-shirts. Early packet pick-up details will be announced. Fundraising is encouraged, with prizes for top fundraisers. All proceeds benefit MIOCA. For more information, visit MIOCA's website.
