title: Early awareness is key for ovarian cancer patients
summary: Early awareness is crucial for ovarian cancer patients, as highlighted by the Tie Michigan Teal campaign led by Jamie Crooker in memory of her mother, Norma Kosmala, who died of ovarian cancer in 2022. Norma's late-stage diagnosis underscores the importance of recognizing symptoms early. The campaign, part of National Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month, involves tying teal ribbons and encouraging communities to raise awareness. The Michigan Ovarian Cancer Alliance (MIOCA) supports this initiative by providing resources, advocating for better legislation, and funding research. Ovarian cancer affects many, with about 19,710 new cases annually in the U.S., and early detection can save lives.

title: Karen O'Brien made teal a common color in Monroe County
summary: Former St. Mary Catholic Central volleyball coach Karen O’Brien, who has been battling ovarian cancer since 2015, recently celebrated being classified as NED (no evidence of disease). O’Brien, known for her efforts in raising awareness and funds for ovarian cancer through her Teal Attack program, is a finalist for the Scientific American Cancer Community’s Unconventional Heroes Award. The award includes a $50,000 prize for the winner's chosen charity, which could help Teal Attack reach its goal of raising $500,000. The program, which started in 2015, uses sports to educate about ovarian cancer and has raised around $380,000. Despite her NED status, O’Brien remains vigilant due to the cancer's tendency to return. She continues to fight and teach others about the disease while helping coach the Vikings, which aids her personal battle.

title: 'Survivors Teach Students' program shows Downstate medical students the human side of ovarian cancer
summary: The "Survivors Teach Students" program, facilitated by ovarian cancer survivor Deborah Polinsky, partners with Downstate Medical School to provide medical students with insights that go beyond textbooks. The program, in collaboration with the Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance, features survivor volunteers sharing their personal experiences, including symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of ovarian cancer. This initiative aims to highlight the human side of medicine, ensuring that students remember the stories even if they forget the faces. With over 1,000 volunteers, the program has educated more than 115,000 medical students over a decade. In 2024, an estimated 20,000 women will be diagnosed with ovarian cancer, which is the fourth leading cause of cancer-related deaths in women.

title: Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance to boost screening for new Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month campaign
summary: The Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance (OCRA) has initiated a campaign during September's Ovarian Cancer Awareness Month to promote at-home screening and preventive surgery for those at risk of ovarian cancer. The campaign targets individuals with a family history of ovarian or related cancers, encouraging them to undergo genetic testing to assess their risk. OCRA is offering a pilot program providing free at-home genetic testing kits and recommending preventive surgery for those at risk. The initiative aims to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer, which is relatively rare but has a high mortality rate. OCRA has already distributed 1,041 genetic test kits, identifying 58 cases with genetic mutations that increase cancer risk. The campaign highlights the significance of genetic testing in managing ovarian cancer risk.

title: Request for Applications: Health Equity Research Grant
summary: The Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance (OCRA) is inviting applications for the 2025 Health Equity Research Grant, with a deadline of March 27, 2024. This grant aims to support research projects that address health disparities in ovarian and related gynecologic cancers. The focus is on promoting equity, inclusivity, and evidence-based approaches to overcome barriers faced by marginalized communities, defined by factors such as gender identity, sexual orientation, race, ethnicity, disability status, and language barriers. The grant offers up to $100,000 USD annually for two years, totaling $200,000 USD. Principal Investigators at all career stages with relevant doctoral degrees are eligible to apply, and international applicants are welcome. Projects must have a clear health equity focus and not solely be community programs. The selection committee favors creative, original projects with the potential for long-term impact and high-impact research.

title: Only 28 years old, Weymouth woman already beat ovarian cancer once
summary: Jenny O’Hear, a 28-year-old woman from Weymouth, has already battled ovarian cancer once. Ovarian cancer, the deadliest of gynecologic cancers, often presents vague symptoms like bloating and cramping, making early diagnosis difficult. Approximately 20,000 American women are diagnosed annually, with a five-year survival rate of about 50%, largely due to late-stage detection. O’Hear was diagnosed at 25 with Stage 3C Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma, a rare subtype affecting younger women. Following a complete hysterectomy and six rounds of chemotherapy, she remained cancer-free until March, when new cancerous spots were found and surgically removed. Genetic testing can help identify risks, allowing preventive surgeries, though this option affects fertility. The Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance offers free genetic testing for qualifying women.

title: New Approach to Adoptive T-Cell Therapy Shows Promise for Boosting Immune Response in Ovarian Cancer
summary: Researchers at Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center have developed a promising new approach to adoptive T-cell therapy for ovarian cancer. This technique uses engineered T cells to deliver bispecific T-cell engagers (BiTEs), which activate both infused and bystander T cells to target cancer cells more effectively. The study focuses on folate receptor alpha (FR?), an antigen associated with ovarian cancer. Preclinical trials demonstrated that FR-B T cells, which secrete BiTEs, efficiently destroy FR?-positive cancer cells and persist outside the tumor to sustain the immune response. This innovative therapy could significantly improve treatment outcomes for ovarian cancer patients and is moving towards clinical trials.

title: Renewed Calls for Fallopian Tube Removal to Avoid Ovarian Cancer
summary: The Ovarian Cancer Research Alliance (OCRA) recommends that all women consider prophylactic removal of fallopian tubes during other pelvic surgeries after childbearing to prevent ovarian cancer. This shift from focusing on symptom awareness and early detection follows disappointing results from a UK study showing that screening with CA-125 blood tests and ultrasounds did not reduce ovarian cancer deaths. Experts, including Audra Moran of OCRA and Stephanie V. Blank of the Society of Gynecologic Oncology, support this recommendation, citing evidence that many high-grade serous ovarian cancers originate in the fallopian tubes. While the procedure, known as opportunistic salpingectomy, is not new, it is gaining renewed attention. Leading organizations like the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists have endorsed it since 2015. The procedure is considered low-risk and may significantly reduce cancer risk, though further research is ongoing.

title: 14th annual Together in Teal celebration raising awareness of ovarian cancer
summary: The 14th annual Together in Teal Celebration aims to raise awareness of ovarian cancer and will take place on Saturday, September 30, at 8 a.m. at Raccoon River Park in West Des Moines. Shonna Swartz, the Iowa Market Manager for the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition, discussed the event on "Good Morning Iowa." More information on registration is available.

title: Survivors speak out, prepare for walk against ovarian cancer
hco: OVARIAN CANCER ALLIANCE OF GREATER CINCINNATI
summary: Survivors of ovarian cancer are speaking out about their experiences as they prepare for the "Teal Power" 5K run/walk organized by the Ovarian Cancer Alliance of Greater Cincinnati. The event aims to raise awareness and funds for research. Survivors like KC Stallings and Dianne Weidman shared their stories, highlighting how initial symptoms such as back and stomach pain led to their diagnoses. Both women emphasized the importance of checking family history due to the disease's hereditary nature and the challenges in early detection. Stallings and Weidman have undergone multiple treatments and surgeries, with Stallings fighting the disease for six years and Weidman surviving four rounds over five years. The walk will take place at Summit Park in Blue Ash, aiming to support ongoing research and better treatments for ovarian cancer.

title: State & Regional Affiliates
summary: ASCO's State/Regional Affiliate program offers oncology professionals opportunities to engage locally and nationally. Membership in these affiliates is separate from ASCO membership but provides numerous benefits such as advocacy, professional development, networking, and continuing education. Affiliates lead state-specific advocacy efforts and foster a vibrant oncology community. The State Society Network is an online platform for members to connect and share experiences. The program includes a comprehensive list of state societies across the U.S., each offering unique resources and opportunities for involvement. The initiative is supported by Conquer Cancer, the ASCO Foundation.

title: Wendy Vogel, MSN, FNP, AOCNP, FAPO, on the Evolving Role of Advanced Practice Providers in Oncology Care
hco: ADVANCED PRACTITIONER SOCIETY FOR HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY
summary: Wendy Vogel, MSN, FNP, AOCNP, FAPO, from the Advanced Practitioner Society for Hematology and Oncology, discusses the evolving role of advanced practice providers (APPs) in oncology care. She highlights a panel discussion on forming interprofessional oncology care teams that include advanced practitioners, emphasizing that such collaboration can improve patient outcomes and enhance practice efficiency.

title: Janssen Launches National Campaign to Recognize and Increase Support for Advanced Practice Providers Who Care ...
hco: ADVANCED PRACTITIONER SOCIETY FOR HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY
summary: Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson, in collaboration with the Advanced Practitioner Society for Hematology and Oncology (APSHO), has launched the "Make It H APP en™" campaign to support Advanced Practice Providers (APPs) who care for people with multiple myeloma. The campaign addresses the need for more educational resources and support for APPs, who play a critical role in patient care. A national survey revealed that 94% of APPs desire more tailored educational resources, and 93% of patients view APPs as essential to their care. The initiative includes webinars, resources, and a dedicated resource center to enhance APPs' knowledge and improve patient outcomes.

title: Wheatley and Gopalsami Highlight the Value of Interdisciplinary Collaboration in HSCT Care
hco: ADVANCED PRACTITIONER SOCIETY FOR HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY
summary: Tia Wheatley and Shivani Gopalsami from UCLA Health discuss the benefits and challenges of interdisciplinary collaboration in hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) care. They highlight how different professionals, including nurse practitioners, doctors of pharmacy, and clinical nurse specialists, contribute unique perspectives that enhance quality improvement initiatives. One successful initiative they implemented is the electrolyte replacement protocol (ERP), which allows nurses to administer medications like magnesium and potassium more timely, reducing the time from lab results to medication administration from 6 hours to 1.5 hours. This collaboration has improved patient outcomes and mitigated barriers to multidisciplinary care.

title: At a loss: NC rape crisis centers struggle as federal funds dry up
summary: North Carolina's rape crisis centers, like the Orange County Rape Crisis Center, are struggling due to significant federal funding cuts. These centers rely heavily on the Crime Victims Fund, which saw reduced contributions following fewer federal prosecutions and a funding glitch. Despite the VOCA Fix Act of 2021 redirecting settlement fines back to the fund, the impact has been severe. The Orange County center, which previously received around $800,000 annually, now gets less than $200,000, leading to staff and service cuts. The crisis comes amid a rise in sexual violence, exacerbated by the pandemic, highlighting the urgent need for sustained funding and support.

title: Orange County Rape Crisis Center faces debilitating funding, budget cuts -
summary: The Orange County Rape Crisis Center (OCRCC) in Chapel Hill is facing severe budget cuts as it approaches its 50th year. Due to a significant decrease in funds from the Victims of Crime Act (VOCA), the center will reduce its services and cut staff by 50%. Demand for OCRCC’s services has increased by over 80% since 2020, exacerbating the impact of these cuts. The VOCA funds, sourced from federal court fines, have declined by 74% since 2018. Despite the 2021 VOCA Fix Act aimed at stabilizing the Crime Victims Fund, the OCRCC has lost around 33% of its funding. Local and state support has also dwindled, forcing the center to limit therapy services, case management, and prevention programs. Community donations have helped but are insufficient to bridge the funding gap.

title: Facing Budget Crunch, Orange County Rape Crisis Center Scales Back
summary: Facing a significant budget crunch, the Orange County Rape Crisis Center (OCRCC) is making major cuts in staff and services. The organization will reduce its staff by 50%, cut therapy caseloads by 60%, limit legal advocacy to urgent cases, and close its Latino outreach and engagement programs. The OCRCC will also scale back its bullying and sexual-assault prevention programs in local schools, which have been available to all grade levels for 35 years. These measures are necessitated by a substantial drop in federal funds and government contracts, including a $400,000 reduction over the last three years. Despite the cuts, the 24-hour sexual assault helpline will remain operational. Executive Director Rachel Valentine expressed cautious optimism, urging the local community to support the OCRCC during this challenging period. The organization has seen an 80% increase in service demand since 2020, serving over 1200 survivors in the last fiscal year.

title: Rape Crisis Center Cuts
summary: The Orange County Rape Crisis Center is facing severe financial challenges due to significant cuts in government funding, forcing it to reduce staff by 50% and cut many services. Federal funding for victim services is expected to be completely gone by 2024, leaving the center with a $250,000 deficit. Over the past three years, the center has seen an $800,000 decrease in government contracts. Executive Director Rachel Valentine is calling on the community for support, noting an 80% increase in service demand this year. Despite the financial strain, the center plans to open a second location in Hillsborough later this year.

title: Orange County Rape Crisis Center prepares to make major cuts
summary: The Orange County Rape Crisis Center, established in 1974, is facing significant budget cuts. Starting in October, the nonprofit will halve its staff and reduce its therapy caseload by 60%, among other service reductions. The center's executive director, Rachel Valentine, attributes these cuts to a decrease of over $400,000 in government funding over the past three years, despite an 80% increase in survivors seeking support. The organization relies heavily on the Crime Victims Fund, which is dwindling. Valentine is now seeking community support to maintain services. This is not the first time the center has faced cuts; a similar situation occurred in 2021.

title: $1.15M grant awarded to continue sexual assault kit initiative in Durham Co.
summary: Durham County's District Attorney’s Office has received a $1.15 million federal grant to enhance services related to untested sexual assault kits. North Carolina, which had over 16,000 untested kits in 2018, has since tested about 95% of them. Durham County initially had the highest number of backlogged kits at 1,783, all of which have now been submitted for testing. The new funding will support a dedicated prosecutor, legal assistant, expert witnesses, and other trial-related expenses. Rachel Valentine, executive director of the Orange County Rape Crisis Center, supports the initiative but emphasizes the need for broader survivor resources.
